游戏设计师面临的挑战

CHALLENGES FOR GAME DESIGNERS

 

 

布伦达·布拉斯韦特

BRENDA BRATHWAITE

伊恩·施莱伯

IAN SCHREIBER

致谢

Acknowledgements

许多人都为本书的创作做出了贡献，尤其是往届学生，其中包括 David McDonough，他获得了协助开发完成每章的非数字短篇的机会，他抓住了这个机会。Blair Cooper 被要求设计这本书的封面。同样，他很乐意提供帮助。对于他们两人的贡献，我们深表感谢。

There were many people who contributed to the making of this book, particularly past students, including David McDonough, was offered the opportunity to assist in the development of the non-digital shorts that complete each chapter, and he jumped at the chance. Blair Cooper, was asked to design the book’s cover. Likewise, he was pleased to assist. For both their contributions, we are grateful.

还要感谢设计大军的成员，特别是 Michelle Menard 和 Chris Schmidt，他们阅读了本书的草稿并根据书中的挑战制作了游戏，其中许多游戏的图片都包含在内。专业游戏设计师 Jeb Havens、Ian Bogost 和 Clint Hocking 非常慷慨地贡献了素材，还有无数其他设计师，包括 Greg Costikyan、Sheri Graner Ray、Sam Lewis、Chris Crowell 和 Linda Currie，他们听我们谈论晦涩难懂和新颖的游戏，并加入了我们常说的对话。

Thanks are due also to members of the Design Army, in particular Michelle Menard and Chris Schmidt, who read drafts of this book and made games from its challenges, a number of which are pictured within. Professional game designers Jeb Havens, Ian Bogost, and Clint Hocking were kind enough to contribute material, and countless other designers, including Greg Costikyan, Sheri Graner Ray, Sam Lewis, Chris Crowell, and Linda Currie, listened to us talk about games obscure and new and added to the proverbial conversation.

最后，但最重要的是，我们的配偶值得称赞。Sharon Schreiber 和 John Romero 是游戏设计师最好的配偶，他们支持我们的写作和持续研究。

Lastly, but most importantly, our spouses deserve much praise. Sharon Schreiber and John Romero are the best spouses game designers could possibly have and support our writing and continued research.


 

 

关于作者

About the Authors

布伦达·罗梅罗（原名布伦达·布拉斯韦特）是一位屡获殊荣的游戏设计师、艺术家和富布赖特学者，她于 1981 年进入电子游戏行业。作为一名设计师，她为许多开创性的游戏做出了贡献，包括《巫术》和《铁血联盟》系列以及《幽灵行动》和《龙与地下城》系列中的游戏。除了机器之外，她的六款模拟游戏系列《机械师就是信息》获得了国内和国际的赞誉，尤其是《火车》和《爱尔兰游戏》，目前收藏在国家游戏博物馆。2015 年，她在游戏开发者选择奖中获得了令人垂涎的大使奖。2014 年，她获得富布赖特奖，以研究爱尔兰的游戏产业、学术和政府政策。 2013 年，她被 Gamasutra.com 评为十大游戏开发者之一，《Develop》杂志也将她列为 2013 年改变游戏的 25 人之一。罗梅罗是位于爱尔兰戈尔韦的 Romero Games 的共同所有人，同时还是利默里克大学即将开设的游戏设计与开发理学硕士学位课程的课程主任。

Brenda Romero (formerly Brenda Brathwaite) is an award-winning game designer, artist and Fulbright scholar who entered the video game industry in 1981. As a designer, she has contributed to many seminal titles, including the Wizardry and Jagged Alliance series and titles in the Ghost Recon and Dungeons & Dragons franchises. Away from the machine, her analog series of six games, The Mechanic is the Message, has drawn national and international acclaim, particularly Train and Síochán Leat (The Irish Game) which is presently housed in the National Museum of Play. In 2015, she won the coveted Ambassador’s Award at the Game Developers Choice Awards. In 2014, she received a Fulbright award to study Ireland’s game industry, academic and government policies. In 2013, she was named one of the top 10 game developers by Gamasutra.com and Develop magazine listed her among the 25 people who changed games in 2013. Romero co-owns Romero Games based in Galway, Ireland, and is Course Director at the upcoming MSc in Game Design & Development at the University of Limerick.

Ian Schreiber 自 2000 年以来一直从事该行业，最初是一名程序员，后来成为一名游戏设计师。他参与了六款已发布的游戏和两个严肃游戏项目，以及许多机密项目。Ian 是全球最大的线下游戏开发活动 Global Game Jam 的联合创始人。Ian 在 gamedesignconcepts.wordpress.com（围绕本书内容设计）和 gamebalanceconcepts.wordpress.com 上教授了两门免费的在线游戏设计课程。Ian 曾在多所两年制和四年制学校教授游戏设计和开发课程，自 2017 年起担任 RIT 的助理教授。

Ian Schreiber has been in the industry since the year 2000, first as a programmer and then as a game designer. He has worked on six published game titles and two serious game projects, as well as numerous confidential projects. Ian is a co-founder of Global Game Jam, the largest in-person game development event in the world. Ian has taught two free online courses in game design, at gamedesignconcepts.wordpress.com (which is designed around the content in this book) and gamebalanceconcepts.wordpress.com. Ian has taught game design and development courses at a variety of two-year and four-year schools, and as of 2017 is an assistant professor at RIT.


 

 

内容

Contents

 

 

第 1 部分：构建模块

Part 1: Building Blocks

·      第 1 章：基础知识

·      Chapter 1: The Basics

·      第 2 章：游戏设计原子

·      Chapter 2: Game Design Atoms

·      第 3 章：谜题设计

·      Chapter 3: Puzzle Design

·      第 4 章：将数字内容转换为实体内容

·      Chapter 4: Converting Digital to Physical

 

 

第二部分：机会与技巧

Part 2: Chance & Skill

·      第 5 章：机会要素

·      Chapter 5: Elements of Chance

·      第 6 章：“战略”技能的要素

·      Chapter 6: Elements of “Strategic” Skill

·      第 7 章：“抽搐”技能的要素

·      Chapter 7: Elements of “Twitch” Skill

·      第 8 章：变化与技能——寻找平衡

·      Chapter 8: Change & Skill – Finding the Balance

 

 

第 3 部分：编写游戏概念

Part 3: Writing Game Concepts

·      第 9 章：什么是知识产权

·      Chapter 9: What is Intellectual Property

·      第 10 章：创作续集

·      Chapter 10: Creating Sequels

·      第 11 章：针对少数群体

·      Chapter 11: Targeting a Minority

·      第 12 章：学习不熟悉的体裁

·      Chapter 12: Learning an Unfamiliar Genre

·      第 13 章：设计一款讲述故事的游戏

·      Chapter 13: Designing a Game to Tell a Story

 

 

第 4 部分：加法设计与减法设计

Part 4: Additive & Subtractive Design

·      第 14 章：加减力学

·      Chapter 14: Adding and Subtracting Mechanics

·      第 15 章：“但要让它成为多人游戏”

·      Chapter 15: “But Make it Multiplayer”

 

 

第五部分：专题

Part 5: Special Topics

 

 

·      第 16 章：创建用户界面

·      Chapter 16: Creating a User Interface

·      第 17 章：游戏即艺术

·      Chapter 17: Games as Art

·      第 18 章：游戏作为教学工具

·      Chapter 18: Games as a Teaching Tool

·      第19章：严肃游戏

·      Chapter 19: Serious Games

·      第 20 章：休闲游戏

·      Chapter 20: Casual Games

·      第 21 章：社交网络和游戏

·      Chapter 21: Social Networks & Games

 

 

 

 

 

 


介绍和欢迎

Introduction & Welcome

 

 

本书旨在挑战您，提高您的头脑风暴能力，并让您在享受乐趣的同时提高您的设计技能，无论您是专业设计师、有抱负的设计师、业余爱好者还是游戏设计的学生。

This book is designed to challenge you, improve your brainstorming abilities, and allow you to have fun and sharpen your design skills whether you’re a professional designer, an aspiring designer, a hobbyist, or a student of game design.

本书的章节涵盖了游戏设计师关注的广泛主题。每章有三个关键部分：

The chapters in this book cover a wide range of topics important to game designers. There are three key parts to each chapter:

·      内容：提供主题的总体概述。所有材料均来自作者的实际行业经验。

·      Coverage: A general overview of the topic is provided. All the material comes from actual industry experience of the authors.

·      设计挑战：五个挑战让您可以应用材料、探索主题并扩展您在该领域的知识。除非需要进行研究，否则所有挑战都不需要任何计算机编程甚至计算机。即便如此，好书也可以。

·      Design Challenges: Five challenges that allow you to apply the material, explore the topic, and expand your knowledge in the area. None of the challenges requires any computer programming or even a computer unless needed for research. Even then, good ol’ books will do.

·      非数字短片：一系列可以制作成功能齐全的非数字游戏的主题。这些短片非常适合快速集思广益或家庭作业。

·      Non-Digital Shorts: A range of topics that can be made into fully functional non-digital games. These are great for quick brainstorming sessions or homework assignments.

专业游戏设计师

PROFESSIONAL GAME DESIGNERS

如果您已经是一名游戏设计师，这些章节中的文字可以作为回顾或为您提供与团队中的其他人（尤其是初级设计师）一起应对挑战的参考框架。您可以随意跳到您感兴趣或与您相关的任何章节。本书中的材料来自行业经验，我们欢迎您对未来版本的任何反馈或贡献。

If you already work as a game designer, the text in these chapters serves as a review or provides you with a frame of reference to conduct the challenges with others on your team, particularly junior designers. Feel free to jump around to whatever chapter is of interest or relevance to you. The material in this book comes from industry experience, and we welcome any feedback or contributions you may have for future editions.

如果你所在的公司有整个设计部门（而不只是你一个人），那么可以时不时地与其他设计师一起接受挑战。如果你有一个大型设计部门（八人或更多），你可以分成几个团队，并在每次会议结束时展示你的工作。当作者们在同一间办公室一起工作时，他们经常与其他设计师一起做这些练习。

If you work at a company where there is an entire design department (and not just you), take on a challenge every now and then with the other designers. If you have a large design department (eight people or more), you can divide into several teams and present your work at the end of each session. The authors regularly did these exercises with other designers when they worked together in the same office.

这些练习（尤其是 Iron Designer 练习）也可以作为潜在候选人的极好的设计测试。

These exercises—particularly the Iron Designer exercises—also serve as excellent design tests for potential candidates.

您还可以考虑在公司定期举办“非设计师设计练习”，向对游戏设计感兴趣或与设计师密切合作的人展示一些材料并发起挑战。您肯定知道，很多人都有兴趣成为设计师，并会欣赏您传授的努力和知识。

You might also consider holding periodic “design exercises for non-designers” at your company, presenting some material and running a challenge for people who are interested in game design or who work closely with designers. As you surely know, lots of people are interested in becoming designers and would appreciate the effort and knowledge you convey.

还不是游戏设计师…… 暂时还不是！

NOT A GAME DESIGNER… YET!

如果您对游戏设计感兴趣，但没有任何行业设计师资格，那么您可能会发现每个章节中的经验都很有启发性。从第 1 章“基础知识”开始，了解您需要的技能和核心知识。对于其他每个章节，如果您还没有玩过该类型的商业或独立游戏，我们建议您在阅读正文之后先玩一玩，然后在最后完成部分或全部挑战来练习您的新技能。如果您是自己做这件事（例如，不是作为课堂布置的作业），您可能会被看起来很简单的挑战所吸引；抵制这种诱惑。准确找到那些看起来令人生畏或根本无趣的练习；这些练习最能培养您想要培养的技能。

If you are interested in game design but don’t have any industry credits as a designer, you may find the experience in each chapter enlightening. Start with Chapter 1, “The Basics,” to get an idea of the kinds of skills and core knowledge you’ll need. For every other chapter, after reading the text, we recommend playing a commercial or indie game of that type if you haven’t already, and follow it up by doing some or all of the challenges at the end to practice your new skills. If you are doing this on your own (for example, not as assigned work for a class), you may be drawn to the challenges that look easy; resist this temptation. Find exactly those exercises that look daunting or just plain un-fun; those are the ones that will best build the skills you want to build.

如果你足够幸运，有其他同事和你一样对游戏设计感兴趣，那么与他们一起组队会取得更好的结果（可以把它想象成读书俱乐部，只不过更有趣）。本书中的许多挑战都建议以小组形式进行头脑风暴；如果你单独行动，你会得到截然不同的结果。

If you are lucky enough to have some other colleagues who are as interested in game design as you, you will get better results by working in a group with them (think of it as a book club, except more fun). Many of the challenges in this book suggest working in a group for brainstorming; you will get very different results if you go it alone.

如果你希望将来成为一名游戏设计师，那么就把你创作的作品留到这些挑战中去吧。它们可以用来充实你的设计作品集。没有什么可以替代设计一款完全实现的视频游戏（这样的作品应该是你作品集的基础），但额外的作品可以展示你对该领域常见设计问题的方法，这将让潜在雇主更好地了解你是哪种设计师，而本书中对挑战的特别创新的解决方案可以成为面试时的谈资。

If you are looking to become a game designer some day, save the work that you create for these challenges. They can be used to fill out your design portfolio. There is no substitute for designing a video game that is fully implemented (such a piece should be the foundation of your portfolio), but additional work that shows your approach to common design problems in the field will give potential employers a better sense of what kind of designer you are, and a particularly innovative solution to a challenge in this book can be a talking point during an interview.

如果你是一名学生，而这本教科书是你的游戏设计课程的必修课，那么它就不是那种你想在课程结束时扔掉的书。这本书的章节和练习太多了，一个季度或一个学期都无法讲完，但每一章和每个挑战都对游戏设计师有用。课程结束后，试着阅读一些你在课堂上没有讲到的章节，甚至完成挑战。你可以利用寒假或暑假作为借口来玩这本书。即使你没有，你有一天也可能成为一名游戏设计师……如果你真的成为了，你会想练习你的技能，这样你就可以成为最好的设计师。

If you are a student and this textbook was required for one of your game design classes, this is not one of those books that you want to get rid of at the end of the course. There are far too many chapters and exercises here to cover in a single quarter or semester, but every chapter and every challenge is meant to be useful to a game designer. After the course is over, try reading some of the chapters that you didn’t get to cover in class and even doing the challenges. You can use winter or summer break as an excuse to play around with this book. Even if you don’t, you may become a game designer some day... and if you do, you will want to practice your skills so that you can be the best designer you can be.

游戏设计讲师

GAME DESIGN INSTRUCTORS

如果您教授游戏设计课程，则可以根据课程的不同以多种方式使用本书。目前，本书的使用方式如下：

If you teach courses in game design, there are several ways you can use this book, depending on the class. It is currently being used in the following ways:

·作为游戏设计实践入门课程的主要教材     

·      As a primary text for an introductory class on the practice of game design

·作为许多课程的补充练习文本     

·      As a supplemental exercise text for numerous classes_

·作为非数字游戏设计课程的主要教材     

·      As a primary text for a course on non-digital game design

如果您的学生已经学习过游戏设计理论的入门课程，本书可以提供一系列挑战，为实际 游戏设计课程奠定基础。快速复习一下课程（您可以在 30 分钟到 1 小时内完成大多数章节的复习），然后直接进入章节末尾的挑战。将研究活动作为家庭作业，并将课堂时间主要用于小组集思广益和设计活动。

If your students have already taken an introductory course in the theory of game design, this book can provide a series of challenges to form the basis for a course in practical game design. Give a quick refresher lecture (you can do this for most chapters in 30 minutes to an hour), and then leap right into the challenges at the end of a chapter. Assign research activities as homework and use class time primarily for group brainstorming and design activities.

非数字化短片也为快速完成课堂项目或家庭作业提供了绝佳的机会。

The non-digital shorts also provide great opportunities for quick in-class projects or homework assignments.

对于高级游戏开发课程，您可以将本书中的大部分挑战强化为为期一周的项目。如果您的学生知道如何编程，任何以游戏概念为可交付成果的挑战都可以通过让学生实现一个可运行的快速原型来扩展。您甚至可以进一步扩展这一点，在课程开始时让学生选择设计挑战，并让他们将其扩展到一个季度或学期（甚至整个学年），使其成为一个完整的可运行游戏。

For an advanced game development class, you can take most of the challenges in this book and enhance them into weeklong projects. If your students know how to program, any challenge that has a game concept as a deliverable can be extended by having the students implement a working rapid prototype. You could even extend this further, starting a course by giving students a choice of design challenges and having them extend that through the quarter or semester (or even an entire academic year) into a full working game.

继续对话

CONTINUING THE CONVERSATION

画家通过画很多画来提高水平；雕塑家通过制作雕塑来磨练技艺；游戏设计师通过设计很多游戏来提高技能。不幸的是，设计一个完整的视频游戏（并实现它，然后看看你做对了什么和做错了什么）可能需要数年时间，我们都希望以更快的速度提高。

A painter gets better by making lots of paintings; sculptors hone their craft by making sculptures; and game designers improve their skills by designing lots of games. Unfortunately, designing a complete video game (and implementing it, and then seeing all the things you did right and wrong) can take years, and we’d all like to improve at a faster rate than that.

本书的核心是一系列挑战。大多数挑战只需要两个小时或更短的时间，每个挑战都侧重于游戏设计师常用的一项重要技能。在其他书中，这些可能被称为本质上无趣的活动，例如练习、问题或家庭作业。本书中的活动旨在令人愉快、有趣、好玩且具有挑战性；因此，它们被称为挑战。

This book, at its heart, is a collection of challenges. Most are designed to take two hours or fewer, and each challenge focuses on a vital skill that is commonly used by practicing game designers. In other books, these might be referred to as inherently un-fun activities, such as exercises or problems or homework. The activities in this book are meant to be enjoyable, interesting, fun, and challenging; hence, challenges.

我们欢迎您针对《游戏设计师挑战》未来版本提出问题和建议。

We welcome your questions and any suggestions you may have for future editions of Challenges for Game Designers.

随机琐事

RANDOM TRIVIA

两位作者的故事都很相似。他们都是游戏设计师，最近辞去了全职游戏开发工作，转而从事全职教学和兼职工作。他们都教授实用游戏设计课程，要求学生定期设计游戏。如果他们的性格（以及设计技巧、外表等）不是完全不同的话，他们可能是双胞胎。

Both authors have similar stories. They are game designers who recently left full-time game development to teach full-time and contract part-time. They both taught a class in practical game design, where the students were expected to regularly design games. They could be twins, if they didn’t have such completely different personalities (and design skills, and looks, and...).

Brenda 找到 Ian，请他与她合作撰写她正在撰写的一本书的提案（不是这本书）。Ian 还提供了一本游戏设计练习书，该书基于他们一起工作时做过的练习。Game_Edu（一个面向游戏开发教育者的 IGDA 邮件列表）上已经出现了对“低技术”游戏设计练习的兴趣，而且没有像这样的书。这本书最终获得了优先地位，因为写起来很有趣，而且源于经验。

Brenda approached Ian, asking him to co-author a book proposal she was writing (not this one). Ian counter-offered with a book of game design exercises, based on the exercises they used to do when they worked together. Interest in “low-tech” game design exercises had already been shown on Game_Edu, an IGDA mailing list for game development educators, and no book like this existed. This book ended up taking precedence, because it was fun to write and born of experience.



 

 

第一部分：构建模块

Part I: Building Blocks



 

 

1：基础知识

1: The Basics

游戏设计是一种艺术形式，作为设计师，我们通过经常挑战自己而成长。有些人很幸运，而且足够优秀，可以专业地从事游戏设计。其他人则将游戏设计作为教育的一部分，或出于个人乐趣（以及希望获得回报）而从事游戏设计。

Game design is an art form, and as designers, we grow by challenging ourselves often. Some are fortunate and good enough to do it professionally. Others design games as a part of their education or do it for personal pleasure (and the hope of reward).

本书由专业游戏设计师撰写。这意味着某些术语会被随意使用，但前提是读者确实知道这些术语的含义。如果我们不定义它们，或者不向您概述游戏设计的基本知识，我们就无法正确分析我们的受众或满足他们的期望。这是游戏设计本身的一大错误。

This book was written by professional game designers. That means that certain terms will be flung about with an assumption that the reader actually knows what these terms mean. If we didn’t define them or if we didn’t give you an overview of the basics of game design, we would have failed to properly analyze our audience or meet its expectations. That’s one of the cardinal sins of game design itself.

本章将作为整本书的教程或“入门级”。如果你对游戏设计领域还比较陌生，那么本章适合你。

This chapter then serves as a tutorial or “intro level” to this entire book. If you’re relatively new to the field of game design, this chapter is for you.

什么是游戏设计？

WHAT IS GAME DESIGN?

游戏设计是创建游戏内容和规则的过程。好的游戏设计是创建玩家有动​​力去实现的目标以及玩家在追求这些目标时必须遵循的规则的过程。

Game design is the process of creating the content and rules of a game. Good game design is the process of creating goals that a player feels motivated to reach and rules that a player must follow as he makes making meaningful decisions in pursuit of those goals.

这也与玩家有关

IT’S ALSO ALL ABOUT THE PLAYER

好的游戏设计是以玩家为中心的。这意味着最重要的是，玩家和玩家的愿望才是真正需要考虑的。游戏本身不应该要求玩家按照规则做某事，而应该从本质上激励玩家朝着设计师希望的方向前进。告诉玩家他们必须在棋盘上移动或晋级到下一关是一回事。如果他们没有理由和愿望去做，那么这就变成了一种折磨。

Good game design is player-centric. That means that above all else, the player and her desires are truly considered. Rather than demanding that she do something via the rules, the gameplay itself should inherently motivate the player in the direction the designer wants her to go. Telling players they must travel around the board or advance to the next level is one thing. If they don’t have a reason and a desire to do it, then it becomes torture.

在创建游戏时，设计师需要退一步并从玩家的角度思考：

In creating a game, designers take a step back and think from the player’s viewpoint:

这个游戏是关于什么的？我怎么玩？我怎么赢？我为什么要玩？我需要做什么？

What’s this game about? How do I play? How do I win? Why do I want to play? What things do I need to do?

有意义的决定

MEANINGFUL DECISIONS

归根结底，游戏设计就是为玩家创造机会，让他们做出影响游戏结果的有意义的决定。想象一下拳击比赛。许多决定都决定了最终的胜利。我要训练多久？我会格挡还是挥拳？我的对手会怎么做？他的弱点在哪里？用左拳还是右拳？即使是这几个简短的问题，也比不上拳击手在比赛中必须做出的无数决定。

Distilled down to its essence, game design is about creating opportunities for players to make meaningful decisions that affect the outcome of the game. Consider a game like a boxing match. So many decisions lead up to the ultimate victory. How long will I train? Will I block or will I swing? What is my opponent going to do? Where is his weakness? Jab left or right? Even those few, brief questions don’t come close to the myriad decisions a fighter must make as he progresses through a match.

游戏会将玩家带入类似的心理空间。俄罗斯方块和国际象棋等游戏迫使我们考虑下一步要采取的几种可能步骤中的哪一种，从而让我们的大脑保持忙碌。在采取这些路径时，我们知道我们可能会拖延或彻底搞砸整个游戏。《模拟人生》游戏和席德·梅尔的《文明》系列游戏每分钟都会迫使玩家做出数十个决定。这些决定中很少有像“你想去东边还是西边？”这样直接的决定，但每个小决定都会影响整个游戏。

Games invite players into similar mental spaces. Games like Tetris and Chess keep our minds busy by forcing us to consider which one of several possible moves we want to take next. In taking these paths, we know that we may be prolonging or completely screwing up our entire game. The Sims games and those in Sid Meier’s Civilization series force dozens of decisions upon the player every minute. Few of these decisions are as direct as “Do you want to go east or west?” but each little decision affects the gameplay overall.

农业综合企业是一款农场游戏，它为玩家提供了众多选择。玩家将在哪里放置下一个农作物地块？如果是廉价农作物，他是想使用自己宝贵的土地还是将其放置在对手的土地上？他是否想拔掉廉价农作物来种植更有价值的农作物？其他玩家决定在该玩家的水坑周围放置岩石会影响玩家获得更多土地和更多农作物的能力。

Agribusiness, a farming game, presents the player with numerous choices. Where will the player place the next crop tile? If it’s a cheap crop, does he want to use his valuable land or place it on his opponent’s? Does he want to uproot a cheap crop to place a more valuable crop instead? The decision by other players to place rocks around this player’s water holes affects the player’s ability to get more land and thus more crops.

不确定游戏是否不过是一系列有意义的选择？回顾一下你上次玩过并输掉的游戏。你很可能确切地知道事情从哪里开始出错。某个决定或一系列决定最终导致了你的失败。我们会在后视镜中记住这些事情，通过反复玩，我们越玩越不容易在决策中动摇。但是，如果你不记得哪里出了问题怎么办？很可能你没有完全掌握规则，而且一旦这些规则开始实施，情况就不会变得更好。当玩家不掌握规则时，他们就不了解这些规则的因果关系。有时，他们会输得很惨，但却不明白为什么。

Not sure if games are nothing more than a series of meaningful choices? Take a look back at the last game you played and lost. Odds are that you know precisely where things started to go wrong. Some decision or series of decisions ultimately led to your downfall. We remember these things in the rear-view mirror, and through repeated play, we become less likely to falter in our decision making the further we go. What if you don’t remember where things went wrong, though? Odds are that you didn’t entirely grasp the rules, and once those rules got in motion, it didn’t get any better. When players don’t grasp the rules, they don’t grasp the cause and effect of those rules. Sometimes, they lose badly but don’t understand why.

以下每个都是游戏中有意义的决策的示例：

Each of these is an example of meaningful decision making in a game:

·实时战略游戏 (RTS) 或回合制战略游戏中的部队部署。     

·      Troop placement in a real-time strategy game (RTS) or a turn-based strategy game.

·角色扮演游戏（RPG）中角色升级时的点数分配     

·      Point allocation during character advancement in a role-playing game (RPG)

·在国际象棋中选择移动哪个棋子     

·      Choosing which piece to move in Chess

·在第一人称射击游戏 (FPS) 中瞄准并射击武器     

·      Aiming and firing your weapon in a first-person shooter (FPS)

·在《吉他英雄》中在正确的时间按下正确的按钮     

·      Pressing the right buttons at the right time in Guitar Hero

只要玩家在游戏中被允许做出选择，并且该选择会影响游戏的结果，设计师就会创造意义。为了创造选择，必须有另一个同样有意义的选项。

Whenever the player is allowed to exercise choice in a game and that choice affects the outcome of the game, then designers are creating meaning. In order to create choice, there has to be another option that has meaning as well.

但有时，玩家根本没有选择。以《大富翁》游戏为例。购买所有财产后，除了“掷骰子并付款”之外，还有什么选择？

Sometimes, however, the player has no choice at all. Consider a game like Monopoly. Once all the property is purchased, what choice is there beyond “roll the dice and pay”?

请注意，“掷骰子并支付”甚至不是一个选择，因为没有其他选择。除非制定内部规则来超越这个有限的范围，否则就没有什么可做的了，也没有什么可做的了。玩家完全了解他需要知道的有关大富翁的一切，任何给定游戏的结果都是可以预测的。这就是为什么大富翁在棋盘上转了几圈后就会让人觉得无聊的原因。

Mind you, “roll the dice and pay” isn’t even a choice, since there are no other options. Unless house rules are invented to take it beyond this limited scope, there’s nothing more to do, and there are no more decisions to make. The player fully understands everything he needs to know about Monopoly, and the outcome of any given game becomes predictable. That’s why Monopoly can become boring for people after just a few trips around the board.

游戏设计不是什么

WHAT GAME DESIGN IS NOT

游戏设计是当今最常被误用的术语之一。有些人想学习游戏设计，但实际上却学习了游戏艺术。还有一些人学习纯编程。虽然编程和艺术都是重要的领域，而且对数字游戏来说确实非常重要，但游戏设计本身就是一种艺术形式，早在计算机、多边形甚至发现电之前就已经存在了。

Game design is one of the most misused terms in use today. Some seek to learn game design, but learn game art instead. Still others learn pure programming. While programming and art are important fields and indeed incredibly important to digital games, game design is its own art form and has been around long before computers, polygons, and even the discovery of electricity.

本书涵盖的正是游戏设计的基本原则——设计精简到其基本本质。毫不奇怪，当今许多最伟大的游戏设计师都是从玩和设计非数字游戏开始的，有些人仍在当今的设计中使用纸质原型。

It is these basic principles of game design that we cover in this book—design distilled down to its basic essence. Not surprisingly, many of today’s greatest game designers got their start playing and designing non-digital games, and some still use paper prototyping in their present-day designs.

考虑游戏设计时，不妨考虑一下棋盘游戏围棋，这是一种具有数千年历史的中国游戏。玩围棋不需要计算机编程或多边形模型。尽管规则简单，但策略深度却非常丰富，至今仍广受欢迎。虽然如今流行的许多游戏一千年后可能不如围棋那么受欢迎，但没有理由不能创造出这样的游戏。

When thinking of game design, think in terms of the board game Go, a Chinese game thousands of years old. It requires no computer programming or polygon models to play. Yet its rules, simple as they are, allow for a depth of strategy so great that it is still played heavily today. While many of the games enjoyed today may not be as popular as Go a thousand years from now, there is no reason why such a game could not be created.

 设计类型

 TYPES OF DESIGN

正如游戏类型多种多样一样，游戏设计也有很多种类型。

Just as there are many types of games, there are many types of game design, too.

·世界设计是游戏整体背景故事、设定和主题的创作。虽然它通常由首席设计师或唯一设计师执行，但它通常决定了下面列出的其他设计任务的范围。     

·      World design is the creation of the overall backstory, setting, and theme of the game. While it’s generally performed by the lead or sole designer, it often determines the scope of the other design tasks listed below.

·      系统设计是创建游戏中的规则和底层数学模式。这是所有游戏都共有的唯一游戏设计任务，因为所有游戏都有规则。因此，本书中的大多数挑战都涉及系统设计。特别是，第 2、5、6、7 和 8 章为系统设计师提供了一个起点。

·      System design is the creation of rules and underlying mathematical patterns in a game. This is the only game design task that is common to all games, because all games have rules. Therefore, most of the challenges in this book involve system design. In particular, Chapters 2, 5, 6, 7 and 8 give a starting point for system designers.

·内容设计是创建角色、物品、谜题和任务。虽然它在视频游戏中更为常见，但角色扮演和集换式卡牌游戏也包含大量内容。第 3 章提供了大量创建谜题的练习，而第 9、10、19 和 20 章则涉及在游戏中整合特殊类型的内容。     

·      Content design is the creation of characters, items, puzzles, and missions. While it’s much more common in video games, role playing and collectible card games also feature a significant amount of content. Chapter 3 gives plenty of practice creating puzzles, while Chapters 9, 10, 19, and 20 involve incorporating special kinds of content within a game.

·游戏写作是游戏世界中对话、文本和故事的写作。第 9 章讨论游戏中的故事。     

·      Game writing is the writing of dialogue, text, and story within the game world. Chapter 9 deals with stories in games.

·关卡设计是游戏中关卡的制作，包括地图布局以及地图中物体和挑战的放置。虽然关卡设计是一门共享学科——地下城主自 20 世纪 70 年代以来一直在绘制桌面纸质游戏中的关卡——但当人们提到“关卡设计师”时，他们指的是视频游戏关卡设计师。     

·      Level design is the crafting of levels in a game, including the layout of maps and placement of objects and challenges within those maps. Though level design is a shared discipline—dungeon masters have been mapping levels in tabletop paper games since the 1970s—when one refers to a “level designer,” it is a video-game level designer that they are referring to.

·用户界面(UI) 设计包括两部分：玩家如何与游戏互动，以及玩家如何从游戏中接收信息和反馈。第 17 章和第 18 章介绍了 UI 设计的许多挑战。所有类型的游戏都有 UI，即使是非数字游戏。棋盘设计为适合放在普通桌子上，卡牌设计为适合握在普通大小的手中。游戏组件必须呈现玩家易于理解、使用和解读的信息。     

·      User interface (UI) design consists of two things: how the player interacts with the game, and how the player receives information and feedback from the game. Chapters 17 and 18 include many challenges of UI design. All types of games have UI, even non-digital ones. Boards are designed to fit on an average table and cards are designed to be held in an average-sized hand. The game components must present information that is easily understood, used, and interpreted by the players.

除了这些特定类型的设计之外，所有设计师都需要有能力在他们选择的媒介上制作游戏或游戏的指定部分，无论是棋盘游戏、主机游戏，还是电视游戏节目。

In addition to these specific types of design, all designers need to have the aptitude to produce a game or their assigned portion of a game on the medium they’ve selected, whether it’s a board game, a console game, or even a television game show.

什么是游戏？

WHAT IS A GAME?

关于“游戏”一词有许多定义，但没有一个定义能够被普遍接受为游戏设计的界限。本书的其中一位作者提出了如下暂定定义：“游戏是一种有规则的活动。它是一种游戏形式，经常（但并不总是）涉及冲突，冲突可以是与其他玩家的冲突，也可以是与游戏系统本身的冲突，也可以是与随机性/命运/运气的冲突。大多数游戏都有目标，但并非全部（例如《模拟人生》和《模拟城市》）。大多数游戏都有明确的起点和终点，但并非全部（例如《魔兽世界》和《龙与地下城》）。大多数游戏都涉及玩家的决策，但并非全部（例如《糖果乐园》和 《蛇梯棋》）。电子游戏是一种以某种方式使用某种数字视频屏幕的游戏（如上所述）。” [2]

There are many definitions of the word “game,” none of which has been universally accepted for the purposes of defining the limits of game design. One of the authors of this book put forth the following tentative definition: “An activity with rules. It is a form of play often but not always involving conflict, either with other players, with the game system itself, or with randomness/fate/luck. Most games have goals, but not all (for example, The Sims and SimCity). Most games have defined start and end points, but not all (for example, World of Warcraft and Dungeons & Dragons). Most games involve decision making on the part of the players, but not all (for example, Candy Land and Chutes and Ladders). A video game is a game (as defined above) that uses a digital video screen of some kind, in some way.”[2]

在本书以及我们自己的职业生涯中，当我们谈论游戏时，我们指的是一般的游戏——从古老的围棋到最新的《Madden》。无论是数字游戏还是非数字游戏，游戏的基本原理以及游戏设计的基本原理都是相同的。尽管技术可能在不断进步，但现代视频游戏设计师使用的核心技能与纸上设计游戏时使用的核心技能相同。

In this book, and in our own careers, when we speak of a game, we are referring to games in general—from the ancient Go to the latest Madden. Digital or non-digital, the underlying fundamentals of a game and therefore of game design are all the same. Though technology may advance, modern video game designers use the same core skills today that were used when designing games on paper.

游戏的核心

THE CORE OF A GAME

游戏的“核心”或“核心动态”是游戏玩法所涉及的唯一内容，即设计师试图传达的单一游戏体验。例如，《Ratchet & Clank》系列游戏是关于以有趣和创造性的方式炸毁物品。《Risk》、 《Carcassonne》和《Go》是关于占领领土。核心通常与特定的“核心机制”相关联，无论是炸飞敌人、在自己的回合中翻转瓷砖还是将单位出售给其他人。这些核心机制反过来可以导致“核心动态”，即一种特定的游戏模式。在行业中，当有人说“核心”时，他们通常指的就是动态。“核心陈述”（有时称为游戏的“愿景”）通常由开发团队撰写，以反映核心机制或核心动态，并总结游戏内容，通常用一句话来概括。

The “core” or “core dynamic” of a game is the single thing gameplay is about—the single play experience the designer is trying to convey. For instance, games in the Ratchet & Clank series are about blowing stuff up in fun and creative ways. Risk, Carcassonne, and Go are about acquiring territory. A core is usually tied to a specific “core mechanic,” be it blowing your enemies away, flipping over tiles on your turn, or selling units to another person. These core mechanics can, in turn, lead to “core dynamics,” which is a particular pattern of play. In the industry, when someone says “core,” the dynamic is typically what they are referring to. “Core statements” (sometimes called the game’s “vision”) are usually written by the development team to reflect the core mechanic or the core dynamic and sum up what the game is about, often in a single sentence.

· “这个游戏是关于……”     

·      “This game is about...”

· “这款游戏的体验是……”     

·      “This game is the experience of being...”

· “这个游戏教……”     

·      “This game teaches...”

· “这款游戏模拟了...的体验”     

·      “This game simulates the experience of...”

那些尝试向发行商推销游戏的人都知道，如果你不能用两句话概括你的游戏，那么你就不算是一个游戏。

As is well known by those who have tried to pitch their game to a publisher, if you can’t sum up your game in two sentences, you don’t have a game.

在游戏中，以下核心动态往往会反复出现：

In games, the following core dynamics tend to show up again and again:

·领土获取：在这个核心下，事情通常是“零和博弈”，也就是说，能分配的领土有限，一旦失去，就再也没有了。其他时候，这是一个控制一块领土的问题，就像一些第一人称射击游戏一样。《Risk》、 《Carcassonne》等游戏和许多回合制策略游戏都以这种核心动态为特色。     

·      Territorial Acquisition: With this core, things are usually “zero sum,” meaning there’s only so much to go around, and when it’s gone, it’s gone. Other times, it’s a question of controlling a piece of territory, as it is in some first-person shooters. Games like Risk, Carcassonne, and many turn-based strategy games feature this core dynamic.

·预测：有些游戏是关于做正确的事情或在正确的时间出现在正确的地点。在许多情况下，这些都是儿童游戏，尽管许多嘉年华或派对游戏也具有这种核心动态。游戏中的所有单个机制都是为了让玩家猜测会发生什么，并且他们会因为在游戏进入下一轮之前预测游戏的可能结果而获得奖励。大多数时候，玩家的预测涉及运气或对赔率的考虑。轮盘赌 或石头剪刀布等游戏符合这一核心动态。     

·      Prediction: Some games are about doing the right thing or being in the right place at the right time. In many cases, these are children’s games, although numerous carnival or party games also feature this core dynamic. All the individual mechanics in the game work toward allowing the players to guess what will happen, and they are rewarded for predicting the possible outcome of a game before it continues to the next round. Most times, the player’s prediction involves luck or consideration of odds. Games like Roulette or Rock-Paper-Scissors fit this core dynamic.

·空间推理：益智游戏通常会将空间推理技能融入到视频游戏中。像俄罗斯方块这样的游戏让玩家不仅考虑他们要放入的棋子，还考虑他们可以放入的棋子，或者在整堆棋子都进入底池之前他们迫切需要放入的棋子。许多棋盘游戏也利用了空间技能，例如井字游戏、四子棋和五子棋。       

·      Spatial Reasoning: Puzzle games often incorporate spatial-reasoning skills into video games. Games like Tetris make the player think not only of the piece that they’re putting in, but also the piece they may put in, or the piece that they desperately need to put in before the whole pile goes to pot. Many board games also make use of spatial skills, such as Tic-Tac-Toe, Connect Four, and Pente.  

·生存：人类天生就具有生存和繁衍的本能，游戏世界也不例外。在游戏开始之前，我们就会出于本能保护自己。生存是许多游戏的核心。但是，重要的是不要将核心与游戏中的失败条件混淆。在许多视频游戏中，您可能会死亡，如果您死了，游戏就结束了。尽管如此，其中一些游戏并不将持续的生死斗争作为游戏的主要活动。如果玩家专注于获得力量、杀死敌人或到达出口，那么生存就是支持另一个核心（例如建造或破坏）的次要活动。     

·      Survival: Human beings are naturally wired to survive and thrive, and it’s no different in the game world. We will protect ourselves out of sheer instinct before we’re even told the point of the game. Survival is a core within many games. However, it’s important not to confuse a core with a lose condition in a game. In many video games, you can die, and if you do it’s game over. Still, some of these games do not involve constant lifeor-death struggles as the primary activity of the game. If the player is concentrating on gaining power, killing enemies, or reaching the exit, then survival is a secondary activity that supports another core (such as building or destroying).

·毁灭：生存动态的另一面，或者说玩家对战 (PvP) 游戏中的同伴动态，是将眼前的一切摧毁殆尽的动态。有史以来制作的每一款 FPS 都具有这种核心动态，但它在具有战争主题的棋盘和纸牌游戏中也很常见，例如《核战争》、《瘟疫与瘟疫》和《汽车战争》。     

·      Destruction: The flip side of the survival dynamic, or the companion side if it’s a player versus player (PvP) game, is the wreck-everything-in-sight dynamic. Every FPS ever made features this core dynamic, but it is also common in board and card games with a warfare theme, like Nuclear War, Plague and Pestilence, and Car Wars.

·建筑：除了生存的动力，人类还天生具有建筑的天性，尽管他们并没有被告知建筑是人类的本能。因此，建筑成为许多游戏的主要核心机制也就不足为奇了。在大多数角色扮演游戏中，核心动力是角色发展——建立角色的力量等级。所谓的“城市建设者”类型的电子游戏，如《模拟城市》和《凯撒》 系列，都以建筑为核心。在一些棋盘游戏中，如《卡坦岛》，玩家大部分时间都在开发自己的资源。     

·      Building: In addition to their drive to survive, human beings are also naturally wired to build, even though they’re not told that it’s the point. It’s not surprising then that building is a prime core mechanic featured in many games. In most RPGs, the core dynamic is character development—building up the power level of a character. Video games in the so-called “city builder” genre, such as the SimCity and Caesar series, feature building as their core. In some board games, like Settlers of Catan, players spend most of their time developing their own resources.

·收集：作为人类，我们也是天生的模式匹配者。作为人类，我们也是天生的模式匹配者。您刚刚注意到这两个句子是相同的，并将它们放在一起，甚至没有意识到这一点。作为人类，您无法控制这一点。我们本能地将相似的物体匹配在一起。收集在收藏卡牌游戏（显然）、休闲游戏（将三件东西匹配在一起）、平台游戏（收集戒指、螺栓或金币）或获得最多资源决定胜负的游戏中占有重要地位。     

·      Collection: As humans, we’re also natural pattern matchers. As humans, we’re also natural pattern matchers. You just noticed those two sentences were identical and put them together without even consciously thinking about it. As a human, you can’t help it. We match similar objects together instinctively. Collection features prominently in collectible card games (obviously), casual games (match three things together), platformers (collect rings, bolts, or gold coins), or games where getting the most of a resource determines the winner.

·追逐或躲避：古代人类必须大量奔跑，以捕获猎物或逃避掠食者。因此，在许多游戏中看到这种动态并不奇怪。它在大多数接触性运动中都很突出，在像吃豆人这样的视频游戏和像苏格兰场这样的棋盘游戏中也是如此。     

·      Chasing or Evading: Ancient humans had to run a lot, either to capture prey or escape predators. So it should not be a surprise to see this dynamic in many games. It is prominent in most contact sports, as well as video games like Pac-Man and board games like Scotland Yard.

·交易：并非所有游戏都具有竞争性。在许多游戏中，玩家会相互合作（即使他们是对手）。在拥有多种资源的游戏中，玩家之间进行交易和谈判是很常见的。交易是许多非数字游戏的核心动态，例如Pit和 Settlers of Catan。它发生在游戏之外，例如集换式卡牌游戏。甚至像《动物之森》和《精灵宝可梦》这样的电子游戏也具有与其他玩家交易的功能。     

·      Trading: Not all play is necessarily competitive. In many games, players cooperate with each other (even if they are opponents). With games that have multiple kinds of resources that belong to each player, it is common to see players trading and negotiating with one another. Trading is a core dynamic of many non-digital games, such as Pit and Settlers of Catan. It happens outside of the game with collectible card games. Even video games like Animal Crossing and Pokemon feature the ability to trade with other players.

·冲向终点：第一个穿过街道、第一个冲过终点线或第一个学会某项技术都是“冲向终点”游戏核心动态的常见用法。与生存、建造和收集一样，人类也会本能地尝试更快地做事，这在很大程度上是因为大脑向我们发出信号，越快越好，这是掌握某项技能的标志。采用这种机制的游戏通常易于创建和玩。这种机制经常用于儿童游戏中。     

·      Race to the End: Being the first to cross the street, the first to cross the finish line, or the first to learn a particular technology are each common uses of the “race to the end” core dynamic of gameplay. Like survival, building, and collection, humans will also intuitively try to do things more quickly, in large part because the brain signals us that faster is better and is a sign of mastery over a given skill. Games featuring this mechanic are typically easy to create and play. The mechanic is often used in children’s games.

在考虑特定核心的功能列表时，设计师会将游戏中的每个功能以某种方式与该单一核心机制（或一组机制）联系起来，最终使游戏更加强大。

In considering a feature list for a given core, designers tie every feature in the game back into that single core mechanic (or set of mechanics) in some way that ultimately makes the game stronger.

然而，从核心机制开发和实现功能集则完全是另一回事，它代表了游戏设计师的真正手艺。功能集列出了产品的所有单个功能。在功能集中，设计师通常会尝试部分创新、部分改进和部分惯例。对于游戏的功能集，游戏设计师使用定义该类型和玩家期望的标准惯​​例，但他们会尝试找到某种方式来创新该类型或类似主题的先前游戏（如果有的话）。

However, developing and implementing a feature set from that core mechanic is another matter entirely, and it represents the real craft of the game designer. Feature sets list all the individual features of the product. Within a feature set, designers generally try for part innovation, part improvement, and part convention. For a game’s feature set, game designers use the standard conventions that define the genre and that players expect, but they try to find some way to innovate on previous games in the genre or with a similar theme, if there are any.

数字游戏实际上极大地扩展了我们作为游戏设计师可以选择的核心可能性，因为它们能够实现许多非数字游戏无法实现的功能。考虑到各种各样的游戏——从大预算游戏到严肃游戏——游戏核心的范围是巨大的。

Digital games actually greatly expanded the core possibility that we as game designers can choose from since they are capable of so many things that non-digital games cannot do. Taking into account the whole variety of games—from big-budget titles to serious games— the range of game cores is tremendous.

创意从何而来？

WHERE DO IDEAS COME FROM?

任何东西都可以变成游戏。从种豆到放牧到编织，在游戏设计方面，一切都是可行的。尽管如此，对于游戏设计师来说，“你的想法从何而来？”是一个常见的问题。

Anything—anything at all—can be turned into a game. From bean farming, to sheep herding, to knitting, everything is fair game when it comes to game design. Nonetheless, for working game designers, the question “Where do you get your ideas?” is a common one.

有多个答案：

There are multiple answers:

·玩很多游戏。通过玩游戏，你可以形成一套机制和动态词汇，而这些是成功游戏设计的必要组成部分。玩很多不同类型的游戏很重要，而不仅仅是那些你熟悉的游戏。想象一下，如果你是一名建筑师，一生都生活在联排别墅社区，然后你试图设计一栋新房子。那栋房子可能与你已经知道的房子相似。同样，想象一下在礼堂长大的关卡设计师（出于某种奇怪的原因）。他的所有关卡都会以某种方式反映出他成长的世界。然而，通过接触许多不同的游戏，你的设计或你团队的设计可能会反映出多种影响。让自己接触许多新类型的游戏来发展你的知识和技能。看纪录片。如果你感兴趣，就去寻找里面的游戏。     

·      Playing lots of games. Through playing games, you develop a vocabulary of mechanics and dynamics that are the necessary building blocks of successful game design. It is important to play many different kinds of games, not just those you are familiar with. Imagine if you were an architect and spent your entire life in a townhouse community, and then you tried to design a new house. That house would probably be similar to the ones you already know. Likewise, think of the level designer raised (for some odd reason) in an auditorium. All of his levels would reflect, in some way, the world that he grew up in. With exposure to lots of different games, however, your designs or the designs of your group are likely to reflect multiple influences. Expose yourself to many new kinds of games to develop your range of knowledge and skills. Watch documentaries. If something interests you, look for the game inside.

·与其他设计师交流。两位设计师讨论某个主题所蕴含的可能性是制作游戏的万无一失的方法。请注意，这款游戏可能很糟糕，因此拥有一批合格的人员来为您提供客观反馈也很重要。尽管如此，设计师们还是会分享方法，并总是互相激励，进行更深入的思考。     

·      Networking with other designers. Two designers talking about the possibility inherent in a topic is a sure-fire way to produce a game. Mind you, it might be a bad game, so it’s important to have a qualified pool of people to give you objective feedback as well. Still, designers share methods and always spur each other on to deeper thinking.

·无处不在。在你所做的每一件事中寻找游戏创意，每天至少挑战自己制作一款游戏或考虑制作一款关于某个主题的游戏。现在你周围有一些你完全忽略的声音：翻页的声音、你自己的呼吸声，也许还有背景中的音乐或电视声。游戏设计可以以同样的方式被忽略或调整。如果你积极倾听可能性并去尝试，你会发现游戏创意无处不在。     

·      Everywhere. Look for game ideas in everything you do and challenge yourself to make a game or think about making a game about a topic at least once a day. Right now around you, there are sounds you are completely tuning out: the flip of the page, the sound of your own breathing, and perhaps music or a television in the background. Game design can be tuned out or tuned in the same way. If you actively listen for the possibility and go with it, you will find game ideas everywhere.

学习游戏设计

LEARNING GAME DESIGN

游戏设计是你必须应用才能学习的领域。确实，没有什么可以替代游戏制作。在此过程中，你学到的东西比仅仅阅读有关游戏制作的内容要多得多。幸运的是，在本书的整个过程中，你将做很多这样的事情。

Game design is a field you must apply to learn. Truly, there is no substitute for making games. In that process, you learn so much more than you would by merely reading about making games. Fortunately, throughout the course of this book, you’ll be doing a whole lot of that.

在这方面，游戏设计就像烹饪。想象一下，一位厨师只阅读烹饪书或各种烹饪技巧方面的书籍，但从未真正踏入厨房或尝试烹饪一顿饭。他做的第一道菜很可能非常难吃。或者想象一下，一位画家从未拿起过画笔。除了对基本概念进行初步研究之外，提高绘画水平的最好方法就是不断绘画。

Game design has been likened to cooking in this respect. Imagine a chef who only reads cookbooks or books on various techniques but never actually sets foot in a kitchen or tries to cook a meal. Odds are his first dishes will be terribly unappetizing. Or imagine a painter who has never picked up a brush. Beyond some initial study of basic concepts, the best way to get better at painting is to paint and then paint some more.

同样，通过创建和玩自己的设计，你可以了解特定机制在各种情况下如何工作以及不工作。也只有在游戏过程中才会出现动态，其中一些可能会让你感到惊讶。

Likewise, by creating and playing your own designs, you learn how particular mechanics work and don’t work under a variety of circumstances. It is also only through the process of play that dynamics arise, and some of these may surprise you.

在原型 Sióchán Leat（也称为“爱尔兰游戏”）中，本书的一位作者试图模拟一个装置的位移，该装置将作为艺术展览的一部分出现。随着游戏的进行，游戏玩法发展出两种游戏设计师没有预料到的动态。实际玩游戏对于充分了解游戏机制和系统的动态是必不可少的。 

In the prototype Sióchán Leat (also known as The Irish Game), one of this book’s authors was attempting to simulate displacement for an installation that would appear as a part of an art exhibit. As play progressed, the gameplay developed two dynamics that the game designer didn’t see coming. The actual play of a game necessary to fully understand the dynamics of the game’s mechanics and systems.  

第一个令人惊讶的动态是游戏节奏的变化，因为一组令牌将其他令牌挤入越来越小的一块领地。有趣的“生存”策略发展起来，玩家会让他们的令牌多次移动，以确保与迎面而来的力量保持最佳距离。

The first surprising dynamic was the change in the pace of play as one group of tokens crowded the others into a smaller and smaller piece of territory. Interesting strategies for “survival” developed where players would allow their tokens to get displaced more than once to ensure an optimum distance from the oncoming forces.

第二个令人惊讶的动态是游戏玩法中存在的明确阶段。游戏中存在阶段是意料之中的事情—— 《Risk》的阶段非常明确——但设计师也对这款游戏中阶段的明确划分感到惊讶。

The second surprising dynamic was the distinct phases that were present in the game play. Phases are to be expected in a game—Risk has very clear phases—but the designer was surprised by the clear delineation of phases in this game, too.

通过阅读规则手册或编写设计文档，这些动态永远不会显现出来。为了进行设计，你必须练习设计，并且必须发挥你所练习的东西。否则就行不通。

By reading a rulebook or writing a design document, these dynamics would never have been evident. In order to design, you must practice design, and you must play what you practice. It doesn’t work any other way.

游戏设计中的常用术语

COMMON TERMS IN GAME DESIGN

和其他行业一样，游戏行业也有术语来定义项目中的特定事件或里程碑，或与游戏相关的一般事物。然而，这些定义都不是一成不变的。对于行业中使用的每个术语，根据公司、个人或学科的不同，可能有五种不同的定义。本书中广泛使用了以下术语：

Like any other industry, the game industry has terms it uses to define specific events or milestones in a project or things related to games in general. None of these definitions are set in stone, however. For every term used in the industry, there are probably five different definitions depending on the company, the person, or the discipline you’re talking about. The following terms are used liberally throughout this book:

·功能列表：详细说明游戏的主要功能或卖点的列表。在已发布的游戏中，这些内容通常位于包装盒背面。     

·      Feature List: A list that details key features or selling points of the game. In published games, these are typically found on the back of the box.

·头脑风暴：一种产生想法的过程，通常在小组中进行。一般来说，头脑风暴会议的参与者会被要求说出他们想到的任何想法，无论这些想法看起来多么奇怪、愚蠢或疯狂。一名参与者将所有这些想法写在每个人都能看到的地方。参与者可以详细阐述或引用他人的想法，但会议结束前不允许批评或排除任何想法。     

·      Brainstorming: A process to generate ideas, usually done in a group. Generally, participants in a brainstorming session are instructed to call out any idea that occurs to them, no matter how strange, silly, or crazy it seems. One participant writes all of these ideas down on a space where everyone can see them. Participants may elaborate on or play off of others’ ideas, but criticism or elimination of ideas is not allowed until after the session is over.

·原型：原型是游戏的可玩早期版本或游戏的一部分，由设计师构建，用于帮助理解和增强玩家体验。原型可以通过软件（“数字原型”）或实物材料（桌面游戏（“物理原型”或“纸质原型”）来实现     

·      Prototype: A prototype is a playable early version of the game or part of the game constructed by the designer to assist in understanding and enhancing the player experience. It may be done with software (“digital prototype”) or with physical materials as a tabletop game (“physical prototype” or “paper prototype”)

·平衡：用于描述游戏系统状态的术语，包括“平衡”或“不平衡”。不平衡的游戏方式意味着太简单、太难，或者只适合某些玩家群体。平衡的游戏方式则为目标受众提供了一致的挑战。对于竞争性多人游戏，平衡还包括这样一种理念：没有任何一种策略天生就比其他策略更好，也不存在任何漏洞让玩家绕过游戏挑战。我们有时也将各个游戏元素称为“平衡”，这意味着获得它的成本与其效果成正比，就像 CCG 中的卡牌或 FPS 或 RPG 中的武器一样。     

·      Balance: A term used to describe the state of a game’s systems as either “balanced” or “unbalanced.” When the play is unbalanced, it is too easy, too difficult, or optimal for only certain groups of players. When play is balanced, it provides a consistent challenge for its target audience. For competitive multiplayer games, it also includes the idea that no single strategy should be inherently better than any other, and that no exploits exist that let a player bypass the challenge of the game. We also sometimes call individual game elements “balanced” with each other, meaning that the cost of obtaining it is proportional to its effect, as with cards in a CCG or weapons in an FPS or RPG.

·机制：游戏规则。常见的非数字机制包括玩牌、轮流、掷骰子和移动。视频游戏中的机制示例包括奔跑、跳跃和射击。第 2 章详细介绍了机制。     

·      Mechanics: The rules of a game. Common non-digital mechanics include trick taking, turn taking, rolling a die, and moving. Examples of mechanics from video games are running, jumping, and shooting. Mechanics are covered extensively in Chapter 2.

·动态：正如 Robin Hunicke、Marc LeBlanc 和 Robert Zubek 的 MDA（力学-动力学-美学）模型[3]所推广的那样，当规则付诸实施时，就会产生动态。允许玩家互相攻击的规则可能是一种机制，但玩家真正使用这些规则组队对抗领先的玩家是一种动态。在一些第一人称射击游戏中，玩家总是从某个位置（“重生点”）开始，这是一种机制；站在重生点旁边并杀死从那里出来的玩家（“重生点防守”）是一种动态。在国际象棋中，棋子的移动是机制，但“开局”（游戏开始时众所周知的移动序列）是动态。     

·      Dynamics: As popularized in Robin Hunicke, Marc LeBlanc, and Robert Zubek’s MDA (mechanics-dynamics-aesthetics) model [3], dynamics result when rules are put in motion. The rules that allow players to attack each other might be a mechanic, but players actually using these rules to team up against the player in the lead is a dynamic. In some first-person shooter games, players always begin in certain locations (“spawn points”), which is a mechanic; standing next to a spawn point and killing players that come out of it (“spawn camping”) is a dynamic. In Chess, the moves of the pieces are mechanics, but “book openings” (well-known sequences of moves at the start of the game) are dynamics.

·系统：一组游戏机制，负责在大型游戏中产生特定的结果，例如角色创建、战斗或施法。     

·      System: A collection of game mechanics that is responsible for producing a given outcome within a larger game such as character creation, combat, or casting spells.

·虚拟形象：游戏中玩家的直接代表。在《大富翁》中，棋盘上移动的棋子（鞋子、狗等）就是虚拟形象。在《古墓丽影》中，主角劳拉·克劳馥就是虚拟形象。在非数字游戏中，这些通常被称为“代币”。     

·      Avatar: The direct representation of a player in a game. In Monopoly, the pieces moved around the board (shoe, dog, and so on) are avatars. In Tomb Raider, the main character Lara Croft is the avatar. In non-digital games, these are often called “tokens.”

·游戏测试：对游戏玩法、系统、平衡和界面进行系统测试，以查找所有错误、不一致或问题并将其报告给设计团队。     

·      Playtesting: The systematic testing of gameplay, systems, balance, and interface to find all the errors, inconsistencies, or issues and report them to the design team.

以下术语通常用于数字游戏设计：

The following terms are usually reserved for digital game design:

·平台：游戏所运行的控制台、设备或系统。     

·      Platform: The console, device, or system upon which the game will be played.

·概念文档：一到三页的文档，提供拟议游戏的高级概述。它通常包含以下部分：介绍游戏主题的介绍性段落；人口统计细分，包括目标受众、类型和目标平台；以及项目要点功能列表和功能列表细分，更详细地解释每个功能。本书的附录中提供了示例概念文档的大纲。     

·      Concept Doc: A one-to three-page document that provides a high-level overview of a proposed game. It usually contains the following sections: an introductory paragraph explaining the theme of the game; demographic breakdown, including target audience, genre, and intended platform(s); and a bullet-point feature-list and a feature list breakout that explains each of the features in more detail. An outline for a sample concept doc is provided in the appendix of this book.

·提案：一份 5 到 20 页的文档，比概念文档更深入地介绍潜在游戏。与概念文档一样，它通常包含介绍段落、人口统计分析、游戏玩法摘要、功能列表和功能列表细分。它还包含预算和时间估算、竞争分析（与竞争对手相比如何）以及初始产品发布后的扩展计划（例如续集）。通常，它包含屏幕模型或概念图。本书后面的附录中还提供了提案文档的大纲。     

·      Proposal: A 5- to 20-page document that provides a more in-depth view of the potential game than a concept document. Like a concept document, it typically contains an introductory paragraph, a demographic breakdown, a gameplay summary, a feature list, and a feature-list breakout. It also contains budget and time estimations, competitive analysis (how it stacks up against the competition), and expansion plans (for example, sequels) beyond the initial product release. Typically, it contains screen mockups or concept art. An outline for a proposal doc is also provided later in the appendix of this book.

·推介：向游戏发行商或风险投资家 (VC) 发表的简短“电梯演讲”，用于为项目募集资金。电梯演讲得名于人们陈述想法的时间长度——相当于你和某人一起乘坐电梯，然后你们其中一人必须下电梯的时间。     

·      Pitch: A brief “elevator speech” given to a game publisher or VC (venture capitalist) to solicit funding for the project. An elevator speech gets its name from the length of time that people have to present their ideas—the amount of time you’d spend riding with someone in an elevator before one of you had to get out.

·设计文档：一份不断修订的“动态”文档，其中包含游戏的整个设计愿景。它可能位于文档文件中或 Wiki 中。一些团队使用敏捷开发，这种开发根本不需要设计文档。有关敏捷的更多信息，请访问 AgileManifesto.org。游戏设计文档 (GDD) 通常与程序员的技术设计文档 (TDD) 和艺术团队的艺术风格指南分开。     

·      Design Document: A “living” document that is continuously undergoing revision, it contains the entire design vision for the game. It may be in a document file or in a wiki. Some teams use Agile development, which requires no design document at all. More information on Agile can be found at AgileManifesto.org. Game design documents (GDDs) are usually separate from the technical design document (TDD) for programmers and the art style guide for the art team.

·错误：游戏设计、代码、艺术、声音或写作中的错误。     

·      Bugs: Errors in the game’s design, code, art, sound, or writing.

·引擎：运行游戏的核心程序。Unreal 和 Unity 是游戏行业常用的引擎。开发人员会在引擎之上添加其他技术，以实现产品的精确设计规格。     

·      Engine: The core program that runs the game. Unreal and Unity are popular engines used in the game industry. Developers will layer additional technology on top of the engine to achieve the exact design specifications of the product.

· Alpha：所有系统都已实现且所有代码在理论上都已完成的里程碑。然而，它通常充满错误，并且平衡性不佳。一些公司还要求所有内容（艺术、声音和叙事）也为 Alpha 实现。因此，alpha 是内容和代码完整的。     

·      Alpha: The milestone at which all systems have been implemented and all code is theoretically complete. It is usually full of bugs, however, and not terribly balanced. Some companies also require that all content—art, sound, and narrative—be implemented for alpha, too. Therefore, alpha is content- and code-complete.

· Beta 版：游戏所有系统和内容都已完成的里程碑。它比 alpha 版稳定得多，许多大错误和平衡问题都已得到解决。     

·      Beta: The milestone at which all systems and content are in the game. It is significantly more stable than the alpha version, and many of the big bug and balancing issues have been addressed.

·黄金版：随后发布的游戏最终版本。     

·      Gold: The final version of the game that is then released.

· Game Jam：一群人日以继夜地努力制作一款完整游戏的限时活动。此类活动通常持续 1-3 天。     

·      Game Jam: A timed period during which a group of individuals attempts to create a complete game while working around the clock. These events are usually 1–3 days in duration.

·里程碑：开发者预计在此节点交付某种预定内容。这可能是一份文档、大量艺术资产或一款完整的游戏。     

·      Milestone: A point at which the developer is expected to deliver some type of predetermined content. It may be a document, numerous art assets, or a complete game.

非数字游戏也有一些常用术语：

Non-digital games also have some common terms:

·游戏部件：游戏随附的部件和零件的非正式名称，包括游戏牌、棋盘和卡片。这些更正式的名称是“组件”或“游戏对象”。     

·      Game Bits: The informal name given to the pieces and parts that ship with a game, including the game tiles, board, and cards. These are more formally called “components” or “game objects.”

·纸牌游戏：使用纸牌的游戏。纸牌可以是标准纸牌、口袋妖怪纸牌、万智牌纸牌或其他纸牌。     

·      Card Game: A game that uses playing cards. They may be a standard deck of cards, Pokemon cards, Magic: The Gathering cards, or other cards.

·棋盘游戏：以棋盘作为游戏场地的游戏。     

·      Board Game: A game whose board serves as the playing field for the game.

·方块游戏：一种游戏，其游戏“棋盘”由方块组成，通常是正方形或六边形。方块可能以预定的配置开始（例如《卡坦岛》或《嘿，那是我的鱼！》），也可能在游戏过程中构建（例如《卡卡颂》）。     

·      Tile Game: A type of game where the game “board” is made out of tiles, usually square or hexagonal. The tiles may start in a predetermined configuration (as in Settlers of Catan or Hey, That’s My Fish!) or built during play (like Carcassonne).

·骰子游戏：使用骰子作为主要筹码的游戏，通常没有棋盘、卡片或牌。     

·      Dice Game: A game that uses dice as the main bits, typically lacking a board, cards or tiles.

游戏设计方法

APPROACHES TO GAME DESIGN

不同的设计师有不同的游戏设计方法，这取决于他们设计游戏的情况和媒介。在创建以下列表时，我们对名称进行了一定的改动。换句话说，我们编造了这些名称来描述我们经历过和经常听到的过程。

Different designers have different approaches to game design, depending on the situation and the medium in which they’re designing. In creating the list that follows, certain liberties have been taken with the names. In other words, we’ve made them up to describe processes that we both experience and regularly hear about.

·蓝天设计：纯粹的蓝天设计允许设计师考虑许多可能性和想法，但时间、金钱、兴趣或以上所有因素都会造成一些例外。从某些方面来看，游戏设计就像没有地图的寻宝。设计师总是在寻找新的想法，因为从一开始就创造游戏的经历对设计师来说本质上是令人愉快的。事实上，对于大多数设计师来说，游戏在于创造游戏。大多数时候，专业设计师都在特定的约束下工作——外部对设计施加的限制。然而，蓝天设计除了设计师的想象力之外不承担任何约束。     

·      Blue-sky: Pure blue-sky design allows designers to consider lots of possibilities and ideas with a few exceptions imposed by time, money, interest, or all of the above. In some respects, game design is like treasure hunting without a map. Designers are always looking for new ideas, because the experience of creating a game right from the inception is inherently pleasurable to the designer. For most designers, in fact, the game lies in creating the game. Most of the time, a professional designer is working under a particular constraint—an externally imposed restriction on the design. Blue-sky design, however, assumes no constraints other than the designer’s imagination.

·慢慢酝酿：当给定一个主题和背景时——比如 19 世纪 80 年代波士顿的爱尔兰人——游戏设计师就开始了一项只能被描述为大规模的研究任务，但这项任务通常没有什么方向，只要它包含主题。正如一位设计师所说，“我把所有我能找到的关于这个主题的东西都塞进脑袋里，然后我等待。一个设计就会出现。”幸运的是，对于大多数设计师来说，他们都是通才，热爱学习，天生的好奇心引导他们朝着这个方向发展。有时，设计需要几天时间，但有时可能需要几周、几个月甚至几年。游戏设计师 Reiner Knizia 经常同时进行 30 种不同的设计，他指出，他更喜欢在脑海中反复思考游戏，反复玩它们，然后再进入原型阶段。新设计师常犯的一个错误是过早推出游戏或没有给它足够的时间来开发。定期把脑海中的想法写下来可以帮助激发更多的想法，特别是如果这些想法以潜在的设计文档或规则集的形式出现。     

·      Slow boil: When given a theme and a setting—say, the Irish in 1880s Boston—game designers begin what can only be described as a massive research mission, but one that often has little direction as long as it encompasses the theme. As one designer noted, “I stuff my head full of everything I can get on the topic, and then I wait. A design will emerge.” Fortunately for most designers, they are expert generalists with a love for learning and a natural curiosity that leads them in this direction. Sometimes, that design takes days, but other times, it may be weeks, months, or even years. Game designer Reiner Knizia regularly has 30 different designs on the go and has noted that he prefers to mull games over in his mind, playing them repeatedly, before moving to a prototype stage. One common mistake new designers make is forcing a game out too early or not giving it enough time to develop. Periodically writing down the ideas in one’s head can help spur still more ideas, particularly if the ideas take the form of a potential design document or rule set.

·机制：机制驱动设计比人们想象的更为常见。以经典的《超级马里奥兄弟》游戏为例。马里奥跳上、越过、撞进物体。游戏的优势就在于这种机制的强大，几乎所有平台游戏类型都从很久以前就开始效仿该游戏。其他游戏，如《块魂》系列，采用粘球滚过物体并将其捡起的机制。同样，同样的机制被反复使用，效果极佳。也许最大的机制驱动游戏就以该类型游戏的名称为特色：第一人称射击游戏。显然，开枪、挥动魔杖或某种东西的机制永远不会过时。甚至马里奥也能发射火球。     

·      Mechanic: Mechanic-driven design is more common than one might think. Consider the classic Super Mario Bros. game. Mario jumps onto things, over things, and into things. The strength of the game is based on the sheer strength of this mechanic, and nearly all games in the platformer genre have followed that game’s lead from long, long ago. Other games, like those in the Katamari Damacy series, feature a mechanic in which a sticky ball rolls over something and picks it up. Again, that same mechanic is used over and over to great effect. Perhaps the largest mechanic-driven games feature the mechanic right in the genre’s title: first-person shooters. The mechanic of firing a gun, a wand, or a something evidently never gets old. Even Mario could shoot fireballs.

· MDA：使用游戏开发的机制-动态-美学模型，设计师可以为各种类型的游戏玩法创建美学模型。美学不是指游戏的外观，而是指设计师和开发团队希望通过游戏动态在玩家身上唤起的情感反应。如果机制是游戏规则，动态是游戏玩法，那么美学通常就是玩游戏时体验到的乐趣（或缺乏乐趣）。设计师会问自己希望实现哪种美学，定义能带来这种感觉的动态，然后创建机制来产生所需的动态。有关 MDA 的更多信息，请访问 Marc 的主页 http://mahk.8kindsoffun.com/。     

·      MDA: Using the mechanics-dynamics-aesthetics model of game development, designers create aesthetic models for various types of gameplay. Aesthetics don’t refer to the looks of the game but rather the emotional response the designer and development team hope to evoke in the players through the game dynamics. If mechanics are the rules and dynamics are the play of the game, then aesthetics are typically the fun (or lack thereof) experienced by playing. Designers ask themselves which aesthetic they hope to achieve, define the dynamics that would lead to this feeling, and then create the mechanics to produce the desired dynamics. More information on MDA can be found at Marc’s homepage at http://mahk.8kindsoffun.com/.

· IP： IP 代表“知识产权”，基于 IP 的游戏在游戏行业非常常见，大多数设计师在职业生涯的某个阶段都会为已有的 IP 开发游戏。术语“IP”用于指代几乎任何事物或任何人，游戏就是基于这些事物或任何人 而构建的。IP 的例子包括《蜘蛛侠》、 《光晕》、《模拟人生》和约翰·马登这样的个人。甚至非数字游戏也属于 IP。大多数热门电视节目都会发布棋盘游戏版本，而热门视频游戏通常会被制作成纸牌和棋盘游戏。《口袋妖怪》和《魔兽世界》只是“脱离网络”的游戏 IP 的两个例子。游戏发行商喜欢使用 IP，因为它可以降低风险。已经知道并喜欢它的人越多，仅凭许可证的强度，潜在市场就越大，这意味着发行商的游戏达不到销售目标的风险就越小。作为 IP 力量的一个例子，请考虑 NFL 橄榄球。现在，想想另一个职业橄榄球联盟。尽管有些战术已经在现实世界和电子游戏中进行了尝试，但没有一种战术能够接近真正的 NFL 的实力。     

·      IP: Standing for “intellectual property,” games based on IP are very common in the game industry, and most designers find themselves developing a game for a pre-existing IP at some point in their career. The term “IP” is used to refer to pretty much anything or anyone upon whose likeness a game is built. Examples of IPs include Spiderman, Halo, The Sims, and individuals like John Madden. Even non-digital games are covered in IP. Most popular television shows release board-game versions, and popular video games are often made into card and board games. Pokemon and World of Warcraft are just two examples of game IP that have gone “off the grid.” Game publishers like to use IP because it mitigates risk. The more people who already know about it and like it, the larger the potential market based on the strength of the license alone, which means the publisher has less risk of the game falling short of sales goals. As an example of the power of an IP, consider NFL football. Now, think of another professional football league. Though some have been tried in the real world and in video games, none ever came close to the strength of the true NFL.

·故事：基于故事开发游戏也是一种常见的设计方法，但在视频游戏中比非数字游戏中更常见。当许可证持有者希望开发者紧密贴合相关书籍、电视节目或电影的故事时，这种方法通常与知识产权相结合。故事也可以代表一个人或一个公司的时间线。作家汤姆·克兰西 (Tom Clancy) 已将他的许多书籍授权用于游戏，史诗《指环王》被雷纳·克尼齐亚 (Reiner Knizia) 改编成广受好评的棋盘游戏。然而，在非数字游戏中，设计师往往像克尼齐亚一样采用主题方法。     

·      Story: Developing a game based on a story is also a common design approach, but more common in video games than non-digital games. This is often done hand-in-hand with IP when the license holder wants the developer to stick closely to the story of the book, television show, or movie in question. The story can also represent the chronological timeline of a person or a company. Author Tom Clancy has licensed many of his books for games, and the epic The Lord of the Rings was turned into an acclaimed board game by Reiner Knizia. More often than not, however, in non-digital games, the designer takes a thematic approach as Knizia did.

·研究：游戏越来越多地被用于研究各种主题或作为研究主题本身。萨凡纳艺术设计学院的学生 Michelle Menard 在她的 MFA 论文中制作了一款制作级棋盘游戏、一部纪录片，并完成了一篇研究论文，探讨了使用情感来创造游戏机制的想法。同样，南加州大学的 Jenova Chen 创造了flOw来探索游戏中的流动和动态难度调整的概念。     

·      Research: Increasingly, games are being used to research a variety of topics or as the topic of research itself. For her MFA thesis, Savannah College of Art and Design student Michelle Menard created a production-grade board game, a documentary, and completed a research paper which explored the idea of using emotion to create game mechanics. Likewise, USC’s Jenova Chen created flOw to explore the concept of flow and dynamic difficulty adjustment in games.

迭代设计

ITERATIVE DESIGN

游戏设计与大多数设计形式一样，是一个迭代过程。这意味着游戏在最终定稿之前需要快速制作原型、试玩和反复完善。它需要理解没有人能第一次就成功，即使是最熟练的设计师也不行，最伟大、最成功的游戏只能通过一系列反复的失败才能实现。任何中等复杂的游戏或游戏中的系统通常都需要多次迭代才能被视为完成。

Game design, like most forms of design, is an iterative process. That means that the game is quickly prototyped, played, and refined again and again before it is finalized. It requires the understanding that no one gets it right on the first try, not even the most skilled designer, and that the greatest, most successful games are only achieved through a series of repeated failures on the way. Any moderately complex game or system within a game usually requires many iterations before it is considered finished.

典型的迭代包括以下组件：

A typical iteration includes the following components:

·快速原型：设计师注重游戏性而非图形。想一想，如何以棋盘游戏形式制作电子游戏《马里奥赛车》的原型。游戏将使用“奔向终点”的核心动态，代币将代表汽车，玩家将根据他们在棋盘上的位置执行各种操作。从那里开始，可以制作其他机制来改善非数字版本的游戏性。原型制作的关键点在于必须快速。游戏可以经历的迭代次数越多，质量就越高，因此花三个月时间讨论粗略原型的问题最终只是浪费时间。有时，设计师希望通过原型回答特定问题（“包括蓝色外壳武器是否太强大？”），有时他们希望评估游戏的整体感觉。设计师之间有一种很大的倾向，即争论某件事的结果，如果只制作原型，就可以在一半的时间内展示出来。     

·      Rapid Prototype: Designers focus on play over graphics. Think for a moment about how one would prototype the video game Mario Kart in a board-game format. A “race to the end” core dynamic would be used, tokens would represent cars, and players would have a variety of actions they could perform, depending on their location on the board. From there, other mechanics could be made to improve the play of the non-digital counterpart. The key point of prototyping is that it has to be rapid. The more iterations a game can undergo, the higher quality it will be, so spending three months discussing a rough prototype’s issues ends up just being a waste of time. Sometimes, designers are hoping to answer a specific question with a prototype (“Would including a blue shell weapon be too powerful?”), and other times they’re hoping to gauge the overall feel of the game. There is a great tendency among designers to debate the outcome of something that could be shown in half the time if only it were prototyped.

·游戏测试：这是一个完整或部分的游戏环节，旨在确定设计中的优势和劣势。     

·      Playtest: This is a full or partial play session to identify strengths and weaknesses in the design.

·修订：对设计进行更改以弥补弱点并增强优势。有时，更改是一次一个地进行的小增量更改。其他时候，设计师会偶然发现意想不到的游戏动态，导致游戏朝着完全不同的方向发展。     

·      Revision: Changes are made in the design to fortify weaknesses and build upon strengths. Sometimes, changes are small incremental changes incorporated one at a time. Other times, designers happen upon unexpected play dynamics that cause the game to go in a completely different direction.

·重复：回到原型并开始下一次迭代。     

·      Repeat: Go back to the prototype and start the next iteration.

在设计游戏原型时，本书的作者还遵循了一些一般规则：

In prototyping games, there are also a couple general rules that the authors of this book follow:

·除非必须写下规则，否则不要写下规则。如果你作为设计师都无法在脑子里记住规则，你又如何指望你的玩家记住呢？另一方面，如果你的玩家在玩游戏时面前有怪物列表之类的东西，你也应该这样做。但是，如果写作是你头脑风暴过程的一部分，或者由于设计会议之间的时间太长，你很可能会忘记游戏的某些部分，那么就抛弃这条规则吧。     

·      Don’t write your rules down until you have to write your rules down. If you as the designers can’t keep them straight in your head, how do you expect your players to? If, on the other hand, your players have things like monster lists in front of them while playing, so should you. If writing is a part of your brainstorming process, though, or if you’re likely to forget parts of your game due to the length of time between design sessions, jettison this rule.

·在识别游戏中的问题时，要小心不要在问题上贴创可贴，而将问题留在游戏中。在某些情况下，设计师最终会贴上一层又一层的创可贴，而最初的不良机制本应被移除。当你反复尝试修复不值得修复的东西时，最好将其完全移除。即使没有其他事情，你远离它的时间可能会改善你的视角，让你对解决方案有新的见解。     

·      In identifying problems in games, be wary of putting a Band-Aid on top of a problem, but leaving the problem in the game. In some cases, designers end up with Band-Aid upon Band-Aid when the initial bad mechanic should have been removed. When you repeatedly try to fix something that’s just not worth it, it might be better to remove it entirely. If nothing else, your time away from it may improve your perspective and give you new insight into a solution.

游戏设计的限制

CONSTRAINTS ON GAME DESIGN

约束是设计师制作游戏时的限制。将约束视为一个通常无法改变的框框。例如，考虑一下如果您有 20 美元或 200,000 美元，您会制作哪种类型的游戏。

Constraints are the confines in which designers build games. Think of constraints as a box that you usually cannot alter. For instance, consider the type of game you would build if you had $20 versus $200,000.

电子游戏的限制

VIDEO-GAME CONSTRAINTS

在主流视频游戏中，设计师通常会以如下约束开始他们的设计过程：

In mainstream video games, designers often start their design process with constraints like the following:

·这款游戏的预算大约是多少？     

·      What is the approximate budget for this game?

·期望的完成时间是什么时候？     

·      What is the desired time frame for completion?

·游戏所需的平台是什么（例如，主机、多主机、智能手机、个人电脑、ARG）？     

·      What is the desired platform for the game (for example, console, multiple consoles, smart phones, PCs, ARGs)?

这三个问题影响着整个设计过程。事实上，这些不同的限制可能会相互冲突。游戏新手（例如，希望制作训练游戏的公司）完全低估普通游戏开发成本的情况并不少见。在推销游戏时，发行商可能会愿意谈判，并要求你提出各种可能性。

These three questions influence the whole course of the design. In fact, these various constraints may conflict with one another. It’s not uncommon for people new to games (a corporation hoping to get a training game made, for instance) to completely underestimate the cost of an average game’s development. In pitching a game, it’s possible that the publisher is open to negotiation and will ask you to suggest various possibilities.

解决了关键问题之后，设计师还会问其他问题：

With the key questions out of the way, there are other questions that designers ask:

·这款游戏的目标受众是哪些人？     

·      What is the target audience for the game?

·游戏的期望评级是什么？（尽管游戏要等到制作完成才会被 ESRB（娱乐软件分级委员会）评级，但如果有的话，出版商心中都有一个理想的评级，并努力开发一款符合该评级的游戏。）     

·      What is the desired rating for the game? (Although the game won’t be rated by the ESRB (Entertainment Software Rating Board) until it’s nearly finished production, if at all, publishers have an ideal rating in mind and strive to develop a game to fit that rating.)

·您心中有什么特定的游戏类型或类别吗？     

·      Do you have any particular genre or category of game in mind?

·您希望在游戏中看到哪些功能？     

·      Are there any features that you’d like to see in the game?

有些开发者还会要求潜在客户用一些形容词来描述他们想要制作的游戏。这可以让开发者了解游戏的整体风格。如果有人说“前卫而逼真”，那么这与“轻松而卡通化”完全不同。

Some developers also ask potential clients for some adjectives that describe the game that they want to make. It tells the developer a lot about the game’s overall style. If someone says “edgy and realistic,” it steers the pitch in a completely different direction than “light and cartoon like.”

虽然这只是游戏开发商背后经常发生的过程的一个非常简单的视图，但有了这些信息，开发商就可以制作出称职的宣传方案（前提是他是一名称职的开发商）。

While this is a very simplified view of the process that takes place regularly behind the doors of game developers, with this information in hand, a developer can craft a competent pitch (provided he is a competent developer).

对于非授权游戏，如果开发者从头开始开发，希望创造自己的知识产权，同样的问题通常也适用。不过，她在回答这些问题时有更大的自由度，因为她在技术上是知识产权持有者。

For non-licensed games in which the developer is working from scratch in hopes of creating her own IP, the same questions generally apply. However, she has a bit more latitude in answering those questions since she is, technically, the IP holder.

发布你的游戏

Publishing Your Game

注意：在当今市场，除非您是已经拥有多款畅销游戏的知名游戏设计师，否则不可能将出色的视频游戏创意出售给发行商。即便如此，这也可能具有挑战性。如果您刚刚起步并有一个好主意，最好的选择是将其制作出来并在独立市场上销售。

NOTE: In today’s market, it is not possible to sell an idea for a great video game to a publisher, unless you are an already established game designer with multiple best-selling titles under your belt. Even then, it might be challenging. If you are just starting out and have a great idea, your best bet is to make it and sell it on the indie market.

非数字化限制

NON-DIGITAL CONSTRAINTS

在非数字游戏设计中，设计师通常会遇到一些限制。首先要设计游戏——机制、主题、游戏体验——然后根据发行商的反馈进行更改。一些常见的限制包括：

In non-digital game design, designers often end with constraints. The design of the game comes first—the mechanics, the theme, the play experience—and then, based on publisher response, changes are made. Some common constraints include the following:

·每单位制造成本。是否值得使用木质瓷砖，或者更便宜的塑料卡片是否同样有效？是否可以使用更轻的组件来降低运输成本？对于某些类型的游戏，有一个目标价格点。重度策略游戏的成本可能高于轻度休闲家庭游戏。     

·      Cost to manufacture per unit. Is it worth using wooden tiles, or could cheaper plastic cards work just as well? Can lighter components be used to reduce shipping costs? For certain types of games, there is a target price point. Heavy strategy games can cost more than light, casual family games.

·物理尺寸。 在实际使用中，玩游戏的人只有有限的桌面或地板空间，因此棋盘（如果有的话）和其他组件必须放在相对较小的区域内。对于适合小孩子玩的游戏，卡片和其他棋子应该适合小手操作。触觉考虑对棋盘游戏玩家来说尤其重要。      

·      Physical dimensions. In practical use, the people playing the game have a limited amount of tabletop or floor space on which to play, so the board (if there is one) and other components have to fit in a relatively small area. For games that are playable by small children, cards and other pieces should be such that they can be manipulated by small hands. Tactile considerations are particularly important to board-game players.

·发行商。在棋盘游戏行业，并非所有发行商都一样。他们中的许多人专注于某些类型的游戏。一家以家庭游戏闻名的公司不太可能发行您的历史战争游戏，无论它有多出色。有些发行商根本不接受外部投稿。非数字设计师对发行商的选择将受到他们所设计游戏性质的限制。     

·      Publisher. Not all publishers are identical in the board-game industry. Many of them specialize in certain genres. A company that is known for family games is unlikely to publish your historical war game, no matter how brilliant it is. Some publishers do not take outside submissions at all. Non-digital designers’ choice of publishers will be limited by the nature of the game they have designed.

·时机。如果一款类似的游戏刚刚发布，发行商可能更愿意等到第二年再制作另一款同类型的游戏。一些非数字化设计可能需要数年才能在功能上完成，然后才能面世。     

·      Timing. If a similar game was just released, publishers may prefer to wait until the following year before manufacturing another game of the same type. Some non-digital designs may be functionally complete for years before they see the light of day.

如果非数字发行商为特定游戏联系特定设计师，那么限制可能与视频游戏的限制类似。发行商可能希望游戏围绕特定 IP 设计，在特定时间发布，定价固定，针对特定年龄组，总游戏时间在给定范围内。

In cases where a non-digital publisher approaches a particular designer for a specific game, the constraints can be similar to those of a video game. The publisher may want a game designed around a specific IP, to be released at a certain time, with a certain cost, targeted at a certain age group, and have a total playtime within a given range.

与数字游戏设计不同，游戏的物理限制（例如，使其基于图块、棋盘或使用卡片）通常是设计的结果，而不是初始限制。例如，在探索了一个想法并制作了一些原型之后，设计师可能会决定最好将游戏设计为基于图块。一旦设计完成，材料成本可能会成为迫使设计师重新考虑的限制因素。然而，在初始设计中，非数字设计师有许多组件和媒介可供选择。这与数字游戏设计形成鲜明对比，在数字游戏设计中，设计师几乎总是从媒介限制（例如平台和类型）开始。

Unlike digital game design, the physical constraints of the game (making it tile based, on a board, or using cards, for instance) usually come about as the result of the design, rather than as an initial constraint. For instance, after exploring an idea and doing a few prototypes, the designer may decide that it’s best to make the game tile based. Once the design is complete, the cost of materials can be a constraint that forces the designer to reconsider. However, in the initial design, the non-digital designer has many components and mediums from which to choose. This is in contrast to digital game design, where the designer almost always starts with medium constraints (such as platform and genre).

克服设计障碍

OVERCOMING DESIGNER’S BLOCK

即使是最好的游戏设计师有时也会弄出完全失败的作品。当您感到卡住并且不确定如何继续时，有时会使用以下技巧来强制对现有游戏设计进行大规模动态更改（就像作家有办法克服“写作障碍”一样）。虽然这些技巧可能产生的设计可能不会立即产生可交付的结果，但它们会迫使您以完全不同的动态进行游戏并解决一系列新问题，并可能为您的大脑提供巩固特定设计所需的想法。

Even the best game designers end up with complete duds from time to time. The following tricks are sometimes employed to force a massive dynamic change upon existing game designs when you feel stuck and aren’t sure how else to proceed (much like writers have ways to overcome “writer’s block”). While the designs these tricks may produce might not lead to immediate shippable results, they will force you to play with a radically different dynamic and address a new set of problems and perhaps give your brain the ideas it needs to solidify a particular design.

限制（或不限制）资源

MAKE A RESOURCE LIMITED (OR UNLIMITED)

当某种资源（金钱、土地、医疗包）是有限且有限的，设计师会说这些资源是“有限的”。这些资源的数量是有限的，当一个玩家得到一个医疗包时，这意味着另一个玩家将失去获得相同医疗包的机会。例如，如果一个关卡中有 20 个医疗包，一个玩家得到其中的 12 个，另一个玩家最多会得到 8 个。这些医疗包将被视为有限资源。

When a resource—money, land, med packs—are limited and finite, designers say that these resources are “limited.” There is only a certain number of them to go around, and when one player gets one, it means that the other player will therefore lose the opportunity to get the same one. For instance, if there are 20 med packs in a level, and one player gets 12 of them, the other player will get eight at most. These med packs would be considered a limited resource.

大富翁游戏中，财产、房屋、酒店都是有限的，而金钱却不是。只要机会允许，你可以获得尽可能多的现金。

In Monopoly, the property, houses, and hotels are limited, while the money is not. You can get as much cash as chance will allow.

为了有效地使用这个技巧，列出游戏中的所有资源，并注意它们是有限的还是无限的。接下来，一次一个地将资源从无限更改为有限（或反之亦然），并玩一局游戏。想象一下，如果您知道关卡中的子弹是有限的而不是无限的，您会如何玩 FPS。想想如果您可以获得您想要的所有财产，大富翁会如何玩。

In order to effectively use this trick, make a list of all the resources in your game and note whether they are limited or unlimited. Next, and one at a time, change the resources from unlimited to limited (or vice versa), and play a session of the game. Consider for a moment how you would play a FPS if you knew that the bullets on a level were limited versus unlimited. Think of how Monopoly would play if you could get all the property you wanted to.

当资源有限时，玩家往往会被迫采取资源收集和管理策略。当资源无限时，这种策略就不那么重要了，但正如你可能从《大富翁》游戏中看到的那样，有趣的新游戏动态可以显现出来。

When resources are limited, they tend to force a resource-gathering and management strategy on players. When they are unlimited, this strategy is less important, but as you can likely tell by the Monopoly example, interesting new play dynamics can be revealed.

与好友互动

INTERACTING WITH YOUR FRIENDS

虽然赢得比赛总是很有趣，但有时阻止别人做同样的事情或以其他方式影响他们的比赛也同样有趣。看看你的玩家在游戏中执行的各种动作。接下来，问问自己，“其他人如何阻止这种情况发生或使其发生得更快？”你甚至可以更进一步，问玩家如何保护自己免受攻击性动作或更直接地向对手寻求帮助。

While it’s always fun to win a game, it’s occasionally as fun to stop someone else from doing the same or otherwise affect their play. Look at the various actions your players are performing in a game. Next, ask yourself, “How could someone else stop that from happening or make it happen even faster?” You can even take it one step further and ask how players could then protect themselves from aggressive moves or solicit help more directly from their opponents.

允许玩家影响其他玩家的游戏是一种有效的手段，即使在最普通的游戏中也能引入一些不确定性。它还迫使玩家采取少量策略，他们必须考虑准备应对攻击的方法或与其他玩家结盟的方法。集换式卡牌游戏是了解这些原则的最佳场所。

Allowing players to affect the play of other players is an effective means of introducing a bit of uncertainty even in the most mundane games. It also forces a minor amount of strategy on players who must consider preparing a counter to that attack or a means to ally with another player. Collectible card games are the best places to see examples of these principles in action.

打乱比赛顺序

MESS WITH THE PLAY ORDER

许多游戏都有固定的游戏顺序——例如，按逆时针方向轮流。考虑允许玩家打乱游戏中事件的顺序。例如，《万智牌：聚会》中的瞬间允许玩家在还未轮到自己时发起移动。棋盘游戏中的“重来”和“跳过一轮”等机制也很常见。

Many games have a set play order—take turns going counterclockwise, for example. Consider allowing players to mess with the sequence of events in your game. For instance, instants in Magic: the Gathering allow players to initiate a move even when it is not their turn. Mechanics such as “go again” and “skip a turn” in board games are also common.

像Fluxx这样的游戏非常擅长扰乱玩家顺序、规则以及游戏中的其他一切。

Games like Fluxx are excellent at messing with the player order, the rules, and everything else in the game.

打破规则

KILL A RULE

虽然这有时会让游戏设计师觉得是亵渎，但在原型阶段废除规则通常是一件好事。在这一点上，人们通常会制定太多规则来弥补他们对玩家和整个游戏的信任不足。“如果玩家不做某事怎么办？”一位设计师说。另一位回答说：“让我们添加一条规则让他们这样做。”不久之后，游戏规则就变得难以驾驭。确定游戏的核心，然后开始废除每一条不直接影响游戏核心的规则。（简单地说“它不起作用”没有任何意义。）

While this sometimes strikes the game’s designer as sacrilege, killing a rule is usually a good thing to do in the prototype stage. At this point, it’s common for people to have too many rules to make up for their lack of player trust and trust in the game as a whole. “What if the player doesn’t do X?” one designer says. Another answers, “Let’s add a rule to make them do it.” Before long, the rules of the game are unwieldy. Identify the core of the game and start by killing every rule that doesn’t directly affect the core of the game. (Simply saying “it doesn’t work” doesn’t mean anything.)

如果有些东西看起来不对劲，但你又不确定是什么，那就取游戏的一个值并将其乘以或除以二。进行如此大的改变可以让你深入了解游戏值如何相互作用以及它们对游戏的影响，而且你通常会意识到如果你进行较小的渐进式更改，你永远不会看到的事情。

If something seems off but you’re not sure what, take one of the game’s values and either multiply or divide it by two. Making such a drastic change gives you insight into how the game’s values interact with each other and what effects they have on play, and you’ll often realize things you never would have seen if you made smaller, incremental changes.

资源

RESOURCES

1   “游戏设计师的类型”，应用游戏设计，Brenda Brathwaite，2007 年 11 月 20 日。可在线访问 http://bbrathwaite.wordpress.com/2007/11/20/types-of-gamedesigners/。2008 年 5 月 18 日访问。

1  “Types of Game Designers,” Applied Game Design, Brenda Brathwaite, November 20, 2007. Available online at http://bbrathwaite.wordpress.com/2007/11/20/types-of-gamedesigners/. Accessed May 18, 2008.

2   IGDA 课程框架。可在线访问：http://www.igda.org/wiki/images/e/ee/Igda2008cf.pdf。2008 年 5 月 18 日访问。
