2  IGDA Curriculum Framework. Available online at http://www.igda.org/wiki/images/ e/ee/Igda2008cf.pdf. Accessed May 18, 2008.

3   MDA 框架，作者 LeBlanc 等人。可在线访问 http://www.cs.north-western. edu/~hunicke/MDA.pdf。访问日期：2008 年 5 月 20 日。

3  MDA Framework, by LeBlanc et al. Available online at http://www.cs.north-western. edu/~hunicke/MDA.pdf. Accessed May 20, 2008.



2：游戏设计原子

2: Game Design Atoms

 

 

化学家和物理学家花了几个世纪的时间试图识别最小的可识别物质以及它们如何相互作用。游戏设计是一个更年轻的领域，但设计师同样试图识别游戏中最小的可识别部分。每个部分都可以单独设计，了解这些部分是什么以及它们如何相互作用是设计或分析完整游戏的必要条件。游戏的这些部分，这些游戏设计的“原子”，就是本章的全部内容。

Chemists and physicists have spent centuries trying to identify the smallest identifiable pieces of matter and how they interact with one another. Game design is a much younger field, but designers have likewise attempted to identify the smallest identifiable parts of a game. Each part can be designed individually, and understanding what the parts are and how they interact is necessary to design or analyze a complete game. These parts of a game, these “atoms” of game design, are what this chapter is all about.

在设计游戏时，许多新手设计师都不知道从哪里开始。像《魔兽世界》这样的完整游戏非常庞大且内容丰富，因此从头开始设计整个游戏似乎是一项不可能完成的任务。即使是像《大富翁》这样相对简单的游戏，设计从哪里开始也不清楚：是从棋子、机会和社区宝箱卡、棋盘、规则还是其他东西开始？通过将游戏视为原子的集合，设计过程本身变得更加清晰。

When designing a game, many novice designers have no idea where to start. A complete game like World of Warcraft is so huge and expansive that designing the entire thing from scratch seems like an impossible task. Even for a relatively simple game like Monopoly, it’s not clear where the design begins: Does it start with the playing pieces, the Chance and Community Chest cards, the board, the rules, or something else? By looking at a game as a collection of atoms, the process of design itself becomes clearer.

需要提醒的是，在开发者和学者中，对“游戏”一词的定义有几十种，而关于游戏如何组合的想法则更多。以下是对游戏进行分类的一种方法，而不是方法本身。鼓励觉得这些讨论有趣的设计师扩展这些定义。

A word of warning—among developers and academics, there are dozens of definitions of the word “game” and still more ideas on how a game is put together. What follows is one way to categorize games, not the way. Designers who find these discussions interesting are encouraged to expand these definitions.

游戏状态和游戏视图

THE GAME STATE AND GAME VIEWS

要理解游戏，首先要了解游戏的总体情况。想象一下你最近玩过的一款游戏。考虑游戏中正在发生的一切，或者当有人轮流玩或离开暂停菜单时可能发生的变化。我们将这种状况称为游戏状态-游戏过程中可能发生变化的所有相关虚拟信息的集合。

To understand games, it’s useful to first take a look at the big picture. For a moment, imagine a game that you’ve recently played. Consider everything that’s going on in a game or may change if someone takes a turn or leaves the Pause menu. We call this picture the game state—a collection of all relevant virtual information that may change during play.

在国际象棋中，游戏状态由棋子列表、棋盘上棋子的位置以及基于先前走棋的某些信息组成（例如，哪些玩家有资格进行王车易位移动，哪些棋子容易被吃掉，以及现在轮到谁了）。

In Chess, the game state consists of a list of pieces, their positions on the board, and certain information based on previous moves (for example, which players are eligible to make a castling move, which pawns are vulnerable to en passant capture, and whose turn it is right now).

在扑克游戏中，游戏状态包括每个玩家的手牌和筹码、底池大小、轮到谁下注、当前手牌中谁弃牌、牌堆中有哪些牌以及牌的顺序等等。在视频游戏中，游戏状态可能极其复杂；例如，在最新的Madden游戏中，游戏状态包含有关整个游戏中每个玩家、每个可能的动作以及每个之前的动作的信息。

In Poker, the game state consists of each player’s hand and chips, the size of the pot, whose turn it is to bet, who has folded on the current hand, which cards are in the deck and in what order, and so on. In video games, the game state can be extremely complicated; in the latest Madden game, for example, the game state contains information about every player, every possible move, and every previous move in the entire game.

从前面的例子可以看出，玩家并不总是知道整个游戏状态。玩家可以看到的游戏状态部分，我们在这里将其称为游戏视图。在国际象棋中，游戏状态就是游戏视图，因为没有隐藏信息。在实时战略游戏 (RTS) 中，战争迷雾为每个玩家提供了自己不完整的游戏视图，仅显示他发现的土地或地形。在大型多人在线游戏 (MMO) 中，玩家不可能知道半个虚拟世界之外发生的事情。

From the previous examples, it’s clear that players are not always aware of the entire game state. The portions of the game state that a player can see, we will refer to here as the game view. In Chess, the game state is the game view, as there is no hidden information. In a real-time strategy game (RTS), the fog of war gives each player his own incomplete game view revealing only the land or terrain he has uncovered. In a massively multiplayer online game (MMO), the player can’t possibly know what’s going on half a virtual world away.

这最终导致了游戏空间，即游戏的整个区域。它可能是游戏的棋盘、巨大的 MMO 或第一人称射击游戏 (FPS) 战役中的单个关卡。在替代或增强现实游戏 (ARG) 中，它可能是玩家的城市、互联网、玩家的正常生活空间或整个世界。

This leads finally to the game space, the entire area of the game. It may be the board on which the game is played, an enormous MMO, or a single level in a first-person shooter (FPS) campaign. In an alternate or augmented reality game (ARG), it may be the player’s city, the Internet, the player’s normal living space, or the entire world.

玩家、角色和游戏片段

PLAYERS, AVATARS, AND GAME BITS

游戏空间可以很大也可以很小，但是没有玩家就不能称之为游戏。根据定义，所有游戏都有玩家，因为是玩家制定了游戏规则。在数字世界中，玩家通常由游戏角色代表。在非数字游戏中，玩家也有代表，但术语并不一致，且因游戏而异（“令牌”和“棋子”是游戏规则中常用的名称）。出于本书的目的，我们将把游戏世界中代表玩家的东西称为头像。这是玩家在游戏视图中标记自己位置的方式。在《大富翁》中，头像包括顶针、汽车和小狗。在《Trivial Pursuit》中，头像就是馅饼。在《国际象棋》中，头像就是国王（其他棋子用于保护国王）。在典型的第一人称射击游戏中，头像是一个士兵或屏幕上的枪的一部分。在许多 3D 视频游戏中，您可以看到您的角色探索世界的背影。

A game space can be as small or as large as it likes, but it wouldn’t be a game without players. By definition, all games have players since it’s the players who set the rules in motion. In digital worlds, the player is frequently represented in the game by an avatar. In non-digital games, the player is also represented, though the terminology is not consistent and varies from game to game (“token” and “pawn” are commonly used names that appear in game rules). For the sake of this book, we will refer to that thing which represents the player in the game world as an avatar. It’s how players mark their location in the game view. In Monopoly, the avatars include the thimble, the car, and the little dog. In Trivial Pursuit, it’s the pie. In Chess, it’s the king (the other pieces are there to protect the king). In the typical FPS, it’s a soldier or the portion of the gun on the screen. In many 3D video games, you watch the back of your avatar as he explores the world.

在某些游戏中，游戏空间中没有化身。相反，玩家代表他或她自己。《扑克》、《风险》和视频游戏《文明革命》都是如此。在后者中，小士兵和火炮正在保卫玩家 - 领导者。同样，大多数 RTS 视频游戏也没有化身。化身不同于棋盘游戏设计师非正式地称之为“游戏比特”，后者是玩游戏所需的物理物品。比特包括财产卡、骰子、《风险》中的塑料军队棋子、动作和法力卡，或《漂亮公主》中的珠宝碎片。在视频游戏中，我们在讨论图标、精灵和模型时经常将这些游戏比特称为“艺术资产”，在谈论它们在编程代码中的表示时称为“对象”。单独来看，它们可能有你熟悉的名称，例如 NPC、物品、怪物、敌人等等。

In some games, there is no avatar in the game space. Instead, the player represents him or herself. This is true of Poker, RISK, and the video game Civilization Revolution. In the latter, the little soldiers and artillery pieces are defending the player—the leader. Similarly, most RTS video games have no avatar. An avatar differs from what board-game designers informally call “game bits,” which are the physical items required to play the game. Bits include things like property cards, dice, the plastic army pieces in RISK, action and mana cards, or jewelry pieces as in Pretty Pretty Princess. In video games, we frequently refer to these game bits as “art assets” when discussing the icons, sprites, and models, and as “objects” when talking about their representation in the programming code. Individually, they are referred to by names you’re likely familiar with, such as NPCs, items, monsters, enemies, and so on.

所有化身和比特（以及玩家，在像Twister这样的体能灵活性游戏中 ）的当前状况是整个游戏空间中游戏状态的一部分。

The current condition of all avatars and bits (and players, in the case of physical-dexterity games like Twister) is part of the game state in the overall game space.

机制

MECHANICS

游戏空间之所以如此有趣，是因为游戏机制。“游戏机制”是其他人通常称之为“规则”的另一种说法。不过，在业内，“机制”一词很常见。机制就是某事物的运作方式。如果你做了 X，那么 Y 就会发生。如果 X 为真，那么你就可以做 Y。在《大富翁》中，如果你停在一处房产上，你就可以买下它。如果你掷出的数字较大，你就可以先走。每个都是一个简单的机制。

What really makes the game space a very interesting place to be are game mechanics. “Game mechanic” is another term for what others might commonly call a “rule.” Among those in the industry, though, the term “mechanic” is commonplace. Mechanics are how something works. If you do X, then Y happens. If X is true, then you can do Y. In Monopoly, if you land on a property, you can buy it. If you roll the higher number, you get to go first. Each is a simple mechanic.

对于游戏设计师来说，游戏机制是非常有趣的东西。想象一下厨师和香料，或者木匠和木头。机制会让每个游戏设计师问自己：“我能用它做什么？”机制就是可能性。对于许多设计师来说，这个创造过程本身就是一个游戏。

For game designers, gameplay mechanics are amazingly fun things. Think of a chef with a spice or a carpenter with a piece of wood. A mechanic makes every game designer ask, “What can I make with this?” A mechanic is all about possibility. For many designers, this process of creation is even a game unto itself.

换句话说，机制是作用于玩家、化身和游戏片段、游戏状态和游戏视图的规则，并描述改变游戏状态的所有方式。

Put another way, mechanics are the rules that act upon the players, avatars and game bits, game state and game views, and describe all of the ways to change the game state.

机制是游戏设计的要素。了解这些对于所有游戏设计师来说都至关重要。事实上，您甚至可以在 BoardGameGeek.com (http://www.boardgamegeek.com/browser.php?itemtype=game&sortby=mechanic) 上按机制搜索棋盘游戏。

Mechanics are the ingredients of game design. Having an understanding of these is critical for all game designers. In fact, you can even search board games by mechanics on BoardGameGeek.com (http://www.boardgamegeek.com/browser.php?itemtype=game&sortby=mechanic).

以下是游戏中常见的一些机制类别：

Here are some common classes of mechanics that are usually found in games:

·设置。必须始终至少有一条规则描述游戏如何开始。     

·      Setup. There must always be at least one rule that describes how the game begins.

·胜利条件。必须始终至少有一条规则来描述如何赢得游戏。有些游戏，如开放式角色扮演游戏 (RPG)，没有胜利条件。因此，有些设计师不认为它们是游戏。其他人认为实现特定目标就是胜利，因为他们会冲向下一个目标。     

·      Victory conditions. There must always be at least one rule that describes how the game is won. Some games, like open-ended role-playing games (RPGs), have no victory condition. As a result, some designers do not consider them games. Others consider the achievement of a specific goal a victory as they race off to the next goal.

·游戏进程。 谁先开始，怎么开始？游戏是回合制还是实时的？对于回合制游戏，游戏是从一名玩家开始，然后顺时针进行，还是玩家在拍卖中竞标资源以获得每轮先开始的权利，还是有其他方法？对于实时游戏，当两个玩家试图同时做某事时，如何解决？     

·      Progression of play. Who goes first, and how? Is the game turn based or real time? For turn-based games, does the game start with one player and then proceed clockwise, or do players bid resources in an auction for the right to go first each round, or is there some other method? For real-time games, when two players try to do something at the same time, how is that resolved?

·玩家动作。有时被称为“动词”，一些最重要的机制描述了玩家可以做什么以及这些动作对游戏状态有什么影响。     

·      Player actions. Sometimes referred to as “verbs,” some of the most important mechanics describe what players can do and what effect those actions have on the game state.

·游戏视角的定义。 机制精确定义了每个玩家在特定时间知道的信息。请注意，某些机制可能会改变视角，例如在特定条件下部分消除 RTS 中的战争迷雾。     

·      Definition of game view(s). Mechanics define exactly what information each player knows at any given time. Note that some mechanics may change the view, such as partially lifting fog of war in an RTS under certain conditions.

一些机制组合也比其他机制组合更容易让人掌握。例如，在棋盘游戏《苏格兰场》中，X 先生在伦敦四处游荡，试图躲避追捕。他每三回合才露面一次，但除此之外一直隐藏着。这款游戏完全基于策略。因此，人们玩起来并不像说“对不起！”那么容易。在第 5-9 章中，我们充分探讨了策略和机制中的运气概念。

Some mechanic combinations are also easier for people to grasp than others. For instance, in the board game Scotland Yard, Mr. X roams around London trying to evade capture. He only surfaces every three turns, but otherwise remains hidden. The game is based purely on strategy. As such, it’s not as easy for people to play as, say, Sorry!. In Chapters 5–9, the concept of strategy and luck in mechanics is examined fully.

动力学

DYNAMICS

“游戏动态”是指玩家启动游戏机制后产生的游戏模式。例如，在本书中，我们提到了一些非常常见的动态，如“奔向终点”和“领土获取”。领土获取本身只是更大动态集合的一种形式（默认情况下，也是留存）。

A “game dynamic” is the pattern of play that comes from the mechanics once they’re set in motion by players. For instance, throughout this book, some very common dynamics are referenced, such as “race to the end” and “territorial acquisition.” Territorial acquisition is itself just a form of a larger dynamic collection (and, by default, retention).

以下游戏涉及领土获取以及其他动态：

The following games involve territorial acquisition, among other dynamics:

·文明     

·      Civilization

·星际争霸     

·      Starcraft

·风险     

·      RISK

·轴心国与同盟国     

·      Axis & Allies

·外交     

·      Diplomacy

·去     

·      Go

所有这些游戏都是以竞速到底为基础的：

All of these games are based on race to the end:

·马里奥赛车     

·      Mario Kart

·糖果乐园     

·      Candyland

·生命的游戏     

·      The Game of Life

·滑梯和梯子      

·      Chutes & Ladders

虽然这些游戏具有相同的动态，但实现该动态的机制在不同游戏中却有所不同。

Though these games share the same dynamic, the mechanics used to achieve that dynamic are different from game to game.

请注意，动态是游戏体验的一部分，但并非所有动态都由机制明确定义或强制执行 - 例如，在游戏状态之外发生的玩家之间的互动（通常称为“元游戏”）。元游戏动态的一些示例包括玩家谈判、讨论、联盟、在线聊天和垃圾话。

Notice that the dynamics are part of the play experience, but not all are explicitly defined or enforced by the mechanics—for example, interactions that take place between players outside of the game state (commonly referred to as the “metagame”). Some examples of metagame dynamics are player negotiations, discussion, alliances, online chat, and trash talking.

目标

GOALS

在所有事物之上的是游戏目标。当然，最终的游戏目标就是胜利条件。有时，游戏中的目标被称为“任务”或“探索”。

Layered on top of all things are game goals. The ultimate game goal is, of course, the victory condition. Sometimes, goals in games are called “missions” or “quests.”

目标通常会提供奖励，激励玩家击败怪物、寻找宝藏、装备越来越好的盔甲并与好友竞争。在 FPS 中，目标通常是击败敌人、夺取旗帜或营救人质。在Bohnanza中，目标是赚取最多的金币。

Goals typically provide rewards that motivate players to defeat creatures, search for treasure, equip themselves with better and better armor, and compete against their friends. In FPSs, the goal is often to defeat the enemy, capture the flag, or rescue the hostage. In Bohnanza the goal is to earn the most gold.

主题

THEME

Bohnanza是一款关于豆类种植的游戏。Super Mario Bros.是一款关于水管工在蘑菇王国搜寻以拯救公主的游戏。Katamari Damacy是一款关于王子必须创造天空中被宇宙之王意外摧毁的星星的游戏。这并不适用于所有游戏；俄罗斯方块不涉及任何事情。

Bohnanza is a game about bean farming. Super Mario Bros. is a game about a plumber searching through the Mushroom Kingdom to save a princess. Katamari Damacy is a game about a prince who must create the stars in the sky that were accidentally destroyed by the King of All Cosmos. This does not apply to all games; Tetris isn’t about anything.

这些信息对于游戏玩法来说都不是必需的。线索可能只是关于寻找丢失的手套或灵魂伴侣，两者的机制完全相同。同时，追捕凶手也让游戏更具吸引力。

None of this information is strictly necessary to the gameplay. Clue could just as easily be about finding a lost mitten or your soul mate with exactly the same mechanics. At the same time, something about hunting down a murderer makes the game more appealing.

游戏“关于”什么的概念有很多名字。它可以被称为主题、色彩、故事或叙事，以及其他术语。在本书中，我们将使用“主题”一词来描述游戏的这一方面，它超出了机制的范围，但如果选择得当，可以让机制感觉更自然。

This concept of what the game is “about” goes by many names. It can be referred to as theme, color, story or narrative, among other terms. Throughout this book, we will use the term “theme” to describe this aspect of games that lies outside of the mechanics and yet somehow, when chosen well, can make the mechanics feel more natural.

什么是最重要的？

WHAT COMES FIRST?

游戏状态、角色、机制、动态、主题……设计师从哪里开始？对于游戏开发者来说，可以按任何顺序进行。假设你想制作一款基于资源收集的游戏。如果动态已经确定，那么问题就变成了机制。究竟如何收集资源？还有主题的问题。收集什么，玩家收集它们的动机是什么？设计师可能会从主题开始。棋盘游戏Redneck Life 的 主题非常丰富，设计师很可能先创建主题，然后再找到合适的游戏。

Game state, avatars, mechanics, dynamics, theme... where does a designer begin? For game developers, it can go in just about any order. Let’s say you want to make a game based on resource collection. If the dynamics are decided, the question now becomes one of mechanics. How exactly does one go about collecting resources? There’s also the question of theme. What is being collected, and what is the player’s motivation for collecting them? A designer might start with a theme. The board game Redneck Life  is so heavily themed that it’s likely the designer created the theme first, and then found a game to fit.

单个机制也可以作为游戏的基础。以《块魂》为例，滚动物体并拾起它们的机制构成了整个游戏其余部分的基础，它可能是最先设计的。同样，无数 FPS 都是从射击机制开始，然后从那里开始分层。

An individual mechanic can also be used as the basis for a game. In the case of Katamari Damacy, the mechanic of rolling over objects and picking them up forms the basis for the entire rest of the game, and it was probably designed first. Likewise, countless FPSs start with the mechanic of shooting and layer from there.

综合起来

PUTTING IT ALL TOGETHER

举个例子，假设你正在设计一款实体卡牌游戏，主题是汽车生产。理想的动态是比赛到最后，并要求玩家先完成汽车的制造。可以让我们做到这一点的机制是：

As an example, let’s say you’re designing a physical card game and the theme is automobile production. The desired dynamic is race to the end and requires the player to finish building a car first. The mechanics that might let us do this are:

·抽一张牌     

·      Draw a card

·打出一张牌（放置或丢弃）     

·      Play a card (either place it or discard it)

游戏内容如下：

The game bits would be:

·卡片（拍一张汽车的照片，将汽车切成 10 块，每块都有汽车的一部分，需要 10 块才能拼成一辆完整的汽车）     

·      Cards (take a picture of a car and cut the car into 10 pieces so each piece has a part of the car on it, and it takes 10 pieces to build a complete car)

·      玩家代表他自己，因此不需要头像。 

·      The player represents himself, so an avatar won’t be necessary. 

就其本身而言，目前它还算不上一款游戏。事实上，目前大多数游戏都算不上。关键是要获得一款基本的游戏，然后通过添加策略或机会元素，或通过添加或删除机制来增强游戏性，让玩家对它更感兴趣。虽然这在第 14 章“添加和删除机制”中进行了全面介绍，但为了便于说明，我们可以根据需要为以下每一项添加机制和游戏元素：

By itself, it’s not much of a game at this point. In fact, at this point, most games aren’t. The point is to get a basic game, and then make it more interesting to the player through the addition of elements of strategy or chance, or by adding or removing mechanics to strengthen the game. While this is covered fully in Chapter 14, “Adding and Subtracting Mechanics,” for the sake of illustration, we could add mechanics and game bits, if necessary, for each of the following:

·生产流水线     

·      A production pipeline

·生产定价将迫使玩家分配工人、零件等，以确定最佳产量     

·      Production pricing that would force players to allocate workers, parts, and the like, to determine optimum output

·破坏，这样一来，一个玩家就可能影响另一个玩家的生产流水线     

·      Sabotage, so that one player could affect another’s production pipeline

·随机卡牌会通过导致生产中断、价格下降、有利宣传等方式将运气引入方程式     

·      Random cards that introduce luck into the equation by causing production breakdowns, price drops, favorable publicity, and so on

根据卡牌和所需策略，这款游戏可能会变得很有趣。对于许多设计师来说，制作游戏不仅能让他们保持敏锐，还能让他们从中享受到很多乐趣。

Depending on the cards and on the strategy required, this game could evolve into something fun. For many designers, creating games not only keeps them sharp, but allows them to have a whole lot of fun in the process.

学会尝试并从你的设计和设计过程中获得乐趣。记住你可以制作任何主题的游戏。一开始对这个过程感到害怕是正常的。讽刺的是，一些游戏玩家更喜欢在数字编辑器中制作 FPS 关卡，而不是制作棋盘游戏。然而，这两种媒介拥有完全相同的构建块。

Learn to experiment and take joy in your designs and in the process of design. Remember that you can make a game about anything. It’s normal to feel intimidated by the process at first. Ironically, some game players are more comfortable making FPS levels in a digital editor than they are making board games. However, the two mediums possess the exact same building blocks.

设计一款游戏并沉迷其中。

Design a game and be hooked.

挑战

CHALLENGES

本章中的挑战难度逐渐增加，旨在让您熟悉非数字格式的游戏设计过程。在其余章节中，我们将在此基础上继续发展。变体为您提供了进一步实施每个建议设计的机会。

The challenges in this chapter grow progressively more difficult and are designed to get you comfortable with the process of game design in a non-digital format. In the remaining chapters, we build upon the foundation started here. Variants offer you a chance to take each suggested design further.

挑战 1——路径

CHALLENGE 1—THE PATH

对于这款游戏，您将探索前面讨论过的“奔向终点”游戏玩法动态。游戏应允许 2 到 4 名玩家，沿着一条路径前进，并让他们从 A 点走到 B 点。最先到达 B 点的玩家获胜。

For this game, you are going to explore the race to the end gameplay dynamic discussed earlier. The game should allow two to four players, be about progressing on a path, and make them go from point A to point B. The first player to point B wins.

作为游戏设计师，您需要确定主题、游戏元素和机制。

As the game’s designer, it’s up to you to figure out the theme, the game bits, and the mechanics.

所需组件

Components Required

·制作原型的材料     

·      Materials to create prototype

可交付成果

Deliverable

·棋盘游戏原型或     

·      Board-game prototype or

·纸牌游戏原型或     

·      Card-game prototype or

·基于图块的游戏原型或     

·      Tile-based–game prototype or

·用一页纸详细描述潜在的游戏设计     

·      One-page write-up of detailing a potential game design

建议流程

Suggested Process

1.            确定主题和目标。玩家要去哪里，为什么要去那里？选择一个涉及参与者之间互动的主题，让事情变得有趣。

1.            Determine a theme and a goal. Where are the players going, and why are they going there? Choose a theme that involves some interaction between the participants, to make things interesting.

2.            确定机制。从简单开始。设想一条从头到尾的赛道，分成许多不同的部分。它可能是 100 个空间、瓷砖或卡片，最终构成玩家将要“比赛”的赛道。现在想想能让玩家在赛道上移动的机制。最简单的一个就是掷骰子。接下来考虑一下你可以做些什么来让游戏更有趣。例如，你可以有一个动作来加快你的速度或减慢你的对手的速度。叙述是否暗示了任何明显的机制？例如，如果你的游戏是关于接力赛跑的，你需要一种传递接力棒的方式（也许暗示了一种权衡，即保持更高的跑步速度会增加意外掉落接力棒的几率）。为了在赛跑中增加一些玩家互动，也许你可以改变主题，让赛车手成为可以互相射击的激光机器人，这暗示了射击和躲避的机制。

2.            Identify mechanics. Start simple. Visualize a track that goes from beginning to end that’s broken up into a bunch of different sections. It may be 100 spaces or tiles or cards that ultimately build the track on which your players are going to “race.” Now think of the mechanic that will get your players moving on that track. The simplest one is rolling a die. Next consider things you could do to make play more interesting. For instance, you could have an action that speeds you up or slows your opponent down. Does the narrative suggest any obvious mechanics? For example, if your game is about a relay foot race, you’ll need a way to pass the baton (perhaps suggesting a tradeoff where maintaining a higher running speed gives a higher chance of accidentally dropping the baton). To add some player interaction in a foot race, perhaps you’d change the theme so that the racers are robots with lasers that can shoot at one another, which suggests mechanics for shooting and dodging.

3.            确定玩家之间的冲突。你如何才能破坏别人的进程或加速自己的进程？权​​衡是什么？

3.            Identify the conflict between players. How can you screw up someone else’s progress or accelerate yours? What’s the tradeoff?

4.            游戏测试。每次你给游戏添加一个机制时，都要测试它。它会让游戏变得更有趣还是更无趣？它是否支持游戏的核心？它是否按照你最初的想法运行？

4.            Playtest. Every time you add a mechanic to the game, test it. Does it make the game more fun or less fun? Does it support the core of the game? Does it work the way you originally thought it would?

5.            创建可交付成果。

5.            Create deliverable.

变体

Variants

尝试再次完成该过程并设计不同的游戏。这一次，从机制开始（上面的第 2 步），然后找出合适的主题（上面的第 1 步）。请注意，这两种方式都可以让您设计出一款完美的游戏，但所涉及的思维过程却截然不同。

Try going through the process again and design a different game. This time, start with the mechanics (step 2 above) and then figure out a fitting theme (step 1 above). Notice that both ways can let you design a perfectly good game, but the thought process involved is quite different.

挑战 2——这是我的！

CHALLENGE 2—IT’S MINE!

对于这个挑战，你将探索领土获取的动态。如果你还没有注意到，这种动态存在于当今绝大多数棋盘游戏中。与前面的例子一样，这个游戏应该允许两到四名玩家。游戏显然必须有某种将被获取的领土。你可以从以下两个获胜条件中选择一个：

For this challenge, you’ll be exploring the dynamic of territorial acquisition. If you haven’t noticed already, this dynamic is present in the great majority of board games made today. As in the previous example, this game should allow two to four players. The game must obviously have some kind of territory which will be acquired. You may select from one of two win conditions:

·第一个占领所有领地的玩家获胜。     

·      The first player to get all the territory wins.

· X 回合后拥有最多领土的玩家获胜。     

·      The player with the most territory after X turns wins.

作为游戏设计师，您需要确定主题、必要的游戏元素和机制。

As the game’s designer, it’s up to you to figure out the theme, the necessary game bits and the mechanics.

所需组件

Components Required

·制作原型的材料     

·      Materials to create prototype

可交付成果

Deliverable

·棋盘游戏原型或      

·      Board-game prototype or

·纸牌游戏原型或     

·      Card-game prototype or

·基于图块的游戏原型     

·      Tile-based–game prototype

建议流程

Suggested Process

1.如果需要，请确定主题。玩家究竟想征服什么？沼泽？一块草地？也许是一群野猴子，它们决心在晚上占领动物园。请记住，您不需要主题，但有一个主题通常可以帮助刚接触该过程的游戏设计师识别潜在的机制。   

1.    Determine a theme, if you desire. Precisely what are the players trying to conquer here? A swamp? A piece of turf? Maybe it’s a wild band of monkeys who are determined to take over the zoo at night. Remember that you don’t need a theme, but having one often helps game designers new to the process identify potential mechanics.

2.继续使用与挑战 1 中相同的流程。   

2.    Continue using the same process as in Challenge 1.

挑战 3 — 当我找到你时...

CHALLENGE 3—WHEN I FIND YOU...

我们在本章中讨论了两种常见的游戏动态：占领领土和奔向终点。然而，这只是一系列动态中的两种。其他常见的动态包括建造、探索和践踏眼前的一切。

We’ve talked about two common gameplay dynamics in this chapter: territorial acquisition and race to the end. These are just two of a whole collection of dynamics, however. Other common dynamics include building, exploration, and stomping everything in sight.

在本练习中，你将重点关注探索动态。首先，考虑如何在 MMO、冒险游戏和 RPG 中使用这种动态。在某些冒险游戏中，“探索每个地点”动态是整个游戏的重点。考虑如何在诸如Clue之类的棋盘游戏中使用它。

For this exercise, you will focus on the exploration dynamic. First, consider how it is used in MMOs, adventure games, and RPGs. In some adventure games, the “explore every location” dynamic is the whole of play. Consider how it is used in board games such as Clue.

你的任务是创建一个可供 2 到 4 人玩的游戏。由于游戏涉及探索，因此需要某种空间来探索，即使该空间不是物理空间。你可以将这种动态与另一种动态结合使用。

You are tasked with creating a game that two to four individuals can play. Since the game involves exploration, it needs some kind of space to explore, even if that space isn’t a physical one. You may use this dynamic in conjunction with another.

您将自行确定此练习的主题、机制、组件和附加动态（如果有）。

It will be up to you to determine the theme, mechanics, components, and additional dynamics, if any, for this exercise.

所需组件

Components Required

·制作原型的材料     

·      Materials to create prototype

可交付成果

Deliverable

·棋盘游戏原型或      

·      Board-game prototype or

·纸牌游戏原型或     

·      Card-game prototype or

·基于图块的游戏原型     

·      Tile-based–game prototype

建议流程

Suggested Process

1.如果需要，请确定一个主题。玩家在探索什么？从停车场到树顶村庄，从芝加哥市中心到天空中的奇幻世界，任何东西都可以。想想你的玩家在探索时可能会做的事情。这些动态将产生你需要的机制。   

1.    Determine a theme, if you desire. What are the players exploring? Anything from a parking garage to a treetop village to downtown Chicago to a fantastical world in the sky are up for grabs. Think of things your player might do while exploring, too. These dynamics will give rise to the mechanics you need.

2.继续使用与挑战 1 中相同的流程。   

2.    Continue using the same process as in Challenge 1.

挑战 4 — 捡起来

CHALLENGE 4—PICK IT UP

走过一个物体来捡起它是电子游戏中一种非常常见的机制，并导致了收集动态。当然，还有其他方法来收集东西。想想在马里奥游戏、扑克或宝石迷阵中收集是如何发挥作用的。

Walking over an object to pick it up is a phenomenally common mechanic in video games, and leads to the collection dynamic. There are, of course, other ways to collect something. Consider how collecting comes into play in the Mario games, Poker, or Bejeweled.

在本练习中，你将采用此机制并利用它制作游戏。这比从动态开始略有挑战性，因为动态本身既暗示了开始，也暗示了结束。

For this exercise, you’re going to take this mechanic and make a game out of it. This is slightly more challenging than starting with a dynamic, which, by itself, suggests both a beginning and an ending.

您必须创建一款 2 到 4 名玩家的游戏，玩家可以“走过”物体并拾起它们。玩家需要收集什么（三种、类似颜色等等）以及需要收集多少由您决定。修改主要机制的机制是可以接受的。例如，您可以让玩家在落到某物上时拾起它，或者让玩家先获得一辆手推车才能拾起物体。

You must create a game for two to four players in which players “walk” over objects and pick them up. What players need to collect (three of a kind, similar color, and so on) and how much they need to collect is up to you. Mechanics that modify the primary mechanic are acceptable. For instance, you could have players pick something up when they land on it, or have a wheelbarrow that they first must acquire in order to pick up the objects.

您必须选择主题、组件和代币（如果适用）。您还可以根据需要添加其他机制。特别要注意叙事。这会帮助您集思广益。将其想象成一个园艺游戏，然后是一个黑帮游戏，然后是一个赛车游戏。每个主题都会带来不同的可能性。

You must choose the theme, components, and tokens, if applicable. You may also add additional mechanics, as needed. In particular, play attention to the narrative. It will help as you brainstorm. Think of this as a gardening game, then a gangster game, and then a car-racing game. Each theme brings different possibilities into play.

所需组件

Components Required

·制作原型的材料     

·      Materials to create prototype

可交付成果

Deliverable

·棋盘游戏原型或      

·      Board-game prototype or

·纸牌游戏原型或     

·      Card-game prototype or

·基于图块的游戏原型     

·      Tile-based–game prototype

建议流程

Suggested Process

1.游戏的目标是...如果您想不出如何开始，一种方法是先说出结束游戏的目标或目的。这将为您提示额外的机制和动态。例如，如果游戏的目标是在时间耗尽时获得最高分，它会立即给您两个问题：玩家如何获得分数，游戏中如何处理时间？对象可能与主题相关，因此您可能会发现同时开发叙事和目标更容易，或者先从主题开始，然后再找到目标。例如，如果您是从银行抢劫案归来的歹徒，也许目标是为自己保留尽可能多的钱并在警察出现之前离开。   

1.    The object of the game is... If you can’t think of how to begin, one way is to start by naming the goal or objective that ends the game. This will suggest additional mechanics and dynamics for you. For example, if the object of the game is to have the most points when time runs out, it immediately gives you two more questions: how do players receive points, and how is time handled in the game? The object may be connected to a theme, so you may find it easier to develop a narrative and objective concurrently, or start with the theme first and then find the objective. For example, if you are gangsters returning from a bank heist, maybe the object is to keep as much money for yourself and get out before the cops show up.

2.确定机制和动态。从主题和目标来看，你可能已经想出了各种游戏机制和动态来支持核心拾取动作。如果你什么也想不出来，那就想出一个新的主题和目标，然后再试一次。   

2.    Identify mechanics and dynamics. From the theme and goal, you probably already have all kinds of ideas for mechanics and dynamics in the game to support the core pick-up action. If nothing occurs to you, come up with a new theme and goal and try again.

3.识别玩家之间的冲突。   

3.    Identify the conflict between players.

4.游戏测试。   

4.    Playtest.

5.创建可交付成果。   

5.    Create deliverable.

变体：

Variants:

想想电子游戏中另一种常见的机制，例如射击目标、避免与敌人碰撞或升级角色。使用此机制重复此挑战，而不是拾取。

Think of another common mechanic in video games, such as shooting targets, avoiding collision with enemies, or leveling up a character. Repeat this challenge using this mechanic instead of picking up.

铁人设计师挑战 5 — 无国界战争

IRON DESIGNER CHALLENGE 5—WAR WITHOUT FRONTIERS

在以领土获取动态为特色的游戏中，尤其是在战争主题游戏中，领土很少通过滑稽的赛跑来获取。它们通常是通过另一个玩家的死亡（无论多么抽象）来获取的。死亡的结果是，玩家获得另一个玩家的领土。拥有领土的人赢得战争。另一种常见的动态是“摧毁对方”，用于没有领土的游戏。

In games featuring the territorial acquisition dynamic, and especially in war-themed games, territories are rarely acquired through a comical foot race. They’re usually acquired through the death, regardless of how abstracted, of another player’s bits. As a result of that death, the player gets the other player’s territory. Whoever has the territory wins the war. Another common dynamic, “destroy the opposing side,” is used for games that don’t have territory.

然而，在本次练习中，您将突破这些传统界限。模拟并解决内战战斗，而不使用占领领土或摧毁敌方所有单位作为主要游戏动态。

For this exercise, however, you’ll be pushing yourself beyond those traditional borders. Simulate and resolve a Civil War battle without using territorial acquisition or destruction of all units on the enemy side as the primary gameplay dynamic.

分成 2 到 4 人的小队。每队应尽力设计一款符合上述限制的游戏。如果想增加挑战性，可以让每队选择其他队伍不允许使用的额外机制或动态。

Split into teams of two to four players. Each team should do its best to come up with a game that fits the above constraints. For a greater challenge, have each team choose an additional mechanic or dynamic that the other team is not allowed to use.

所需组件

Components Required

·制作原型的材料      

·      Materials to create prototype

可交付成果

Deliverable

·棋盘游戏原型或      

·      Board-game prototype or

·纸牌游戏原型或     

·      Card-game prototype or

·基于图块的游戏原型     

·      Tile-based–game prototype

建议流程

Suggested Process

1.确定主题。你的游戏模拟哪场战斗？       

1.        Determine a theme. Which battle does your game simulate?

2.确定机制。如果不占领领土，拥有领土是否有意义？也许有意义，也许没有意义。考虑一下玩家除了占领领土之外还能如何赢得战斗。如果不是占领领土，那么目标是什么？玩家可以执行哪些机制来实现该目标？       

2.        Identify mechanics. Without territorial acquisition, does it make sense to even have territory? It might, or it might not. Consider how a player can win a battle other than claiming territory. What is the goal, if not territory? What kinds of mechanics can players perform to achieve that goal?

3.识别玩家之间的冲突。       

3.        Identify the conflict between players.

4.游戏测试。每次你给游戏添加一个机制时，都要进行测试。       

4.        Playtest. Every time you add a mechanic to the game, test it.

5.创建可交付成果。       

5.        Create deliverable.

变体

Variants

不要选择内战，而是选择其他冲突。第一次和第二次世界大战是显而易见的选择。您也可以使用其他冲突，例如公司收购、邻居争斗或竞争的连锁店。

Instead of the Civil War, choose a different conflict. World Wars I and II are obvious choices. You could also use other conflicts like corporate acquisition, feuding neighbors, or competing chain stores.

资源​

RESOURCES

我无话可说，但我必须设计，Greg Costikyan，www.costik.com/nowords.html。

I Have No Words, and I Must Design, Greg Costikyan, www.costik.com/nowords.html.

正式抽象设计工具，Doug Church，http://www.gamasutra.com/features/19990716/design_tools_01.htm。

Formal Abstract Design Tools, Doug Church, http://www.gamasutra.com/features/ 19990716/design_tools_01.htm.

 

 


3：谜题设计

3: Puzzle Design

 

 

谜题到底是什么？这个词经常被滥用，尤其是在游戏中。以《俄罗斯方块》 和《宝石迷阵》为代表的所谓“益智游戏”类型并不涉及太多的解谜方式，尤其是与填字游戏或数独等有实际和游戏结束解决方案的游戏相比。与此同时，被称为“谜题”的挑战似乎进入了各种各样的数字游戏，如《Zork》、 《塞尔达传说》 、《MYST》、《最终幻想》和《猴岛》系列。考虑一下这个“谜题”中常见的视频游戏模式：“找到物体 X 并将其放在位置 Y。”

Exactly what is a puzzle? The word is often overused, particularly in games. The so-called “puzzle game” genre, as exemplified by Tetris and Bejeweled, does not involve much in the way of puzzle solving, particularly when compared to games with an actual and game-ending solution like a crossword puzzle or Sudoku puzzle. Meanwhile, challenges referred to as “puzzles” seem to find their way into digital games as varied as the Zork, Zelda, MYST, Final Fantasy, and Monkey Island series. Consider the common video-game pattern in this “puzzle”: “find object X and put it in location Y.”

被称为“迷你游戏”的谜题也很常见。这些游戏提供简短的插曲或挑战，需要在更大的游戏背景下解决。许多视频游戏使用迷你游戏来打开锁，让玩家进入关卡的下一节。

Also common are the puzzles referred to as “mini-games.” These games offer brief interludes or challenges to be solved within the context of the larger game. Many video games use mini-games to open locks that allow the player to access the next section of the level.

Dictionary.com 为“拼图”一词提供了不少于 12 种不同的定义，其中只有一个似乎与游戏有关：“1.一种玩具、问题或其他装置，通过提出需要通过聪明才智或耐心努力来解决的难题来娱乐大众。” 2

Dictionary.com provides no fewer than 12 different definitions for the word “puzzle,” only one of which seems relevant to games: “1.a toy, problem, or other contrivance designed to amuse by presenting difficulties to be solved by ingenuity or patient effort.”2

就本书而言，为了反映该词在电子游戏行业的用法，谜题被非常广泛地定义为非战斗事件或一系列事件，需要玩家完成一项任务或一项行动或一系列任务或行动才能继续游戏。完成这些谜题可能是可选的，也可能是必需的。

For the purposes of this book and mirroring the use of the word in the video-game industry, a puzzle is very broadly defined as a noncombat event or series of events that requires the player to complete a task or an action or some series of tasks or actions in order to progress play. Completing these puzzles may be optional or required.

不幸的是，对于玩家来说，谜题和停车标志有时并没有什么区别。在本章中，我们将探讨如何以及何时设计谜题并将其纳入大型游戏的一部分。

Unfortunately, as far as a player is concerned, there is sometimes no difference between a puzzle and a stop sign. In this chapter, we’ll explore how and when to design puzzles and incorporate them as part of a larger game.

基本拼图特征

BASIC PUZZLE CHARACTERISTICS

设计一种新型谜题与设计游戏类似。谜题有“状态”（类似于游戏状态）、改变状态的机制以及作为胜利条件的目标状态。一旦决定了机制，设计师就会对其进行调整以产生不同的动态。通常还有一个主题。例如，在游戏《生化奇兵》中，有一个“黑客”迷你游戏，玩家可以解决该游戏以解锁门并控制电子物体。这里的主题是计算机黑客，机制包括旋转管道以在电路板的输入和输出之间形成一条路径。可以在 http://guides.gamepressure.com/bioshock/guide.asp?ID=3348 找到黑客迷你游戏的屏幕截图和内部工作原理的详细描述。

Designing a new kind of puzzle is similar to designing a game. There’s the “state” of the puzzle (similar to a game state), mechanics for changing the state, and a goal state that is the victory condition. Once the mechanics are decided, the designer tweaks them to come up with different dynamics. There is also usually a theme. In the game BioShock, for instance, there is a “hacking” mini-game that the player can solve to unlock doors and take control of electronic objects. The theme here is computer hacking, and the mechanics involve rotating pipes to form a path between the input and output of a board. A screenshot and in-depth description of the inner workings of the hacking mini-game can be found at http://guides.gamepressure.com/bioshock/guide.asp?ID=3348.

在设计谜题或小游戏的规则时，需要具备以下特征：

When designing the rules for a puzzle or mini-game, the following traits are necessary:

·可供性：应该很容易弄清楚规则和控制。     

·      Affordances: It should be easy to figure out the rules and controls.

·可识别的图案：谜题中的图案应该清晰，以便玩家能够识别出解决游戏所需的一系列可能性。颜色和形状是常用的，其他形式的预先存在的知识也是如此，例如单词的拼写或常见物体的功能。     

·      Identifiable patterns: Patterns within the puzzle should be clear so that players are able to identify a series of possibilities required for the game to be solved. Colors and shapes are commonly used, as are other forms of pre-existing knowledge like the spelling of words or the function of common objects.

·易于使用：良好的用户界面（UI）。     

·      Ease of use: Good user interface (UI).

·奖励玩家技能： 如果玩家多次遇到同一个谜题，玩家应该能够提高自己的技能。     

·      Reward player skill: If a player is encountering the puzzle many times, the player should be able to improve his or her skill.

在设计适合大型游戏的谜题或小游戏规则时，以下附加特征通常会使谜题对玩家更有趣：

When designing the rules for a puzzle or mini-game that fits in a larger game, the following additional traits generally cause the puzzle to be more interesting to the players:

·沉浸感：主游戏和迷你游戏之间的平滑过渡（这主要由艺术家负责，确保迷你游戏界面与游戏其他部分采用相同的视觉风格，但设计师必须考虑与故事和世界的契合度）。     

·      Immersion: Smooth transition between the main game and mini-game (this mostly falls to the artists making sure that the mini-game interface is done in the same visual style as the rest of the game, but the designer must consider the fit with the story and world).

·游戏中除迷你游戏之外的有意义的后果：不仅仅是“你打开了一扇门”，而且“你得到了很酷的物品”。     

·      Meaningful consequences in the game, outside of the mini-game: Not just “you unlock a door” but “you get cool items.”

是什么让拼图变得有趣？

WHAT MAKES PUZZLES FUN?

如果游戏设计师的目标是让游戏变得有趣，那么在游戏中加入谜题只是为了让游戏更有趣，也就是支持游戏的核心。在某些游戏中，谜题根本不合适。在其他游戏中，设计师只能设计某些类型的谜题。例如，大多数类型的谜题（尤其是逻辑谜题和谜语）在快节奏的动作射击游戏中可能会显得格格不入。即使在“益智游戏”中，设计师也主要局限于空间谜题。暂停俄罗斯方块游戏以要求玩家回答谜语或探索地图以寻找物品会偏离游戏的核心。

If the game designer’s goal is to make a game fun, then the inclusion of puzzles in a game should only be done to make the game more fun—that is, to support the core of the game. In some games, puzzles are not appropriate at all. In other games, the designer is limited to certain kinds of puzzles. For example, most kinds of puzzles (especially logic puzzles and riddles) would likely feel out of place in a fast-paced action shooting game. Even in a “puzzle game,” the designer is limited primarily to spatial puzzles. Pausing a game of Tetris to require the player to answer a riddle or explore a map to find an item would take away from the core of the game.

一般来说，谜题是玩家的直接障碍，阻止他们达成目标，除非他们解开谜题。谜题的乐趣通常来自胜利的快感、解决难题的成就感，以及在这些时刻之前逐渐掌握的感觉。最好的情况是，一个好的谜题会让玩家对自己能完成的事情感到自豪。

In general, puzzles are a direct obstacle to players, preventing them from reaching a goal until they solve the puzzle. The fun in a puzzle generally comes from the thrill of victory, the sense of achievement of solving a difficult puzzle, and the gradual sense of mastery that precedes those moments. At best, a good puzzle makes players feel great about themselves for what they can accomplish.

如果谜题设计得不好，它就会减少或消除游戏其余部分的乐趣，就像交通堵塞会毁掉一次不错的驾驶体验一样。玩家无法解决的谜题会阻碍他们进一步体验游戏，并给他们带来更大的挫败感，而玩家认为随意或不公平的谜题会让他们讨厌游戏（及其设计师）。

Done poorly, puzzles can reduce or eliminate the fun in the rest of the game just like a traffic jam can ruin a decent drive. A puzzle that players can’t solve prevents them from experiencing the game further and causes them even greater frustration, and a puzzle that players see as arbitrary or unfair causes them to hate the game (and its designer).

谜题类型

PUZZLE TYPES

谜题种类繁多。幸运的是，谜题可以分为几大类，每类谜题都有一些共同的设计实践。

There are many different puzzles. Luckily, they can be classified into general categories, where each category of puzzles shares certain design practices.

谜语

RIDDLES

“我的尖齿很长 / 我的尖齿很短 / 我的尖齿在第一次报告之前就结束了。/ 我是谁？”（来自Beyond Zork 的谜语）

“My tines be long / My tines be short / My tines end ere my first report. / What am I?” (Riddle from Beyond Zork)

谜语是只有一个正确答案的问题，但答案并不明显。通常，谜语涉及文字游戏，需要玩家以非标准方式解释它才能解决它。

Riddles are questions that have one right answer, but that answer is not obvious. Typically, a riddle involves a play on words that requires the player to interpret it in a nonstandard way in order to solve it.

如今，谜语在游戏中的出现频率远低于 20 年前。部分原因在于实际。谜语需要花费大量时间和精力来创作，但玩家只会遇到一次。谜语也没有重玩价值，因为第一次解开谜语的玩家可以在以后的游戏中回忆起答案。与其他类型的内容相比，谜语的这一特性使其成本较高。

Riddles are far less common in games today than they were 20 years ago. This is partly for practical reasons. A riddle takes a fair amount of time and effort to create, yet is only encountered by a player once. Riddles also have no replay value, as a player who solves it the first time can recall the solution on future playthroughs. This property of riddles makes them costly compared to other kinds of content.

对于大多数玩家来说，谜语也不是特别有趣。一旦知道答案，就会有一种成就感。然而，玩家要么立即知道谜语的答案，要么不知道，如果他们不知道，那么他们就会永远被困住，或者开始互联网搜索任务（除非他们最终自己想到了答案）。这并不是有趣的游戏玩法。

Riddles also aren’t particularly fun to try to solve for the majority of players. Once the solution is known, there’s a sense of reward. However, players either immediately know the answer to the riddle or they don’t, and if they don’t, then they’re stuck for good or are off on an Internet search mission (unless the solution eventually occurs to them on their own). Not exactly the stuff of fun gameplay.

话虽如此，如果设计师坚持要添加谜语，那么有一些技巧可以让谜语不那么令人沮丧：

That said, there are a few tricks to making riddles less frustrating if a designer insists on including them:

·让谜语成为纯粹的可选内容。在经典角色扮演游戏《克朗多的背叛》中，谜语被用作宝箱的锁。打开宝箱会给玩家带来有用但非必需的物品。     

·      Make the riddles purely optional. In the classic RPG Betrayal at Krondor, riddles were used as locks on treasure chests. Opening a chest would give the player useful but nonessential items.

·提供线索。《克朗多的背叛》并不是简单地要求玩家输入谜语的答案。相反，玩家会确切地看到答案中有多少个字母，并且每个字母只有几个选项。有决心的玩家可以写下每个可能性并搜索有效的单词，从而将谜语变成类似Boggle的单词搜索。玩家还可以通过与游戏中的 NPC 交谈来找到一些谜语的线索。     

·      Offer clues. Betrayal at Krondor did not simply ask the player to type in the answer to a riddle. Instead, the player was shown exactly how many letters were in the answer, and each letter only had a few choices. A determined player could write down each possibility and search for valid words, turning a riddle into a Boggle-like word search instead. Players could also find hints to some riddles by talking to NPCs in the game.

·允许备选解决方案。也许玩家可以解开一个谜语或完成不同的挑战。在《龙与地下城》中，如果英雄回答了谜语，狮身人面像将允许他们通过，但他们也可以攻击狮身人面像并在战斗中击败它。     

·      Allow alternate solutions. Perhaps the player could solve a riddle or complete a different challenge. In Dungeons & Dragons, a Sphinx will allow the heroes to pass if they answer a riddle, but they can also attack the Sphinx and defeat it in combat.

要设计一个谜语，设计师通常先给出答案，然后再设计谜题。因此，如果答案是“汽车”，那么一个有效的谜语可能是“它坐在四号车厢上，二号车厢上的车厢在里面。”

To create a riddle, designers usually start with the answer and create the puzzle afterward. So, starting with an answer of “car,” a valid riddle could be, “It sits on four and those on two sit within.”

对于好奇的人来说，本节开头提出的谜语的答案是“闪电”。

For the curious, the answer to the riddle posed at the beginning of this section is “lightning.”

横向思维

LATERAL THINKING

和谜语一样，横向思维谜题是只有唯一正确答案的陷阱问题。这些谜题的构造方式是让玩家做出不正确的假设，而解决谜题需要玩家质疑自己的假设。这是一个典型的例子：

Like riddles, lateral-thinking puzzles are trick questions that have a single correct answer. These puzzles are constructed in such a way that players make assumptions that are not true, and solving the puzzle requires the player to question his or her assumptions. Here is a classic example:

·      画一个 3 点乘 3 点的网格（总共 9 个点）。

·      Draw a grid of three dots by 3 dots (nine dots total).

·      每个点之间的距离约为 1 英寸。

·      Separate the dots by approximately 1 inch each.

将一支铅笔放在这张纸上。不要将铅笔从纸上拿开，画出四条直线，使所有九个点都连接起来。（如果你想尝试解答，请在解答之前不要继续阅读。）

Place a pencil on this sheet of paper. Without removing the pencil from the page, draw four straight lines in such a way that all nine dots are connected. (If you’d like to try solving it, do not read further until you’re done.)

按照显而易见的方法解决这个难题，至少需要五条线才能将所有点连接起来。然而，大多数人都基于一个不言而喻的假设，即我们画的线必须保持在由点组成的正方形内。通过消除这个假设并允许我们画出延伸得更远的线，这个难题就可以解决。试着通过在点之外画线来解决这个难题（试着从左上角到左下角画第一条线，并将其延伸，就好像那里有第四个点一样）。 

By approaching this puzzle the obvious way, it takes at least five lines to connect all the dots. Most people, however, work on the unstated assumption that the lines we draw must remain within the square formed by the dots. By removing this assumption and allowing ourselves to draw lines that extend farther, the puzzle can be solved. Try solving the puzzle by drawing your lines beyond the dots (try drawing your first line from top left to bottom left and extend it as if there were a fourth dot there).  

谜题的分析也适用于此。横向思维谜题的制作成本很高，它们只能体验一次，如果它们阻碍了玩家的前进，玩家无法想出解决方案，它们可能会令人沮丧。与其他形式的谜题一样，让这些谜题成为可选的，提供其他解决方法，并在玩家花费很长时间解决它们时为玩家提供额外的线索，以指引他们正确的方向。

The analysis from riddles applies here as well. Lateral-thinking puzzles are expensive to create, they are only experienced once, and they can be frustrating if they block a player’s path and the player can’t think of the solution. Like other forms of puzzles, make these optional, offer alternate ways to solve them, and give players additional clues to point them in the right direction if they are taking a long time to solve them.

空间推理

SPATIAL REASONING

空间谜题涉及对物体的操纵，无论是在脑海中还是在游戏表面上。俄罗斯方块 本质上是一种连续、快速移动的空间谜题。《洛洛历险记》系列和《推箱子》是一系列空间谜题组合成完整游戏的例子。其他游戏（尤其是角色扮演游戏和冒险游戏）经常将空间谜题用作大型游戏中的较小任务。想想控制台角色扮演游戏和动作游戏中无数的滑动板条箱谜题。

Spatial puzzles involve the manipulation of objects, either in the mind or on the playing surface. Tetris is essentially a continuous, fast-moving spatial puzzle. The Adventures of Lolo series and Sokoban are examples of a series of spatial puzzles made into a complete game. Other games (notably RPGs and adventure games) often use spatial puzzles as smaller quests in a larger game. Consider the myriad sliding crate puzzles in console RPGs and action games.

空间推理也经常用于 Boss 战，玩家必须利用怪物本身的等级或结构才能在战斗中获胜。《汪达与巨像》在每场战斗中都精通了这一点，有效地将怪物变成了它们自己的可玩等级。

Spatial reasoning is also often used in boss battles where the players must use the level or the structure of the creature itself to succeed in battle. Shadow of the Colossus mastered this in each of its battles, effectively turning the creatures into their own playable levels.

模式识别

PATTERN RECOGNITION

模式识别谜题要求玩家在获得信息时寻找并识别出某种模式。当然，密码破解是这种解谜形式的巅峰。在电子游戏中，模式可以越来越快地出现在玩家面前，使识别变得更加困难，或者模式之间存在细微差异，例如每五次呈现模式时就会缺少一个组件。在体育运动中，人们经常研究竞争队伍的模式，以便建立更优越的进攻和防守。

Pattern-recognition puzzles require the player to look for and identify a pattern when presented with information. Code breaking is the height of this form of puzzle solving, of course. In electronic games, patterns can come at the player faster and faster, making recognition more difficult, or have mild differences in them, such as a missing component every fifth time the pattern is presented. In sports, people regularly study the patterns of competing teams in order to establish both a superior offense and defense.

在 Boss 战中，玩家通常需要识别 Boss 的模式并找出 Boss 容易受到攻击的弱点。

Boss battles often involve players recognizing the pattern in the boss and identifying the weak point at which the boss is vulnerable to attack.

逻辑

LOGIC

“你有四个球体，颜色分别为黑色、蓝色、红色和黄色。你必须按照正确的顺序将它们放在四个基座上。黑色在左边。红色在蓝色旁边。黄色在红色的右边。” 

“You have four orbs, colored black, blue, red and yellow. You must place them on four pedestals in the correct order. Black is on the left. Red is next to blue. Yellow is to the right of red.”  

逻辑谜题要求玩家根据给定的一组信息并获取更多信息来找到解决方案。这些谜题最常出现在解谜杂志和冒险游戏中，但它们也可以用作其他类型游戏中的挑战。

Logic puzzles require the player to take a set of given information and derive additional information to find the solution. These puzzles are most frequently seen in puzzle magazines and adventure games, but they can also be used as challenges in other types of games.

与谜语和横向思维谜题一样，玩家必须解决一个解决方案才能继续前进，因此应谨慎使用逻辑谜题。另一方面，逻辑谜题可以宽容一些。在前面的例子中，如果猜错只会受到轻微惩罚或没有惩罚，玩家可以尝试所有球体组合，直到猜对为止。游戏还可以设计为提供提示，向玩家展示他们距离正确解决方案有多近。无论哪种情况，玩家都应该因猜错而受到惩罚，或者因立即得到答案而获得奖励；否则，谜题似乎是一个任意的、毫无意义的障碍，只会浪费玩家的时间。

As with riddles and lateral thinking puzzles, there is a single solution that the player must solve to progress, so logic puzzles should be used with caution. On the other hand, logic puzzles can be forgiving. In the case of the preceding example, if there is only a minor penalty or no penalty for guessing wrong, players could try all combinations of orbs until they get it right. The game could also be designed to give hints, showing player how close they are to the correct solution. In either case, the player should either get a penalty for a wrong guess or a bonus for getting the answer right away; otherwise, the puzzle seems like an arbitrary, pointless barrier to the rest of the game that just wastes the player’s time.

勘探

EXPLORATION

迷宫、地下城、世界地图……探索环境是各种游戏中必不可少的元素。探索活动的例子可能是在大型城镇中找到特定的人、在迷宫般的走廊中找到一条路，或者找到当前关卡上的所有宝箱。在 FPS 游戏中，就生存而言，探索和了解关卡仅次于玩家技能。《塞尔达传说》等冒险游戏以探索型谜题而闻名，RPG 也是如此。《块魂》通过迫使玩家以新的方式考虑关卡来提升关卡设计——将其作为更大关卡的子集，并以不同的规模反复访问。在 2D 和 3D 平台游戏中，探索关卡通常就是谜题。如何从 A 到 B 再到 Z 来完成关卡？在这种情况下，您不是在与敌人战斗，而是在努力完成关卡。

Mazes, dungeons, world maps... exploring the environment is found in a wide variety of games. Examples of exploration activities might be locating a specific person in a large town, finding a path through a maze-like series of corridors, or finding all of the treasure chests on the current level. In FPS games, exploration and knowledge of a level is second only to player skill when it comes to survival. Adventure games like The Legend of Zelda are well known for exploration-based puzzles, as are RPGs. Katamari Damacy elevated level design by forcing players to consider levels in a new way—as subsets of even greater levels that would be revisited again and again at different sizes. In 2D and 3D platformers, exploration of a level is often the puzzle. How do you get from A to B to Z to finish the level? In this case, you’re not fighting against the enemy so much as you are trying to complete the level.

对于许多玩家来说，探索本身就很有趣。进入地下城并绘制其走廊的想法相当于数字洞穴探险。事实上，在电子游戏的早期，巫术系列甚至附带方格纸，后来还包含自动地图功能——在玩家在游戏中找到自动地图工具包之后！如今，自动地图很常见，许多自动地图会识别“卡点”，要求玩家找到某种物品、解决谜题或完成特定任务才能通过。

For many players, exploration is fun in and of itself. The thought of going down into a dungeon and mapping its corridors is the digital equivalent of spelunking (caving). In the early days of video games, in fact, the Wizardry series even shipped with graph paper and later included an auto-map as a feature—after the player found the automap kit in the game! Nowadays, automaps are commonplace and many identify “stuck points” that require players to find some kind of item, solve a puzzle, or complete a specific quest to pass.

虽然探索对许多人来说是一种巨大的奖励，事实上，许多游戏将这种美学提升为一种艺术形式，但当玩家遇到他们无法进入或穿越的区域（可能是露天坑或上锁的门）时，它也可能成为一种障碍。当玩家被困在关卡中，没有其他前进的方向时，其效果类似于一个糟糕的谜语或谜题。它就像一个停止标志，让玩家感到沮丧。

While exploration is a great reward for many and, in fact, an aesthetic many games elevate to an art form, it can also become an obstacle when players encounter an area they cannot enter or cross (perhaps an open pit or a locked door). When players become stuck in levels and have no alternate way forward, the effect is similar to that of a bad riddle or a puzzle. It functions as a stop sign and frustrates the player.

物品使用

ITEM USE

有些游戏，尤其是像Myst这样的图形冒险游戏和动作角色扮演游戏，会使用涉及使用物品的谜题。玩家必须弄清楚要使用哪些物品，以何种顺序来解决特定挑战。一个简单的例子是使用打火机点燃蜡烛上的灯芯，然后使用蜡烛作为光源来观察黑暗的房间。

Some games, notably graphic adventure games like Myst and action RPGs, use puzzles that involve the use of objects. The player must figure out which item(s) to use, in what order, to solve a particular challenge. A simple example is using a lighter to light the wick on a candle, and then using the candle as a light source to see around a dark room.

如果物品可以组合或相互使用，或者以不明显的方式使用，则基于物品的谜题更具挑战性。《Maniac Mansion 》中有一个特别困难的谜题，要求玩家弄湿一些邮票以将其粘贴在信封上，但游戏没有“舔邮票”命令。解决方案：将空瓶装满水，然后将瓶子和邮票放入微波炉中。

Item-based puzzles are more challenging if items can be combined or used on each other, or if they are used in non-obvious ways. A particularly difficult puzzle in Maniac Mansion required the player to moisten some postage stamps in order to stick them on an envelope, but the game did not have a “lick stamps” command. The solution: fill an empty bottle with water and place the bottle and the stamps in a microwave.

为了减少玩家的挫败感，设计师可以给出一些不明显物品用途的线索，比如，在游戏早期向 NPC 显示谁正在使用该物品。

To reduce player frustration, the designer can give clues about non-obvious item use, for example, by showing an NPC early in the game who is using the item in question.

关卡设计和谜题设计

LEVEL DESIGN AND PUZZLE DESIGN

关卡设计和谜题设计之间存在着相似性，而且这种相似性非常强。在关卡设计中，你会使用现有的机制（怪物、墙壁、武器、开关、门等），并将它们组合在一起，以创造独特而有趣的游戏体验。从机制上讲，在狭长的走廊中射击外星人和在狭小的封闭房间中射击外星人没有区别。然而，动态却完全不同。关卡设计师的工作是使用关卡的不同构建块来改变动态。

There is a parallel between level design and puzzle design, and it is a strong one. In level design, you’re using existing mechanics (monsters, walls, weapons, switches, doors, etc.) and putting them together to create unique and interesting play experiences. Mechanically, there’s no difference between shooting an alien in a long narrow corridor and shooting an alien in a small enclosed room. However, the dynamics are totally different. It’s the level designer’s job to use the different building blocks of a level to change the dynamics.

同样，在谜题设计中，设计师会利用现有的机制，例如滑动板条箱谜题的规则，并尝试以新的方式将它们组合在一起。在这种情况下，它是板条箱的放置。在填字游戏中，它是单词的放置。在数独游戏中，它是数字的放置。

Similarly, in puzzle design, the designer uses existing mechanics, like the rules of sliding crate puzzles, for instance, and attempts to put them together in new ways. In this case, it’s the placement of crates. In crossword puzzles, it’s the placement of words. In Sudoku, it’s the placement of numbers.

人人为我，我为人人

ALL FOR ONE AND ONE FOR ALL

谜题是游戏设计中最难做好的事情之一。对一个玩家来说太难的东西对另一个玩家来说可能太简单了。你如何找到对所有人都有吸引力的东西？

Puzzles are one of the most difficult things to do well when designing a game. What’s too hard for one player might be too easy for another. How do you find something that’s appealing to all?

为了让玩家觉得有意义，谜题必须具有足够的挑战性，让玩家努力寻找解决方案，但又不能让玩家感到沮丧，从而厌恶地转身离​​开或上网寻找剧透。这首先是一种谨慎的平衡行为，而不同的玩家具有不同的解谜能力和对谜题挑战的容忍度，这让这项工作变得更加困难。对于谜题设计师来说，更难的是，很难衡量自己设计的谜题的难度，因为您已经知道了解决方案。您自己的谜题通常比您最初想象的要难得多。了解谜题难度的唯一方法是观察测试人员尝试解决它。

In order to be meaningful to the player, puzzles must be challenging enough to get the player to work hard and find the solution, without being so frustrating that the player turns away in disgust or to the Internet for a spoiler. It is a careful balancing act to begin with, made even more difficult by the fact that different players have different levels of puzzle-solving ability and different tolerances for challenge in puzzles. To make things even harder for a puzzle designer, it’s extremely difficult to gauge the difficulty of your own puzzles, since you already know the solution. Your own puzzles are usually much harder than they initially seem to you. The only way to get a true picture of a puzzle’s difficulty level is to watch testers try to solve it.

许多游戏谜题都会变成“卡点”，玩家如果不解决谜题，就无法继续游戏（如果他们无法解决谜题，他们就会被卡住）。卡住时，玩家有五个选择：再试一次、购买攻略指南、联系朋友、上网查看常见问题解答或放弃。这些都不是“好玩”。

Many game puzzles become “stuck points,” where the player cannot proceed without solving the puzzle (and if they cannot solve it, they are stuck). When stuck, players have five choices: try again, buy a strategy guide, contact a friend, go online for a FAQ, or give up. None of these scream “fun.”

另一个极端是，谜题可能非常简单，对玩家来说毫无挑战性。当玩家立即看到解决方案并不得不花五分钟摆弄界面来实现它时，感觉就像在忙碌工作。

At the other extreme, puzzles can be so easy that they present no challenge to a player at all. When a player immediately sees a solution and has to spend five minutes fiddling with the interface to implement it, it feels like busywork.

一旦确定谜题太简单或太难解决，设计师可以采取一些措施来相应地平衡：

Once it’s determined that a puzzle is too easy or too difficult to solve, there are a few things the designer can do to balance things accordingly:

·添加或删除其他线索。如前所述，给玩家连续的提示可以让谜题更容易解决。     

·      Add or remove additional clues. As mentioned earlier, giving the player successive hints makes puzzles easier to solve.

·移动线索。如果线索位于它们有助于解决的谜题旁边，玩家可以很容易地看到其中的联系。如果它们位于地图的中间，玩家可能不会立即建立联系，这会增加难度。     

·      Move the clues around. If the clues are located right next to the puzzle that they help to solve, players can see the connection easily. If they are found halfway across the map, the player may not immediately make the connection, which increases the difficulty.

·允许多种解决方案。如果您注意到许多测试人员尝试了某个无效的解决方案，这将特别有用。您可以更改谜题以使该解决方案正确，或者提供其他线索以明确表示无效解决方案不起作用。     

·      Allow multiple solutions. This is especially useful if you notice many of your testers trying a particular invalid solution. You can either change the puzzle to make that solution correct, or provide additional clues to make it clear that the invalid solution will not work.

·提供动态、游戏敏感的帮助。《Ratchet & Clank》系列和《Portal》等游戏在玩家第一次完成任务失败后提供额外帮助。这有助于让玩家继续前进，而不会剥夺他第一次解谜的机会（以及随后的奖励）。     

·      Offer dynamic, play-sensitive help. Games like the Ratchet & Clank series and Portal offer the player additional help after he has failed at a task the first time. This serves to get the player going without robbing him of his initial shot at the puzzle (and subsequent reward).

·利用动态难度调整 (DDA)。通过 DDA，游戏可以根据玩家的表现来调整难度，以保持适当的挑战水平。多年来，桌面角色扮演游戏一直采用这种调整方式；地下城主或游戏大师几乎都会通过投掷骰子来让角色存活，或者让怪物比原先预期的更容易或更难击败。1985 年，Dani Berry 的《非洲之心》首次将 DDA 引入数字游戏；如果玩家难以找到关键位置，游戏就会移动这些位置。     

·      Make use of dynamic difficulty adjustment (DDA). With DDA, the game makes itself easier or harder based on how the player is doing in order to preserve a proper level of challenge. This was practiced in tabletop RPGs for years; few are the dungeon masters or game masters who haven’t fudged a few die rolls to keep a character alive, or made a monster easier or harder to defeat than it was originally supposed to be. DDA first crossed over into digital games in 1985 with Dani Berry’s Heart of Africa; the game would move key locations if the player was having trouble finding them.

·消除线性。如果玩家因为某种原因无法朝某个方向前进，他们应该有其他方向或其他选择。玩家总是需要做点什么——一个积极前进的目标。多线性设计中的多个目标有助于实现这一点。     

·      Remove linearity. If players are prevented from going in a particular direction for one reason or another, they should have another direction to go or other options. Players always need something to do—a goal to progress actively toward. Multiple goals in a multilinear design facilitate this.

·添加时间限制。当玩家面临时间压力时，相对简单的谜题会变得更具挑战性。     

·      Add a time limit. A relatively simple puzzle becomes more challenging when the player is under time pressure.

·添加或删除反馈。一些早期的文字冒险和图形冒险游戏在玩家尝试错误解决方案时，除了“你不能这样做”或“那行不通”之外，很少向玩家提供任何指导。如果没有反馈，玩家必须在没有其他信息的情况下继续尝试。但如果玩家得到一些关于他们的解决方案为何行不通的提示，他们就可以调整自己的方法。例如，如果玩家被阻止进入没有光源的黑暗房间，游戏可以说“那里真的很黑，你害怕黑暗”，而不是简单地说“你现在不能走那条路。”     

·      Add or remove feedback. Some early text-adventure and graphic-adventure games gave very little direction to the player when an incorrect solution was tried, other than “you can’t do that” or “that didn’t work.” With no feedback, the player must continue trying with no additional information. But if players are given some indication of why their solution did not work, they can adjust their approach. For example, if a player is prevented from entering a dark room without a light source, the game could say “it’s really dark in there, and you’re scared of the dark” instead of simply saying “you can’t go that way right now.”

·让各种玩家测试游戏。视频游戏最熟练的玩家往往是从一开始就测试游戏的人。一些游戏设计师犯了一个错误，他们把这些测试者作为唯一的难度衡量标准，结果他们的游戏对普通玩家来说有点太难了。没有什么比定期让一批新测试者加入游戏更能揭示潜在的卡点了。     

·      Test the game on a variety of players. The most skilled players of a video game are often the ones who have tested it from the beginning. Some game designers make the mistake of using these testers as their only gauge of difficulty, and as a result their games end up a bit too challenging for the average Joe or Jane. Nothing reveals potential stuck points like a fresh battery of testers introduced to the game on a regular basis.

还有一种设计师不应该用来平衡困难谜题的方法是：不要把解决方案放在游戏的官方攻略指南中并要求玩家购买。

There is also a method that a designer should not use to balance difficult puzzles: Do not put the solution in the game’s official strategy guide and require players to purchase it.

JEB HAVENS 谈拼图设计

JEB HAVENS ON PUZZLE DESIGN

Jeb Havens 是 Maxis 的游戏设计师，曾参与制作多款数字和非数字游戏，包括《孢子》和《羊妈妈》。

Jeb Havens is a game designer with Maxis and has worked on multiple digital and non-digital games including Spore and Mother Sheep.

让谜题变得有趣的最重要的因素之一是“顿悟时刻”。这些时刻是某些东西被锁定到位的时刻，为之前混乱或毫无意义的事物增加了一层意义和理解。人类的大脑天生就能够找到秩序，并将意义和结构应用于它不断接收的大量感官数据。如果没有这种分类、划分和分块的能力和本能，我们就会不知所措。所以，当面对一个混乱的谜题时，人类的大脑自然会想要弄清楚，这样才能更容易地处理它。例如，如果我告诉你你必须记住这个序列——]ANEBARPRAYUNULUGEPCTOVEC——你可能会遇到一点麻烦。

One of the most important elements of what makes a puzzle fun is the “aha moments.” These are the moments when something locks into place, adding a layer of sense and understanding to something that was previously chaotic or meaningless. The human mind is designed to find order and apply meaning and structure to the huge amount of sensory data it constantly takes in. Without this ability and instinct to classify, compartmentalize, and chunk, we would be overwhelmed. So, when confronted with the disorder of a puzzle, the human mind naturally desires to figure it out so that it can be processed more easily. For example, if I told you that you had to memorize the sequence—]ANEBARPRAYUNULUGEPCTOVEC—you might have a bit of trouble.

试试看。闭上眼睛，试着背诵。真的，试试看，然后继续阅读。你答对了多少？也许你在序列中看到了单词“bar”和“pray”，你用它们来帮助你记忆？看到了吗？你的大脑已经在试图把它分解成更有意义的部分。现在，如果我告诉你这个序列只不过是一年 12 个月的第二个和第三个字母（jAN、fEB、mAR、aPR 等）呢？似乎没有那么多信息需要记住，是吗？闭上眼睛，再试着背诵一遍。解决一个难题几乎总是意味着以一种让所有部分都具有更具凝聚力的意义的方式将元素组合在一起。这就像能够从场景中缩小，现在事情变得更有意义了。当事情变得更有意义时，大脑就更容易处理它们。如果某件事让大脑的工作更容易，很可能是进化让它感觉很好。因此，当你获得那种“顿悟时刻”，当事情变得明了时，你会感到温暖。当你周围的世界变得更易于管理和理解时，你会变得更强大，因为你更容易控制你在更基本层面上理解的东西。所以，我猜谜题只是书呆子的力量之旅。

Try it. Close your eyes and try reciting it. No really, try it and then keep reading. How many did you get? Perhaps you saw the words “bar” and “pray” within the sequence, which you used to help you remember? See? Your brain is already trying to break it down into more meaningful parts. Now, what if I told you that the sequence is nothing more than the second and third letters of the 12 months of the year (jAN, fEB, mAR, aPR, etc.)? Doesn’t seem like so much information to remember anymore, does it? Close your eyes and try reciting it again. Solving a puzzle almost always means bringing elements together in a way that gives all the parts a more cohesive meaning. It’s like being able to zoom out from a scene, and now things make more sense. And when things make more sense, they are easier for the brain to handle. And if something makes the brain’s job easier, chances are that evolution made it feel good to do. Hence the nice warm feeling you get when you get that “aha moment,” when things click into place. When the world around you becomes more manageable and understandable, you become more powerful, since it’s easier to control things you understand at a more fundamental level. So, I guess puzzles are just nerdy power trips.

因此，大脑喜欢解决问题，将之前不相关的事物联系在一起。然而，要看出不相关事物之间的联系却很难。这就是它们不相关的原因。因此，作为一名谜题设计师，你的工作是温和地引导你的解谜者找到这些关系。做到这一点的方法之一是了解和操纵玩家在游戏中的先前体验。如果你的谜题涉及找到一种使用现有物品的新方法，那么玩家应该已经多次使用过该物品，以便充分了解它在其他各种情况下的作用，并且应该允许和鼓励玩家自由地尝试该物品。游戏中的一般对象类别必须表现一致，这样玩家才能开始建立对象类别和交互的词汇表（所有这种类型的敌人都会避开巨大的噪音，所有板条箱在被砸碎时都会解体，所有控制面板在被弄湿时都会发生故障，等等）。

So, the brain loves to solve things, bring things together that were previously unrelated. However, seeing the connection between unrelated things is hard. That’s why they’re unrelated. So, as a puzzle designer, your job is to gently guide your solver toward the relationships. One way to do this is by understanding and manipulating the player’s previous experiences in the game. If your puzzle involves finding a novel way to use an existing item, the player should have already used the item several times to get a solid understanding of what it does in various other contexts, and the player should be allowed and encouraged to freely experiment with the item. It is important that general object classes in the game behave consistently, so that the player can start to build up a lexicon of object classes and interactions (all enemies of this type run away from loud noises, all crates disintegrate when smashed, all control panels malfunction when they get wet, etc.).

引导解谜者找到答案的另一种重要方法是让谜题逐渐展开，并伴随着一系列“顿悟时刻”。每一步，解谜者都会感到鼓舞，他们走在正确的轨道上，或者已经掌握了完整解决方案的关键部分。这可以简单到一声叮当声，也可以复杂到 NPC 动画状态的变化，但它必须是玩家行为的明确反应，而不是一些随机的背景事件。只要某种变化表明玩家刚刚采取的步骤正朝着正确的方向前进，即使是最困难的谜题和逻辑上的飞跃也是可以解决的。除了对沿途的每一小步感到满意之外，玩家在最后还会获得额外的胜利，回顾他们的完整解决方案，感受到拥有它，即使他们一路上有点被人牵着鼻子走。

Another important way to guide a puzzle solver toward the solution is by having the puzzle unfold gradually, with a series of “aha moments.” At each step, the solver is encouraged that they are on the right track or have grasped a key component of the full solution. This can be as simple as a dinging sound, or as complex as a change in the animation state for an NPC, but it must be something that is unmistakably a reaction to the player’s actions, and not some random background event. As long as something changes in a way that signals that the steps the player just took are heading in the right direction, even the most difficult puzzles and leaps in logic are solvable. Along with feeling good at each small step along the way, the player gets that extra jolt of triumph at the end, looking back upon their full solution, feeling ownership of it, even if they were somewhat handheld along the way.

挑战

CHALLENGES

尽管它们很难制作——制作一个好的拼图本身就很困难——但设计师们仍然被要求制作它们。幸运的是，制作一个好的拼图有时本身就是一个难题。

In spite of their difficulty—and creating a good puzzle is difficult—designers are continually called upon to create them. Fortunately, creating a good puzzle is sometimes a puzzle in itself.

挑战 1 — 这是炸弹！

CHALLENGE 1—IT’S DA BOMB!

与游戏一样，有时在设计谜题时您会得到一个主题，然后您必须创建适合该主题的机制。

As with games, sometimes when designing a puzzle you’re given a theme and you must create the mechanics to fit the theme.

在这种情况下，您正在设计一款基于老电视剧《百战天龙》的游戏，游戏情节的一部分涉及主角拆除炸弹。您没有将其制作成非交互式过场动画，而是选择将其制作成定时谜题，如果花费太长时间解决谜题或解错谜题，游戏就会结束。如果这都不能给玩家带来一些紧张感，那就没有什么能做到了。

In this case, you’re designing a game based on the old TV show MacGyver, and part of the storyline in the game involves the main character defusing a bomb. Rather than making it a non-interactive cutscene, you’ve chosen to make it into a timed puzzle, where taking too long to solve the puzzle or solving it incorrectly results in the game being over. If that doesn’t provide some tension to the player, nothing will.

考虑本章中提到的不同类型的谜题，并选择至少三种适合主题的谜题类型。然后选择您最喜欢的类型并创建谜题的工作原型。

Consider the different kinds of puzzles mentioned in this chapter and choose at least three puzzle types that would be appropriate to the theme. Then choose your favorite type and create a working prototype of the puzzle.

所需组件

Components Required

·制作原型的材料     

·      Materials to create prototype

·      厨房计时器用于倒计时玩家剩余的时间

·      Kitchen timer to count down the time remaining for the player

可交付成果

Deliverable

·每个谜题类型各有三段文字和随附的草图，描述谜题的基本机制     

·      Three paragraphs and accompanying sketch, one per puzzle type, describing the basic mechanics of the puzzle

·三个谜题之一的可玩原型     

·      Playable prototype of one of the three puzzles

建议流程

Suggested Process

1.集思广益。思考角色拆除炸弹的不同方法。您可以将炸弹连接到滑动拼图上，但这似乎有些武断。思考适合给定主题的拼图机制。哪些类型的拼图（谜语、横向思维、空间、逻辑、探索、物品使用）适合您的机制？继续思考，直到您确定至少三种不同的拆弹拼图核心机制。   

1.    Brainstorm. Think about the different ways a character could defuse a bomb. You could have the bomb attached to a sliding-tile puzzle, but this would seem arbitrary. Think of puzzle mechanics that fit the given theme. What kinds of puzzles (riddles, lateral thinking, spatial, logic, exploration, item use) lend themselves well to your mechanics? Keep thinking until you identify at least three different core mechanics for a bomb-defusal puzzle.

2.选择一个谜题。选择核心机制之一并充实它。创建其余机制。确定总体目标。然后选择这个特定谜题的细节：起始状态、目标状态以及正确和错误的解决方案。   

2.    Choose one puzzle. Take one of your core mechanics and flesh it out. Create the rest of the mechanics. Identify the general goal. Then choose the details for this specific puzzle: the beginning state, the goal state, and the correct and incorrect solutions.

3.游戏测试和迭代。让一些朋友尝试你的谜题。他们能正确解开吗？他们花了多长时间？他们是否按照你期望的方式解开谜题？如果谜题的某些方面不清楚，或者太难（或者太简单，尽管谜题设计师很少会设计出太简单的谜题），请返回并修改谜题。   

3.    Playtest and iterate. Try your puzzle on some friends. Did they solve it correctly? How long did it take them? Did they approach the puzzle in the way that you expected them to? Go back and modify your puzzle if some aspects of it weren’t clear, or if it was too hard (or too easy, although it’s rare for a puzzle designer to actually create something too easy).

4.创建可交付成果。   

4.    Create deliverable.

5.添加难度等级（可选）。在你展示原型后，游戏发行商会坚持要求有多个难度等级，并且谜题的难度应该受到影响。除了改变玩家的时间量外，至少找到三种方法来修改炸弹谜题的难度。要具体。    

5.    Add difficulty levels (optional). After you show off your prototype, the publisher of your game insists that there be multiple difficulty levels, and that the difficulty of the puzzle should be affected. Find at least three ways to modify the difficulty of your bomb puzzle—other than changing the amount of time given to the player. Be specific.

挑战 2 — 不仅仅是迷宫

CHALLENGE 2—MORE THAN A MAZE

把迷宫看作是一种探索谜题。对于已经见过很多迷宫的玩家来说，具有任意路径的基本迷宫并不是特别有吸引力。许多较旧的 RPG 要求玩家在玩游戏时绘制一系列迷宫的地图。今天，大多数玩家会认为这是“无用功”，并且更喜欢游戏提供自动绘图功能。不过，对于这个挑战，让我们给玩家一个制作自己地图的理由。

Consider the maze to be a type of exploration puzzle. A basic maze with arbitrary paths is not particularly compelling to a player who has seen many mazes before. Many older RPGs required players to make a map of a series of mazes as they played. Today, most gamers would consider this “busywork” and prefer that the game provided an automatic mapping function. For this challenge, though, let’s give the player a reason to make his own map.

集思广益，想出尽可能多的可以添加到简单迷宫中的机制，使得绘制地图的过程本身成为一个谜题。想出至少三个想法。其中一个例子（您不能将其作为本次挑战的自己的想法之一）是经典 Atari 2600 游戏Adventure中的迷宫。在这个游戏中，迷宫“环绕”，因此向左移动可能会导致您重新出现在迷宫的右侧。当您实际上位于迷宫的完全不同部分时，您可能会多次经过同一点附近。这样，尽管迷宫本身不是很大，但绘制地图和导航变得更加困难，并且成为一个难题。

Brainstorm as many mechanics as you can think of that can be added to a simple maze, which makes the process of mapping a puzzle in and of itself. Come up with at least three ideas. One example (which you’re not allowed to use as one of your own ideas for this challenge) is the maze from the classic Atari 2600 game Adventure. In this game, the maze “wraps around” so that moving to the left may cause you to reappear on the right side of the maze. You may pass near the same point several times when you’re actually in a completely different section of the maze. In this way, mapping and navigating are made more difficult, and become quite a puzzle, even though the maze itself is not very large.

所需组件

Components Required

·方格纸     

·      Graph paper

可交付成果

Deliverable

·用一句话到一段话来描述你能想到的每个机制     

·      A short sentence up to a paragraph describing each mechanic that you can think of

·手绘迷宫示例，阐明了所描述的机制     

·      A sample hand-drawn maze illustrating the mechanics described

建议流程

Suggested Process

1.集思广益。首先考虑一下你玩过的游戏，它们有非标准的地图或导航机制，这很诱人。然而，这样做可能会限制你的创造力，因为如果你总是想着别人的想法，你可能会很难想出自己的想法。首先要尝试原创，然后只有当你自己的想法用尽时才考虑现有的游戏。   

1.    Brainstorm. It’s tempting to start by thinking of any games you played that had nonstandard mapping or navigation mechanics. However, this runs the risk of constraining your creativity, because you may have trouble coming up with your own ideas if you’re constantly thinking of other people’s. Try to be original first, and then think of existing games only when your own ideas are spent.

2.创建可交付成果。   

2.    Create deliverable.

挑战3——密码是什么？

CHALLENGE 3—WHAT’S THE PASSWORD?

一个人走进家门，轻轻松松地在安全键盘上输入四五个数字。在工作场所、家中和银行取款机上，这些密码是我们生活的一部分。它们也经常用于电子游戏中，作为让一组人进来而将另一组人拒之门外的手段。

A person walks into his home and punches four or five numbers handily into the security pad. At work, at home, and at bank machines, these codes are a part of our lives. They are frequently used in video games, too, as a means to let one group in and keep another out.

在本挑战中，您的目标是设计三个不同的密码谜题。这分为三个部分：

For this challenge, your goal is to design three different password puzzles. There are three parts to this:

·确定代码（不必是数字）     

·      Determine the code (it need not be numbers)

·确定玩家如何输入代码     

·      Determine how the player enters the code

·首先确定玩家如何获取代码     

·      Determine how the player gets the code in the first place

这里有一个简单的方法：将代码设为四个数字，然后杀死四个生物，每个生物都有数字的一部分。然后玩家只需要找出顺序。虽然这条路线可行，但它几乎太明显了。考虑玩家意想不到的事情，比如在关卡中进行物理交互以操纵某个对象输入代码或找到与必要模式匹配的特定物品。研究中世纪时期用来将人们拒之门外（和将人们关在里面）的许多独特“钥匙”。

There’s an easy way out here: make the code four numbers, and kill four creatures, each with one part of the number. Then the player needs only to figure out the order. While this route would work, it’s almost too obvious. Consider things that players don’t expect, like physical interaction within a level to manipulate some object into entering a code or finding particular items that match a necessary pattern. Research the many unique “keys” that were used to keep people out (and to keep people in) in the medieval period.

所需组件

Components Required

·没有任何     

·      None

可交付成果

Deliverable

·各个谜题的模型     

·      Mockups of the individual puzzles

·拼图玩法说明     

·      Description of how the puzzle works

·如果适用，请在方格纸上进行水平设计     

·      Level design on graph paper, if applicable

建议流程

Suggested Process

1.研究。在现代和过去，人们用什么方法来保护贵重物品不被那些不应该接触它们的人接触？用什么方法允许接触？你的谜题应该是合理的。当然，你可以说一个高度安全的区域有一个密码，它被写在几个办公室的墙上，以数学问题的形式写成，任何有基本代数知识的人都可以解开，但现实世界中真的有人会这样做吗？如果没有，谜题就会显得做作和武断。   

1.    Research. In modern day and in the past, what methods were used to keep valuable objects safe from those who were not supposed to have access to them? What methods were used to allow access? Your puzzles should be plausible. Sure, you could say that a high-security area has a passcode that’s written down on the walls of several offices, in the form of a math problem that could be solved by anyone with a rudimentary knowledge of algebra, but would anyone in the real world actually do that? If not, the puzzle will seem contrived and arbitrary.

2.集思广益。在你见过的密码方法中，哪些看起来最像游戏？想办法将它们应用于大型游戏中的谜题。   

2.    Brainstorm. Of the password methods you’ve seen, which ones seem the most game like? Think of ways to adapt them to a puzzle found in a larger game.

3.制定细节。尝试根据自己的想法制作一些谜题。你不必设计完整的游戏，只需设计一套谜题规则即可。   

3.    Work out the details. Try creating a few puzzles from your own ideas. You don’t have to design a complete game, just a set of rules for puzzles.

4.创建可交付成果。   

4.    Create deliverable.

挑战 4 — 令人震惊的谜题

CHALLENGE 4—A SHOCKING PUZZLE

电流是电子游戏中的绝妙谜题，因为从一侧流向另一侧的电流在逻辑上可以导致执行某些操作，前提是电流确实正确流过。对于此挑战，您的目标是创建一个谜题的纸质原型，其中电流从屏幕的一侧流向另一侧。您可以使用任何您喜欢的界面，只要它需要玩家的空间推理能力。

Electricity makes for great puzzles in video games, since passing its current from one side to another can logically result in some action being performed, provided it is, in fact, passed correctly. For this challenge, your goal is to create a paper prototype of a puzzle in which electrical current is passed from one side of the screen to the other. You may use any interface you like, provided that it requires spatial reasoning on the part of the player.

所需组件

Components Required

·制作原型的材料     

·      Materials to create prototype

可交付成果

Deliverable

·原型，以及一套书面规则，指明起始状态、目标以及玩家可以采取的行动     

·      Prototype, along with a written set of rules indicating the beginning state, objective, and actions that the player may take

建议流程

Suggested Process

1.集思广益。如何让电流从屏幕的一侧流到另一侧？“成功”是什么样子的？有没有“失败”的方法，或者玩家只是不断尝试直到成功？   

1.    Brainstorm. How do you get electrical current from one side of the screen to the other? What does a “success” look like? Are there any ways to “fail” or does the player simply keep trying until he succeeds?

2.创建机制。定义玩家可以采取的行动。这些行动对谜题的状态有什么影响？   

2.    Create the mechanics. Define the actions that a player can take. What effects do these actions have on the state of the puzzle?

3.创建示例谜题。使用你的规则制作一个谜题。一定要写下你自己的解决方案。如果你有时间，可以制作两个谜题：一个非常简单的谜题，用于向新玩家传授基本机制；另一个更高级的谜题，用于展示你的机制的深度。   

3.    Create a sample puzzle. Using your rules, make a puzzle. Be sure to write down the solution for yourself. If you have time, make two puzzles: one very simple puzzle meant to teach the basic mechanics to a new player, and a more advanced puzzle that shows the depth of your mechanics.

4.游戏测试和迭代。让一些朋友尝试你的谜题，并根据需要调整规则和难度级别。   

4.    Playtest and iterate. Try your puzzle on some friends, and adjust the rules and difficulty level as needed.

5.创建可交付成果。   

5.    Create deliverable.

铁设计师挑战 5 — 玩新 Eleusis（直播）

IRON DESIGNER CHALLENGE 5—PLAY NEW ELEUSIS (LIVE)

新埃莱夫西斯是一种使用两副标准牌的游戏，可供五到八人玩。它最初由罗伯特·阿博特设计，并于 1977 年发表在《科学美国人》上。牌按顺序打出。一名玩家（扮演上帝的角色）制定规则，确定哪些牌在什么条件下可以打出（例如，“总是在黑牌后打出红牌”）。其他玩家（扮演科学家的角色）尝试打出他们的牌，并通过逻辑归纳法尝试确定上帝创造的隐藏规则。上帝的角色轮换，因此每个玩家都可以制定规则。在每一轮结束时，所有玩家都会获得一个分数；游戏结束时得分最高的玩家获胜。

New Eleusis is a game played with two standard decks of cards, for five to eight players. It was originally designed by Robert Abbott and published in Scientific American in 1977. Cards are played in order. One player (taking the role of God) creates a rule that determines which cards are legal to play, under what conditions (for example, “always play a red card after a black card”). The other players (playing the role of scientists) attempt to play their cards, and through logical induction try to determine the hidden rule that God created. The role of God rotates so that each player gets to create a rule. At the end of each round, all players receive a score; highest score at the end of the game wins.

计分系统会奖励上帝想出一条具有挑战性但并非不可能推断的规则。具体来说，如果桌上至少有一名玩家（经过一段时间）弄清楚了规则，并且至少有一名玩家完全无法掌握规则，上帝的分数就会最大化。设计师就哪些规则往往会产生高分提出了以下建议：

The scoring system rewards God for coming up with a rule that is challenging but not impossible to deduce. In particular, God’s score is maximized if at least one player at the table figures out the rule (after taking awhile), and at least one player completely and utterly fails to grasp the rule. The designer makes the following suggestions regarding what rules tend to produce good scores:

·你的规则几乎总是比你想象的更难弄清楚。     

·      Your rule is almost always harder to figure out than you think it is.

·如果你给出任何提示，不要让它们误导玩家。规则本身就很难理解，你甚至不需要主动误导其他玩家。     

·      If you give any hints, don’t make them misleading. The rule is hard enough to figure out without you actively leading the other players astray.

·在任何给定时间，牌堆中大约一半的牌应该是合法的。如果玩家几乎总是正确（或错误），他们将无法获得足够的信息来推导你的规则。     

·      At any given time, about half of the cards in the deck should be legal plays. If players are almost always right (or wrong), they will not get enough information to induce your rule.

虽然这款游戏最初旨在教授科学方法，但它也恰好教授谜题设计。当玩家制定规则时，他实际上是在创建一个逻辑谜题，其他玩家必须通过实验来弄清楚。评分系统会奖励制定适当难度规则的玩家，也会奖励解决彼此谜题的玩家。

While this game was originally intended to teach the scientific method, it also happens to teach puzzle design. When a player makes a rule, he is essentially creating a logic puzzle that other players must figure out through experimentation. The scoring system rewards players who create rules of the appropriate difficulty, and it also rewards players for solving each other’s puzzles.

和你的谜题设计师同事一起玩游戏。游戏结束后，讨论每条规则，以及是什么让它变得太简单、太难或恰到好处。

Play the game with your fellow puzzle designers. After the game, discuss each rule and what made it too easy, too difficult, or just right.

所需组件

Components Required

·两副标准扑克牌     

·      Two standard decks of playing cards

·新埃莱夫西斯规则，可从许多地方在线获取（截至本文印刷时，规则可在以下网址找到：http://matuszek.org/eleusis0.html，但也可通过 Google 搜索在其他地方找到）     

·      Rules for New Eleusis, available online from many locations (as of this printing, the rules can be found at: http://matuszek.org/eleusis0.html but they can also be found elsewhere through a Google search)

可交付成果

Deliverable

·没有任何     

·      None

建议流程

Suggested Process

1.玩游戏。与你的拼图设计师同伴一起玩。游戏结束后，在小组中讨论每条规则，以及是什么让它变得太简单、太难或恰到好处。   

1.    Play the game. Play with your fellow puzzle designers. After the game, in a group discuss each rule and what made it too easy, too difficult, or just right.
