2.写下学到的经验教训（可选）。玩这个游戏后，你学到了什么关于如何制作出好拼图的知识吗？写下来并与没有和你一起玩的同事分享。   

2.    Write down the lessons learned (optional). Did you learn anything about what makes a good puzzle from playing this game? Write it down and share with any colleagues who did not play with you.

非数字短片

NON-DIGITAL SHORTS

以下列表包含棋盘游戏、纸牌游戏或其他不含数字组件的游戏的创意。它们非常适合非数字设计练习。

The following list contains ideas for board games, card games, or other games that are free of a digital component. They are ideal for a non-digital design exercise.

1.创建一个基于图块的游戏，模拟探索地下城的过程。它应该包括玩家进一步前进所需的各种物品。   

1.    Create a tile-based game that simulates the process of exploring a dungeon. It should include various items that players require to progress further.

2.创建一个基于图块的游戏，其中图块只能以一种特定方式正确组合在一起才能解决游戏。创建动态，使其可以作为单人游戏或多人游戏。   

2.    Create a tile-based game where the tiles can only fit together correctly in one particular way to solve the game. Create the dynamics that would allow this to happen as a solo or multiplayer game.

3.使用方格纸和一个简单的六面骰子，创建一张玩家必须穿过的地图，其中包含至少两种不同类型的谜题。   

3.    Using graph paper and a simple six-sided die, create a map that players must travel through that includes at least two different types of puzzles.

4.为使用以下组件的游戏制定规则：一块 100 块的拼图（最初未组装），用作在游戏过程中构建的游戏板，并使用棋子代表玩家。如果需要，您可以使用其他组件。   

4.    Create the rules for a game that uses the following components: a 100-piece jigsaw puzzle (initially unassembled) for use as a game board that’s built during play, and uses pawns to represent the players. You may use additional components if desired.

5.创建一个在魔方表面上玩的游戏。假设有磁性棋子代表玩家，它们可以粘在魔方的侧面和底部。   

5.    Create a game played on the surface of a Rubik’s Cube. Assume that there are magnetic pawns, representing the players, which can stick to the sides and bottom of the cube.

6.采取任何一种通常由一名玩家解决的谜题（例如填字游戏或数独），并修改规则，使其成为双人竞争游戏。   

6.    Take any kind of puzzle that is normally solved by one player (such as a crossword or Sudoku) and modify the rules so that it becomes a two-player competitive game.

7.以多人游戏为例，其目标是解决难题（例如棋盘游戏Clue、益智游戏Mastermind或纸牌游戏Sleuth），并修改规则，使其成为单人游戏。确保玩家拥有足够的信息来解决难题，并且无需计算机或其他人提供线索或信息即可玩。   

7.    Take a multiplayer game where the goal is to solve a puzzle (such as the board game Clue, the puzzle game Mastermind, or the card game Sleuth) and modify the rules so that it is a single-player puzzle. Make sure that the player has enough information to solve the puzzle, and that it is playable without a computer or another human providing clues or information.

8.使用模式识别，创建一个游戏来教孩子们如何拼写。请注意，正确拼写的单词实际上就是模式识别。   

8.    Using pattern recognition, create a game that teaches children how to spell. Note that a correctly spelled word is, in fact, pattern recognition.

9.创建一个基于琐事的游戏，其中一群人必须解决琐事谜题才能在游戏中前进。   

9.    Create a trivia-based game in which trivia puzzles must be solved by a group in order to progress within the game.

10.查看各大报纸的谜题版面。选择一个谜题，然后根据它创建一个模组，该模组既可以改变主题，也可以引入或改变至少一个机制。

10. Look at the puzzles page of any major newspaper. Select a puzzle and create a mod of it that changes both the theme and introduces or changes at least one mechanic.

资源

RESOURCES

“设计谜题”，鲍勃·贝茨，http://www.scottkim.com/thinkinggames/GDC00/bates.html。

“Designing the Puzzle,” Bob Bates, http://www.scottkim.com/thinkinggames/GDC00/ bates.html.

1该图像由维基百科用户 Michael J. 创建，并根据自由软件基金会发布的 GNU 自由文档许可证 1.2 版或任何后续版本的条款进行分发。

1 This image was created by Wikipedian User: Michael J. and distributed under the terms of the GNU Free Documentation License, Version 1.2 or any later version published by the Free Software Foundation.

2谜题。Dictionary.com。Dictionary.com Unabridged（1.1 版）。Random House, Inc. http://dictionary.reference.com/browse/puzzle（访问时间：2007 年 12 月 30 日）。

2 puzzle. Dictionary.com. Dictionary.com Unabridged (v 1.1). Random House, Inc. http://dictionary.reference.com/browse/puzzle (accessed: December 30, 2007).



 

 

 

 

4：将数字内容转化为实体内容

4: Converting Digital to Physical

 

 

刚上第一堂游戏设计课时，许多学生惊讶地发现，他们接到的任务是他们觉得是倒着做的：制作一款电子游戏的棋盘游戏版本。虽然他们可能不会说出来，但教授们仍然能从他们的眼睛里看出一个问题：“我到底为什么要这么做？”

Having just entered their first game-design class, many students are surprised to be tasked with an assignment that they perceive to be working backward: making a board-game version of a video game. Though they may not say it, professors can still see the question in their eyes: “Why on earth would I want to do that?”

有很多好的理由。然而，最重要的原因可能是：如果你不能从数字游戏设计非数字游戏，如果你不能“逆向”工作，你就没有真正理解艺术背后和通过编程实现的纯设计的细微差别。

There are plenty of good reasons. However, the most important reason of all may be this: If you can’t design a non-digital game from a digital game, if you can’t work “backward,” you don’t truly understand the nuances of the pure design underneath the art and realized through programming.

你可能已经知道，非数字设计非常容易暴露，而且往往会很快暴露出糟糕的游戏机制。如果你能在非数字媒体上取得成功，人们会更信任你，你也会对自己作为游戏设计师更有信心。

As you may have learned, non-digital design is very exposed and tends to reveal bad gameplay mechanics rather quickly. People will have more faith in you, and you’ll have more faith in yourself as a game designer, if you can succeed in a non-digital medium, too.

实际应用

PRACTICAL APPLICATION

“但这种事情在业界从未发生过。”当然会发生。从《光环》到《席德·梅尔的文明》再到《魔兽世界》 ，

“But this never happens in the industry.” Sure it does. Everything from Halo to Sid Meier’s Civilization to World of Warcraft has

被改编成非数字化游戏，而《指环王》、《龙与地下城》和《宠物小精灵》等系列的跨媒体流行为游戏设计师提供了一个虚拟的机遇舞台。

been turned into non-digital games, and the transmedia popularity of franchises like The Lord of the Rings, Dungeons & Dragons, and Pokémon provide game designers with a virtual arena of opportunity.

正如精彩的动作片有时会被制作成视频游戏一样，精彩的视频游戏也会被制作成非数字游戏。它们也被制作成电影，但通常效果并不好。

Just as great action movies are sometimes made into video games, so too are great video games made into non-digital games. They’re also made into movies, but usually that hasn’t turned out so well.

流行游戏的非数字版本也可以成为很好的作品集，如果游戏是基于他的某个知识产权而制作的，甚至可能会给面试官留下深刻的印象。

Non-digital versions of popular games also make for good portfolio pieces, and may even impress an interviewer if the game is based on one of his IPs.

如何开始

HOW TO START

有多个地方可以启动数字游戏的非数字版本。

There are multiple places to start a non-digital version of a digital game.

·字面转换试图在最适合的非数字媒体中尽可能地重现游戏体验。《超级马里奥赛车》就是一个很好的例子，它可以在不改变游戏结构的情况下转换为竞速棋盘游戏。     

·      Literal conversions attempt to re-create the gameplay experience as closely as possible in a non-digital medium for which it is ideally suited. Super Mario Kart is an excellent example of a game that could be converted to a race to the end board game with little modification to the game structure.

·主题转换将数字游戏的基本主题应用于传统风格的非数字游戏。例如，可以将原版《超级马里奥兄弟》变成类似于《龙与地下城》传统角色扮演游戏。可以借用《超级马里奥兄弟》的故事情节，但不借用游戏机制。相反，玩家可以滚动角色（或获得预先选择的角色），并寻找隐藏在城堡中的公主。     

·      Thematic conversions take the basic theme of the digital game and apply that to a traditional style of non-digital game. For instance, one could make the original Super Mario Bros. into something similar to a Dungeons & Dragons traditional RPG. One would borrow the storyline from Super Mario Bros., but not the mechanics. Instead, players might roll characters (or get preselected ones), and search for a princess hidden in a castle.

·机制转换采用数字游戏中特定的、常见的机制，并将其作为非数字游戏的基础。     

·      Mechanic conversions take a particular, common mechanic in the digital game and use it as the basis for a non-digital game.

进行转换时，不要强迫。想想一款游戏，并考虑它在非数字格式下如何运作。良好的匹配不会让人觉得强迫。有时，它甚至让人觉得很明显。

When doing a conversion, don’t force it. Think of a game, and consider how it might work in a non-digital format. A good match doesn’t feel forced. Sometimes, it even feels obvious.

挑战

CHALLENGES

本部分的挑战将考验您所学到的技能——您在创建各种不同形式的游戏时分析数字游戏 IP、确定其优势和劣势以及考虑其目标市场的能力。

The challenges in this section put the skills you learned to the test—your ability to analyze a digital-game IP, determine its strengths and weaknesses, and take into consideration its target market as you create games in a variety of different forms.

每个挑战都应该是一场需要至少 30 分钟才能玩完的棋盘游戏，并且不涉及滚动和前进机制。

Each challenge should result in a board game that takes at least 30 minutes to play and does not involve the roll and move forward mechanic.

挑战 1 — 选择一款游戏，任何游戏都可以

CHALLENGE 1—PICK A GAME, ANY GAME

针对这一挑战，Activision/Blizzard 已联系您，要求您审查今年发布的游戏，并为其中一款游戏创建棋盘游戏原型。他们正在考虑在未来同时发布数字和非数字版本，并希望了解您的团队如何以棋盘游戏形式诠释电子游戏。

For this challenge, you have been contacted by Activision/Blizzard and asked to review the current year’s releases and create a board-game prototype for one of those games. They are considering simultaneous digital and non-digital releases in the future and want to get an idea of how your group would interpret a video game in board-game form.

所需组件

Components Required

·互联网连接（用于研究）     

·      Internet connection (for research)

·您计划改编成棋盘游戏的视频游戏副本（可选）     

·      Copy of video game you plan to turn into a board game (optional)

可交付成果

Deliverable

·精致、生产级的棋盘游戏，配备所有组件     

·      Polished, production-grade board game complete with all components

·原型棋盘游戏包含所有组件     

·      Prototype board game complete with all components

·完整的书面规则     

·      Complete set of written rules

建议流程

Suggested Process

1.选择你的游戏。列出你拥有的或至少玩过的相关游戏。有两种方法可以实现这一点。为了更容易一些，从列表中选择一个看起来特别有趣的棋盘游戏。如果你是一位经验丰富的设计师（或者只是有点冒险精神），请选择一款真正利用数字媒体的游戏，这样就不可能直接转换成棋盘游戏。   

1.    Choose your game. Make a list of the relevant games that you own, or at least have played. There are two ways to approach this. For an easier challenge, choose a game on your list that seems like it would make a particularly interesting board game. If you are an experienced designer (or just feeling a bit adventurous), choose a game that really takes advantage of the digital medium so that a direct conversion to a board game is impossible.

2.选择一种方法。文字、主题还是机制？基于单一核心机制设计棋盘游戏与从叙事开始设计棋盘游戏不同。文字转换是否可行？大多数情况下是可行的，但这可能不是最引人注目的选择。   

2.    Choose a method. Literal, thematic, or mechanic? Designing a board game based on a single core mechanic is different from starting with a narrative. Is a literal conversion even possible? Most of the time it is, but it may not make for the most compelling choice.

3.确定玩家的期望。当玩家玩你的棋盘游戏版本时，他们会期待什么？至少，他们通常希望看到与数字游戏相同的标志和符号、熟悉的角色以及一些让人联想到游戏玩法的东西。列出你认为玩家会期望在你的游戏中出现的所有内容，然后确定其中哪些是真正可以呈现的。   

3.    Determine player expectation. What will players of the video game expect when they play your board-game version of it? At minimum, they usually expect to see the same signs and symbols of the digital game, the familiar characters, and something reminiscent of the gameplay. List everything you think players will expect in your game, and then determine which of those are actually possible to present.

4.尽可能地搜集信息。列出所有你可以立即从视频游戏中获取的元素。这可以为你提供一个起点，要么给你一个故事，一个核心机制，要么给你一整套机制和动态。例如，如果你的视频游戏涉及获取土地，那么你可以将获取土地和用于获取土地的机制作为棋盘游戏的中心点。   

4.    Scavenge what you can. List all of the elements you can lift immediately from your video game. This provides you with a starting point, either by giving you a narrative, a core mechanic, or an entire set of mechanics and dynamics. For instance, if your video game involves acquiring land, you can probably make the acquisition of land and the mechanics used to acquire it a central point of your board game.

5.填补空白。列出您在完成游戏之前缺少的所有东西。您可能需要设计额外的机制、玩家目标、故事或其他一些东西。从第 4 步的起点开始，一点一点地发展您的游戏，直到您有足够的游戏可以玩为止。   

5.    Fill in the blanks. List everything you’re missing before you have a complete game. You may need to design additional mechanics, or player goals, or a narrative, or several other things. Grow your game from your starting point in step 4, one item at a time, until you have enough of a game to play it.

6.创建可交付成果。创建原型和一套暂定的书面规则。使用废弃材料，这样更改起来就容易了。（保证在最初的原型之后，你会做很多更改。）玩几次游戏，看看你是否遇到规则没有提到的任何情况，并使你的规则更加完整。还要注意体验。游戏好玩吗？玩家是否做出了有趣的决定？游戏是否感觉像是原始材料的坚实代表？   

6.    Create deliverables. Create a prototype and a tentative set of written rules. Use scrap materials, so that changes are easy to make. (You will be making many changes after your initial prototype, guaranteed.) Play the game a few times and see if you run into any situations the rules don’t mention, and make your rules more complete. Also pay attention to the experience. Is the game fun? Are players making interesting decisions? Does the game feel like a solid representation of the source material?

变体

Variant

如果您有多个团队，您可以将其作为“铁人设计师挑战赛”！让每个团队从给定公司中选择一款他们认为很难变成棋盘游戏的视频游戏，并将该 IP 交给另一个团队。或者随机选择一个视频游戏，让所有团队竞争，看看谁能在两小时内制作出最好的 棋盘游戏代表。

If you have several teams, you can make this an Iron Designer Challenge! Have each team choose a video game from the given company that they think will be very difficult to turn into a board game, and hand that IP to another team. Or randomly choose one video game and have all teams compete to see who can make the best board-game representation within two hours.

挑战 2 — 大型双人离线卡牌游戏

CHALLENGE 2—MASSIVELY TWO-PLAYER OFFLINE CARD GAME

一家流行的 MMO 游戏公司想要发布一款独立的卡牌游戏，以反映虚拟世界的主题内容。他们并不希望游戏有字面解释，而是希望玩家能够在卡牌中加入一定程度的故事情节，并至少展示游戏中的一个地点。如何做到这一点取决于玩家，但他们希望游戏中至少有 50 张卡牌，可供两名玩家玩。

A popular MMO wants to release a separate stand-alone card game that reflects the thematic content of the virtual world. They are not looking for a literal interpretation, but hope that you’ll be able to incorporate some degree of story into the cards and feature at least one of the locations in the game. How you do that is up to you, but they’d like to have at least 50 cards total in the game and have it be for two players.

所需组件

Components Required

·互联网连接（用于研究）     

·      Internet connection (for research)

·体验玩 MMO（请注意，有很多免费的 MMO）     

·      Experience playing an MMO (note that there are many free MMOs)

可交付成果

Deliverable

·基于您选择的 IP 的 50 张牌游戏牌组一页规则表     

·      50-card playing deck based off your selected IP One-page rule sheet

建议流程

Suggested Process

1.选择合适的 MMO。当然，如果你选择的 MMO 还没有基于它的卡牌游戏，那么这个挑战会更有意义。选择你不熟悉的 MMO 也会扩展你的知识。   

1.    Choose a suitable MMO. This challenge will be more meaningful if you choose an MMO that doesn’t already have a card game based on it, of course. Selecting an MMO you’re unfamiliar with will also expand your knowledge.

2.专注于游戏的一个方面。大多数 MMO 游戏都拥有大量的内容、故事情节和游戏世界，你不可能指望在 50 张卡片中捕捉到所有这些内容。相反，你可以考虑捕捉大型游戏中你认为可以很好地转化为这种新媒介的一部分。   

2.    Focus on one aspect of the game. Most MMOs have massive amounts of content, storylines, and game worlds, and there is no way you can hope to capture all of that in 50 cards. Instead, consider capturing one part of the larger game that you think will translate well to this new medium.

3.设定目标。与之前的挑战一样，通过陈述游戏目标来开始设计通常会有所帮助。这可能自然而然地来自于您选择关注的 MMO 部分。   

3.    Create a goal. As with earlier challenges, it often helps to start your design by stating the goal of the game. This may come naturally from the piece of the MMO on which you’ve chosen to focus.

4.创建机制。玩家如何在游戏中获胜？通过捕获所有卡牌？通过夺取其他玩家的所有生命值？他们可以采取哪些行动？这些行动会产生什么效果？考虑到你的机制，考虑卡牌上必须包含哪些内容。如果你的游戏基于战斗，卡牌可能需要列出战斗统计数据。如果你的游戏基于玩家之间的拍卖和交易，卡牌可能需要代表物品及其价格。考虑卡牌在游戏中的所有使用方式。它们可以洗牌以组成玩家抽牌的公共牌组。玩家可以握在手中。它们可以在玩家面前打出（正面朝上或正面朝下）以表示所有权。它们可以放在网格中以形成临时游戏板。想想你想如何在游戏中使用卡牌，以及由此产生的机制。   

4.    Create the mechanics. How do players achieve victory in your game? By capturing all the cards? By taking all the other player’s hit points? What actions can they take? What effects do those actions have? Given your mechanics, consider what kinds of things must be on the cards. If your game is based on combat, the cards may need to list combat stats. If your game is based on auctions and trade between players, the cards may need to represent items and their costs. Consider all the ways that cards can be used in a game. They can be shuffled to make a common deck from which players draw. They can be held by players in a closed hand. They can be played in front of a player (face up or face down) to signify ownership. They can be placed in a grid to form a makeshift game board. Think about how you would like to use cards in your game, and what mechanics come from that.

5.设计卡牌。一旦你对游戏的玩法有了大致了解，就可以在每张卡牌上设计内容。这可能是这项挑战中最耗时的部分。首先用铅笔在索引卡上写字，这样如果某些卡牌看起来太强大、太弱或太混乱，你就可以轻松进行更改。你可能会发现先在一张标准纸上或计算机电子表格上写卡牌更容易，这样你就可以看到所有卡牌并排摆放，并比较它们之间的区别。然后，你可以手动将它们转移到纸上或打印出来。   

5.    Design the cards. Once you have a general idea of how the game works, create the content on the individual cards. This is likely to be the most time-consuming part of this challenge. Start by writing on index cards with a pencil, so that you can easily make changes if certain cards seem too powerful or weak or confusing. You may find it easier to write the cards on a standard piece of paper or in a computer spreadsheet first, so that you can see all of the cards next to each other and how they compare to one another. You can then transfer them to paper manually or print them out.

6.创建可交付成果。一定要测试你的游戏，以确保规则完整。   

6.    Create deliverable. Be sure to test your game to make sure that the rules are complete.

变体

Variant

在听你谈论你正在开发的游戏时，营销人员补充说，如果这些卡牌将来能以某种方式融入实际游戏，他会非常高兴。他希望你能修改你计划创建的游戏（如有必要），并向他简要说明如何将其融入 MMO。

In hearing about the game you were working on, the marketing guy adds that he would love it if the cards could somehow work into the actual game in the future. He would like you to modify the game you were planning to create, if necessary, and give him a quick write-up on how exactly you might incorporate it into the MMO.

挑战 3——二战：桌面角色扮演游戏

CHALLENGE 3—WWII: THE TABLETOP RPG

您的小组已被选中创建一款入门级纸笔类 RPG，类似于《龙与地下城》，但使用历史视频游戏作为参考点。高中生将使用您的游戏来促进学习。

Your group has been selected to create an introductory-level pencil and paper RPG similar to Dungeons & Dragons, but using a historical video game as your point of reference. Your game will be used by high-school students to facilitate learning.

该项目有具体限制：

There are specific constraints on this project:

1.你应该能够在一小时内玩完整个游戏   

1.    You should be able to play a full game in one hour

2.角色创建需要非常快，但应该允许一定程度的定制   

2.    Character creation needs to be really quick, but should allow some degree of customization

3.游戏应该包含一个“战役”，供 4 到 6 名玩家组队参与，并有一名“裁判”（通常称为“游戏管理员”或“GM”）负责主持游戏、解释规则并决定玩家的行为。战役实际上相当于电子游戏中的任务或探索。   

3.    The game should come with one “campaign” for a group of four to six players, with one “referee” (often referred to as the “game master,” or “GM”) who runs the play session, interprets rules, and resolves player actions. A campaign is effectively the video-game equivalent of a mission or a quest.

4.游戏需要制定规则来处理玩家在战役过程中可能遇到的情况。那么，玩家要做什么？你又如何确定他们在这些任务中是否成功？   

4.    The game will need rules to handle the situations in which players may find themselves during the campaign. So, what do players do, and how can you determine their success in those tasks?

所需组件

Components Required

·一款历史类电子游戏     

·      A historical video game

·熟悉传统 RPG 系统或愿意学习该系统     

·      Familiarity with a traditional RPG system or the willingness to learn about one

可交付成果

Deliverable

·角色生成系统     

·      Character-generation system

·必要时可采用对抗系统     

·      Confrontation system, if necessary

·必要时其他系统     

·      Other systems, as necessary

·活动     

·      Campaign

·游戏管理员规则     

·      Game master rules

建议流程

Suggested Process

1.选择一款视频游戏。具有强大叙事的游戏比专注于快节奏战斗的游戏更容易转换。此外，具有强大角色发展（例如，升级和角色进步）的游戏很有可能在转换过程中保持乐趣。   

1.    Choose a video game. Games with a strong narrative are easier to convert than games that focus purely on fast-paced combat. Furthermore, games with strong character development (for example, leveling and character progression) have a good chance of surviving the conversion with fun intact.

2.选择并设计战役中的角色和场景。玩家角色 (PC) 是谁？他们的目标是什么？他们是要相互合作还是相互对抗？确定角色需要哪些统计数据以及这些统计数据的用途。例如，力量可用于确定角色推开锁着的门的能力。为了应对这一挑战，建议您保持简单。   

2.    Choose and design the characters and setting for your campaign. Who are the player characters (PCs)? What are their goals? Are they meant to cooperate with each other or work against each other? Determine which statistics characters need and what these statistics are for. For instance, strength might be used to determine a character’s ability to shove open a locked door. For the sake of this challenge, it’s recommended you keep it simple.

3.为生物或敌人创建一个模板（如果适用）。你的敌人会拥有哪些属性？如果一个角色与其中一个敌人正面交锋，你会如何解决局面，以确定结果，如果有必要，谁会在激烈的战斗中获胜？   

3.    Create a template for creatures or enemies, if applicable. What stats will your enemies have? If a character went head to head with one of these enemies, how would you resolve the situation to determine the outcome and, if necessary, who wins in violent combat?

4.如果适用，请为物品创建模板。物品将具有哪些属性？它们只是造成伤害、保护免受伤害，还是具有特定的特殊能力？   

4.    Create a template for items, if applicable. What stats will items have? Do they just do damage, protect from damage, or have specific special powers?

5.创建机制。你希望 PC 在游戏世界中做哪些事情来实现他们的目标？列出清单。对于清单上的每一项，确定该动作是否有任何限制（例如，你可能决定玩家只有在有弹药的情况下才能开枪）。对于可能失败（从一个屋顶跳到另一个屋顶而不掉下来）或有争议（试图赢得一场手臂摔跤比赛）的动作，决定如何解决这些动作是成功还是失败。这可能涉及运气（例如掷骰子）或角色统计数据或两者的某种组合。任何 PC 都可以做其他 PC 无法做的事情吗？考虑为角色添加这些特殊能力，并明确定义触发使用它们的条件。   

5.    Create the mechanics. What kinds of things do you expect the PCs to do in the game world in order to accomplish their goals? Make a list. For each item on the list, decide if there are any limitations on that action (for example, you might decide that players can only shoot their guns if they have ammunition). For actions that can fail (leaping from one rooftop to another without falling) or be contested (trying to win an arm wrestling match), decide how these actions will be resolved to success or failure. This could involve luck (such as the rolling of dice) or character stats or some combination of the two. Can any of the PCs do something that none of the other PCs can do? Consider adding these special abilities to the characters and defining exactly what conditions trigger their use.

6.写下战役的细节。这可能包括每个玩家的角色表，以及 GM 的一套战役说明和规则。它可能包括其他内容，具体取决于您的特定游戏。   

6.    Write down the details of the campaign. This probably includes a character sheet for each player, as well as a set of campaign notes and rules for the GM. It may include other things, depending on your specific game.

变体

Variant

最初，老师们要求您设计一款可供 5 到 7 名学生（包括 GM）一起玩的游戏，并认为他们会将班级分成多个小组，同时运行游戏。现在他们改变了主意，他们更希望设计一款可供 20 到 25 名学生一起玩的大型游戏，由老师担任唯一​​的 GM。

Originally, the teachers asked you to create a game that could be played with a group of five to seven students total (including the GM), figuring that they would divide their classes into small groups that ran the game concurrently. Now they’ve changed their minds, and they would prefer a game that could be played with an entire class of 20 to 25 students in a single large game, with the teacher as sole GM.

创建一个适合如此多玩家的系统非常困难。你不希望个别学生在等待其他玩家轮流时感到无聊。你能想到任何允许学生同时轮流的机制吗？

Creating a system suitable for that many players is difficult. You don’t want individual students to get bored while they’re waiting for other players to take their turns. Can you think of any mechanics that would allow students to take their turns simultaneously?

挑战 4 — TWITCH 棋盘游戏？

CHALLENGE 4—TWITCH BOARD GAMING?

如果你正在制作一款在线回合制策略游戏的棋盘游戏版本，这通常相当容易。但是如果你正在制作一款激烈的实时动作游戏版本呢？此时，新手设计师会耸耸肩说这是不可能的。自然，这让他们很难走上相反的方向——为动作游戏创建棋盘游戏原型。

If you’re creating a board-game version of an online turn-based strategy game, that’s usually pretty easy. But what if you’re making a version of an intense real-time action game? At this point, novice designers shrug and say it can’t be done. Naturally, this makes it difficult for them to go in the opposite direction—creating a board-game prototype for an action game.

事实证明，将实时游戏转换为回合制游戏并不那么困难。假设一个“回合”由半秒的实时游戏时间组成（足以移动或转动一小段距离或执行射击等动作）。您可以同时进行回合（所有玩家秘密宣布他们的行动，然后一次揭示并解决一个问题）以营造不确定性的感觉。

It turns out that converting real-time games to turn-based is not all that difficult. Suppose that one “turn” consists of, say, half a second of real-time play (enough to move or turn a short distance or perform an action like shooting). You can make turns simultaneous (all players declaring their actions secretly, then revealing and resolving one at a time) to give the feel of uncertainty.

如果实时游戏没有棋盘，而是有一张没有整齐划分成正方形或六边形的大地图怎么办？你只需自己划分地图即可。如果你将两者进行比较，就会立即明白其中的原因，大多数设计师更喜欢每个空间都是六边形而不是正方形的棋盘。

What if the real-time game doesn’t have a board, but has instead a large map that isn’t neatly divided into squares or hexes? All you have to do is divide the map yourself. For reasons that will become immediately apparent if you compare the two, most designers prefer boards where each space is a hex rather than a square.

一些著名的实时游戏已被改编成成功（且有趣）的商业棋盘游戏，包括《DOOM》、《魔兽争霸 3：混乱之治》和《魔兽世界》。所以，这绝对是可以做到的。

Several well known real-time games have been converted into successful (and fun) commercial board games, including DOOM, Warcraft 3: Reign of Chaos, and World of Warcraft. So, it can absolutely be done.

对于此挑战，请选择任何尚未有官方棋盘游戏的 FPS、RTS 或 MMORPG。设计将该游戏转换为棋盘游戏的文字转换。

For this challenge, choose any FPS, RTS, or MMORPG that does not already have an official board game based on it. Design a literal conversion of that game to a board game.

所需组件

Components Required

·用于研究的互联网连接     

·      Internet connection for research

·棋盘游戏原型的材料     

·      Materials for a board-game prototype

·您决定模拟的视频游戏的副本（可选，但推荐）     

·      A copy of the video game you decide to emulate (optional, but recommended)

可交付成果

Deliverable

·可玩的棋盘游戏原型     

·      Playable board-game prototype

·完整的书面规则     

·      Complete set of written rules

建议流程

Suggested Process

1.选择游戏。显然，如果可能的话，你应该选择一款你玩过并且熟悉的游戏。检查 boardgamegeek.com 以确保没有棋盘游戏版本。   

1.    Choose your game. Obviously, you should choose a game that you have played and are familiar with, if at all possible. Check boardgamegeek.com to make sure that there is no boardgame version.

2.选择合适的目标。对于 RTS，在棋盘游戏版本中消灭其他玩家是一个合理的目标。对于 FPS，请查看多人游戏模式（死亡竞赛、夺旗游戏等），并选择一个游戏模式作为棋盘游戏的基础。对于 MMORPG，选择游戏的一个方面（例如单个地牢或一系列简短的任务）作为棋盘游戏的重点。   

2.    Choose a suitable goal. For an RTS, eradicating the other player is a reasonable goal in a board-game version. For an FPS, look at multiplayer modes (death match, capture-the-flag, and so on) and choose one game mode on which to base your board game. For an MMORPG, choose one aspect of the game (a single dungeon or a short series of quests, for example) as the focus of your board game.

3.机制清单。列出你选择的视频游戏中所有相关的机制。如果你对游戏不是很熟悉，你可能不知道这些机制。在这种情况下，请查阅官方策略指南（如果你有的话）、玩演示版或在线查找常见问题解答。   

3.    Mechanics inventory. Make a list of all relevant mechanics in the video game that you choose. If you are not intimately familiar with the game, you may not know the mechanics. In this case, consult an official strategy guide (if you own one), play a demo, or look online for a FAQ.

4.机制转换。一次将视频游戏的机制转换为棋盘游戏的表示。在某些情况下，原始机制会非常复杂（毕竟计算机可以实现这一点），您可能希望通过删除或合并一些统计数据并减少数字范围来简化事情。请随意尝试这种方法，因为它可能会简化您的游戏玩法。   

4.    Mechanics conversion. One at a time, convert the mechanics of the video game to your board-game representation. In some cases, the original mechanics will be extremely complicated (computers enable this, after all) and you may want to simplify things by removing or combining some stats and reducing numeric ranges. Feel free to experiment with this, as it will likely streamline your gameplay.

5.制作原型、进行游戏测试和迭代。制作一个简单的游戏板。您只需在一张白纸上画画，或者您可以在网上找到一个六角网格并打印出来即可。对于棋子，您可以从您拥有的其他游戏中寻找棋子和骰子等组件，或者您可以将索引卡切成小方块。如果您选择后者，请注意不要在游戏中打喷嚏。玩游戏并根据需要修改规则。您的目标是让游戏可玩且有趣，并获得一套完整的规则。   

5.    Prototype, playtest, and iterate. Make a simple game board. You can do this by simply drawing on a blank piece of paper, or you can find a hex grid online and make printouts. For pieces, you can scavenge components like pawns and dice from other games that you own, or you can cut up index cards into small squares. If you do the latter, be careful not to sneeze during a game. Play the game and modify the rules as needed. Your objective is to make the game playable and fun and get a complete set of rules.

6.创建可交付成果。   

6.    Create deliverable.

铁人设计师挑战赛 5 — 你喜欢玩这个游戏吗？（直播）

IRON DESIGNER CHALLENGE 5—WOULD YOU LIKE GAMES WITH THAT? (LIVE)

汉堡王游戏机的成功让其他一些广告商认为“广告游戏”或许有些道理。但是，您的客户已经创建了一款可在其网站上在线使用的广告游戏，并且没有资金资助另一个团队来创建另一款数字游戏。

The success of the console Burger King games has made some other advertisers think that maybe there is something to the whole “advergame” thing. Your client has already created an advergame available online at his Web site, however, and doesn’t have the money to fund another team for another digital game’s creation.

在本次练习中，他们希望您制作一款棋盘游戏，该游戏将在所有销售其产品的零售店免费赠送。由于是免费赠送，因此需要将其包装在 12.9 英寸的马尼拉信封中，并且除了卡片纸外不包含任何其他物品。但是，产品的设计完全由您决定。不过，他们确实希望您能整合其数字游戏的一些组件。

For this exercise, they want you to create a board game that will be given away at all retail locations that stock their product. Because it will be given away, it needs to be packaged in a 12 9-inch manila envelope, and contain nothing other than cardstock paper. However, the design of the product is totally up to you. They do hope, however, that you will integrate some components of their digital game.

如果与另一个团队竞争，您可以为您的对手选择一个广告游戏，并让他们为您选择一个。

If competing against another team, you may choose an advergame for your opponents, and have them choose one for you.

所需组件

Components Required

·互联网（用于研究）。     

·      Internet (for research).

·      几张信纸大小的卡片纸（任意重量）马尼拉信封

·      Several sheets of letter-size card stock (any weight) Manila envelope

可交付成果

Deliverable

·棋盘游戏或纸牌游戏     

·      Board game or card game

·最终马尼拉信封包装     

·      Final manila envelope packaging

·描述游戏玩法的书面规则     

·      Written rules that describe the play of the game

建议流程

Suggested Process

1.研究。如果你不熟悉你被分配的广告游戏，那就去玩吧。记下游戏的哪些方面可以很好地转化为实体棋盘游戏或纸牌游戏。   

1.    Research. If you’re unfamiliar with the advergame you’ve been assigned, go and play it. Make note of what aspects of the game would translate well to a physical board or card game.

2.集思广益。想出点子。您是否尝试对原版游戏进行逐字转换？您是否只想转换一些机制，而自己发明其余的机制？或者也许您想完全放弃这些机制，只保留主题？想出一套合适的核心机制。请记住，您的所有游戏组件都是纸板。这会限制您可以做的一些事情，尽管您可能会找到巧妙的解决方法（例如，使用一小叠洗过的、编号的卡片来模拟“掷骰子”）。   

2.    Brainstorm. Come up with ideas. Do you attempt a literal conversion of the original game? Are there just a few mechanics you want to translate, while inventing the rest on your own? Or perhaps you want to scrap the mechanics entirely and only preserve the theme? Come up with a set of core mechanics that fit. Keep in mind that all of your game components are cardboard. This will limit some of the things you can do, although you may find clever workarounds (like using a small deck of shuffled, numbered cards to simulate a “die roll” when you have no dice).

3.创建规则、原型并进行游戏测试。研究一组游戏组件和机制，在白板或一些草稿纸上记下想法，直到你觉得游戏已经完成并可玩。然后创建原型并试用你的新游戏。根据需要修改组件和规则。   

3.    Create the rules, prototype, and playtest. Work on a set of game components and mechanics, jotting down ideas on a whiteboard or some scrap paper, until you’ve got a game that you think is complete and playable. Then create a prototype and take your new game out for a spin. Modify the pieces and the rules as needed.

4.创建可交付成果。由于原型是可交付成果，因此这主要包括将其放入马尼拉信封中并密封。记得写下规则并将其包括在内。   

4.    Create deliverable. Since your prototype is the deliverable, this mostly consists of placing it in the manila envelope and sealing it. Remember to write up the rules and include them as well.

非数字短片

NON-DIGITAL SHORTS

以下列表包含棋盘游戏、纸牌游戏或其他不含数字游戏组件的游戏的创意。它们鼓励您以非数字格式探索非常动态的概念。它们是非数字设计练习的理想选择。

The following list contains ideas for board games, card games, or other games that are free of a digital game component. They encourage you to explore very dynamic concepts in a non-digital format. They are ideal for a non-digital design exercise.

1.创建一个模拟圣诞节礼物制作的棋盘游戏。   

1.    Create a board game that simulates the production of presents at Christmas time.

2.创建一个集换式卡牌游戏，将 100 张不同的卡牌分成 5 包，模拟广播电台的运营。开发某种系统，让您可以争夺听众，并达到梦寐以求的电台排名第一的里程碑。   

2.    Create a collectible card game of 100 different cards separated into packs of five that simulates the running of a radio station. Develop some kind of system that allows you to compete for listeners and reach the coveted #1 station milestone.

3.开发一款包含一些非常非传统元素的游戏，比如强迫您每天只进行一次轮流，或者仅在特定时间进行某些动作。   

3.    Develop a game in any medium that incorporates something exceptionally non-traditional, like forcing you to take only one turn per day or making certain moves possible only at certain times.

4.制作一个模拟视频游戏制作的纸牌游戏。   

4.    Make a card game that simulates the making of a video game.

5.开发一款包含实时组件的基于牌的游戏。例如，虽然玩家可以轮流放下牌，但在某些时候，游戏中会有一个事件（或类似事件）迫使玩家进入实时模式。像Slap Jack这样的游戏就是以同样的方式运作的。玩家轮流翻牌，直到翻出一张 Jack。此时，所有玩家都会进入实时模式，看看谁先打出 Jack。   

5.    Develop a tile-based game that incorporates a real-time component. For instance, though players may take turns laying tiles down, at some point, there is an event in the game (or something similar) that forces players into a real-time mode. Games like Slap Jack work the same way. Players take turns flipping cards until a Jack is revealed. At that point, all players go into a real-time mode to see who hits the Jack first.

6.在任何媒体上创建一款从一开始就设计为包含续集的游戏。因此，其媒体必须允许扩展和包含扩展组件。   

6.    Create a game in any medium that is designed to incorporate sequels right from the get-go. As such, its medium must allow for expansion and incorporation of expansion components.

7.开发一款游戏和一套规则，供最多 50 名玩家在公共场所玩。您可以将团队纳入您的设计中。   

7.    Develop a game and a set of rules to be played in a public place by up to 50 players. You may incorporate teams into your design.

8.选择任何著名的纸牌游戏并开发它的棋盘游戏版本。   

8.    Select any well-known card game and develop a board-game version of it.

9.选择任何知名但最终无聊的棋盘游戏，通过使其基于图块并根据需要添加或删除机制来创造可重玩性和不可预测性。   

9.    Select any well-known but ultimately boring board game and create replayability and unpredictably by making it tile-based and by adding or removing mechanics as necessary.

10.用任何媒介制作一个游戏，模拟交通高峰期人流的起伏。游戏的目标以及玩家数量完全由你决定。

10. Create a game in any medium that simulates the ebb and flow of people during rush hour. The goal of the game, as well as the number of players, is entirely up to you.





第二部分：机会与技巧

Part II: Chance & Skill



 

 

5：机遇因素

5: Elements of Chance

象棋和 围棋等游戏纯粹是战略性的。所有信息都可供所有玩家使用，相同的操作总是会导致完全相同的结果。然而，对于大多数游戏来说，情况并非如此。大多数游戏至少包含一些随机或不可重复的因素。例如，许多纸牌游戏涉及随机洗牌。大多数角色扮演游戏中的战斗包括可变的伤害范围。像石头剪刀布这样的游戏即使没有任何随机机制，其动态也看似随机。本章探讨了游戏的随机性以及设计师如何使用它们。

Games such as Chess and Go are purely strategic. All information is available to all players, and the same actions always end in exactly the same results. For the majority of games, however, this is not the case. Most games contain at least some factors that are random or not repeatable. For instance, many card games involve a random shuffle. Combat in most RPGs includes a variable damage range. A game like Rock-Paper-Scissors has dynamics that appear random, even without any random mechanics. This chapter explores the random aspects of games and how a designer can use them.

游戏中机会的作用（掷骰子？）

THE ROLE (ROLL?) OF CHANCE IN GAMES

为什么这么多游戏都包含运气元素？例如，在设计一款全家都能玩的游戏时，硬核策略游戏不太可能如此成功。另一方面，包含运气元素的游戏更容易被更广泛的受众接受和取胜。归根结底，原因有很多，但每个都是设计师为了创造所需的动态而做出的有意识的决定。

Why do so many games include an element of chance? In creating a game an entire family could play, for instance, a hard-core strategy game is not likely to work so well. On the other hand, games that include an element of luck are approachable and winnable by a wider audience. Ultimately, there are many reasons, but each is a conscious decision by the designer to create the desired dynamics.

延迟或阻止可解决性

DELAYING OR PREVENTING SOLVABILITY

如果整个可能性空间是预先知道的，并且可以加以利用，使得特定玩家在玩得正确的情况下总能获胜（或打平），那么游戏就是“可解的”。井字游戏无法长期保持吸引力的部分原因是它很容易解决。一旦玩家解决了游戏问题，游戏就失去了最初使其成为游戏的部分要素：不确定的结果，为实现目标而奋斗。

A game is “solvable” if the entire possibility space is known ahead of time and can be exploited such that a specific player, playing correctly, can always win (or draw). Part of the reason that Tic-Tac-Toe fails to remain compelling for long is that it can be easily solved. Once a player solves a game, that game loses part of what makes it a game in the first place: an uncertain outcome, a struggle toward a goal.

可解的游戏不一定是坏游戏。国际象棋是可解的，但可能性空间太大，因此仍然具有娱乐性。然而，对于可能性空间足够小、计算机（尤其是人类）可以解决的游戏，必须采取一些措施来保持游戏的新鲜感。添加随机元素是实现这一点的一种方法。它阻止我们掌握游戏，因为做出完全相同的决定可能会导致不同的结果。

Solvable games are not automatically bad. Chess is solvable, but the possibility space is so large that it continues to entertain. For games with small enough possibility spaces to be solvable by a computer (and especially a human), however, something must be done to keep the game fresh. Adding a random element is one way to accomplish this. It prevents us from mastering the game, because making the same exact decisions may lead to different outcomes.

让所有玩家都能参与“竞争性”游戏

MAKING PLAY “COMPETITIVE” FOR ALL PLAYERS

在象棋这样的纯策略游戏中，实力足够强的玩家总是会击败实力较弱的玩家。有些人竞争意识很强，喜欢游戏的这个方面，因为他们知道，如果他们击败了其他玩家，那他们就完全赢得了胜利。同样，如果他们输了，他们知道这是由于他们的失误或其他玩家的技能，而不是随机掷骰子。

In a pure strategy game like Chess, a sufficiently strong player will always beat a weaker player. Some people are competitive enough to enjoy this aspect of games, knowing that if they beat another player that they wholly earned that victory. Likewise, if they lost, they know it was through their error or another player’s skill, not a random roll of the die.

虽然这对某些玩家来说可能没问题，而且游戏玩法引人入胜，但人们不能总是指望两个势均力敌的玩家在同一时间和地点玩游戏。如果所有游戏都靠技巧，那么父母和孩子之间的游戏通常会导致一次又一次泪流满面的失败、无聊或沮丧。较弱的玩家会站起来走开，决心再也不玩这个游戏（或者至少不会和同一个人一起玩）。

While this might be fine for some players and result in compelling gameplay, people can’t always count on two equally matched players being available at the same time and the same place for a game. If all games were all about skill, games between a parent and a child would generally result in tear-laden defeat after tear-laden defeat, boredom, or frustration. The weaker player simply gets up and walks away determined to never play the game again (or at least not with the same person).

随机元素偶尔会让经验不足的玩家获胜（或至少提供优势），这可以通过两种方式让这些玩家更长时间保持兴趣。首先，总有获胜的机会。其次，当玩家可以责怪自己的运气不好时，失败的痛苦就会减轻。

Random elements that occasionally allow a less experienced player to win (or at least offer an advantage) keep these players interested for longer in two ways. First, there is always the chance of victory. Second, the sting of defeat is lessened when a player can blame her own bad luck.

增加多样性

INCREASING VARIETY

不含随机元素的游戏总是以完全相同的方式开始，并且经常会出现某些模式（例如国际象棋中的开局）。因此，玩家在每一场游戏中的体验可能非常相似，并且他们会发现自己做出了相同类型的战略选择。

Games with no random elements always start exactly the same, and certain patterns (such as book openings in Chess) often emerge. As a result, players can have highly similar experiences from one game to another, and they can find themselves making the same kinds of strategic choices.

当引入随机元素时，玩家必须应对各种各样的情况。《卡坦岛》的随机设置让每场游戏的感觉都不同。基于图块的游戏通常允许玩家以几十种不同的方式构建。《Risk》或《Axis & Allies》中的随机战斗要求玩家改变策略，并且当骰子没有按照玩家希望的方式行动时，玩家经常会以非常规或创新的方式进行游戏。以正确的方式添加随机元素可以增加玩家体验的多样性，从而增加游戏的重玩价值。 

When a random element is introduced, players must cope with a wider variety of situations. The random setup of Settlers of Catan makes each game feel different. Tile-based games often allow players to build in dozens of different ways. The random battles in Risk or Axis & Allies require players to change their strategies and often play in unconventional or innovative ways when the dice do not act as one hoped they would. Adding random elements in the right ways can increase the variety of a player’s experience, thus increasing the replay value of a game.  

创造戏剧性时刻

CREATING DRAMATIC MOMENTS

 

 

当玩家精心制定策略，然后不得不依靠掷骰子（或其他方法）来判断他的计划是否成功时，那个关键时刻可能会非常紧张。角色扮演游戏 (RPG)、实时战略游戏 (RTS) 和许多棋盘游戏都依赖这种紧张感。你的治疗法术会在怪物袭击之前到达受伤的伙伴吗？人工智能会让你与两个生物战斗还是一个？玩家会降落在你最近开发的公园广场或木板路上，还是会路过？即使没有策略，在适当的情况下观看随机过程的展开也会非常引人注目 - 看看轮盘赌或掷骰子赌桌上的兴奋程度。偶然性产生的兴奋或紧张程度与玩家对结果的期望成正比。

When a player carefully crafts a strategy and then has to depend on the roll the dice (or what have you) to see if his plan succeeds, that moment of truth can be deliciously tense. Roleplaying games (RPGs), real-time–strategy games (RTSs), and many, many board games rely on this tension for play. Will your healing spell get to your wounded partner before the monster strikes? Will the AI give you two creatures to battle or one? Will the player land on your recently developed Park Place or Boardwalk or just pass it by? Even without strategy, watching a random process play out can be extremely compelling in the right circumstances—witness the excitement at a Roulette or Craps table. The level of excitement or tension created by chance increases in direct proportion to how much one has riding on the results.

增强决策能力

ENHANCING DECISION MAKING

大多数游戏的本质是玩家做出的决定。在纯策略游戏中，玩家拥有完整的信息，并且知道他们所做的每一步的确切结果。由于所有变量都是已知的，因此某些决定并不特别令人兴奋；如果您有机会在国际象棋 中毫无障碍地免费捕获对手的皇后，那么这个决定就没什么意思了，因为有一个明确的“正确”答案。

The essence of most games is the decisions that the players make. In a pure strategy game, players have complete information and know the exact outcome of every move that they make. Since all variables are known, some decisions aren’t particularly exciting; if you have the opportunity to capture your opponent’s queen in Chess for free with no drawbacks, it’s not much of an interesting decision because there is a clear “right” answer.

当游戏中存在随机因素时，不再存在始终正确的策略。某些行动可能失败的可能性很高，但也可能带来巨大的潜在收益，因此它们是一个冒险的选择；其他行动可能是安全的，但收益很小。因此，玩家会分析不同的行动、它们的相对风险和收益，并根据他们在游戏中的感知位置来权衡它们。由于存在未知因素，决策变得更加复杂，因此也更加引人注目。

When random elements exist in a game, there is no longer a strategy that is always right. Some moves might have a high chance of failure but also a big potential payoff, making them a risky choice; other moves might be safe but with only a small gain. A player thus analyzes the different moves, their relative risks and benefits, and weighs them with respect to their perceived position in the game. Since there are unknown elements, the decisions become more complicated and thus more compelling.

机遇机制

MECHANICS OF CHANCE

有很多方法可以为游戏添加随机性。这里讨论了一些较常见的方法。

There are many ways to add randomness to a game. A few of the more common ways are discussed here.

骰子

DICE

骰子有多种形状和大小。标准骰子有六面，但有些骰子有 4、8、10、12、20、30 甚至 100 面。投掷一个骰子会产生一个介于 1 和骰子面数之间的随机数，每个数字都有相同的概率被投掷。投掷 1d10（一个十面骰子）有相同的概率产生从 1 到 10 的任何值。因此，投掷一个骰子几乎是你能得到的最随机的。

Dice come in many shapes and sizes. Standard dice have six sides, but some dice have 4, 8, 10, 12, 20, 30 or even 100 sides to them. Rolling a single die creates a random number between 1 and the number of faces on the die, with each number having an equal chance of being rolled. Rolling 1d10 (a single ten-sided die) has an equal chance of producing any value from 1 to 10. As such, rolling a single die is about as random as you can get.

通过投掷多个骰子并将它们加在一起，结果不再是同样随机的。中间的数字投掷得更频繁，而两端的数字很少投掷。投掷的频率变得类似于“钟形曲线”。例如，当投掷 2d6（两个六面骰子加在一起）时，最常见的投掷结果是 7，而最不常见的是 2 和 12。涉及的骰子越多，结果越偏向中心（因此随机性降低）。每个骰子的面数越多，范围越大（因此随机性增加）。

By rolling multiple dice and adding them together, the result is no longer equally random. The numbers in the middle are rolled more frequently while the numbers at the extreme ends are rolled only rarely. The frequency of rolls becomes similar to a “bell curve.” For example, when rolling 2d6 (two six-sided dice added together) the most common roll is 7, while the least common are 2 and 12. The more dice involved, the more heavily the result skews towards the center (thus randomness is decreased). The greater the number of faces on each die, the greater the range (thus randomness is increased).

骰子是少数几种随机机制之一，之前的结果不会影响未来的结果。无论掷出多少次 1d8，下一次掷出的结果仍然有相等的概率在 1 到 8 之间。即使前 10 次掷出的都是 5，下一次掷出的也是 5 的概率也恰好是 1/8——不多也不少。赌徒经常忽略这一事实，并假设骰子是“热”还是“冷”，这是游戏设计师不能犯的谬论。虽然这似乎与上一段讨论的“钟形曲线”相反，但请记住，单次掷骰只是有掷出特定数字的概率，而不是确定性。之前的掷骰永远不会影响未来的掷骰。

Dice are one of the few random mechanics where previous results do not influence future ones. No matter how many times 1d8 is rolled, the next roll still has an equal chance of being anywhere between 1 and 8. Even if the previous 10 rolls were all 5, there is still exactly a 1 in 8 chance that the next roll will be 5 also—no more, no less. Gamblers often ignore this fact and assume that the dice are “hot” or “cold,” a fallacy that game designers cannot afford to make. While this may seem contrary to the “bell curve” discussed in the previous paragraph, keep in mind that an individual roll merely has a probability of rolling certain numbers, not a certainty. Previous rolls never influence future ones.

牌

CARDS

纸牌是用途极为广泛的游戏元素。纸牌可以洗牌，随机排列。纸牌可以面朝下放在桌上，使所有玩家都无法看到纸牌信息。纸牌也可以发给只能看自己纸牌而不能看别人纸牌的玩家，让每个玩家都获得特权信息。

Cards are wonderfully versatile game elements. They can be shuffled, randomizing their order. They can be played face-down on the table, making their information hidden from all players. They can also be dealt to players who can only look at their own cards and no one else’s, giving each player privileged information.

卡牌可以用作资源，可以放在手中、堆成堆，也可以放在单个玩家面前的某个区域。它们还可以用来跟踪游戏信息，而不会增加随机性。人们甚至用它们作为投射物来确定起始位置。

Cards can be used as resources, either by being kept in a hand, in a pile, or played in an area in front of an individual player. They can also be used to track game information without adding randomness. People have even used them as projectiles to determine a starting location.

由于任何游戏中的牌数量都是有限的，因此揭示一张牌会影响其他牌的概率。例如，在赌博游戏Blackjack中，剩余牌堆中人头牌比例高对玩家有利，人头牌较少则对庄家有利。随着从牌堆中发出的牌越来越多，人头牌与其他牌的比率会不断变化。如果玩家连续收到 10 张人头牌，则再次获得人头牌的概率会降低（与骰子不同）。当所有牌都收集起来并重新洗牌后，概率会重置。有些纸牌游戏甚至包含一张在抽牌后强制立即重新洗牌的牌 — — 一种随机改变牌堆随机性的方式！请注意，如果每次抽牌后都重新洗牌，则从一副n张牌中抽出一张牌相当于掷一个n面的骰子。

Since there is a finite number of cards included with any game, revealing a card affects the probability of other cards. For example, in the gambling game Blackjack, a high proportion of face cards in the remaining deck favors the players; fewer face cards favor the dealer. This ratio of face cards to other cards changes over time as more cards are dealt out of a deck. If a player receives 10 face cards in a row, the probability of getting another decreases (unlike dice). The probabilities are reset when all cards are collected and reshuffled. Some card games even include a card that forces the deck to be reshuffled immediately when it is drawn—a way of randomly varying the amount of randomness in the deck! Note that if the deck is reshuffled after every draw, drawing a single card from a deck of n cards is equivalent to rolling a die with n sides.

伪随机数生成器

PSEUDO-RANDOM–NUMBER GENERATORS

尽管计算机拥有强大的处理能力，但它仍然由非随机指令驱动；大多数计算机不可能产生真正的随机数。不过，计算机有许多常用算法来产生所谓的“伪随机”数——从技术上讲，伪随机数并非随机数，但对于大多数游戏来说，伪随机数已经足够接近随机数了。

For all their processing power, computers are still driven by nonrandom instructions; it is impossible for most computers to produce a truly random number. However, there are plenty of algorithms in common use for computers to produce what is geekily called a “pseudo-random” number—a number that is technically not random, but that is close enough for the purposes of most games.

计算机可以生成各种类型的伪随机数，如果设计师想在游戏中加入一定数量的机会，那么它们就非常灵活。例如，要在 Microsoft Excel 中创建伪随机数，请输入=RAND()*5+1

Computers can generate pseudo-random numbers of every type imaginable, making them extremely versatile if a designer wants to include defined amounts of chance to a game. For instance, to create a pseudo-random number in Microsoft Excel, enter =RAND()*5+1

在单元格中输入 并将单元格格式化为显示零小数。结果将模拟 d6 掷骰。必须小心确保生成的数字足够随机；本书的一位作者曾经玩过一款在线纸牌游戏，结果发现使用的洗牌方法更倾向于出现在牌堆顶部的某些牌。

in a cell and format the cell to show zero decimals. The result will simulate a d6 roll. Care must be taken to ensure that the numbers generated are sufficiently random; one of the authors of this book once worked with an online card game only to discover that the card shuffling method used favored certain cards over others appearing at the top of the deck.

隐藏信息

HIDDEN INFORMATION

即使非随机信息对玩家隐瞒，从玩家的角度来看它仍然是随机的。例如，在儿童纸牌游戏Go Fish中，玩家必须向另一位玩家索要一张所选类型的牌。如果没有任何其他信息，这开始只是随机猜测，即使对手手中的牌对对手而言并不是随机的。（他们清楚地 知道自己手中有什么。）RTS 游戏通常包含“战争迷雾”，以隐藏对手正在建造什么的信息。即使没有任何其他随机性，如何最好地应对未知威胁的不确定性也会产生随机动态。在石头剪刀布游戏中也可以看到类似的动态，尤其是在与伪随机数生成器而不是人类对战时。

When nonrandom information is concealed from the players, it is still random from the player’s perspective. For example, in the children’s card game Go Fish, a player must ask another player for a card of a chosen type. Without any further information, this starts out as a random guess, even though the cards in the opponent’s hand are not random as far as the opponent is concerned. (They know exactly what they have.) RTS games often include a “fog of war” that conceals information about what the opponents are building. Even without any other randomness, the uncertainty of how best to respond to the unknown threats creates random dynamics. Similar dynamics are seen in Rock-Paper-Scissors, especially if played against a pseudo-random–number generator instead of a human.

如果隐藏信息也是随机的（例如，某种武器造成的随机伤害量完全未知），玩家就有感到困惑或沮丧的危险。玩家应该能够理解其行为的后果，并能够形成某种程度的策略，将游戏中的随机元素考虑在内。如果系统对他们隐藏，他们理解游戏的任务就会困难得多。在制作游戏（尤其是视频游戏）时，设计师在加入未向玩家显示的随机机制时要小心谨慎。

When hidden information is also random (such as a weapon that deals a completely unknown amount of random damage), there is the danger of the player becoming confused or frustrated. Players should be able to understand the consequences of their actions and be able to form some degree of strategy that takes into account the random elements of the game. If the systems are hidden from them, their task of understanding the game is much more difficult. When making a game, especially a video game, designers are careful when including a random mechanic that is not displayed to the player.

其他游戏内容

OTHER GAME BITS

大多数其他形式的随机性都是上述随机性的变体。旋转器（通常在儿童棋盘游戏中使用，您可以旋转箭头并查看箭头指向的位置）的作用与骰子相同。抛硬币本质上与掷两面骰子相同。陀螺产生的结果与四面骰子相同。从袋子中抽出的纸板牌（在许多欧洲游戏中很受欢迎，例如卡卡颂和底格里斯河与幼发拉底河）提供的随机性与一副牌相似。

Most other forms of randomness are variants of the above. Spinners (often found in children’s board games, where you spin an arrow and see what it points to) behave just like dice. Flipping a coin is essentially the same as rolling a two-sided die. A dreidel produces the same result as a four-sided die. Cardboard tiles drawn from a bag (popular with many European games such as Carcassonne and Tigris & Euphrates) provide similar randomness to a deck of cards.

并非所有随机性都是平等的

ALL RANDOMNESS IS NOT CREATED EQUAL

考虑一下这个问题：扑克是运气游戏还是技巧游戏？当然，两者都有，但哪个占主导地位？事实证明，答案取决于玩了多少手牌。

Consider this question: Is Poker a game of luck, or a game of skill? There are certainly elements of both, but which dominates the game? It turns out that the answer depends on how many hands are played.

如果手牌数量较少，那么一名玩家可能比其他玩家拿到更多的获胜手牌，从而获得基于运气的优势。如果玩的手牌越来越多，那么每位玩家最终拿到的获胜手牌总数将大致相同，游戏的焦点将转移到谁能从每手获胜手中赚到最多的钱。同样的游戏变成了一场技巧游戏。

For a small number of hands, it is likely that one player will be dealt more winning hands than the others, giving them a luck-based advantage. If more and more hands are played, each player will end up with about the same total number of winning hands, and the focus of the game shifts to who can maximize the money that he earns from each winning hand. The same game shifts to a game of skill.

此示例说明了纯随机游戏与所谓的“可测量随机性”之间的区别，在“可测量随机性”中，随机元素的性质是已知的，并且可以由玩家规划。每手牌（或掷骰子或旋转轮盘）可能都是随机的，但如果数量足够多，随机性就会降低。

This example illustrates the difference between a purely random game and what is called “measured randomness,” where the nature of the random elements are known and can be planned for by the players. Each individual hand (or die roll or spin of the wheel) may be random, but with a sufficiently large number of them, the randomness decreases.

完全随机的游戏

COMPLETELY RANDOM GAMES

除少数例外，大多数游戏（即使是那些主要由运气决定胜负的游戏）都至少包含一些技巧成分。第 8 章“机会与技巧：寻找平衡”介绍了如何调整运气与技巧之间的平衡。有没有完全随机、完全没有技巧成分的游戏？当然有。

With few exceptions, most games—even those whose winner is primarily determined by luck—have at least some small component of skill. Modifying the mix between luck and skill is covered in Chapter 8, “Chance and Skill: Finding the Balance.” Are there any games that are completely random, with no elements of skill at all? Absolutely.

有两种类型的游戏完全依赖运气：儿童游戏和赌博游戏。这并不是说所有儿童游戏或赌博游戏都不需要技巧；许多此类游戏也包含技巧元素。但如果你发现一款纯粹依赖运气的游戏，那么它很可能就是这两种游戏之一。

There are two general kinds of games that involve pure chance: children’s games, and gambling games. This is not to say that all children’s or gambling games involve no skill at all; many of these games contain skill elements as well. But if you find a game that is pure chance, it is probably one of these two types of games.

儿童游戏

CHILDREN’S GAMES

年幼的孩子还没有发展出理解更具战略性的游戏中复杂决策所需的认知技能，他们喜欢玩纯粹靠运气的游戏——观察随机元素碰撞时会发生什么。讽刺的是，许多孩子会将此归功于他们自己掷骰子或选对牌的“技能”。例子包括棋盘游戏《Chutes & Ladders》和《Candy Land》，纸牌游戏《War》和《Old Maid》，以及骰子游戏《Thunderstorm》 （请参阅第 6 章“‘战略’技能要素”挑战 1 中的规则）。在这些游戏中，决策相当有限。你根据随机结果执行游戏指示的操作。

Young children who have not developed the cognitive skills necessary to understand complex decision-making in more strategic games enjoy the games of pure luck—watching what happens as the random elements collide. Ironically, many children will attribute this to their own “skill” in rolling dice or selecting the right cards. Examples include the board games Chutes & Ladders and Candy Land, the card games War and Old Maid, and the dice game Thunderstorm (see Chapter 6, “Elements of ‘Strategic’ Skill,” Challenge 1 for rules). In these games, the decision making is rather limited. You do what the game tells you to do based on the random outcome.

对儿童有吸引力的运气游戏往往会形成一定的紧张感，并通过随机事件化解，比如《战争》中的“战争”或《雷雨》中随着骰子越来越少而越来越难的掷骰子。它们还允许命运的突然变化，比如《蛇梯棋》中的特殊空间会导致玩家突然前进或后退，或者《老处女》中玩家抽到一张危险的牌后突然处于输掉的境地。最后，这些游戏允许总是后来居上并获胜的可能性，所以最终结果永远是不确定的。这就是《蛇梯棋》规则的目的，要求玩家准确地落在最后一个空间；无论玩家领先多远，总有可能她继续掷得太高，另一个玩家会赶上来并获胜。

Luck games that appeal to children tend to have a level of building tension that is resolved by a random event, such as the “wars” in War, or the more difficult rolls as the dice get fewer in Thunderstorm. They also allow sudden changes of fortune, such as the special spaces in Chutes & Ladders that cause a player to advance or fall back suddenly, or when a player draws the one dangerous card in Old Maid and is suddenly in a position to lose. Lastly, these games allow the possibility of always coming from behind and winning so that the end result is never certain. This is the purpose for the rule in Chutes & Ladders that requires players to land exactly on the final space; no matter how far ahead a player is, there is always a possibility that she’ll keep rolling too high and another player will catch up and win.

将这些游戏中的运气与《Risk》等游戏中的运气进行比较。在《Risk》中，三张同类型或独特类型的卡牌可以为玩家提供数量不断增加的部队以加入其军队。乍一看，这似乎是一种完全随机的机制。虽然玩家收到的实际卡牌可能是随机的，但玩家何时使用卡牌，甚至最初获得卡牌的方式，都在很大程度上取决于玩家的技能。

Compare the use of luck in these games to the use of luck in a game like Risk. In Risk, three cards of a kind or of a unique kind can provide the player with a progressively increasing number of units to add to her army. At a glance, this seems like a completely random mechanic. While the actual card the player receives may be random, when the player uses the cards, and even the means of gaining the cards in the first place, is heavily dependent upon the player’s skill.

赌博游戏

GAMBLING GAMES

赌博游戏的本质机制是，玩家在游戏中赢钱或输钱。如果没有金钱作为赌注，纯靠运气的赌博游戏很快就会失去吸引力。一些不需要技巧的赌博游戏包括轮盘赌、掷骰子和老虎机。

The defining mechanic of gambling games is that real money is won and lost in the process. Without money at stake, pure-luck gambling games quickly lose their appeal. Some gambling games with no skill aspects are Roulette, Craps, and slot machines.

有趣的是，大多数赌博游戏，即使是纯粹碰运气的游戏，仍然提供选择。玩家可以在轮盘赌中选择一个数字进行下注，在掷骰子中可以选择下注类型，甚至可以选择许多老虎机一次玩多少个硬币（从一枚到三枚或五枚）。游戏可能仍然是完全随机的，但选择元素让玩家产生了控制的错觉，因为不同的选择会导致不同的结果。

It’s interesting to note that most gambling games, even those that are pure chance, still offer choices. Players can choose a number to bet on in Roulette, are offered a choice of betting types in Craps, and are even allowed to choose how many coins to play at a time (from one up to three or five) for many slot machines. The game may still be completely random, but the element of choice gives players the illusion of control, since different choices lead to different outcomes.

那么扑克之类的游戏呢？如前所述，玩的牌越多，随机性就越小。然而，扑克中真正的技巧并非来自抽牌，而是玩家如何处理抽牌。他会拿什么牌？他会下多少赌注？他的虚张声势有多厉害？这些决定与其他玩家的决定相结合，形成了一个基于技巧的游戏场，而不是基于运气的游戏场。

What about games like Poker? As noted earlier, the more hands one plays, the less random it is. The substantial skill in Poker, however, comes not from the draw but from what the player does with that draw. What cards will he hold? How much will he bet? How good is his bluff? Each of these decisions in conjunction with the decisions of the other players factors in to create a skill-based playfield versus a luck-based playfield.

挑战

CHALLENGES

本章中的挑战可让您练习处理各种随机元素。通过以下挑战试试您的运气技巧。

The challenges in this chapter let you practice working with various random elements. Try your skill at making luck with the following challenges.

挑战 1 — 运气棋

CHALLENGE 1—LUCK TAC TOE

让我们从一个简单的游戏开始，井字游戏（在世界某些地方更广为人知的名字是Crosses and Naughts ）。最初的游戏纯粹是一种技巧游戏 — 您决定将 X 或 O 放在哪里。让我们添加一些运气。

Let’s start with a simple game, Tic-Tac-Toe (better known as Crosses and Naughts in some parts of the world). The original game is purely a game of skill—you decide where you want to put the X or the O. Let’s add some luck.

通过添加一个或多个基于机会的机制来修改此游戏。您还可以添加其他基于技能的机制，前提是游戏的核心仍然类似于井字游戏。同时，您必须让游戏适合成年玩家，这是一个重大挑战，特别是因为他们通常对游戏感到厌倦。您上次听到八岁以上的人说“好啊！我们来玩一局井字游戏吧！”是什么时候？

Modify this game by adding one or more chance-based mechanics. You may also add other skill-based mechanics provided that the game still resembles Tic-Tac-Toe at its core. At the same time, you must make the game good for adult players, a significant challenge, particularly since they are often jaded about the game. When’s the last time you heard someone over the age of eight say, “Yeah! Let’s play a game of Tic-Tac-Toe!”

请记住，通过掷骰子来决定将 X 或 O 放在哪里不太可能带来引人入胜的游戏体验。但是，存在一些机制组合，可以让这个老套路再次引人注目。

Remember that rolling a d10 to decide where you place your X or your O isn’t likely to result in riveting gameplay. However, out there exists some combination of mechanics that can make this old standby compelling again.

所需组件

Components Required

·      没有任何

·      None

可交付成果

Deliverable

·      新游戏

·      The new game

·      新游戏的书面规则修改

·      Written rules modification for the new game

·      分析你的修改是否使原始游戏变得更好或更差，以及原因（可选）

·      Analysis of whether your modification makes the original game better or worse, and why (optional)

建议流程

Suggested Process

1.    集思广益并进行游戏测试。有很多方法可以为这款游戏添加运气元素。掷骰子。选择一张牌。牌。选择一种并亲自尝试。注意添加运气对这款游戏的影响。还要注意当您使用不同类型的机会时游戏的玩法有何不同。

1.    Brainstorm and playtest. There are many ways to add an element of luck to this game. A die roll. Selecting a card. Tiles. Select one and try it out against yourself. Notice the effect that adding luck has on this game. Also notice how different the game plays when you use different kinds of chance.

2.    创建可交付成果。

2.    Create deliverable.

挑战 2——GDC CCG

CHALLENGE 2—THE GDC CCG

在每一个游戏行业贸易展上，尤其是游戏开发者大会上，名片经济都十分盛行。陌生人会走到你面前，递给你一张名片，你也会以在会议上很正常的方式把名片递给他们，但如果你在你的家乡街头对陌生人做同样的事情，那就会显得非常恐怖。

At every game-industry trade show, and especially the Game Developers Conference, there is an economy of business cards. Complete strangers walk up to you and give you one, and you give them yours in a way that’s completely normal at a conference and would be completely creepy if you did the same thing to a random person on the street in your hometown.

无论如何，每个人都会带着一叠收集的名片离开。大多数名片大小相同（如果你想知道的话，是 2 3.5 英寸），因此它们堆叠和洗牌都很好。是时候有人用所有这些卡片制作一款值得玩的游戏了。那个人可能是你。

At any rate, everyone leaves with a stack of business cards they’ve collected. Most business cards are the same size (2 3.5-inch, if you’re wondering) so they stack and shuffle well. It’s high time someone made a game worth playing with all of these cards. That someone could be you.

对于这一挑战，请为类似《万智牌》的集换式卡牌游戏 (CCG) 设计规则。您的游戏必须遵守以下限制：

For this challenge, design the rules for a collectible card game (CCG) like Magic: The Gathering. Your game must adhere to the following constraints:

·      仅限两名玩家。

·      Two players only.

·      您的游戏必须支持“构组牌组”格式。也就是说，每个玩家都带来自己收集的一叠名片，并且每个玩家都使用自己的牌组进行游戏。

·      Your game must support “constructed deck” format. That is, each player brings her own stack of business cards she’s collected, and each player plays from her own deck.

·      任何标准尺寸的名片都必须适用于您的游戏。因此，您必须利用名片上通常出现的信息（姓名、电话号码、职位等）。例如，您不能依赖人们在名片上放置特殊图标来支持您的游戏规则。

·      Any standard-size business card must be playable in your game. You must therefore make use of the information that is typically found on business cards (names, phone numbers, job titles, etc.). For example, you cannot rely on people putting special icons on their cards just to support your game rules.

·      由于这是一款收藏 游戏，所以卡牌必须彼此不同。也就是说，在任何给定的牌组中，应该有理由将一张卡牌放在另一张卡牌之上；牌组构建应该是战略性的，而不是随意的。想想在现实生活中，你可能会让某人对新认识的人说：“哇，好卡牌……我可以多拿一张给我的牌组吗？”除此之外，任何事情都可以。

·      Since this is a collectible game, the cards must be distinct from one another. That is, there should be a reason to include one card over another in any given deck; deck building should be strategic and not arbitrary. Think of how you might get someone in real life to say to a new acquaintance, “Wow, nice card... can I have an extra copy for my deck?” Other than that, anything goes.

所需组件

Components Required

·      一叠用于游戏测试的各种名片（可选）

·      A stack of assorted business cards for play-testing purposes (optional)

可交付成果

Deliverable

·      完整的书面规则

·      Complete set of written rules

建议流程

Suggested Process

1.    找到一个起点。对于像这样的开放式挑战，很难知道从哪里开始。部分原因是有太多地方可以开始。选择一个：考虑名片及其包含的信息。您可以为每张卡片分配什么属性？/游戏的主题是什么？正在玩的牌代表什么？/游戏的目标是什么？你如何获胜？/你如何设置游戏？玩家在游戏开始时会做一些特殊的事情（例如洗牌或抽牌），而这些事情以后不会重复？/游戏的进展如何？事情发生的顺序是什么，如何解决？

1.    Find a starting place. For an open-ended challenge like this, it can be hard to know where to begin. This is partly because there are so many places to begin. Pick one: Consider business cards and the information contained on them. What attributes can you assign to each card? / What is the theme of your game? What does a card in play represent? / What is the object of the game? How do you win? / How do you set up the game? Do the players do anything special at the beginning of the game (such as shuffling their decks or drawing cards) that is not repeated later? / What is the progression of play? What is the order that things happen, and how are they resolved?

2.    研究。如果你以前从未玩过 CCG，你可能需要对该类型游戏进行一些研究。玩游戏，或在线阅读一些规则，或与熟悉这些游戏的朋友或同事交谈。

2.    Research. If you have never played a CCG before, you may want to do some research on the genre. Play the games, or read some rules online, or talk with a friend or colleague who is familiar with them.

3.    填写详细信息。上一节中的所有问题都需要回答。先回答一个问题，然后再回答其他问题。

3.    Fill in the details. All of the questions in the previous section need to be answered. After you start with one, work on the others.

4.    游戏测试和迭代。尝试你的游戏，无论是自己玩还是和朋友一起玩。继续调整游戏，直到找到有趣的东西。

4.    Playtest and iterate. Try out your game, either against yourself or with a friend. Continue tuning the game until you have something fun.

5.    创建可交付成果。

5.    Create deliverable.

变体

Variant

为了增加难度，请创建一个除了上面列出的限制之外还符合以下限制的游戏：

For greater difficulty, create a game that conforms to the following constraints in addition to those listed above:

·      由于这款游戏应该可以在 GDC 等大型会议上（或会议结束后）玩，因此规则应该足够简单，以便能够在短时间内教会其他游戏开发者。书面规则不应超过一页，您应该能够在两分钟内亲自解释完整的规则。规则也不应该与 GameLab 的GDC 2008游戏相同，该游戏在本书开始后首次亮相。

·      Since this game should be playable at (or immediately following) a large conference like GDC, the rules should be simple enough to be able to teach another game developer in a short period of time. The written rules should be no longer than a page, and you should be able to explain the complete rules in person in less than two minutes. The rules should also not be the same as GameLab’s GDC 2008 game, which debuted after this book was begun.

·      为了最大程度地提高难度，请添加以下约束：书面规则必须足够短，以适合放在您自己的名片背面。（使用可读的字体大小——使用四号字体来容纳整页规则是不公平的。）

·      For maximum difficulty, add this constraint instead: The written rules must be short enough to fit on the back of your own business card. (In a font size that’s readable—no fair using four-point font in order to fit a full page of rules on there.)

挑战三——第四个轮子

CHALLENGE 3—THE FOURTH WHEEL

大多数棋盘游戏都说“适合 2 到 4 名玩家”，其实他们的意思是指“适合 2到4 名玩家”。三人游戏的设计难度很大，因为它们的动态性很强。如果玩家之间有很多互动，可以互相攻击或帮助，那么两名玩家联手对抗第三名玩家就太容易了。如果互动很少，那么一名玩家领先其他玩家并无人能追上的情况很常见。

When most board games say “for two to four players,” what they really mean is “for two or four players.” Three-player games are difficult to design because of their dynamics. If the players have a lot of interaction and can attack or help each other, it’s often too easy for two players to join forces against the third player. If there’s little interaction, it’s common for one player to pull ahead of the others and be uncatchable.

视频游戏有一个简单的方法来解决这个问题：添加一个由计算机控制的第四个角色（AI）。然而，在棋盘游戏或纸牌游戏中实现类似人类的 AI 则更加困难。让我们采用另一种方法：添加一个完全不切实际、混乱的 AI。

Video games have an easy way of solving this problem: Add a fourth character controlled by the computer (an AI). Implementing a human-like AI in a board or card game, however, is more difficult. Let’s take another approach: Add a completely unrealistic, chaotic AI instead.

对于此挑战，请选择一款支持至少两名、三名和四名玩家（可能更多）的非数字游戏。示例包括Risk、Monopoly和Blokus。为三人游戏创建一套新规则，其中包括第四名随机控制的非人类玩家。这个假玩家的行动必须由一组随机洗牌的牌控制，不受游戏中其他玩家的影响。因此，第四名玩家为游戏增加了运气元素。

For this challenge, choose a non-digital game that supports at least two, three, and four players (and possibly more). Examples include Risk, Monopoly, and Blokus. Create a new set of rules for a three-player game that includes a fourth, randomly controlled nonhuman player. This fake player’s actions must be governed by a set of cards that are randomly shuffled, not influenced by the other players in the game. The fourth player therefore adds an element of luck to the game.

所需组件

Components Required

·      游戏副本

·      Copy of the game

·      索引卡用于控制第四位玩家的行动

·      Index cards to control the fourth player’s actions

可交付成果

Deliverable

·      第四位玩家的一组牌

·      Set of cards for the fourth player

·      修改后的三人游戏规则，使用你的卡牌

·      Written set of rules for a modified three-player game using your cards

建议流程

Suggested Process

6.选择游戏。为了遵循本章的精神，您可以随意选择一款游戏。玩一玩，或者至少通读一下规则，以了解游戏的机制和动态（尤其是在只有三名玩家的情况下）。            

6.             Choose a game. In keeping with the spirit of this chapter, feel free to choose a game randomly. Play it, or at least read through the rules, to get a feel for the mechanics and dynamics of the game (especially when playing with exactly three players).

7.设计卡片。卡片上写着什么？简单指示攻击哪个玩家？打破规则以利于第四个玩家的特殊能力？影响所有玩家规则的随机事件？请记住，第四个玩家做出的所有决定都必须写在卡片上，而不是由人类玩家选择。            

7.             Design the cards. What goes on the cards? Simple instructions on which player to attack? Special abilities that break the rules in favor of the fourth player? Random events that affect the rules for all players? Remember that all of the decisions the fourth player makes must be written on the cards and not chosen by the human players.

8.设计规则。如何玩牌？第四位玩家是否只需每回合抽一张牌并按照其指示操作？是否有几堆牌可供抽取？在什么条件下重新洗牌？            

8.             Design the rules. How are the cards played? Does the fourth player simply draw a card and follow its instructions each turn? Are there several piles of cards that are drawn from? Under what conditions are the decks reshuffled?

9.创建可交付成果。            

9.             Create deliverable.

挑战四——沙漠里的外星人

CHALLENGE 4—THE ALIEN IN THE DESERT

很多机会游戏都专注于骰子或纸牌（从机制上讲，旋转器只是骰子的另一种形式）。非数字游戏中未充分利用的机制是战争迷雾，尽管它是许多视频游戏中的必备元素。如果你的角色看不到它，你也看不到。你将把这个概念应用到一款新的基于图块的游戏《沙漠中的外星人》中。你的游戏必须使用或采用以下内容：

So many games of chance focus on dice or cards (and spinners are just another form of dice, mechanics wise). An under-used mechanic in non-digital games is the fog of war, although it’s a staple in many video games. If your character can’t see it, neither can you. It is this concept you will apply to a new tile-based game, The Alien in the Desert. Your game must use or employ the following:

·与      《卡卡颂》或《卡坦岛》等游戏中使用的瓷砖类似

·      Tiles similar to those used in games like Carcassonne or Settlers of Catan

·      沙漠中的外星人这个名字，虽然它的解释取决于你 

·       The name The Alien in the Desert, although its interpretation is up to you

·      战争迷雾

·      Fog of war

为了实现此效果并创建可玩的原型，您可以采用任何您想要的机制或部件。

To achieve this effect and create a playable prototype, you may employ any mechanics or bits you want.

所需组件

Components Required

·      纸质或木质瓷砖

·      Tiles of either paper or wood

可交付成果

Deliverable

·      可玩的原型

·      Playable prototype

·      制定书面规则

·      Written rule set

建议流程

Suggested Process

1.    集思广益。您必须回答许多问题。这款游戏的名称对您来说意味着什么？如何在实体棋盘游戏中实现战争迷雾机制？如何使用方块？然后是任何非数字游戏都会问的旧问题。游戏的目标是什么？有多少玩家？使用了哪些游戏元素？核心机制是什么？

1.    Brainstorm. There are many questions you must answer. What does the name of this game mean to you? How do you implement fog of war mechanics in a physical board game? How can you use tiles? Then there are the old standby questions to ask for any non-digital game. What is the object of the game? How many players? What game bits are used? What is the core mechanic?

2.    游戏测试和迭代。将一些东西拼凑起来并开始玩。找到游戏中的缺陷并修复它们。获得一些功能齐全、可玩且有趣的东西。与任何游戏一样，如果您觉得自己走错了方向，这可能意味着放弃一切并重新开始几次。

2.    Playtest and iterate. Throw something together and start playing it. Find the broken parts of the game and fix them. Get something functional, playable, and fun. As with any game, this may involve scrapping everything and starting over a few times if you feel you’ve gone in the wrong direction.

3.    创建可交付成果。

3.    Create deliverable.

铁人设计师挑战 5——开放式随机性

IRON DESIGNER CHALLENGE 5—OPEN-ENDED RANDOMNESS

分成 2 到 4 人一组。每组有 100 张空白卡片和一支笔。只用这些卡片制作一个游戏，并使其比其他团队设计的游戏更好。游戏必须包含随机元素，可以是抽牌、翻牌、洗牌等。不过，游戏中不能包含任何骰子，或 100 张卡片以外的任何东西。玩家可以按照自己认为合适的方式塑造或改变卡片。

Break into groups of two to four players. Each group is given 100 blank index cards and a pen. Make a game with only these bits, and make it better than the game that the other teams are designing. The game must include an element of randomness, be it through a draw, card flipping, shuffling, and so on. The game may not include any dice, however, or anything other than the 100 cards. The player may shape or alter the cards any way he or she sees fit.

所需组件

Components Required

·       3 张 5 英寸索引卡

·      3 5-inch index cards

·      钢笔

·      Pens

可交付成果

Deliverable

·      可玩游戏的演示

·      Demonstration of a playable game

建议流程

Suggested Process

1.    集思广益。回到基础。主题。游戏目标。设置。游戏进程。决定其中一个并从那里扩展。

1.    Brainstorm. It’s back to basics. Theme. Object of the game. Setup. Progression of play. Decide on one of these and extend from there.

2.    创建可交付成果。遵循挑战 1 中的其余流程。

2.    Create deliverable. Follow the remaining process in Challenge 1.

变体

Variant

不要使用纸牌，而是使用一大袋骰子（有不同面数）作为唯一的游戏筹码。

Instead of cards, use a large bag of dice (with varying numbers of sides) as the only game bits.

非数字短片

NON-DIGITAL SHORTS

以下列表包含棋盘游戏、纸牌游戏或其他鼓励进一步创造的游戏的想法。

The following list contains ideas for board games, card games, or other games that encourage further creation.

选择一款非常注重技巧的经典纸牌游戏（如尤克牌），并将其重新设计为完全依赖运气。重新设计经典纸牌游戏《战争》，使其至少包含三种不同类型的运气，而不仅仅是洗牌。

Choose a classic card game with a heavy emphasis on skill (such as Euchre) and redesign it to be entirely dependent on chance. Redesign the classic card game War to incorporate at least three different kinds of chance other than the shuffled deck.

在《Risk》中，随机性通过加入掷骰子的方式在战斗中创造戏剧性时刻。重新设计游戏以在游戏的不同阶段（例如增援或防御）创造此类时刻。找出现实生活中偶然发生或受偶然性严重影响的事物。想想偶然相遇或会让人说“我从未想到过！”的事物，然后创建一个重现这种体验的游戏。

In Risk, randomness is used to create dramatic moments during battle by incorporating dice rolls. Redesign the game to create these types of moments during a different stage of the game, such as reinforcement or fortification. Identify something that occurs by chance or is heavily influenced by chance in real life. Think of chance meetings or something that would make someone say, “I never expected it!” Then create a game that re-creates this experience.

设计一款桌面角色扮演游戏，仅使用抛硬币来创造随机性。全世界的父母都在恳求您创建一款既需要技巧又需要运气的游戏——父母需要技巧，孩子需要运气。修改现有的儿童游戏或创建自己的游戏以满足这些要求。

Design a tabletop role-playing game that only uses coin flips to create randomness. Parents the world over are begging you to create a game that involves both skill and chance—skill for them and chance for their kids. Modify an existing kids’ game or create your own that fulfills these requirements.

选择您从本书不同章节的挑战或非数字短片中创建的游戏。将游戏重新设计为完全基于机会或完全没有机会。设计一款基于机会的游戏，使用以下每种类型的骰子：六面、八面、十面、十二面和二十面。

Choose a game you have created from a challenge or non-digital short from a different chapter in this book. Redesign the game to be either entirely based on chance or entirely devoid of chance. Design a game based on chance that uses exactly one of each of the following types of die: six-sided, eight-sided, 10-sided, 12-sided, and 20-sided.

设计一款游戏，使用以下每种机会机制中的一种：洗过的一副牌、发牌和翻牌，以及从袋子中盲抽的牌。使用著名儿童游戏（如Candy Land）的元素来创建赌博游戏。

Design a game using exactly one of each of the following mechanisms of chance: a shuffled deck of cards, tiles dealt and flipped, and tiles blind-drawn from a bag. Use the elements of a well-known children’s game (such as Candy Land) to create a gambling game.

资源

RESOURCES

骰子游戏正确解释，Reiner Knizia（书）

Dice Games Properly Explained, Reiner Knizia (book)

 

 


 

 

6：“战略”技能的要素

6: Elements of “Strategic” Skill

策略对玩家来说具有非常强大的吸引力。事实上，这也是让我们一次又一次回到游戏中的原因。正如 Raph Koster 在其优秀著作《游戏设计的乐趣理论》中指出的那样，我们玩游戏并享受这个过程是因为我们试图掌握游戏中的模式。在掌握模式的同时，玩家也会获得乐趣。他们还会根据对游戏动态的理解制定策略。这种掌握，这种策略的发展，并非偶然。这是设计师通过使用创造策略和战术的机制所期望的（或至少是希望的）。

Strategy is a very powerful draw for players. In fact, it’s what keeps us coming back to games again and again. As Raph Koster notes in his excellent book A Theory of Fun for Game Design, we play games and enjoy the process because we are seeking to master the pattern in the game. While mastering a pattern, players are having fun. They are also forming strategy based on their understanding of the game’s dynamics. That mastery, that development of strategy, isn’t accidental. It’s something the designer intended (or at least hoped for) through the use of mechanics that create strategy and tactics.

如上一章所述，大多数游戏都至少涉及一点技巧。即使是那些看似全靠运气的游戏（如石头剪刀布），也有自己的策略网站。

As noted in the previous chapter, most games have at least a little bit of skill involved. Even games that seem like all luck (like Rock-Paper-Scissors) have their own strategy Web sites.

我们如何在游戏中运用技巧？

How do we use skill in games?

技能在游戏中的作用

THE ROLE OF SKILL IN GAMES

从本质上讲，一款好游戏就是一系列有趣的决策——向右或向左、组建进攻或防守部队、确定你的部队下一步该做什么。决策的成功——无论是心理反应还是身体反应——都是衡量玩家技能的标准。

At its heart, a good game is a series of interesting decisions—go right or left, build an offensive or defensive unit, figure out what your unit should do next. The success of decisions—whether a mental or a physical reaction—is a measure of player skill.

好的游戏会让玩家不断锻炼技能，并给予他们即时而明显的反馈。在整个游戏过程中，玩家会想知道下一步该做什么，下一步该做什么。很快，他就进入了所谓的“魔法圈”——当他穿过显示器或电视进入游戏世界时。这种效果与我们看电影或读一本特别好的书时进入的效果类似，但好的游戏具有更强的吸引力，因为它们将玩家及其决策融入体验中。

Good games cause players to exercise their skills frequently and reward them with immediate and obvious feedback. Throughout play, the player wonders what thing he should do next, and next, and next. Soon, he has entered what’s known as the “magic circle”— when he has fallen through the monitor or TV and into the game world. The effect is similar to the one we enter when we watch a movie or read a particularly good book, but good games have a stronger pull because they integrate players and their decisions into the experience.

当玩家不断做出决定时，他们会进入一种被心理学家和著名研究员米哈里·契克森米哈赖称为“心流”的状态。这是一种最佳的游戏状态，设计师需要努力实现这种状态。契克森米哈赖就这个主题写了一本书，名为《心流：最佳体验心理学》。这本书不仅限于游戏，还从广泛的角度涵盖了这种状态。

When the player is constantly making decisions, he enters a state that psychologist and noted researcher Mihaly Csikszentmihalyi called “flow.” It is an optimal play state and one designers work hard to achieve. Csikszentmihalyi wrote a whole book on the topic, Flow: The Psychology of Optimal Experience. The book isn’t limited to games, but covers this state from a wide perspective.

决策类型

TYPES OF DECISIONS

玩家技能对游戏结果的影响有多大？这取决于游戏允许玩家做出的决定，以及这些决定的重要性。玩家行为对游戏结果的影响程度大致可归类为“技能”（与玩家影响之外的因素，称为“机会”或“运气”）相对。玩家体验主要涉及做出影响游戏状态的决定。因此，专注于玩家体验的游戏设计师应该认真思考这些决定是什么，以及为什么做出这些决定是有趣的、有意思的或引人注目的。如果你做出了选择，但它对游戏状态没有影响，那还有什么意义呢？

How much does player skill influence the outcome of a game? It depends on the decisions the game lets the players make, as well as the weight of those decisions. The extent that the player’s actions affect the outcome of the game is broadly classified as “skill” (as opposed to factors outside of player influence, called “chance” or “luck”). The player experience largely involves making decisions that influence the game state. Therefore, a game designer focusing on the player experience should give a great deal of thought to what these decisions are, and why making them is fun or interesting or compelling. If you make a choice, and it has no effect on the game state, what’s the point?

游戏中有很多种决策。有些决策比其他决策更有趣，因此也更引人入胜。

There are many kinds of decisions found in games. Some decisions are more interesting than others, and therefore offer more compelling play.

显而易见的决定

OBVIOUS DECISIONS

这是一个名为“最高数字游戏”的愚蠢的双人游戏。第一个玩家选择一个数字，任何数字都可以。然后，在听到第一个玩家的选择后，第二个人选择一个不同的数字。谁说出的数字最高谁就赢了。

Here’s a silly two-player game called the Highest Number Game. The first player chooses a number, any number at all. Then, after hearing the first player’s choice, the second person chooses a different number. Whoever says the highest number wins.

对于第二个玩家来说，这不是一个有趣的决定。数字越大获胜，数字越小则输。获胜的决定是显而易见的，所以这根本不是一个决定。这些选择并不特别引人注目，因为除了最佳选择之外，没有理由做出任何其他选择。

This is not much of an interesting decision for the second player. A higher number wins, a lower number loses. The winning decision is obvious, so it’s not much of a decision at all. These choices are not particularly compelling because there is no reason to make any choice other than the optimal one.

您认为现实游戏中不会发生这种情况吗？考虑一下棋盘游戏Talisman，其主要机制是掷骰子，然后沿着轨道移动许多空间，顺时针或逆时针。移动方向当然是一种选择，但很多时候一个空间会伤害玩家，而另一个空间会有所帮助。所以这是一个显而易见的决定。或者考虑一款“轨道” RPG 或 FPS，玩家不断被告知要向哪个方向移动。玩家可能会做出许多决定，但下一步去哪里不是其中之一。这些游戏因许多其他原因而有趣，但不是因为这些显而易见的决定。有些游戏甚至根本不提供任何决定。掷骰子，降落在 Park Place，然后给你的朋友很多钱。通​​常正是在大富翁游戏 的这个阶段，人们开始等待游戏结束。

Think this doesn’t happen in real games? Consider the board game Talisman, where the primary mechanic is rolling a die and then moving along a track that many spaces, either clockwise or counterclockwise. The direction to move is certainly a choice, but much of the time one space harms the player and the other space helps. So it is an obvious decision. Or consider an “on-rails” RPG or FPS where the player is constantly told which direction to move. The player may be making many decisions, but where to go next is not one of them. These games are fun for many other reasons, but not because of these obvious decisions. Some games even offer no decisions at all. Roll the die, land on Park Place, and pay your friend lots of money. It’s often at this stage of Monopoly that people begin waiting for the game to end.

在大多数情况下，如果决策显而易见，设计师可以移除选择并使其自动化。例如，现代 RPG 很少要求玩家休息和进食以补充体力，尽管 20 世纪 80 年代和 90 年代初期的许多 RPG 都要求玩家休息和进食。相反，游戏会通过随时间推移补充体力并完全消除进食的需要来自动完成此操作。一些 FPS 游戏会在武器空弹时自动重新装填。通过自动化琐碎的决策，玩家可以更加专注于有趣的决策。

In most cases where the decision is blindingly obvious, a designer can remove the choice and make it automatic. For example, modern RPGs rarely require players to rest and eat in order to replenish their stamina, although many RPGs from the 1980s and early 1990s did. Instead, the games do this automatically by replenishing stamina over time and eliminating the need to eat entirely. Some FPS games automatically reload the weapon when it’s empty. By automating the trivial decisions, more focus is given to the interesting ones.

另一种选择是做出一个显而易见的决定并增加时间压力，将其从战略决策转变为敏捷性的测试。有关这些快速决策的更多信息，请参阅第 7 章“‘抽搐’技能的要素”。

Another option is to take an obvious decision and add time pressure, changing it from a strategic decision to a test of dexterity. See Chapter 7, “Elements of ‘Twitch’ Skill,” for more information on these fast kinds of decisions.

毫无意义的决定

MEANINGLESS DECISIONS

比一个明显正确答案的选择更令人沮丧的是根本没有正确或错误答案的选择。虽然选择似乎存在，但它对游戏结果没有影响。早期的角色扮演游戏因这一点而臭名昭著。“你想见国王吗？”仆人会问，玩家会得到是/否的选择。如果玩家说是，他就会去见国王。如果玩家说不，仆人会回答，“但你必须去！”玩家无论如何都会见到国王。无论玩家说是或否，他们都会得到同样的待遇，所以选择本身无关紧要。

The only thing more frustrating than a choice with an obvious right answer is a choice with no right or wrong answers at all. Though the choice is seemingly present, it has no effect on the game’s outcome. Early RPGs were notorious for this. “Dost thou wish to see the king?” a servant would ask, and the player would be given a yes/no choice. If the player said yes, he went to see the king. If the player said no, the servant would respond, “But thou must!” and the player would see the king anyway. The player was treated the same whether he said yes or no, so the choice itself was irrelevant.

如果决策之所以有趣是因为它们会影响游戏结果，那么无意义的决策就毫无意义了，因为它们不会影响任何事情。同样，最好将这些决策从游戏中完全消除。

If decisions are interesting because they affect the outcome of the game, then meaningless decisions are not interesting because they don’t affect anything. Again, it’s usually better to eliminate these from the game entirely.
