然而，这有一个警告，那就是玩家的感知。许多现代游戏为玩家提供了叙事选择，而这些选择实际上并不影响游戏的整体结果。然而，由于游戏对他们的回应方式，玩家肯定会感觉到它会影响游戏的整体结果。只有在重玩游戏时，他们才会明显地意识到，他们第一次选择的路线——看起来如此精心设计以适应他们的选择——实际上并没有那么精心设计。然而，在第一次玩游戏时，对选择的感知使这些选择变得有意义。

There is one caveat to this, however, and that caveat is player perception. Many modern games offer players a choice in narrative that doesn’t actually affect the overall outcome of the game. However, the player certainly perceives that it does, due to the way the game responds to them. Only upon replaying the game is it obvious to them that the route they took the first time—the one that seemed so crafted toward their choices—wasn’t actually all that crafted after all. However, on that first play, the perception of choice makes those choices meaningful.

盲目决策

BLIND DECISIONS

在轮盘赌中，玩家可以真正决定押注哪个数字。这个决定并不明显，因为事先并不清楚正确的数字是什么。这个决定并非毫无意义，因为它会影响游戏的结果。但这也不是一个有趣的决定，因为玩家没有信息来作为选择的基础。它完全是随机的；一个数字和其他数字一样好。游戏仍然很吸引人，因为它提供现金作为奖励；如果没有现金，决策本身就一点也不有趣。

In Roulette, the player has a real decision of what number to bet on. The decision is not obvious, because it is not clear ahead of time what the correct number is. This decision isn’t meaningless, as it affects the outcome of the game. But it’s also not an interesting decision, because the player has no information to base her choice on. It’s entirely random; one number is as good as any other. The game is still compelling because it offers cold, hard cash as a reward; remove that, and the decisions themselves aren’t entertaining in the least.

更具战略性的游戏也可能无意中包含这些决策。如果玩家在游戏中接近 NPC 并被给予如何介绍自己的选择（秘密握手、标准问候或展示徽章等），而没有任何附加信息，则必须盲目做出选择。如果玩家之前听说过关于这个 NPC 的一些传闻，或者 NPC 先自我介绍，那么这个决定不仅有趣而且有益。

More strategic games can inadvertently include these decisions as well. If a player approaches an NPC in a game and is given a choice of how to introduce himself (with a secret handshake, a standard greeting, or by showing a badge, etc.) without any additional information, the choice must be made blind. The decision becomes not only interesting but rewarding if the player heard some rumors about this NPC earlier, or if the NPC introduces himself/herself/itself first.

一般来说，只要向玩家提供足够的信息，盲目决策就可以转变为其他类型的决策。顺便说一句，这并不意味着完整的信息。只要玩家有一些信息可以作为选择的基础，决策就不是盲目的。事实上，一些正在进行的决策相当有趣，因为它们会随着时间的推移而随着更多信息的披露而发生变化。

In general, blind decisions can be turned into other kinds of decisions by giving the player enough information. This does not mean complete information, by the way. As long as the player has some information on which to base a choice, the decision is not blind. In fact, some ongoing decisions are quite interesting because they change as more information is revealed over time.

权衡

TRADEOFFS

当玩家没有足够的资源来实现所有目标时，就会发生权衡。有足够的金币来购买更好的武器、更好的盔甲或 新的咒语。追捕逃跑的邪恶巫师或从龙的手中救出公主。雇佣一支步兵大军或建造狮鹫孵化场并增加一些飞行员。带上狙击步枪或AK-47。

A tradeoff happens whenever a player doesn’t have enough resources to accomplish all of his goals. There’s enough gold to either buy a better weapon or some better armor or a new spell. Pursue the escaping evil wizard or save the princess from the dragon. Hire an army of footmen or build a gryphon hatchery and add some fliers. Pack a sniper rifle or an AK-47.

在这场 Boss 战中使用爆炸魔杖，或者留到之后可能更困难的战斗中。这些选择没有明确的“正确”或“错误”，但都有利弊。突然间，感觉这是一个真正的选择，而且是一个重要的选择。

Use the Wand of Explosions on this boss fight or save it for a later, potentially more difficult battle. None of the choices is clearly “right” or “wrong” but all have advantages and disadvantages. All of a sudden it feels like a real choice, and an important one.

如果一个选择比另一个更好，那么这类决定很容易变得显而易见。如果选择是经过权衡的，以至于没有单一的最佳方法总是获胜，那么游戏就被称为平衡的。当游戏提供多种可行的获胜途径，玩家必须根据个人风格和游戏环境因素在它们之间做出选择时，所做的决定就相当有趣。

These kinds of decisions can easily become obvious, if one choice is better than another. A game is called balanced if the choices are weighted so that there is no single best method that always wins. When games offer several viable paths to victory, and players must choose between them based on their personal styles and environmental factors in the game, the decisions made are quite interesting.

困境

DILEMMAS

困境类似于权衡，但当所有选择都会损害玩家时就会发生。例如，在《塞尔达传说》中，玩家可能会遇到一个房间，他们必须支付一些钱或永久降低他们的最大生命值。

A dilemma is similar to a tradeoff, but occurs when all choices will harm the player. For example, in The Legend of Zelda, players could encounter a room where they had to either pay some money or permanently lower their maximum health.

囚徒困境是一个特殊的例子，它是博弈论中的一个著名问题。在囚徒困境中，两个玩家必须独立做出选择：尝试与对方合作或背叛（即在背后捅对方一刀）。如果双方都合作，他们各自都会受到较小的惩罚。如果双方都背叛，他们各自都会受到更重的惩罚。如果一个玩家背叛而另一个玩家合作，那么尝试合作的一方会受到最大惩罚，而背叛的一方则不会受到任何惩罚。这之所以是一个“困境”，是因为无论对手做什么，玩家都可以通过背叛来减少自己的惩罚。然而，通过遵循这种“最优”策略，玩家最终会陷入每个人都背叛的次优境地，这比每个人都合作更糟糕。

A special case is the Prisoner’s Dilemma, a famous problem from game theory. In the Prisoner’s Dilemma, two players have to independently make a choice: attempt to cooperate with the other player or defect (i.e., stab your partner in the back). If both players cooperate, they each pay a minor penalty. If both players defect, they each pay a much heavier penalty. If one player defects while the other cooperates, the one who tried to cooperate pays a maximum penalty while the one who defected gets no penalty at all. The reason this is a “dilemma” is that no matter what the opponent does, a player can reduce his personal penalty by defecting. However, by following this “optimal” strategy, players end up in the suboptimal situation of everyone defecting, which is worse than if everyone cooperated.

囚徒困境的例子可以在许多游戏中找到，尤其是回合制策略游戏。例如，在棋盘游戏《外交》中，棋盘上有几个位置可以为控制它们的玩家提供巨大的战略优势，但这些位置一开始就在两个对立玩家的中间。如果双方玩家合作，他们可以离开这个区域，而不必浪费资源互相争斗，但不战斗的威胁和让对手毫无抵抗地走进来足以让双方玩家在游戏的第一部分陷入毫无意义的战斗。

Instances of the Prisoner’s Dilemma can be found in many games, especially turn-based strategy games. For example, in the board game Diplomacy, there are several locations on the board that give a large strategic advantage to any player who controls them, but the locations start out right in the middle between two opposing players. If both players cooperate, they can leave the area alone and do not have to waste resources fighting each other, but the threat of not fighting and just letting their opponent walk in unopposed is enough to keep both players tied up in a meaningless battle for the first part of the game.

囚徒困境有很多变体。如果玩家遇到一系列这样的决定，而不是只有一个，动态就会发生很大变化。增加多个玩家（这样少数叛逃的玩家会占优势，但太多则对所有人都不利）也会改变情况，特别是如果玩家有能力对叛逃者进行报复。如果玩家不知道谁合作了，谁叛逃了，这同样会改变情况，带来偏执的感觉。

The Prisoner’s Dilemma has many variants. If players encounter a series of these decisions instead of just one, the dynamics change greatly. Adding multiple players (so that a small number of players defecting gets an advantage, but too many hurts everyone) changes things as well, especially if players have the ability to seek retribution against those who defected. If players don’t know who cooperated and who defected, that can likewise change things, bringing in feelings of paranoia.

风险与回报的权衡

RISK VERSUS REWARD TRADEOFFS

风险与回报的权衡是一种权衡形式，即玩家面临一种有多种结果但风险程度不同的情况时，就会发生这种权衡。问题不在于“我想要哪一件正确的事情”，而是“我是否愿意冒着一切风险去获得潜在的巨额回报……或死亡？”

A form of tradeoff, a risk versus reward tradeoff happens when the player finds herself faced with a situation that has multiple outcomes, but whose level of risk is different. It’s not so much a question of “Which one of these right things do I want” but rather, “Am I willing to risk it all for a potentially huge payoff... or death?”

例如，在《文明》 系列中，玩家会做出许多有趣的选择，并且需要做出许多权衡。你会追求军事胜利还是经济胜利？在某个时刻，玩家可能想要攻击邻近的文明。在评估是否发动攻击时，玩家会考虑任务的风险及其潜在回报。在攻击美国人时，玩家是否会获得她迫切想要的某些技术？

For instance, in the Civilization series, players make many interesting choices, and there are many tradeoffs to be had. Will you pursue a military victory or an economic one? At some juncture, the player may want to attack a neighboring civilization. In evaluating whether or not to launch the attack, the player considers the risk of the mission along with its potential reward. In attacking the Americans, will the player gain some technology that she desperately wants?

这类权衡在使用骰子、纸牌或其他随机机制的棋盘游戏中很常见。玩家通常可以选择走一步更安全但回报较少的棋，或者走一步冒险但成功时回报较大（失败时则受罚）的棋。例如，在《西洋双陆棋》中，玩家可以选择是否让一枚棋子暴露在外。如果对手掷得好，就可以吃掉这枚棋子并让玩家退后；否则，玩家在下一轮的棋盘位置会大大改善。另一个例子是《黑桃》，玩家可以叫空牌（试图不拿一手牌）。如果成功，这个叫牌值很多分，如果失败，则会受罚。这个叫牌也很难叫，这意味着通常只有当玩家手牌不寻常，或者他们落后很多，不得不绝望地冒巨大风险时才会叫空牌。在这些游戏中，落后的玩家通常会冒更大的风险以赶上，而领先的玩家则更愿意稳妥行事以保持领先。电视游戏节目《危险边缘》中的玩家也表现出类似的行为。风险与回报之间的这种紧张关系可能会导致一些非常紧张的动态。

These kinds of tradeoffs are common in board games with dice, cards, or other random mechanics. Players often have the option of making a safer move with a smaller reward, or a risky move with a greater reward if it succeeds (and a penalty if it fails). For example, in Backgammon, a player might have a choice of whether to leave a piece exposed. If the opponent rolls well, the piece could be captured and the player is set back; otherwise, the player has greatly improved board position on the following turn. Another example is Spades, where players can bid null (attempting to take no tricks in a hand). This bid is worth a lot of points if it succeeds, and it has a large penalty if it fails. It is also difficult to make, meaning that it is generally bid only when players have unusual hands, or when they are far enough behind that they must take huge risks out of desperation. In these games, typically, a player who is behind tends to take more risks in order to catch up, while a player in the lead prefers to play it safe in order to preserve his lead. Players exhibit similar behavior on the television game show Jeopardy. This tension between risk and reward can lead to some wonderfully tense dynamics.

在角色扮演游戏和 MMO 游戏中，玩家也经常会遇到风险与回报的对决。“如果我试图干掉这个怪物，他可能会把我打得半死。但另一方面，他可能会有一些很棒的战利品。”

Players also frequently encounter risk versus reward in RPGs and MMOs. “If I try to take this creature out, there’s a possibility that he will smear me into the ground. On the other hand, man, he could have some awesome loot.”

决策频率或预期

FREQUENCY OR ANTICIPATION OF DECISIONS

在游戏中设计决策时，设计师有时会忘记玩家决策的频率至关重要。如果玩家每 20 分钟才做一次决策，而不是每秒都做一次，游戏的质量就会受到影响，即使 20 分钟的决策很重要。设计师的目标，最低层次，是让玩家的大脑忙于各种可能性。 《模拟人生》或《文明》系列等游戏非常擅长为玩家提供一系列持续的积极选择。我接下来会做哪一件好事？当然，玩家可以故意决定做一些不利于良好游戏玩法的事情，但他总是有多种积极的前进道路。

In creating decisions in games, designers sometimes forget that the frequency with which the players make decisions is paramount. The quality of a game is affected if the player is only making decisions every 20 minutes versus every second, even if those decisions at the 20-minute mark are significant. A designer’s goal, at its lowest level, is to keep the player’s brain busy with possibilities. Games like The Sims or the Civilization series are excellent at providing the player with a constant series of positive choices. Which one of these good things will I do next? Granted, the player can deliberately decide to do things not conducive to good gameplay, but he always has multiple positive paths forward.

当然，有些情况下，玩家并不需要频繁做出决定，但对已知待决决定的预期会让玩家思考在需要做出决定时自己可以做什么。带有电梯或升降机的 FPS 游戏就是一个完美的例子。尽管玩家在电梯中无法做出选择，但对一系列待决决定的预期足以让她坚持下去。同样，有时通向 Boss 战的隧道有助于营造玩家的焦虑感和叙事张力，从而维持心流状态。

There are some cases, naturally, where decisions are not frequent, but the anticipation of a known pending decision sustains the player with thoughts of what she may do when decision time rears its head. FPS games with elevators or lifts provide a perfect example of this. Although the player cannot make a choice while in the elevator, the anticipation of a pending series of decisions is enough to hold her over. Likewise, the tunnels that sometimes lead up to boss battles serve to build player anxiety and narrative tension and thus sustain a state of flow.

战略与战术

STRATEGY AND TACTICS

游戏玩家和开发者从军事术语中借用了“战略”和“战术”这两个术语，尽管它们经常被误用 - 例如，许多所谓的“实时战略”游戏更注重战术而不是战略。 

Gamers and developers have borrowed the terms “strategy” and “tactics” from military jargon, although they are often misused—for example, many so-called “real-time strategy” games have more of a focus on tactics than strategy.  

从技术上讲，“大战略”是实现最终长期目标（例如，在游戏中取得胜利）的总体手段。大战略由几个支持战略、必须执行的中期目标组成，以实现大战略（例如，在一场大规模战争中，是否打一场特定的战斗是一个战略选择）。“战术”是执行战略时做出的最低级别的微观决策：步兵调动、是否下令空袭以及何时开始射击都是军事战斗期间做出的战术决策。有时，游戏设计师将这些称为宏观和微观选择。

Technically, a “grand strategy” is the overarching means to achieving an ultimate, long-term goal (for example, a victory in a game). A grand strategy consists of several supporting strategies, intermediate goals that must be performed in order to achieve the grand strategy (for example, in a large war, the choice of whether to fight a particular battle is a strategic choice). “Tactics” are the lowest-level micro-decisions made when carrying out a strategy: infantry maneuvers, whether to order an air strike, and when to start firing are tactical decisions made during a military battle. Sometimes, game designers refer to these as macro- and micro-choices.

非正式地说，游戏中的玩家在进行长期规划时会做出战略决策（“长期”是相对于游戏长度而言的），而在实现短期目标时会做出战术决策。

Informally, players in a game make strategic decisions when they are planning for the long term (where “long” is relative to the length of the game), and tactical decisions when they are achieving short-term goals.

权衡利弊可以做出有趣的战略或战术决策。快速决策（“抽搐”机制）仅限于战术。这表明，更注重战略的游戏（通常是象棋和围棋等回合制游戏）最好专注于涉及权衡的决策。注重战术的游戏可以使用权衡或快速决策（或两者结合），从而产生非常不同的游戏玩法。一种主要使用权衡的战术游戏的例子是战术角色扮演游戏，因《最终幻想战略版》而流行起来。大多数第一人称射击游戏和其他动作游戏都是主要注重本能决策的战术游戏的例子。

Tradeoffs make for interesting strategic or tactical decision-making. Fast decisions (“twitch” mechanics) are limited to tactics. This suggests that games that focus more on strategy—generally turn-based games like Chess and Go—do better to focus on decisions that involve tradeoffs. Games that focus on tactics can use either tradeoffs or fast decisions (or a mixture of both), resulting in very different gameplay. An example of a kind of tactical game that uses mostly tradeoffs is the tactical RPG, popularized by Final Fantasy Tactics. Most first-person shooters and other action games are examples of tactical games that focus mostly on instinctive decisions.

完全基于技能的游戏

COMPLETELY SKILL-BASED GAMES

注重策略和权衡的游戏往往至少包含一些机会元素。当这些游戏纯粹基于技能时，如井字游戏或大多数冒险游戏，它们可以被解决，并且当最终只有一个已知的“正确”步骤时，曾经有趣的决定可以变成显而易见的决定。设计这样的游戏需要游戏中有足够的选择深度，以至于人类无法轻易解决它......最好甚至计算机也无法解决。

Games that focus on strategy and tradeoffs tend to have at least some elements of chance. When these games are purely skill-based, like Tic-Tac-Toe or most adventure games, they can be solved, and the decisions that were once interesting can become obvious decisions when there ends up being a single known “right” move. Designing a game like this requires that there be enough depth of choices in the game that it cannot easily be solved by humans... and preferably not even by computers.

大多数完全依赖技巧的游戏都是基于物理的动作游戏。这可能是因为，与权衡决策不同，它不是要得到正确的答案，而是要快速得到答案。人类的反应时间可以随着时间的推移不断提高，尤其是在人类相互对抗的游戏中。

Most games that are entirely skill are physically based action games. This is probably because, unlike tradeoff decisions, it is not about getting the right answer but getting it quickly. Human reaction time can continue improving over time forever, especially in games where humans play against each other.

技能机制

MECHANICS OF SKILL

到目前为止，本章的内容有些抽象。说权衡决策涉及有限的资源是完全可以的，但游戏中的资源种类繁多：棋子的数量和能力、回合数、棋盘位置、黄金或木材等公开资源，仅举几例。接下来是一些导致有趣决策的机制示例：

So far in this chapter, things have been a bit abstract. It is all well and good to say that tradeoff decisions involve limited resources, but there are so many kinds of resources in games: number and abilities of pieces, number of turns, board position, overt resources like gold or lumber, to name a few. What follows, then, are examples of some mechanics that lead to interesting decisions:

权衡机制

TRADEOFF MECHANICS

权衡让玩家处于必须在两件事之间做出选择的境地。为了保住自己的钱，他们不能拥有自己想要的盔甲。设计师使用各种机制让玩家处于这种境地。

A tradeoff puts players in a situation where they must choose between things. In order to keep their money, they can’t have the armor they have their eye on. Designers use a variety of mechanics to put players in this situation.

拍卖

Auctions

在拍卖中，玩家出价一些资源（通常是金钱）来获得物品。拍卖获胜者支付出价并拿走物品。

In an auction, players bid some resource (usually money) in order to earn an item. The winner of the auction pays his bid and takes the item.

拍卖有很多种。

There are many kinds of auctions.

·      在“公开拍卖”中，玩家可以随时叫出出价，每次叫价都比上一次高，直到所有人都安静下来。（这是大多数人都熟悉的形式——以“一次叫价，两次叫价，成交！”结束）

·      In an “open auction,” players call out bids at any time, each one being higher than the last, until everyone is silent. (This is the form most people are familiar with—it ends with “going once, going twice, sold!”)

·       “顺序拍卖”是指玩家按顺序依次出价。这种拍卖有很多变体：它可能只进行一次，也可能无限期地继续，玩家可能被允许或不允许不出价就放弃，并且放弃（如果允许）可能会或可能不会阻止玩家在下一轮（如果有）中再次出价。顺序拍卖通常发生在纸牌游戏中，玩家会对他们要获得的花样数量进行出价。出价最高的人将证明自己的实力。“无声拍卖”或“封闭式拍卖”是指每个玩家同时秘密出价，并立即公布他们的出价。

·      A “sequential auction” involves players each making a bid in turn order, one at a time. There are many variants on this kind of auction: it may only go around once, or it may continue indefinitely, players may or may not be allowed to pass without bidding, and passing (if allowed) may or may not prevent the player from bidding again in a later round (if there is one). Sequential auctions often occur in card games where players bid on the number of tricks they will take. The highest bidder is left to prove his prowess. A “silent auction” or “closed auction” involves players each making their own bid, simultaneously and in secret, and revealing their bids at once.

·      在“固定价格拍卖”中，物品以指定价格出售，第一个接受指定价格的玩家将购买该物品。（您可以在 eBay 上看到这种拍卖，某些物品上有“立即购买！”选项。）

·      In a “fixed-price auction,” an item is offered at a named price, and the first player to accept the named price buys it. (You can see this on eBay with the “buy it now!” options on some items.)

·       “荷兰式拍卖”以初始高价提供物品，但价格随着时间的推移缓慢下降；第一个接受当前价格的玩家赢得拍卖。

·      A “Dutch auction” offers the item at an initial high price but the price falls slowly over time; the first player to accept the current price wins the auction.

·      在“反向拍卖”中，竞标的物品是一种劣势或负面事件，玩家会竞标以避免陷入困境。

·      In a “reverse auction” the item up for bid is a disadvantage or negative event, and players bid to avoid getting stuck with it.

设计师可以改变拍卖机制。拍卖物品可以成批（成组）拍卖，而不是单件拍卖。可以同时进行多个拍卖，玩家可以在它们之间分配资源。所有玩家都可以出价失败，而不仅仅是拍卖获胜者。或者出价第二高的玩家赢得一件较低的物品（或受到惩罚，使高出价变得危险）。获胜者可以将出价支付给部分或所有失败者，而不是将资源从游戏中移除。

Designers can vary auction mechanics. Instead of auctioning a single item, items can be auctioned in lots (groups). Multiple auctions can be performed at once, with players allocating their resources between them. Players can all lose their bids, instead of just the auction winner. Or the player with the second-highest bid wins a lesser item (or gets hit with a penalty, making high bids dangerous). Instead of the resources being removed from play, the winner can pay his bid to some or all of the losers.

使用动作机制的游戏包括Pitch、Bridge、Modern Art和Monopoly （尽管后者中很少有人真正使用这些机制）。

Games that use action mechanics include Pitch, Bridge, Modern Art, and Monopoly (though few actually play using those mechanics in the latter).

购买

Purchases

玩家无需参与竞拍，而是能够以固定价格购买物品、能力或行动。玩家的选择包括购买哪些物品（因为玩家购买时使用的货币有限）以及何时购买（特别是当资源有限且玩家可能无法在游戏后期购买时）。

Instead of players competing in an auction, they have the ability to purchase items, abilities, or actions at fixed prices. The choices come from which stuff to purchase, given that players will be limited in the currency used to make purchases, and when to purchase, particularly if the resource is limited and players may be unable to purchase it later in the game.

限制使用的特殊能力

Limited-Use Special Abilities

特殊能力让玩家能够以特定方式打破游戏的标准规则。这种机制最初因棋盘游戏《宇宙邂逅》而流行。

Special abilities give players the ability to break the standard rules of the game in specific ways. This mechanic was originally popularized with the board game Cosmic Encounter.

如果玩家每场游戏只能获得一次优势（或两次，或其他），那么何时 使用能力就成为一个令人难以抉择的决定。玩家知道现在使用能力能获得什么优势，但不知道以后是否有更好的使用方式。

If players can gain some advantage but only once per game (or twice, or what have you), the choice of when to use the ability becomes a compelling decision. A player knows what advantage he will get by using the ability right now, but it is unknown whether a better use will make itself available later.

动态限制使用特殊能力

Dynamic Limited-Use Special Abilities

通过根据空间、时间、位置或其他因素改变特殊能力的强度，决策的战略性得到了放大。例如，持有物品的时间越长（或按住按钮的时间越长），物品的威力就越大。是立即使用还是留到以后使用，玩家需要做出一个有趣的决定。在《Risk》中，玩家在决定何时使用游戏中的卡牌时会面临这一决定。玩家使用卡牌时会立即获得奖励，但当对手随后使用卡牌时，奖励也会增加。权衡即时利益与未来更大的回报并不总是一个显而易见的决定。

By varying the strength of special abilities based on space, time, location, or some other factor, the strategic nature of the decision is amplified. For instance, the longer you hold the item (or the longer you hold the button down), the more powerful it may become. Using it now or saving it until later presents the player with an interesting decision. In Risk, players face this decision when they try to decide when they should use the cards in the game. Players get an immediate bonus when they use their cards, but they also increase the bonus when their opponents subsequently use their cards. Weighing the immediate benefit against larger future rewards isn’t always an obvious decision.

明确的选择

Explicit Choices

有时，游戏会为玩家提供选择，并明确说明两种选择的效果。也许玩家会抽一张牌，上面写着“选择一项：获得 10 点金币，或恢复 5 点生命值”。然后玩家必须权衡这些选择的相对价值。

Sometimes, a game gives a choice to a player, making clear the effects of both choices. Perhaps the player draws a card that says “Choose one: gain 10 gold, or heal 5 life points.” The player must then weigh the relative values of those choices.

限制行动

Limited Actions

在玩家拥有一个角色的游戏中，他们的所有动作都通过该角色进行。如果玩家拥有多个角色，那么选择哪个角色执行哪个动作就变得很难决定（假设玩家无法同时向每个角色下达命令）。这在棋盘游戏中更为常见（想想玩家在棋盘上有多个棋子并且可以选择移动哪个棋子的游戏，如Backgammon），但在视频游戏中也可以做到。（一个例子是The Lost Vikings，玩家有三个角色，但一次只能控制一个，而其他两个角色则处于弱势。）

In games where players have one avatar, all of their actions are taken through that avatar. Where players have multiple avatars, choosing which one takes which action becomes a difficult decision (assuming that the player cannot give orders to every avatar simultaneously). This is more common in board games (think of games where players have multiple pawns on a board and can choose which to move, like Backgammon), but can be done in video games as well. (An example would be The Lost Vikings, where the player has three characters but can only control one at a time, leaving the other two vulnerable.)

交易与谈判

Trading and Negotiation

每当多个玩家共同努力实现共同目标时，就会出现一系列社会选择。合作与竞争并存。联盟可以建立，也可以破裂。可以承诺未来的回报以换取当前的帮助。（根据游戏规则，这些承诺可以是正式约束性的、非约束性的，或者在合同被破坏时受到惩罚。）甚至还有游戏之外的玩家社会关系的元游戏考虑因素；玩家与亲密朋友玩棋盘游戏外交的方式与与陌生人玩的方式不同。

Whenever multiple players are working together toward mutual goals, a whole host of social choices come into play. There’s the mix of cooperation versus competition. Alliances can be forged and broken. Promises of future considerations in exchange for help at present can be made. (Based on the rules of the game, these can either be formally binding, nonbinding, or else with a penalty when the contract is broken.) There are even the metagame considerations of the social relationships of the players outside of the game itself; one plays the board game Diplomacy differently with close friends than with total strangers.

战略评估

STRATEGIC EVALUATION

游戏设计师如何评估他们希望创建的战略和战术的成功？通过采访玩家或观察他们玩游戏，设计师可以收集大量信息。请记住，并非每个玩家都喜欢国际象棋、围棋或冒险游戏。游戏中的策略级别应与观众的愿望相称。以下是您可能会问的一些问题。

How do game designers assess the success of the strategy and tactics they hoped to create? By interviewing players or watching them play, a designer can gather a lot of information. Remember that not every player likes a game of Chess, Go, or Risk. The level of strategy in your game should be commensurate with the audience’s desire for the same. Here are some questions you might ask.

玩家会介意其他玩家何时轮到自己吗？

Do players care when other players are taking their turn?

如果游戏的策略性很高，玩家就不愿意离开桌子，更不用说离开房间了。为了说明这一点，请考虑一下您让朋友独自玩大富翁游戏的可能性与让朋友独自玩风险游戏的可能性。

If a game has a high degree of strategy, players are reluctant to leave the table, let alone the room. To illustrate, consider how likely you would be to leave your friends alone with a game of Monopoly versus a game of Risk.

战略游戏要求玩家关注每个玩家行动的结果，因为这些行动反过来会影响他们的行动。当每个玩家轮流行动时，他们会不断重新评估游戏状态。

A strategic game requires players to care about the outcomes of each player’s move, because those moves will, in turn, affect their move. They are constantly reassessing the play state as each player takes his or her turn.

球员们是否制定了长期计划？

Are players making long-term plans?

战略游戏鼓励玩家制定可以在多个回合内实施的策略。如果玩家被游戏现有的机制所束缚，或者被给予太多自由，他们可能无法看到自己的策略如何在多个回合内持续或实现。在玩游戏时，询问玩家他们计划做什么或他们认为如何才能赢得游戏。这些答案通常会揭示策略或缺乏策略。

Strategic games invite the player to form strategies that can be carried out over multiple turns. If players are stifled by the existing mechanics of the game or allowed too much latitude, they may be unable to see how their strategy could be sustained or achieved over multiple turns. When playing a game, ask the players what they plan to do or how they think they will win the game. These answers usually reveal a strategy or lack thereof.

是否有多种游戏适用的多种策略？

Are there multiple strategies for multiple games?

在任何游戏开始时，玩家都应该知道自己将如何玩游戏。战略机会越丰富，答案就越多样化。例如，在《风险》中，玩家可能有几十种不同的策略来对抗不同的玩家或弥补不同的起始状态。

At the beginning of any given game, the player should have an idea of how he will approach the play of the game. The more rich the strategic opportunities are, the more diverse the answers will be. In Risk, for instance, a player may have literally dozens of different strategies to play against different players or to compensate for different starting states.

挑战

CHALLENGES

本章中的挑战让您练习使用各种基于技能的元素。试试您的技能……

The challenges in this chapter let you practice working with various skill-based elements. Try your luck at making skill...

挑战 1——无从掌握的技能

CHALLENGE 1—SKILL FROM NOWHERE

以下是德国传统儿童游戏骰子游戏“雷暴”的规则：

Here are the rules for the dice game Thunderstorm, a traditional children’s game from Germany:

·      选择一名玩家开始，然后游戏按顺时针方向进行。

·      One player is chosen to begin and then play proceeds clockwise.

·      第一轮，玩家投掷六个标准骰子（6d6）。

·      On the first turn, the player throws six standard dice (6d6).

·      如果玩家在轮到自己时掷出任何 1，则这些骰子将被搁置一旁，其余的骰子将传递给下一位玩家。这样，玩家在轮到自己时可以掷的骰子可能少于六个。

·      If a player rolls any 1s on his turn, those dice are set aside and the remaining dice are passed to the next player. In this way, players may have fewer than six dice to throw on their turn.

·      如果一名玩家在其轮次只掷出1，则所有六个骰子将传递给下一名玩家。

·      If a player rolls only 1s on his turn, all six dice are passed to the next player.

·      如果玩家没有掷出任何 1，他将受到惩罚。前五次发生这种情况时，玩家会在纸上画五条线，形成一个房子的形状。第六次失败时，闪电会击中该玩家的房子（画出穿过房子的第六条线），他将出局。游戏的目标是成为游戏中剩下的最后一个玩家。当除一名玩家外所有玩家都被淘汰时，剩下的玩家就是赢家。

·      If a player fails to roll any 1s, he is penalized. The first five times this happens to a player, he draws five lines on his paper in the shape of a house. On the sixth failure, lightning strikes that player’s house (draw a sixth line through the house), and he is eliminated from the game. The object of the game is to be the last player remaining in the game. When all players but one have been eliminated, the remaining player is the winner.

·      这款游戏没有决定，全靠运气。这款游戏适合儿童玩，但成年人可能很快就会厌倦。

·      This game has no decisions and is all luck. It is fine for a children’s game, but adults may tire of it quickly.

创建此游戏的变体，至少需要一些技巧。你的目标是让此游戏更受成年人的欢迎（例如喜欢原版游戏的孩子的父母），同时保持与原版游戏足够接近，让孩子们自己有兴趣玩。

Create a variant of this game that involves at least some skill. Your goal is to make this game more palatable to adults (such as the parents of the children who like the original game), while still keeping it close enough to the original that the children are themselves interested in playing.

所需组件

Components Required

·      六个标准骰子，用于游戏测试

·      Six standard dice, for playtesting

可交付成果

Deliverable

·      新游戏的书面规则修改

·      Written rules modification for the new game

·      可玩的游戏

·      Playable game

·      分析你的修改是否使原始游戏变得更好或更差，以及原因（可选）

·      Analysis of whether your modification makes the original game better or worse, and why (optional)

建议流程

Suggested Process

1.集思广益并进行游戏测试。 考虑为这款游戏添加技巧元素的可能方法。您可以添加拍卖吗？可以添加对结果下注的外部能力吗？还有什么？集思广益，提出各种可能性，无论多么奇怪，然后亲自尝试。注意添加技巧对这款游戏的影响。还要注意，当您使用不同类型的基于技巧的机制时，游戏玩法会有何不同。    

1.     Brainstorm and playtest. Consider possible ways to add an element of skill to this game. Could you add an auction? An outside ability to bet on the outcome? What else? Brainstorm various possibilities no matter how odd and try them out against yourself. Notice the effect that adding skill has on this game. Also notice how different the game plays when you use different kinds of skill-based mechanics.

2.创建可交付成果。    

2.     Create deliverable.

变体

Variant

创建不同基于运气的游戏的变体，例如赌博游戏“掷骰子”或儿童棋盘游戏“糖果乐园”。

Create a variant of a different luck-based game, such as the gambling game Craps or the children’s board game Candy Land.

挑战 2——游戏系统

CHALLENGE 2—GAME SYSTEMS

“游戏系统”是一组可用于玩多种游戏的组件，而不是单一游戏。最著名的游戏系统是一副标准的扑克牌，可用于数百种游戏。

A “game system” is a set of components that can be used to play a variety of games, rather than a single game. The best-known game system is a standard deck of playing cards, which can be used for hundreds of games.

Piecepack（可在 www.piecepack.org 上找到）是一个公共领域游戏系统，可用于创建棋盘游戏。Piecepack 包含以下内容：

The Piecepack (available at www.piecepack.org) is a public domain game system that can be used to create board games. A Piecepack contains the following:

·       24 张牌：每张牌一面都有独特的花色组合（四种不同颜色的花色）和数字（0 到 5），背面相同，上面有一个十字架，暗示着将其分成四个小方格。

·      24 tiles: Each contains a unique combination of suit (out of four differently colored suits) and number (zero to five) on one side, and identical back sides that contain a cross, suggesting a division into four small square quarters.

·       24 个圆形小标记：每个标记都包含独特的花色和数字组合，一面是花色，另一面是数字。标记可以放在每块牌背面的一个小方块上，正面和背面都包含一个小的刻度标记，以指示方向/朝向。

·      24 small circular tokens: Each contains a unique combination of suit and number, with the suit on one side and the number on the other. Tokens can fit on one of the small squares on the back of each tile, and both front and back side contain a small tick-mark to indicate direction/facing.

·       4 个棋子：每种花色各一个，每个棋子都很小，可以放在每块瓷砖背面的一个小方块上，每个棋子上都有一个小刻度标记以指示方向/朝向。

·      4 pawns: One of each suit color, each small enough to fit on one of the small squares on the back of each tile, and each containing a small tick-mark to indicate direction/facing.

·       4 个六面骰子，数字 0 到 5：每个骰子对应一个花色。

·      4 six-sided dice, numbered 0 to 5: Each one corresponding to a suit.

对于此挑战，请设计一款仅使用单个 Piecepack 中的游戏部件的欧式游戏。第 11 章“瞄准市场”中详细讨论了欧式游戏。为了应对此挑战，欧式游戏被定义为具有以下约束：

For this challenge, design a Eurogame that uses only the game bits found in a single Piecepack. Eurogames are discussed in detail in Chapter 11, “Targeting a Market.” For the purposes of this challenge, a Eurogame is defined as having the following constraints:

·      游戏时间大约为 60 到 90 分钟

·      Playable in roughly 60 to 90 minutes

·      设置时间短

·      Short setup time

·      规则简单，学习曲线短

·      Simple rules, short learning curve

·      合作而非对抗

·      Cooperative, not confrontational

·      包含战略决策以及可衡量的随机性，如上一章所述

·      Contains strategic decision making along with measured randomness, as described in the last chapter

·      最大程度减少玩家停机时间

·      Minimal player downtime

在创建游戏时，您不需要使用 Piecepack 中的所有位，也不需要使用所使用的位的所有功能，但您不能使用 Piecepack 中未包含的任何位。

In creating your game, you do not need to use all of the bits in the Piecepack, nor do you need to use all of the capabilities of the bits you use, but you cannot use any bits that are not contained in the Piecepack.

所需组件

Components Required

·      印刷版 Piecepack 套装

·      A printed Piecepack set

可交付成果

Deliverable

·      完整的书面规则

·      Complete set of written rules

建议流程

Suggested Process

1.    找到一个起点。找到上面列出的最令你害怕或感觉最受限制的约束。从那里开始，集思广益，想出一些潜在的核心机制，你可以围绕它构建。选择一个看起来运行良好的机制。另一种方法是考虑 Piecepack 组件本身，因为它们非常灵活。这些瓷砖可以面朝下放置，形成一个临时的游戏板，也可以像一副牌一样使用。这些代币可以像游戏板上的棋子一样使用，也可以将它们花色面朝上放置以隐藏数字（反之亦然）以隐藏一些信息，或者可以像硬币一样翻转它们。骰子可用于跟踪游戏中的分数或其他变量，它们可以用作棋子，也可以掷骰子来产生随机数。每个游戏位都可以充当一个或多个角色。

1.    Find a starting place. Find the constraint listed above that scares you the most or feels the most restrictive. Start there and brainstorm some potential core mechanics, something you can build around. Choose a mechanic that seems as if it works well. Another approach is to consider the Piecepack components themselves, as they are quite versatile. The tiles can be placed face-down to form a makeshift game board, or they can be used like a deck of cards. The tokens can be used like playing pieces on a game board, or they can be placed suit-side up to conceal number (or vice versa) to keep some information hidden, or they can be flipped like coins. Dice can be used to track score or other variables in the game, they can be used as pawns, or they can be rolled to produce random numbers. Each game bit can serve a single role, or several.

2.    从这里开始构建。充实细节。创建一套可玩的规则。

2.    Build from there. Flesh out the details. Create a playable set of rules.

3.    游戏测试和迭代。尝试你的游戏，无论是自己玩还是和朋友一起玩。填补你在规则中发现的漏洞。继续调整游戏，直到你找到有趣的东西。

3.    Playtest and iterate. Try out your game, either against yourself or with a friend. Fill in the holes that you find in the rules. Continue tuning the game until you have something fun.

4.    约束检查。验证您的游戏是否满足上述所有约束。如果不满足，请问问自己如何修改游戏机制。请注意，只有在发现游戏中的乐趣后才应这样做；为有趣的游戏添加约束比为受限的游戏添加乐趣要容易得多。

4.    Constraint check. Verify that your game meets all of the constraints listed above. If it doesn’t, ask yourself how to modify your mechanics. Note that you should do this only after finding the fun in your game; it is much easier to add a constraint to a fun game than to add fun to a constrained game.

5.    创建可交付成果。

5.    Create deliverable.

变体

Variant

使用不同的游戏系统。以下是一些建议：

Use a different game system. Some suggestions:

·      冰屋碎片（由 Looney Labs 出品，可在线访问 www.looneylabs.com）。包含大、中、小金字塔各 5 个。碎片是空心的，可以堆叠（较小的碎片被较大的碎片完全覆盖）。它们可以立在底座上，面朝上或倾斜在一端。每套碎片都涂成不同的颜色；每位玩家使用一套。

·      Icehouse pieces (by Looney Labs, online at www.looneylabs.com). Contains five each of large, medium, and small pyramids. The pieces are hollow, allowing them to be stacked (with smaller ones being completely covered by larger). They can stand on their base facing up or tilted on an end. Each set of pieces is painted a different color; use one set per player.

·      巨石阵(Paizo Publishing 出版，在线网址为 www.paizo.com)。作为“棋盘游戏选集”进行营销，这是一套以巨石阵为主题的游戏系统，包含一块棋盘、一副牌和一大堆塑料棋子。

·      Stonehenge (by Paizo Publishing, online at www.paizo.com). Marketed as a “board game anthology,” this is a Stonehenge-themed game system containing a board, a deck of cards, and a large pile of plastic pieces.

·      任何经过修改的牌组。从每个花色中移除几张牌，或添加一个额外的花色，或组合几副牌，或添加一些不属于任何花色的特殊牌（小丑除外）。您可以购买几副具有相同牌背的牌组并根据需要修改牌，从而创建自己的自定义牌组，或者您可以搜索附带非标准牌的已发布纸牌游戏。

·      Any modified deck of cards. Remove a few cards from each suit, or add an extra suit, or combine several decks, or add some special cards that aren’t part of any suit (other than the Jokers). You can create a custom deck of your own by purchasing several decks with the same card back and modifying the cards as needed, or you can search for published card games that come with nonstandard cards.

挑战 3 — 奔跑中的策略

CHALLENGE 3—STRATEGY ON THE RUN

设计一款游戏，像欧洲游戏（在之前的挑战中描述过）一样，设置时间短，规则简单，最大限度地减少玩家的停机时间，并且至少包含一些策略和有趣的决定。您可以使用任何您想要的游戏元素集合。

Design a game that, like a Eurogame (described in the previous challenge), has short setup time, has simple rules, minimizes player downtime, and contains at least some strategy and interesting decisions. You may use any collection of game bits that you want.

您的游戏时间应为 15 分钟或更短。

Your game should have a playtime of 15 minutes or fewer.

由于游戏时间短暂，您需要对游戏进行迭代和完善，以达到非常高的质量。

Due to the short play time, you are expected to iterate and polish your game to very high quality.

所需组件

Components Required

·      游戏片段合集

·      Collection of game bits

可交付成果

Deliverable

·      包含所有游戏元素的原型

·      Prototype with all game bits included

·      完整的书面规则

·      Complete set of written rules

建议流程

Suggested Process

1.    回顾一些游戏时间较短的欧洲游戏。这些游戏都讲的是什么？《龙之游行》讲的是在游行路线上放置摊贩的位置。《嘿，那是我的鱼》讲的是在下一个要降落在哪个方块上。快速逛逛当地的游戏商店可以帮助您拓宽理解。

1.    Review some Eurogames with short play times. What are these games all about? Dragon Parade is about where to put your vendors on a parade route. Hey, That’s My Fish is about which tile to land on next. A quick trip to a local game store can help you broaden your understanding.

2.    选择决策。短游戏通常只有少数机制，玩家需要重复多次。在较长的游戏中，最好为玩家提供更多变化，这样他们就不会因为少数机制而感到厌烦，但在短游戏中，最好保持简单。更简单的规则还具有缩短学习曲线和设置时间的优势。考虑游戏中可以做出的不同类型的战略决策（本章中列出的或您自己设计的），然后选择一种作为游戏的基础。

2.    Choose a decision. Short games typically only have a small number of mechanics that players repeat many times. In a longer game, it’s preferable to give players more variety so that they don’t get burned out on a small set of mechanics, but in a short game it’s better to keep things simple. Simpler rules also have the advantage of shortening the learning curve and setup time. Consider the different kinds of strategic decisions that can be made during a game, either listed in this chapter or of your own devising, and choose one as the basis for your game.

3.    创建机制。根据玩家将要做出的主要决定，创建一个核心机制来支持它。想想当玩家连续多次做出同样的决定时会发生什么。从那里开始，填写完整游戏所需的其余细节：设置规则、游戏进程和胜利/结束条件。

3.    Create the mechanics. From the primary decision players will be making, create a core mechanic to support it. Think about what happens when players make this same kind of decision several times in series. From there, fill in the remaining details required for a complete game: rules for setup, progression of play, and victory/end conditions.

4.    游戏测试和迭代。游戏速度非常快，你可以在很短的时间内玩很多次。每次尝试做一点小改动，看看它对游戏有什么影响。至少这样做 20 次（相当于 5 小时的游戏测试）。

4.    Playtest and iterate. With a game that plays so quickly, you can play many times in a short period of time. Each time, try making a small change and see how it affects play. Do this at least 20 times (five hours’ worth of playtesting).

5.    创建可交付成果。

5.    Create deliverable.

变体

Variant

不要从头开始制作游戏，而是采用挑战 2 中制作的游戏，并将其游戏时间缩短至 15 分钟或更短。对您认为合适的机制进行任何更改。

Instead of creating a game from scratch, take the game you made from Challenge 2 and reduce its play time to 15 minutes or less. Make any changes to the mechanics that you feel are appropriate.

挑战 4——全新维度

CHALLENGE 4—A WHOLE NEW DIMENSION

你们都准备好玩跳棋（或国际跳棋，取决于你们住在哪里），但你们没有使用普通棋盘，而是用这个 12 12 方格棋盘。你们可以忽略每边的四个方格，但那样太无聊了。相反，设计一个使用更大棋盘的变体。你们可以对规则进行任何必要的更改，以支持新的更大尺寸。这对游戏玩法有什么影响？

You were all ready to play a game of Checkers (or Draughts, depending on where you live), but instead of a normal board, you have this 12 12 square board instead. You could just ignore four squares on each side, but that’s boring. Instead, design a variant that uses the larger board. You may make any rules changes necessary to support the new larger size. What effect does this have on gameplay?

所需组件

Components Required

·       12 x 12 棋盘和一套跳棋或棋子。这些可能是自制的，因为这种跳棋变体通常不在商店出售。

·      12 x 12 board and a set of checkers or tokens. These will probably be homemade since this Checkers variant is not typically sold in stores.

·      一台可连接互联网的计算机，以防您忘记如何玩跳棋（这种情况比您想象的更常见）

·      A computer with an Internet connection, in case you’ve forgotten how to play Checkers (more common than you know)

可交付成果

Deliverable

·      列出您尝试过的规则变化并分析它们对游戏玩法的影响。

·      Written list of rules changes you tried and an analysis of their effect on gameplay.

建议流程

Suggested Process

1.构建游戏。创建组件。这可以简单到使用硬币或标准纸张上的剪纸。    

1.     Build the game. Create the components. This can be as simple as using coins or cutouts from a standard sheet of paper.

2.玩游戏。自己或与朋友一起玩游戏。玩游戏时，记下事情发生了怎样的变化。你做出的决定比原来的更有说服力还是更没有说服力？仅仅通过改变棋盘的大小，玩家的决定发生了怎样的变化？    

2.     Play the game. By yourself or with a friend, play the game. As you play, take notes on how things have changed. Are the decisions you make more or less compelling than the original? How have the player decisions changed, just by changing the size of the board?

3.创建可交付成果。    

3.     Create deliverable.

变体

Variant

使用 6 x 6 棋盘。小棋盘与标准游戏有何不同？它与较大的 12 x 12 棋盘有何不同？随着尺寸的增加或减少，是否会出现任何趋势，还是每种尺寸都有其独特、不可预测的体验？

Use a 6 x 6 board. How is a smaller board different from the standard game? How is it different from the larger 12 x 12 board? Do there appear to be any trends as size increases or decreases, or is each size its own unique, unpredictable experience?

变体

Variant

使用 7 x 7 或 9 x 9 棋盘。现在棋盘是对称的，这应该对游戏动态产生更大的影响。现在情况如何变化？这是否符合您在之前的变体中发现的尺寸趋势，还是奇数尺寸和偶数尺寸的棋盘是完全不同的游戏体验？

Use a 7 x 7 or 9 x 9 board. Now the board is symmetrical, which should have a greater effect on game dynamics. How do things change now? Does this fit the size trends you found in the previous variant, or are odd-sized and even-sized boards completely different play experiences?

变体

Variant

不要使用跳棋，而要使用诸如国际象棋之类的其他基于方块的游戏。

Instead of Checkers, use a different square-based game such as Chess.

铁人设计师挑战 5 — 黑色星期五：棋盘游戏

IRON DESIGNER CHALLENGE 5—BLACK FRIDAY: THE BOARD GAME

把玩家分成 2 到 4 人一组。每组列出一个经常发生的事件。或者使用以下列表：

Break into groups of two to four players. Each group names a regularly occurring event. Or use this list:

·       “黑色星期五”（美国感恩节后的购物日）

·      “Black Friday” (the shopping day immediately after Thanksgiving in the United States)

·      高中同学聚会

·      High school class reunion

·      游戏开发者大会

·      Game Developers Conference

·      定期牙齿清洁

·      Routine dental cleaning

·      奥斯卡奖

·      Academy Awards

·      丰田马拉松

·      Toyotathon

每个团队都会被分配一个活动（或者所有团队都会随机选择一个活动）。根据活动制作棋盘游戏或纸牌游戏。游戏必须具有很强的策略元素和有趣的玩家决策（尽管一些机会元素是可以接受的）。

Each team is assigned an event (or a single event is randomly chosen for all teams). Make a board or card game based on the event. The game must have a strong element of strategy and interesting player decisions (although some elements of chance are acceptable).

所需组件

Components Required

·      游戏所需的游戏比特

·      Game bits required for the game

可交付成果

Deliverable

·      可玩游戏的演示

·      Demonstration of a playable game

建议流程

Suggested Process

1.选择一个视角。 主题可能已经确定，但每个主题可以从不同角度看待。参与者是谁？如果主题是高中同学聚会，那么每个头像是班级毕业生（表明目标是给同学留下深刻印象或玩得开心），还是策划委员会成员（目标是确保每个人都玩得开心），还是看门人（目标可能是以最快的速度清理您所在的区域）？    

1.     Choose a perspective. The theme may be decided, but each theme can be looked at from different angles. Who are the players? If the theme is a high school class reunion, is each avatar a graduate of the class (suggesting that the objective is to impress your classmates or have a good time), or a member of the planning committee (so that the objective is making sure everyone has a good time), or a janitor (where the objective might be to clean up your area fastest)?

2.选择机制。确定主题和目标后，决定允许玩家实现该目标的核心机制。他们将做出哪些决定，这些决定如何影响游戏状态？    

2.     Choose mechanics. With a theme and an objective, decide on the core mechanics that allow players to achieve that objective. What decisions will they make, and how do those decisions affect the game state?

1.创建可交付成果。    

1.     Create deliverable.

非数字短片

NON-DIGITAL SHORTS

掷一个 d10 并考虑创建其中一个游戏。

Roll a d10 and consider creating one of these games.

创建一款可以分多轮或多组玩的基于图块的游戏，以方便进行长期规划。选择一款简单的基于技能的棋盘游戏（例如跳棋），并设计一款“速度”版本，要求玩家在规定的时间限制内做出决定。

Create a tile-based game to be played in multiple rounds or sets that facilitate long-term planning. Choose a simple skill-based board game (such as Checkers) and design a “speed” version of it that requires players to make decisions within a set time limit.

设计一款以囚徒困境为核心机制的纸牌游戏。设计一款基于方块的游戏，每个玩家提前记录一个大战略，只有实现该战略后才能获胜。设计一款纸牌游戏，玩家可以购买为其他玩家做决定的权利。设计一款赛跑棋盘游戏，其中有一个隐藏目标，需要玩家通过购买或拍卖机制来揭示它。重新设计大富翁，使每个头像标记（汽车、铁、狗、船等）都具有有限使用的特殊能力。重新设计一款经典的掷骰子游戏（如Parcheesi），使其涉及交易和谈判。重新设计运气游戏Craps，使其至少涉及三种基于技能的机制。创建一款强调游戏设计是一项技能的游戏，迫使玩家在短时间内想出可信的（但可能很幽默）设计。

Design a card game that uses the Prisoner’s Dilemma as its core mechanic. Design a tile-based game in which each player records a grand strategy in advance and wins only when it is achieved. Design a card game in which players may purchase the right to make other players’ decisions for them. Design a race to the end board game with a hidden objective that requires players to reveal it by a purchase or auction mechanic. Redesign Monopoly such that each of the avatar tokens (the car, iron, dog, ship, etc.) has a limited-use special ability. Redesign a classic roll-and-move game (such as Parcheesi) to involve trading and negotiation. Redesign the luck game Craps to involve at least three skill-based mechanics. Create a game that emphasizes game design as a skill by forcing players to come up with believable (though likely humorous) designs in a short amount of time.

资源

RESOURCES

www.worldrps.com：世界 RPS 协会网站，其中包含许多关于玩石头剪刀布的（严肃的）策略文章。

www.worldrps.com: The World RPS Society Web site, which includes a number of (serious) strategy articles for playing Rock-Paper-Scissors.



 

 

7：“抽搐”技巧的要素

7: Elements of “Twitch” Skill

    

    

在上一章中，我们探讨了游戏中的一种技能，即深思熟虑的决策技能（俗称“策略”）。还有一种技能经常出现在电子游戏中，有时也出现在非数字游戏中。第二种技能需要快速思考、灵巧和反应速度。这些快速决策通常被称为“抽搐机制”，以它们为核心的游戏被称为“抽搐游戏”。许多早期的街机游戏几乎完全是对这种技能的测试。一些现代游戏，特别是射击游戏，也属于这一类。

In the previous chapter, we explored one type of skill in games, the skill of deliberate, considered decision making (colloquially referred to as “strategy”). There is another kind of skill that sees frequent use in video games, and even the occasional non-digital game. This second kind of skill requires fast thinking, dexterity, and reaction speed. These fast decisions are often referred to as “twitch mechanics,” and the games that use them at their core are called “twitch games.” Many early arcade games were almost entirely tests of this kind of skill. Some modern games, particularly shooting games, also fall into this category.

挑战玩家

CHALLENGING THE PLAYER

玩家玩游戏是因为游戏有挑战。通过一次又一次地应对挑战，玩家逐渐变得更好，最终成为大师。如果游戏在短时间内呈现太多挑战，玩家可能会不知所措和沮丧。另一方面，如果挑战太容易克服，玩家很快就会感到无聊。找到两者之间的平衡点，当玩家在能力达到顶峰时感到挑战，这被称为“调整”，这是游戏设计师最重要的工作之一。为了让游戏保持趣味性，设计师还必须允许游戏逐渐变得更难。吉他英雄就是一个很好的例子。起初，一些玩家很难唱完“我爱摇滚乐”。一个小时之内，他们就可以轻松唱完。

Players play games because they present challenges. Gradually, by responding to a challenge again and again, players become better, ultimately achieving mastery. If a game presents too many twitch challenges too quickly, the player can be overwhelmed and frustrated. At the other extreme, if the challenges are too easy to overcome, the player quickly becomes bored. Finding the balance between them, when the player feels challenged at the peak of his ability, called “tuning,” is one of the game designer’s most important jobs. To keep the game interesting, designers also have to allow for the game to become progressively more difficult. Guitar Hero is an excellent example of this. At first, some players struggle through the song “I Love Rock and Roll.” Within an hour, they’re blowing through it.

战略游戏也必须处理难度升级问题，但这类游戏的问题在于决策的深度，因为玩家通常有足够的时间来考虑他们的选择。在抽搐游戏中，挑战压倒玩家（或令玩家失望）的问题更为明显。

Strategic games also have to deal difficulty progression, but in those games the question is one of depth of decision making, because players typically have all the time they need to consider their options. In twitch games, the problem of overwhelming (or underwhelming) the player with challenge is much more obvious.

调校

TUNING

Twitch 挑战的一个难点是，它们必须精心设计，以最佳难度挑战玩家。这本来很容易，但每个玩家的能力水平都不同，所以任何级别的挑战对某些玩家来说都太难，而对其他玩家来说又太容易。幸运的是，游戏设计师已经学会了一些解决这个问题的方法。

One difficulty of twitch challenges is that they must be crafted to challenge the player at an optimal level of difficulty. This would be easy except that every player’s ability level is different, so any level of challenge is going to be too hard for some players and too easy for others. Luckily, game designers have learned a few ways around this.

难度等级

DIFFICULTY LEVELS

你可以将游戏调整为更简单或更困难，然后让玩家选择自己的挑战级别。大多数形式的抽搐技能都可以轻松调整：可以修改玩家在纯速度挑战中必须反应多快的要求；可以扩大或缩小计时挑战的机会窗口；可以提高精确度挑战的宽容度或通过某种形式的自动瞄准来辅助；可以修改躲避挑战中要躲避的事物数量；可以更改计时挑战的严格时间限制以减轻或增加时间压力。

You can scale the game to be easier or harder, and then allow players to choose his own level of challenge. Most forms of twitch skill can scale easily: the requirements of how fast a player must react in a pure speed challenge can be modified; the window of opportunity for a timing challenge can be widened or narrowed; a precision challenge can be made more forgiving or can be assisted by some form of automatic aiming; the number of things to avoid in an avoidance challenge can be modified; and a strict time limit for a timed challenge can be changed to ease or increase the time pressure.

动态难度调整

DYNAMIC DIFFICULTY ADJUSTMENT

有些游戏不仅有多个难度等级，还可以随时更改。如果玩家表现很好，难度就会增加，直到玩家感到足够有挑战性。如果玩家经常失败，游戏就会稍微轻松一点，这样玩家就不会感到沮丧。

Some games not only have multiple difficulty levels but also can change them on the fly. If the player is doing too well, the difficulty can increase until the player is sufficiently challenged. If the player is losing frequently, the game can ease up a bit so that the player is not frustrated.

难度曲线

DIFFICULTY CURVES

有些游戏，尤其是有一系列关卡的视频游戏，一开始很简单，然后随着时间的推移难度逐渐增加。这种情况会一直持续下去，直到玩家最终不知所措。许多经典的街机游戏，如吃豆人和太空侵略者，以及俄罗斯方块等益智游戏都是这样做的。

Some games, particularly video games that have a sequence of levels, simply start off easy and become progressively more difficult as time goes on. This continues until the player is finally overwhelmed. Many classic arcade games like Pac-Man and Space Invaders do this, as do puzzle games like Tetris.

游戏测试

PLAYTESTING

在调整游戏时，稳定的游戏测试人员是必不可少的。设计师对自己的游戏非常了解，因此无法独自判断新玩家的体验。有游戏经验的测试人员很擅长发现错误，但他们的技能水平可能已经提高到无法客观测试难度的程度。在整个开发过程中，要不断寻找新的游戏测试人员，并不断监控他们对游戏难度的第一反应。

When tuning a game, a steady stream of playtesters is indispensable. Designers understand their own games too well to discern the new player experience on their own. Testers who have experience with a game are great for finding bugs, but their skill level has likely increased to the point where they can no longer objectively test for difficulty. Throughout development, find new playtesters on a continual basis and constantly monitor their first reactions to the difficulty of the game.

TWITCH 决策

TWITCH DECISION MAKING

玩家在节奏快的环境中做出的决定与速度较慢、更具战略性的游戏中的决定性质不同。玩家仍然在做出决定，但这些决定的速度要快得多（每秒做出多次决定，而纯战略游戏中每隔几秒或几分钟做出一次决定）。

The decisions a player makes in a twitch environment are of a different nature than those in a slower, more strategic game. The player is still making decisions, but those decisions are being made on a far more rapid basis (many times per second, as opposed to one decision every few seconds or minutes in a pure strategy game).

大多数快速决策都有玩家应该采取的明显正确行动。挑战在于快速准确地执行该行动。例如，在 FPS 中，玩家所做的决定包括转向和射击的方向。信息就在屏幕上，挑战不仅在于做出正确的决定，还在于比敌人更快地做出决定。参与其中的不是玩家大脑的思考部分，而是大脑的本能反应部分。 

Most twitch decisions have an obvious correct action that the player should take. The challenge comes from executing that action quickly and accurately. In an FPS, for example, the decisions a player makes involve which way to turn and fire. The information is there on the screen, and the challenge is not just to make the right decision, but to make the decision faster than the enemy. It is not the thinking part of the player’s brain that is engaged, as much as the instinctive, reactive part of the brain.  

这里有一个教训。在战略环境中，显而易见的决定（参见第 6 章“‘战略’技能要素”）并不十分引人注目，但如果玩家做出这些决定的时间有限，它们可以变得更有趣。游戏No Brainer 1就是一个完美的例子，玩家在极端的时间压力下被问到一系列极其简单和明显的琐事问题。不久之后，大多数玩家会发现自己说西兰花是由金属制成的，或者石灰岩有大脑，仅仅是因为他们的思维跟不上游戏的节奏。

There is a lesson here. Obvious decisions (see Chapter 6, “Elements of ‘Strategic’ Skill”) are not very compelling in a strategic environment, but they can be made more interesting if the player has limited time to make those decisions. A perfect illustration of this is the game No Brainer 1, where the player is asked a series of extremely easy and obvious trivia questions under extreme time pressure. Before long, most players will find themselves saying that broccoli is made of metal or that limestone rock has a brain, simply because their minds cannot keep pace with the game.

抽搐机制

TWITCH MECHANICS

尽管抽搐机制通常被归入一个类别，但实际上它有几种类型，每种类型对游戏都有不同的影响。

While twitch mechanics are often lumped into a single category, there are actually several types, each of which has a different effect on play.

纯粹速度

PURE SPEED

有些游戏要求玩家在最短时间内完成一项常规任务（例如赛车游戏），或在设定的时间限制内尽可能多地执行重复任务（通常称为“按键乱按”，经典街机游戏《田径》就是一个例子，它本质上是对玩家快速按下按钮的奖励）。现实生活中的赛跑也是这种情况的一个例子。

Some games ask players to perform a routine task in a minimum amount of time (such as a car racing game), or perform a repetitive task as many times as possible within a set time limit (often referred to as “button mashing,” exemplified by the classic arcade game Track and Field, which essentially rewarded the player for hitting a button rapidly). Foot races in real life are an example of this as well.

在非数字游戏中，这种机制出现在普通人可能想不到的地方——休闲游戏和儿童游戏。游戏Slapjack要求玩家在将 J 牌翻到牌堆上时，率先将其拍下。胜者为王。同样，一些问答游戏（尤其是像Jeopardy!这样的游戏节目）会奖励第一个答对的玩家。

In non-digital games, this mechanic shows up in places the average person might not expect—causal and children’s games. The game Slapjack tasks players with being the first to slap a jack card when it is flipped face up onto a pile of cards. Winner takes all. Likewise, some trivia games (especially game shows like Jeopardy!) award the player with the first right answer.

定时

TIMING

电子游戏的一个常见机制是要求玩家在正确的时间按下正确的按钮。《热舞革命》和《摇滚乐队》不仅要求玩家快速移动，还要求玩家掌握准确的时间。游戏的目标不仅仅是快速按下按钮，还要在正确的时间踩到正确的箭头或按下正确的输入设备。

A common mechanic in video games is to require the player to press the right button at the right time. Dance Dance Revolution and Rock Band not only require rapid movement, but also precise timing. The objective is not merely to hit buttons rapidly, but to step on the right arrows or hit the right input device at the correct time.

精确

PRECISION

有时挑战不仅仅是快速做某事或在特定时刻执行某个动作，而是准确地做某事。第一人称射击游戏通常要求玩家瞄准目标，玩家必须快速移动十字准线，但也要朝着正确的方向（通常是移动的目标）移动。

Sometimes the challenge is not simply to do something fast or to perform an action at a particular moment, but to do something accurately. First-person shooters generally require the player to aim at a target, and players must move the crosshairs quickly but also toward the correct facing (and often a moving target).

需要精准度的非数字游戏通常被称为“灵巧游戏”，因为它们需要谨慎的手动灵巧性，而不是纯粹的速度。例如堆叠游戏Jenga，玩家必须从塔中移除积木而不使其倒塌；电子游戏Operation，玩家需要用镊子拾取小塑料片；派对游戏Twister，玩家必须将手脚放在尴尬的位置而不跌倒。最明显的精准度类型出现在体育游戏中，玩家需要在正确的时间和正确的位置击球，等等。

Non-digital games that require precision are often referred to as “dexterity games,” as they require careful manual dexterity rather than pure speed. Examples include the stacking game Jenga, where players must remove blocks from a tower without causing it to fall, the electronic game Operation, which requires players to pick up small plastic pieces with a set of tweezers, and the party game Twister, where players must place their hands and feet in awkward positions without falling down. The most obvious type of precision occurs in sports games where the player needs to hit the ball at the right time and in the right place, among other things.

回避

AVOIDANCE

横向卷轴游戏的一大特色是，躲避有害敌人或投射物的方法因游戏而异。有些游戏（主要是 2D 游戏）会显示整个周边区域，因此，这主要是一项挑战，即如何保持视野范围内的威胁并前往更安全的区域。在视野有限的游戏中（如第一人称 3D 游戏），还有一项额外的挑战，即确定威胁的位置。有时，会为玩家提供俯视小地图；有时，他们只需要经常朝不同方向看。

A favorite of side-scrolling games, staying away from harmful enemies or projectile works differently depending on the game. Some games (mostly in 2D) show all of the surrounding area, making this mostly a challenge of keeping threats in view and heading for safer areas. In games where field of vision is limited (as with first-person 3D games), there is an additional challenge of identifying where the threats are. Sometimes, players are provided with an overhead view mini map; other times, they are expected to just look in different directions a lot.

在某些情况下，尤其是当投射物或敌人速度非常快时，找到掩护区域对于避免威胁非常重要。在其他游戏中，一切都移动得更慢，而且“掩护”的概念是不存在的。

In some cases, particularly when projectiles or enemies are very fast, locating areas of cover is important in avoiding threats. In other games, everything moves slower, and the concept of “cover” is nonexistent.

在非数字形式中，这种技能最常见于体育运动和其他体育游戏中，例如Tag或Dodgeball。

In non-digital form, this type of skill is most often found in sports and other physical games such as Tag or Dodgeball.

时间压力

TIME PRESSURE

任何任务在增加时间限制后都会变得更加困难。时间限制可以是明确的（例如在三分钟内解决难题）或隐含的（找到并射击对手的速度要比对手对你做同样的事情快）。所有类型的技能（包括战略和抽搐）都可以添加时间限制，从而以剧烈的方式改变游戏的动态。考虑一下国际象棋和快棋之间的区别，在国际象棋中，玩家可以随意移动，而在快棋中，玩家在整个游戏中总共有五分钟的时间来完成所有移动。这两种游戏的规则相同，但感觉却完全不同。

Any task becomes more difficult when a time limit is added. This can be an explicit time limit (such as solving a puzzle within three minutes) or implicit (find and shoot your opponent faster than they can do the same to you). Time limits can be added to all types of skill (both strategic and twitch), changing the dynamics of the game in often drastic ways. Consider the difference between Chess, where players are given as long as they want to make a move and Speed Chess, where players have a total of five minutes to make all of their moves for the whole game. The rules of both games are identical, but they have an entirely different feel.

挑战

CHALLENGES

你在读这篇文章做什么？赶快在时间耗尽之前选择一个挑战吧！

What are you doing reading this? Hurry up and pick a challenge before time runs out!

挑战 1——将 TWITCH 添加到策略中

CHALLENGE 1—ADDING TWITCH TO STRATEGY

此项挑战的目的是了解当游戏的战略元素添加抽搐机制时游戏动态如何变化。

The purpose of this challenge is to gain an understanding of how play dynamics change when a strategic element of a game has a twitch mechanic added to it.

选择任何一款纯策略游戏，没有运气和抽搐机制。例如国际象棋、 围棋和黑白棋。修改规则以允许某种抽搐组件。玩游戏，并注意新游戏有何不同，以及游戏是否因更改而变得更好或更差（或只是不同）。

Choose any game that is a pure strategy game, with no luck and no twitch mechanics. Examples are Chess, Go, and Othello. Modify the rules to allow some kind of twitch component. Play the game, and note how the new game is different and whether the game was made better or worse (or just different) from the change.

所需组件

Components Required

·      您选择的游戏的可玩版本

·      A playable version of the game you have chosen

可交付成果

Deliverable

·      新游戏的书面规则修改

·      Written rules modifications for the new game

·      分析游戏动态如何变化，你的修改是否使原始游戏变得更好或更糟，以及原因（可选）

·      Analysis of how the game dynamics have changed, whether your modification makes the original game better or worse, and why (optional)

建议流程

Suggested Process

·      集思广益并进行游戏测试。有很多方法可以为这款游戏添加抽搐技巧元素。时间压力是最明显的（只需为玩家移动的时间添加时间限制，就像Speed Chess一样），但你应该能够想出一些更新颖的东西。尝试添加灵巧组件。

·      Brainstorm and playtest. There are many ways to add an element of twitch skill to this game. Time pressure is the most obvious (just add a time limit to how long a player can take to move, as with Speed Chess), but you should be able to come up with something more original. Try adding a dexterity component instead.

·      创建可交付成果。

·      Create deliverable.

挑战 2 — 多球

CHALLENGE 2—MULTI-BALL

在非数字领域，最常见的抽搐机制是体育运动。大多数体育运动需要速度、精准度和时间压力，接触性运动也需要躲避。大多数流行的体育运动都涉及球员在球场上移动球，通常试图将球放入某个特定区域。让我们尝试一些不同的东西：比赛中不只有一个球，而是必须同时有两个或多个球。这些球可以是相同的，也可以是

In the non-digital realm, the most common place to find twitch mechanics is in sports. Most sports require speed, precision, and time pressure, and contact sports also contain avoidance. A majority of popular sports involve the players moving a ball around a field of play, usually trying to put it into some specific area. Let’s try something different: instead of one ball in play, there must be two or more balls in play at once. The balls may be identical, or

它们可以发挥不同的功能，由您决定。流行体育游戏的设计通常是一项棘手的工作，因为设计

they may serve different functions, at your discretion. The design of popular sports games is normally a tricky business, because the de

签名者不仅要考虑一项容易参与、好玩的运动，还要考虑一项观看起来很有趣的运动。对于这个挑战，不要担心这些细节。只要制作一款好玩的游戏就行了。

signer must consider not only a sport that is accessible and fun to play, but also one that is fun to watch. For this challenge, do not worry about these details. Simply make a game that is fun to play.

所需组件

Components Required

·      至少两个相同种类的球

·      At least two balls of some kind

可交付成果

Deliverable

·      完整的书面规则

·      Complete set of written rules

建议流程

Suggested Process

1.选择你的约束。 体育界包括许多不同类型的球：足球、棒球、高尔夫球、网球、乒乓球和许多其他球。你想要几个相同类型的球还是几种不同类型的球？哪种类型？有许多潜在的比赛场地。你想让你的运动可以在室内还是室外进行？它可以在水泥地上进行吗，还是必须是草地或沙地等柔软的表面？注意比赛场地如何与球互动。有些球只能在某些表面上弹跳或滚动。你可以使用现有的比赛场地，如当地的足球场或篮球场，进行比赛测试吗？有多少名球员？每个球员是单独比赛还是球员组成球队？你不需要一次回答所有这些问题，但其中任何一个问题都可以给你一个起点。一旦你选择了两个排球，你就可以问自己打算如何使用它们。    

1.     Choose your constraints. The world of sports includes many different kinds of balls: footballs, baseballs, golf balls, tennis balls, ping-pong balls, and dozens of others. Do you want several balls of the same type or one ball each of several different types? Which types? There are many potential fields of play. Do you want your sport to be playable indoors or outside? Can it be played on concrete, or must it be a soft surface like grass or sand? Note how the field of play interacts with the balls. Some balls will only bounce or roll on certain surfaces. Can you use an existing play area, like a local football field or basketball court, for playtesting? How many players? Is each player competing on his own or do players form teams? You do not need to answer all of these questions at once, but any one of them can give you a starting point. Once you’ve chosen, say, two volleyballs, you can then ask yourself how you intend to use them.

2.培养核心技巧。 体育运动中使用的球类具有高度互动性。它们可以被扔下、踢、扔、用钝器击打、弹起等等。你希望球员以哪些方式与两个球互动？是否有任何互动方式是不允许的（例如在篮球比赛中带球）？    

2.     Develop core mechanics. The kinds of balls used in sports are highly interactive. They can be dropped, kicked, thrown, hit with a blunt object, bounced, and so on. What are the ways you want your players to interact with the two balls? Are there any methods of interaction that are not allowed (such as carrying a ball in Basketball)?

3.充实规则。 游戏的目标是什么？游戏如何玩？什么时候结束？找出核心概念，并将其发展为一套完整的规则。    

3.     Flesh out the rules. What is the object of the game? How is it played? When is it over? Take your core concept and develop it to a complete rule set.

4.安全和现实检查。 你的游戏应该是安全的。如果你想让玩家朝其他玩家的大致方向扔球，这些球应该足够柔软，以免造成伤害。除非你准备提供足够的安全设备，否则请避免全接触运动。一定要禁止任何可能导致受伤的玩家动作。以其他运动为一般指导方针，如有疑问，你应该谨慎行事。你的游戏也应该是可玩的。魁地奇听起来可能是一个有趣的游戏设计，但你在玩测试时会遇到困难。    

4.     Safety and reality check. Your game should be safe to play. If you want players to throw balls in the general direction of other players, those balls should be soft enough not to cause injury. Avoid full-contact sports unless you’re prepared to provide sufficient safety equipment. Be sure to prohibit any player actions that could cause injury. Look to other sports as a general guideline, and when in doubt you should err on the side of caution. Your game should also be playable. Quidditch may sound like a fun game to design, but you’ll have a difficult time playtesting.

5.尝试一下。约上几个朋友一起玩吧。    

5.     Try it out. Get some friends together and play.

6.创建可交付成果。    

6.     Create deliverable.

挑战 3 — 抽搐骰子

CHALLENGE 3—TWITCH DICE

设计一款只涉及抽动机制和运气的游戏，不涉及战略元素，仅使用骰子作为组件。您可以在游戏中使用 5 到 10 个骰子，并且可以从可用的骰子中选择骰子类型。

Design a game that involves only twitch mechanics and luck—no strategic elements—using only dice as your components. You may use anywhere between five and ten dice for your game, and you can choose what kinds of dice from those that you have available.

您的游戏应该可以在五分钟或更短的时间内运行。

Your game should be playable in five minutes or fewer.

所需组件

Components Required

·      骰子，最好有几种类型（d4、d6、d8、d10、d12、d20）和多种颜色

·      Dice, preferably of several types (d4, d6, d8, d10, d12, d20) and in a variety of colors

可交付成果

Deliverable

·      完整的书面规则清单

·      Complete list of written rules

建议流程

Suggested Process

1.    集思广益或研究。骰子可以实现哪些类型的抽搐机制？如果您想不出任何东西，请在互联网上查找具有抽搐组件的纸牌游戏规则（例如Slapjack、Brawl和Egyptian Ratscrew）。

1.    Brainstorm or research. What kinds of twitch mechanics are possible with dice? If you can’t think of anything, look on the Internet for rules of card games that have twitch components (such as Slapjack, Brawl, and Egyptian Ratscrew).

2.考虑物理困难。 避免使用可能使游戏变得困难的机制。例如，如果掷骰子后玩家必须快速抓取某些骰子，那么在玩家抓取骰子时，骰子的正面可能会发生变化。如果骰子上显示的数字很重要，那么不加区别地抓取或囤积骰子可能会造成问题，需要避免或解决。    

2.     Consider physical difficulties. Avoid mechanics that might make play difficult. For example, if the dice are rolled and then players must quickly grab certain dice, there is the possibility that the facing of the dice could be changed while players grab them. If the numbers displayed on the dice matter, indiscriminate grabbing or hoarding of dice could cause problems and would need to be avoided or worked around.

3.创建机制。想出一套初步的机制。确定目标、游戏进程以及游戏结束的规则。    

3.     Create mechanics. Come up with a preliminary set of mechanics. Decide on an objective, progression of play, and rules for how the game ends.

4.游戏测试。对于这样一款节奏紧凑的游戏，你应该能够在短时间内玩很多次，最终获得高质量的完美体验。    

4.     Playtest. For such a fast-moving game, you should be able to play many times in a short period of time, ending up with a high-quality polished experience.

5.创建可交付成果。    

5.     Create deliverable.

挑战四——压力之下逃避

CHALLENGE 4—AVOIDANCE UNDER PRESSURE

躲避是电子游戏中常见的机制。街机游戏经常迫使你躲避敌人、射弹或汽车，否则就会被杀死。其他游戏将躲避作为次要策略。在 FPS 中，躲避是留在游戏中的关键。有些游戏将躲避发挥到了极致，让玩家必须练习隐身。选择任何你拥有或可以玩的没有明确时间限制的电子游戏（如果是你自己创作的，那就更好了）。创建该游戏的非数字版本，使用躲避策略，并通过使用时间压力逐渐增加挑战性。你甚至可以使用计时器来查看玩家是否按时完成任务。

Avoidance is a common mechanic employed in video games. Arcade games regularly force you to avoid enemies, projectiles, or cars, or be killed. Other games use avoidance as a secondary tactic. In an FPS, avoidance is key to staying in the game. Some games take avoidance to the peak by putting the player in the position where she must practice stealth. Choose any video game that you own or have access to that does not have an explicit time limit (if it’s your own creation, so much the better). Create a non-digital version of that game that employs avoidance and gets progressively more challenging through the use of time pressure. You may even use a timer to see whether players complete their tasks on time.

所需组件

Components Required

·      可玩的视频游戏

·      Playable video game

·      计时器（如时钟、秒表或厨房计时器）

·      Timer (such as a clock, stopwatch, or kitchen timer)

可交付成果

Deliverable

·      制定书面规则

·      Written rule set

·      游戏原型

·      Prototype of game

建议流程

Suggested Process

1.选择一款游戏。一款需要避免某些事情的游戏是必要的。如果您遇到困难，请在 BoardGameGeek.com 上查找苏格兰场，了解成功避免某些事情的示例。    

1.     Choose a game. A game where there is something to avoid is necessary. If you’re having trouble, look up Scotland Yard on BoardGameGeek.com for an example of avoidance done well.

2.选择躲避手段。 你的玩家在躲避什么，他们会用什么手段来躲避？记住，躲避应该是主要活动，而不是从 A 点冲到 B 点的次要活动。    

2.     Choose a means of avoidance. What are your players avoiding, and what means will they be using to avoid it? Remember that avoidance should be the primary activity, not secondary to blasting your way from point A to point B.

3.选择一种时间推进方式。什么可以加快游戏中的时间？为什么玩家需要加快速度？如果游戏的叙述或设置中有可信的东西，那么这将大大增加可信度。    

3.     Choose a means of time progression. What speeds up the time in the game? Why is it that players need to go faster? If there’s something believable in the narrative or setting of the game, that goes a long way toward increasing believability.

4.测试游戏。你是否发现自己以隐秘的方式玩游戏，因为这是最佳方式，还是因为你试图让挑战对你有利？加入时间压力会如何影响事情？    

4.     Test the game. Do you find yourself playing in a stealthy way because it’s optimum or because you’re trying to make the challenge work for you? How does the inclusion of time pressure affect things?

5.创建可交付成果。    

5.     Create deliverable.

铁杆设计师挑战 5——太难了！

IRON DESIGNER CHALLENGE 5—THAT’S HARD!

过去，街机游戏的目标是让玩家输钱（最好在三分钟或更短的时间内输掉），以使机器尽可能赚钱。这些游戏通常没有多个难度级别。今天，许多玩家希望获得更长、更可定制的体验，但可能不那么紧张。也许是时候我们考虑一下如何将早期的安排（吸引玩家，然后付费玩游戏）运用到今天。

Back in the day, the goal of arcade games was to make the player lose (preferably in three minutes or fewer) to make the machines as profitable as they could be. These games did not typically have multiple difficulty levels. Today, many players expect a longer and more customizable experience that is perhaps not quite so intense. Maybe it’s time we consider how that early arrangement—hook ’em, and then pay for play—could be employed today.

选择任何你熟悉的游戏，并添加必要的机制，结束游戏但允许玩家继续玩，前提是他们负担得起。你可能还需要添加一些机制，让玩家在游戏正常结束之前被移除。你可以为这个练习选择一款数字或非数字游戏（或者让一个有虐待倾向的人为你选择一款游戏）。

Select any game with which you’re familiar and add the necessary mechanics that end the game but allow players to keep playing, provided they can afford it. You may need to also add mechanics that cause the player to be removed from the game before its normal end. You may choose a digital or non-digital game for this exercise (or have someone with a sadistic streak choose a game for you).

所需组件

Components Required

·      用于研究的视频游戏或非数字游戏原型组件

·      A video game or non-digital game for research Components for prototype

可交付成果

Deliverable

·      允许难度扩展原型的机制列表

·      List of mechanics that allow for difficulty scaling Prototype

建议流程   

Suggested Process    

1.选择游戏考虑选择一款不会提供直接和明显解决方案的游戏。事实上，解决方案越不明显，你从挑战中获得的收获就越多。    

1.     Select a game Consider picking a game that doesn’t offer up an immediate and obvious solution. In fact, the less obvious, the more you’ll get out of the challenge.

2.集思广益，想出各种机制。 至少，这里有三件事需要解决：a) 游戏如何结束，b) 玩家如何继续玩，以及 c) 玩家如何获得允许他继续玩的资源（如果有的话）。尝试各种可能性。    

2.     Brainstorm mechanics. At a minimum, there are three things to be addressed here: a) how the game ends, b) how the player keeps playing, and c) how the player gets the resource (if any) that allows him to keep playing. Experiment with a variety of possibilities.

3.创建可交付成果。    

3.     Create deliverable.

非数字短片

NON-DIGITAL SHORTS

这些短片将锻炼你制作让别人感动的游戏的能力。

These shorts will exercise your ability to make games that cause others to move.

1.    创建一个不涉及痛苦的游戏，使用 10 支铅笔，谁先将所有铅笔都用完，谁就是获胜者。

1.    Create a game that doesn’t involve pain that uses 10 pencils and whose winner is the one to get rid of all those pencils first.

2.    时间压力通常是游戏的一个因素。但有时，时间压力也取决于设计师。从家里或办公室的杂物抽屉里或桌子上拿出的前 10 件东西来制作游戏。您有 20 分钟的时间来完成该游戏的第一次迭代。（类似的练习通常用于教导入门级设计学生，他们可以制作任何主题的游戏。）

2.    Time pressure is usually a factor in a game. Sometimes, though, it’s on the designer. Create a game from the first 10 things you pull from your home or office junk drawer or which are sitting on your desk. You have 20 minutes to complete your first iteration of that game. (A similar exercise is commonly used to teach entry-level design students that one can make a game about anything.)

3.    将 FPS 重新设想为非数字艺术作品，其中的枪不再是枪，但游戏的基本机制保持不变。该作品应具有政治性质，并旨在表达某种观点。

3.    Re-envision an FPS as a non-digital art piece where the gun isn’t a gun but the basic mechanics of the game remain unchanged. The piece should be political in nature and be designed to make a statement.

4.    创建一个包含实时游戏的基于图块的游戏。想想Slapjack，但不要做Slapjack。

4.    Create a tile-based game that incorporates real-time play. Think Slapjack, but don’t do Slapjack.

5.    创建一款单人游戏，要求玩家在一定时间内完成一系列给定的任务。您可以为现有游戏添加时间限制，也可以创建自己的游戏。

5.    Create a single-player game that requires the player to complete a given series of tasks within a certain period of time. You may add a time limit to an existing game or create one of your own.

6.    创造一款只使用棍棒和石头作为游戏道具的敏捷游戏。游戏必须不涉及身体风险——不存在骨折的可能性。

6.    Create a dexterity game using only sticks and stones as game bits. The game must involve no physical risk—no possibility of broken bones.

7.    制作一款卡牌游戏，游戏概念是玩家必须齐心协力拆除炸弹。设置时间限制，炸弹爆炸后，玩家如果花费的时间太长就会输。

7.    Create a card-based game with the concept that the players must work together to defuse a bomb. Use a time limit, where the bomb blows up and the players lose if they take too long.

8.以    Trivial Pursuit之类的问答游戏为例，修改规则，让玩家必须快速回答问题，而不仅仅是准确回答。请注意这会如何改变动态。

8.    Take a trivia game like Trivial Pursuit and modify the rules in such a way that players must answer their questions quickly, not just accurately. Note how this changes the dynamics.

9.    修改现有的主要使用灵巧机制的非数字游戏，将其重点改为纯速度。或者将纯速度游戏修改为灵巧游戏。

9.    Modify an existing non-digital game that uses primarily dexterity mechanics, changing its focus to pure speed. Or modify a pure speed game to be a dexterity game.

10. 考虑任何有身体接触的运动。修改规则，使运动员之间完全没有接触（甚至不使用触摸或旗帜）。

10. Consider any physical contact sport. Modify the rules so that there is absolutely no contact between players at all (not even using touching or flags).

参考

REFERENCES

1可在线访问：http://www.shockwave.com/contentPlay/shockwave.jsp?id=nbrainer& preplay=1（2008 年 5 月 26 日访问）。

1 Available online at http://www.shockwave.com/contentPlay/shockwave.jsp?id=nbrainer& preplay=1 (Accessed May 26, 2008).



 

 

8：机会与技巧：寻找平衡

8: Chance & Skill: Finding the Balance

有些游戏完全是靠运气，玩家的决策不需要技巧。其中大部分要么是儿童游戏（如《蛇梯棋》和《战争》），要么是赌博游戏（如《轮盘赌》和《基诺》）。儿童游戏对于那些没有太多观察随机过程经验的人来说很有吸引力。赌博游戏之所以引人注目，是因为它们提供了给玩家真钱的可能性。这些游戏在第 5 章“运气元素”中进行了详细讨论。

Some games are all chance and have no skill-based player decisions. Most of these are either children’s games (like Chutes and Ladders and War) or gambling games (such as Roulette and Keno). Children’s games are compelling for those who do not have much experience observing random processes. Gambling games are compelling because they offer the possibility of giving the player real money. These games are discussed in detail in Chapter 5, “Elements of Chance.”

相反，有些游戏则完全依赖技巧。这些游戏从简单的井字游戏到复杂的国际象棋和围棋，各不相同。战略技巧（与大多数回合制战略游戏一样）和敏捷技巧（在灵巧游戏和体育运动中发现）之间也存在差异。这些游戏之所以有趣，是因为玩家做出了有意义的决定。这两类技巧在第 6 章“‘战略’技巧的要素”和第 7 章“‘敏捷’技巧的要素”中进行了介绍。

Some games, by contrast, are all skill. These vary from the simplistic (Tic-Tac-Toe) to the complex (Chess and Go). There are also differences between strategic skill (as with most turnbased strategy games) and twitch skill (found in dexterity games and sports). These games can be fun because of the meaningful decisions that players make. These two types of skill are covered in Chapters 6, “Elements of ‘Strategic’ Skill,” and 7, “Elements of ‘Twitch’ Skill.”

许多游戏介于两者之间。《卡坦岛》有许多基于技能的游戏元素，包括交易、建造和资源管理。但是，它也有随机掷骰子、一副洗好的牌和随机棋盘设置。双陆棋 和扑克都具有很强的技巧和运气元素。想象一下没有掷骰子的双陆棋游戏，或者没有下注或虚张声势能力的扑克游戏，很明显，有些游戏结合了技巧和机会会更好。去掉其中任何一个，游戏就无法那么引人注目。

Many games fall somewhere in between. Settlers of Catan has many skill-based gameplay elements, including trading, building, and resource management. However, it also has random die rolls, a deck of shuffled cards, and a random board setup. Backgammon and Poker both have strong skill and luck elements. Imagine a game of Backgammon without die rolls, or Poker without the ability to bet or bluff, and it becomes apparent that some games are better with a mix of skill and chance. Remove either one, and the game fails to be as compelling.

游戏设计师如何在游戏中合理结合技巧和运气？何时适合将游戏推向一个极端或另一个极端？

How does a game designer include the correct mix of skill and chance in a game? When is it appropriate to shift a game toward one extreme or the other?

考虑目标受众

CONSIDER THE TARGET AUDIENCE

谁是玩家？这是一个重要的问题，通常是设计师首先要问的问题。为六岁儿童设计的游戏与为大学年龄的男性设计的游戏结果截然不同。不同的玩家对机会和技巧的容忍程度不同。对于小女孩来说可能很有趣的游戏，对于成年人来说很快就会变得无聊，玩过许多儿童游戏的父母可以证明这一点。

Who is the player? This is an important question, often the first one that a designer asks. Designing a game for six-year-olds leads to very different results than a game meant for college-age males. Different players have different levels of tolerance for chance and skill. What might be a blast for a young girl quickly becomes boring for an adult, as parents that have played any number of children’s games can attest.

孩子们

CHILDREN

当第一次被要求为儿童设计游戏时，许多成年人都认为这是一件容易的事。然而，当他们开始真正设计或测试游戏时，他们很快意识到制作一款简单但引人入胜的游戏是多么复杂。平衡运气和技巧是一项关键任务，要做到这一点，就必须了解目标受众。

When first tasked with designing a game for children, many adults assume it’s an easy proposition. However, when they start to actually design or playtest the game, they quickly realize just how complicated it can be to make a game that’s simple but compelling. Balancing luck and skill is a critical task, and to do this it is necessary to understand the target audience.

首先，孩子们玩游戏是为了获得乐趣。老师可能会给他们布置一些游戏来学习，但孩子们听到“游戏”这个词的主要目的是为了在游戏过程中获得乐趣。这意味着他们希望获胜，并希望有机会打败与他们一起玩的任何人，尤其是他们的父母。当然，对于普通孩子来说，这需要很大的运气。

First and foremost, children are playing a game to have fun. Teachers may assign them games to learn, but the children’s primary goal upon hearing “game” is to have fun along the way. That means that they hope to win and want to have a chance of beating anyone they’re playing with, especially their parents. Naturally, for the average child, this requires a lot of luck.

五岁以下的儿童可能还不具备在游戏中做出战略决策或追踪资源所需的心理技能。幼儿游戏往往很少有玩家需要做出决策，而且这些游戏有很大的运气成分。通常，这些游戏还允许儿童在游戏过程中脱离游戏的节奏，这样每一轮游戏都与即时性有关（我现在需要做什么？），而不是持久性和策略性（上一轮我该如何行动，这一轮我最终会如何行动，以及这一轮最终会如何实现我最终想要达到的目标？）。随着孩子年龄的增长，基于技能的决策的数量和复杂性会逐渐增加，从而取代一些运气因素。

Children younger than five may not yet possess the mental skills necessary to make strategic decisions in a game or to keep track of resources. Games for the young tend to have few, if any, player decisions, and those games have strong elements of chance. Often, these games also allow children to disconnect from turn to turn so that each turn is about immediacy (what do I need to do now?), not permanence and strategy (how will my move last turn and this turn ultimately lead to where I want to be in the end?). As children get older, the number and complexity of skill-based decisions can gradually increase, displacing some of the luck.

这是否意味着孩子们只能玩纯粹靠运气的游戏？不，特别是当他们在相对势均力敌的比赛中互相对抗时。棒球和捉人等体力游戏需要技巧。井字游戏也是如此。

Does that mean that children can only play games that are purely luck based? No, particularly if they are playing against each other where they are relatively evenly matched. Physical games like Baseball and Tag involve skill. So does Tic-Tac-Toe.

然而，游戏的复杂程度与技巧水平必须同步提高。幸运的是，许多幼儿游戏中缺乏技巧和运气成分较高，并不会破坏大多数孩子的游戏体验。事实上，如果被问到，大多数孩子都会坚称自己擅长玩纯粹靠运气的游戏。例如，幼儿常常觉得掷骰子掷出高数字是一种技巧。

However, the level of skill involved must go hand in hand with the degree of complexity. Fortunately, the lack of skill and the high degree of luck in many young kids’ games doesn’t ruin the play experience for most kids. In fact, if asked, most kids will insist they are great at games that involve pure luck. For example, young children often feel that rolling high numbers on dice is a skill.

竞技游戏玩家

COMPETITIVE GAMERS

具有竞争意识的玩家往往更喜欢技巧性更强的游戏。这为他们提供了与其他玩家一对一较量的机会，让他们的大脑与大脑、反应与反应、策略与策略进行较量。真正具有竞争意识的玩家最不 希望看到的是，掷骰子毁掉了完美执行和技巧娴熟的游戏。

Players with a competitive streak tend to prefer games with more elements of skill. It provides them with a chance to go one on one with another player, matching brain against brain, reflexes against reflexes, strategy against strategy. The last thing a truly competitive player wants is a die roll ruining a perfectly executed and skillful play.

为了说明这一点，我们来看看保龄球游戏。想象一下，如果有 20% 的概率，一阵强风会将球吹向某个方向。显然，一般的保龄球手会放弃这样的游戏，或者至少会宣称游戏“只是为了好玩”，而不是真正衡量他的技术。

To illustrate this, consider the game Bowling. Imagine if there was a 20-percent chance that a strong breeze would push upon the ball causing it to go in one direction or another. Obviously, the average bowler would quit such a game, or at the very least declare that the game was “just for fun” and not a true measure of his skill.

像国际象棋这样的游戏都是靠技巧来玩的。风险部分是运气，但只是因为它包含了战斗掷骰子和随机抽牌。然而，运气被首先袭击另一个国家的战略决策所减轻。

Games like Chess are all about skill. Risk is partly luck, but only because of its inclusion of die rolls for combat and random card draw. The luck, however, is mitigated by the strategic decision to raid another country in the first place.

为什么设计师会在基于技能的游戏中增加运气元素？原因有很多——它让游戏变得不可预测，增加了可玩性，并允许技能略有不同的玩家相互竞争。如果更优秀的玩家总是获胜，那么唯一有趣的游戏就是两个势均力敌的玩家之间的游戏。游戏中的运气成分越多，玩家技能水平之间的潜在差异就越大，同时仍能保证游戏的精彩性。此外，即使是很小的随机元素也能减轻输掉游戏的痛苦；一些竞争激烈的玩家是为了赢而玩，而半运气半技能的游戏会让赢家觉得自己技能出众，而输家则觉得自己只是运气不好。

Why would designers add luck to skill-based games? Many reasons—it keeps things unpredictable, increases replayability, and it allows players of slightly differing skills to compete. If the better player always wins, then the only games that are interesting are those between two players who are evenly matched. The greater the amount of luck in the game, the greater the potential difference between the players’ skill levels while still allowing for a good game. Additionally, even a small random element can take some of the sting out of losing; some highly competitive players play to win, and a part-luck, part-skill game allows the winner to feel like he has superior skill while the loser can feel like it was just an unlucky die roll.

社交游戏玩家

SOCIAL GAMERS

每当很多人谈论游戏时，就会发生一场有趣的争论。有些人会强烈宣称大富翁是一款糟糕的游戏。其他人则坚持认为它很精彩。造成这种差异的原因是什么？我们玩游戏的原因不同。

There’s an interesting discussion that happens whenever lots of people talk about games. Some will vehemently declare that Monopoly is a terrible game. Others will insist that it’s brilliant. The reason for the difference? We play games for different reasons.

社交型玩家（即那些主要出于社交目的而玩游戏的人）并不太在意激烈的策略。事实上，有些人可能认为这会削弱游戏的“乐趣”。他们玩大富翁是为了社交和与朋友聊天。对他们来说，游戏体验才是最重要的，输赢无所谓。这些人可以容忍更大范围的运气，尽管仍然需要有足够多的有趣决定（尤其是那些影响其他玩家的决定，从而引发社交游戏）来创造玩游戏的理由。
