对于此变体，请选择不同的运动。理想情况下，选择一项您已经觉得无聊或毫无意义的运动。这将帮助您培养进行各种其他市场研究所需的同理心技能。您的运动必须至少有一款基于它的已发布视频游戏。

For this variant, choose a different sport. Ideally, select a sport that you already find boring or pointless. This will help you build the empathy skills you’ll need to do all kinds of other market research. Your sport must have at least one published video game that is based on it.

挑战 2——塑造群体

CHALLENGE 2—MOLDING THE MOB

以黑手党为主题的电影、电视节目和书籍一直很受欢迎。黑手党也是游戏中的热门主题，尽管人们在想到“黑手党游戏”时首先想到的并不是社交模拟游戏。您的出版商认为这是一个疏忽。鉴于《模拟人生》系列的巨大成功，出版商认为有人会很好地探索黑手党的黑暗面只是时间问题。他们希望您能成为这样做的团队。他们希望您不仅能为潜在游戏创造概念，还能在此过程中为他们创造原创 IP。因此，您不得使用任何现有的与黑手党相关的 IP。

Movies, televisions shows, and books that feature the Mafia are ever popular. The Mafia is also a popular subject in games, although social simulations aren’t the first genre that comes to mind when one thinks of a “Mob game.” Your publisher believes this is an oversight. Given the amazing success of The Sims series, the publisher figures it’s only a matter of time before someone explores a darker side well. They hope you’ll be the team to do it. They expect you to create not only a concept for a potential game, but also an original IP for them in the process. As such, you may not use any existing Mob-related IPs.

所需组件

Components Required

·      互联网连接（用于研究）

·      Internet connection (for research)

可交付成果

Deliverable

·      一页纸概括模拟游戏的定义特征

·      One-page summary of the defining hallmarks of a simulation game

·      一页纸的关于您新 IP 的摘要

·      One-page summary of your new IP

·      非正式推介，重点介绍游戏的核心、新兴叙事的潜力以及功能集

·      Informal pitch featuring the game’s core, potential for emergent narrative, and feature set

建议流程

Suggested Process

1.    研究黑手党。 选择一种方法来研究黑手党的组织结构。研究您认为在以社会模拟的形式表达时可能与该主题相关的所有内容。列出玩家希望在黑手党游戏中看到的内容。

1.    Research the Mob. Select a means to research the organizational structure of the Mob. Research everything you feel might be relevant to the topic when expressed as a social simulation. Make a list of things players will expect to see in a game that features the Mafia.

2.    研究社交模拟。哪些功能使游戏成为社交模拟？这些游戏如何运作？查找在线提示指南或常见问题解答，并研究这些游戏的结构。

2.    Research social simulations. What features make a game a social simulation? How do these games work? Find an online hint guide or FAQ and study the structure of these games.

3.    研究现代 Mob 游戏。玩一款基于 Mob 的现代游戏。他们强调了哪些主题？这些主题是该类型游戏的要求还是该主题的要求？

3.    Research modern Mob games. Play a modern game based on the Mob. What topics did they highlight? Were those topics a requirement of the genre or of the topic?

4.    集思广益。集体讨论可能的概念。留出两个小时的时间就一个概念达成一致，并充实一些基本细节。

4.    Brainstorm. In a group, discuss potential concepts. Allow two hours to agree on a single concept and flesh out some basic details.

5.    创建可交付成果。

5.    Create deliverable.

挑战 3——创意探索

CHALLENGE 3—IDEA EXPLORATION

一位出版商联系了您，提出了一个并不奇怪的要求：他们想再次接触到那个难以捉摸的“普通人”（请参阅​​第 11 章“瞄准市场”，挑战 3），并正在寻求能够超越第一人称射击游戏的创新开发商的提案。首先，他们希望您找到一个游戏前提，每个人都可以一目了然地理解，甚至不需要翻开盒子。对于这款产品，他们对知道“frag”是什么的人不感兴趣——他们想吸引在 PC 过道购物的普通圣诞节购物者。在你们初次见面时，他们会建议讨论烹饪、烧烤和度假等话题——几乎每个人——无论年轻还是年老、富有还是贫穷——都能理解和认同这些话题。

A publisher has contacted you with a not-so-odd request: They want to reach that elusive “everyman” again (see Chapter 11, “Targeting a Market,” Challenge 3) and are seeking proposals from innovative developers able to see beyond the shelves of first-person shooters. First, they want you to find a game premise that everyone can understand at a single glance without even flipping over the box. For this product, they’re not interested in someone who knows what a “frag” is—they want to grab the average Christmas shopper going through the PC aisle. During your initial meeting, they suggest topics like cooking, barbecuing, and vacations—topics that practically every person—young or old, rich or poor—can understand and identify with.

对于这个挑战，你的任务是开发一个人们一眼就能看懂的 IP（比如Deer Hunter）。开发完 IP 后，为该 IP 在各种类型中开发一系列潜在应用：大亨游戏、RTS、FPS、RPG、MMO、休闲游戏等。

For this challenge, it’s your task to develop an IP that someone can understand at a glance (like Deer Hunter). Once you have developed the IP, develop a spectrum of potential applications for that IP in a variety of genres: tycoon, RTS, FPS, RPG, MMO, casual games, and so on.

查看视频游戏类型的列表，看看有哪些可能性。发行商希望看到该 IP 在各种类型的范围内至少有六种不同的应用。

Go down the list of video-game genres to see what the possibilities are. The publisher would like to see at least six different applications of the IP across a spectrum of genres.

所需组件

Components Required

·      没有任何

·      None

可交付成果

Deliverable

·      知识产权和

·      Summary of the IP and

·      撰写或讨论该 IP 在至少六种不同类型中的应用。针对每种类型，讨论一两个关键功能，并用几句话总结游戏玩法。

·      A write up or discussion on the IP applied to at least six different genres. For each, discuss one or two key features and summarize gameplay in a few sentences.

建议流程

Suggested Process

1.    集思广益。考虑出版商的要求，集思广益，列出一整套想法，无论它们看起来与视频游戏有多小的关联。记下每个人都能理解的爱好、喜欢、不喜欢、物质商品和工作。将列表缩小到 10 种不同的可能性。

1.    Brainstorm. Consider the request of the publisher, and brainstorm a whole list of ideas, no matter how little they seem to relate to video games. Note hobbies, likes, dislikes, material goods, and jobs everyone understands. Narrow your list down to 10 different possibilities.

2.    考虑游戏类型。将您想到的每个想法归类到一系列游戏类型中，看看是否有游戏创意出现。有些游戏很容易让人联想到游戏——例如烹饪大亨。其他游戏则会带来更多的笑声而不是可能性（例如烧烤 FPS）。也不要觉得有必要将自己限制在主流游戏类型中。对于这个挑战，一切都是开放的。考虑 4X 游戏、冒险游戏、2D 平台游戏和战术角色扮演游戏。要了解不同类型的好主意，请访问流行的独立游戏网站，其中列出了按这些类型列出的游戏。

2.    Think genre. Subject each idea you come up with to a series of genres to see if any game ideas rise. Some will suggest games easily—cooking tycoon, for instance. Others will provide more laughter than possibility (like the barbecue FPS). Don’t feel the need to limit yourself to mainstream genres, either. For this challenge, it’s all open. Consider 4X games, adventure games, 2D platformers, and tactical RPGs. For a good idea of different genres, visit a popular indie games site where games are listed by these genres.

3.    想好名字。2005年，《卡特彼勒建筑大亨》发布。你可能从未听说过这款游戏，但你已经知道它到底是什么了。试着给你的潜在游戏起一个类似的名字。记住，这是你这个项目可交付成果的一部分。你能给一款游戏打上品牌烙印，让它在标题中告诉你它的全部内容吗？

3.    Think names. In 2005, Caterpillar Construction Tycoon was released. You may never have heard of the game, but you already know exactly what it’s about. Try to title your potential games similarly. Remember that this is a component of your deliverable for this project. Can you brand a game such that it tells you what it’s all about in the title alone?

4.    创建可交付成果。

4.    Create deliverable.

挑战 4 — 一无所知

CHALLENGE 4—CLUELESS

在上一个挑战中，你可能选择了一种让你感觉至少舒服的游戏类型，相对比较安全。但对于这个挑战，你必须选择一个你一无所知的游戏类型，定义其特征（是什么让它成为游戏类型），并尝试为它设计一款游戏。

In the previous challenge, you’ve probably played it relatively safe by selecting a genre that made you feel, at the very least, comfortable. For this challenge, though, you must select a genre about which you know nothing, define its hallmarks as a genre (what makes it what it is), and attempt to design a game for it.

所需组件

Components Required

·      用于研究的互联网连接

·      Internet connection for research

·      选定类型的游戏（可选）

·      Game of selected genre (optional)

可交付成果

Deliverable

·      三页概念文档或

·      Three-page concept doc or

·      五页的提案文件，列出游戏的人口统计、功能和游戏概述或

·      Five-page proposal document listing the game’s demographics, features, and gameplay overview or

·      非数字化的纸质游戏原型。您可以选择任何您喜欢的媒介，包括传统的 RPG。

·      Non-digital paper prototype of the game. You may choose any medium you like, including a traditional RPG.

建议流程

Suggested Process

1.    寻找游戏类型。 向其他人询问游戏类型建议或查看 Wikipedia 的游戏类型列表（在“视频游戏类型”下搜索）。选择一个你不熟悉的类型。可能的候选类型包括 4X 游戏、冒险游戏、射击游戏、回合制幻想游戏或文字冒险游戏。访问任何优秀的独立游戏网站，如 ManifestoGames.com，查看主流行业之外提供的各种游戏类型。

1.    Find a genre. Ask others for genre recommendations or review Wikipedia’s listing of game genres (search under video game genres). Select one that’s not known to you. Likely candidates are 4X games, adventure games, shmups, turn-based fantasy games, or text adventures. Visit any good indie game site, like ManifestoGames.com, to see the variety of genres offered outside the mainstream industry.

2.    探索游戏类型。 玩多款同类型的游戏，了解基本的游戏风格以及玩家的期望。例如，玩过几款射击游戏后，你对其中一款游戏的期望就会有一个基本的概念。在玩游戏时仔细思考，并记下该类型的基本机制，以及它如何奖励玩家的进步。

2.    Explore the genre. Play multiple games in the genre to get an idea of the basic gameplay style, as well as player expectations. After you play a few shmups, for instance, you have a basic idea of what to expect in one of those games. Think through the games as you play them and make note of the basic mechanics of the genre, as well as how it rewards its players for progress.

3.    集思广益。

3.    Brainstorm.

4.    创建可交付成果。

4.    Create deliverable.

铁艺设计师挑战 5——类型转变

IRON DESIGNER CHALLENGE 5—GENRE CHANGE

似乎每个人都在玩最新的游戏——无论你和谁聊天，他们都会津津乐道这款游戏，而且这款游戏会让他们彻夜难眠。它的在线游戏、故事情节、人工智能或其他东西都是首屈一指的。它可能是 MMO 或 FPS，但无论它是什么，你已经知道了。

It seems everyone’s playing the latest game—no matter who you talk to, it’s the game on the tip of their tongues and the one that’s keeping them up half the night. Its online play or storyline or AI or something is second to none. It might be an MMO or an FPS, but whatever it is, you know it already.

发行商热衷于最大限度地提高游戏的潜在收入，并已与您接洽，希望您设计一款新游戏——IP 的集换式卡牌游戏 (CCG) 版本。他们自然希望复制《万智牌》或《精灵宝可梦》卡牌的成功。他们希望 CCG 能够利用 IP 并实现在线游戏。但是，它必须提供完全不同的游戏体验。玩家无需玩过或拥有主产品即可玩 CCG，但如果 CCG 能够融入主产品的一些组件，让玩家认出并欣赏这些组件，那就再理想不过了。游戏如何融入这些想法取决于您。

Its publishers are keen to maximize the game’s potential revenue, and have approached you to design something new—a collectible card game (CCG) version of the IP. Naturally, they hope to replicate the success of the Magic: The Gathering or Pokémon cards. They want the CCG to take advantage of the IP and be playable online. However, it must provide a different play experience altogether. Players need not have played or own the main product to play the CCG, but it would be ideal if the CCG incorporated some components of the main product that players will recognize and appreciate if they had. How the game incorporates these ideas is up to you.

所需组件

Components Required

·      用于研究的互联网连接

·      Internet connection for research

·      所选游戏的副本（可选）

·      Copy of selected game (optional)

可交付成果

Deliverable

·      涉案游戏的非数字卡牌原型

·      Non-digital card prototype of game in question

·      描述游戏玩法的书面规则

·      Written rules that describe the play of the game

·       CCG 的功能列表，并分析这些功能如何代表 CCG 类型以及如何融入您为此练习选择的 IP。

·      Feature list for CCG with analysis of how these features are representative of the CCG genre and incorporate the IP you have selected for this exercise.

建议流程

Suggested Process

1.    研究游戏。 如果你只是听说过大家都在谈论的最新游戏，那就花点时间实际玩一下，先以玩家的身份，然后以设计师的身份。如果出于实际原因无法这样做，至少要阅读足够多的评论和常见问题解答，以了解游戏。

1.    Research the game. If you’ve only been hearing about the latest new game that everyone’s talking about, take some time to actually play it, first as a player and then as a designer. If there are practical reasons that prevent you from doing so, at least read enough reviews and FAQs to get an understanding of the game.

2.    研究游戏类型。 如果你以前从未玩过 CCG，可以玩一些该类型的游戏，阅读一些可以在网上找到的 CCG 规则和卡牌列表，或者找几个喜欢该类型的人（在你当地或网上）并向你解释。

2.    Research the genre. If you’ve never played a CCG before, play some games in the genre, read some rules and card lists that can be found online for a selection of CCGs, or find several people (in your local area or online) who are fans of the genre and can explain it to you.

3.    集思广益。

3.    Brainstorm.

4.    创建可交付成果。 创建整个 CCG 是一项艰巨的任务；大多数基本套装都有超过 200 张独特的卡片。你只需要制作一个可玩的原型：一个单一的入门卡组（总共可能 60 张卡片，有些是重复的）打印两次。游戏不需要为了这个挑战而进行广泛的游戏测试和平衡，只要有基本机制就行。

4.    Create deliverable. Creating an entire CCG is a massive undertaking; most basic sets have over 200 unique cards. You only need to make a playable prototype: a single starter deck (perhaps 60 cards total, with some duplicates) printed twice. The game does not need to be extensively playtested and balanced for the purposes of this challenge, as long as the basic mechanics are there.

非数字短片

NON-DIGITAL SHORTS

每个短片都鼓励您以不同的方式探索一种类型或新类型。

Each of these shorts encourages you to explore a genre or a new genre in a different way.

1.    分析一款领土获取游戏（例如《卡卡颂》）并确定三种定义机制。使用相同的机制设计一款卡牌游戏。

1.    Analyze a territorial acquisition game (such as Carcassonne) and identify three defining mechanics. Design a card game using those same mechanics.

2.    设计一个游戏并编写两组规则，一组使用牌，另一组使用卡片，保持相同的核心和动态。

2.    Design a game and write two sets of rules, one using tiles and the other using cards, that maintain the same core and dynamics.

3.    选择一款经典纸牌游戏（例如Spades），并将其扩展为包含至少三种桌面角色扮演游戏中常见的机制。

3.    Choose a classic card game (such as Spades) and expand it to incorporate at least three mechanics common to tabletop role-playing games.

4.    设计一款无需骰子即可玩的桌面角色扮演游戏。

4.    Design a tabletop role-playing game, playable without dice.

5.创建    《Risk》的纸牌游戏版本。

5.    Create a card-game version of Risk.

6.    重新设计大富翁 ，使用所有原始棋子，使其像模拟游戏一样运行。

6.    Redesign Monopoly to operate like a sim game using all the original pieces.

7.    仅使用一副标准扑克牌和一把卷尺设计一款桌面微型游戏。

7.    Design a tabletop miniature game using only a standard deck of playing cards and a tape measure.

8.    选择你最喜欢的电子游戏类型，然后从该类型中选择一个你最喜欢的游戏。根据该电子游戏创建一个棋盘游戏或纸牌游戏。如果已经有一个，请选择不同的电子游戏。

8.    Choose your favorite video-game genre and then choose one of your favorite games within that genre. Create a board or card game based on the video game. If one already exists, choose a different video game.

9.    与前面类似，选择本章挑战 4 中选择的类型，并以此为基础创建棋盘游戏或纸牌游戏。您可以制作原创游戏，也可以基于现有视频游戏 IP 制作游戏。

9.    Similar to the preceding, choose the genre you selected for Challenge 4 in this chapter, and create a board or card game based on that. You may either make an original game or one based on an existing video-game IP.

10. 借鉴任何数字 RPG 中的战斗机制，并对其进行修改，以用于桌面 RPG。这可能涉及找到一个提示指南或常见问题解答，解释战斗机制的工作原理，然后对其进行简化，这样就不需要计算机进行数百次计算了。

10. Take the combat mechanics from any digital RPG and modify them to be used in a tabletop RPG. This may involve finding a hint guide or FAQ that explains how the combat mechanics work and then simplifying them so that they don’t require hundreds of calculations from a computer.

            

            


 

 

13：设计一个讲述故事的游戏

13: Designing a Game to Tell a Story

从某种意义上说，所有游戏都在讲述一个故事，即使这个故事是随着玩家在游戏中的行为而产生的。晚间新闻每晚都会播报体育比赛胜利的故事，而且越来越多的体育迷自己也变成了运动员，向朋友讲述他们在《Madden》和《Tiger Woods Golf》中的成功故事。这些也是故事。

In a sense, all games tell a story, even if that story is emergent and develops as a result of the player’s actions in the game. Stories of sports victories are told nightly on the evening news, and increasingly, fans of sports have turned players themselves, relating successes in Madden and Tiger Woods Golf to their friends. These are stories, too.

然而，当设计师创建一款讲述特定故事的游戏时，情况就不同了，而且具有挑战性。许多新晋设计师都计划在游戏中讲述史诗般的故事，但他们忘记了最重要的特点——游戏是关于玩家做出影响游戏结果的有意义的选择。如果“游戏”只是关于在一个或另一个故事分支中移动，那么实际上根本没有选择，因此，也就没有游戏了。“互动剧”可能是这些作家和设计师所创造的更好的术语。

When designers create a game to tell a specific story, however, it’s a different matter, and a challenging one. Many newly minted designers have grand plans to tell epic stories in their games, but they forget the most important feature of all—games are about players making meaningful choices that affect the outcome of the game. If the “game” is only about moving through one narrative branch or another, there’s really no choice at all, and therefore, there’s also no game. “Interactive dramas” might be a better term for what these writers and designers are creating.

由于游戏涉及做出影响游戏玩法的选择，因此讲述结构化的故事会出现某种悖论。想象一下，如果你能够打断电影 10 次以做出有意义的决定，电影会是什么样子——例如，角色是生是死，实现他的愿望，离开他的伴侣，或者其他任何转折。第一次看这部电影可能很有趣也很新奇，但过了一段时间，观众可能会更喜欢更有条理的东西。

Since games are about making choices that affect gameplay, telling a structured story presents a paradox of sorts. Think of how a movie would seem if you were able to interrupt it 10 different times to make meaningful decisions—for example, whether a character lives or dies, gets his wish, leaves his partner, or whatever the twist may be. It might be fun and novel the first time, but after a while, viewers might prefer something more structured.

在游戏中，有各种各样的方式来融入故事。我们将在这里介绍其中的一些方式。

In games, there are a variety of ways that stories are incorporated. We’ll cover some of those ways here.

作家、设计师，还是两者兼而有之？

WRITER, DESIGNER, OR BOTH?

游戏设计师创造游戏。游戏作家如 Lee Sheldon、Bob Bates、Mark Nelson 或 Susan O'Connor 创作故事。在许多情况下，游戏作家也是游戏设计师，但这两个工作截然不同，需要不同的技能。这个行业有许多出色的系统设计师，为了大家的利益，他们应该与游戏故事保持距离。在专业视频游戏开发中，当游戏作家从游戏一开始就参与其中时，效果最佳。对游戏写作感兴趣的人应该阅读Lee Sheldon 的《游戏角色发展和故事叙述》一书。

Game designers create games. Game writers like Lee Sheldon, Bob Bates, Mark Nelson, or Susan O’Connor create stories. In many cases, the game writer is also a game designer, but the two jobs are distinctly different and require different skill sets. There are many brilliant systems designers in this industry that should be kept at arm’s length of a game story for the good of everyone. In professional video-game development, the best results are achieved when a game writer is involved from the beginning of the game. Those interested in game writing should explore the book Character Development and Storytelling for Games by Lee Sheldon.

故事情节

STORY ARCS

就像长途旅行一样，对故事的发展方向有一个概念比临时拼凑故事更能产生更好的执行效果。为了做到这一点，游戏编剧会创建故事情节。“故事情节”是故事从头到尾的路径。在游戏中，通常使用两种情节：亚里士多德《诗学》中定义的经典三部分故事情节和约瑟夫·坎贝尔在《千面英雄》中定义的五部分情节。

Like taking a long road trip, having an idea of where your story is going results in a better execution than slapping a story together on the fly. To do this, game writers create story arcs. A “story arc” is the path that a story takes from beginning to end. In games, two kinds of arcs are commonly used: the classic three-part story arc, as identified in Aristotle’s Poetics and Joseph Campbell’s five-part arc, as defined in The Hero with a Thousand Faces.

三幕故事线

THE THREE-ACT STORY ARC

在三幕故事线中，故事遵循以下路径：

In the three-act story arc, the story follows this path:

·      第一幕：故事以一个激励时刻开始。“激励时刻”是一个从根本上改变或影响角色的问题。这是他感到被驱使去追求的东西。在这个激励时刻（前奏或开场）之前，可能要花几个小时玩游戏，但所有的游戏都会导向这个关键点。如果游戏没有从激励时刻开始，它至少应该让玩家从问题开始。进入一个没有目标、没有方向感、没有问题需要解决的游戏世界，会让玩家感到困惑、沮丧或无聊。事实上，游戏中的一个常见问题是，所谓的激励时刻根本无法激励玩家，或者看起来完全不可信，即使在想象的背景下也是如此。在激励时刻之后，玩家会花一段时间朝着他的最终目标前进——消灭反派、恢复家族名声等。

·      Act 1: The story begins with an inciting moment. An “inciting moment” is a problem that fundamentally changes or affects the character. It’s something he feels driven to pursue. There may be hours of gameplay before this inciting moment (a prelude or an opening), but all play leads up to this key point. If a game doesn’t start with the inciting moment, it should, at the very least, start the player with a problem. Arriving in a game world with no goal, no sense of direction, and no issue to resolve leaves players feeling confused, frustrated, or bored. A common problem in games, in fact, is that the alleged inciting moment fails to motivate the player at all or seems completely unbelievable, even in an imaginary context. Following the inciting moment, the player progresses for some time toward his ultimate goal—destroying the villain, restoring his family name, etc.

·      第二幕：戏剧性逆转发生。例如，也许主人公意识到他以为是朋友的人其实是他的敌人，而且一直在与他作对。戏剧性逆转应该合乎逻辑且可行，而不是亚里士多德所说的“天降神兵”，即一种不可能或不可能出现的“神之机器”，它是为了帮助作者实现自己的需求而创造的。

·      Act 2: A dramatic reversal occurs. For instance, perhaps the hero realizes that the person he thought was his friend is actually his enemy and has been working against him this whole time. The dramatic reversal should seem logical and possible, not what Aristotle calls a “deus ex machina,” an impossible or improbable “machine of the gods” created to help the writer achieve his needs.

·      第三幕：在激励时刻提出的目标得到解决。英雄得到他想要的东西，或者决定不得到他想要的东西。无论哪种方式，都会实现不可逆转的解决方案。有时，可能会发生第二次逆转。

·      Act 3: The goal presented in the inciting moment is resolved. The hero gets what he is looking for or resolves not to get what he is looking for. Either way, an irreversible resolution is achieved. Sometimes, a second reversal may occur.

许多游戏设计师都写过关于将三幕结构应用于视频游戏的文章。搜索 Gamasutra.com 的档案将提供大量参考资料，帮助您理解这种故事结构。

Numerous game designers have written about the three-act structure as applied to video games. A search through Gamasutra.com’s archives will provide numerous references to assist you in understanding this story structure.

五部曲英雄之旅

THE FIVE-PART HERO’S JOURNEY

1949 年，约瑟夫·坎贝尔出版了一部开创性的作品《千面英雄》。他在书中断言，尽管关于英雄的故事可以讲述成千上万个，但他们走的路其实只有一条。因此，在坎贝尔看来，只有一个英雄和一条路，但讲述的方式却千差万别。他称之为“单一神话”。

In 1949, Joseph Campbell published a seminal work, The Hero with a Thousand Faces. In his book, he asserted that although stories may be told about thousands of heroes, there really is only one path that they follow. Therefore, as Campbell saw it, there is but one hero and one path told in a thousand different ways. He called this the “monomyth.”

坎贝尔的五部分故事情节如下：

Campbell’s five-part story arc is as follows:

·      第 1 部分：英雄收到“冒险的召唤”，开始旅程。

·      Part 1: The hero receives a “call to adventure” and begins a journey.

·      第二部分：英雄经历了一系列的挑战（“考验之路”）。

·      Part 2: The hero passes through a series of challenges (a “trail of trials”).

 

 

·      第三部分：英雄对抗最后的邪恶，并实现目标。

·      Part 3: The hero confronts the final evil and achieves the goal.

·      第四部分：英雄重返日常世界。

·      Part 4: The hero returns to the everyday world.

·      第五部分：英雄将冒险中得到的教训或收获应用到日常生活中。

·      Part 5: The hero applies the lesson or object learned in the adventure to that everyday world.

和三幕结构一样，游戏设计师也探索了英雄之旅在视频游戏中的应用。在游戏开发网站上可以找到大量文章。

As with the three-act structure, game designers have also explored the use of the hero’s journey as applied to video games. Numerous articles can be found on game-development Web sites.

编剧大师图表

THE SCREENWRITER’S MASTER CHART

编剧玛丽·肖蒙 (Mary Shomon) 在她的《编剧大师图表》中扩展了亚里士多德的经典故事情节，其中包含 14 个独立幕，以及剧本页码，这些页码表明当这些事件发生时，编剧应该在剧本中的位置。完整的图表可以在肖蒙的网站上找到，网址为 http://members.aol.com/maryjs/scrnrite.htm。

Screenwriter Mary Shomon expanded upon Aristotle’s classic story arc in her “Screenwriter’s Master Chart,” which includes 14 separate acts, as well as script page numbers that suggest where a writer should be in the script when these events happen. The full chart may be found online on Shomon’s site at http://members.aol.com/maryjs/scrnrite.htm.

叙事学与游戏学

NARRATOLOGY AND LUDOLOGY

尽管主要在学术圈进行讨论，但了解叙事学和游戏学对于那些学习游戏讲故事的人来说很有用。

Though primarily discussed in academic circles, an understanding of narratology and ludology is useful to those learning about storytelling in games.

“游戏学”是研究游戏规则（或机制）的学科。游戏学家认为，游戏首先是一组规则，当玩家通过某种界面启动游戏时，这些规则会产生游戏动态。从这个角度来看，现代游戏是围棋和 国际象棋等古老游戏的延伸。故事不是游戏的一部分，而是叠加在游戏顶层的东西，就像劳拉·克劳馥和其他无数的故事叠加在第三人称射击游戏的机制之上一样。从本质上讲，第三人称射击游戏的规则保持不变。

“Ludology” is the study of games as rules (or mechanics). Ludologists believe that a game is first and foremost a collection of rules that give rise to the dynamics of play when a player sets the game in motion through an interface of some sort. From this perspective, modern-day games are an extension of ancient games like Go and Chess. Story is not a part of a game, but rather something layered on top, much like Lara Croft and other innumerable narratives are layered on top of the mechanics of third-person shooters. At the core, the third-person shooter rules remain unchanged.

“叙事学”是研究游戏作为一种叙事媒介的学科。正如电影要播放，剧场、摄像机、座位和布景必不可少，游戏规则对于讲故事也必不可少。从这个角度研究游戏的人被称为叙事学家。

“Narratology” is the study of games as a storytelling medium. Just as a theatre, camera, seats, and a setting are necessary for a movie to play out, so too are the rules of a game necessary for a story to be told. Those who study games from this perspective have been called narratologists.

这两种截然不同的思想流派在很大程度上就是思想。在游戏设计师的日常工作中，很少会像上面那样以黑白分明的定义来讨论这些话题。相反，设计师通常会关注游戏中哪些地方不够好，无论是平衡性问题还是他尚未实施的未经测试的故事路线。

These two divergent schools of thought are, for the most part, exactly that—thought. In the life of a work-a-day game designer, the topics are rarely discussed in as black-and white definitions as they are above. Rather, the designer usually focuses on what’s not up to snuff in the game, whether it’s something whacked with the balance or an untested story path he has yet to implement.

此外，这两种思想流派并不像许多人所描绘的那样处于“对立”状态。本书的一位作者是一位坚定的游戏学家，他认为游戏作家对于将当今一代的视频游戏提升到新水平至关重要。这两个流派是互补的。

Furthermore, these two schools of thought aren’t in a “versus” situation as many portray them to be. One of the authors of this books is a staunch ludologist, who believes that game writers are essential in order to bring today’s generation of video games to their next level. The two schools are complementary.

 游戏中的故事类型

 TYPES OF STORIES IN GAMES

在设计讲述故事的游戏时，设计师通常会有几种模型可供选择。设计师选择的模型通常由相关故事决定。例如，冒险游戏通常使用线性或分支叙事。大型现代 RPG 具有非线性或分支叙事。MMO 通常以实例或突发故事为特色。任何游戏都没有一种完美的故事类型。

When designing games to tell a story, designers typically have several models from which to choose. The model the designer chooses is usually dictated by the story in question. Adventure games, for instance, usually use linear or branching narratives. Larger, modern RPGs feature nonlinear or branching narratives. MMOs typically feature instances or emergent stories. There is no one perfect story type for any game.

线性故事

LINEAR STORIES

线性故事从 A 点发展到 B 点再到 C 点，并且经常有定期的可选支线任务。这类游戏通常被称为像火车一样“在轨道上”；玩家从某个点开始，直接走到终点。线性故事的好处是它与其他讲故事媒体有最多共同点，因此很熟悉。线性故事可以产生强烈的情感（只要问问玩过《星球陨落》或《最终幻想 VII》的人，当他们的同伴死去时，他们有什么感受）。它们也是唯一不需要玩家多次玩游戏才能看到所有可能结果的叙事结构； 对于非线性的故事，玩家可能会在第一次玩游戏时错过很多游戏内容。

Linear stories progress from point A to B to C and frequently have periodic, optional side quests. Games like this are often referred to as being “on rails” like a train; players start at one point and go straight to the end. The benefit of a linear story is that it shares the most in common with other storytelling media so it is familiar. Linear stories can be emotionally powerful (just ask anyone who played Planetfall or Final Fantasy VII what they felt when their companion died). They are also the only narrative structure that does not require players to play through the game several times just to see all possible outcomes; for stories that are not linear, the player may miss much of the game content on their first playthrough.

分支故事

BRANCHING STORIES

分支故事为玩家提供了多种方式来完成故事，并有可能出现多个结局。游戏路径会根据玩家的选择而改变。分支故事利用了游戏作为媒介所提供的互动性，并为故事情节留下了很大的空间，使其能够可信地响应玩家的决定。然而，根据媒介的不同，它们可能很昂贵，因为作者必须创作几个相关的故事，而不仅仅是一个。在电子游戏中，每个分支都可能意味着独特的艺术资产。

Branching stories present the player with multiple ways to get through a story with a possibility of multiple endings. The play paths change in response to choices the player makes. Branching stories take advantage of the interactivity offered by games as a medium, and they leave a lot of room for the storyline to respond believably to player decisions. However, depending on the medium, they can be expensive, as the writer must create several related stories instead of just one. In a video game, each of these branches could mean unique art assets.

完整分支故事的一种变体是平行路径，它迫使故事在某些关键点折回自身。通过这种方式，玩家可以多次分支，但总会发现自己面对相同的关键戏剧性时刻，尽管由于分支，他们可以通过各种方式到达这些时刻。通过这种方式，分支的成本保持在可控范围内，因为整体故事情节仍然是线性的。

One variant of a complete branching story, a parallel path, forces the story to fold back on itself at certain critical points. In this way, players can branch several times but will always find themselves facing the same key dramatic moments, although they can reach these moments in a variety of ways due to the branching. In this way, the cost of branching is kept manageable because the overall story arc is still linear.

开放式故事

OPEN-ENDED STORIES

开放式（或多线或线索式）故事让玩家从特定地点或多种地点开始，并允许他们向许多不同方向前进，每个方向都会影响游戏结果。《上古卷轴》系列，尤其是《湮没》，就是很好的例子。这类故事很难编写，因为玩家可能会以任何顺序采取任意数量的路径，而故事仍必须有意义。故事中可能出现的路径数量甚至比分支故事的数量还要多。设计师会小心防止出现由于顺序混乱而导致故事毫无意义的情况，方法是通过事实树限制玩家的选择（例如，如果他们不知道 X，就不要告诉他们 Y），或者为玩家采取的不同路径编写不同的故事。

Open-ended (or multilinear or threaded) stories start players in a particular place or a variety of places and allow them to progress is many different directions, each of which affects the outcome of their play. The Elder Scrolls series, particularly Oblivion, are excellent examples. These kinds of stories are difficult to write because the player may take any number of paths in any order, and the story still has to make sense. The number of possible paths through the story is even greater than that of a branching story. Designers are careful to prevent situations where the story makes no sense because it is told out of order, either by limiting the player’s choices through fact trees (for example, if they don’t know about X, don’t tell them about Y), or writing different stories for different paths that the player takes.

开放式游戏往往有专门的游戏作家或游戏作家团队，他们的工作是创造和实现这些宏大的故事。

Open-ended games tend to have dedicated game writers or teams of game writers whose job it is to create and implement these vast stories.

实例

INSTANCES

实例是开放式故事的一个特例。它们通常用于 MMO，为玩家或玩家组呈现特定故事线索的“实例”。例如，它可能很简单，如“去拿物体 Y，把它带给 X 先生，然后回到这里”。玩家可以选择尝试哪些实例以及尝试的顺序。就像电视剧中的情节一样，实例通常不会对整体故事情节产生太大影响。相反，它们是完整的、独立的小故事。这使得它们更容易编写，并且还允许在以后添加新的实例。

Instances are a special case of open-ended stories. They are commonly used in MMOs and present the player or group of players with an “instance” of a particular story thread. For example, it might be as simple as “Go get object Y, bring it to Mr. X, and then return here.” Players can choose which instances they attempt and in what order. Like episodes in a TV series, instances don’t usually affect the overall story arc that much. Rather, they are complete, self-contained mini-stories. This makes them easier to write, and it also allows new instances to be added at a later time.

新兴故事

EMERGENT STORIES

突发故事纯粹源自游戏的玩法机制。这些故事由玩家体验或玩家创建的内容创造，而不是由游戏设计师置于世界中。《模拟人生》系列就是大量使用突发故事的游戏的一个例子。玩家甚至会在网上发布他们的《模拟人生》冒险游戏视频。

Emergent stories arise purely from the play mechanics of the game. The stories are created by player experience or player-created content and are not placed within the world by the game’s designers. The Sims series is an example of a game that makes heavy use of emergent stories. Players even post gameplay movies of their Sims adventures online.

主题设置

THEMATIC SETUPS

主题设置，业内称为“开场过场动画”，在游戏开始时为玩家描绘了一幅画面，但在游戏开始后不再融入其他故事元素。许多棋盘游戏、动作游戏和早期的 8 位游戏都使用这种设置。在这种情况下，故事只不过是为规则设置背景的装饰。

Thematic setups, called “opening cutscenes” in the industry, paint a picture for the player in the game’s beginning, but integrate no further story components once the game has begun. Many board games, action games, and early 8-bit games use this setup. In this case, the story is little more than window dressing to set context for the rules.

算法故事

ALGORITHMIC STORIES

算法故事（例如《Façade》中的故事）由计算机 AI 构建，并根据玩家的输入确定故事的方向。虽然所有写作工作仍由人类完成，但 AI 仍被赋予了一组预先确定的情节点。它类似于基于幕的结构，其中每个“幕”都有多个入口和出口点，并且每个幕中的结局都是开放式的。因此，它就像是将一堆独立的、小的、结局开放的故事串联起来，形成一个更大的、结局开放的宏观故事。

Algorithmic stories such as the one found in Façade are constructed by computer AI and respond to player inputs to determine the story’s direction. While all the writing is still done by a human, the AI is still given a set of predetermined plot points. It’s similar to an act-based structure where each “act” has multiple entry and exit points, and within each act it’s kind of open-ended. So, it’s like having a bunch of self-contained, small, open-ended stories linked together in a larger, open-ended macro-story.

这些故事具有平行路径的优点（非线性、富有表现力的故事，没有全分支的爆炸性复杂性和成本）。缺点是这种故事形式非常新颖。Façade本身花了五年多的时间来构建，其故事情节仅在 20 分钟左右的时间内展开。

These stories share the advantages of parallel paths (nonlinear, expressive story without the explosive complexity and cost of full branching). The disadvantage is that this form of story is very new. Façade itself took over five years to construct, and its story plays out in a mere 20 minutes or so.

讲故事的方法

STORYTELLING METHODS

把任何游戏从架子上拿下来，或者更好的是，下载一个有故事情节的独立游戏。玩一个小时后，你通常就能看出设计师用什么方法来讲述游戏故事。游戏通常会使用多种方法的组合。

Take any game down from the shelf or, better yet, download an indie game with a story component. Within an hour of play, it’s generally obvious what methods the designers are using in order to tell the story of the game. Games often use a combination of methods.

过场动画和电影特效

CUTSCENES AND CINEMATICS

“过场动画”是设置或延续游戏叙事的电影，但发生在游戏引擎之外。

“Cutscenes” are movies that set up or continue the narrative of the game, but occur outside of the game’s engine.

 “过场动画”（或脚本事件）在游戏中使用游戏引擎来设置场景或以其他方式推进故事叙述。在某些情况下，玩家能够在过场动画期间控制部分动作或做出一两个选择。

 “Cinematics” (or scripted events) occur within the game using the game’s engine in order to set up a scene or otherwise advance the story’s narrative. In some cases, the player is able to control some of the action or make a choice or two during the cinematic.

请注意，这两个术语有时会互换使用。

Note that these two terms are occasionally used interchangeably.

过场动画和电影是一种以情感吸引人的方式呈现游戏故事的流行方式。许多游戏都有丰富的背景故事或基于生动细致的世界，但这些信息很难仅通过游戏玩法传达。因此，游戏作家有时会转向熟悉的媒介——电影的惯例。与迷你电影一样，电影和过场动画不受常规游戏的技术或界面要求的约束，因此它们可以真正令人叹为观止。许多玩家认为精心制作的精美过场动画为他们最喜欢的游戏增添了很大的深度和吸引力。《暗黑破坏神》 和《最终幻想》等游戏以拥有令人惊叹的过场动画而闻名。

Cutscenes and cinematics are a popular way to present a game’s story in an emotionally engaging way. Many games have rich back stories or are based on vibrantly detailed universes, but this information can be difficult to convey through gameplay alone. As a result, game writers sometimes turn to the conventions of a familiar medium—film. Like mini-movies, cinematics and cutscenes are unbound by the technical or interface demands of the regular game, and they can thus be truly spectacular. Many players feel that well-crafted, beautiful cutscenes add a great deal of depth and holding power to their favorite games. Games such as Diablo and Final Fantasy are renowned for having stunning cutscenes.

这些故事事件还可以用来缓解特别紧张的时刻（比如 Boss 战）之后的紧张气氛，让玩家放松。

These story events can also be used to break the tension after a particularly tense moment (such as a boss fight) as a way to allow the player to relax.

游戏内活动

IN-GAME EVENTS

虽然在某些方面与电影相似，但游戏中脚本事件通常不会剥夺玩家的控制权，而是在玩家在游戏中执行某​​些操作时触发。例如，当玩家到达某个关卡时，她可能会打断其他角色谈论某个特定事件。他们会转过头来看到她并发起攻击。在此过程中，玩家永远不会失去控制权。

While similar in some respects to a cinematic, scripted in-game events often do not remove control from the player, but trigger when the player does something within the game. For instance, as the player arrives on a level, she may interrupt other characters talking about a particular event. They turn to see her and attack. During this process, the player never loses control.

对话

DIALOGUE

对话由游戏中的角色或 NPC 说出。有时，这种对话不会被听到，而是以文本形式显示在屏幕上。当玩家可以选择回应时，对话就可以变得具有互动性。其他时候（例如在过场动画期间），对话是固定的。无论如何，纯口语对话的游戏通常允许显示文本作为选项，以方便听障玩家或关闭声音的玩家。

Dialogue is spoken by the avatar or the NPCs in the game. Sometimes, this dialogue isn’t heard but rather appears as text on the screen. When the player is given the option to respond, dialogue can become interactive. Other times (such as during cutscenes), the dialogue is fixed. In any case, games with purely spoken dialogue typically allow text display as an option for the benefit of gamers who are deaf or who are playing with the sound off.

 

 

文本

TEXT

文本包含在游戏中的描述性消息、笔记、书籍、墙上的蚀刻画或作者可能选择的任何其他内容中。此类方法对于传达背景故事特别有用。但请记住，文本本身并不是互动的。在短时间内，它肯定有互动的潜力，就像即时消息窗口中的对话一样具有互动性。当然，强迫玩家阅读一页又一页的文本只是为了继续玩游戏，这会让玩家感到无聊，而跳过文本的玩家最终会错过他们以后需要的关键信息。

Text is contained in in-game descriptive messages, notes, books, etchings on the wall, or whatever else the writers may choose. Such methods are particularly useful for conveying back story. Remember, though, that text is not inherently interactive. In short bursts, it most certainly has the potential to be, much like a conversation in an instant-messaging window is interactive. Forcing the player to read through pages and pages of text just to continue playing the game can make the player bored, of course, and players who skip the text end up missing critical information that they need later.

关于互动性的说明

A NOTE ABOUT INTERACTIVITY

除了允许回应的对话外，上面列出的每种方法都以被动的方式向玩家呈现故事。在一种旨在从玩家那里引出有意义的选择的媒介中，你如何讲述一个故事，而这个故事本质上需要玩家被动地消化提供给他们的信息？

With the exception of dialogue that allows responses, each method listed above presents the story to the player in a passive way. In a medium crafted to elicit meaningful choices out of the player, how do you tell a story, something that by its nature requires players to passively digest information given to them?

讲述、展示、实践

TELL, SHOW, DO

2005 年 7 月，在 Gamasutra 上发表的一篇题​​为《每个游戏开发者需要知道的故事》的文章中，作家 John Sutherland 将人们熟悉的讲故事格言“展示，不要讲述”改成了“做，不要展示” GS01。后来，在 2007 年 1 月，游戏开发者杂志的 Noah Falstein（他自己也是一位资深游戏设计师）强调了这一点。

In an article in the July 2005 article on Gamasutra titled “What Every Game Developer Needs to Know about Story,” writer John Sutherland twisted the familiar storytelling maxim “Show, Don’t Tell” into “Do, Don’t Show”GS01. Later, in January 2007, Game Developer magazine’s Noah Falstein, himself a veteran game designer, emphasized the point.

Sutherland 和 Falstein 要求设计师让玩家真正参与到行动中，而不是告诉玩家他或她需要做什么，或者在过场动画或电影中向他们展示信息。这一点对于游戏设计师来说至关重要，需要考虑和实施。想象一下，如果你在自己的生活中被要求站在一边，看着一个关键事件的展开，而你实际上却无法参与这一重大行动或事件的过程。对于观看过场动画的玩家来说，效果可能是相似的。因此，玩家不必在游戏中阅读有关激进组织起义的文章或通过过场动画看到起义的发生，而是可以成为起义的一部分或起义的起因，或成为同样受到其影响的另一个组织的一部分。

Rather than tell the player what he or she needs to do, or show them information in cutscenes or cinematics, Sutherland and Falstein challenged designers to allow the player to actually take part in the action. The point is a critical one for game designers to consider and implement. Imagine if, in your own life, you were asked to step aside and watch as a critical event unfolded, and you were not actually able to participate during the course of this great action or event. For a player watching a cutscene, the effect can be similar. So, rather than read about an uprising among a militant group within the game or see the uprising happening through the cutscene, the player can be a part of or the cause of the uprising or a part of another group that is similarly affected by it.

游戏设计师还通过哪些方式让玩家参与？

What other ways do game designers allow players to participate?

角色扮演游戏或许是最好的例子。这些游戏的核心是角色发展。通过探索和战斗，玩家不断参与游戏的核心。故事通常是游戏进展的动力。在战斗和探索中，玩家需要做出大量决定，从如何攻击、攻击什么、攻击哪里等等。故事是关键，它告诉玩家什么是重要的以及如何解决它，这为决策增添了意义。这些许多有意义的决定中的每一个都会引导玩家获得回报——角色的进步。设计师创建了一种模式——玩家控制/设计师控制/玩家控制/设计师控制。这种模式将有意义的选择放在首位，并使故事成为一个不可或缺的组成部分。玩家选择角色如何发展，这本身是由通过完成任务或战斗获得的经验推动的，这也是另一个由选择驱动的系统。游戏支持玩家发展的核心，而这种发展发生在故事的范围内。

RPGs provide perhaps the greatest example. Consider that the core of these games is character development. Through exploration and combat, players are continuously engaged with the core of the game. The story is often the impetus for progression in the game. In combat and in exploration, there are a multitude of player decisions, from how to attack, what to attack, where to attack, and so on. The story serves as the key, informing players about what is important and how to go about addressing it, which adds meaning to the decisions. Each of these many meaningful decisions leads players to their rewards—progression of their characters. Designers create a pattern of sorts—player control/designer control/player control/designer control. This pattern keeps meaningful choices front and center and makes story an integral component as well. The player makes choices about how the character develops, which is, itself, fueled by experience gained through quest completion or combat, yet another choice-driven system. The game supports the core of player development and that development happens within the confines of a story.

背景和人物

SETTING AND CHARACTER

设计师要做的两个最重要的决定是游戏的“人物”和“地点”（故事是“人物、事物和地点”等式中的“事物”）。玩家扮演的角色以及这些角色的发挥对于故事驱动型游戏的成功至关重要。拉斯维加斯的二手软件推销员似乎不太可能成为游戏的人物和背景，但《花花公子拉里》及其众多​​续集的实力表明情况并非如此。一位意大利水管工一生都在寻找公主，他是他们当中最伟大的英雄。任何事情都可能是电子游戏的潜在主题，只要它执行得当，有扎实的游戏玩法支持，并遵循吸引玩家的故事情节。

Two of the most important decisions designers make are the “who” and “where” of games (with story being the “what” of the “who, what, and where” equation). The roles the players take on and where these roles play out are of significant importance to the success of story-driven games. A used-software salesman in Vegas might seem an unlikely character and setting for a game, but the strength of Leisure Suit Larry and its many sequels suggests otherwise. An Italian plumber who began life looking for a princess is the biggest hero of them all. Anything is a potential topic for a video game, provided it is carried out well, supported by solid gameplay, and follows a story arc that draws the player in.

人们玩游戏是因为游戏提供了探索他们不太可能探索的世界的机会，并体验他们在现实生活中不太可能拥有的体验。人们想扮演很酷的角色。他们想探索令人兴奋的目的地。有时，就像在《模拟人生》中一样，他们只是想体验日常生活并创造自己的故事。

People play games because they provide an opportunity to explore a world that they would be unlikely to explore and play out an experience they would be unlikely to have in real life. People want to play cool characters. They want to explore exciting destinations. Sometimes, as in The Sims, they just want to experiment with everyday life and make their own stories.

角色设计

CHARACTER DESIGN

角色不仅仅是概念草图。他们来自某个地方，有优点和关键缺点。他们有记忆和历史等等。在为视频游戏创建角色时，设计师对该角色了如指掌，如果呈现假设情况，设计师知道角色会如何反应以及原因。两个伟大的游戏角色，Duke Nukem 和 Solid Snake，经受住了时间的考验，成为经典，这在很大程度上不是因为他们的外表或他们所在的游戏，而是因为他们角色的力量——外表之外的个性。在这个角色中，游戏允许玩家做出决定，并邀请玩家进入这个角色。游戏中的角色如 NPC 可以具有类似的深度。

Characters are about much more than concept sketches. They come from somewhere and have strengths and key weaknesses. They have memories and histories and more. When creating a character for a video game, the designer knows that character inside and out, and if presented with a hypothetical situation, the designer knows how the character would respond and why. Two great game characters, Duke Nukem and Solid Snake, have survived the test of time and become classics based not so much on how they look or even the games that they’re in but rather on the strength of their character—the personality beyond the looks. Within this character, games allow players to make decisions, and they invite the player to step into this role. In-game characters like NPCs can have similar depth.

许多设计师实际上会“采访”他们的角色，以期唤起角色的个性并在他们的脑海中巩固该人物的形象。

Many designers actually “interview” their characters in an effort to evoke the character’s personality and solidify the person in their head.

环境设计

ENVIRONMENT DESIGN

出色的环境不仅仅能用充满多边形的广阔场景让人们“惊叹”。虽然这些可能很重要，但出色图形带来的刺激感会逐渐消失。

Great environments do more than “wow” people with expansive polygon-filled scenes. While those may be important, the thrill of great graphics wears off.

环境更多的是感觉。想象一下一个人在陌生的建筑里，在城市的一个糟糕地段，在黑暗中独自一人手无寸铁，会是什么感觉。在这种情况下，恐惧是显而易见的，这完全取决于感觉，而不是图像。此外，考虑两个相同的停车场。我们知道一个是安全的。另一个是上周发生过一起残酷犯罪的现场。相同的场景，但感觉却完全不同。环境、机制和叙事共同决定了玩家的感受。

Environments are more about feel. Consider how one might feel in a strange building, in a bad part of town, alone and unarmed in the dark. In such a scenario, the fear is palpable, and it’s all about the feel, not the graphics. Furthermore, consider two identical parking garages. We know one is secure. The other was the scene of a brutal crime the previous week. Identical scenes with totally different feels. Environments, mechanics, and narrative work together to determine how the player feels.

通过回忆他们有某种感觉的某个时刻，设计师利用记忆为玩家重现体验。宫本茂是许多成功游戏的创造者，包括《塞尔达传说》系列和《马里奥》系列，他利用童年记忆来影响他几款游戏中的地点。从他小时候探索过的洞穴到他认为是巨大水体的山湖，宫本记得他感受到的奇妙感觉，并为他的玩家重现了那种体验。

By thinking back to a certain time when they felt a certain way, designers use memories to recreate experiences for players. Shigeru Miyamoto, the creator of a great many successful games including the Zelda series and the Mario franchise, used childhood memories to influence the locations in several of his games. From the caves he explored as a child to a mountain lake he took to be an enormous body of water, Miyamoto remembers the sense of wonder he felt, and recreates that experience for his players.

然而，对于每一条游戏准则，似乎都有多个例外。例如，Jason Rohrer 的艺术游戏《Passage》让玩家扮演一个普通人，过着平淡无奇的生活。尽管如此，这款游戏还是非常吸引人，其极简主义的画面也为游戏增添了美感。

For every game maxim, however, there seems to be multiple exceptions to the rule. For instance, Jason Rohrer’s art game Passage lets the player play an everyman walking through a graphically unimpressive life. The game is, nonetheless, exceptionally engaging, and its minimalist graphics contribute to the aesthetic.

逆向工作

WORKING BACKWARD

一旦确定了故事情节，一些游戏开发者就会逆向而行来确定各个情节点，就像谜题设计师有时从解决方案开始，然后再从该点回溯一样。

Once the story arc is decided upon, some game developers work backward to determine individual plot points, much like puzzle designers sometimes start with the solution and work back from that point.

例如，假设一个巫师被关在城堡里。一系列的问题和答案

For instance, consider a wizard locked up in a castle. A series of questions and answers

可以帮助您确定玩家如何将巫师赶出：

can assist you in determining how the player might get the wizard out:

·      为什么我不能进入城堡杀死巫师？

·      Why can’t I get into the castle to kill the wizard?

·      门被锁上了。

·      The door is locked.

·      钥匙在哪里？

·      Where’s the key?

·      这是他最信任的助手。

·      It’s with his most trusted assistant.

·      他最信任的助手在哪里？

·      Where is his trusted assistant?

有时，逆向工作的过程可以帮助设计师集思广益，想出他们原本没有考虑过的故事情节或支线任务。

Sometimes, the process of working backward helps designers brainstorm plot points or side quests they hadn’t otherwise considered.

选择与故事相匹配的机制

CHOOSING MECHANICS TO MATCH THE STORY

有时，设计师在知道如何处理之前就已经知道了故事。非数字游戏设计和基于 IP 的设计尤其如此。例如，如果你要制作一款关于你最喜欢的电影的游戏，你可能对故事有一个想法，但在决定游戏类型或实现该类型所需的机制之前，你必须考虑各种选择。

Sometimes, the designer knows the story before he knows the treatment for it. This is particularly true of non-digital game design and designs made from IP. For instance, if you were to make a game about a favorite movie, you might have an idea of the story, but you would have to consider various options before deciding upon a game genre or the mechanics necessary to pull that genre off.

在几乎所有情况下，故事都直接映射到一个或多个常见的数字类型或非数字设计。例如，考虑约翰·斯坦贝克的《愤怒的葡萄》这样的经典书籍。在书中，汤姆·乔德和他的家人在沙尘暴和大萧条期间离开俄克拉荷马州，到加利福尼亚肥沃的田野寻找财富。正如亚里士多德的弧线一样，当他们到达时发生了戏剧性的逆转，他们要克服的困难比他们最初计划的要多。在不破坏结局的情况下，这本书是一本关于生存和探索的书。

In almost all cases, stories directly map to one or more common digital genres or non-digital designs. For instance, consider a classic book like John Steinbeck’s The Grapes of Wrath. In the book, Tom Joad and his family leave Oklahoma during the dust bowl and the Great Depression in search of riches in the fertile fields of California. True to Aristotle’s arc, there is a dramatic reversal when they arrive, and they are left to overcome more than they’d originally planned. Without ruining the ending, the book is one of survival and exploration.

在评估使用哪些机制来制作这个故事时，请退一步，首先问自己这个故事最适合哪种类型。从理论上讲，《愤怒的葡萄》可能是以下任何一种：

In assessing which mechanics to use to make this story, take a step back and first ask yourself which genre the story best fits. Theoretically, The Grapes of Wrath could be any one of these:

·      冒险游戏

·      Adventure game

·      动作游戏

·      Action game

·      角色扮演

·      RPG

·      教育游戏

·      Educational game

·      大亨游戏

·      Tycoon game

哪一个最好？这取决于你对故事的处理方式。你想关注主角和他的挣扎吗？它可能在风格上类似于 20 世纪 20 年代版的 《马克思·佩恩》 。你想关注农民工的困境吗？它可能是一款有说服力的经营大亨游戏，富裕的农民依靠被他们监禁的人来发家致富。你想制作一款教育人们了解大萧条的游戏吗？这些中的每一个都可能是一款可行的游戏，但每个游戏的机制都完全不同。

Which one is the best? That depends on your treatment for the story. Do you want to focus on the main character and his struggles? It could be similar in style to a 1920s version of Max Payne. Do you want to focus on the plight of the migrant farmer? It could be a persuasive tycoon game where the rich farmers build off the backs of those they have effectively imprisoned. Do you want to build a game that educates people about the Great Depression? Each of these could be a viable game, but each one would have entirely different mechanics.

除了游戏类型之外，还可以探索各种核心动态。可能适用于《愤怒的葡萄》的常见动态包括以下内容：

Apart from a game genre, one can also explore various core dynamics. Common dynamics that might work with The Grapes of Wrath include the following:

     

     

·      领土获取

·      Territorial acquisition

·      权力斗争

·      Power struggle

·      探索

·      Exploration

·      跑到终点/另一边

·      Race to the end/to the other side

·      建筑

·      Building

·      角色升级

·      Character advancement

·      收藏

·      Collection

您选择的类型和动态只会帮助您选择要匹配的机制。实际上有数百种机制可供选择。《游戏设计模式》一书是设计师的绝佳资源，将拓展您的视野。以领土获取为例。有多少种方法可以接管或控制某人的土地？有多少种不同的探索方式？有多少种不同的收集资源方式？

The genre and dynamics that you choose will only assist you in choosing mechanics to match. There are literally hundreds of mechanics to choose from. The book Patterns in Game Design is an excellent resource for designers and will expand your horizons. Take territorial acquisition as an example. How many ways can you take over or control a person’s land? How many different ways can you explore? How many different ways can you collect resources?

选择适合你的故事的机制的最佳方式是先在脑子里装满它们。

The single best way to choose mechanics to go with your story is to have a head already full of them.

挑战

CHALLENGES

本节中的挑战让您探索故事创作的各个组成部分。

The challenges in this section allow you to explore the various components of story creation.

挑战 1——你是谁？

CHALLENGE 1—WHO ARE YOU?

电子游戏中令人难忘的角色——林克、劳拉·克劳馥、士官长、毁灭公爵和索利德·斯内克——有时比他们最初出现的游戏更出名。然而，对于每一个知名角色，至少有 100 个角色已经淡出人们的视线（尽管令人遗憾）。

Memorable characters in video games—Link, Lara Croft, Master Chief, Duke Nukem, and Solid Snake—are sometimes bigger than the games in which they initially appeared. However, for every well known character, there are at least 100 characters that have faded blissfully (if regrettably) into obscurity.

对于这项挑战，你的目标是从头开始创建一个角色。不过，你需要的不仅仅是视觉效果。要完成这项挑战，你需要一个全面的角色，有时间和地点、过去和未来计划。你的角色可能是虚构的，但它必须存在于过去或现在的现实世界中。

For this challenge, your goal will be to create a character from the ground up. You need more than a visual, though. To complete this challenge, you need a fully rounded character with a time and a place, a past, and plans for the future. Your character may be fictional, but it must exist in the real world in the past or present.

所需组件

Components Required

·      用于研究的互联网连接

·      Internet connection for research

可交付成果

Deliverable

·      概念草图（可选）

·      Concept sketch (optional)

·      人物专访

·      Character interview

·      个人简介，包括优点、缺点、个人历史和两个决定性时刻

·      Biography including strengths, weaknesses, personal history, and two defining moments

·      故事情节（可选）

·      Story arc (optional)

建议流程

Suggested Process

·      为你的角色选择一个时间段和一个地点。如果你的角色是为某个你已经在制作的游戏而设，那么你可能已经完成了。否则，选择一个你感兴趣但不太了解的时间段或地点。这种天生的好奇心将帮助你研究角色的历史。（如果你不太关心公元 800 年爱尔兰的历史，那么随机为你的角色选择它不会让你更关心它。）如果你完全不确定要研究什么，请在 Microsoft Excel 中的单元格中输入公式：=RAND()*2009。该公式将随机生成 0 到 2009 之间的年份。你可以将单元格设置为不显示小数或忽略它们。每次按 F9 键，你都会得到一个新的年份。如果您更喜欢非数字方法，请掷三个 10 面骰子以获得年份的最后三位数字，然后掷第四个骰子以获得千位数字，如果不是 0、1 或 2，则重新掷骰子。

·      Select a time period and a place for your character. If your character is for a particular game that you have already been working on, then maybe you’re already finished. Otherwise, select a time period or a place that you’re interested in, but do not know a lot about. This natural curiosity will serve you well as you research your character’s history. (If you don’t care much about the history of Ireland in the year 800, then randomly selecting it for your character isn’t going to make you care about it more.) If you are completely uncertain about what to research, type the formula into a cell in Microsoft Excel: =RAND()*2009. The formula will kick out a random year between 0 and 2009. You can set the cell to show you no decimals or just ignore them. Every time you press F9, you’ll get a new year. If you prefer a non-digital method, roll three 10sided dice to get the last three digits of the year, then roll a fourth die for the thousands digit and re-roll if it isn’t 0, 1 or 2.

·      完成采访。 对于你的角色，假装你正在采访那个人。想想他会如何回答这些问题。代表你的角色自己回答这些问题：你叫什么名字？性别？种族？宗教？年龄？你在哪里出生？你的父母呢——他们在哪里，他们还活着吗？在你成长的过程中，你是否挣扎过，如果有，是哪些方面？现在是哪一年？别人一眼就会对你产生什么刻板印象？你有恋爱对象吗？如果有，是谁？你最好的朋友是谁，他/她/它是什么样的？你的朋友会如何描述你？你的经济状况如何？你做过什么工作？你会偷东西吗？你对撒谎有什么看法？你的朋友能信任你吗？你还有其他的恶习吗？什么让你快乐？什么让你难过？你有什么秘密是不能让任何人知道的？你害怕死亡吗？你有恐惧症吗？你脾气暴躁还是有耐心？

·      Complete the interview. For your character, pretend you are interviewing that person. Think about how he would answer these questions. Answer them for yourself, on your character’s behalf: What is your name? Gender? Race? Religion? Age? Where were you born? What about your parents—where are they, and are they alive? When you were growing up, did you struggle, and if so, in what way? What year is it now? How would someone stereotype you at a glance? Do you have a romantic partner? If so, whom? Who is your best friend and what is he/she/it like? How would your friend describe you? What is your economic situation? What have you done for work? Would you steal? How do you feel about lying? Can you be trusted by your friends? Do you have any other vices? What makes you happy? What makes you sad? What is the one secret that no one must know about you? Are you afraid to die? Do you have any phobias? Are you quick tempered or patient?

·      创建可交付成果。

·      Create deliverable.

变体

Variants

不要塑造任何旧角色，而是为自己创造一个敌人：一个针对你弱点的人。认真对待这一挑战，它通常会产生富有洞察力的结果。

Instead of creating any old character, create a nemesis for yourself: someone who targets your weaknesses. Take this challenge seriously, and it usually produces insightful results.

为你的角色创建一个包含戏剧性逆转的故事线。这个故事线不需要基于现实生活经历。与另一位团队成员交换为这个挑战创建的角色，并让他创建一个与你创建的角色互补的得力助手男人或女人。

Create a story arc for your character that involves a dramatic reversal. This arc need not be based on a real-life experience. Trade the character created for this challenge with another team member, and ask him to create a right-hand man or woman that complements the character you have created.

挑战2——你在哪里？

CHALLENGE 2—WHERE ARE YOU?

回想一下你有过以下一种或所有感觉的时候。每想一下一次，让你的记忆浮现出来。这些感觉是：

Think back to a time when you felt one or all of these things. Pause a moment on each to let your memories rise. The feelings are:

·      敬畏或惊奇

·      Awe or wonder

·      恐惧或深深的不确定性（但不是害怕的情况）

·      Fear or deep uncertainty (not an instance of being scared, however)

·      有探索的欲望

·      A desire to explore

在这个练习中，脑海中浮现的场景将成为电子游戏场景的基础。你不需要逐字逐句地翻译场景。例如，如果你在陌生的城市里走错路并迷路时感到恐惧。你不必将这座城市变成一个场景。相反，探索为什么你认为这种情况令人恐惧。也许你担心找不到出路。也许那个地方光线昏暗，路标很少。也许有人在阴影里。也许你已经迟到了，这增加了你的焦虑。也许有明显的证据表明，留在这里的其他汽车已经被拆解，它们的骨架腐烂了。

In this exercise, what comes to mind will the basis for a video-game setting. You need not translate the setting literally. For instance, if you felt fear when you took a wrong turn and got lost in an unfamiliar city. You don’t have to literally turn that city into a setting. Rather, explore why you perceived the situation to be fearful. Perhaps you worried that you couldn’t find your way out. Maybe the area was poorly lit and signs were few. Maybe there were people in the shadows. Perhaps you were already late for an event and that added to your anxiety. Maybe there was visible evidence that other cars left here had been parted out and their skeletons left to rot.

创建一个列表或简要写下这些看法（是什么让你有这样的感觉），并使用每一个来创建一个唤起相同感觉的视频游戏设置。

Create a list or a brief write-up of those perceptions (what made you feel the way you felt) and use each to create a video-game setting that evokes the same feeling.

所需组件

Components Required

·      没有任何

·      None

可交付成果

Deliverable

·      一段描述你记忆的段落或讨论

·      A paragraph or discussion that describes your memory

·      描述你希望玩家感受到的情感反应

·      A statement of the emotional response you want the player to feel

·      列出让你产生这种感觉的事物

·      A list of the perceived things that caused you to feel that way

·      描述你打算设计的关卡或世界，并详细说明你计划如何融入灵感元素

·      A description of the level or world you propose to design along with a detailing of how you plan to incorporate the elements of your inspiration

建议流程

Suggested Process

1.    先写段落。让你的想象力回到你感受到上述部分或全部感受的时候，并尽力让自己处于同样的心态。想想你记得的细节：你有没有注意到某种特殊的气味、声音或景象？有什么事情看起来不对劲、奇怪或不合时宜吗？让自己沉浸在记忆中。然后写下来。

1.    Write the paragraph first. Let your imagination go back to the time when you felt some or all of the above feelings, and do your best to put yourself in the same state of mind. Think of the details that you remember: Did you notice a particular smell, sound, or sight? Did something seem wrong, strange, or out of place? Immerse yourself in the memory. Then write about it.

2.    描述情绪。 趁着上面的记忆还记忆犹新，继续写下你当时的感受和情绪。你之前写的段落描述了发生的事情；现在描述一下你对发生的事情的反应。

2.    Describe the emotions. While the memory from above is still fresh in your head, continue to write about your feelings and emotions at that time. The paragraph you wrote earlier describes what happened; now describe your reaction to what happened.

3.    定义机制。 如果你的生活是一场游戏，那么你记忆中当时的情绪就是美感。是什么机制导致了这些情绪？你认为你为什么会有这种感觉？你的情绪的哪些方面是由你、你的经历和你的个性引起的？你的环境和情况的哪些方面导致了情绪反应？在草稿纸上集思广益，把你能想到的一切都写下来。当你满意时，将你的笔记重写成一个有组织的列表。

3.    Define the mechanics. If your life were a game, then your emotions at that time in your memory would be the aesthetics. What were the mechanics that caused them? Why do you think you felt that way? What aspects of your emotions were caused by you, your experiences, and your personality? What aspects of your environment and situation contributed to the emotional response? Brainstorm everything that you can think of on scrap paper. When you’re satisfied, rewrite your notes as an organized list.

4.    创建可交付成果。 最后要做的就是将您已经写的内容转化为实际的游戏机制。考虑一下您周围世界中引发您情绪的系统，以及如何在游戏中模拟它们，以便为玩家创造相同的情绪。

4.    Create deliverable. The last thing to do is translate what you’ve already written into actual game mechanics. Consider the systems in the world around you that led to your emotions and how you can model them in a game in such a way as to create the same emotions for a player.

变体

Variant

在纸上或数字形式设计实际水平。

Design the actual level, on paper or digitally.

挑战3——意义何在？

CHALLENGE 3—WHAT’S THE POINT?

探索不同的故事情节可以让设计师考虑单一故事概念的多种可能性。在这个挑战中，你的目标是为单一故事概念开发一个故事情节，并提出可能促进故事发展的游戏机制。你的故事概念由你决定。

Exploring different story arcs allows designers to consider multiple possibilities for a single story concept. In this challenge, your goal is to develop an arc for a single story concept and suggest gameplay mechanics that might facilitate your story’s progression. The concept for your story is up to you.

从本章前面介绍的故事情节中进行选择——三幕故事情节、五部分英雄之旅和编剧大师图表中的 14 部分情节。如果愿意，您也可以使用在挑战 1 中开发的角色。

Select from the story arcs covered earlier in this chapter—the three-act story arc, the five-part hero’s journey, and the 14-part arc from the Screen Writer’s Master Chart. You may also use the character you developed in Challenge 1, if you like.

所需组件

Components Required

·      用于研究的互联网连接

·      Internet connection for research

可交付成果

Deliverable

·      用段落形式陈述你的故事的基本前提

·      Paragraph statement on your story’s basic premise

·      三幕故事情节或

·      Three-act story arc or

·      五部分的英雄之旅篇章或

·      Five-part hero’s journey arc or

·       14 部分编剧大师图表弧

·      14-part Screen Writer’s Master Chart arc

建议流程

Suggested Process

1.    选择一个前提。 如果你脑子里有一个故事，那么你已经完成了一部分。如果没有，你可以从很多地方寻找起点。选择一个角色、一个情境或一个目标，然后从那里开始构建。或者看看一个典型故事情节中的不同幕，问问自己你想在每一幕中看到什么。你可以从开头的一个激动人心的时刻开始，也可以从结尾开始，然后倒着写。

1.    Choose a premise. If you have a story in your head, you’re already part-way there. If not, there are a lot of places you can look for starting points. Choose a character, or a situation, or a goal, and build from there. Or look at the different acts in a typical story arc and ask yourself what you would want to see in each act. You can start at the beginning with an inciting moment, or you can start at the end and then work backward.

2.    拓展故事情节。 从起点开始，向前和向后推进，添加细节，直到故事情节完整。

2.    Grow your story. From your starting point, work your way forward and backward, adding detail until you have a complete story arc.

3.    考虑游戏玩法。 对于你的故事，什么样的机制和动态比较合适？

3.    Think of gameplay. For your story, what kinds of mechanics and dynamics would fit well?

4.    创建可交付成果。

4.    Create deliverable.

挑战 4 — 常见与不常见

CHALLENGE 4—THE COMMON UNCOMMON

有时普通人会被要求采取非常措施。这种事情在电影、书籍和电视中经常发生。无数动作片让人们相互对抗，而越过这个界限，“普通男人”或“普通女人”就越不普通。埃琳·布罗克维奇就是这种人的典型例子。

Sometimes average people are called to extraordinary measures. It happens in movies, in books, and on television all the time. Innumerable action movies pit people against one another, and pushed past the point, the “common man” or “common woman” becomes quite uncommon. Erin Brockovich is a classic example of such a person.

对于这个挑战，你的任务是选择一个普通世界里从事普通工作的普通男人或女人。没有什么会让你对他们三思而后行。为了测试这一点，问问自己，“我现在会看一部讲述这个人生命最后一周的电影吗？”如果答案是“是”，那么你很可能发现他们并不那么普通。

For this challenge, your task is to select a common man or woman in a common job in a common world. There is nothing that might cause you to think twice about them. To test this, ask yourself, “Would I presently watch a movie that covered the last week in the life of this person?” If the answer is “yes,” then odds are you don’t find them all that common after all.

想想你在日常生活中遇到的普通人，但不是特定的人：医生、护士、杂货店员工、建筑工人、公交车司机或出租车司机。任何常见的职业都可以。

Think of a common, but not specific, person you meet in your everyday life: a doctor, nurse, grocery-store employee, construction worker, bus driver, or a cabbie. Any profession that’s common will do.

想象一下，当这个角色的日常生活突然发生戏剧性的转折时，你如何能够构建一款基于他的日常生活的游戏。

Think of how you could build a game based around this character’s everyday life when it suddenly takes a dramatic turn.

所需组件

Components Required

·      没有任何

·      None

可交付成果

Deliverable

·      简单描述一个普通男人或普通女人的性格

·      Brief description of a common man or common woman character

·      描述一个现实的、激动人心的时刻，让角色与众不同

·      Details of a realistic, inciting moment that makes the character uncommon

·      基于角色的非数字游戏

·      Non-digital game based on the character

建议流程

Suggested Process

1.    选择一个常见的职业和一个常见的男人或女人。如果你无法决定，就到你家附近散步。当你在街上遇到人们时，看看你是否能仅凭看他们一眼就猜出他们的职业。选择你看到的最能激励你的人。

1.    Pick a common profession and a common man or woman. If you can’t decide, go out for a walk in your neighborhood. As you pass people on the street, see if you can guess their profession just by looking at them. Choose the person you see who most inspires you.

2.    确定什么是刺激时刻。它可能是像亲人去世和复仇欲望一样戏剧性的事情（《马克思·佩恩》），也可能是像餐厅里争夺座位和服务顾客一样看似微不足道的事情（ 《美女餐厅冲刺》）。有人可能会说，后一款游戏中的刺激时刻是食客开始压倒弗洛的时候。

2.    Determine what the inciting moment will be. It could be something as dramatic as the death of a loved one and the desire for revenge (Max Payne) or as seemingly trivial as the race to fill seats and serve people in a restaurant (Diner Dash). One could say the inciting moment in the latter game is when the diners start to overwhelm Flo.

3.    确定要构建的游戏类型。什么样的核心动态适合角色？建筑？探索？竞速？还是其他什么？什么样的机制适合这些动态？游戏板感觉合适吗？还是卡牌或方块更合适？玩家在游戏中会采取什么样的行动？你玩过可以重新主题化的非数字游戏吗？

3.    Determine a type of game to build. What kinds of core dynamics would suit the character well? Building? Exploration? Race to the end? Or something else? What kinds of mechanics fit those dynamics? Does a game board feel right, or are cards or tiles more suitable? What kinds of actions would the player(s) take in the game? Have you played any non-digital games that could be re-themed?

4.    创建可交付成果。

4.    Create deliverable.

变体

Variant

通过类似但相反的激励时刻，将一个不寻常的人变成普通人，并探索这会对角色产生什么影响。

Turn an uncommon person common through a similar, but reverse, inciting moment and explore how that affects the character.

根据角色开发故事情节。

Develop a story arc based upon the character.

不要设计一款棋盘游戏，而是写一个以你的角色为主角的电子游戏提案。

Instead of a board game, write a proposal for a video game featuring your character as the protagonist.

铁人设计师挑战赛 5 — 叙述者的复仇 (LIVE)

IRON DESIGNER CHALLENGE 5—NARRATOLOGIST’S REVENGE (LIVE)

在游戏设计中，人们非常关注游戏机制，这是理所当然的。然而，有时我们会忘记故事的影响。如果做得好，故事实际上可以促进游戏机制的发展，而不是让位于游戏机制。

In game design, much attention is paid, and rightly so, to the game’s mechanics. Sometimes, however, we forget the impact that story can have. Done well, story can actually give rise to mechanics, rather than play second fiddle to them.

对于这一挑战，你的工作是主持一场有 4-10 名玩家参加的现场叙事练习，从以下设置开始，遵循两条规则：

For this challenge, your job is to host a live narrative exercise with 4–10 players, starting with the setup below and two rules:

1.    规则会随着故事的发展而制定。

1.    Rules will be made up as the story evolves.

2.    规则一旦制定，就会在整个游戏世界中适用。

2.    Once a rule is made up, it is applied throughout the game world from that point forward.

设置：

The Setup:

一名玩家必须担任叙述者。（这样游戏会更容易进行。但是，如果没有人愿意扮演叙述者，那么就组建一个小组，让他们充当集体叙述者。有关更多信息，请参阅“变体”部分。）

One player must serve as the narratologist. (The game will work more easily this way. However, if there is no one who wishes to play the narratologist, then set up the group to act as a collective narratologist. See the “Variants” section for more information on that.)

·      玩家 1-4 应是小镇的游客或居民。他们不必彼此认识，可能分散在小镇各处。哪个小镇？我们很快就会讲到。

·      Players 1–4 should be visiting or residents of a small town. They need not know each other and may be scattered across the town. What town? We’ll get to that shortly.

·      玩家 5-7 应该从某种问题开始。那个“激发时刻”或普通问题可能由您决定。

·      Players 5–7 should start with a problem of some sort. What that “inciting moment” or plain ol’ problem might be is up to you.

·      玩家 8 刚刚抵达城镇并且正在逃亡。

·      Player 8 has just arrived in town and is on the lam.

·      玩家 9–10 正在一起做某事。

·      Players 9–10 are working together on something.

正如您所看到的，这个设置有一些漏洞。这些漏洞将由您的球员来填补。

The setup, as you certainly see, has some holes in it. Those holes will be filled by your players.

开始游戏：

Starting the game:

·      在白板、黑板或所有玩家都能看到的纸上勾勒出一个非常简陋的城市。你的城市除了道路和几个关键的东西（如警察局和公园）外，不应该包含太多东西。

·      Sketch a very skeletal city on a whiteboard, blackboard, or piece of paper that all players can see. Your city shouldn’t include much more than roads and maybe a couple key things, like the police station and maybe a park.

·      让玩家在 1 到 10 之间选择一个数字，并根据他们选择的数字告诉他们是谁。例如，选择数字 4 的玩家可能是该小镇的居民。

·      Ask players to select a number between 1 and 10, and tell them who they are based on the number they have selected. For instance, a player who selected number 4 could be a resident in that small town.

·      询问新晋玩家，他或她想在城镇中待在哪里。他们可以自由地编造地点。可以自由地对他们可以编造的地点类型设置一些限制。提前决定是否接受“宇宙飞船着陆点”或“龙穴”。无论你的玩家说什么，都要在地图上画出他或她的号码和位置。让所有其他玩家确定他们的起始位置。

·      Ask the newly minted player where he or she wants to be located in the town. They are free to make up locations. Feel free to set some limits on the types of locations they can make up. Decide up front if you’ll accept “spaceship landing site” or “dragon’s lair.” Whatever your player says, draw his or her number and the location on a map. Ask all other players to determine their starting position.

·      询问玩家 1 想要做什么，或者允许他们提出可能的问题。例如，玩家可以说“我想去餐厅”，或者问“我有武器吗？”当玩家完成自己的动作后，轮到下一位玩家。

·      Ask player 1 what he or she wants to do or allow them to ask questions he or she might have. For instance, players can say, “I want to go to the restaurant,” or ask, “Do I have a weapon?” When the player is finished performing his or her action, the turn goes to the next player.

问答：

Q&A:

一圈要多久？这取决于叙述者。如果餐厅在半个城市之外，也许他们只能走到四分之一的路程。

How long is a turn? It’s up to the narratologist. If the restaurant is half a city away, maybe they only get a quarter of the way there.

您如何处理问题？制定规则以使玩家故事发挥作用。一个好建议是使用骰子来确定答案。对于上面的问题，您可以说掷出 1-4 表示您没有武装。掷出 5 或 6 表示您有武装。

How do you handle questions? Invent rules to allow the player story to function. A good suggestion is to use a die to determine the answer. For the question above, you could say that rolling a 1–4 indicates you’re not armed. A 5 or 6 means that you are armed.

你如何处理事件？同样，要制定规则来处理它们。假设玩家 1 最终与一个生物展开战斗。你可以用一个骰子解决整个事情：

How do you handle events? Again, invent rules to handle them. Let’s say that player 1 ends up in a battle with a creature. You can solve the whole thing with a single die:

·      掷骰子决定谁先击中目标 — 玩家还是怪物。骰子点数高的获胜。

·      Roll the die to see who hits first—the player or the monster. High die wins.

·      掷骰子决定获胜者击中其他生物的哪个部位。将数字 1 到 6 应用于各个身体部位。

·      Roll the die to see where the winner hits the other creature. Apply numbers 1 through 6 to various body parts.

·      掷骰子看看打击的威力有多大。1 表示有点疼，6 表示击倒对方。您还可以使用骰子来确定生命值系统。（例如，掷骰子看看要掷多少次。然后，将后续掷骰子掷出的数字相加。）

·      Roll the die to see how powerful the hit is. A 1 is slightly painful, and a 6 knocks its block off. You can also use dice to determine a hit point system. (For example, roll the die to see how many times to roll. Then, add up the numbers rolled during these subsequent rolls.)

游戏如何结束？这又取决于叙述者。

How does the game end? Again, it’s up to the narratologist.

这项练习需要敏锐的头脑和处理大量信息的能力。实际上，这是一种自由形式的游戏掌握体验。

This exercise requires a sharp mind and the ability to juggle lots of information. In effect, it’s a freeform game mastering experience.

所需组件

Components Required

·      使用骰子或其他方法解决出现的问题_白板、黑板或其他可供小组观看的绘画媒介

·      Dice or another method to resolve issues as they arise_Whiteboard, chalkboard, or other medium upon which to draw that the group can see

可交付成果

Deliverable

·      没有任何

·      None

建议流程

Suggested Process

·      参见上文

·      See above

变体

Variant

不要指派一个人扮演叙述者，而是让小组扮演集体叙述者的角色。为此，您需要给每个玩家一张索引卡和一支铅笔。另外，手上要有两个六面骰子。当玩家想要执行一个看起来不常见的动作或制定一条新规则时，每个玩家都必须投票决定他们认为这个动作有多难。

Instead of assigning one person to play the narratologist, allow the group to play the role of a collective narratologist instead. To do this, you will need to give each player an index card and a pencil. Also, have two six-sided dice on hand. When a player wishes to perform an action that seems uncommon or to create a new rule, each player must vote on how difficult an action they think this is.

·       12 是极难的操作，或当前未生效的狂野规则

·      12 is an action that is extremely difficult or a wild rule that is not currently in play

·       1 是一个很容易执行但目前尚未实施的动作或规则

·      1 is an action or a rule that is trivial to perform, but not currently in play

任何玩家都可以随时宣布某项行动需要投票。因此，如果玩家 Cindy 说她希望召唤外星人来到她的城市，Bob 可以要求投票决定该行动是否成功。

Any player can declare that an action requires a vote at any time. So, if player Cindy says she wishes to summon aliens to her city, Bob can demand a vote on the likelihood of that succeeding.

每个玩家在自己的索引卡上写下 1 到 12 之间的数字，并将其藏起来，直到每个人都写完为止。12 表示发生这种情况的可能性几乎为零。1 表示您认为该规则或操作应该发生。

Each player writes down a number between 1 and 12 on his or her index card and keeps it hidden until everyone is done. A 12 means that the likelihood of this happening is near impossible. A 1 means that you think the rule or action should happen.

所有玩家同时翻牌。你可以用以下几种方式之一来决定难度（提前决定）：

All players flip their cards at the same time. You may decide the difficulty in one of several ways (decide on this ahead of time):

·      显示的最高值

·      The highest value shown

·      显示的所有值的平均值

·      An average of all the values shown

·      经玩家讨论并相互同意

·      By player discussion and mutual agreement

一旦确定了行动的难度，玩家就必须掷骰子来决定自己是否成功。玩家必须掷出大于或等于难度数字的点数。因此，为了得到外星人，辛迪需要掷出 12。为了在游戏世界中拥有一辆汽车，鲍勃只需要掷出 2 或更好的点数。

Once the difficulty of the action is decided, the player must roll to see if he or she succeeded. The player must roll above or equal to the difficulty number. So, in order to get an alien, Cindy needs to roll a 12. In order to own a car in the game world, Bob only needs to roll a 2 or better.

非数字短片

NON-DIGITAL SHORTS

在电力出现并为我们带来电子游戏之前，故事就已经是游戏的一部分了。这些非数字短片可以让你练习这一点。在设计这些之前，你可能想探索一下 Reiner Knizia 的纸牌游戏Once Upon a Time。

Stories were a part of games way before electricity arrived to bring us video games. These non-digital shorts allow you to practice that. Before designing these, you may want to explore the card game Once Upon a Time by Reiner Knizia.

1.    创建一个受著名探险家的故事启发的基于图块的探索游戏。

1.    Create a tile-based exploration game inspired by the story of a famous explorer.

2.    使用公共领域的小说或戏剧，创建一个紧跟故事情节的棋盘游戏。

2.    Using a novel or a play in the public domain, create a board game that closely follows the arc of the story.

3.    创建一款教授讲故事艺术的纸牌游戏（而不仅仅是《童话镇》的翻拍）。

3.    Create a card game that teaches the art of storytelling (not just a remake of Once Upon a Time).

4.    用任意媒介创建一个游戏，讲述一位失意的讲故事者如何成为伟大的讲故事者。

4.    Create a game in any medium about a dejected storyteller who becomes a great storyteller.

5.    想想你认识的能给你启发的人。用任何媒介创作一款能反映这种启发的游戏。

5.    Think of someone you personally know who inspires you. Create a game in any medium that reflects that inspiration.

6.    设计一款主题鲜明的棋盘游戏，每个玩家扮演一个英雄，目标是遵循你设计的英雄旅程故事情节。

6.    Design a strongly themed board game where each player plays a hero, and the goal is to follow a hero’s journey story arc of your design.

7.    当故事情节与玩家决策强度重叠时，故事情节会变得更具戏剧性。拿一款现有的非数字游戏，添加故事元素。尽量让故事的戏剧性高潮出现在游戏的关键时刻。雷纳·克尼齐亚的《指环王》是做好这一点的绝佳参考。

7.    Story arcs become more dramatic when they overlap with the intensity of player decision making. Take an existing non-digital game and add story elements to it. Try to make it so that the story’s dramatic climax comes at key moments during play. Reiner Knizia’s Lord of the Rings is a great reference for how to do this well.

8.    通过添加故事来修改抽象策略游戏。不要修改任何规则。与朋友一起玩，并注意故事对玩家体验的影响（或没有影响）。

8.    Modify an abstract strategy game by adding a story. Do not modify any rules at all. Play it with friends and note the effect that the story had (or did not have) on the player experience.

9.    修改之前非数字短片中的游戏，更改一个或多个规则以更好地适应您的故事。再玩一次，看看体验是否有所改善。

9.    Modify the game from the previous non-digital short by changing one or more rules to fit your story better. Play it again and see if the experience is improved.

10. 设想一款现有的非数字游戏，它有很多主题元素，但玩法不多（例如，《糖果乐园》）。创建一个主题相同但规则完全不同的新游戏。让规则尽可能与主题紧密贴合。

10. Think of an existing non-digital game that has a lot of thematic elements but not very much gameplay (for example, Candy Land). Create a new game with the same theme but a completely different set of rules. Make the rules fit the theme as tightly as possible.

参考

REFERENCES

《每个游戏开发者需要了解的故事》，作者：John Sutherland。可在线访问：http://www.gamasutra.com/features/20050727/sutherland_01.shtml。

“What Every Game Developer Needs to Know about Story” by John Sutherland. Available online at http://www.gamasutra.com/features/20050727/sutherland_01.shtml.



 

 

第四部分：加法设计与减法设计

Part IV: Additive & Subtractive Design


 

 

14：加减机制

14: Adding & Subtracting Mechanics

它通常是这样开始的：“如果......那不是很好吗？”接下来你会发现有人希望你在游戏中添加或删除一些东西。

It usually starts like this: “Wouldn’t it be great if...?” Next thing you know, someone wants you to add something to or take something out of a game.

我们在游戏中添加或删除一些机制，以便让它们始终更具吸引力。大富翁游戏中的免费停车只是一个例子。原始规则规定，当你停在停车区时什么也不会发生，但大多数人会遵循给予某种奖励的内部规则来玩游戏。有时，我们也会添加或删除一些游戏机制，以便让它们更容易玩。本书的一位作者经常修改传统的纸笔角色扮演游戏（如《龙与地下城》）的规则，以使它们更适合刚接触D&D和整个游戏的玩家。

We add or remove mechanics in games in order to make them more compelling all the time. Free parking in Monopoly is just one example. The original rules state that nothing at all happens when you land on it, but most people play with a house rule that gives some kind of bonus. Sometimes, we add or remove mechanics from games in order to make them easier to play, too. One of the authors of this book routinely modifies the rules of traditional pencil-and-paper role-playing games like Dungeons & Dragons in order to make them more palatable to players new to both D&D and gaming as a whole.

在游戏行业中，出于类似的原因添加或删除机制。对于有抱负且在职的游戏设计师来说，在保持游戏整体视觉效果和提高游戏质量的同时添加和删除电子游戏机制的能力是一项关键技能。

In the game industry, mechanics are added or removed for similar reasons. For the aspiring and practicing game designer, your ability to add and remove mechanics from a video game while maintaining the game’s overall vision and enhancing its quality is a key skill.

为什么要添加机制？

WHY ADD MECHANICS?

游戏设计师经常需要为游戏添加功能。理想情况下，他们在游戏投入生产之前就知道该功能或机制，但由于游戏是一种互动媒体，有时如果不将其付诸实践，就无法知道其好坏。

Game designers often need to add a feature to a game. Ideally, they know about the feature or mechanics before the game enters production, but since games are an interactive medium, sometimes there’s just no way to know how good or bad something is without putting it into motion.

以下部分探讨开发人员添加功能的原因。

The following sections explore the reasons developers add features.

出版商需求

PUBLISHER DEMAND

主流游戏行业（尤其是游戏机行业）的开发商通常通过发行商发行游戏。发行商为游戏制作提供资金，以换取许多东西，包括他们希望获得的投资回报。作为游戏的主要资助者，发行商对游戏的制作有很大的影响力，并且可能会不时要求进行更改。

Developers in the mainstream game industry, and the console industry in particular, generally release games through a publisher. The publisher funds the production of the game in return for numerous things, including a hoped-for return on their investment. As the primary funder of the game, the publisher has more than a bit of influence in its production and may request changes from time to time.

开发者与发行商的制作人或高级设计师合作。他们或他们的团队的工作是试玩游戏的不同版本、评估可玩性并提出修改或添加建议。

Developers work with a producer or a senior-level designer on the publisher’s side. It’s their job or their team’s job to play the various builds of the game, assess playability, and recommend course corrections or additions.

市场变化

CHANGES IN THE MARKETPLACE

游戏行业竞争激烈、神秘莫测且瞬息万变。因此，当一项令人惊叹的新技术出现并改变整个游戏领域时，整个开发者团队措手不及的情况并不罕见。《MYST》、《毁灭战士》和《万智牌：聚会》等游戏当然有这种影响，从 2D 到 3D 的转变也是如此。

The game industry is competitive, secretive, and constantly changing. As a result, it’s not uncommon for a whole group of developers to be caught unawares when an amazing new piece of technology hits and alters the whole playing field. Games like MYST, Doom, and Magic: The Gathering certainly had this effect, as did the transition from 2D to 3D.

不过，很多时候，开发者会因为一些细微的改变而感到困扰。如果你正在开发《Ravishing Radishes VI》（又一个你可以随意窃取的糟糕虚构 IP），而你的头号竞争对手添加了自动保存功能，你可能会觉得有必要添加一个——尤其是如果粉丝和媒体的反应良好的话。开发者时刻关注市场动态，定期玩游戏，与业内其他人建立联系，并关注行业新闻，以保持其产品尽可能具有竞争力。

Many times, though, it’s smaller and more subtle changes that get developers. If you were working on Ravishing Radishes VI (yet another terrible made-up IP you’re free to steal), and your number one competition added an autosave feature, you might feel compelled to add one—particularly if fan and press reaction were favorable. Developers stay on top of the market, regularly playing games, networking with others in the industry, and following industry news to keep their product as competitive as it can be.

游戏很烂

THE GAME SUCKS

正如多次提到的，游戏设计是一个迭代过程，除非开发者在设计过程中有经验，否则他们永远无法确定某件事情会如何发展，除非他们有机会玩它。相比之下，想象一下厨师面对着摆满配料和香料的柜台，脑子里只有一个通用的菜谱。从某些方面来看，创建游戏也类似。菜谱也是通过迭代过程进行改进的。

As has been mentioned several times, game design is an iterative process, and barring experience in the process, developers never really know for certain how something’s going to turn out until they have a chance to play it. In comparison, imagine being a cook facing a counter full of ingredients and spices with only a general recipe in mind. Creating a game is similar, in some respects. Recipes are refined through an iterative process, too.

有时，游戏就是不尽如人意。人们玩了游戏，却一点也不想再回去玩。设计师认为会带来重大改变的功能似乎毫无意义。测试人员无法弄清楚到底发生了什么，尽管人们希望能够执行某个操作，但游戏不允许他们这样做。所有这些情况都可能表明需要添加一些功能。

Sometimes, the game just doesn’t turn out. People play it, and don’t feel at all compelled to go back and play it again. The feature that a designer thought was going to make all the difference seems pointless. The testers can’t figure out what the heck is going on, and though people want to be able to perform a certain action, the game doesn’t let them do it. All of these instances might suggest additions.

这在实际制作的游戏中真的会发生吗？相信我。

Does this actually happen in real production games? Count on it.

续集

A SEQUEL

当开发人员开发现有系列的续集时，几乎总是会添加新机制。行业在向前发展，玩家想要更多，博客上充满了很酷的建议，其中一些建议你会认真考虑。你可能从旧游戏的代码库开始，然后向其中添加这些新东西。

When developers work on a sequel to an existing franchise, new mechanics are almost always added. The industry moves ahead, players want more, and the blogs light up with cool suggestions, some of which you seriously consider. You may be starting with the old game’s code base, and to it, you will add these new things.

头脑风暴

THE BRAINSTORM

当你在玩游戏时，突然想到了某个点子——它真的会让你的游戏从 A 级升至 AAA 级，或者至少提升一个档次。通常，当有这样的想法时，你可以肯定没有足够的时间来实现它。你为这种可能性安排的时间已经被你没有预见到的其他问题占用了。

You’re playing the game when it hits you—something that would truly take your game from A to AAA or at least move it up a notch. Usually, when ideas like this hit, you can bet there won’t be enough time in the schedule to do it. The time that you had scheduled for just such an eventuality was already eaten up by other problems you hadn’t foreseen.

整个团队都同意你的观点，认为这个想法很棒，他们愿意加班加点来实现它。头脑风暴的副产品“功能蔓延”是行业中常见的问题。不过，有时这样做确实值得。

The whole team agrees with you that the idea is great, and they’re willing to put in the extra overtime in order to make it happen. The byproduct of brainstorms, “feature creep,” is a common problem in the industry. Sometimes, though, it’s truly worth it.

为什么要削减机械部分？

WHY CUT MECHANICS?

删除游戏中的机制（尤其是数字游戏）可能会带来惊人的不稳定和高昂的成本。在花费了设计、编程甚至艺术时间来实现其实施后，做出删除机制的决定并不总是那么容易。

Removing a mechanic in a game—particularly a digital game—can have amazingly destabilizing and costly effects. Having spent design, programming, and possibly art time to realize its implementation, making the decision to remove a mechanic doesn’t always come easily.

为什么开发者会这么做？毫不奇怪，上一节中的前三项也适用于此。发行商、市场条件或糟糕的游戏玩法都可能导致取消某项功能及其相关机制。

Why would developers possibly do such a thing? Not surprisingly, the first three items in the previous section also apply here. Publishers, market conditions, or bad gameplay might warrant killing a feature and its associated mechanics.

然而，开发人员也可能会因为一些特殊的原因而放弃这些机制。
