However, there are some unique reasons developers might put mechanics on the chopping block, too.

评级

RATINGS

在游戏开发接近尾声时，它会被提交给评级委员会进行审查，并最终进行评级。在美国，这个评级委员会就是 ESRB。如果开发者希望获得“成人”评级，结果却获得了“仅限成人”评级，那么影响将是巨大的。最重要的是，“仅限成人”评级会严重限制游戏的发行。大多数零售商不会进货这样的游戏。

Toward the end of a game’s development, it is submitted to a ratings board for review and ultimately a rating. In the United States, that rating board is the ESRB. If the developers are hoping for a “Mature” rating and receive an “Adults Only” rating instead, the implications are huge. Most significantly, an “Adults Only” rating severely limits distribution of a title. Most retailers won’t stock such games.

如果开发者收到的评级高于计划或可接受的评级，则他必须删除某些内容才能重新提交。这些内容很可能涉及游戏机制的削减。

In the event a developer receives a rating higher than planned or acceptable, he will have to remove something before resubmitting again. That something may very well involve the cutting of gameplay mechanics.

按时交货

TO DELIVER ON TIME

... 或者比他们原本应该的更及时。在游戏制作即将结束时，人们愿意为之献身的功能（当然是比喻意义上的）突然看起来并不那么重要了。所以他们被删掉了。当它们被删掉时，机制也会随之消失。虽然许多玩家可能没有意识到这一点，但游戏中有很多关卡从未面世，在发行的游戏中，有很多半成品、仍有缺陷的功能，这些功能已从代码中注释掉，但仍然存在。

... Or in better time than they otherwise would have. Toward the end of a game’s production, features that people were willing to die for (figuratively, of course) suddenly don’t seem so critical after all. So they get cut. When they get cut, mechanics go right along with them. Although many gamers may not realize it, there are whole levels to games out there that have never seen the light of day, and in shipped games, there are plenty of half-finished, still buggy features that have been commented out of the code but are still very much there.

核心检查

CORE CHECK

在开发过程中，开发人员经常会检查现有的功能列表，并将其与游戏的核心（游戏的核心）进行对比。该功能是否让游戏的核心更加强大？它是多余的吗？你会花时间和金钱在它上面，而没有真正让你的游戏变得更强大吗？同样的时间可以用来改进必要的功能吗？

During the course of development, it’s not uncommon for developers to review their existing feature list and check it against the core of the game—the one thing that game is about. Does that feature make the core stronger? Is it superfluous? Will you spend time and money on it, and not really make your game stronger? Could that same time be used to make a necessary feature better?

修补之后

AFTER THE TINKERING

游戏设计的迭代过程是相同的，无论你是在添加还是在削减。改变它，玩它，然后评估。重复。有时改变机制可能会产生意想不到的副作用，这些副作用会过于强大或表现不佳。你永远不会知道，直到你玩。任何有过虚拟世界经验的人都可能亲身经历过这个过程，因为世界的设计师会调整这样或那样的东西。首先，游戏中的某个职业太强，然后太弱，然后又太强……等等。

The iterative process of game design works the same whether you’re on the adding or the cutting end. Change it, play it, and evaluate. Repeat. Sometimes altering mechanics can have unintended side effects that are overpowering or underperforming. You never know until you play. Anyone who’s had any experience in virtual worlds has likely experienced this process live as the world’s designers tweak one thing or another. First, a profession in the game is too strong, then too weak, then too strong...and so on.

每当开发人员向游戏中添加任何内容时，就会发生类似的事情：

Stuff like this happens all the time whenever developers add anything to a game:

·      添加新的咒语、武器或能力，它会太强大或太弱。

·      Add a new spell, weapon, or ability, and it is way too powerful or too weak.

·      在游戏中添加一种新职业，而且它非常好，以至于没有人会选择其他职业。

·      Add a new profession to the game, and it’s so good, no one selects anything else.

有游戏开发经验的人都知道，即​​使是最简单的改变也会产生意想不到的副作用。发现这些问题的唯一方法是玩游戏，并评估你目前的改变如何影响游戏中的其他内容。

Those with experience developing games know that even the simplest change can have adverse, unintended side effects. The only way to uncover these is to play the game and evaluate how your present change affected other things in the game.

挑战

CHALLENGES

游戏通常包含多个相互关联的系统，机制上的一个微小变化可能会产生连锁反应，从而彻底改变其他系统中的游戏平衡。正如您在这些挑战中看到的，每当您对机制进行任何重大更改时，您都需要对整个游戏进行游戏测试，而不仅仅是对一个小系统进行游戏测试。

Games often contain several interlocking systems, and one small change in the mechanics can have ripple effects that drastically alter the balance of the game in other systems. As you’ll see with these challenges, you need to playtest the entire game and not just one small system whenever you make any nontrivial change to the mechanics.

挑战 1——扑克和龙

CHALLENGE 1—POKER AND DRAGONS

出于某种原因，许多角色扮演游戏都以游戏内赌场的形式提供赌博小游戏。有时，这些游戏是现实世界赌博游戏（如扑克、二十一点和轮盘赌）的精确复制品。然而，在幻想世界中，它可以帮助玩家沉浸其中，让这些游戏具有异国情调——既有熟悉的元素，又独特和原创。这样的游戏可以在视频游戏中实现，也可以在桌面角色扮演游戏中使用。（“您的团队进入旅馆休息。你发现一群看起来很友好的旅行者在角落里玩某种纸牌游戏......”）

Many RPGs, for some reason, have gambling mini-games in the form of an in-game casino. Sometimes, these games are exact copies of real-world gambling games like Poker, Blackjack, and Roulette. However, in a fantasy world, it can help player immersion to give these games an exotic twist—something that has familiar elements, but is also unique and original. Such a game can be implemented in a video game, and can also be used in a tabletop RPG. (“Your party enters the inn to rest. You spot a group of friendly looking travelers playing some kind of card game over in the corner...”)

对于这个挑战，从扑克开始。扑克有几十种甚至几百种变体（抽牌、 梭哈、德州扑克、高低牌等），您可以选择任何适合您的版本，也可以根据需要创建自己的版本。

For this challenge, start with Poker. There are dozens, if not hundreds, of poker variants (Draw, Stud, Texas Hold ‘Em, Hi-Lo, etc.), and you can choose whatever version suits you or create your own if you want.

在该游戏中，添加一些四面骰子（骰子数量不限，但至少两个）。这些骰子必须是游戏的一部分。适当修改游戏规则，以包含这些新组件。

To this game, add some four-sided dice (any number of dice, but at least two). These dice must be part of the play of the game. Modify the rules of the game, as appropriate, to include these new components.

请记住，您的游戏应该足够熟悉，以便可以立即识别为扑克变体，但又要足够不同，让人感觉与众不同。

Remember, your game should be familiar enough to be instantly recognizable as a Poker variant, but different enough to feel otherworldly.

所需组件

Components Required

·      一副基本的纸牌

·      A basic deck of cards

·      一堆四面骰子

·      A pile of four-sided dice

可交付成果

Deliverable

·      为你的可玩游戏制定一套完整的书面规则

·      A complete set of written rules for your playable game

建议流程

Suggested Process

1.    研究。如果您不熟悉许多扑克 变体，请阅读至少三种不同类型的规则，并在小组中玩这些游戏。您可以在网上或《霍伊尔的游戏规则》等书籍中找到规则，或者您可以找到可以教您的朋友或同事。

1.    Research. If you are unfamiliar with many Poker variants, read the rules of at least three different kinds and play them in a group. You can find rules online or in books like Hoyle’s Rules of Games, or you can find friends or colleagues who can teach you.

2.    集思广益。回答有关游戏的关键问题。你觉得扑克的哪些元素需要保留，哪些机制可以改变或丢弃以使其感觉更棒？你如何将骰子融入游戏中？你如何确定每手牌的获胜者？玩家在玩每手牌时要经历哪些不同的步骤？

2.    Brainstorm. Answer key questions about the game. What elements of Poker do you feel you need to keep, and what mechanics can be changed or discarded to give it a more fantastic feel? How can you integrate dice into the game? How do you determine who wins each hand? What are the different steps players go through during the play of each hand?

3.    游戏测试和迭代。 尝试在小组中玩游戏。你的机制是否有趣且有意思？骰子是否为体验增添了一些东西，还是感觉是附加的？尝试不同的规则变体，直到找到一个足够引人注目的规则。

3.    Playtest and iterate. Try playing the game in a group. Are your mechanics fun and interesting? Do the dice add something to the experience, or do they feel tacked on? Experiment with different rules variants until you find one that is sufficiently compelling.

4.    创建可交付成果。 写下规则后，玩几局，确保你没有遗漏规则中的任何细节。你的规则应包括以下内容：设置。每局如何开始？/游戏进展。每局发生的事情的顺序是什么？/下注。玩家在什么时候下注？这样做的机制是什么？/确定赢家。谁得到下注的钱？在什么条件下以及何时？

4.    Create deliverable. After writing the rules down, play a few hands to make sure that you didn’t leave any details out of the rules. Your rules should include the following: Setup. How does each hand begin? / Progression of play. What is the order that things happen in each hand? / Betting. At what points do players wager money? What are the mechanisms for doing so? / Determining winner(s). Who gets the money that is wagered? Under what conditions and when?

变体

Variant

选择与扑克牌不同的纸牌游戏。拉米牌、尤克牌和Pitch等游戏都是不错的选择，但实际上有数百种纸牌游戏可供选择。

Choose a different card game than Poker. Games like Rummy, Euchre, and Pitch are good candidates, but there are literally hundreds of card games that could be used.

变体

Variant

不用骰子，而是选择不同的组件。添加第二副牌。或者添加（或移除）小丑牌。或者使用其他游戏的牌组而不是标准扑克牌 组。或者添加一个 20 面骰子而不是几个 4 面骰子。你明白了。

Instead of dice, choose a different component. Add a second deck of cards. Or add (or remove) the jokers. Or play with a deck from a different game instead of a standard Poker deck. Or add a single 20-sided die instead of several four-sided dice. You get the idea.

变体

Variant

不要添加骰子等组件，而是添加新规则。例如，所有玩家都会得到三手牌，而不是一手。或者给玩家发不同数量的牌，扑克牌 由四张或六张牌组成，而不是五张。（这需要你改变获胜牌是什么以及它们的相对等级。）或者有两个底池而不是一个，它们在游戏过程中有不同的功能。或者其他什么——发挥你的想象力。

Instead of adding components like dice, add a new rule. For example, all players are dealt three hands instead of one. Or players are dealt a different number of cards, and Poker hands are made from four or six cards instead of five. (This would require you to change what the winning hands are and what their relative ranks are.) Or there are two pots instead of one, and they have different functions during gameplay. Or something else—use your imagination.

变体

Variant

将“瞬间牌”添加到牌组，这样您就可以从其他玩家那里偷牌、换手或再次抽牌。

Add “instants” to the deck, allowing you to steal cards from other players, swap hands, or draw again.

挑战 2——社交网络：游戏

CHALLENGE 2—SOCIAL NETWORKING: THE GAME

在任何社交网站中，都会有一场元游戏：谁拥有最多的联系人？谁拥有更好的 联系人？谁拥有最酷的联系人？为了应对这一挑战，设计一款游戏添加到社交网站中，以利用这些自然趋势。至少，需要有某种挑战和至少一个总体目标。此外，由于它是一个社交网络，玩家之间也必须有游戏互动，而不仅仅是某种排名系统（例如，谁拥有最多的朋友）。游戏必须不仅仅是高分。

In any social-networking site, there is a meta-game going on: Who has the most contacts? Who has the better contacts? Who has the coolest contact of all? For this challenge, design a game to be added to a social-networking site that takes advantage of these natural tendencies. At minimum, there needs to be some kind of challenge and at least one overall goal. Furthermore, since it’s a social network, there must also be gameplay interaction between the players, and not merely a ranking system of sorts (for example, who has the most friends). The game must be about more than the high score.

游戏不需要影响社交网络本身，但可以利用它，就像梦幻足球利用真实的足球运动员和统计数据而不影响游戏本身一样。

The game need not affect the social network itself, but can take advantage of it, much like fantasy football takes advantage of real football players and stats without affecting the game itself.

所需组件

Components Required

·      互联网连接和社交网络会员资格（例如 Facebook、LinkedIn 或 Instagram）

·      Internet connection and membership in a social network (such as Facebook, LinkedIn, or Instagram)

可交付成果

Deliverable

·      游戏设计文档

·      Game-design document

·      非正式的推介，列出游戏的功能以及它如何融入整个更大的社交网络

·      Informal pitch listing the game’s features and how it integrates into the larger social network as a whole

建议流程

Suggested Process

1.    研究社交网络。对于您选择的社交网络，列出个人资料的属性（例如，他或她的好友列表、照片和电子邮件地址）。突出显示当个人参与某种社交活动（例如添加新朋友）时发生变化的属性。

1.    Research the social network. For the social network that you chose, list the attributes of an individual’s profile (such as his or her friends list, photos, and e-mail address). Highlight those attributes that change when the individual engages in some kind of social activity, such as adding a new friend.

2.    集思广益，想出游戏机制。 这些属性，尤其是那些改变属性的活动，是否能为游戏提供机制或动态？在小组中讨论可能的概念。留出两个小时的时间，就一个概念达成一致，并充实一些基本细节。

2.    Brainstorm mechanics. Do any of these attributes, or especially the activities that change the attributes, suggest mechanics or dynamics for a game? In a group, discuss potential concepts. Allow two hours to agree on a single concept, and flesh out some basic details.

3.    创建可交付成果。

3.    Create deliverable.

挑战 3 —强臂拼字游戏

CHALLENGE 3—STRONG ARM SCRABBLE

您有 Q、U 和 I 牌。如果您只有 T 牌（或者您可以从某个地方拿走一个），那么您就可以获得高分。幸运的是，为了应对这一挑战，您正在玩​​ Strong Arm Scrabble，这是该游戏的自制修改版，允许您在需要时拿走字母。为了做到这一点，您必须在游戏中添加一个或多个机制。您从哪里拿走这些字母以及这样做的后果（如果有的话）由您（设计师）决定。

You have Q, U, and I tiles. If you only had a T—or if you could take one from somewhere—you could score big. Fortunately for you, and for the sake of this challenge, you are playing Strong Arm Scrabble, a home-modified version of the game that allows you to take letters when you need them. In order to do this, you must add one or more mechanics to the game. Where you take these letters from and the consequences for doing that (if any) are up to you, the designer.

所需组件

Components Required

·      拼字游戏或类似的游戏

·      Scrabble board game or a suitable equivalent

可交付成果

Deliverable

·      修改了拼字 游戏

·      Modified Scrabble game

·      对原始游戏规则修改的书面说明

·      Written description of the modification(s) to the original game rules

·      全新完整规则集（可选）

·      New complete set of rules (optional)

建议流程

Suggested Process

 

 

1.    考虑你的选择。注意，拿取方块的方法有很多种，甚至可能有一种方法可以防御。你不希望人们说“嘿，这不公平……”或类似的话，并对你添加的机制感到恼火。找到添加此机制的方法，但不要破坏游戏的平衡性。此外，你添加到游戏中的机制不应破坏当前的游戏状态。如果玩家从棋盘上拿起一个 T，它不应该让单词处于部分完成的状态，除非你成功地将其巧妙地融入规则中。你的游戏应该既可玩又合乎逻辑。

1.    Consider your options. Note that there can be multiple ways to take tiles, and possibly even a way to defend against it. You don’t want people to say, “Hey, that’s not fair...” or something similar and become irritated at the mechanic you add. Find ways of adding this mechanic that do not unbalance the game. Also, the mechanic that you add to the game shouldn’t break the current state of play. If the player lifts a T off the board, it shouldn’t leave words in a partial state of finish, unless you succeed in working that elegantly into the rules. Your game should be both playable and logical.

2.    游戏测试和迭代。 添加每个机制后，立即测试游戏。不要花大量时间争论一个或另一个添加的优点。几轮游戏就可以解决任何争论，因为修改的优点和缺点会立即显现出来。

2.    Playtest and iterate. After adding each mechanic, test the game immediately. Don’t spend a whole lot of time debating the merits of one addition or another. A few turns of play can settle any arguments by making a modification’s merits and flaws immediately obvious.

3.    创建可交付成果。

3.    Create deliverable.

变体

Variant

使用与拼字游戏相同的机制，尝试创建另一个基于图块的游戏，要求您在放下某些图块组之前收集它们。例如，除了字母，还可以考虑地牢碎片或森林小径。任何可以通过将一个图块链接到下一个图块来创建的东西都是可能的。

Using the same mechanics present in Scrabble, attempt to create another tile-based game that requires you to collect certain tile groups before laying them down. For instance, instead of letters, consider dungeon pieces or forest pathways. Anything that can be created by linking one tile to the next is a possibility.

变体

Variant

为不同的经典棋盘游戏或纸牌游戏添加类似的“偷窃”机制。考虑Strong Arm Monopoly、Strong Arm Rummy、Strong Arm Candy Land等。

Add a similar “stealing” mechanic to a different classic board or card game. Consider Strong Arm Monopoly, Strong Arm Rummy, Strong Arm Candy Land, and so on.

挑战 4 — 每一分钱都很重要

CHALLENGE 4—EVERY CENT COUNTS

如果你按顺序阅读了本书的章节，那么你可能已经从第 5 章到第 8 章中找到了让你引以为豪的一些棋盘、纸牌和骰子游戏设计。选择你最喜欢的。现在，假设一个棋盘游戏出版商向你提供了批量生产游戏的合同。恭喜你！只有一个问题。为了以最低的价格出售游戏

If you’ve been reading the chapters of this book in order, you probably have some board, card and dice game designs from Chapters 5–8 that you are quite proud of. Choose your favorite. Now, suppose that a board-game publisher has offered you a contract to mass-produce your game. Congratulations! There’s only one problem. In order to sell the game at the de

价格点，他们需要你减少材料。在不添加任何新游戏材料或将一种材料换成另一种材料的情况下，

sired price point, they’re going to need you to reduce the materials. Without adding any new game materials, or swapping one material out for another,

您必须移除以下至少一项：所有骰子、所有卡片、所有纸板牌或游戏板。您可以根据需要修改游戏规则以应对此变化，只要您不添加任何新的物理组件即可。

you must remove at least one of the following: all of the dice, all of the cards, all of the cardboard tiles, or the game board. You may alter the game rules as needed to deal with this change, as long as you don’t add any new physical components.

由于目标是降低成本，因此您无法“移除”游戏最初未使用的组件。要求玩家提供自己的骰子也是不可能的。如果您要移除骰子，您必须将其从游戏机制中移除，而不仅仅是从盒子中移除。

Since the objective is to decrease costs, you can’t “remove” a component that your game didn’t originally use. Requiring players to supply their own dice is also out of the question. If you’re going to remove the dice, you must remove them from the game mechanics, not just the box.

如果您感觉自己正在摘除肾脏，那么这项练习将让您真实体验到当外部影响强加给您的减法设计时会是什么感觉。如果这个挑战看起来微不足道，请选择其他游戏。

If it feels like you’re extracting a kidney, then this exercise is giving you a realistic taste of what it’s like when subtractive design is forced on you by outside influences. If this challenge seems trivial, choose another game.

所需组件

Components Required

·      没有任何

·      None

可交付成果

Deliverable

·      上一个挑战的更新交付成果（例如，修订后的规则集，或新的可玩原型，或两者兼有）

·      An updated deliverable of the previous challenge (for example, either a revised set of rules, or a new playable prototype, or both)

建议流程

Suggested Process

1.    找出问题所在。删除重要组件应立即使游戏无法按照现有规则进行。在做其他任何事情（包括惊慌失措）之前，列出必须修改的规则，因为它们涉及不再存在的游戏部分。您可能会发现最简单的方法是打印出规则并使用荧光笔。这将为您提供一个起点。

1.    Figure out what’s broken. The removal of a vital component should immediately make the game unplayable by the existing rules. Before you do anything else (including panic), make a list of what rules have to be modified because they refer to parts of the game that no longer exist. You might find it easiest to just print out the rules and use a highlighter. This will give you a starting point.

2.    修复损坏。 在某些情况下，您可能会找到其他方法来表示旧机制，而无需添加新组件（例如，向曾经位于新删除的卡片上的板添加附加信息）。这些是最简单的修复方法，因为它们可以让您以最少的麻烦保留旧机制，因此请先执行这些操作以消除它们。

2.    Repair the damage. In some cases, you may find other ways to represent the old mechanics without adding new components (such as adding additional information to the board that used to be on the newly deleted cards). These are the easiest fixes, because they let you preserve the old mechanics with a minimum of fuss, so do those first to get them out of the way.

3.    重塑缺失的部分。对于剩余的机制，开始考虑使用新机制来代替它们。忘记游戏最初想要成为的样子，因为可能不再可能保留它了。你可能不得不改变游戏的核心，才能让事情再次顺利进行。不要哀叹这种改变如何毁了你的游戏，而是把它当作创造新 游戏的机会。保留你能保留的东西，但不要害怕彻底改变你必须改变的东西。

3.    Reshape the missing pieces. For the remaining mechanics, start thinking about new mechanics to use in their place. Forget about what the game was originally trying to be, because it might no longer be possible to preserve it anymore. You may have to alter the very core of the game to get things to work well again. Instead of lamenting about how this change has ruined your game, think of it as an opportunity to make a new game. Preserve what you can, but don’t be afraid to completely change what you must.

4.    修改原型并进行游戏测试。根据新规则创建一个新原型并进行测试。根据需要进行迭代。

4.    Alter the prototype and playtest. Create a new prototype with your new rules and try it out. Iterate as necessary.

5.    创建可交付成果。  

5.     Create deliverable.

铁杆设计师挑战 5 — 选择机械师，任何机械师均可（现场直播）

IRON DESIGNER CHALLENGE 5—PICK A MECHANIC, ANY MECHANIC (LIVE)

用单一机制制作游戏也许是终极的附加练习。当一个随机机制被强加到一款毫无防备的棋盘游戏上时，它既是一个附加挑战，又是一个减法挑战，这就是这个挑战的意义所在。

Making a game from a single mechanic is perhaps the ultimate additive exercise. When a random mechanic is foisted upon an unsuspecting board game, it becomes both an additive and a subtractive challenge, and that’s what this challenge is all about.

在本次挑战中，您将与另一位设计师或设计师团队展开激烈较量，创造出极具挑战性的作品。本次挑战分为三个阶段：

For this challenge, you and another designer or team of designers will go head to head to create something exceptionally challenging. There are three stages to this challenge:

1.    选择一款游戏（最好是游戏时间短的游戏，30分钟或者更短，以便进行更多次迭代）。

1.    Select a game (preferably one that plays in a short period of time, 30 minutes or less, in order to allow for more iteration).

2.    从 BoardGameGeek.com 机制列表（http://www.boardgamegeek.com/browser.php?itemtype=game&sortby=mechanic）中选择一个机制或游戏动态。

2.    Select a mechanic or play dynamic from the BoardGameGeek.com mechanics list at http://www.boardgamegeek.com/browser.php?itemtype=game&sortby=mechanic.

3.    将其交给另一位设计师或设计师团队，以整合到您选择的游戏中。

3.    Give it to another designer or team of designers to integrate into the game you’ve selected.

因为另一支队伍必须应对你的选择，所以你可以自由发挥创造力或残忍行事。几乎可以肯定的是，这项练习将要求另一支队伍增加和减少机制，以使游戏再次变得有趣。

Since the other team has to deal with your choices, feel free to be creative or cruel. It’s virtually certain that the exercise will require the other team to both add and subtract mechanics to make the game fun again.

所需组件

Components Required

·      网络连接

·      Internet connection

·      游戏组件的选择：骰子、棋子、木制标记等（可选）

·      A selection of game components: dice, pawns, wooden markers, etc. (optional)

·      一份所选棋盘游戏（最好每队一份）

·      A copy of the chosen board game (or preferably, one copy per team)

可交付成果

Deliverable

·      所涉游戏的可玩原型以及描述游戏玩法的书面规则或

·      Playable prototype of game in question and written rules that describe the play of the game or

·      新规则的非正式游戏演示。

·      Informal play demonstration of the new rules.

建议流程

Suggested Process

1.    研究。考虑一下你得到的机制。你在哪些其他游戏中见过它？如果答案是没有，请在 BoardGameGeek.com 上搜索包含该机制的游戏，并阅读一些游戏描述以获得想法。大多数机制在大型游戏中都有广泛的用途。

1.    Research. Consider the mechanic you’re given. What other games have you seen it in? If the answer is none, search for games including that mechanic on BoardGameGeek.com and read some play descriptions to get an idea. Most mechanics have a wide range of uses within a larger game.

2.    集思广益。思考如何以有趣的方式使用该机制，以及将其与游戏结合起来的可能方法。

2.    Brainstorm. Think of interesting ways to use that mechanic and possible ways to tie it into your game.

3.    游戏测试和迭代。 当您认为您找到了一个有潜力的想法时，请尝试一下。使用您的游戏副本，尝试使用新机制玩几轮，看看游戏如何反应。根据需要进行修改，或者如果它似乎不起作用，请重新开始。

3.    Playtest and iterate. When you think you’ve found an idea with potential, try it out. With your copy of the game, try playing a few turns with your new mechanic and see how the game responds. Make modifications as needed or go back to the drawing board if it just doesn’t seem to be working.

4.    创建可交付成果。

4.    Create deliverable.

非数字短片

NON-DIGITAL SHORTS

游戏通常包含几个相互关联的系统，机制中的一个小变化可能会对整个游戏体验产生深远的影响。

Games often contain several interlocking systems, and one small change in the mechanics can have far-reaching effects on the entire play experience.

1.    选择一款你认为平庸或糟糕的常见棋盘游戏。添加或删除一项可以改善游戏的机制。

1.    Choose a common board game you consider to be mediocre or terrible. Add or subtract one mechanic that improves the game.

2.    除了第 1 条之外，还可以添加尽可能多的机制，让游戏真正有趣。尽量少添加新内容。

2.    Alternatively to #1, add as many mechanics as necessary to make the game genuinely fun. Try to do it with as few additions as possible.

3.    除了#1-2，还可以尝试通过减去机制来实现。在游戏消失之前尝试成功！

3.    Alternativelyto#1-2, try doing it by subtracting mechanics. Try to succeed before the game disappears!

4.    选择一款经典的双人棋盘游戏（如西洋双陆棋），并将其重新设计为可供四人玩。

4.    Choose a classic two-player board game (such as Backgammon) and redesign it to be playable by four players.

5.    从本书不同章节的挑战或非数字短片中选择一个游戏。从中选择一个机制，然后重新设计游戏，就好像该机制因出版商不同意而被删除一样。

5.    Choose a game you have created from a challenge or non-digital short from a different chapter in this book. Select one mechanic from it and redesign the game as if that mechanic had been cut due to publisher disapproval.

6.    选择一款常见的儿童游戏（例如Go Fish），您可以合理地认为该游戏的评级为“E”。添加一个机制，将评级提升至青少年。尽可能继续下去——每个评级级别添加一个机制。

6.    Choose a common children’s game (such as Go Fish) that you can reasonably consider to have an “E” rating. Add one mechanic that will bump the rating to Teen. Continue as far as you are able—one mechanic per rating level.

7.    从本书不同章节的挑战或非数字短片中选择一个你创建的游戏。找三个不熟悉该游戏的人来提出一个机制，然后将他们添加到你的游戏中，而不会破坏它。

7.    Choose a game you have created from a challenge or non-digital short from a different chapter in this book. Find three people unfamiliar with the game to suggest a mechanic and then add these to your game without breaking it.

8.    想出一个可以引入您最喜欢的集换式卡牌游戏的新机制。制作五张原创卡牌来展示您的新机制。

8.    Think of a new mechanic that can be introduced into your favorite collectible card game. Create five original cards to showcase your new mechanic.

9.    设计一种在回合制桌面角色扮演游戏中进行战斗的方法。现在，通过从中去除一种机制来简化它。

9.    Design a means for combat to occur in a turn-based tabletop RPG. Now, simplify it by taking a mechanic out of it.

10. 选择一款基于图块的建筑游戏，例如《卡卡颂》，重新设计其主题，使其成为您自己的游戏，并添加新的机制。

10. Select a tile-based building game like Carcassonne, re-theme it to make it your own, and add a new mechanic to it.



 

 

15：但要让它成为多人游戏

15: But Make it Multiplayer

20 世纪 90 年代初，无论请求的潜力、可能性或敏感性如何，整个游戏行业的营销部门都会说这句话。游戏（传统上是一种多人游戏媒介）在其原本无可挑剔的历史上曾经历过短暂的历史转折，在这段转折中，游戏不是社会团结者，而是社会孤立者。玩家打开电脑，独自消失在游戏世界中。

In the early 1990s, marketing departments throughout the game industry could be heard to utter this line no matter the potential, possibility, or sensibility of the request in question. Games—traditionally a multiplayer medium—had enjoyed a short and historical blip in their otherwise spotless history in which they were not social uniters but social isolators. Players turned on their computers and disappeared into game worlds by themselves.

然而，随着调制解调器和宽带逐渐普及到普通家庭，多人游戏开始重新出现。大约在同一时间，网络连接使整个办公室或极客社区能够联网并一起玩游戏。

With the ready acceptance of modems and later broadband into the average home, however, multiplayer games began to reappear. At about the same time, network connectivity allowed whole offices or communities of geeks to network and play games together.

结果，多人游戏大卖。虽然大学里的人们早就可以接触到大型机上的游戏，但这些机器超出了普通游戏玩家的承受范围。然而，调制解调器和网络改变了这一现状。对许多人来说，第一款让他们接触到多人电脑游戏媒介的游戏是《毁灭战士》。在约翰·罗梅罗 (John Romero) 创造的“死亡竞赛”游戏中，与朋友正面交锋，办公室里的人们因此损失了大量的工作时间。

The result was that multiplayer games sold like hotcakes. While people at universities had long had access to games on mainframes, the machines were outside the reach of the average game player. Modems and networking changed that, however. For many, the first game to introduce them to the medium of multiplayer computer games was Doom. Going head-to-head against their friends in what John Romero coined “deathmatch” play, people in offices lost many hours of productivity.

RPG 领域的早期作品也吸引了来自单人游戏世界的玩家。暴雪的《暗黑破坏神》是一款动作 RPG，玩家可以组成一队人马冒险进入地下城寻找怪物和战利品。与当时传统的“硬核”RPG 不同，《暗黑破坏神》对新手来说相对容易上手，而且由于游戏提供了出色的网络游戏功能，玩家可以放心，他们提出的几乎任何问题都不会长时间得不到解答。Origin的MMORPG《网络创世纪》在其虚拟世界中拥有数十万玩家。在游戏开发社区中，说由于对这些游戏的“研究”而导致数周的工作付诸东流并不为过。

Early entries in the RPG field also courted people from the single-player world. Blizzard’s Diablo, an action RPG, let whole parties of individuals venture down into a dungeon in search of monsters and loot. Unlike the traditional “hard-core” RPGs of the time, Diablo was relatively easy for newcomers to pick up, and since the game offered excellent network play, players could be assured that virtually any question they had would not go unanswered for long. Ultima Online, an MMORPG from Origin, hosted hundreds of thousands players within its virtual walls. Within the game-development community, it is not at all inaccurate to say that weeks of work were lost due to the “research” invested in these games.

如果多人游戏在 20 世纪 90 年代如此流行，那么今天讨论它还有什么意义呢？

If multiplayer hit like mad in the 1990s, what’s the point of discussing it today?

期待

LOOKING FORWARD

尽管非数字游戏、个人电脑和游戏机已经支持多人游戏很长一段时间了，但该行业仍有许多机会有待探索。

Although non-digital games, PCs, and consoles have facilitated multiplayer for quite some time, the industry has many more opportunities left to explore.

独处

BEING ALONE TOGETHER

例如，在 MMO 游戏中，虽然我们可以互相交谈并一起执行各种任务，但玩家作为个人或小团体在一个更大的世界中实际上是孤独的。游戏的“实例”迫使个人或个人团体一个接一个地排队完成同一组任务。当然，你可以选择执行任务 C 而不是任务 B，但总而言之，有时我们会觉得我们并没有真正体验到同一个世界，也没有同时听到所有相同的事情，尤其是当我们排队等待与前面的五个玩家相同的 NPC 对话时。甚至生物数量也是动态的，因此玩家 A 和玩家 B 总是有足够的生物可以遭遇。我们可能认为我们都在一起遇到这个世界，但很多时候，我们被一个实例化的故事分开，这个故事让我们在轨道上，旁边是另一个也在轨道上的人。除了聊天系统之外，我们本质上是孤独的。然而，尽管如此，这些游戏中的社交场景非常真实和庞大。

In MMOs, for instance, while we can talk with one another and perform various missions with each other, players are really alone as individuals or as small groups within a much larger world. The game’s “instances” force individuals or groups of individuals to queue through the same set of missions one after the other. Sure, you can opt to do mission C instead of mission B, but all in all, there is sometimes a sense that we are not truly experiencing the same world and hearing all the same things at the same time, particularly when we’re waiting in line to address the same NPC as the five players ahead of us. Even creature population is done dynamically, so that there is always enough to encounter for player A and player B. We might think we’re all encountering the world together, but very often, we are separated by an instanced narrative that has us on rails right next to another person also on rails. Apart from a chat system, we are, in essence, alone together. That said, however, the social landscape in these games is very much real and massive.

“副本”是多人游戏出现一段时间后开发出来的一项创新。这些副本专门解决了数千名玩家同时出现在同一个区域的问题。有些玩家将这些副本视为问题，这确实很讽刺，因为副本最初是为了解决一个较早的问题而开发的。

“Instances” were an innovation developed after multiplayer games had been around for a while. These instances specifically addressed the problem of having thousands of players in the same area simultaneously. That some players are presenting these instances as a problem is indeed ironic since instances were originally developed as a solution to an earlier problem.

尽管如此，这种“独自一人”的问题还是让一些人质疑 MMO 设计是否还有更多可取之处。显然，从玩家数量来看，设计并不失败，但仍然有人怀疑是否还有更多可取之处。

Nonetheless, this issue of “alone together” has led some to question whether there isn’t something more to be had from MMO design. Clearly, judging from player numbers, the design isn’t a failure, but still, some wonder if there is something more.

多人游戏、多平台

MULTIPLAYER, MULTIPLATFORM

尽管游戏行业已经坚定地接受了多人游戏，但多平台游戏则完全是另一回事。设想一个虚拟世界，它同时欢迎所有人，无论他们使用什么设备，并根据设备的能力和最佳带宽输出定制显示和选项。这个概念在各种互联网服务中都很流行，但在游戏世界中却不那么受欢迎，因为游戏世界中的大部分内容都是视觉化的，而且价格昂贵，因此在中等到中等的传播效果并不如人们所希望的那样好。

Though the game industry has firmly embraced multiplayer play, multiplatform play is another beast entirely. Consider a virtual world that welcomes everyone simultaneously, no matter their device, and customizes the display and options to the device’s abilities and optimum bandwidth output. The concept is prevalent for all kinds of Internet services, but not so well adopted in the game world where much of the content is visual and high priced, and therefore doesn’t move medium to medium as well as one would like.

目前，大多数游戏都局限于其平台。在手机上玩扑克的玩家无法与坐在他对面使用 PDA 的人一起玩。人们可能会说“好吧，这不是开玩笑”，但更有远见的说法是“好吧，为什么不呢？”在这方面，数字游戏已经比非数字兄弟姐妹退后了一步。棋盘游戏可以在任何桌子上、任何地方玩。

At present, most games are constrained to their platform. A player playing Poker on his cell phone cannot play that game with the person sitting directly across from him using his PDA. It may be tempting to say, “Well, no kidding,” but it’s more forward-looking to say, “Well, why not?” In this regard, digital games have taken a step back from their non-digital brothers and sisters. A board game is ready to go on any table, anywhere.

多人游戏、多用途

MULTIPLAYER, MULTIPURPOSE

目前，大多数具有多人或大型多人游戏特色的游戏都是娱乐游戏。然而，就像在团队中玩游戏更令人满足一样，工作也是如此。多人游戏现在正在使用和创建，让许多人处于培训或教育的情境中。例如，第二人生是最早和最成功的 MMO 世界之一，被希望与学生一起探索虚拟空间的学者使用。考虑一下如果虚拟世界得到充分利用，各种学科之间合作的可能性。

At present, most games that feature multiplayer or massively multiplayer play are entertainment games. However, just as play is more fulfilling in a group, so too is work. Multiplayer games are now in use and are being created which put many people in situations for training or education. Second Life, for instance, was one of the earliest and most successful MMO worlds to be used by academics looking to explore the virtual space with their students. Consider the possibilities for collaboration in all kinds of disciplines if virtual worlds were used to their fullest extent.

社交网络

SOCIAL NETWORKING

本书的其他地方有一整章关于社交网络的内容（第 21 章“社交网络和游戏”）。然而，社交网络显然也在这里占有一席之地。Facebook 及其蓬勃发展的游戏社区目前主要是多人游戏社区，但正是由于人们的社交网络规模较小，这些网络才无法达到“大型”多人游戏的里程碑。在未来几年，这些网络最终将被用于社交网络之外的游戏，但这些游戏会广泛利用社交网络进行玩家社交、招募和游戏。

Elsewhere in this book, there is a full chapter on social networking (Chapter 21, “Social Networks and Games”). However, it clearly has a place here, too. Facebook and its ever burgeoning game community is mostly a multiplayer community at present, but it is only the smaller scale of people’s social networks that keeps these networks from hitting the “massively” multiplayer milestone. In the years to come, these networks will eventually be harnessed for games housed outside of the social network but that draw upon it extensively for player socialization, recruitment, and play.

多人游戏的类型

TYPES OF MULTIPLAYER GAMES

当营销部门在 20 世纪 90 年代要求开发多人游戏时，他们的意思很笼统——让人们和朋友一起玩。他们并不特别关心如何实现这一点，只要在某种程度上实现就行。从那时起，技术和设计不断进步（或者在某些情况下，重新利用了旧的游戏风格），导致我们以一种或多种方式定义多人游戏。

When marketing departments asked for multiplayer games in the 1990s, they meant it in a general sense—let people play with their friends. They didn’t particularly care how this happened, provided that it happened on some level. Since that time, technology and design have advanced (or, in some cases, repurposed old play styles), leading us to define multiplayer games in one or more ways.

基于数量的区别

QUANTITY-BASED DISTINCTIONS

多人游戏通常根据游戏支持的玩家数量进行分类。例如，多人游戏支持 2 到 700 名玩家。当我们开始谈论数千和数百万玩家时，我们称这些游戏为大型多人游戏。

Multiplayer games are regularly separated depending on the number of players the game supports. For instance, multiplayer games support anywhere from two to hundreds of players. When we start speaking of thousands and millions of players, we call these games massively multiplayer games.

游戏设计必须根据同时有多少玩家在互动而采取不同的方法。例如，双人游戏不必考虑更多玩家时产生的交易和谈判等社交动态。一旦游戏超过 4 到 8 名玩家，就很少看到每个人都只顾自己的自由游戏；随着玩家人数的增加，将他们分组到团队中就变得更加常见，这就使游戏设计师需要考虑一系列团队动态。面对成千上万的玩家，设计师必须回答诸如“如何让单个玩家感觉自己与众不同”这样的问题，更不用说诸如“我们如何同时支持这么多人，而不会让游戏服务器因带宽不足而崩溃”这样的技术问题了。

The design of a game must be approached differently depending on how many players are interacting with one another at a given time. A two-player game, for example, does not have to consider social dynamics such as trading and negotiation that come into play with more players. Once a game exceeds four to eight players, it becomes rarer to see free-for-all gameplay where everyone is out for himself; with larger numbers of players, it is more common to have them grouped into teams, which brings a host of team dynamics into the considerations of the game designer. With thousands or millions of players, the designer must answer questions like “How can a single player feel like he makes a difference,” not to mention technical questions like “How can we support this many people simultaneously without the game server dying for lack of bandwidth?”

基于游戏的区别

PLAY-BASED DISTINCTIONS

多人游戏有四种玩法：

Multiplayer games feature four types of play:

·      即时的

·      Real time

·      回合制

·      Turn based

·      竞争的

·      Competitive

·      合作

·      Cooperative

通常，游戏是这些的混合。

Usually, games are a mix of these.

合作游戏（也称为玩家对战环境，简称 PvE）允许玩家一起玩游戏以解决特定目标。竞争性游戏（玩家对战玩家，简称 PvP）让玩家或团队相互对抗，以追求目标。大多数大型多人游戏都提供这两种模式，让玩家选择自己喜欢的风格。

Co-op games (also called player versus environment, or PvE) allow players to play together to solve a particular goal. Competitive games (player versus player, or PvP) pit player against player or group against group in pursuit of a goal. Most massively multiplayer games offer both, and let players choose the style they like.

基于时间的区别

TIME-BASED DISTINCTIONS

实时游戏允许玩家同时移动。它们可能是同步的，迫使玩家一起玩才能进行游戏，也可能是异步的，允许玩家随时玩，无论是一起还是单独玩。回合制游戏迫使玩家在移动或执行其他操作时轮流。有些游戏是实时和回合制游戏风格的混合。例如，有些游戏具有实时冒险和回合制战斗。一个常见的非数字示例是纸牌游戏Slap Jack。游戏是回合制的，直到翻转杰克。然后它变成实时模糊，因为玩家热切地试图先拍打该杰克。

Real-time games allow players to move simultaneously. They may be synchronous and force players to play together in order for a game to happen, or asynchronous and allow players to play whenever they want, whether together or alone. Turn-based games force players to take turns when moving or performing other actions. Some games are a mix of real-time and turn-based play styles. For example, some games feature real-time adventuring and turn based combat. A common non-digital example is the card game Slap Jack. The game is turn-based until a jack is flipped. Then it becomes a real-time blur as players fervently attempt to slap said jack first.

回合制游戏让玩家有时间考虑自己的行动——如果愿意的话，可以考虑好几天。有些游戏使用计时器来限制回合数（国际象棋通常就是这么做的），但许多游戏只是采用“有时间就行动”的模式。随着社交网络上的游戏不断扩大，这些回合制、社交网络、多人游戏很可能代表休闲游戏新模式的第一波浪潮。

Turn-based games allow players time to consider their moves—for days if desired. Some games use timers to limit turns (Chess commonly does this), but many games just go on the “show up when you can” model. As play across social networks continues to broaden, these turn-based, social net, multiplayer games are likely to represent the first wave of a new paradigm in casual games.

如今，回合制游戏主要在 PC 上流行，但有迹象表明这种情况可能正在改变。优秀的回合制策略游戏正在游戏机上出现，随着游戏机进军休闲游戏市场，这种游戏玩法肯定会重新流行起来。

Nowadays, turn-based games are largely the domain of PCs, but there are signs this may be changing. Good turn-based strategy games are appearing on consoles, and as consoles make inroads into the casual game market, this type of game play is sure to reassert itself.

基于技术的区别

TECHNOLOGY-BASED DISTINCTIONS

在多人游戏的发展过程中，它们被赋予了许多含义。其中包括：

Throughout the course of multiplayer games, they have been referred to as many things. Among them are the following:

·       MUD：多用户地下城，多人基于文本的世界

·      MUDs: Multiuser dungeons, multiplayer text-based worlds

·       MOBA：多人在线战斗竞技场

·      MOBAs: Multiplayer online battle arena

·       MMO：大型多人在线游戏

·      MMO: Massively multiplayer online games

·       LAN game：局域网络游戏

·      LAN game: Local area network games

·       BBS 门户：客户端托管的公告板系统 (BBS) 游戏 IP 特定：Valve、Steam 或 Xbox Live 等服务

·      BBS door: Bulletin board system (BBS) game hosted client-side IP-specific: Services like Valve’s, Steam, or Xbox Live

多人游戏设计中的问题

ISSUES IN MULTIPLAYER GAME DESIGN

除了多人游戏带来的许多技术挑战之外，多人游戏的设计还为开发团队带来了他们在传统单人游戏中不会遇到的独特问题。请记住，这只是一个简短的概述。关于这个主题已经并将继续写出整本书。

Apart from the many technical challenges imposed by a multiplayer game, the design of a multiplayer game presents development teams with unique issues they wouldn’t face in a traditional single-player game. Bear in mind that this is but a brief overview. Whole books have and will continue to be written on this subject.

动态可扩展性

DYNAMIC SCALABILITY

当多人游戏没有固定的玩家数量时，它们必须支持动态可扩展性。玩家可以随意进出，但游戏本身应该保持可玩性。考虑一下典型 MUD 的一天。假设 MUD 刚刚开始，目前有两个人在线，他们都为相关公司工作。随着新闻稿在媒体上发布，玩家从几十人开始，然后是几百人。在此之前，设计师需要找到某种方法让世界对其中的玩家数量做出反应。因此，通常情况下，生物是根据区域中的人数生成的。例如，如果有 300 名玩家，游戏可能会在任何给定时间在该区域中播种 600 个生物，这样它就会感觉很有竞争力，而不会感觉太容易或像是一场正在进行的屠杀。通常，大型多人游戏会扩展物品、金币和

When multiplayer games don’t have a fixed number of players, they must support dynamic scalability. Players may come and go as they please, but the game itself should remain playable. Consider a day in the life of a typical MUD. Let’s say the MUD just started, and there are presently two people online, both of whom work with the company in question. As the press releases run in the media, players show up by the tens and then by the hundreds. In advance of this, the designers need to find some way to have the world react to the number of players in it. So, usually, creatures are spawned in accordance with the number of people in a zone. For instance, if there are 300 players, the game may seed the zone with 600 creatures at any given time so that it feels properly competitive without it feeling too easy or like a slaughter in the works. Typically, massively multiplayer games scale items, gold, and the

根据在场玩家的数量，特定区域中的生物数量。对于其他类型的多人游戏，如 FPS 或传统纸牌和棋盘游戏的在线版本，设计师必须回答一系列不同的问题。如果玩家提前退出会发生什么？AI 机器人是否应该接替离开的玩家，或者游戏是否可以无缝继续进行而不会中断，还是整个游戏都会被毁掉？新玩家可以加入正在进行的游戏吗，还是必须等到当前比赛结束？一场比赛中同时参与的玩家数量是否有限制（最大或最小）？玩家是否应该能够对彼此的声誉进行排名，以此来创造期望的最佳体验？

number of creatures in a particular area based on the number of players present. For other kinds of multiplayer games such as FPSs or online versions of traditional card and board games, the designer must answer a different set of questions. What happens if a player drops out early—should an AI bot take over for the player who left, or can the game continue on seamlessly without interruption, or is the entire game ruined? Can a new player join a game already in progress, or must he wait until the current match is finished? Is there a limit to how many players can play in a single match at once (maximum or minimum)? Should players be able to rank each other’s reputation as a means of creating a hoped-for optimal experience?

悲伤

GRIEFING

为了获得乐趣而攻击或以其他方式对其他玩家造成负面影响的过程被称为“恶意破坏”。自游戏诞生之初，游戏内外的人们就一直在互相恶意破坏，无论是通过跨桌说垃圾话、在线口水战还是杀人。在 MMO 游戏的早期，杀人行为非常流行，因此恶意破坏者通常被称为“PKers”，即“玩家杀手”。虽然恶意破坏对于煽动者来说可能很有趣，但对于不幸成为恶意破坏者目标的玩家来说，这很少令人愉快。事实上，破坏其他人的乐趣才是恶意破坏者的乐趣所在。

The process of attacking or otherwise negatively affecting other players for enjoyment is known as “griefing.” Since the earliest days of gaming, people inside and outside of games have been griefing one another, whether by trash talking across tables, online flame wars, or player killing. So popular was player killing in the early days of MMOs that the griefers were regularly referred to as “PKers,” as in “player killers.” While griefing may be fun for the instigator, it is rarely enjoyable for the unfortunate players who are the targets of the griefer. It is, in fact, the ruination of other people’s fun that is fun for the griefer.

为了打击不必要的恶意破坏，游戏采用了多种技术，包括玩家对战 (PvP) 服务器、报告和记录功能、以及阻止针对单个玩家和玩家之间的通信和联系的功能。

To combat unwanted griefing, games employ several techniques, including player-versus-player (PvP) servers, reporting and recording abilities, and the ability to block communication and contact on a player-by-player and player-to-player basis.

尽管现代游戏玩家往往认为“PK”是 MMO 的专属，但许多人因玩扑克、橄榄球、板球、足球等游戏而丧命。这些 PK 的历史可以追溯到几百年前。

Although modern-day gamers tend to think of “PKing” as something reserved for MMOs, many a person has lost his life over a game of Poker, Rugby, Cricket, Soccer, and many more games. These PKers date back hundreds of years.

社区建设与支持

COMMUNITY FORMATION AND SUPPORT

虽然所有游戏（或至少所有优秀游戏）都有粉丝社区，但多人游戏，尤其是大型多人游戏，粉丝社区是其中最重要的组成部分。在这里，社区经理要确保论坛和社区内各种交流方式正常运转，并确保信息从开发者到公会再到个人玩家自由流动。

While all games (or at least all good games) have a fan community, nowhere is it more integral than in multiplayer games, and particularly in massively multiplayer games. Here, community managers make sure that the forums and various means of networking within the community are up and running and that information is flowing freely from the developers to the guild to the individual player.

设计师应该考虑如何支持社区，以及游戏中是否有任何方法可以让玩家联系更有意义。这包括支持玩家创建的团体（通常称为“公会”或“部落”），玩家可以保存在线好友列表，以及在游戏中对玩家社区领导者的特别认可。

Designers should consider how the community can be supported, and if there are any means within the game to make player contact meaningful. This includes support for player-created groups (often called “guilds” or “clans”), the ability of players to keep lists of friends online, and special recognition within the game for player community leaders.

吸引旧人还是新人？

ATTRACT THE OLD OR THE NEW?

在线游戏，尤其是大型多人在线游戏，必须考虑几种类型的玩家。首先，有些玩家以前从未玩过 MMO，所以一切对他们来说都是新的。然后，有些玩家熟悉 MMO，但对这款游戏却并不熟悉。这些玩家经常和朋友一起从一个游戏转移到另一个游戏。有时，整个公会都会从一个游戏转移到另一个游戏。最后，有些玩家已经玩了一段时间的游戏（可能从一开始就玩）。关于多人游戏的设计，一些机制使游戏对新玩家更友好，但对有经验的玩家吸引力较小（例如等级上限，即限制角色的强大程度），反之亦然（例如 PvP 环境，更适合有经验的玩家）。

There are several kinds of players who must be considered with online games, especially massively multiplayer games. First, there are players who have never played an MMO before, so everything is new to them. Then there are players who are familiar with MMOs but are new to this game in particular. These players often move in migratory herds with their friends from one game to another. Sometimes, entire guilds transition from game to game. Lastly, there are players who have played the game for a while (perhaps since the beginning). With respect to the design of multiplayer games, some mechanics make a game more friendly for new players but less compelling to experienced ones (like level caps, where there is a limit to how powerful a character can become), or vice versa (like PvP environments, which favor the more experienced players).

界面问题

INTERFACE ISSUES

在棋盘游戏中，多人界面的问题最为明显。设计师现在平均每方负责一名玩家，而不是每个玩家一个屏幕。究竟如何让 20 个人围坐在一块棋盘上？1000 个人呢？然而，拥有数千甚至数十万玩家的非数字游戏确实存在。例如 ARG（另类现实游戏）和大型城市游戏。这些游戏将玩家从电脑中解放出来，带入现实世界。

In board games, nowhere is the issue of multiplayer interface more clear. Rather than one screen per player, the designer is now tasked with one player per side, on average. Exactly how would one put 20 people around a single board? What about 1,000? However, non-digital games with thousands and even hundreds of thousands of players do exist. Examples include ARGs (alternate reality games) and big urban games. These games take players away from their computers and into the real world.

挑战

CHALLENGES

与任何类型的游戏一样，获得多人游戏开发经验的唯一方法就是实际开发。这些挑战将让您了解设计师在考虑多人游戏时遇到的一些问题。

Like any type of game, the only way to get experience working on multiplayer games is to actually work on them. These challenges will give you an idea of some of the issues that designers grapple with when they consider multiplayer games.

挑战 1——旧游戏，新生活

CHALLENGE 1—OLD GAMES, NEW LIFE

当多人 RPG 和 MMO 游戏兴起时，许多经典 RPG 系列的制作者未能转型。单人游戏的基本战斗方式与 MMO 相同，但在一个任何人都可以随时进入的世界里，单人游戏中的庞大故事情节很难实现。你会运行 900 万个相同的大型故事实例，其中独特的物品、联盟和信息很重要吗？理论上是的。实际上呢？并非如此。在 MMO 游戏中，这并不是人们玩的真正原因。结果，许多旧系列游戏完全停止发行。

When multiplayer RPGs and MMOs took off, many makers of classic RPG series failed to make the transition. The single-player games featured the same basic combat as the MMOs, but their vast narratives found in these single player games would be challenging to pull off in a world where anyone can come in at any time. Do you run nine million instances of the same massive story where unique possession of items, alliances, and information matters? Theoretically, yes. In practice? Not so much. In MMOs, it’s not really why people are there. As a result, a lot of these old series stopped publishing altogether.

为了完成这个挑战，我们假设一位开发商的经纪人联系了你。她希望你看看这些老游戏，看看你是否能想象出其中一款是现代的 MMO。她告诉你，在它们的鼎盛时期，每款游戏的受众都超过一百万。你可以从以下老派 RPG 或它们的同代游戏中选择：

For the sake of this challenge, let’s say that a developer’s agent approached you. She wants you to take a look at these old games and see if you can envision one as a modern day MMO. In their heyday, she tells you, each had an audience of over a million. You may select from the following old-school RPGs or their contemporaries:

·      巫术

·      Wizardry

·      魔法门

·      Might and Magic

·      吟游诗人的故事

·      Bard’s Tale

·      高级龙与地下城：旁观者之眼

·      Advanced Dungeons & Dragons: Eye of the Beholder

经纪人指出，她不希望你仅仅用新的故事情节重新打造一款现有的 ​​MMO。相反，原系列的玩家需要认识到，这是他们老牌 RPG 游戏的全新多人游戏化身。

The agent notes that she doesn’t want you to merely recreate an existing MMO with a new narrative. Rather, the players of the original series need to recognize it as the new, multiplayer incarnation of their old RPG home.

所需组件

Components Required

·      互联网用于研究

·      Internet for research

可交付成果

Deliverable

·      一系列功能，体现了旧系列的特点，以及玩家对其 IP 在 MMO 中的应用期望

·      A list of features that captures the old series and what players would expect from its IP as applied to an MMO

·      一款新 MMO 的概念文档

·      Concept doc for a new MMO

·      可选：数字 MMO 中的游戏原型，让玩家能够创建自己的内容

·      Optional: Prototype of play in a digital MMO that gives players the ability to create their own content

建议流程

Suggested Process

1.    研究原版游戏。哪些机制让你选择的游戏与当时其他单人 RPG 游戏脱颖而出？游戏在哪些方面进行了创新？为了进行这些比较，你可能需要研究其他 RPG 游戏，而不仅仅是你选择的游戏。

1.    Research the original game. What mechanics made your chosen game stand out as being different from other single-player RPGs of its time? Where did the game innovate within the genre? You may want to research other RPGs and not just your chosen one, in order to draw these comparisons.

2.    研究类似的转变。看看其他转型为 MMO 的老派 RPG，比如Ultima 系列转型为Ultima Online。开发人员在转型过程中做了哪些设计变更？根据您自己的经验或阅读专业评论，新设计的哪些方面效果良好，哪些方面效果不佳？

2.    Research similar transitions. Look at other old-school RPGs that made the transition to MMO, such as the Ultima series becoming Ultima Online. What design changes did the developers make in the transition? Based on your own experience or from reading professional reviews, what aspects of the new design worked well, and what did not?

3.    将研究应用到您的游戏中。根据您对所选游戏核心的描述以及创建旧版 RPG 的 MMO 版本时要做的事情（和不要做的事情）的列表，为您的新游戏列出初步的功能列表。

3.    Apply your research to your game. From your description of the core of your chosen game and your list of what to do (and what not to do) when creating an MMO version of an older RPG, make a preliminary list of features for your new game.

4.    创建可交付成果。

4.    Create deliverable.

变体

Variant

以任何目前不支持多人游戏的休闲游戏（如《俄罗斯方块》、《宝石迷阵》或《Diner Dash》）为例，让其可供多人玩。增加多人游戏必须改变游戏玩法的某些方面，不能只是一个玩家玩一半的回合。考虑添加 PvP 模式。

Take any casual game that is not presently multiplayer (such as Tetris, Bejeweled, or Diner Dash) and make it playable by more than one player. The addition of multiplayer must change some facet of the game’s play, and can’t merely be one player taking half of the turns. Consider adding a PvP mode.

挑战 2 — “但要让它变成多人游戏！”

CHALLENGE 2 — “BUT MAKE IT MULTIPLAYER!”

冒险游戏曾经给很多人带来了无穷乐趣……直到这些人开始想和其他人一起玩。让事情变得更加复杂的是，冒险游戏的可玩性并不高。除非游戏提供了完全不同的故事路径，有多个结局甚至多个开头，否则其可玩性很低。

Adventure games were once a whole lot of fun for a whole lot of people... until those people wanted to start playing with other people, that is. Complicating this matter, adventure games aren’t terribly replayable. Unless the game offers substantially different paths through the story with multiple endings and even multiple beginnings, its replayability is low.

然而，最近，贵公司的营销部门开始重新审视这些游戏。手机和新型掌上电脑等众多新平台使得这些游戏的风险低于其他类型的游戏。此外，老游戏的授权费用相对便宜。

Lately, however, your company’s marketing department has been taking another look at these games. A multitude of new platforms like cell phones and the newer handhelds make these games a potentially lower risk than other types of games. And besides, the licenses to older games are cheap, comparatively speaking.

对于这个挑战，你的市场部门希望你选择任何一款老款的冒险游戏，比如King's Quest或Monkey Island系列、Day of the Tentacle或Grim Fandango。程序员可以负责将老款游戏移植到手机和掌上电脑上。你的工作是让游戏支持多人游戏。

For this challenge, your marketing department wants you to take any older adventure game, such as any of the King’s Quest or Monkey Island series, Day of the Tentacle, or Grim Fandango. The programmers can worry about porting the older game to cell phones and handhelds. Your job is to make the game multiplayer.

所需组件

Components Required

·      互联网用于研究

·      Internet for research

·      成功的冒险游戏，例如《The Shivah》、《Psychonauts》、《Indigo Prophecy》等。

·      Successful adventure titles such as The Shivah, Psychonauts, Indigo Prophecy, or others.

可交付成果

Deliverable

·      您计划修改的旧游戏的名称

·      Name of the old game that you plan to modify

·      多人游戏玩法描述

·      Description of multiplayer gameplay

建议流程

Suggested Process

1.    研究现有的冒险游戏。定义这一类型的常见机制是什么？你玩过的游戏之间有哪些相似之处和不同之处？你（或其他人）觉得冒险游戏的哪些部分有趣或有趣？显然，你也需要研究你选择的游戏。

1.    Research existing adventure games. What are the common mechanics that define this genre? What similarities and differences are there between the games you’ve played? What parts of adventure games do you (or other people) find fun or entertaining? Obviously, you’ll want to research the game you’ve chosen particular as well.

2.    转换为多人游戏。 如何将几乎完全是单人游戏的游戏类型转变为多人游戏体验？考虑一下您计划采用的方法。是同时多人游戏吗？异步、同步还是回合制？如果您在想办法时遇到困难，请研究已经完成这种转变的其他游戏类型。例如，MUD（以及 MMO）是单人文字冒险游戏的衍生品。FPS 源自较旧的射击和动作游戏（可以追溯到《小行星》和《太空侵略者》），这些游戏主要是单人游戏体验。

2.    Convert to multiplayer. How do you take a genre that’s almost exclusively single player and turn it into a multiplayer experience? Think of the means in which you plan to do this. Is it simultaneous multiplayer? Asynchronous, synchronous, or even turn based? If you’re having trouble thinking of ideas, research other genres that have already made this transition. For example, MUDs (and by extension, MMOs) are derivative of single-player text adventure games. FPSs are derived from older shooting and action games (going back all the way to Asteroids and Space Invaders), which were primarily one-player experiences.

3.    创建可交付成果。

3.    Create deliverable.

变体

Variant

为了增加难度，可以使用记事卡或纸笔模块格式创建冒险游戏的可玩版本。

For added difficulty, create a playable version of your adventure game using note cards or a pencil-and-paper module format.

挑战 3——迁徙的畜群

CHALLENGE 3—MIGRATORY HERDS

这可能是目前最热门的游戏，但再过一两年，本月的 MMO 游戏可能就会失宠。虽然从今天的角度来看这似乎不太可能，但想想看，没有人能想到会有游戏能超越《Asheron's Call》或《Everquest》，当然，这两款游戏都不再是 MMO 世界的佼佼者。

It might be the biggest thing going right now, but in another year or two, the MMO of the month will likely be out of favor. While it may seem unlikely from today’s perspective, consider that no one imagined anything would come along to top Asheron’s Call or Everquest and, of course, both are no longer top of the MMO world.

作为一款新 MMO 游戏的设计师，你的工作就是“占领社区”。你的项目制作人希望你研究现有的 MMO 市场，并弄清楚你需要做些什么才能在即将推出的游戏中占领这个市场。考虑一下哪些功能可以让他们的过渡尽可能简单。他们如何让他们现在的“家”成为家？以前的公司是如何做到的？为什么他们应该选择你和你的游戏而不是别人的游戏？

As a designer on a new MMO, it’s your job to take on a job called “community capture.” The producer of your project wants you to study an existing MMO market and figure out what you need to do to capture it in your upcoming game. Consider features that would make their transition as easy as possible. How do they make their current “home” a home? How have previous companies done it? Why should they come to you and your game versus someone else’s?

所需组件

Components Required

·      互联网（仅供参考）和相关游戏

·      Internet (for reference) and the games in question

·      最好具有 MMO 游戏经验

·      Previous experience playing an MMO is desirable

可交付成果

Deliverable

·      分析某款游戏及其最大的公会

·      Analysis of a particular game and its largest guild

·      对于“社区捕获”至关重要且有用的功能列表

·      List of features that would be critical and useful for a “community capture”

建议流程

Suggested Process

1.    确定 MMO 及其最受欢迎的公会。您可以选择任何您想要的 MMO。一旦您选择了一个，在游戏中找到一个受欢迎的玩家群体就只是研究的问题了。如果您不熟悉该游戏并且对此一无所知，请尝试查找和浏览公共留言板或粉丝网站（通常这些都链接到游戏或开发者的主网站）。

1.    Identify an MMO and its most popular guild. You may choose any MMO you wish. Once you choose one, finding a popular player group within the game is simply a matter of research. If you are unfamiliar with the game and don’t know this off the top of your head, try finding and browsing public message boards or fan Web sites (often these are linked to from the game’s or developer’s main Web site).

2.    研究公会的现有功能。大多数受欢迎的公会都有自己的玩家创建的网站。环顾四周，尝试发现是什么让这个特定的公会在游戏中如此受欢迎。如果您在游戏中有玩家帐户，请登录并采访其他玩家。

2.    Study existing features of the guild. Most popular guilds have their own player-created Web site. Look around and try to discover what makes this one particular guild so popular within the game. If you have a player account in the game, log in and interview other players about it.

3.    研究其他公司捕捉流动人口的过程。

3.    Research the process where by other companies capture migrating populations.

4.    列出功能列表。这款游戏有哪些功能是其最有经验的玩家（尤其是在指定公会内）真正喜欢的？这款游戏的哪些方面与其他 MMO 游戏不同？您是否在玩家留言板上看到任何关于烦人的游戏玩法或开发人员尚未解决的所需功能的持续投诉？使用这些信息以及您所有其他的研究，列出对这一特定玩家群体特别有吸引力的功能列表。

4.    Develop a list of features. What features does the game have that its most experienced players (especially within the identified guild) really like? What aspects of the game make it different from other MMOs? Do you see any persistent complaints on player message boards of annoying gameplay or desired features that the developer has not yet addressed? Use this information, along with all of your other research, to develop a list of features that would be particularly compelling to this specific player group.

5.    创建可交付成果。

5.    Create deliverable.

挑战 4 — 隐身教育 MMO

CHALLENGE 4—STEALTH EDUCATIONAL MMO

您被您所在国家最大的教育机构之一聘用，并被要求创建一款“隐身学习” MMO。（即玩家在学习教育材料时却没有意识到自己正在学习的游戏。）这个项目可以适用于任何级别的历史，只要项目是现实的并且适合学龄儿童。管理员提醒您，现在可能不是开发战争游戏的合适时机，但其他类型的虚拟世界肯定是可行的。MMO 需要教授以下内容：

You’ve been brought in by one of the largest educational outfits in your country and have been asked to create a “stealth learning” MMO. (That is, a game where the players are learning educational material without realizing that they are learning.) This project can be for any level of history, provided the project is realistic and suitable for school-aged children. The administrator cautions you that this might not be the right time for a game on a war, but certainly all other kinds of virtual worlds are possible. The MMO needs to teach the following:

·      气候与地理

·      The physical climate and geography

·      社会环境

·      The social environment

·      社会政治环境

·      The socio-political environment

·      经济环境

·      The economic environment

在教授这些概念时，游戏不应该说教或讲得太过分。请记住，这应该是一个游戏，学生应该在玩乐的同时学习，而不是被灌输这些主题。

While teaching these concepts, the game should not be preachy or layer it on too thick. Remember, this is supposed to be a game, and students are supposed to learn while having fun, not by being banged over the head with the topic.

管理员需要看到您提供的基本设计，然后她才能转而向全国推广。

The administrator needs to see a basic design from you that she can then turn around and pitch on the national level.

所需组件

Components Required

·      互联网用于研究

·      Internet for research

可交付成果

Deliverable

·      概念文档，包括前面列出的项目以及游戏功能列表

·      Concept doc that includes the items listed previously, as well as a list of gameplay features

建议流程

Suggested Process

1.    选择要涵盖的主题。考虑历史课中涵盖的时间段和地点列表。（如果您没有世界历史书，可以去当地公共图书馆查阅，然后翻阅目录。）在这些潜在主题中，哪些主题最能吸引人们做出许多有趣的决定 — 也就是说，哪些历史主题可以带来良好的游戏体验？

1.    Choose a topic to cover. Consider a list of time periods and locations that are covered in a history class. (You may want to look at a world history book, available at the local public library if you do not own one, and flip through the table of contents.) Of these potential topics, which ones stand out as having many interesting decisions for individuals to make—that is, which historical topics suggest good gameplay?

2.    研究该主题。如果你不熟悉所选主题，请至少了解你想要教授的年级所要求的知识。

2.    Research that topic. If you are unfamiliar with your chosen topic, learn about it, at least as much as would be required at the grade level where you want to teach it.

3.    创建可交付成果。

3.    Create deliverable.

铁艺设计师挑战赛 5— SOCIALTAIRE

IRON DESIGNER CHALLENGE 5—SOCIALTAIRE

为了秉承本章的精神，如果您有足够的人分成多个团队，这个挑战将发挥最佳效果。

In keeping with the spirit of this chapter, this challenge works best if you have enough people to divide into teams.

每支队伍选择一款使用标准扑克牌的单人纸牌 游戏。这类游戏有数百种；大多数人称之为“单人纸牌”的游戏更适合称为克朗代克。你可以在网上或霍伊尔游戏书等书籍中找到规则 。将每款游戏随机分配给不同的队伍。（如果你是单独完成这项挑战，请随机选择一款游戏。）

Each team chooses a Solitaire game that uses a standard deck of playing cards. There are hundreds of such games; the one that most people call “Solitaire” is more properly referred to as Klondike. You can find rules online, or in a book such as Hoyle’s Book of Games. Randomly assign each game to a different team. (If you are doing this challenge alone, choose a game randomly.)

接受分配给您的游戏并修改规则，使其成为具有竞争性的双人或多人游戏。

Take the game you are assigned and modify the rules so that it is a competitive twoplayer or multiplayer game.

所需组件

Components Required

·      每队一副扑克牌

·      One deck of playing cards per team

可交付成果

Deliverable

·      为你的游戏制定完整的书面规则

·      Complete set of written rules for your game

建议流程

Suggested Process

1.    了解规则。 如果您不熟悉Solitaire游戏，请阅读规则并玩几次，以熟悉游戏的机制和动态。尝试了解游戏的哪些方面需要保留，以及哪些方面可以安全地修改或删除，而不会破坏游戏的核心。

1.    Learn the rules. If you are unfamiliar with your Solitaire game, read the rules and play it a few times to familiarize yourself with the mechanics and dynamics of the game. Try to get a feel for which aspects of the game need to be preserved and what can be safely modified or removed without destroying the core of the game.

2.    确定潜在的冲突源。在单人游戏中，唯一的挑战或冲突是玩家与游戏本身之间的冲突。这种游戏的哪些方面可以从牌组或规则本身转移到另一个玩家身上？有两种方法可以解决这个问题，我们鼓励您探索这两种方法。您可以让玩家对称：保留大部分规则，这样两个玩家不仅可以相互竞争，还可以与游戏系统竞争。或者，您可以让玩家不对称，其中一个玩家部分或完全取代游戏规则（例如堆叠或重新排序牌组），而另一个玩家遵循游戏的正常规则。要知道大多数单人纸牌游戏都很难赢，所以您可能需要重新定义游戏的目标以使其公平，特别是如果您创建了一个不对称的游戏。

2.    Identify potential sources of conflict. In a single-player game, the only challenge or conflict is between the player and the game itself. Which aspects of this play could be transferred from the deck of cards or the rules themselves to another player? There are two ways to approach this, and you are encouraged to explore both. You could make the players symmetric: preserve most of the rules, so that both players are competing with each other but also with the game’s systems. Or you could have the players be asymmetric, where one player partially or completely replaces the game rules (by perhaps stacking or reordering the deck) and the other player follows the normal rules of the game. Realize that most Solitaire games are difficult to win, so you may want to redefine the object of the game to make it fair, especially if you create an asymmetric game.

3.    制定规则。 尝试玩一些游戏，边玩边制定规则。大多数单人纸牌游戏不需要花很长时间，因此您应该能够在短时间内进行游戏测试和修改。

3.    Build your rules. Try playing some games, inventing the rules as you go. Most Solitaire games don’t take very long to play, so you should be able to playtest and modify a lot within a short period of time.

4.    创建可交付成果。

4.    Create deliverable.

非数字短片

NON-DIGITAL SHORTS

调整游戏中的玩家数量或一次性使用系统是设计师的常见问题。这些练习让您有机会探索这些可能性。

Adjusting the number of players in a game or using a system at a single time is a common designer issue. These exercises give you a chance to explore these possibilities.

1.    拿一副标准扑克牌，设计一个回合制游戏，让两名玩家组成的团队相互竞争，完成一系列的牌局（例如，三张牌连成一串，四张牌连成一花色等等）。团队中的个人成员应齐心协力，支持团队，同时努力击败对方团队。

1.    Take a standard deck of playing cards and create a turn-based game in which teams of two players compete against one another to complete a series of card runs (for example, three cards in a series, four cards of a suit, and so on). The individual members of the teams should work together in support of the team while working to defeat the other team.

2.    使用与挑战 1 相同的系列，创建最多 20 名玩家可以玩的棋盘或方块游戏。玩家应该能够随心所欲地来去，独立或与其他玩家一起解决任务和行动，前提是他们同时玩游戏。作为设计师，您面临的最大挑战是确定游戏如何结束或是否结束。您将如何为玩家提供持续的娱乐？如何阻止他们在一次游戏中快速通关？

2.    Using the same series as in Challenge 1, create aboard or tile-based game that up to 20 players can play. Players should be able to come and go as they please and solve missions and function independently of other players or with them, provided they are playing the game simultaneously. As a designer, your biggest challenge will be to determine how the game ends or if it ends at all. How will you provide your players continuing entertainment? What’s to stop them from racing through in a single play?

3.    非数字游戏往往会吸引和数字游戏一样多甚至更多的追随者。例如，卡坦岛 的销量超过了GTA 3。万智牌：聚会 的销量一票难求。它们的保质期更长，不需要专门的硬件，几乎任何人都可以玩。但它们是否像挑战 3 中讨论的那样拥有迁徙的兽群？当然有。现在，有很多万智牌：聚会或 Pokémon玩家至少会喜欢尝试类似的游戏。欧洲游戏的玩家通常会寻找类似的游戏来玩。对于这项任务，您的目标是创建一款非数字游戏，旨在吸引其他流行游戏的玩家。

3.    Non-digital games tend to build up a following as large as—or even larger than— digital games. Settlers of Catan, for instance, has sold more copies than GTA 3. Magic: The Gathering sold its way into record books pack after pack. Their shelf lives are far longer, they don’t require specialized hardware, and almost anyone can play them. But do they have migratory herds, as discussed in Challenge 3? Absolutely. Right now, there are herds of Magic: The Gathering or Pokémon players who would enjoy at least trying something similar. Players of Eurogames often look for something similar to play next. For this task, your goal is to create a non-digital game that is designed to capture players of another popular game.

4.    设计一个在知名的公共场所（例如博物馆或购物中心）进行的游戏。

4.    Design a game to be played in a well-known public setting, such as a museum or a shopping mall.

5.    设计一款棋盘游戏，在两个不同地点的两个不同棋盘上进行。假设每个棋盘上的玩家无法面对面见面或进行实时交流。

5.    Design a board game to be played on two distinct boards in two separate locations. Assume the players at each board cannot meet each other face to face or exchange real-time communication.

6.    选择一种常见的竞争性棋盘游戏（例如Risk），并将其重新设计为合作性游戏。

6.    Choose a common competitive board game (such as Risk) and redesign it to be cooperative.

7.    从本书不同章节的挑战或非数字短片中选择一个你创建的游戏。重新设计游戏，以容纳你最初设计的两倍玩家数量。

7.    Choose a game you have created from a challenge or non-digital short from a different chapter in this book. Redesign the game to accommodate twice the number of players for which you originally designed.

8.    选择一种常见的回合制棋盘游戏（例如Parcheesi）并重新设计它以包含实时游戏。

8.    Choose a common turn-based board game (such as Parcheesi) and redesign it to include real-time play.

9.    制作一款 4 到 10 人参与的聚会游戏，玩家如果能想出最好的故事，就会获得奖励。游戏必须包含多种创作故事的机制，以及确定获胜者的方法。

9.    Create a four-to-ten player party game where people are rewarded for coming up with the best stories. The game must include multiple mechanics to create the stories and a means for determining who the winner is.

10. 为 2 到 4 名玩家创建一款回合制、基于图块的冒险游戏，故事随着游戏的进行而展开。您也可以选择让玩家改变故事的进程。

10. Create a turn-based, tile-based adventure game for two to four players where the story unfolds as the game is played. Optionally, you may give players the ability to change the course of the story.

 

 

第五部分：专题

Part V: Special Topics


 

 

16：创建用户界面

16: Create a User Interface

用户界面（通常缩写为 UI）是计算机编程早期的一个相当古怪的术语，在这里它用来描述玩家和游戏相互交流的方式。在视频游戏中，UI 由两个不同的部分组成：玩家如何将他们选择的操作传达给游戏（“输入”，通常称为控件），以及游戏如何向玩家显示这些操作的结果（“输出”，例如屏幕显示和控制器振动）。这两者在许多方面是相互关联的，这就是为什么我们将 UI 视为单独的实体，尽管它们由较小的部分组成。

User interface (often abbreviated UI) is a rather geeky term from the early days of computer programming, and it is used here to describe the way the player and the game communicate with each other. In a video game, the UI consists of two distinct parts: how the players communicate their chosen actions to the game (the “input,” usually referred to as the controls), and how the game displays the results of those actions to the player (the “output,” such as the screen display and controller vibration). These two are interlinked in many ways, which is why we talk of UIs as individual entities even though they are composed of smaller parts.

每个游戏都需要一个 UI，每个游戏开发者在职业生涯的某个阶段都会设计或实现至少一部分 UI。考虑到这一点，本章将帮助您练习 UI 设计技能。请记住，UI 设计是一个庞大的话题；关于这个主题的书籍很多（质量参差不齐），如果您感兴趣，我们鼓励您继续研究这个庞大的话题。本章末尾列出了推荐阅读的书籍列表。

Every game needs a UI, and at some point in every game developer’s career he or she designs or implements at least part of one. With that in mind, this chapter allows you to practice your UI design skills. Keep in mind that UI design is a huge topic; many books (of varying quality) have been written on the subject, and you are encouraged to continue your study of this vast topic if it interests you. A list of recommended reading appears at the end of this chapter.

UI 的目标

GOALS OF THE UI

偶尔，游戏设计时会以 UI 作为起点（以特殊控制器或控制方案的形式），然后再在上面添加机制。但更常见的情况是，控制方案是游戏设计的最后几个部分之一。虽然开发人员可能知道他们正在设计的控制器，但在设计初期，他们可能对游戏本身了解不够，无法确定如何将其控件映射到控制器上。因此，首先要创建机制，然后必须创建合适的 UI 以允许玩家调用这些机制。在这些情况下，从已知的机制开始，并回答这个问题：“玩家如何采取每个可能的操作？”

Occasionally, there are situations where the game is designed with the UI as a starting point (in the form of a special controller or control scheme), and mechanics are then layered on top. But more often, the control scheme is one of the last parts of a game that is designed. While developers may know the controller upon which they’re designing, in the early days of design, they may not know enough about the game itself to determine how they will map its controls on to the controller. So the mechanics are created first, and then a suitable UI must be created to allow the player to invoke those mechanics. In these cases, start with known mechanics and answer the question, “How does the player take each possible action?”

要回答这个问题，首先必须问一个更基本的问题：UI 的用途是什么？通常，UI 代表玩家和游戏之间的一道（可能令人沮丧的）障碍。玩家想要在游戏中采取行动，必须将这种愿望转化为物理动作，例如按下一系列按钮。UI 设计师的目标是创建一组尽可能透明且易于使用的控件，以便玩家可以专注于实际玩游戏而不是掌握控件。虽然可以以教程级别的形式向玩家传授更复杂的控件，但最好使控件尽可能简单，以首先减少对此类教程的需求。

To answer this question, you must first ask a more basic question: What is the purpose of the UI in the first place? Usually, the UI represents a (potentially frustrating) barrier between the player and the game. The player wants to take an action in the game and must translate that desire into a physical action, such as a series of button presses. The goal of the UI designer is to create a set of controls that is as transparent and easy to use as possible, so that the player can concentrate on actually playing the game rather than mastering the controls. While more complex controls can be taught to players in the form of tutorial levels, it is better to make the controls as simple as possible to reduce the need for such tutorials in the first place.

设计师的工具箱中有一个主要工具可用于简化控制：使用可供性。

There is a major tool in a designer’s toolbox that can be used to simplify controls: the use of affordances.

可供性：正确 = 简单，错误 = 困难

AFFORDANCES: RIGHT = EASY, WRONG = HARD

唐纳德·诺曼 (Donald Norman) 在他的《日常设计》一书中首次在 UI 的背景下使用了“可供性”一词。可供性是可以对对象执行的明显、显而易见的操作。例如，可以按下控制器按钮；任何曾经见过小圆形按钮的人都熟悉此操作和此行为，因此我们说按钮“可供”按压。按钮不可供滑动、投掷、咀嚼或任何其他我们通常不与之关联的操作。

Donald Norman, in his book The Design of Everyday Things, first used the term “affordance” in the context of UI. An affordance is an obvious, readily apparent action that can be performed on an object. For example, a controller button can be pressed; anyone who has ever seen a small, circular button before is familiar with this action and this behavior, so we say that the button “affords” pressing. Buttons do not afford sliding, or throwing, or chewing, or any other action that we do not normally associate with them.

要利用可供性，有一个主要原则：每个控件应该只做它所能做的事情。换句话说，玩家应该能够轻松地以正确的方式使用每个控件，而玩家很难在错误的时间使用错误的控件。做正确的事情很容易，做错事情很难。

To make use of affordances, there is one main principle: each control should do only what it affords. Said another way, it should be easy for the player to use each control in the correct way, and difficult for the player to use the wrong control at the wrong time. Doing things right is easy; doing things wrong is hard.

值得注意的是，可供性不仅取决于物体，还取决于试图使用该物体的人（以及该人的过去经历、文化和身体能力）。双摇杆很容易为俯视射击游戏提供左摇杆 = 移动、右摇杆 = 射击的控制方案，但仅适用于玩过Robotron 2084和Smash TV等类似游戏的人；对于不熟悉电子游戏的人来说，这种控制方案可能不是立即显而易见的。

It’s important to note that affordances are dependent not just on the object, but also the person trying to use that object (and that person’s past experiences, culture, and physical abilities). Dual analog sticks easily afford a left stick = move, right stick = fire control scheme for an overhead shooter, but only for people who have played similar games like Robotron 2084 and Smash TV; for people unfamiliar with video games in general, this control scheme may not be immediately obvious.

这表明，正如本书多次提到的那样，开发人员必须了解他们的目标受众。例如，对于 PlayStation 2，绝大多数游戏使用 X 按钮接受菜单选择，使用 O 按钮取消。这是一个简单的功能，原因有很多。首先，它借鉴了玩家以前在游戏机上玩其他游戏的经验。其次，索尼要求设置该按钮。事实上，开发人员必须向索尼提出令人信服的理由，才能改变游戏中的这一惯例。与其他游戏保持一致是最容易利用的功能之一。

This suggests that, as mentioned many times in this book, developers must be aware of their target audience. For the PlayStation 2, for instance, the vast majority of games use the X button to accept a menu selection and the O button to cancel. This is an easy affordance for numerous reasons. First, it draws on players’ former experience with other games on the console. Second, Sony requires that button setup. In fact, developers would have to make a compelling argument to Sony to change this convention in your game. Being consistent with other games is one of the easiest affordances to take advantage of.

讽刺的是，对于从未使用过 PlayStation 控制器的美国玩家来说，使用 X 表示选择、使用 O 表示取消其实并不是一件好事。在美国文化中，“X”表示“不”或“不是”，因此 X 符号表示取消操作（同样，“O”放在“X”旁边时表示接受），因此当许多美国玩家第一次遇到这种惯例时，X 和 O 之间既定角色的逆转让他们感到困惑。

Ironically, the use of X to select and O to cancel is actually not that great an affordance for American players who have never used a PlayStation controller before. In American culture, “X” denotes “no” or “not,” so the X symbol suggests a cancel action (and likewise, “O” denotes acceptance when placed next to an “X”), so this reversal of established roles between X and O confused many American gamers when they first encountered this convention.

在电脑上，鼠标/键盘控制具有一系列的功能——不仅来自其他电脑游戏，还来自非游戏应用程序。你可以期望玩家（即使是那些从未玩过游戏的玩家）理解鼠标的物理移动和屏幕光标的移动之间的关系。计算机用户可以识别按钮并知道左键单击按钮可以激活它。为了增强这种功能，开发人员将按钮设计成 3D 的而不是平面的，这样它们看起来就像可以按下的一样。他们还会突出显示按钮或使它们在鼠标悬停在按钮上方时发光，以便清楚地显示鼠标处于可以按下按钮的位置。这些都是增强按钮自然功能的方法，使其非常易于使用。

With computers, the mouse/keyboard control comes with a whole host of affordances—not just from other computer games, but from non-game applications. You can expect players (even those who have never played a game before) to understand the relationship between the physical movement of the mouse and the movement of an on-screen cursor. Computer users can be expected to recognize push buttons and know that left clicking on a button activates it. To enhance this affordance, developers make buttons 3D instead of flat, so that they look like they can be pushed. They also highlight buttons or make them glow when the mouse is hovering above them to make it really obvious that the mouse is in a position to press the button. These are ways of enhancing the natural affordances of the button, making it really easy to use.

Nintendo Wii 控制器也具有许多功能，但这些功能来自现实世界，而非计算机体验。许多早期为该游戏机制作的游戏都需要握住遥控器并做出模仿屏幕上想要执行的操作的物理动作，例如挥动高尔夫球杆或滚动保龄球。

The Nintendo Wii controller also comes with many affordances, but these come from the real world rather than computer experience. Many of the early games made for this console involved holding the remote and making physical motions that mimicked what you wanted to do on the screen—swinging a golf club or rolling a bowling ball, for example.

最后两个例子表明，即使要创建一款完全原创的游戏，需要发明一种前所未见的控制方案，依靠游戏世界之外的资源也是不错的选择。如果你想拓宽市场，你应该这样做。

These last two examples suggest that even when creating a completely original game that requires inventing a never-before-seen control scheme, it’s good to rely on affordances from outside of the world of games. If you want to broaden your market, you probably should.

关于可访问性的说明

A NOTE ABOUT ACCESSIBILITY

有些人是聋子、盲人或色盲。有些人是四肢瘫痪。有些人患有关节炎。有些人非常年轻或年老，缺乏极端的运动协调能力。这些人中的许多人都愿意玩游戏并享受游戏乐趣，只要开发者允许他们这样做。

Some people are deaf, or blind, or colorblind. Some are quadriplegic. Others have arthritis. Some are very young or very old, and lack extreme motor coordination. Many of these people would like to play and enjoy games, if only developers let them.

事实证明，让游戏更容易上手，可以让所有玩家都玩得更尽兴。如果游戏有单独的生命值和法力值计量表，那么不仅要用颜色区分，还要用形状和图标区分，这样色盲玩家才能理解它们。这也让其他人更容易理解。一般来说，开发者通过各种感官传达信息的方式越多，游戏就越容易上手，信息对每个人来说就越明显。

It turns out that making a game accessible makes it more playable for all gamers. If the game has separate meters for health and mana, differentiating them not only by color but also by shape and icon makes it possible for a colorblind player to interpret them. It also makes it easier for everyone else. In general, the more ways that a developer conveys information across various senses, the more accessible the game is and the more obvious that information is to everyone.

定义输入时需要考虑以下几点：

Here are some points to consider when defining your inputs:

·      避免要求玩家同时按下多个按钮。有些人缺乏协调能力，尤其是当必须用同一只手按下两个按钮时。作为替代方案，请考虑将几个类似的控件映射到一个按钮并使其具有上下文相关性。

·      Avoid requiring the player to press multiple buttons simultaneously. Some people lack the coordination, especially if both buttons must be pressed with the same hand. As an alternative, consider mapping several similar controls to a single button and making it context-sensitive.

·      允许玩家重新定义控制。有些玩家习惯于某些位置的某些按钮功能，他们可能不适应默认的控制方案。在电脑上尤其如此，有些人喜欢使用 WASD 键移动，而另一些人则喜欢使用箭头键。

·      Allow the player to redefine the controls. Some players are used to certain button functions in certain places, and they may not match the default control scheme. This is especially true on computers, where some people prefer to use the WASD keys for movement and others prefer the arrow keys.

·      考虑减少控件数量的方法……如果可以的话，甚至可以减少到单个上下开关或按钮。按钮越少，游戏对没有经验的玩家的威胁就越小。充分减少控件，即使仅限于特殊游戏模式，每个人都可以玩游戏，包括那些可能已经失去四肢使用能力的人。

·      Consider ways to reduce the number of controls... even down to a single up/down switch or button if you can. The fewer the buttons, the less intimidating the game is to inexperienced gamers. Reduce the controls sufficiently, even if it’s limited to a special game mode, and the game is playable by everyone, including those who may have lost the use of their limbs.

·      支持多种难度等级。即使游戏主要针对“硬核”玩家，增加“简单”模式也无妨，因为这样新玩家也能享受游戏体验。使用简单、清晰、简洁的语言。如果不是因为对话似乎是哈佛大学文学博士写的，许多原本很棒的游戏也能被小孩子玩得尽兴。

·      Support multiple difficulty levels. Even if the game is targeted mainly at the “hardcore” player, nothing is lost by adding an “easy” mode that lets newer players enjoy the experience, too. Use simple, clear, and concise language. Many otherwise excellent games could be thoroughly enjoyed by young children, if not for the fact that their dialogue was apparently written by someone with a Ph.D. in literature from Harvard.

·      不要仅通过颜色来区分屏幕元素。使用不同的形状、声音和纹理。对于大多数游戏玩家来说，这使得游戏的这些元素更容易区分，并且 UI 感觉更灵敏。对于色盲者来说，游戏不再完全无法玩。

·      Do not differentiate screen elements by color alone. Use different shapes, sounds, and textures. For the majority of gamers, this makes those elements of the game far easier to tell apart, and the UI feels more responsive. For the colorblind, the game is no longer completely unplayable.

·      如果有文字，请将其放大（或允许手动调整大小）。有些玩家的视力不是 20/20。有些玩家的视力非常清晰，但电视又旧又模糊。如果文字太小，玩家就无法阅读。添加音轨是传达信息的另一种方式——对于部分文盲的玩家来说，这是一种至关重要的方式。

·      Where there is text, make it large (or allow manual resizing). Some players don’t have 20/20 vision. Some players have crystal-clear vision and an old, fuzzy TV. If the text is too small, players can’t read it. Including an audio track adds another way to get the message across—a critical one for gamers who are partially illiterate.

·      允许对比度调整。同样，这与显示设备的变化有很大关系。如果游戏太暗或太亮，即使是视力完美的人也无法玩。

·      Allow contrast adjustment. Again, this has to do more with the variation in display devices. If the game is too dark or too bright, it is unplayable even for someone with perfect vision.

举一个有趣的例子，看看当你的 UI 无法访问时会发生什么，下载并玩Game Over!吧，它的开发者称它是“世界上第一个（希望是唯一一个）普遍无法访问的游戏”。你可以从 http://www.ics.forth.gr/hci/ua-games/game-over/ 阅读并下载它。

For an amusing example of what happens when your UI is not accessible, download and play Game Over!, billed by its developers as “the world’s first (and hopefully only) universally inaccessible game.” You can read about and download it from http://www.ics.forth.gr/hci/ua-games/game-over/.

反馈

FEEDBACK

到目前为止，我们主要讨论了玩家输入。游戏还必须以视觉、听觉，有时还有触觉（身体感觉）反馈的形式向玩家提供有关游戏当前状态的信息。这些也可以通过使用可供性而变得更加清晰。UI 中的常见惯例包括生命值计量表（用红色绘制）、周围区域的小地图（以玩家为中心）以及使用图标代替全文描述。

So far, we have talked mostly about player input. Games also must give the player information on the current state of the game in the form of visual, auditory, and sometimes tactile (physical sensation) feedback. These, too, can be made much clearer through the use of affordances. Common conventions in UI include life meters (drawn in a red color), minimap of the immediate surrounding area (centered on the player), and the use of icons instead of full-text descriptions.

开发人员还可以通过分组让信息更易于访问。如果几条信息彼此相关，请将它们放在屏幕上的邻近位置。如果玩家的生命值和魔法值同等重要且相互影响（例如，如果魔法值主要用于治疗生命值），则将它们各自的计量表放在屏幕的相对两侧只会让游戏更难玩。将它们放在相邻位置可让玩家一眼便能获得所需的所有信息。

Developers can also make information easier to access by grouping. If several pieces of information relate to each other, place them in close proximity on the screen. If the player’s hit points and mana points are equally important and affect each other (for example, if mana is used primarily to heal hit points), placing their respective meters on opposite sides of the screen just makes the game harder to play. Making them adjacent lets the player get all the information he needs at a single glance.

除了玩家健康和位置等持久信息外，还要考虑玩家需要了解的游戏中发生的事件。如果玩家被击中并受到伤害，他需要通过屏幕闪烁红光、播放声音、控制器振动或三者的组合来了解情况。

Aside from persistent information like the player’s health and location, also consider events that happen in the game that the player needs to know about. If a player gets hit and takes damage, he needs to know either through the screen flashing red, a sound playing, the controller vibrating, or a combination of all three.

UI 设计流程

THE PROCESS OF UI DESIGN

UI 设计遵循一些相当简单的步骤。首先，设计师列出 UI 中需要的所有元素。然后，他们根据玩家使用每个元素的频率对它们进行优先排序。记下游戏 UI 可以利用的任何自然功能。然后，制作原型、进行游戏测试并重复。在整个过程中，寻找简化控制的方法，并确保玩家在其操作后立即收到可理解的反馈。

UI design follows some fairly straightforward steps. First, designers list all of the elements that are needed in a UI. Then, they prioritize them based on how often the player uses each one. Make note of any natural affordances the game’s UI can take advantage of. Then, prototype, playtest, and repeat. Throughout the process, look for ways to simplify the controls, and make sure the player receives immediate, understandable feedback in response to his or her actions.

输入/输出是什么？

WHAT ARE THE INPUTS/OUTPUTS?

列出玩家在游戏中执行的所有动作。列出玩家需要知道的所有游戏状态信息。

List all of the actions that the player performs in the game. List all of the game-state information that the player needs to know.

优先考虑

PRIORITIZE

在每个输入和输出旁边注明玩家是经常使用还是偶尔使用。访问每个项目的难易程度应与访问频率成正比。例如，关键信息不应隐藏在子屏幕中，否则玩家会不断在主游戏和该子屏幕之间来回移动。同时，每小时仅有用一次的信息不应一直显示在主屏幕上，否则它只会使事情变得混乱，并分散玩家对更重要信息的注意力。

Note next to each input and output whether the player uses it constantly or only occasionally. The ease of accessing each item should be proportional to how often it must be accessed.
