For example, critical information should not be buried in a subscreen, or else the player constantly moves back and forth between the main game and that subscreen. Meanwhile, information that is only useful once every hour should not be displayed constantly on the main screen, or it simply clutters things and draws attention away from the more important information there.

找到可供性

FIND THE AFFORDANCES

对于每个玩家动作，请考虑哪种控件最适合该动作。如果有多个动作自然映射到同一个控件，则可能同时使用这两个动作（如果可能），并使其与上下文相关。

For each player action, consider what control best affords that action. If there are several actions that naturally map to the same control, perhaps use both actions, if possible, and make it context-dependent.

如果最佳输入不清楚，请询问其他人的意见。“如果你想发射鱼雷，但你没有阅读手册，你会先尝试什么？”询问几个人后，可能会形成强烈的共识。虽然可能不清楚为什么 人们认为右肩按钮应该执行某个操作，但他们确实会这样做，这为 UI 设计师提供了一个很好的起点。当然，为了获得最佳结果，请询问目标市场中的人。

If the best input is unclear, ask others their opinions. “If you wanted to fire your torpedoes, and you hadn’t read the manual, what would you try first?” After asking a few people, a strong consensus will likely develop. Although it may not be clear why people assume the right shoulder button should perform a certain action, they do, and that gives a UI designer an excellent starting point. For best results, of course, ask people who are part of the target market.

对于输出，有几个考虑因素。首先，存在是否显示信息的问题。如果信息不重要，或者游戏的一部分涉及故意向玩家隐藏某些信息以增加紧张感或不确定性，开发人员可能根本不想显示它。他们只显示部分信息，例如模糊的进度条，而不是特定数字。

For outputs, there are several considerations. First, there is the question of whether to display the information at all. If it is unimportant, or if part of the game involves keeping some information intentionally hidden from the player to increase tension or uncertainty, developers may not want to show it at all. They only show some of the information, such as a fuzzy progress bar, rather than a specific number.

其次，如果必须向玩家显示信息，那么下一个问题就是在哪里显示。考虑一下玩家的眼睛通常在屏幕上看什么。关键信息应该放在附近，这样玩家就不必环顾屏幕的各个角落。这也是为什么在许多现代 FPS 游戏中，剩余弹药实际上印在玩家携带的枪上的原因之一。除了美观和身临其境之外，它还将信息放在靠近屏幕中心的位置，也就是动作发生的地方。

Second, if information must be displayed to the player, the next question is where. Consider where the player’s eyes are normally looking on the screen. Critical information should be placed nearby, so that the player does not have to glance around at all corners of the screen. This is part of the reason why in many modern FPS games, the ammo remaining is actually printed on the gun the player carries. Aside from being aesthetically pleasing and immersive, it also puts the information close to the center of the screen where the action is.

立即对您的意见做出反馈

GIVE IMMEDIATE FEEDBACK FOR YOUR INPUTS

当玩家尝试执行某个操作但什么也没发生时，这可能会让人非常沮丧。更糟糕的是，当确实发生了某些事情，但玩家却没有意识到，所以他一次又一次地采取相同的操作，后来才发现自己无意中做得太过了。

When a player tries to take an action and nothing happens, it can be very frustrating. Even worse is when something does happen, but the player is not aware of it, so he takes the same action again and again, only to find out later he has unintentionally done too much.

避免这种情况的最佳方法是在玩家做某事时给予反馈。同样，反馈可以是视觉、听觉、触觉，也可以是三者的结合。这会让游戏感觉令人满意且反应灵敏——假设反馈显然是对输入的响应，而不是其他东西（再次，我们看到了可供性的使用）。

The best way to avoid this is to give the player feedback whenever he does something. Again, this can be visual, auditory, tactile, or some combination of all three. It makes the game feel satisfying and responsive—assuming that the feedback is obviously responding to the input and not something else (again, we see the use of affordances).

减少一切

REDUCE EVERYTHING

典型的 PC 键盘上有 100 多个按键，某些游戏机控制器上有 10 多个模拟控件，因此玩家很容易想用到所有控件。对于一款本应很复杂的逼真飞行模拟器来说，拥有数十种不同的控件可以提升游戏体验。对于典型的 FPS 来说，这只会让 UI 难以使用。想办法减少和折叠控件，让它们使用最少的操纵杆和按钮移动。

With over 100 keys on a typical PC keyboard, and over 10 analog controls on some console controllers, there is the temptation to make use of everything. For a realistic flight simulator that is supposed to be complicated, having dozens of different controls can add to the experience. For a typical FPS, it just makes the UI frustrating to use. Think of ways to reduce and collapse the controls so that they use a minimum of joystick and button movement.

同样，让每个游戏屏幕、菜单和子屏幕都为生存而战。如果玩家必须深入菜单系统三层才能完成一些简单的事情，比如使用治疗药水，那么请重新考虑 UI。大多数游戏操作（尤其是那些经常使用的操作）应该始终只需按一下按钮即可完成。

Likewise, make every game screen, menu, and subscreen fight for its life. If the player has to go three levels deep into a menu system to do something as simple as using a healing potion, rethink the UI. Most game actions—especially those that are used frequently— should be no more than a single button press away at all times.

原型

PROTOTYPE

如果说快速原型设计真正能给游戏带来好处，那就是 UI。根据定义，用户界面是主动的，并且是实时发生的。被动的、静止的设计文档根本无法显示 UI 质量水平。同样，如果不是你来实施 UI 设计，书面文档也有可能与程序员沟通不畅。具有活动部件的工作原型更能传达想法。

If there’s one place where rapid prototyping can really benefit a game, it’s the UI. By definition, the user interface is active and happens in real time. A passive, unmoving design document cannot begin to show the level of UI quality. Likewise, a written document runs the risk of miscommunicating to the programmer, if someone other than you is implementing the UI design. A working prototype with moving parts is much better at communicating the idea.

如何制作 UI 原型？从纸开始：例如，在白板或海报板上绘制屏幕模型，并使用索引卡显示屏幕元素。这样做的好处是可以轻松进行更改：就像移动索引卡一样简单！如果游戏支持鼠标，则使用手指作为鼠标光标。

How does one make a UI prototype? Start with paper: draw a screen mockup on a whiteboard or poster board, for example, and use index cards to show screen elements. This has the advantage of making changes painless: it’s as easy as moving index cards around! Use a finger as the mouse cursor, if the game works with a mouse.

最后，考虑开发数字原型。游戏的 UI 由移动部件组成，评估其质量需要将其设置为运动状态并与之交互（与游戏动态非常相似）。游戏逻辑不需要实现（可以使用虚假数据），但要确保所有移动部件都能真正发挥作用。Adobe Flash 可以用于此目的，因为它可以轻松制作屏幕模型并以最少的麻烦响应鼠标点击。如果 UI 涉及鼠标点击的简单行为，则原型可以简单到用 HTML 链接在一起的一系列屏幕模型。完全没有技术经验的 UI 设计师通常会与程序员合作，然后由程序员实现数字原型。

Eventually, consider developing a digital prototype. A game’s UI consists of moving parts, and evaluating its quality requires setting it in motion and interacting with it (much like game dynamics). The game logic doesn’t need to be implemented (fake data can be used), but make sure that all of the moving parts actually do something. Adobe Flash can be useful for this, as it is easy to make screen mockups and respond to mouse clicks with a minimum of fuss. In cases where the UI involves simple behavior from mouse clicks, a prototype can be as simple as a series of screen mockups linked together in HTML. UI designers with no technical experience at all often team up with a programmer who then implements the digital prototype.

游戏测试！

PLAYTEST!

游戏测试 UI 的重要性怎么强调都不为过。在焦点测试或游戏环节中，开发人员会观察从未玩过游戏的玩家尝试使用 UI。玩家经常会意外按错按钮，或者抱怨游戏太难，因为他们缺乏关键信息（或者根本没注意到）。明智的开发人员不会因为错过“明显”的东西而责备游戏测试人员，而是将其视为 UI 不够直观的强烈信号，并通过改变控制方式或在屏幕上添加新反馈来使关键事件更加明显，让玩家更容易理解。

The importance of playtesting UI cannot be overstated. During focus tests or play sessions, developers watch people who have never played the game try to use the UI. Often, players press the wrong buttons accidentally or complain that the game is too hard because they lack critical information (or simply did not notice it). Instead of chastising playtesters for missing “obvious” things, the wise developer takes this as a strong signal that the UI is not intuitive enough and makes things easier for the player to understand by changing the controls around or adding new feedback to the screen to make critical events more obvious.

每次更改都会有新一批测试人员进行另一轮测试。持续使用新测试人员很重要。一旦游戏测试人员了解并熟悉了 UI，他就不会再注意到事情是否不直观，就像开发人员不会注意到一样。

With every change, there’s also another round of testing with a new batch of testers. It’s important to use new testers continuously. Once a playtester has learned the UI and become familiar with it, he no longer notices if things are unintuitive any more than the developer would notice it.

故意“糟糕”的用户界面

INTENTIONALLY “BAD” UI

到目前为止，我们已经讨论了如何让 UI 尽可能易于使用、直观和无缝。每个开发人员的目标都是让 UI 不妨碍玩家并变得透明，以便玩家思考要做什么，游戏也会按照玩家的想法做出反应。事实上，在绝大多数游戏中，这实际上是最终目标。毕竟，玩家想要体验游戏玩法 ，而对 UI 的任何关注都会分散对游戏本身的注意力。

So far, we have discussed how to make UI as easy to use, intuitive, and seamless as possible. Every developer’s objective is to make the UI get out of the player’s way and become transparent so that the player thinks of what to do and the game responds exactly as the player thought it would. In the vast majority of games, this is, in fact, the ultimate goal. Players want to experience the gameplay after all, and any attention that must be paid to the UI is attention taken away from the game itself.

故意设计一个让人沮丧、难以使用或晦涩难懂的 UI 有用吗？开发者会为了制作更好的游戏而降低可用性吗？答案是肯定的——但要做到这一点，人们仍然需要在打破良好 UI 规则之前了解它们。

Is it ever useful to make a UI that is intentionally frustrating, difficult to use, or opaque? Would developers ever make things less usable in order to make a better game? The answer is yes—but to do so, one still has to know what the rules of good UI are before breaking them.

这种 UI 的一个例子是 Persuasive Games 的Disaffected!。这款游戏旨在让玩家感受到作为 FedEx Kinko's 员工的挫败感和压力。控制缓慢且反应迟钝，同事的化身不断挡住玩家的路，目标不直观。UI 结合在一起让玩家感到不满——这正是游戏的设计意图。

An example of such a UI would be Persuasive Games’ Disaffected!. This game is designed to make the player feel the frustration and stress of being a FedEx Kinko’s employee. The controls are slow and unresponsive, the avatars of co-workers are constantly getting in the player’s way, and the goals are unintuitive. The UI comes together to make the player feel, well, disaffected—which is the design intent of the game.

要设计出糟糕的 UI，设计师首先必须理解“好”的 UI为何好。对于常见的控件，是什么让它们如此？为什么大多数生命条都是深红色？为什么 PC 游戏中的 Esc 键会弹出允许玩家退出游戏的菜单？了解这些惯例是如何形成的，就能理解这些惯例改变后对游戏体验的影响。

To make a bad UI, the designer must first understand why a “good” UI is good. For controls that are common conventions, what originally made them so? Why do most life meters have a dark-reddish color? Why does the Esc key in a PC game bring up the menu that allows players to exit from the game? Understand how these conventions came to be, and one understands the effect on the game experience when these conventions are changed.

挑战

CHALLENGES

把 UI 想象成电影院的座位。如果座位不舒服，就没人会留下来看电影。这些练习旨在带你完成创建、制作和完善 UI 的过程。

Think of UI as the seats in a movie theater. If it’s uncomfortable, no one’s going to stay for the show. These exercises are designed to take you through the process of creating, crafting, and refining UI.

挑战 1——体育 UI

CHALLENGE 1—THE SPORTS UI

设计体育游戏（尤其是团队运动）的 UI 非常困难。在大多数游戏中，玩家只有一个角色。在团队运动中，需要同时控制多个角色。

Designing the UI for sports games (especially team sports) is difficult. In most games, the player only has a single avatar. In team sports, there are many avatars that must be controlled simultaneously.

对于这一挑战，选择一项你熟悉的团队运动并以此为基础为视频游戏创建 UI。

For this challenge, take a team sport that you are familiar with and create the UI for a video game based on it.

所需组件

Components Required

·      至少有一款你选择的运动的现代游戏和一台可以玩这款游戏的机器；或者，如果没有，需要互联网连接来研究用户界面

·      At least one modern game of the sport you chose and a machine to play it on; or, if unavailable, an Internet connection to research the UI

可交付成果

Deliverable

·      双人游戏过程中所有主要屏幕的屏幕模型，显示每个屏幕上显示的信息以及每个元素的大致位置

·      Screen mockups of all major screens during the play of a two-player game, showing the information displayed on each screen and the approximate location of each element

·      对于每个屏幕，使用任何现代控制台控制器列出该屏幕上的所有控件

·      For each screen, a list of all controls on that screen, using any modern console controller

建议流程

Suggested Process

1.    列出状态。不同的游戏状态有哪些（例如，对于棒球，状态包括“投球前”和“投球后但挥棒前”）？玩家在每个状态期间会做出哪些决定？每个状态都需要一套单独的控件，并且值得拥有自己的屏幕模型。

1.    Make a list of states. What are the different play states (for example, for baseball, states would include “before a pitch,” and “immediately after the pitch but before the swing”)? What decisions are players making during each state? Each state needs its own separate set of controls and deserves its own screen mockup.

2.    制作行动清单。对于每个状态，列出每个玩家可以采取的行动以及游戏中哪些信息对每个玩家来说很重要。这可以让你很好地了解哪些控件和屏幕元素是必需的；一旦你有了这个清单，接下来的步骤将指导你将它们转化为可交付成果。

2.    Make an action list. For each state, list what actions each player can take and what information about the game is important to each player. This gives you a good idea of what controls and screen elements are necessary; once you have that list, the next steps guide you toward turning these into the deliverables.

3.    研究惯例。 看看其他体育游戏，并回答以下问题：对于涉及秘密选择不同比赛方式的运动（如美式足球），你如何做到这一点，让你知道自己选择了什么，而不会将相同的信息透露给对手？/ 有哪些摄像机角度可用于观看比赛，它们是如何控制的？在双人游戏中，最好使用单摄像机视图还是分屏（水平或垂直）？每种方法的优缺点是什么？/ 在游戏过程中（以及在动作中断时，如果有的话），屏幕上应始终显示哪些类型的信息？_一次控制团队中所有人的最佳方法是什么？您是否一次控制一名球员，并且有某种直观的方式在球员之间切换，或者您可以同时指挥整个团队？/ 您是否在专业视频游戏中找到了您之前创建的状态列表和操作列表中未出现的控件或操作？添加它们。 / 如果您没有游戏来进行这项研究，请查看专业游戏评论中的屏幕截图。但是，强烈建议您拥有游戏本身。

3.    Research conventions. Look at other sports games, and answer the following questions: For sports that involve choosing different plays secretly (like American football), how do you do this in a way that lets you know what you’ve selected without giving that same information to your opponent? / What camera angles are available for viewing the game and how are they controlled? In two-player games, is it better to have a single camera view or a split screen (horizontal or vertical)? What are the advantages and disadvantages of each?  / What kinds of information should be displayed on the screen at all times during play (and at breaks in the action, if any)?_What is the best way to control all of the people on your team at once? Do you control one player at a time and have some intuitive way to switch between players, or can you direct the entire team concurrently? / Did you find any controls or actions in the professional video game that did not appear on your lists from your state list and action list that you created earlier? Add them. / If you do not own a game to do this research, look at screenshots included in professional game reviews. However, ownership of the game itself is heavily recommended.

4.    解释惯例。 对于传统的 UI，哪些部分利用了可供性？确保保留这些（或多或少）原样。是否有任何控件或反馈对您来说似乎不直观？如果是这样，您必须决定是遵循目标受众熟悉的惯例，还是以可能迫使玩家学习一套新惯例的方式改进 UI。

4.    Explain the conventions. For conventional UI, what parts take advantage of affordances? Make sure that you keep those (more or less) as they are. Are there any controls or feedback that seem unintuitive to you? If so, you have to decide between conforming to conventions that are familiar to the target audience versus improving the UI in ways that might force players to learn a new set of conventions.

5.    创建可交付成果。 如果您不想使用您的艺术才能（或者粗略的手绘就是您的艺术才能），您的屏幕模型可以是带有火柴人、方框和文本的粗略手绘。确保显示所有相关的屏幕元素。您只需要包括在玩双人游戏时发现的屏幕。保存/加载屏幕、主菜单等不需要包括在内。对于每个屏幕模型，请包含现代控制台上的控制器图表，并显示哪些控件映射到哪些游戏内操作。

5.    Create deliverable. Your screen mockups can be crude hand drawings with stick figures, boxes, and text if you prefer not to use your artistic ability (or if crude hand drawings are your artistic ability). Make sure you show all relevant screen elements. You need only include screens that are found during the play of a two-player game. Saving/loading screens, the main menu, etc. do not need to be included. For each screen mockup, include a diagram of a controller on the modern console and show what controls map to which in-game actions.

变体

Variant

如果您已经完成“体育游戏”挑战（第 8 章，挑战 1），请为该游戏创建 UI。

If you’ve completed the “Sports Games” challenge (Chapter 8, Challenge 1), create the UI for that game instead.

挑战 2 — 360 度旋风

CHALLENGE 2—TWISTER 360

假设 Milton Bradley 和 Microsoft 刚刚宣布建立新的合作伙伴关系，让经典派对游戏Twister 登陆 Xbox Live Arcade。凭借你不可思议的运气（好或坏，取决于你的观点），你成为了该项目的首席设计师。

Suppose Milton Bradley and Microsoft just announced a new partnership to make the classic party game Twister available on Xbox Live Arcade. Through your incredible luck (either good or bad, depending on your viewpoint), you are the lead designer on the project.

游戏明确地告诉你，原版游戏的体验应该尽可能地保持完整。显然，单机游戏支持多人游戏，但游戏也应该支持在线游戏。

It is made clear to you that the play experience of the original game should be left as intact as possible. Multiple players on a single console are obviously preferred, but the game should support online play as well.

我们鼓励您使用现有的控制器（默认的 360 控制器，或者可能是跳舞毯或类似的东西）。但是，您也可以提出一种用于此游戏的新控制器设计，但您必须准备好证明其必要性，因为专门制造的控制器会给项目增加大量成本和风险。如果您真的觉得它增加了游戏体验，欢迎讨论。

You are encouraged to make use of a controller that already exists (either the default 360 controller, or perhaps a dance pad or something similar). However, you may also propose a new controller design for use with this game, but you must be prepared to justify its necessity since a specially manufactured controller adds significant costs and risk to the project. If you really feel it adds to the gameplay experience, they are open to discussion.

所需组件

Components Required

·      一份带规则的实体棋盘游戏Twister ，或合适的替代品

·      A copy of the physical board game Twister with rules, or suitable substitute

可交付成果

Deliverable

·      游戏设计文档，包括 UI 的完整描述，或

·      Game-design document, including a complete description of the UI, or

·      一页正式商务电子邮件（打印版），说明如果您无法利用已在其他游戏中使用的控制器，则需要特殊控制器。游戏设计文档中应包含控制器本身及其在游戏中的用途的描述

·      One-page formal business e-mail (printed) that describes the need for a special controller, if you cannot take advantage of a controller already in use with other games. A description of the controller itself and its use with the game should be contained in the game design document

建议流程

Suggested Process

1.    扭扭乐。大多数人小时候都玩过扭扭乐。如果你有机会玩这个游戏，就玩一玩。如果没有，试着回忆一下当时的体验。成年人通常不愿意玩这个游戏，因为它可能会让人陷入尴尬的境地。当然，这也是乐趣的一半。写下你玩扭扭乐的体验。这就是你试图在游戏中模拟的体验。你为什么喜欢玩这个游戏？你为什么喜欢看别人玩这个游戏？

1.    Twist. Most people played Twister as a child. If you have access to the game, play it. If not, try to remember the experience. Often, adults are reluctant to play the game due to the potentially embarrassing situations it can put one in. That, of course, is half the fun. Write down what the Twister experience was for you. This is the experience you are attempting to simulate in the game. Why did you enjoy playing it? Why did you enjoy watching others play it?

2.    集思广益。两三个人一组，集思广益，想出这款游戏可能的用户界面。不要想当然地就想到在地板上放一个Twister大小的垫子。从您知道的和您的发行商想要的控件开始——控制台控制器、Wii 遥控器、DDR 垫子，甚至 PC 摄像头。您如何重现您在上一步中确定的体验？

2.    Brainstorm. In groups of two or three people, brainstorm possible UIs for this game. Don’t automatically think of a Twister-sized mat on the floor. Start with the controls you know and your publisher wants—a console controller, the Wii remote, a DDR mat, or even a PC camera. How can you recreate the experience you identified in the previous step?

3.    列出可能的控制方案。将可能的输入设备缩小到两种。接下来，尝试定义每种控制方案：玩家如何在屏幕上看到自己？/玩家如何在游戏中选择动作？/玩家如何确定动作是否会导致角色以不可能或舒适的方式弯曲？如何重现已确定的体验？/对于许多设计师来说，握住控制器（如果适用）并闭上眼睛，假装自己正在玩游戏会有所帮助。

3.    Develop a list of possible control schemes. Narrow your possible input devices down to two. Next, attempt to define the control scheme for each: How does the player see herself on the screen? / How does the player select movements in the game? / How does the player determine if the movement will cause her character to bend impossibly or comfortably? How do you recreate the experiences you have identified? / For many designers, it helps to hold the controller in your hand (if applicable) close your eyes, and pretend that you are actually playing the game.

4.    模拟控制。 将所有可能的操作映射到您选择的输入设备上。

4.    Mock up controls. Map all possible actions to the input device of your choice.

5.    创建可交付成果。

5.    Create deliverable.

挑战 3 — 动作角色扮演游戏子屏幕

CHALLENGE 3—ACTION RPG SUBSCREEN

在许多情况下，您不会一次性设计整个 UI，而是一次设计一个部分。这种情况在先设计机制再设计控件的项目中更常见。对于这个挑战，您将设计一个更大游戏的单个组件。

In many cases, you won’t be designing the entire UI all at once, but rather a single piece at a time. This happens more often in projects where the mechanics are designed before the controls. For this challenge, you’ll be designing a single component of a much larger game.

讨论的游戏是一款简单的 PC 动作角色扮演游戏。此类型中较为知名的游戏包括《暗黑破坏神》 、 《博德之门：黑暗联盟》和《泰坦之旅》。如果您不熟悉此类型，则需要对其进行研究才能继续。

The game in question is a simple action RPG for the PC. Better known games in this genre include Diablo, Baldur’s Gate: Dark Alliance, and Titan Quest. If you are unfamiliar with the genre, you need to research it in order to proceed.

与同类其他游戏相比，该游戏的机制简单：

The mechanics for this game are simple, compared to other games in the genre:

·      玩家控制单个角色。

·      The player controls a single character.

·      角色拥有生命值和法力。受到伤害时生命值会减少，找到地牢中的治疗神殿会增加。施法时法力会减少，找到地牢中的魔法神殿会增加。返回城镇即可完全恢复生命值和法力。使用物品无法恢复生命值和法力。

·      The character has hit points and mana. Hit points decrease when damage is taken and increase by finding healing shrines in the dungeon. Mana decreases when casting spells, and it increases by finding magic shrines in the dungeon. Both are completely restored by returning to town. Neither can be restored through use of items.

·      角色拥有两种属性：力量和魔法。每增加一点力量，生命值 +1，所有物理攻击伤害 +1。每增加一点魔法，法力 +1，所有法术攻击伤害 +1。

·      The character has two stats: strength and magic. Each extra point of strength adds +1 hit point and adds +1 damage to all of your physical attacks. Each extra point of magic adds +1 mana and adds +1 damage to all of your spell attacks.

·      角色获得经验值。达到一定阈值时，角色将获得一个等级，这允许玩家将力量增加 +2，或将魔法增加 +2，或将力量和魔法各增加 +1。

·      The character gains experience points. At certain thresholds, the character gains a level, which allows the player to increase his strength by +2, or magic by +2, or strength and magic by +1 each.

·      角色最多可以携带六件物品。没有物品大小或重量的概念，物品不能堆叠。你可以放下一件物品以将其从库存中移除。游戏中没有消耗品。物品有三种：宝石、武器和法术书。宝石没有任何用处；它们占用库存位置，可以在城里卖很多钱，但携带时没有任何好处。武器在装备时会增加物理攻击的伤害，而仅仅携带时则不会产生任何作用。

·      The character can carry up to six items. There is no concept of item size or weight, and items cannot stack. You can drop an item to remove it from inventory. There are no consumable items in the game. There are three kinds of items: gems, weapons, and spellbooks. Gems are not useful in any way; they take up inventory slots, and they can be sold for a lot of money in town, but they provide no benefit while being carried. Weapons increase the damage from physical attacks when equipped, and do nothing when merely carried.

·      您一次最多可以装备一件武器，装备新武器时会取消装备之前装备的武器（如果有的话）。您一次最多可以装备三本法术书；每本法术书都可以让您在装备时施放法术。施放法术时会对敌人造成伤害（在可能值范围内）。

·      You can equip up to one weapon at a time, and equipping a new weapon unequips the previously equipped one (if any). You can equip up to three spellbooks at a time; each spellbook enables you to cast a spell while equipped. Spells do damage to enemies (within a range of possible values) when cast.

·      角色拥有一定数量的金钱。这些金钱可以在地下城或城镇中出售物品获得，并可用于在城镇中购买新物品。金钱不算作物品，也不会占用库存空间。

·      The character has a certain amount of money. This money is found in the dungeon and by selling items in town, and can be used to purchase new items in town. Money does not count as an item and does not take up any room in inventory.

对于这个游戏，设计子屏幕（或一系列子屏幕）的 UI，让玩家可以查看和操作他们的库存。

For this game, design the UI for the subscreen (or series of subscreens) that allows the player to view and manipulate their inventory.

由于这是一款 PC 游戏，因此假设最小屏幕分辨率为 800 600。将原型制作成该尺寸。

Since this is a PC game, assume a minimum screen resolution of 800 600. Make your prototype that size.

所需组件

Components Required

·      方格纸

·      Graph paper

可交付成果

Deliverable

·      所有子屏幕的屏幕模型，以及该屏幕上所有控件的文本描述。

·      Screen mockup of all subscreens, along with a text description of all controls on that screen.

建议流程

Suggested Process

1.    考虑您的选择。您有很多信息需要显示。考虑如何布局这些信息以便于查找。考虑如何以及何时吸引玩家注意某些关键信息，例如他们是否可以升级。是否有任何信息可以对玩家隐藏，或者只需要在特定时间显示？您是否应该在子屏幕上一直显示装备的法术书的效果，还是仅在特定时间显示（例如，当它们突出显示时，或当鼠标悬停在它们上面时）？最后，考虑在一个屏幕上显示所有信息（如果您不非常小心，可能会有点密集和混乱）与将内容分散到多个子屏幕上并包括一种在它们之间导航的方式（这又需要一个额外的问题，即哪些信息应该放在哪个屏幕上）。

1.    Consider your options. You have a lot of information to display. Think of how the information should be laid out so that it’s easy to find. Think about how and when you should draw the player’s attention to certain critical information, such as whether they can level up. Is there any information that you can keep hidden from the player, or that only needs to show up at certain times? Should you display the effects of equipped spellbooks all the time on the subscreen or only at certain times (for example, when they’re highlighted, or when the mouse is hovering over them)? Lastly, consider the tradeoff between having one screen with all of the information (it may be a bit dense and cluttered if you’re not extremely careful) versus spreading things out onto several subscreens and including a way to navigate between them (which then requires the additional question of which information goes on which screen).

2.    创建可交付成果。 如果您有可以作为起点的东西，那么以数字形式实现这一点会容易得多。拿一张方格纸，在上面画一个按比例缩放的大矩形，然后开始绘制屏幕元素。使用铅笔并尝试不同的放置位置。考虑玩家想要执行的任务，例如升级或查看角色统计数据。玩家如何完成这些任务：单击、双击、单击并拖动、悬停鼠标或使用键盘（或这些操作的组合）？最常见的任务是否易于完成，而无需多次单击鼠标和在屏幕上大量移动眼球？控件是否在适当的情况下遵循了类型惯例？

2.    Create deliverable. It’s much easier to implement this in digital form if you have something to start from. Take a sheet of graph paper and draw a large, to-scale rectangle on it, and start drawing the screen elements in. Use a pencil and experiment with different placements. Think about the tasks a player wants to perform, like leveling up or looking up character stats. How does the player accomplish these tasks: clicking, double-clicking, clicking-and-dragging, hovering the mouse, or using the keyboard (or some combination of these)? Are the most common tasks easy to do, without requiring many mouse clicks and heavy movement of eyeballs around the screen? Do the controls follow genre convention, where appropriate?

3.    实现数字原型（可选）。要改进您的设计，请在计算机上实现它。使用您熟悉的任何开发工具（流行的选择包括 Microsoft Visual Basic 和 Adob​​e Flash）。首先，处理非交互式组件，例如显示不会改变的当前统计数据。（您可以使用虚构的数字。）然后创建可以操作的交互式部分：升级、丢弃物品以及装备/取消装备武器和法术书的能力。最后，添加对 UI 有意义的图形修饰：例如，使事物发光或闪烁以吸引玩家的注意力。

3.    Implement a digital prototype (optional). To improve your design, implement it on a computer. Use whatever development tools you have available and are familiar with (popular choices include Microsoft Visual Basic and Adobe Flash). First, take care of the non-interactive components, such as the display of current stats that don’t change. (You can use made-up numbers.) Then create the interactive parts that can be manipulated: the ability to level up, drop items, and equip/unequip weapons and spellbooks. Lastly, add graphical polish that is meaningful to the UI: make things glow or sparkle to attract the player’s attention, for example.

4.    游戏测试和迭代（可选）。试用数字原型并执行您设计的所有任务。它们是否像您想象的那么简单？如果没有，请返回并修改原型。如果存在导致原型崩溃或无法正常运行的错误，只要您的设计意图可以观察到，这是可以接受的。找一些熟悉该类型的朋友或同事，看他们玩您的原型。让他们完成某些任务，看看他们会怎么做。他们是否尝试过意想不到的事情？他们是否因为不了解控件而无法完成您为他们设置的任务？记下它并重新制作原型以进行弥补。

4.    Playtest and iterate (optional). Try out your digital prototype and perform all of the tasks that you designed. Are they as easy as you thought they’d be? If not, go back and alter your prototype. If there are bugs that cause the prototype to crash or otherwise not function properly, this can be acceptable, as long as your design intent can be observed. Find some friends or colleagues who are familiar with the genre and watch them play with your prototype. Ask them to accomplish certain tasks and see what they do. Do they ever try something unexpected? Are they unable to accomplish the task you set them because they don’t understand the controls? Make a note of it and redo your prototype to compensate.

挑战 4 — 主机 RTS

CHALLENGE 4 — THE CONSOLE RTS

自从该类型游戏诞生以来，实时战略游戏几乎都是专门为 PC 开发的，因为该类型游戏非常适合鼠标/键盘控制。当为游戏机开发 RTS 游戏时，它通常是从 PC 游戏直接移植而来，而且通常很糟糕。为什么？因为控制方案发生了如此彻底的变化，以至于它也导致了游戏机制的意外变化，从而使游戏变得与以前大不相同。

Since the invention of the genre, real-time strategy games have been developed almost exclusively for PC, because the genre lends itself well to mouse/keyboard control. When an RTS game is developed for console, it’s usually a direct port from a PC title, and it’s usually terrible. Why? The control scheme changes so radically that it also causes an unintentional change in the game mechanics, thus rendering the game something other than what it used to be.

在本次挑战中，您将加入索尼设计团队，负责将 PC 上的现代 RTS 游戏移植到 PlayStation 3。您可以选择游戏并期望索尼能够获得许可。唯一的限制是您不能选择之前已移植到此游戏机的游戏。

For this challenge, you are on a design team working for Sony, tasked with porting a modern RTS game on PC to the PlayStation 3. You may choose the game and expect that Sony is able to procure the license. The only restriction is that you may not choose a game that has previously been ported to this console.

您需要使用默认的六轴控制器（例如，不需要 USB 鼠标/键盘来玩游戏）。好的一面是，您可以自由更改游戏机制，只要您保留原始游戏的一般故事情节和感觉即可。此外，您不必担心单个控制台上的多人游戏。假设单人游戏对抗 AI 对手或多人在线游戏。

You are expected to use the default six-axis controller (for example, no fair requiring a USB mouse/keyboard to play the game). On the bright side, you have been given free license to change the game mechanics, as long as you keep the general storyline and feel of the original game. Also, you do not have to worry about multiplayer on a single console. Assume either single player against AI opponents or multiplayer online.

您必须解决将 UI 从一个平台移植到另一个平台的问题。由于这是移植，因此您无需担心游戏的其余设计，以满足此挑战。

You must solve the problem of porting the UI from one platform to another. Since this is a port, you don’t have to worry about the rest of the game’s design for the purposes of this challenge.

所需组件

Components Required

·      用于研究的互联网连接

·      Internet connection for research

·      原版 PC 游戏（可选）

·      Original PC game (optional)

可交付成果

Deliverable

·      主游戏屏幕（以及子屏幕，如果有）的屏幕模型

·      Screen mockup of the main gameplay screen (and subscreens, if any)

·      每个屏幕的所有游戏控制列表。使用控制器图表并显示每个按钮的效果。

·      A list of all gameplay controls for each screen. Use a diagram of the controller and show the effects of each button.

建议流程

Suggested Process

1.    研究原版游戏。熟悉游戏，包括：故事情节和整体外观和感觉/玩家在游戏过程中可以采取的行动 / 核心机制。玩游戏，或阅读专业评论并查看屏幕截图。决定游戏的哪些方面必须保留，哪些方面（如果有的话）可以更改而不会破坏体验。

1.    Research the original game. Familiarize yourself with the game, including: Storyline and overall look and feel / Actions that the player can take during the game / Core mechanics. Play the game, or read professional reviews and look at screenshots. Decide what aspects of the game must be preserved, and which (if any) can be changed without ruining the experience.

2.    寻找可能性。 截至撰写本文时，主机上成功的 RTS 游戏寥寥无几，因此您无法借鉴该类型游戏的现有惯例。相反，请考虑最有意义的可能性，并考虑玩家拥有的其他类型的游戏和其他非游戏体验。

2.    Find affordances. As of the time of this writing, there have been few, if any, successful RTS games on console, so you do not have the benefit of existing conventions to draw on in this genre. Instead, consider the affordances that would make the most sense, and consider other kinds of games and other non-game experience that your players have.

3.    决定——改变机制还是改变 UI？对于游戏中的每个 UI 元素，找到在主机上最自然的映射。有些元素，你可能选择保留原样；其他的，你可能会改变，让游戏在新平台上玩起来更容易或更自然。

3.    Decide—change the mechanics or change the UI? For each UI element in the game, find the most natural mapping on console. Some elements, you might choose to preserve as is; others, you might change to make the game easier or more natural to play on the new platform.

4.    创建可交付成果。

4.    Create deliverable.

铁人设计师挑战 5 — 隐形界面（直播）

IRON DESIGNER CHALLENGE 5—INVISIBLE INTERFACE (LIVE)

想想你最喜欢的动作片。明白了吗？很好。想想这个——如果它是你最喜欢的电影，你很可能会完全沉浸在它的世界里，能够感受到悬念、焦虑、危险等等，而这一切都不需要 HUD 的帮助。过山车和其他主题公园游乐设施也明显没有 HUD。一些设计师开始问：“为什么电子游戏需要 HUD？”

Think of your favorite action movie. Got it? Good. Consider this—if it’s your favorite movie, odds are you feel completely immersed in its world and are able to feel suspense, anxiety, sense danger, and so on all without the aid of a HUD. Roller coasters and other theme park rides are also noticeably HUD free. Some designers are beginning to ask, “Why do we need HUDs in video games?”

在计算机和视频游戏的早期，没有颜色和图形来传达某人的感觉。因此游戏开发者用数字列出健康状况。你想知道法师 Zynaryx 的健康状况吗？它是 38/50。渐渐地，图形取代了文字来向我们展示而不是告诉我们。有些游戏甚至完全放弃了 HUD。最早这样做的游戏之一是Fight Night Round 3。游戏通过多种方式传达信息，包括：

In the early days of computer and video games, there were no colors and no graphics to convey how well someone was feeling. So game developers listed health numerically. You want to know Zynaryx the Mage’s health? It’s 38/50. Gradually, graphics took over text to show us instead of tell us. Some games are going so far as to abandon the HUD entirely. One of the earliest games to do this was Fight Night Round 3. The game conveyed information in a number of ways including these:

·      当战士们疲惫不堪时，他们的移动速度会变得更慢，而且他们的手臂会放低。

·      As fighters tire, they move more slowly, and their arms drop lower in their stance.

·      玩家亲眼看到角色受到了多么严重的伤害。

·      The player sees just how hurt the character is in flesh and blood.

·      人群通过站立、坐下和欢呼来表达兴奋之情。

·      The crowd shows its excitement by standing, sitting, and cheering.

·      场边播音员将持续对游戏进行评论。

·      The ringside announcer provides ongoing gameplay commentary.

如果电影不需要HUD，我们为什么需要？

If movies don’t need HUDs, why do we?

对于这个挑战，将玩家分成 2 到 4 人一组。选择任何 RPG、RTS 或 FPS，并将该游戏交给另一组。您的目标很明确，但也很有挑战性：想办法移除您游戏的 HUD，但要为玩家提供他们需要知道的一切。

For this challenge, divide into groups of two to four people. Choose any RPG, RTS, or FPS and give that game to another group. Your goal is clear, but challenging: figure out a way to remove the HUD of the game you’re saddled with, but provide the player everything he needs to know.

所需组件

Components Required

·      网络连接，用于查看游戏截图

·      Internet connection, to view screenshots of your game

可交付成果

Deliverable

·      原始游戏主屏幕的手绘模型，带有 HUD，或打印的屏幕截图（用于比较）

·      Hand-drawn mockup of the main screen of the original game, with HUD, or a printed screenshot (for comparison)

·      手绘主屏幕模型，适用于现在没有 HUD 的游戏

·      Hand-drawn mockup of the main screen for your now HUD-less game

·      用文字描述旧 HUD 中的信息现在如何传达给玩家，以防屏幕模型无法直观地显示

·      Text description of how the information in the old HUD is now conveyed to the player, in cases where it is not obvious from your screen mockup

建议流程

Suggested Process

1.    从截图开始。 查看原始游戏的 HUD，列出所有必须删除的屏幕元素。你可以一次解决一个问题，独立解决。

1.    Start with a screenshot. Look at the HUD of the original game and make a list of all screen elements that you must remove. You can tackle these one at a time, independently.

2.    集思广益。对于HUD的每个元素，想出尽可能多的方法来表示相同的信息。

2.    Brainstorm. For each element of the HUD, come up with as many ways as you can think of to represent that same information.

3.    碰撞检查。 确保不要将两个 HUD 元素映射到同一事物。例如，如果在角色生命值低下时以及在受到加速法术影响时改变角色的颜色，如果两者同时发生，事情可能会变得混乱。尽量保持您的表示彼此不同，尤其 是对于两个彼此无关的信息。

3.    Collision checking. Make sure that you don’t map two HUD elements to the same thing. For example, if you change a character’s color when it is running low on health and also when it is under the influence of a Haste spell, things could get confusing if both happen at the same time. Try to keep your representations distinct from one another, especially for two bits of information that have nothing to do with each other.

4.    优化。HUD并不是现代 UI 中唯一不切实际的方面。在现实世界中，图标和名称不会漂浮在玩家头顶，执行操作时文本也不会凭空出现。让一切尽可能逼真，以提高玩家的沉浸感。

4.    Optimize. The HUD isn’t the only unrealistic aspect of modern UI. Icons and names don’t float over people’s heads in the real world, nor does text appear out of thin air when you perform an action. Make things as realistic as possible to improve player immersion.

5.    创建可交付成果。

5.    Create deliverable.

推荐阅读

RECOMMENDED READING

如果你想更深入地了解 UI，以下书籍会很有帮助：

If you would like to gain a deeper understanding of UI, the following books are helpful:

·       《日常事物的设计》，作者：唐纳德·诺曼。这本书探讨了日常设备（如门、厨房炉灶和收音机闹钟）的用户界面。诺曼详细介绍了可供性和可用性的使用。一旦你意识到像门这样简单的东西可能很难使用，你就不会再以同样的方式看待游戏的HUD了。

·      The Design of Everyday Things, by Donald Norman. This book explores the UI of everyday devices such as doors, kitchen stoves, and radio alarm clocks. Norman goes into great detail on the use of affordances and usability. Once you realize how something as simple as a door can be difficult to use, you will never look at a game’s HUD in the same way.

·      视觉解释：图像和数量、证据和叙述，作者：Edward Tufte。尽管遵守了所有类型的惯例，但人们可能会认为只有一两种方法来显示生命值或弹药数量。Tufte 打破了这种幻想，展示了显示重要信息的多种不同方式，以及每种方式的优缺点。

·      Visual Explanations: Images and Quantities, Evidence and Narrative, by Edward Tufte. For all the adherence to genre conventions, one might think that there are only one or two ways to display a life meter or ammo count. Tufte shatters this illusion, showing many different ways to display important information, and the benefits and drawbacks of each.

·      面向程序员的用户界面设计，作者：Joel Spolsky。这本书之所以“面向程序员”，唯一的原因是它用过于逻辑的程序员也能理解的术语来解释事情。这本书几乎没有实际的编程内容。相反，这本书用通俗易懂的英语解释了什么是好的软件 UI 设计、它为什么重要，以及任何人（即使是毫无人类同理心的程序员）如何创建反应灵敏的软件。如果文字处理器的良好 UI 可以让人开心，想象一下，当你将这些经验应用到娱乐游戏中时会发生什么！

·      User Interface Design for Programmers, by Joel Spolsky. The only reason this book is “for programmers” is that it explains things in terms that overly logical programmers can understand. There is little to no actual programming in this book. Rather, this book explains in plain English what good software UI design is, why it is important, and how anyone (even a programmer with no human empathy whatsoever) can create software that feels responsive. If a good UI for a word processor can make people happy, imagine what can happen when you apply these lessons to an entertainment game!



 

 

17：游戏即艺术

17: Games as Art

当本书的一位作者在 2007 年决定创建一款文字冒险游戏时，显然不是出于商业原因。事实上，她不是出于职业原因，也不是为任何特定的人或客户着想。相反，她之所以创建这款游戏，是因为她相信，很久以前的电子游戏具有某种美感，那时玩家可以直接与设计师交谈，设计师也可以回应。

When one of the authors of this book decided to create a text adventure game in 2007, it clearly wasn’t for commercial reasons. In fact, it wasn’t for professional reasons or with any particular person or client in mind. Rather, she created the game because she believed that there was a certain beauty in video games of long ago, when the player could talk directly with the designer, and the designer could talk back.

这种游戏就是所谓的“艺术游戏”，即为表达艺术观点或具有艺术意图而制作的游戏。在某种程度上，所有游戏都可以被视为艺术游戏，因为游戏本身就是一种互动艺术。然而，与传统游戏相比，被归类为艺术游戏的游戏往往具有故意不完全符合任何特定类型或我们对特定类型的期望的设计。

That game is what one might refer to as an “art game,” a game created to make an artistic statement or with artistic intent. To some degree, all games can be considered art games since games themselves are a form of interactive art. In contrast to traditional games, though, games classified as art games tend to feature designs that purposefully don’t fit neatly within any particular genre or within the conventions we expect from a particular genre.

不幸的是，“艺术”的定义比“游戏”的定义更具争议性。所以当你把两者放在一起时，这是一个定义雷区。为了本章的目的，我们将完全回避这个问题，从另一个领域窃取一个伪定义——当你看到它时，你就知道这是一款艺术游戏。

Unfortunately, the definition of “art” is even more contentious than the definition for “game.” So when you put the two together, it’s a definition minefield. For the sake of this chapter, we will evade the issue entirely by stealing a pseudo-definition from another space—you know an art game when you see it.

就像人们创作歌曲、绘画、电影、纪录片、书籍、诗歌和口语表演一样，设计师也利用数字游戏来表达观点、陈述和探索某个特定的想法或理想。

Just as people have created songs, paintings, movies, documentaries, books, poems, and spoken-word performances, so, too, are designers embracing digital games to make a point, a statement, and an exploration of a particular idea or ideal.

超越视觉

BEYOND THE VISUAL

在游戏中，艺术并不总是视觉化的。这听起来有点奇怪。事实上，许多游戏确实拥有令人惊叹的画面，环境和角色令人叹为观止。随着处理能力的提高，毫无疑问，建模师、动画师、纹理艺术家、关卡设计师、装配工和环境艺术家确实在创造艺术。许多人都同意 8 位艺术也有美感，而且今天许多人仍在从事这种媒介的工作。

In games, the art is not always visual. This may seem like an odd statement to make. Indeed, many games do have amazing graphics with environments and characters that are breathtaking. As processing power increases, there is no doubt that the modelers, animators, texture artists, level designers, riggers, and environmental artists are indeed creating art. Many would agree that there is beauty in 8-bit art, too, and many are still working in that medium today.

然而，游戏中也有艺术，游戏根本不需要有图形才能成为游戏。正如我们在第 2 章“游戏设计原子”中探讨的那样，游戏是组件的集合——机制、系统、玩家、目标等等。因此，在将游戏视为艺术时，重要的是要超越可见的东西。

However, there is art in the game, too, and a game need not have graphics at all to be a game. As we explored in Chapter 2, “Game Design Atoms,” a game is a collection of components—mechanics, systems, players, goals, and more. So, when considering a game as art, it is important to look beyond that which can be seen.

人们总是倾向于先根据画面来判断游戏，这是一种习得反应。有些人仅仅基于这种印象就否定了一款游戏。这是一件不幸的事情。

It is a temptation—a form of learned response—for people to judge games first by their graphics. Some dismiss a game based on this impression alone. This is an unfortunate thing.

奇怪的是，许多人追求游戏中的出色图形，却因平淡无奇的游戏体验而感到失望。当下一代多边形游戏问世时，这种体验很少会被人们所记住。

Oddly enough, there are many who chase great graphics in games, only to be disappointed by lackluster gameplay. That experience is rarely remembered when the next polygonal powerhouse comes along.

如果将游戏视为一组受规则支配的交互系统，那么在适当的情况下，游戏实际上可以比其他艺术媒体更富有表现力。想象一下，在阳光明媚的日子里，躺在山上凝视云朵时，会激发出孩童般的好奇和想象力。一本书可以详细描述这种感觉。一部电影可以展示一个孩子的外部反应。一首歌可以试图激起听众的相同情感。但游戏实际上可以让玩家亲身体验这种情感，而这是非交互式媒体无法做到的。事实上，这就是游戏Cloud所做的。这种感觉不是来自图像或音乐，而是直接来自游戏玩法。

If one considers the game as a set of interacting systems that are governed by a set of rules, games can actually be more expressive than other artistic media in the right circumstances. Consider the emotion of childlike wonder and imagination invoked by lying on a hill and gazing up at the clouds on a bright, sunny day. A book can describe the feeling in great detail. A movie can show an individual child’s external reactions. A song can attempt to stir those same emotions in the listener. But a game can actually let the player experience this emotion first hand, in a way that is impossible with noninteractive media. This is, in fact, what the game Cloud does. This feeling comes not from the graphics or music, but directly from the gameplay.

在探索游戏艺术时，重要的是要超越图像，关注底层体验。下面评论的Passage就是人们可能拥有的体验的完美示例。

When exploring a game as art, it is important to look beyond the graphics to the underlying experience. Passage, reviewed below, is a perfect example of an experience one might have.

有些游戏将视觉效果与游戏机制相结合，创造出艺术效果。《迷失在静态中》就是这样一款游戏。它的特点是屏幕上呈现黑白静态。游戏在静态中进行，通过创建多个静态场并利用这些场中的差异向玩家提供必要的信息。

Some games mingle the visuals with the mechanics to create art. Lost in the Static is one such game. It features black-and-white static on a screen. The game takes place within that static by creating multiple static fields and using the differences in those fields to give necessary information to the player.

棋盘游戏，例如Fluxx 以及之前的Cosmic Encounter和Nomic，都采用了固定、约束和不变的规则概念，这种概念有时被用作游戏的定义概念。然而，这两款游戏的规则都挑战了这一概念，而这种挑战也可以说是艺术。

Board games like Fluxx and, before it, Cosmic Encounter and Nomic, play with the concept of fixed, binding, and unchanging rules that is sometimes used as a defining concept of a game. However, the rules of both of these games challenge that concept, and in that challenge, there is something one could call art, too.

乐趣无穷

BEYOND FUN

对于大多数人来说，坐下来玩游戏是一种逃避、一种娱乐形式，而且非常有趣。它很少涉及对某个概念的深刻思考或艺术探索。它几乎从不涉及我们不想感受甚至不想去想的东西。这并不是说游戏没有所有这些主题，但这些主题很少是游戏的重点。然而，随着“艺术游戏”的出现，这种情况正在改变。

For most people, sitting down to play a game is an escape, a form of entertainment, and a whole lot of fun. It’s rarely about deep thoughts or artistic explorations of a concept. It’s almost never about feeling something we’d rather not feel or even think about. That’s not to say that games don’t have all of these themes and more, but rarely are these themes the point of the game. With the advent of “art games,” though, this is changing.

游戏是一种富有表现力的媒介，新一代互动艺术家已经开始探索这种媒介的艺术潜力。目前，艺术家和开发者只触及了其巨大潜力的皮毛。此外，游戏不需要娱乐性就可以被视为“游戏”。它们甚至不需要特别有趣。游戏可以表达艺术家想让它们表达的任何内容。

Games are an expressive medium, and a new breed of interactive artist has begun to explore this medium for its artistic potential. At present, artists and developers are only scratching the surface of the tremendous potential that lies underneath. Furthermore, games need not entertain to be considered “a game.” They don’t even need to be especially fun. Games can say whatever the artist wants them to say.

在接下来的章节中，我们将探索两款这样的游戏，并更深入地探索游戏作为艺术。与之前的章节不同，我们避开了传统的“如何”探索。相反，我们将通过其他人的话语来探索概念、游戏和论点。

In the following sections, we’ll explore two such games, as well as a deeper exploration of games as art. Unlike previous chapters, we have sidestepped the traditional “how to” exploration. Rather, we’ll provide an exploration of the concepts, the games, and the argument through the words of others.

通道：一款差点让我哭的游戏——游戏设计师帕特里克·杜根

PASSAGE: A GAME THAT ALMOST MADE ME CRY—PATRICK DUGAN, GAME DESIGNER

以下评论由 Patrick Dugan 于 2007 年 12 月 6 日撰写，并发表在评论独立游戏的网站 Play This Thing (http://playthisthing.com/passage) 上。经许可在此转载。

The following review was authored by Patrick Dugan on December 6, 2007 and appeared on Play This Thing (http://playthisthing.com/passage), a site that reviews indie games. It is reprinted here with permission.

Passage的创建者 Jason Rohrer在他的网站上发表了一份创建者声明，但他希望您在阅读声明之前先玩一下这款游戏。您可以在他的网站上找到该声明：http://hcsoftware.sourceforge.net/passage/。

On his site, Passage’s creator, Jason Rohrer, includes a creator’s statement, but he hopes you play the game before reading it. You can find that statement on his site at: http://hcsoftware.sourceforge.net/passage/.

制作此类游戏是 Rohrer 的全职工作。他免费提供游戏和软件。他通过网站上的捐款获得支持。

The production of such games is Rohrer’s full-time job. He gives away his games and software for free. He is supported through donations on his site.

Passage是一款特殊的游戏，由一位不同寻常的游戏开发者制作。Jason Rohrer 和他的妻子和孩子住在纽约州北部的一间小屋里。这间小屋经过特殊隔热处理，可在冬季保持温暖；它有收集雨水的装置，后院还有一个设施齐全的花园。因此，Jason 和他的家人每月的生活费约为 800 美元。他拥有计算机科学硕士学位，并有网络应用程序开发经验，但他不玩美国企业的游戏。相反，他是自由的，他可以自由地制作精美的艺术游戏，这些游戏就像他的房子一样，在技术和体验上都十分紧凑，可以自给自足。

Passage is a special kind of game made by an unusual kind of game developer. Jason Rohrer lives with his wife and child in a cabin in upstate New York. This cabin is specially insulated to maintain heat during the winter; it has a means of collecting rainwater and a fully implemented garden in the back yard. As a result, Jason and his family live on around $800 a month. He has an MS in Computer Science and experience doing network applications, but he doesn’t play the Corporate America game. Instead, he’s free, and he’s free to make beautiful art games that, like his house, are technically and experientially tight to the point of self-sufficiency.

《Passage》讲述的是穿越迷宫的真正过程，但它也讲述了时间的流逝。你一开始是个年轻人；你的北边是一堵墙，你可以向右移动，也可以探索南边的迷宫。一开始你会遇到一个女人；如果你碰到她，你会爱上她并成为她的伴侣。你们一起走过人生，就像壁纸的变化一样；你们一起变老，一起探索。

Passage is about the literal passage through a maze, but it is also about the passage of time. You begin as a young man; you have a wall foregrounded directly to your north, and can move to the right or explore the maze to the south. Early on you encounter a woman; if you bump into her, you will fall in love and become her companion. Together, you walk through life, illustrated as a variation in wallpaper; you age together, you explore together.

向下探索涉及算法生成的柱子和墙壁，你需要通过它们找到宝箱（代表金钱或成功或其他东西），或者可能只是为了看看你能走多远是否有极限（这个限制是算法不可避免的副产品，你走得越远，墙壁出现的频率就越高）。和女人在一起会限制你的探索范围，然而，这正是游戏天才之处；我非常乐意放弃更容易探索的实用性，以获得不孤单的好处。我说的是八色像素精灵让我感觉到最终幻想只能通过廉价（阅读：极其昂贵）的 CG 技巧和专业配音以非交互方式实现的东西。

Exploring downward involves an algorithmically generated smattering of pillars and walls that you navigate in order to find treasure chests (representing money or success or something) or maybe just to see if there’s an ultimate limit to how far down you can go (this limit is an inevitable byproduct of the algorithm, which increases the frequency of walls the further you go). Being with the woman limits how much you can explore, and yet, this is where the game’s genius shone through for me; I was more than happy to give up the utility of easier exploration for the benefit of not being alone. I’m talking about eight-color pixel sprites making me feel something that Final Fantasy could only pull off noninteractively with cheap (read: extremely expensive) parlor tricks of CG and professional voice acting.

平衡探索与进步机制是屏幕视图的限制；您一次只能看到一行，这实际上给人一种感觉，您不是在探索迷宫，而是在探索一生。进一步充实这个比喻的是像素堆叠效果。一开始，您可以辨认出远距离阶段的像素图案，但它们只是单列像素，随着您的进步，它们会一层一层地拉长。一旦你过了中年，重点就会转移：现在大多数堆叠的像素都在你身后，你会发现自己越来越靠近屏幕的最右边缘。这既是一个有趣的视觉效果，也是我见过的对 Phi 概念的最佳说明。

Balancing the exploration vs. progress mechanic is the limitation of the screen view; you’re only able to see a single row at a time, which effectively gives a sense that you aren’t exploring a maze but a lifetime. Further fleshing out this metaphor is the pixel-stacking effect. At the beginning, you can make out the pixel patterns of distant phases, but they’re only single columns of pixels, and as you progress they become elongated layer by layer. Once you pass mid-life, the emphasis shifts: now most of the stacked pixels are behind you, and you find yourself centered closer and closer to the right-most edge of the screen. This is both an interesting visual effect and the best illustration of the concept of Phi that I have ever seen.

无论你是尝试探索更多，还是追求漫长、稳定、重复的平庸生活，你都会变老、变白，最终你的妻子也会死去。当你看到这一切突然发生时，你可能会感受到比艾瑞斯被刺穿时更戏剧化、更真实的东西。你可能会感受到一种真正的失落感，五分钟的情感投入带来的反噬，然后你也会在标题再次出现时倒地不起。

Whether you try to explore a lot or you go for the boring mediocrity of a long, stable, repetitive life, you will become old and gray, and eventually your wife will die. And when you see this happen, so abruptly, you may feel something more dramatic and real than when Aireth was impaled. You may feel a genuine sense of loss, blow-back from a five-minute emotional investment, and then you too will collapse to dust while the title passes over again.

哥伦拜恩、电子游戏作为表达方式和不可言喻性 - 伊恩·博格斯特，说服性游戏

COLUMBINE, VIDEOGAMES AS EXPRESSION, AND INEFFABILITY - IAN BOGOST, PERSUASIVE GAMES

以下文章由 Ian Bogost 博士于 2006 年 5 月 21 日撰写，并发表于 Water Cooler Games (http://www.watercoolergames.org/archives/000558.shtml)。经许可在此转载。

The following article was authored by Dr. Ian Bogost on May 21, 2006 and published on Water Cooler Games (http://www.watercoolergames.org/archives/000558.shtml). It is reprinted here with permission.

Super Columbine Massacre RPG是一款由 Danny Ledonne 设计和制作的游戏。它探索了发生在哥伦拜恩高中的令人不安的事件。该游戏可在 http://www.columbinegame.com 上在线获取。Super Columbine Massacre RPG的艺术家声明可在 http://www.columbinegame.com/statement.htm 上找到。

Super Columbine Massacre RPG is a game designed and created by Danny Ledonne. It is an exploration of the disturbing events that took place at Columbine High School. It is available online at http://www.columbinegame.com. The artist statement for Super Columbine Massacre RPG can be found at http://www.columbinegame.com/statement.htm.

《Super Columbine Massacre RPG》让玩家扮演 Eric Harris 和 Dylan Klebold 的角色，试图描绘出他们在那个可怕日子的动机、计划和行动。这当然是一个有争议的话题，但这正是我们在电子游戏中应该探讨的主题：难以解决的难题。

Super Columbine Massacre RPG puts the player in the shoes of Eric Harris and Dylan Klebold and attempts to paint a picture of their motivations, plans, and actions on that terrible day. It’s a controversial topic to be sure, but exactly the kind of subject we should be taking on in videogames: hard problems for which there are no easy answers.

我知道公众对这款游戏的反应会非常负面。我因为谈论这款游戏就收到了很多仇恨邮件。但我认为我并没有完全准备好面对伴随这款游戏而来的普遍无知。我认为我们这些深陷“严肃游戏”、“变革游戏”或“有议程的电子游戏”甚至只是电子游戏开发领域的人低估了我们还有多么长的路要走，才能让电子游戏成为与电影、文学和艺术相称的表达媒介。

I knew that public reaction to the game would be largely negative. I’ve received plenty of hate mail just for talking about the game. But I don’t think I was fully prepared for the widespread ignorance that has accompanied reception to the game. I think those of us deeply mired in the fields of Serious Games or Games for Change or Videogames with an Agenda or even just videogame development underestimate just how long a road we still have to tread for videogames to be treated as a medium of expression commensurate with film, literature, and art.

在我报道之后，Kotaku 的 Brian Crecente 采访了一位哥伦拜恩高中的幸存者，采访内容非常精彩、细致，而且很有启发性。他随后为《落基山新闻》撰写了一篇文章，标题很谨慎，说是“游戏重新揭开哥伦拜恩高中的伤痛”。文章内容均衡，采访了受害者家属、幸存者以及当时仍匿名的游戏创作者。Brian 随后还在 Kotaku 上发布了对创作者的完整采访。所有这些报道都非常好，无论是作为一般新闻报道，还是作为对一个不寻常游戏的报道。

After my coverage, Kotaku’s Brian Crecente interviewed a Columbine survivor about the game, a terrific, careful, and enlightening piece of coverage. He then wrote an article for the Rocky Mountain News with the careful headline “Game reopens Columbine wounds.” The article was balanced, including interviews with victims’ families, with survivors, and with the game’s then-still-anonymous creator. Brian then also posted the full interview with the creator on Kotaku. All of this coverage was very good, both as journalism generally and as videogame coverage of an unusual specimen.

随后美联社电讯报获得了该消息。

Then the AP wire got their hands on it.

通讯社很危险。他们从当地消息来源摘取“最佳”新闻，将其剪辑成简短的片段，然后将其发送到世界各地进行转载。布莱恩的精彩报道被缩减为篇幅和细节的一小部分。但更有趣的是，这个故事被重新命名，并在各地再次重新命名。“重新揭开旧伤疤”的谨慎含糊被扭曲为全面的反对和谴责。《今日美国》将其报道为“科伦拜恩视频游戏引起亲属的愤怒”。丹佛当地电视新闻节目将其报道为“科伦拜恩视频游戏引发抗议和厌恶”。您可以在 Google 新闻上找到其他内容。

Wire services are dangerous. They pull the “best” news from local sources, cut it down into sound-bites, and then send it out all over the world for reprinting. Brian’s fantastic coverage was cut down to a fraction of the size and detail. But more interestingly, the story got retitled, and retitled again everywhere. The careful ambiguity of “reopening old wounds” was contorted into wholesale disapproval and censure. USA Today ran it as “Columbine video game draws relatives’ ire.” A local Denver TV news program ran it as “Columbine Video Game Sparks Protest, Disgust.” You can find others at Google News.

美联社的报道引起了广泛关注，这引来了更多媒体的报道，其中最重要的是昨天《华盛顿邮报》上游戏作家 Jose Antonio Vargas 的报道。Vargas 解释说，在哥伦拜恩高中一名受害者的朋友设法辨别出他的身份并将其发布到游戏讨论板上后，游戏创作者的身份被“曝光”。Danny Ledonne 现已公开承认自己是该游戏的创作者。

The widespread attention the AP wire story brought only begat more press coverage, the most important of which is yesterday’s Washington Post story by frequent game writer Jose Antonio Vargas. Vargas explained that the creator had been “outed” after a friend of one of the Columbine victims managed to discern his identity and post it to the game’s discussion boards. Danny Ledonne has now gone on the record as the game’s creator.

但对我来说， 《华盛顿邮报》这篇报道最有趣的地方在于，瓦尔加斯如何将电子游戏描述为一种文化评论。请看以下报道：

But for me, the most interesting feature of the Washington Post story is how Vargas characterizes the role of videogames as cultural commentary. Take a look at this:

...这款以 1999 年科罗拉多州利特尔顿哥伦拜恩高中枪击事件为背景的游戏如今引发了争议，这并不奇怪。

...it’s no surprise that the game, based on the 1999 shootings at Columbine High School in Littleton, Colo., now is generating controversy.

有一部纪录片（《科伦拜恩的保龄球》）、一部电影（《大象》）和几本书（《没有简单的答案》、《清算日》）来讲述那个黑暗的日子是一回事，但有一款游戏则是另一回事。

For it’s one thing to have a documentary (“Bowling for Columbine”), a movie (“Elephant”), and several books (“No Easy Answers,” “Day of Reckoning”) about that dark day, but it’s quite another to have a game.

Vargas 并没有以任何方式扩展或支持这一说法。为什么制作一款关于科伦拜恩的游戏“完全是另一回事”？是因为电子游戏没有能力解决这些问题吗？还是因为它们确实有，但公众不理解？Vargas 没有提出自己的观点，而是诉诸情感来解释。这一段紧接着上面引用的那段：

Vargas does not expand or support this claim in any way. Why is it “quite another thing” to have a game about Columbine? Is it because video games do not have the power to address such issues? Is it because they do, but the public does not understand them? Vargas does not offer his opinion, but instead uses an appeal to emotion to explain it away. This paragraph follows the one cited above:

“有电子游戏吗？”当天遇害的教师威廉“戴夫”桑德斯的遗孀琳达桑德斯震惊地问道。“发生了什么事？”

“There’s a video game?” asked a shocked Linda Sanders, widow of William “Dave” Sanders, a teacher slain that day. “On what happened?”

她心烦意乱，说不出话来。

She was too distraught to keep talking.

当然，我们的心与桑德斯女士以及那天失去朋友和亲人的所有人同在。她对关于“科伦拜恩的保龄球”或“清算日”的采访会有同样的反应吗？很难说。但是，对于我们这些对电子游戏表达感兴趣的人而言，媒体中的一件作品先验地具有伤害性、破坏性、不道德、腐败或其他令人反感的观点应该发出巨大的警告。尽管媒体广泛报道，但新闻报道并不是关于游戏对科伦拜恩的表现。它们是关于存在以某种方式代表科伦拜恩的游戏这一事实。显然，这些故事的大多数作者、受访者和读者都没有玩过这款游戏（自本月初这些故事曝光以来，该游戏的下载量已达到 30,000 次，考虑到巨大的曝光率，这个数字相对较小）。许多打电话给我询问这款游戏的记者都承认他们没有玩过，声称他们的办公室电脑出现了技术问题，或者在我催促他们下载时遇到了麻烦。

Of course, our hearts go out to Ms. Sanders and everyone who lost friends and loved ones that day. Would she have had the same reaction to an interview about “Bowling for Columbine?” Or about “Day of Reckoning?” It’s hard to say. But the notion that an artifact in a medium about a subject is a priori hurtful, damaging, immoral, corrupt, or otherwise objectionable should send up a huge red flag for those of us interested in video-game expression. Despite the widespread press coverage, the news stories are not about the game’s representation of Columbine. They are about the fact that a game that represents Columbine in some way exists. Clearly most of the authors, interviewees, and readers of these stories have not played the game (which has logged 30,000 downloads since these stories broke earlier this month, a relatively small number given the massive exposure). Many of the journalists who have called me about the game have admitted that they haven’t played it, claiming technical problems with their office computers or trouble downloading when I press them.

如果他玩过这款游戏，也许纽约锡拉丘兹市 News 10 的 Brian Dwyer 就不会说“这类游戏证明了反暴力项目的重要性”，因为游戏中的暴力令人深感不安，旨在迫使玩家考虑导致这些男孩采取致命行动的可怕和悲惨的状况。

If he had played it, perhaps Brian Dwyer of News 10 in Syracuse, New York wouldn’t have argued that “games like this prove just how important anti-violence programs are,” since the violence in the game is deeply disturbing and meant to force the player to consider the dire and tragic state of affairs that made these boys take the fateful actions they did.

也许《纽约邮报》的斯蒂芬妮·科恩不会在她的文章中把这款游戏的创作者称为“扭曲的”和“病态的”，她也许明白这款游戏的“业余场景”和“笨拙的二维图形”会让人联想到哈里斯和克莱伯德致命的业余主义。

Perhaps Stefanie Cohen of the New York Post might not have called the game’s creator “twisted” and “sick” in her article, and she may have understood that the game’s “amateurish scenes” and “clumsy 2-D graphics” invoke the fatal amateurism of Harris and Klebold.

读者们，我们的工作已经做好了。我们必须提醒自己，公众舆论和大众媒体更愿意从震撼人心的报道中获取比认真、经过研究的新闻报道更多的利益。尽管像 Brian Crecente 这样的游戏记者相对享有盛誉和价值，但他们的工作迎合了我们这些已经对电子游戏有深入了解的人。一旦这些故事进入更广泛的媒体，我们就可以预料到会出现天真、无知和新闻懒惰的情况。也不要指望电子软件协会 (ESA) 的支持；虽然他们是电子游戏言论的主要支持者，但他们也得到了主要出版商的资助，作为说客，因此只支持那些企业利益。

Readers, we have our work cut out for us. We must remind ourselves that public opinion and the popular press gets more mileage out of sound bites for shock value than for careful, researched journalism. Despite the relative renown and value of game journalists like Brian Crecente, their work caters to those of us who already have deep video-game literacy. Once these stories get out into the broader press, we can expect naïveté, ignorance, and journalistic laziness. Don’t look for support from the Electronic Software Association (ESA) either; while they are the predominant supporters of video games as speech, they are also funded as lobbyists by the major publishers, and thus support those corporate interests alone.

最后，我想谈谈不可言喻性，这是美国政治和文化中令人不安的趋势，超出了电子游戏这一媒介的范畴。对这款游戏的常见反对意见之一是，它冒犯了或可能会冒犯悲剧的受害者及其家人。这种情绪中蕴含着这样一种观念，即任何关于困难话题或事件的表述都是禁忌。最近，我们看到了一些关于电影《联合 93 航班》的类似争论，这部电影讲述了 9/11 事件中在宾夕法尼亚州坠毁的被劫持飞机的故事。但即使是对这部电影的报道也证明了它的价值，主要是因为记者和评论家在觉得有资格写这部电影之前，实际上已经去看了这部电影。即使是在二线和三线媒体，作家们也会问“我们怎么能不看这部电影”，并认为“对于一部重要的电影来说，什么时候上映都不嫌早”。但《超级科伦拜恩大屠杀 RPG》并非如此。请看《圣安东尼奥快报》的一段社论。

Finally, I want to say something about ineffability, a disturbing trend in American politics and culture that goes beyond the medium of video games. One of the common objections to this game is that it offends, or might offend, victims of the tragedy and their families. Embedded in this sentiment is the notion that any representation about a difficult topic or event is simply off-limits. Recently, we saw some debate along these lines about the film United 93, which tells the story of the hijacked plane that crashed in Pennsylvania on 9/11. But even coverage of that film argued for its value, largely because the journalists and reviewers actually went and saw the movie before they felt qualified to write about it. Even in the second- and third-tier press, writers asked “how can we not see this film” and argued that “it’s never too soon for an important movie.” Not so for Super Columbine Massacre RPG. Consider this snippet of an editorial from the San Antonio Express-News.

[该游戏的创造者]拒绝透露自己的身份，但在接受《落基山新闻》的电子邮件采访时，他表示自己希望“就校园枪击案问题推动真正的对话”。

[The game’s creator] refused to identify himself, but in an e-mail interview with the Rocky Mountain News, he said he wanted to “promote a real dialogue on the subject of school shootings.”

...

...

如果他的意图真如他声称的那样纯粹，那么这位制片人本可以引发对话，而不会伤害那些已经受到足够伤害的亲人的感情。

If his intentions were as pure as he claims, the producer could have sparked a dialogue without assaulting the feelings of those already hurt enough—the loved ones left behind.

丹尼·莱多恩正确地指出，尽管受害者遭受了巨大的痛苦，但公众对哥伦拜恩事件的反应并不由受害者自己决定。另一个反驳者是理查德·卡斯塔尔多，他因哥伦拜恩事件受伤而腰部以下瘫痪。卡斯塔尔多谈到这款游戏时说：“我觉得这么说很奇怪，但从杀手的角度来看这款游戏，我还是欣赏它的。”当然，这就是电子游戏的力量，无论是作为媒介还是这款游戏。这并不容易，也不应该容易。试图理解杀手的观点不应该是件容易的事。但如果我们真的想避免将来再发生这样的悲剧，我们必须承认这种同理心可能会有所帮助。杰拉德·琼斯在他那本精彩的著作《杀死怪物》中指出，一系列复杂的因素导致了校园枪击案的发生，其中最重要的或许是支持网络，包括父母的支持。从这些陷入致命困境的孩子的有利位置进行表演可能会激发人们对探究造成悲剧的复杂场景的更大兴趣。

Danny Ledonne rightly offered that the victims, despite their egregious suffering, do not own the public response to an event like Columbine. Another counter-argument comes from Richard Castaldo, who is paralyzed from the waist down from his Columbine injuries. Said Castaldo of the game, “It’s weird for me to say this, I guess, but there’s something about it that I appreciated, seeing the game from the killers’ perspective.” Of course, this is the power of the video game, both the medium in general and this game in particular. It’s not easy, and it shouldn’t be. It shouldn’t be easy to try to understand the perspective of the killers. But if we are really interested in avoiding these tragedies in the future, we must admit that such empathy might be productive. In his fantastic book Killing Monsters, Gerard Jones argues that a complex array of influences create school shooters, perhaps the most important being a support network, including parental support. Playing from the vantage point of these fatally troubled kids might help spark a greater interest in interrogating the complex scenarios that produce tragedy.

最重要的是，我深感担忧的是这种无法言喻的文化，这种文化宁愿什么都不要谈论，因为担心会让人感到不舒服。这种趋势源于西奥多·阿多诺的观点，即大屠杀在艺术中表现时会“发生改变，一些恐怖被消除”，因此他有句著名的话，说在奥斯维辛之后写诗是野蛮的。这些事件被认为是“无法言喻的”——无法言说，无法表现。这是一种我们必须超越的陈词滥调。当然，像 9/11 这样的话题应该让我们感到不舒服。当然，哥伦拜恩应该让我们感到不舒服。但这不是把这些问题放在抽屉里，等待奇迹般的解决方案出现并为我们解决的借口。如果我们这样做，历史很可能会忘记它们。我不在乎我们是否制作电子游戏、电影、小说、诗歌、街头艺术、纸杯蛋糕或毛皮来审视我们的世界。但我们不能害怕这个世界。

Most of all, I am deeply worried by this culture of ineffability, a culture that would rather not talk about anything at all for fear that it might make someone uncomfortable. This trend descends from Theodor Adorno’s argument that the holocaust becomes “transformed, with something of the horror removed” when represented in art, thus his famous statement that to write poetry after Auschwitz would be barbaric. These events are considered “ineffable”—unspeakable, unrepresentable. It is a tired sentiment that we must move beyond. Of course, topics like 9/11 should make us uncomfortable. Of course, Columbine should make us uncomfortable. But that is no excuse to put these issues away in a drawer, waiting for some miraculous solution to spring forth and resolve them for us. If we do so, history is much more likely to forget them. I don’t care if we make video games, films, novels, poems, sidewalk art, cupcakes, or pelts as a way to interrogate our world. But we must not fear that world.

论游戏创作者身份-育碧设计总监克林特·霍金

ON AUTHORSHIP IN GAMES - CLINT HOCKING, DESIGN DIRECTOR, UBISOFT

以下文章由 Clint Hocking 于 2007 年 8 月 10 日撰写，并发表在 Click Nothing (http://clicknothing.typepad.com) 上。经许可在此转载。

The following article was authored by Clint Hocking on August 10, 2007 and published on Click Nothing (http://clicknothing.typepad.com). It is reprinted here with permission.

在文章中，霍金对电影评论家罗杰·艾伯特 (Roger Ebert) 的断言提出了异议，称电子游戏不是艺术。引发这些回应的艾伯特的原始文章可以在他 2005 年 11 月 27 日的“答疑人”专栏中找到（从顶部开始的第三个答案）：http://rogerebert.suntimes.com/apps/pbcs.dll/section?category=ANSWERMAN&date=20051127。

In the article, Hocking takes issue with movie critic Roger Ebert’s assertion that video games are not art. Ebert’s original writing that sparked the responses can be found in his Answer Man column from November 27, 2005 (third answer from the top): http://rogerebert.suntimes.com/ apps/pbcs.dll/section?category=ANSWERMAN&date=20051127.

巴克在 2007 年好莱坞和游戏峰会上发表主题演讲时现场发表了他的回应。他的部分言论转载于此：http://www.gamesindustry.biz/content_page.php?aid=26131。艾伯特对巴克的回应见：http://rogerebert.suntimes.com/apps/pbcs.dll/article?AID=/20070721/COMMENTARY/70721001。

Barker’s reaction was given live at his keynote address to the Hollywood and Games Summit in 2007. Some of his quotes are reprinted here: http://www.gamesindustry.biz/ content_page. php?aid=26131. Ebert’s response to Barker is at: http://rogerebert.suntimes. com/apps/pbcs.dll/ article?AID=/ 20070721/COMMENTARY/70721001.

霍金的文章（此处转载）位于http://clicknothing.typepad.com/click_nothing/2007/08/on-authorship-i.html。

Hocking’s article (reprinted here) is at http://clicknothing.typepad.com/click_nothing/2007/08/on-authorship-i.html.

不久前，著名电影评论家罗杰·艾伯特表示，游戏不是艺术，也不可能是艺术。

Not that long ago, famed film critic Roger Ebert stated that games are not, and indeed, cannot be, art.

最近，针对作家兼游戏融合专家克莱夫·巴克 (Clive Barker) 在好莱坞和游戏峰会上所作的回应，艾伯特澄清了自己的说法。

Recently, following up on a response made by author/game convergence guy Clive Barker at the Hollywood and Games Summit, Ebert clarified his claims.

埃伯特的基本论点是，艺术需要作者，而游戏将作者权交给了玩家，因此不能算是艺术。这当然是一个令人信服且有用的论点，因为它触及了我们媒介的本质，而不是我们经常制作的内容。埃伯特很聪明，他没有费心去争论另一个无聊的老套游戏，即你使用 24 种不同的武器在 18 个独特的关卡中杀死 6 种不同类型的外星人，拯救人类免于灭绝，这是否是艺术。他正在杀戮，这对他来说是好事。

Ebert’s basic argument is that art requires authorship, and that games abdicate authorship to the player, and therefore cannot be art. This is certainly a compelling and useful argument, as it strikes at the nature of our medium, not at the content we so frequently produce. Ebert is clever not to bother arguing whether or not another boring old rehash of the game where you use 24 different weapons to kill six different types of aliens in 18 unique levels and save mankind from annihilation is art or is not. He is going for the kill, and good for him.

作为设计“流派”的学生，我经常大声而热情地提倡将尽可能多的创作权移交给玩家，我想我需要站出来帮助埃伯特理解他想要表达的意思和含义。

As a student of the “school” of design that often loudly and passionately advocates abdication of as much authorship as possible to the player, I guess I need to step up and help Ebert understand what he’s trying to say and what it means.

埃伯特声称，由于游戏（或者实际上任何互动媒体）在某种程度上将创作权让给了玩家，这至少会削弱甚至破坏互动作品（或至少是游戏）作为艺术作品的能力。他还温和地提出了这样一种观点：艺术性可能存在于与作品的互动中，因此游戏或其他互动作品中的任何艺术性都不是天生的，而是由观众灌输的，即使它存在的话。

Ebert claims that because games—or indeed, any interactive medium, abdicate authorship to some degree to the player, that this at least diminishes, and potentially destroys the capacity of an interactive work (or at least a game) to be art. He also tugs gently at the idea that it is potentially in the interaction with the work that the artistry lies, and thus any artfulness in a game or other interactive work is not innate but rather, if it exists at all, is imbued by the audience.

艾伯特的错误有两个重要原因。

Ebert is wrong for two important reasons.

首先，无论我们如何放弃创作，游戏中都存在着作者身份。作者身份的形式各不相同，也难以理解，但无论我们如何试图放弃创作，作者身份始终存在。作者身份无可否认地存在，并且与游戏创作行为密不可分。

First, there is authorship in games, no matter how much we abdicate. The form of the authorship is different, and hard to understand, but no matter how much we try to abdicate it, it will always remain. It is undeniably there, and it is inextricable from the act of creating a game.

其次，与作品互动不会塑造作品，只会揭示作品。因此，虽然揭示艺术的方式可能是一种表达艺术，但这不一定会削弱作品本身设计的艺术性。

Second, interacting with a work does not shape the work, it only reveals it. Therefore, while there can be an art of expression in the way someone reveals the art, this does not necessarily diminish the art in the design of the work itself.

正如埃伯特和巴克都承认的那样，我们可以无休止地争论什么是艺术，什么不是艺术，什么是艺术的有效定义，什么不是艺术的有效定义。为了论证的目的，我将接受埃伯特的粗略陈述，即艺术需要作者身份。事实上，我实际上同意他的观点。我认为他只是不明白游戏中作者身份在哪里。

As both Ebert and Barker acknowledge, we could debate endlessly what is and is not art, or what is and is not a valid definition of art. For the sake of argument, I will accept Ebert’s roughly stated thesis that art requires authorship. In fact, I actually agree with him. I think he just does not understand where authorship lies in games.

工作原理如下：

Here is how it works:

·      我能够通过交互系统的设计来表达我的想法、思想和感受。

·      I am able to express my ideas, thoughts, and feelings through the design of interactive systems.

·      因为游戏是一个完整的形式系统，所以这些系统的所有可能输出范围都由我决定。

·      Because a game is a complete formal system, the entire possible range of outputs from those systems is determined by me.

·      人们与这些设计的系统进行交互并接收我所确定的输出。

·      People interact with those designed systems and receive the outputs I have determined.

·      了解该媒介的人可以通过体验这些输出来重建我的想法、思想和感受。

·      People literate in the medium can reconstruct my ideas, thoughts, and feelings by experiencing these outputs.

·      因此，根据定义，我的想法、思想和感受与玩家的体验之间存在着牢不可破的联系——我编写的机制可以在游戏动态中产生确定性的输出，从而引导玩家体验到我希望他们体验到的美感（在给定的容差范围内）。

·      Therefore, by definition, there is an unbreakable chain between my ideas, thoughts, and feelings and the player’s experience—I author mechanics that yield deterministic outputs in the game dynamics that lead the player to experience the aesthetic I want them to experience (within a given tolerance).

现在，为了澄清这个解释以及抢先提出一些反驳的论点，我将尝试列出最好和最有效的论点。

Now—by way of clarifying this explanation as well as pre-empting some of the counter arguments, I’ll try to lay out the best and most valid ones.

认识论论证

The Epistemological Argument

首先，存在认识论论证——其反驳是“你怎么知道你能够在交互系统的设计中表达你的想法和感受。”信不信由你，这是最好的论证，因为最好的反驳就是说“我就是知道。”你可以问“你怎么知道你说的这句话不是胡说八道？”我知道，因为我理解它。我所表达的东西对我来说在理智和情感上都是有意义的。如果别人不理解，这实际上不是我是否在表达自己的问题，而是我是否表达清楚的问题。

First, there is the epistemological argument—which counters by saying “How do you know you are able to express your thoughts and feelings in the design of interactive systems.” Believe it or not, this is the best argument, because the best rebuttal is simply to say “I just know it.” You could ask “How do you know the sentence you are speaking is not nonsense?” I know because I understand it. What I am expressing makes sense to me both intellectually and emotionally. If others do not understand it, it is not really a question of whether I am expressing myself, but rather one of whether I am expressing myself clearly.

除了主观认识论之外，这一论点还要求受众识字。在我看来，象形文字无法表达任何东西，但显然写出象形文字的人有能力表达自己，他们也知道这一点。最后，虽然这是一个令人信服的论点，但它很快就会退化为纯粹的认识论论点，而在这方面的争论不会增进任何人对游戏中作者身份问题的理解。我想，即使是埃伯特也不会对进一步探讨这一论点感兴趣。

Beyond the subjective epistemological edge of this argument, there is a requirement that the audience be literate. Hieroglyphics can’t express anything to me, but clearly the people who wrote them had the capacity to express themselves, and they knew it. In the end, while this is a compelling argument, it degenerates quickly to a purely epistemological one, and arguing on that front is not going to enhance anybody’s understanding of the issue of authorship in games. I’d like to think even Ebert is not interested in pursuing this argument any further.

关于作者不完整的论证

The Argument to the Incompleteness of Authorship

下一个争论是，游戏系统的所有可能输出是否真的由我决定。老实说，不是的。游戏极其复杂，许多输出并非由我决定。

The next argument is whether or not it is, in fact, true that the entire possible range of outputs from a game’s systems are really determined by me. Well, honestly, no—they are not. Games are extraordinarily complex, and there are many outputs which are not literally determined precisely by me.

如果我们进行某种逆图灵测试，把我关在一个房间里，让我尝试向正在玩《细胞分裂：混沌理论》的玩家返回与 Xbox 完全相同的输出（忽略速度和计算精度等荒谬因素）……那么，我就无法冒充正在运行《细胞分裂：混沌理论》的 Xbox 。游戏中的每一行代码都是我编写的，我也不完全理解这些代码。因此，可以说我对这款游戏的创作只是近似的，或者说是不完整的。

If we were to conduct a sort of inverse Turing test and put me in a room and have me attempt to return the exact same outputs (ignoring ridiculous factors such as speed and precision of calculation) to a player playing Splinter Cell: Chaos Theory as he or she would receive from an Xbox... well, I would fail to pass myself off as an Xbox running SC:CT. I did not write every line of code in the game, nor do I have a complete comprehension of that code. Therefore, the argument could be made that my authorship of the game is only approximate, or incomplete.

反驳这一论点的方法是将其与电影、音乐或任何其他合作艺术创作进行比较。交响乐的每一个音符都是由作曲家完美决定的吗？进入电影每个观众视网膜的每一个光子都是由导演决定的吗？不是的。这些系统中也有噪音——一些来自其他人的合作，一些来自随机噪音。我们不会因为《欢乐颂》被指挥家戏谑地操纵，也不会因为第三支单簧管折断了簧片而否认它的艺术地位。游戏也是如此。输出大致由我决定，并由与我一起工作的一大群人严格形式化，以实现承诺的美学。有时我们会犯错误，也会出现 bug。即使是平庸的艺术也能容忍这种近似或不完整的创作，所以我不得不断言游戏也可以。

The rebuttal to this argument lies in a comparison to film or to music or to any other collaborative artistic creation. Is every single note of a symphony perfectly determined by the composer? Is every single photon of light that enters the retina of every single viewer of a film determined by a director. No. There is noise in these systems too—some of it comes from the collaboration of others, and some of it comes from random noise. We do not deny “Ode to Joy” its status as art because it is playfully manipulated by a conductor, nor because the third clarinet breaks a reed. It is the same with games. The outputs are broadly determined by me and heavily formalized by a large crew of people working with me to deliver on a promised aesthetic. Sometimes we make mistakes, and there are bugs. Even mediocre art can tolerate this approximate or incomplete authorship, so I am forced to assert that games can too.

噪音和无稽之谈

The Arguments from Noise and Nonsense

下一个论点是，观众无法通过与系统交互来重构我期望他们理解的含义。至少，这里有一个合理的挑战，即“也许他们可以重构它，但他们也可以构造出如此多的随机含义或相反含义，或者通常只是给体验带来如此多的噪音，以至于将含义稀释到无法辨认的程度。”

The next argument would be that audiences cannot reconstruct the meaning I intend them to by way of interacting with systems. At very least there is a legitimate challenge here in saying “Maybe they could reconstruct it, but they can also construct so many random meanings or contrary meanings, or generally just bring so much noise into the experience as to dilute the meaning to the point where it is not legible.”

这是一个有趣的观点，但同样，这与其他艺术作品并无不同。人们可以观看《公民凯恩》，然后快进“无聊的部分”。他们可以分 10 次观看，或者在观看过程中睡着并忘记它的内容。这并没有剥夺电影的地位。所以，是的，我承认，因为（某些）游戏为玩家提供了如此多的玩法，玩家很可能会“错过”其含义，但我不认为错过含义的可能性应该决定作品的艺术性。卢浮宫后面的房间里挂着一些画作，可能需要全速不间断地步行四个小时才能到达——这并没有降低它们的艺术性。如果观众不参与作品，他们可能永远无法感知艺术，但这并不意味着它不存在。

This is an interesting point, but again, this is not unlike other works of art. People can watch Citizen Kane and fast-forward the “boring parts.” They can watch it in 10 sittings or fall asleep during parts of it and forget what it’s about. This does not strip the film of its status. So, yes, I would concede that because (some) games offer the player so many ways to play, players might well “miss” the meaning, but I don’t think the likeliness of missing the meaning should determine the artfulness of the work. There are some paintings hanging in far away back rooms of the Louvre that would likely take four hours of walking full speed non-stop to get to—this does not diminish their artfulness. If the audience does not participate with the work, they may never perceive the art, but that does not mean it is not there.

那么那些无意义的互动呢？这里的论点与上面的论点类似，表明人们可以以各种愚蠢的方式与游戏互动，而这些方式并不支持或发展创作者希望他们体验的意义。这是真的。我可以纯粹把《GTA 3》当作赛车游戏来玩，而从不做任何非赛车任务。这如何支持游戏的核心意义（我认为是关于自由和后果）？嗯，答案是，它不支持。但等等……我也可以用《战争与和平》来支撑沙发的断腿，或者在漆黑的房间里看沃霍尔的金宝汤罐头，然后说我不明白其中的意思。关键是观众必须始终在某种程度上与作品互动（在游戏中，这是非常字面化的），但他们以无意义的方式与作品互动的能力并不会削弱或摧毁艺术。

And what about those nonsensical interactions? The argument here is similar to the one above, and suggests that people can interact with games in all kinds of silly ways that don’t support or develop the meaning the creator intends them to experience. That’s true. I can play GTA 3 purely as a racing game, without ever doing any of the non-racing missions. How does that support the game’s central meaning (which I take to be about freedom and consequence)? Well, the answer is, it doesn’t. But hold on... I can also use War and Peace to prop up the broken leg of my couch, or view Warhol’s Campbell’s Soup cans in a pitch-black room and then say I don’t get the message. The point is that the audience must always interact with a work on some level (in games, this is very literalized), but their ability to interact with a work in nonsensical ways does not diminish or destroy the art.

你可以说，在托尔斯泰的例子中，书不是在读，在沃霍尔的例子中，画不是在看——但在我的《侠盗猎车手》例子中，游戏是被玩的……这就是区别。我其实想说，这种说法是不准确的。当你只玩《侠盗猎车手》的一小部分时，你根本就没有真正玩过它，就像你只读性感的部分，  就不是在读布拉姆·斯托克的《德古拉》 一样。

You could say that in the Tolstoy example, the book is not being read, and in the Warhol example, the painting is not being viewed—but in my GTA example, the game is being played... and that’s the difference. I would actually simply say that is inaccurate. When you’re only playing one tiny part of GTA, you’re not really playing it at all, any more than you are reading Bram Stoker’s Dracula if you are only reading the sexy bits. 

合法性论证

The Argument from Legitimacy

另一个反对游戏中存在真实作者身份的论点是关于我所谈论的作者身份的合法性的论点。在对 Barker 的回复中，Ebert 说道：

Another argument against the existence of real authorship in games is the argument about the legitimacy of the kind of authorship I am talking about. In his responses to Barker, Ebert says:

“如果你能经历‘每一段情感旅程’，那不是会贬低每一段情感旅程的价值吗？艺术旨在引导你走向一个必然的结局，而不是一堆选择。”

“If you can go through ‘every emotional journey available,’ doesn’t that devalue each and every one of them? Art seeks to lead you to an inevitable conclusion, not a smorgasbord of choices.”

换句话说，他质疑专注于提供单一视角的作者身份的本质，以及为玩家提供多种视角的作者身份的本质。

In other words, he is questioning the nature of an authorship focused on providing a single perspective, versus an authorship that affords the player a range of perspectives.

我同意埃伯特的观点，这两种创作方式是有区别的。《罗密欧与朱丽叶》是一部爱情故事。该剧让我们对莎士比亚希望我们在这个特定情况下、在这两个特定角色之间、在特定情况下如何看待爱情有了具体的、有作者的理解。但埃伯特认为游戏——在提供不同类型的创作方式时——不会以某种方式导致不可避免的结论，或者它们提供了一个简单的“大杂烩”，其中“每一段情感旅程”都是有可能的，这是错误的。

I agree with Ebert that there is a difference in these two kinds of authorship. Romeo and Juliet is one love story. The play gives us a specific and authored understanding of what Shakespeare wants us to think about love in this specific case, between these two specific characters, in this specific set of circumstances. But Ebert is wrong to suggest that games—in affording a different kind of authorship—somehow do not lead to inevitable conclusions, or that they offer a simple “smorgasbord” wherein “every emotional journey” is somehow possible.

从某种意义上说，电影或戏剧的作者身份需要采用归纳方法来理解其含义。如果我从文艺复兴时期维罗纳两个不幸的青少年之间的特殊爱情开始，他们的家庭互相鄙视，然后试图概括爱情的含义，我可能会得出很多无用的结论。从具体到一般是一个归纳且容易出错的过程。由于可能出现所有归纳错误，我能从《罗密欧与朱丽叶》中真正理解爱情的什么？我可以合理地推断，真正的爱情只能存在于戏剧中错综复杂的环境中，一个恋人喝了安眠药，另一个恋人——看到他们的爱“死去”而心烦意乱——用毒药自杀，这样第一个恋人就可以通过在醒来时也喝毒药来证明他们的爱情是平等和真实的。

In a sense, the kind of authorship in a movie or a play requires an inductive approach to understanding the meaning. If I start with the specific love of two star-cross’d teenagers in Renaissance Verona whose families despise one another, and then try to generalize what love means, I am likely to end up with a lot of useless conclusions. It’s an inductive and error-prone process to move from the specific to the general. With all of the inductive errors possible, what can I truly understand about love in general from Romeo and Juliet alone? I could reasonably induce that real love can only exist in the convoluted set of circumstances of the play where one lover drinks a sleeping potion, and the other—distraught at seeing their love “dead”—suicides with poison, so that the first can then prove their love equal and true by also drinking poison on awakening.

当然，那将是一种荒谬的爱情观念，而归纳法的问题正是我们继续以惊人的速度创作爱情故事的根本原因……因为当你提供爱情的单一例子，并试图让观众感受到爱情时，你总会有更多例子的空间。你可以永远写出独特而有力的爱情故事，永远不会耗尽物质“爱情”的无限范围。例子永远堆积起来，永远不会堆积到无限。无论如何——有充分的理由——这种“归纳”形式的艺术表达是我们在大多数媒体中看到的那种创作方式（而且很奇妙）。

Certainly that would be an absurd notion of love, and that problem with induction is fundamentally why we continue to write love stories at a breathtaking rate... because when you are providing singular examples of love, and trying to facilitate the audience feeling love, you will always have room for more examples. You can write unique and powerful love stories forever and never exhaust the infinite scope of the material “love.” Examples piled on examples forever will never pile up to infinity. Regardless—and for good reasons—this “inductive” form of artistic expression is the kind of authorship that we see in most media (and it is wondrous).

游戏则有所不同。艺术家不仅创作了囚犯在监狱转运巴士遭到伏击后突然获释的具体案例……还讲述了一名罪犯了解自由的重要性以及不受约束的自由的后果的故事。艺术家还能够创造一个完整的表达系统空间，探索自由和解放的不同概念的潜在无限性。大多数其他媒体都要求观众推断其含义，而游戏至少为观众提供了推断其含义的可能性。

In games, it is different. The artist does not only create the specific case of the convicted criminal suddenly set free when his prison transfer bus is ambushed... it does not only tell the story of one criminal learning about the importance of liberty and the consequences of unchecked freedom.
