The artist is also capable of creating an entire expressive system space that explores a potential infinity of different notions of freedom and liberty. Where most other media require the audience to induce their meaning, games afford the audience at least the possibility of deducing their meaning.

在其他媒体中，与作品中心主题一致的“支持材料”在 B 情节中被推到一边……在游戏中，这些支持材料为艺术家提供了从许多可能的方向阐明含义的方法，让玩家探索艺术家试图提供的含义。潜在的原因是，由于游戏设计师能够通过系统而不是示例来表达自己，因此可以检查无限性。

In other media, “supporting material” that is coherent with the central themes of the work is pushed to the side in a B-plot... in games, this supporting material affords the artist ways to illuminate the meaning from many, many possible directions, allowing the player to explore the meaning the artist is trying to provide. Potentially, because the game designer is able to express himself in systems rather than in examples, infinities can be examined.

现在，我想这有点难以理解，但埃伯特肯定能理解这个概念。从塔拉蒂诺到伊纳里图再到哈吉斯等数十位电影制作人，他们越来越多地尝试从多个角度探索故事，试图模仿游戏天生就能做到的事情——在这种媒介中，游戏在这方面受到严重限制。如果哈吉斯获得最佳影片奖的《撞车》长达 100 个小时，包含 100 个不同的相互关联的情节，从不同角度呼应种族紧张的同一主题，它会突然失去艺术地位吗？它可能不会是一部很好的电影，因为 100 个小时的电影很痛苦。无论如何，无论你把《撞车》拍多长，你都永远无法完全探索现代美国种族紧张的主题领域。一百个小时只是电影已经提供的 50 个小时，并没有比现有的两小时电影更接近主题的无限深度。

Now, I guess this is kind of hard to wrap your head around, but surely this is a concept Ebert can understand. Many filmmakers, from Taratino to Inarritu to Haggis and dozens more have been increasingly attempting to explore stories from multiple angles in an attempt to mimic—in a medium severely limited for this purpose—what games can do innately. If Haggis’ Best Picture winning Crash was 100 hours long, and contained 100 different interconnected plots all echoing the same themes of racial tension from different perspectives, would it suddenly lose its status as art? It probably wouldn’t be a very good movie, because 100 hours of movie is painful. In any case, no matter how long you make Crash, you will never fully explore the domain of the themes of racial tension in modern America. One hundred hours is just 50 what the movie already offers, and is no closer to the infinite depth of the theme than is the existing two-hour film.

另一方面，我玩了大约 100 个小时的《GTA：圣安德列斯》让我对 20 世纪 90 年代初期加利福尼亚州的种族紧张和不平等有了彻底改变的看法，我被震撼到了核心，并被迫重新审视我的世界观的很大一部分。

GTA: San Andreas on the other hand—which I played for a good 100 hours or so, gave me such a world transforming view of racial tension and inequity in early 1990s California, that I have been shaken to the core, and have been forced to re-examine a huge part of my world view.

艾伯特在 2005 年 11 月 27 日回复读者来信时说：

In a response to a reader letter dated November 27, 2005 Ebert said:

“据我所知，业内外没有人能够举出一款能与伟大的戏剧家、诗人、电影制作人、小说家和作曲家相媲美的游戏。”

“To my knowledge, no one in or out of the field has ever been able to cite a game worthy of comparison with the great dramatists, poets, filmmakers, novelists and composers.”

好吧，就这样。让我清楚地陈述一下，并记录在案：

Well, here you go. Let me state it clearly and for the record:

总体而言，《GTA：圣安德列斯》是一部比《古惑狼》更引人注目、更有意义、更重要的艺术作品。

Taken as a whole, GTA: San Andreas is a more compelling, meaningful, and important work of art than Crash.

诚然，并不是每个人都会同意，而且诚然，我对阅读系统有很高的理解能力。这里的关键不是要参与关于什么是优秀艺术作品的主观辩论，而是要说——是的——如果一款游戏提供了一堆互不相关的机制，既不相互支持，也不朝着一个连贯的主题发展，如果它们没有为玩家提供创作者试图表达的特定含义的广泛视角，那么埃伯特是对的。

Admittedly, not everyone will agree, and admittedly, I have a high level of literacy in reading systems. The point here is not to enter a subjective debate about what is a superior work of art, rather the point is to say that—yes—if a game is offering a smorgasbord of unrelated mechanics that are neither supporting each other nor driving toward a coherent theme, if they are not providing the player with a broad range of perspectives on a specific meaning that the creator is trying to express, then Ebert is right.

但如果游戏创作者确实想要传达某些特定的东西，并且他的游戏设计得很好，而且游戏机制和动态能够连贯地支持这种美感，并为玩家提供 — — 无论他做什么（假设它不是故意无意义的） — — 洞察这种含义，那么是的……这就是艺术。

But if a game creator does have something specific he is trying to communicate, and he designs his game well, and the mechanics and dynamics are coherently supporting that aesthetic, and providing the player—more or less whatever he does (assuming it is not willfully nonsensical)—with insight into that meaning, then yeah... it’s art.

迁移作者身份的争论

The Argument to Migrated Authorship

我认为剩下的最后一个论点是“这里的艺术家到底是谁？”埃伯特说：

The final argument that I see remaining is the one that asks “Who is the artist here anyway?” Ebert says:

“我相信艺术是由艺术家创造的。如果你改变了它，你就成为了艺术家。”

“I believe art is created by an artist. If you change it, you become the artist.”

这个问题比较容易解决，因为 Ebert 的论证本身就存在谬误。他暗示与作品互动就等于改变作品。但事实并非如此。我的“绘画”不是“玩家所做的”。我的绘画是“控制玩家行为的规则”。玩家表达自己的方式是一种艺术表达形式（或者至少可以），但他不可能改变规则，甚至不可能在我制定的规则范围之外表达自己。而且，这不仅仅是说“画画的人一定是艺术家，画家也可以是艺术家”。我做的不仅仅是“画画”。如果我所做的只是“画画”，我会承认 Ebert 在回复读者时指出游戏无法“超越工艺而达到艺术的高度”。

This is a much easier point to tackle simply because there is a fallacy in Ebert’s argument. He is implying that interacting with a work is the same as changing it. But this is not true. My “paint” is not “what the player does.” My paint is “the rules that govern what the player can do.” The way the player expresses himself is a form of artistic expression (or a least it can be), but it is impossible for him to change the rules or even to express himself outside the domain of the rules that I have created. And it is not simply a case of saying “People who make paint are necessarily artists, while painters can be artists.” I do more than “make paint.” If all I did was “make paint,” I would concede the point in Ebert’s response to his reader where he states games cannot move “beyond craftsmanship to the stature of art.”

如果我创作了“魔法颜料”，只能用来画看起来非常像阴道的花朵，那么我是不是比乔治亚·奥基夫更不具艺术家风范？虽然有些画家用我的颜料画出了一些蹩脚的、毫无艺术感的阴道花朵画，而另一些人却能创作出精美的杰作——但我认为，我之所以是一位艺术家，是因为我创作了“限制了我选择的一系列主题下可能实现的绘画的颜料”。这里有一个声明——一个关于花朵和阴道（以及颜料）的声明，它和奥基夫作品中的任何声明一样重要。它甚至可能和奥基夫所有作品中的所有声明加起来一样重要……但我们不必在这里超前。

If I created “magic paints” that could only be used to paint flowers that appeared highly vaginal, would I be less an artist than Georgia O’Keefe? While some painters using my paints could make crappy paintings of vaginal flowers that were not artful, and others could create beautiful masterpieces—I think it would remain clear that I was an artist for having created “paints that constrained the set of possible paintings achievable to those that dealt with a set of themes I had chosen.” There is a statement there—a statement about flowers and vaginas (and paint) and it is as important as any statement in any of O’Keefe’s works. It may even be as important as all of the statements made in all of O’Keefe’s works combined... but we don’t need to get ahead of ourselves here.

这里最好的类比还是交响乐。交响乐的创作本身就是一门艺术——歌曲的创作和使用交响乐团重现该歌曲的指令的录制。然而，由于转录相对模糊，这些指令的解释往往具有高度的可塑性，而很好地解释这些指令并帮助管弦乐队真正演奏交响乐的能力是一项艺术任务。有非艺术性的方法可以做到这一点。从技术上讲，节拍器和乐谱可以完成指挥管弦乐队的工作，但我们为指挥家留出了很大的空间，因为在他们的艺术中，他们可以为本来就很美的作品增添巨大的美感。

The best analogy here, again, is that of a symphony. There is an art in the composing of the symphony itself—the creation of the song and the recording of the instructions for reproducing that song using a symphony orchestra. Yet, because of the comparative fuzziness of the transcription, there is often a high degree of malleability in interpretation of those instructions, and the ability to interpret those instructions well and to facilitate an orchestra to actually play the symphony is an artistic task. There are ways to do it non-artistically. Technically, a metronome and sheet music could do the job of conducting an orchestra, but we make a lot of room for conductors because in their art, they can add a tremendous amount of beauty to what is already a beautiful work.

埃伯特的谬误延伸到，作曲家指挥《欢乐颂》后，它就不再是艺术作品，指挥家的艺术也不会长期成为艺术，因为音乐家一演奏它，就成了艺术家。事实上，他们都可以成为艺术家，当一部艺术创作的作品由艺术指挥家指挥，由艺术音乐家演奏时，作品的全貌才真正令人欣赏。

Ebert’s fallacy extends to suggest that “Ode to Joy” is not a work of art once a composer conducts it, and that the conductor’s art is not art for long anyway, because as soon as a musician plays it, he or she becomes the artist. The reality is, they can all be artists, and when an artfully composed work is conducted by an artful conductor, and played by artful musicians, the full perspective of the work is truly appreciable.

游戏和玩家也是一样。从技术上讲，游戏可以由计算机来玩——许多游戏都是由计算机来玩的。虽然这样做可能会削弱甚至破坏特定游戏体验的美感，但它不会削弱或破坏游戏本身固有的艺术性。

It is the same with a game and a player. Technically, a game could be played by a computer—many games are played by computers. While the beauty of the particular play experience might be diminished or even destroyed by doing it that way, it does not diminish or destroy the artfulness inherent to the game itself.

在我看来，设计师和演奏者之间的关系就是这样的。设计师是作曲家，演奏者是指挥。乐团是硬件，乐谱是软件。

Such is the relationship between the designer and the player as I see it. The designer is the composer, the player is the conductor. The orchestra is the hardware and the sheet music is the software.

结论

Conclusion

我想这大概就是我对 Ebert 先生的反驳。几个月前他第一次发表声明时，我主要是感到不安和被侮辱，但随着他最近对这些原始声明的澄清，他不仅更仔细地审视了真正相关的问题，而且为描述游戏中作者身份的真正性质打开了大门。我希望——如果他碰巧路过这里并读到这篇文章——他最终会理解这个问题的范围并承认他错了。

I think that about sums up my rebuttal to Mr. Ebert. When he made his first statements months ago, I was mostly just upset and insulted, but with his latest clarification of those original statements, he has not only looked more carefully at the real and relevant question, but he has opened the door to have the real nature of authorship in games described. I hope—should he happen past here and read this—he’ll finally understand the scope of the issue and admit that he’s wrong.

挑战

CHALLENGES

本节中的挑战要求您反思上述作品，并将游戏视为一种艺术形式。与本书其他章节不同，并非所有挑战都要求您创建游戏或设计游戏。但是，通过退后一步，将游戏视为一种有趣和娱乐体验以外的其他东西，我们可以提高对整个媒介的欣赏，并拓展自己的视野。

The challenges in this section ask you to reflect upon the works above and to consider games as an art form. Unlike other chapters in this book, not all challenges require you to create games or designs for games. However, by standing back and appreciating a game as something other than a fun and entertaining experience, we increase our appreciation of the medium as a whole and push our own horizons.

挑战 1——他们看到了什么？

CHALLENGE 1—WHAT DO THEY SEE?

到目前为止，您可能已经阅读了本章前面出现的 Patrick Dugan 对Passage的评论。如果您翻阅了该章节以了解挑战，请不要回头阅读。在这种情况下，这不是一件坏事。

By this point, you may have read Patrick Dugan’s review of Passage that appeared earlier in this chapter. If you flipped through the chapter to get to the challenges, don’t go back and read it now. In this case, it’s not a bad thing.

对于这个挑战，需要考验的是你的想法，而不是你的设计技巧。你的目标是玩Passage，并确定为什么这么多知名的游戏设计师认为它是一件艺术品。在分析过程中，考虑你在玩游戏时对游戏的反应，并考虑你的游戏方式。

For this challenge, it’s your thinking and not your design skills that are going to be pushed. Your goal is to play Passage and determine why so many high-profile, established game designers think it is a work of art. In your analysis, consider your reactions to the game as you play it, and consider how you play.

所需组件

Components Required

·      互联网连接以下载Passage（可从 App Store 或 http://hcsoftware.sourceforge.net/passage/ 下载）

·      Internet connection to download Passage (available the App Store or from http://hcsoftware.sourceforge.net/passage/)

可交付成果

Deliverable

·关于      段落的讨论和个人思考

·      Discussion and personal reflections on Passage

建议流程

Suggested Process

1.    下载并玩 Passage。无需阅读作者的目的陈述或对游戏的其他想法，下载Passage并玩几遍。随身携带一支铅笔和一张纸，记录您对游戏的想法。

1.    Download and play Passage. Without reading the artist’s statement of purpose or other thoughts on the game, download Passage and play the game several times. Keep a pencil and paper with you to record thoughts that you have on the game.

2.    什么是艺术？思考一下你自己对原创作品是否是“艺术”的先入之见和定义。也可以考虑一下其他关于“艺术”的观点，比如本章前面讨论过的观点。

2.    What is art? Think about your own preconceptions and definitions of what makes an original work “art” (or not). Consider also other views of what “art” is, such as those discussed earlier in this chapter.

3.    解读意图。考虑一下你在玩《Passage》时的反应。你有什么感觉？你在想什么？考虑一下作者。你认为 Jason Rohrer 想通过这款游戏表达什么？他是否在陈述人类体验的某些方面？你认为他是否希望玩家感受到某些特定的情感？

3.    Interpret the intent. Consider the reactions you had while playing Passage. What did you feel? What were you thinking of? Consider the author. What do you think Jason Rohrer was trying to say with this game, if anything? Was he making a statement about some aspects of the human experience? Were there particular emotions that you think he wanted the player to feel?

4.    应用你的定义。 你认为《通道》是艺术作品吗？你认为它是“纯艺术”还是“高雅艺术”？为什么或为什么不是？如果你的答案是否定的，请回去阅读 Patrick Dugan 的评论，并在网上搜索其他类似的反应（如果你还没有这样做的话）。你不必同意他们的观点，但至少要试着理解为什么这个问题值得争论，并尽力理解另一方的观点。

4.    Apply your definition. Is Passage a work of art in your opinion? Would you consider it “fine art” or “high art”? Why or why not? If your answer is no, go back and read Patrick Dugan’s review and search the Web for other similar reactions (if you have not already done so). You do not have to agree with them, but at least try to understand why the matter is open to debate, and do your best to understand the other side.

5.    创建可交付成果。

5.    Create deliverable.

变体

Variant

探索另一款艺术游戏以及你对此的反应。推荐以下游戏：

Explore another art game and your reactions to the same. The following games are recommended:

·       flOw，可免费在线玩，网址为http://intihuatani.usc.edu/cloud/flowing/

·      flOw, playable for free online at http://intihuatani.usc.edu/cloud/flowing/

·      云，可在http://intihuatani.usc.edu/cloud/免费下载

·      Cloud, downloadable for free at http://intihuatani.usc.edu/cloud/

·       Knytt，可在 http://nifflas.ni2.se/index.php?main=03Knytt 免费下载

·      Knytt, downloadable for free at http://nifflas.ni2.se/index.php?main=03Knytt

·       Samarost，可在 http://www.amanita-design.net/samorost-1/ 上免费在线玩，或其续集Samarost 2 ，可在 http://amanita-design.net/samorost-2/ 上玩

·      Samarost, playable for free online at http://www.amanita-design.net/samorost-1/ or its sequel, Samarost 2 at http://amanita-design.net/samorost-2/

·      游戏游戏游戏游戏和再次游戏，可在http://www.secrettechnology.com/gamegame/agame.html免费在线玩

·      game game game game and again game, playable for free online at http://www.secrettechnology.com/gamegame/agame.html

挑战 2——游戏是否是艺术

CHALLENGE 2—GAMES AS ART... OR NOT

对于这项挑战，您需要 a) 反驳或 b) 支持霍金的论点，即游戏实际上是艺术。通过评估霍金的每一个观点与当代游戏来捍卫自己的论点，并详细探讨您相信这些观点的原因。由于霍金的文章从一般意义上讨论了游戏，因此您的分析应该具体，详细说明游戏的各个方面以支持您的观点。

For this challenge, you are tasked with either a) rebutting or b) supporting Hocking’s thesis that games are, in fact, art. Defend your own arguments by assessing each of Hocking’s points against a contemporary game, and explore in detail why you believe what you believe. As Hocking’s piece discussed games in a general sense, your analysis should be specific, detailing the game’s various aspects as necessary to support your point.

所需组件

Components Required

·      互联网连接（用于研究）

·      Internet connection (for research)

·      霍金的文章，出现在本章前面

·      Hocking’s article, which appears earlier in this chapter

·      任意游戏

·      Any game

可交付成果

Deliverable

·      详细说明你的立场的陈述或讨论，或

·      A presentation or discussion detailing your position, or

·      详细说明你的立场的文件，或

·      A paper detailing your position, or

·      准备讨论笔记

·      Prepared notes for discussion

建议流程

Suggested Process

1.    形成观点。 既然你正在读这本书，你可能已经对游戏是否是艺术有了看法。选择你想在论点中表达的基本核心思想。

1.    Form an opinion. Since you’re reading this book, you probably already have an opinion on whether games are art. Choose the basic core ideas that you’d like to express in your argument.

2.    选择一款游戏。 根据您的经验，找到最好的例子来支持您的观点。如果您不是这款游戏的拥有者，请在网上查找一些评论、截图和其他材料。如果您打算在交付成果中使用这些内容，请务必注明来源。

2.    Choose a game. From your experience, find the best example you can to support your opinion. If you do not own the game, find some reviews, screenshots, and other materials online. If you plan to use these in your deliverable, be sure to credit your sources.

3.    研究。阅读本章前面的 Hocking 的文章。您可能还希望在网上寻找更多评论，无论是关于“游戏是艺术吗？”的一般讨论，还是关于您的游戏的具体讨论。

3.    Research. Read Hocking’s piece earlier in this chapter. You may also wish to seek out additional commentary online, either on the “Are games art?” discussion in general or your game in particular.

4.    创建可交付成果。

4.    Create deliverable.

变体

Variant

探索对罗杰·艾伯特“游戏不是艺术”的断言的其他反应，以及他“游戏不能成为高雅艺术”的后续反应 (http://rogerebert.suntimes.com/apps/ pbcs.dll/article?AID=/20070721/COMMENTARY/70721001)。考虑这些反应如何与霍金的立场形成对比或支持霍金的立场。

Explore other reactions to Roger Ebert’s assertion that games are not art, and his follow-up reaction that games cannot become high art (http://rogerebert.suntimes.com/apps/ pbcs.dll/article?AID=/20070721/COMMENTARY/70721001). Consider how these reactions contrast with or support Hocking’s stance.

挑战3——蒙娜丽莎

CHALLENGE 3—MONA LISA

她的微笑迷住了数百万人。正是这种微妙、缺乏动机的确定性让我们想知道，“她的微笑在说什么？她在想什么？”在她的微笑中，达芬奇似乎捕捉到了我们尚未能够解读的东西，但它却让我们静止不动。

Her smile has captivated millions. It’s the subtlety, the lack of motivational certainty that makes us wonder, “What does her smile say? What is she thinking?” In her smile, DaVinci seemed to capture something that we’ve not yet been able to decipher, but it draws us still.

对于这一挑战，你的任务是探索两个不同的问题：

For this challenge, you are tasked with exploring two different questions:

·      游戏中是否也有像蒙娜丽莎那样深刻而持久的时刻？

·      Do games have a Mona Lisa moment, something so deep and enduring?

·      如果您负责开发一款有关蒙娜丽莎微笑的游戏，您会如何设计这款游戏？

·      If you were tasked to create a game about the experience of Mona Lisa’s smile, what would the design of that game be?

所需组件

Components Required

·      没有任何

·      None

可交付成果

Deliverable

·      一份游戏中“蒙娜丽莎时刻”的书面清单，每个你能想到的时刻都附上一段文字，解释为什么它符合条件

·      A written list of “Mona Lisa moments” in games, with each moment you can think of supported by a paragraph explaining why it qualifies

·      基于蒙娜丽莎微笑的体验的游戏概念

·      A game concept for a game based on the experience of Mona Lisa’s smile

建议流程

Suggested Process

1.    研究。阅读至少三位艺术评论家对《蒙娜丽莎》的评论。这些评论可能是当代的，也可能是几百年前的，可能在网上或实体书中找到。这可以帮助你用语言表达你（尤其是其他人）在看这幅画时的感受。

1.    Research. Read what at least three art critics have written about the Mona Lisa. These reviews may be contemporary or centuries old, and may be found online or in physical books. This helps you put words to what you (and especially others) feel when looking at this painting.

2.    考虑游戏中的相似之处。一旦你能用语言表达出蒙娜丽莎的感觉，想想你在玩游戏时最接近的感觉。如果你很难想出任何感觉，想想那些让你感受到任何情感的游戏——除了肾上腺素激增和权力幻想。

2.    Consider parallels in games. Once you can put the feeling of the Mona Lisa into words, think of the closest feelings you’ve had when playing games. If you are having trouble thinking of any, consider games that have made you feel any emotion at all—other than adrenaline rush and power fantasy.

3.    集思广益，构思游戏概念。独自一人或与团队一起，思考如何在游戏中表达蒙娜丽莎所激发的情感。考虑其他表达情感的游戏，如Cloud或flOw，作为起点。

3.    Brainstorm game concepts. Alone or in a group, think of ways to express the emotions stirred by the Mona Lisa in a game. Consider other games that express emotions, like Cloud or flOw, as a starting point.

4.    创建可交付成果。

4.    Create deliverable.

挑战 4——创建艺术游戏

CHALLENGE 4—CREATE AN ART GAME

正如Passage、Cloud和其他艺术游戏向我们展示的那样，游戏可以探索各种不同的概念——生活、衰老、环境问题等等。其他游戏以非常规方式探索问题。想想像沃霍尔这样的艺术家，他探索了金宝汤罐头等主题，或者奥基夫以新的、戏剧性的方式捕捉自然之美。

As Passage, Cloud, and other art games show us, games can explore a variety of different concepts—life, aging, environmental issues, and more. Other games explore issues in nonconventional ways. Consider artists like Warhol who explored topics like Campbell’s Soup cans, or O’Keefe who captured natural beauty in new, dramatic ways.

选择一些类似的内容 — — 一个概念、一个过程、日常生活中的某些事物，然后从中创建一个游戏设计。

Select something similar—a concept, a process, something from the everyday, and create a game design from it.

对于这一挑战，您的游戏概念可能是数字游戏或非数字游戏。

For this challenge, your game concept may be for a digital or non-digital game.

所需组件

Components Required

·      没有任何

·      None

可交付成果

Deliverable

·      两到三页的书面游戏概念

·      Two- to three-page written game concept

建议流程

Suggested Process

1.    研究。探索其他艺术游戏，看看已经做了什么。然后，将你的探索转向传统和非传统的现代艺术家。互动艺术家可能是一个极好的灵感来源。

1.    Research. Explore other art games to see what’s already been done. Then, turn your exploration to look at both conventional and nonconventional modern artists. Interactive artists may prove an excellent source of inspiration.

2.    选择一个主题。 你想在游戏中艺术地探索什么？请记住，游戏包含系统，因此你可以通过表达具有多个部分的东西来发挥媒介的优势，这些部分在启动时会相互作用。

2.    Choose a topic. What would you like to explore artistically in a game? Remember that games contain systems, so you play to the strengths of the medium by expressing something that has several parts that interact with each other when set in motion.

3.    创建可交付成果。

3.    Create deliverable.

铁人设计师挑战 5——痛苦世界

IRON DESIGNER CHALLENGE 5—WORLD OF PAIN

游戏世界如何帮助我们探索一个困难的话题，并迫使我们从另一个角度考虑一个问题？《达尔富尔正在消亡》和《九月十二日》等游戏迫使我们走上一条我们自己从未选择的道路。它们试图通过使用唯一真正提供主动而非被动体验的媒介来开阔我们的眼界。

How can a game world facilitate our exploration of a difficult topic and force us to consider a subject from another perspective? Games like Darfur is Dying and September 12 force us to walk a path we’d never choose for ourselves. They seek to open our eyes by using the only medium that truly provides an active versus a passive experience.

对于这个挑战，你的目标是以非数字游戏的形式探索一个困难的话题。分成两到四人的小组，拿上一盒原型制作材料，然后开始。

For this challenge, your goal is to explore a difficult topic in the form of a non-digital game. Break into groups of two to four people, grab a box of prototyping materials, and get started.

所需组件

Components Required

·      互联网或书籍（用于研究）原型材料

·      Internet or books (for research) Prototyping materials

可交付成果

Deliverable

·      可玩的棋盘游戏或纸牌游戏原型

·      Playable prototype of a board game or card game

建议流程

Suggested Process

1.    研究。选择一个事件或一个困难的话题。如果你不熟悉这个话题，那就快速学习。特别注意那些可以在游戏中清晰表达的元素：系统、权衡和因果关系。

1.    Research. Select an event or a difficult topic. If you are unfamiliar with the topic, learn fast. Pay particular attention to those elements that can be expressed clearly in games: systems, tradeoffs, and cause-and-effect relationships.

2.    集思广益。想出点子。你是想尝试将主题进行字面转换，还是尝试更抽象的转换？

2.    Brainstorm. Come up with ideas. Do you attempt a literal conversion of the topic or something more abstract?

3.    创建机制。 逆向思考。你希望玩家在游戏过程中体验什么？选择能够创造这种游戏体验的动态。然后选择能够创造这些动态的机制。

3.    Create mechanics. Work backward. What do you want your players to experience during play? Choose dynamics that can create that play experience. Then choose mechanics that can create those dynamics.

4.    创建可交付成果。

4.    Create deliverable.

变体

Variant

探索您选择的另一个困难主题。当然，该主题不必像 Ledonne 的《Super Columbine Massacre RPG》那样具有争议性。事实上，以类似的方式探索类似的主题只不过是对 Ledonne 的原创作品进行修改。在这项挑战中突破自己的界限，创造出原创作品。

Explore a different difficult topic of your choice. The topic need not be as controversial as Ledonne’s Super Columbine Massacre RPG, of course. In fact, exploring a similar subject in a similar way would mean little more than a modification of Ledonne’s original work. Push your own boundaries in this challenge to create something original.

变体

Variant

不要创建物理游戏原型，而是创建数字游戏的概念。

Instead of a physical game prototype, create a concept for a digital game.

非数字短片

NON-DIGITAL SHORTS

非数字短片可让您快速探索各种概念。有时，由于媒介的触觉特性，非数字游戏可能更适合此类主题。

Non-digital shorts allow you to explore various concepts quickly. Sometimes, because of the tactile nature of the medium, non-digital games may be more suited for such topics.

1.    设计一个游戏，向孩子们介绍悲伤的概念。

1.    Design a game that introduces children to the concept of grief.

2.    设计一款游戏，向人们介绍你选择的宗教。

2.    Design a game that introduces people to a religion of your choice.

3、    重新设计风险 ，倡导世界和平。

3.    Redesign Risk to advocate world peace.

4.    重新设计大富翁 来展现大萧条的影响。

4.    Redesign Monopoly to illustrate the effects of the Great Depression.

5.    选择常见的游戏令牌，例如骰子或牌，并创建以非标准方式使用这些材料的游戏。

5.    Choose a common game token, such as dice or tiles, and create a game that uses these materials in a non-standard way.

6.    除了方法5以外，设计一款使用非标准回合结构或节奏的游戏。

6.    Alternatively to #5, design a game that uses a non-standard turn structure or pacing.

7.    创建一个获胜条件不断变化或无法理解的纸牌游戏。

7.    Create a card game whose win condition constantly changes or is impossible to understand.

8.    创建基于“不可能的选择”（或一系列不可能的选择）的纸牌游戏——一种两种选择都意味着失败的困境。

8.    Create a card game based on an “impossible choice” (or a series of them)—a dilemma where both choices mean certain failure.

9.    设计一款故意不完整的游戏，需要玩家在运行时拥有创作权才可玩。

9.    Design a game that is intentionally incomplete, requiring player authorship at runtime to be playable.

10. 选择一款你认为是艺术的数字游戏，并创建它的非数字版本。媒介的差异如何影响信息？

10. Choose a digital game that you consider to be art and create a non-digital version of it. How does the difference in medium affect the message?

资源

RESOURCES

http://experimental-gameplay.org/ http://www.playthisthing.com

http://experimental-gameplay.org/ http://www.playthisthing.com

 

 


18：游戏作为教学工具

18: Games as a Teaching Tool

 

 

真的吗？当然。游戏有一种神奇的魔力，教育工作者可以欣赏。许多人可能会抱怨在游戏前花费的时间，但其他人提出了一个棘手的问题：“这个游戏有什么是我课程所没有的？”答案不仅仅是“ 娱乐”，因为课程也可以很有趣。我们看到患有注意力缺陷障碍的孩子在听了 10 分钟的讲座后就走神了，但这些学生却能连续几个小时沉迷于游戏。这是怎么回事呢？

Seriously? Absolutely. There’s something magical going on with games that educators can appreciate. Many might lament the hours spent in front of games, but others pose a formidable question: “What does that game have that my courses don’t?” The answer is more than “entertainment,” because courses can be entertaining, too. We see children with ADD tune out after 10 minutes of a lecture, yet these same students stay engaged in a game for hours at a time. What’s going on?

幸运的是，许多人正在研究这个问题。其他人，比如本书的作者，他们既是行业资深人士，又是教育工作者，已经将游戏融入课堂并取得了很大成功。

Fortunately, many individuals are studying this exact thing. Others, like the writers of this book who are both industry veterans and educators, have already integrated games into their classroom with much success.

我听到的那些疯狂故事是怎样的？

WHAT ABOUT THOSE CRAZY STORIES I HEAR?

关于电子游戏确实有很多疯狂的故事，就像 20 年前的摇滚乐、30 年前的纸笔游戏和 50 年前的漫画一样。这种相对较新的媒介，就像之前的新媒介一样，引起了一些人的担忧。

There certainly are many crazy stories out there about video games, just like there were about rock music 20 years ago, pencil and paper games 30 years ago, and comics 50 years ago. This relatively new medium, like the new mediums before it, is a concern for some.

研究表明，无论来源如何，暴力媒体都有可能增加某些人的暴力倾向。幸运的是，小学课堂上不会播放 M 级游戏和 R 级电影。截至撰写本文时，提交给 ESRBTM 的电子游戏中只有 8% 被评为 M 级，这一事实或许令人欣慰。M 级游戏和 R 级电影一样，面向 17 岁及以上的个人。

Studies have shown that violent media, regardless of its source, has the potential to increase the likelihood of violence in some individuals. Fortunately, M-rated games and R-rated movies are not used in the grade-school classroom. As of the year of this writing, in fact, only eight percent of the video games submitted to the ESRBTM were rated M., a fact that may be reassuring. M-rated games, like R-rated movies, are intended for individuals 17 and older.

关于游戏也有很多好故事。比如这个：每周玩电子游戏至少三个小时并进行腹腔镜手术的外科医生完成手术的速度提高了 27%，错误率降低了 37% [DRR01]。其他研究表明，电子游戏可以保护我们的大脑免于衰老 [GM01]。游戏甚至被用来治疗患有创伤后应激障碍的士兵 [NPR01]。关于游戏的好消息甚至促使英国广播公司新闻网刊登了一篇文章，标题为“电子游戏‘对你有好处’”。[BBC01] 这些研究只是冰山一角。游戏被用于各种有益的目的。学习只是其中之一。

There are lots of good stories about games, too. Consider this one: surgeons who play video games at least three hours per week and perform laparoscopic surgery complete the surgery 27 percent quicker with 37 percent fewer errors [DRR01]. Other studies show video games protect our brains from aging [GM01]. Games are even being used to treat soldiers who suffer from post traumatic stress disorder [NPR01]. Good news about games even prompted the BBC News to title an article, “Video games ‘good for you.’” [BBC01] These studies are just the tip of the iceberg. Games are being used for all kinds of good purposes. Learning is just one of them.

利用游戏作为学习的催化剂

USING GAMES AS A CATALYST FOR LEARNING

2007 年，本书的一位作者与一群高危青少年举办了一场游戏设计研讨会。对于这些学生来说，他们现在所在的教室是他们街区里的最后一站。他们因为捣乱行为被从一个教室赶出另一个教室。有些人已经进了监狱。与此同时，一些孩子还表达了长大后想成为游戏设计师的愿望。

In 2007, one of the authors of this book held a game design workshop with a group of at-risk teens. For these students, their current classroom was the last educational stop on the block. They’d been removed from one classroom after another due to their disruptive behaviors. Some had already been to jail. At the same time, some of the kids had also expressed a desire to be game designers when they grew up.

游戏设计研讨会对学生和研讨会负责人来说都是神奇的。几乎没有人不尊重他们。事实上，学生们都对学习如何制作游戏的前景感到非常兴奋。当他们被告知英语、数学、科学和历史是游戏设计师的关键科目时，他们在这些研究中看到了新的意义。当要求学生应用历史概念并将其用于制作游戏时，他们照做了。学生们玩得很开心，研讨会负责人也是如此。他们也学到了东西。然而，学习对他们来说是次要的。如果学习是制作游戏所必需的，那就这样吧。

The game design workshop turned out to be magic for both the students and the workshop leader. Few were disrespectful. In fact, the students were all very excited about the prospect of learning how to make games. When they were told that English, math, science, and history were critical subjects for game designers, they saw new purpose in those studies. When students were asked to apply a concept from history and use it in a way that would make a game, they did. The students had lots of fun, as did the workshop leader. They learned, too. However, the learning was secondary to them. If learning is what it takes to make games, so be it.

为了进入下一届游戏设计研讨会，这些处于危险中的孩子们自愿通过取得好 成绩和撰写关于他们想要设计的游戏的选修论文来竞争。这里有一个信息：游戏具有独特的力量，可以吸引人们以玩家或设计师的身份进入互动世界。作为玩家、家长和教育者，我们有责任

To get into the next game design workshop, these at-risk kids are voluntarily competing by getting good grades and writing optional papers about the game they want to design. There is a message here: games have a unique power to draw people into an interactive world as a player or as a designer. It is up to us as players, as parents, and as educators to

充分利用这种媒介的优势。您如何整合游戏？

harness this medium for its strengths. How do you integrate games?

为学生设计和修改游戏

DESIGNING AND MODIFYING GAMES FOR STUDENTS

在幼儿园，一位老师给孩子发了一款配对游戏。游戏要求学生将单词配对，然后用它们造句。这个游戏一开始效果不错。但过了不久，孩子们就厌倦了。最终，许多家长也放弃了这款游戏。但有一位家长恰好是专业的游戏设计师。她修改了游戏，增加了奖励机制。她增加了高分和奖励卡，为游戏带来了一些不可预测性。结果，她女儿对游戏的兴趣持续了很长时间。虽然修改很小，但游戏的持久性和学习能力却增加了。

In kindergarten, a teacher sent home a matching game. Students were asked to pair up words and then use them in a sentence. It worked well for a while. After a short time, however, the children became bored with it. Eventually, many parents abandoned the game, too. One parent, however, happened to be a professional game designer. She modified the game to offer a reward structure. She added a high score and bonus cards that introduced some unpredictability into the game. As a result, her daughter stayed interested much longer. The modifications were minor, but lasting and learning power of the game was increased.

在创建以教育为设计目标的游戏时，人们可能会想：“有趣”和“教育”不是互相排斥的吗？毕竟，许多所谓的“寓教于乐”游戏并不特别有趣，玩过足够多此类游戏的孩子理所当然地会怀疑任何成年人带来的“有趣游戏”本应是教人一些东西。善意的教育工作者只是简单地将游戏叠加在本来就无聊的内容之上，创造出的游戏被嘲讽为“巧克力西兰花”。我们可以而且必须做得更好。

When creating a game that must be educational as a design goal, one may wonder: Aren’t “fun” and “educational” mutually exclusive? After all, many so-called “Edutainment” games are not particularly fun, and children who have played enough of them are rightfully skeptical when any adult brings in a “fun game” that is supposed to teach something. By simply layering a game on top of inherently boring content, well-meaning educators create games that are derisively referred to as “chocolate-covered broccoli.” We can and must do better.

教师可以采取多种方法。

There are several approaches teachers can take.

寻找乐趣

FIND THE FUN

在设计原创教育游戏时，要从趣味性入手——不是游戏机制，而是内容。每个学科都有有趣、激动人心或明显有用的方面，学生都想学习它们。如果设计师能在教育内容中找到乐趣，那么围绕它设计游戏并不像看起来那么困难：我们要做的就是不要去除乐趣，找到一种让人们玩它的方法。《西部扩张》可以成为一款充满冒险、可怕的遭遇和偶尔的定居的游戏。《1960：总统的诞生》是一款相对较新的棋盘游戏，它继续获得好评如潮，而这款游戏讲述的是 1960 年的总统大选。它的设计师不仅找到了乐趣，而且做得非常出色。

In the case of designing an original educational game, start with the fun—not in game mechanics, but in content. Every subject has aspects that are interesting, exciting, or so obviously useful that students want to learn them. If the designer can find the fun in the educational content, designing a game around it is not as difficult as it may seem: all one has to do is not remove the fun and find a way to let people play with it. Westward expansion can become a game filled with adventure, terrifying encounters, and occasional settlements. A relatively new board game, 1960: The Making of a President continues to receive rave reviews, and it’s about the 1960 Presidential election. Not only did its designers find the fun, they knocked it out of the park.

请记住，“有趣”一词并不严格指游戏像情景喜剧一样有趣。想想纪录片、艺术展览、伟大的演讲者、发人深省的书籍或讲座。即使它们鼓励我们探索具有挑战性、痛苦或充满情绪的话题，它们也都是“有趣”和娱乐性的。在寻找“乐趣”时，您可以自由地制作模拟这些困难时刻的游戏。乍一看，制作一个困难话题的游戏似乎会使其变得微不足道。然而，事实并非如此。相反，可以将其视为一种抽象的模拟，它为玩家提供了一种以其他媒介无法实现的方式理解事件的能力。通过制作互动内容，动态自然会带来有效的动手学习体验。游戏是促进这种理解的极其强大的媒介。

Keep in mind using the term “fun” doesn’t strictly mean games that are entertaining in a sitcom-type of way. Think of documentaries, art exhibits, great speakers, thought-provoking books, or lectures. Each of these is “fun” and entertaining, too, even if it encourages us to explore a challenging, painful or emotionally-charged topic. In finding the “fun,” feel free to make games that simulate these difficult moments. At first glance, it may seem that making a game of a difficult topic trivializes it. However, nothing could be further from the truth. Rather, consider it an abstracted simulation that provides players with an ability to understand an event in a way that no other medium possibly can. By making something interactive, the dynamics naturally result in an effective hands-on learning experience. Games are an extremely powerful medium to promote this understanding.

从系统开始

START WITH SYSTEMS

请记住，游戏的核心是系统。打个比方，游戏中的系统类似于汽车中的引擎。系统位于数字游戏的引擎盖下，正是这些系统让整个游戏得以运转。

Remember that games, at their heart, are systems. By way of metaphor, the systems in a game are similar to an engine in a car. Systems are under the hood in digital games, and it is those very systems that make the whole game roll.

游戏中简单的原子部分（玩家、机制、做出的决定等等）相互作用，形成复杂的行为和结果。正因为如此，游戏非常适合教授基于这些相同类型系统的内容。例如，物理科学专业的学生学习质量、速度和力之间的关系。展示这些事物运动的物理游戏是这些概念的绝佳展示，使抽象的数学方程式更容易理解和直观。系统也可以在生物学、数学、经济学中找到 - 事实上，它涉及的学科比不多。如果它不能随着时间的推移保持不变，那么就可以将系统变成游戏。

The simple atomic parts of the games (the players, mechanics, decisions made, and so on) interact with one another to form complex behaviors and results. Because of this, games are a natural fit for teaching content that is based on these same kinds of systems. For example, students in physical science learn about the relationships between mass, velocity, and force. A physics game that shows these things in motion is an excellent demonstration of these concepts, making abstract math equations more understandable and intuitive. Systems can also be found in biology, mathematics, economics—more subjects than not, in fact. If it fails to stay constant over time, there’s a system that can be turned into a game.

大多数游戏主要由玩家的决策驱动。如前几章所述，当存在权衡或比较时，决策会变得更有趣。支付 50 美元出狱还是掷骰子？现在攻击你的敌人还是等到下一轮？在没有掩护的情况下跑过空地去拿火箭发射器还是躲在掩体里拿着狙击步枪？这些决定都需要权衡行动和后果，或者对两种截然不同的商品赋予相对价值。这样的权衡不仅仅发生在游戏中；它们贯穿于整个生活。因此，任何涉及理解权衡或比较的主题都是游戏的绝佳基础。例如，经济学领域完全基于权衡几种商品的相对价值。因此，许多游戏都包含游戏内经济也就不足为奇了。应用科学也涉及权衡，尤其是在设计实验并考虑成本、风险和收益时。商业课程通常涉及成本效益分析，这基本上是玩家在游戏中不断做的事情。

Most games are driven primarily by player decisions. As discussed in earlier chapters, decisions become more interesting when there is a tradeoff or comparison. Pay 50 dollars to get out of jail or roll the dice? Attack your enemy now or wait until next turn? Run over open ground without cover to get the rocket launcher or hide in a bunker with a sniper rifle? These decisions all require weighing actions and consequences or placing relative values on two very different commodities. Tradeoffs such as these do not just happen in games; they are found throughout life. As such, any topic that involves understanding tradeoffs or comparisons is an excellent basis for a game. For example, the field of economics is based entirely on weighing the relative value of several commodities. It is no surprise, then, that many games include an in-game economy. The applied sciences also involve tradeoffs, especially when designing an experiment and considering the costs, risks, and benefits. Business classes often involve cost-benefit analysis, which is essentially what players are doing in games on a constant basis.

由于游戏是由玩家的决策驱动的，因此它们非常清楚地显示了因果关系。当两个人玩策略游戏时，双方通常都清楚为什么一个输了而另一个赢了。考虑课堂上的因果关系。在化学中，结合化学物质或加热会引起物理变化。在历史上，重要事件源于一系列可识别的原因。在计算机编程中，机器完全按照程序员的指令行事，因此程序员的操作与计算机的结果之间存在直接联系。

As a consequence of games being driven by player decisions, they show the relationships between cause and effect quite clearly. When two people play a strategy game, it is often clear to both players why one lost and the other won. Consider cause-and-effect relationships in classes. In chemistry, combining chemicals or adding heat can cause a physical change. In history, important events emerge from a series of identifiable causes. In computer programming, the machine does exactly what the programmer tells it, so there is a direct link between the programmer’s actions and the computer’s results.

当大多数教师考虑使用游戏作为教学工具时，他们会将游戏视为死记硬背的辅助手段，因此课堂上很流行问答游戏和抽认卡。但要记住的内容是静态的，而课堂上的概念和系统（有趣且重要的内容）是动态的，就像游戏一样。要利用游戏作为媒介，需要超越内容，找到那些本身就很像游戏的主题。

When most teachers think of using games as teaching tools, they think of using games as rote memorization aids, hence the popularity of quiz-show mechanics and flash cards in the class. But content to be memorized is static, while the concepts and systems in classes— the interesting and important stuff—is dynamic, just like games. To take advantage of games as a medium, look beyond the content and locate those topics that are inherently game-like themselves.

使用他们玩的游戏

USE GAMES THEY PLAY

选取孩子们已经 玩过的游戏，通过直接从教学中添加教育内容来修改它们，使其更具优势。更好的方法是让学生进行整合。如果学生没有特别的建议，请访问 Boardgamegeek.com 获取潜在游戏列表以及基于玩家的质量评级。例如， RISK ® 可以修改为在北美、美国、加拿大各省或任何其他位置的地图上玩。

Take the games kids already play and modify those to your advantage by adding an educational component directly from your teaching. Better yet, ask students to do the integrating. If students have no particular suggestions, visit Boardgamegeek.com to get a list of potential games along with a player-based quality rating. RISK®, for instance, could be modified to play on the map of North America, the United States, the Canadian Provinces or any other location for that matter.

在幼儿园阶段，像Pretty Pretty Princess ® 这样的游戏效果很好。访问 PBSKids.org 等网站，了解为该特定阶段的儿童制作了哪些类型的游戏。这些游戏甚至可以修改为新主题来教育学生。让学生进行实际修改可以巩固材料，并让他们享受设计过程。

At the kindergarten level, games like Pretty Pretty Princess® work great. Visit sites like PBSKids.org to see what types of games are made for children at that particular level. Even these games can be modified with new themes to educate students. Allowing the students to do the actual modification reinforces the material and allows them to enjoy the process of design as well.

在高中，Monopoly®、 Carcassonne或Risk适合进行修改。加速班可能会发现像Puerto Rico或Settlers of Catan®这样的游戏很不错。这些游戏中的每一款都可以进行修改以适应特定的科目。事实上，Mayfair Games 甚至为教师提供了有关如何将Settlers of Catan融入课堂的详细信息 [MFG01]。

In high school, Monopoly®, Carcassonne or Risk are appropriate for modification. Accelerated classes may find luck with games like Puerto Rico or Settlers of Catan®. Every one of these games can be modified to fit a particular subject. In fact, Mayfair Games even offers detailed information for teachers on integrating Settlers of Catan into the classroom [MFG01].

分配游戏设计

ASSIGN GAME DESIGN

另一种选择是让学生围绕手头的主题创建新游戏。虽然学生似乎不太可能完成这样的壮举，但老师可能会感到惊讶。如今，学生对游戏有了大量的了解，光是想到真正制作游戏就让他们兴奋不已。

Another option is to challenge students to create new games focused on the subject matter at hand. While it may seem unlikely that students could pull off such a feat, teachers may be surprised. Today, students have a great amount of knowledge about games, and the mere thought of actually making one gets them excited.

例如，假设学生正在尝试学习美国的各个州。作为一项作业，要求学生制作一款棋盘游戏，以促进他们记住各个州的名称和位置。您甚至可以提供一系列现有的棋盘游戏来激发他们的灵感。会发生什么？在创建游戏的过程中，学生：

For instance, let’s say that students are trying to learn the individual states of the United States. As an assignment, task your students with creating a board game that promotes retention of the individual state names and locations. You can even provide an array of existing board games to inspire them. What happens? In the process of creating the game, the students:

·      了解你希望他们了解的信息

·      Learn the information you wanted them to learn

·      通过艺术板设计表达创造力

·      Express creativity through artistic board design

·      练习空间推理

·      Practice spatial reasoning

·      锻炼团队合作能力

·      Practice teamwork skills

·      练习数学技能（因为所有游戏的根本都是数学模式）

·      Practice mathematical skills (since all games, at their root, are mathematical patterns)

·      玩得开心

·      Have fun

我们一次又一次地看到这样做的成功。因此，为了吸引学生的注意力，使用他们熟悉的游戏，并利用现有的游戏设计。从这个角度来看，每个人都是游戏设计师。

Time and time again, we have seen success in doing so. So, in order to capture students’ attention, use the games they know, and take advantage of pre-existing game designs. Taken in this context, everyone is a game designer.

挑战

CHALLENGES

本章中的练习提供了一个独特的双重挑战：

The exercises in this chapter offer a unique double challenge:

·      对于教育工作者来说，这些挑战提供了一个机会，可以在课堂上创建游戏，以强化或传递所需的教育内容。这些游戏可以在课堂外创建，也可以与其他教育工作者或学生一起创建。

·      For educators, these challenges provide an opportunity to create games for use in the classroom to reinforce or deliver the desired educational content. The games are created outside of the classroom or in conjunction with other educators or the students themselves.

·      对于学生来说，挑战赛提供了绝佳的机会来研究指定主题并将其应用于现有游戏（可能是他们最喜欢的游戏）或根据指定主题创建全新的游戏。当然，每款游戏的细节程度以及所需的策略数量都需要根据学生的能力进行调整。

·      For students, the challenges provide an excellent opportunity to research an assigned topic and apply it to an existing game (likely their favorite) or create a brand new game from an assigned topic. Naturally, the level of detail in each game, as well as the amount of strategy required, will need to be altered to suit the students’ abilities.

挑战 1——旧游戏，新生活

CHALLENGE 1—OLD GAME, NEW LIFE

棋盘游戏的适应性极强。以大富翁为例。目前大富翁有 1,200 多个版本，每个版本都有不同的主题。Irishopoly 、 Dogopoly、Catopoly — 你能想到的都有。对于这项挑战，你必须使用任何标准棋盘游戏并为其赋予历史背景。对于创作游戏的学生来说，这项挑战的目标应该是掌握主题。

Board games are extremely adaptable creatures. Consider Monopoly. There are presently over 1,200 different versions of Monopoly, each with a different theme. Irishopoly, Dogopoly, Catopoly—you name it, and it’s been done. For this challenge, you must use any standard board game and give it an historical setting. For students creating games, the goal of this challenge should be topic mastery.

所需组件

Components Required

·      网络连接或供研究的书籍

·      Internet connection or books for research

可交付成果

Deliverable

·      棋盘游戏的修改版本，包括新棋盘

·      A modified version of the board game, including new board

·      修改规则集（可选）

·      A modified set of rules (optional)

·      一套经过修改的游戏代币（可选）

·      A modified set of game tokens (optional)

建议流程

Suggested Process

1.    选择要修改的游戏。所有游戏都可以适应不同的主题。难度只在于理解原始游戏的方向。一定要选择一些容易解释、容易理解且可以在你分配的时间段内在课堂上玩的游戏。例如，一个简单的Twilight Imperium™游戏不太可能玩，因为游戏时间大约为四个小时，不包括解释规则所需的时间。

1.    Choose a game to modify. All games are adaptable to different themes. The degree of difficulty comes only in understanding the directions of the original game. Be sure to pick something easily explained, understood, and played in a classroom in the time period you’ve allocated. A simple game of Twilight Imperium™, for instance, is unlikely to be had, as the playing time is about four hours, not including the time necessary to explain the rules.

2.    选择主题。 主题越具体越好。不过，这只是经验法则，而不是硬性规定。目前正在研究的主题自然是目标。

2.    Choose a topic. The more specific the topic, the better. However, this is only a rule of thumb and not a rigid rule. Topics that are currently being studied are natural targets.

3.    研究主题。选定主题后，使用互联网或其他资源研究主题。

3.    Research your topic. Once the topic is selected, research your topic using the Internet or other resources provided.

4.    修改主题。 列出所有游戏元素，并确定如何替换它们以适应新主题。例如，如果您使用Clue ® 作为游戏，也许您可​​以使用同样著名的历史背景和角色。研究角色、场景等对于游戏设计师来说通常是一个非常有趣的过程，它是游戏创作回报的一部分。

4.    Modify the theme. Make a list of all the game bits and determine how you will replace these to fit the new theme. For instance, if you use Clue® as a game, perhaps you could use equally famous historical settings and characters. Researching characters, sets, and the like is often a very fun process for game designers, and it is part of the reward of game creation.

5.    制作原型。选定主题后，制作相关游戏的原型。请记住，棋盘游戏原型不需要很漂亮。你的目标是看看游戏本身是否可玩且有趣。如果你选择添加游戏机制，测试这个原型就变得比以往任何时候都重要。

5.    Make a prototype. Once a topic has been selected, make a prototype of the game in question. Remember that board game prototypes don’t need to be pretty. Your goal here is to see if the game itself is playable and interesting. If you opt to add a gameplay mechanic, testing this prototype becomes more important than ever.

6.    创建可交付成果。

6.    Create deliverable.

变体

Variants

您可以通过这项挑战探索多种变体。为游戏添加适合所选主题的机制。您可能需要修改其他几种机制来平衡新机制。根据主题创建一个全新的游戏。这是一项非常具有挑战性的练习，特别是如果学生没有任何限制。考虑给他们一些指导，例如创建一个基于领土获取的游戏或像Candy Land这样的游戏中常见的“竞速到终点”范式的游戏。

There are numerous variants you can explore with this challenge. Add a mechanic to the game that fits the chosen theme. You may have to modify several other mechanics to balance the new one. Create a brand new game from a topic. This is a very challenging exercise, particularly if students have no constraints. Consider giving them some direction, such as creating a game based around territorial acquisition or the “race to the end” paradigm common in games like Candy Land.

挑战 2——教育娱乐

CHALLENGE 2—EDUCATIONAL ENTERTAINMENT

“孩子们，历史课到了！”这可能不是教育工作者们所希望的口号。然而，通过游戏，也许可以。许多游戏都以娱乐为幌子进行教学。历史类游戏可能是最常用的。像《俄勒冈之旅》和《文明》 系列这样的游戏立刻浮现在我的脑海中，还有其他几十种游戏。加拿大政府甚至委托开发了一款加拿大历史游戏，该游戏使用了加拿大公司 Bitcasters 开发的《文明 IV》引擎。

“History time, kids!” It might not be the rallying cry educators wish it were. Through games, however, perhaps it can be. Numerous games have been created that teach under the cover of entertainment. The history genre is probably the most commonly used. Games like The Oregon Trail™ and the Civilization™ series immediately come to mind, and there are dozens of others. The Canadian government even commissioned a Canadian history game that used the Civilization IV engine developed by Canadian company Bitcasters.

其他主题也通过游戏提出。例如Dimenxion — 一款教授代数的 FPS！

Other topics have been broached via games as well. Consider Dimenxion—an FPS that teaches algebra!

对于这一挑战，您的目标是创建一个电脑游戏的概念，以有趣但不说教的方式教授任何中学课程。

For this challenge, your goal is to create a concept for a PC game that teaches any middle grade school subject in a way that is entertaining without being didactic.

所需组件

Components Required

·      没有任何

·      None

可交付成果

Deliverable

·      游戏的概念演示，解释游戏将如何教授特定主题以及为什么游戏会很有趣

·      A concept presentation for a game that explains how the game will teach a particular subject and why this might be entertaining

建议流程

Suggested Process

·      选择主题。 如本章前面所述，游戏中最容易建模的主题是那些具有交互系统、比较、权衡和因果关系的情况。远离那些仅通过重复和记忆来教授内容的游戏。《危险边缘！》已经做过了。更重要的是，如果你过于关注内容而不是概念，你就会忽略这种媒介的最大优势：建模系统并展示系统启动时会发生什么的能力。你不必在一整年的时间里教授一门完整的学科。你可以专注于一个学科中特别适合游戏的方面。你的游戏的规模和复杂性应该与它涵盖的课程材料量成正比。

·      Choose a subject. As mentioned earlier in this chapter, subjects that are easiest to model in games are those with interacting systems, comparisons, tradeoffs, and cause-and-effect situations. Stay away from games that merely teach content through repetition and memorization. Jeopardy! has already been done before. More importantly, if you focus too much on content rather than concepts, you ignore the greatest strength of the medium: the ability to model systems and show what happens when they are set in motion. You do not have to teach a complete subject over the course of a full year. You can focus on one aspect of a subject that lends itself particularly well to games. The scale and complexity of your game should be proportional to how much course material it covers.

·      创建游戏模型。找到主题中与游戏本质上相似的方面。基于现实世界中驱动系统的“机制”，思考如何在游戏环境中对系统进行建模。如果您感到困惑，浏览 BoardGameGeek.com 应该会有所帮助。在查看游戏描述时，思考如何将您的主题插入其设计中。您可能会遇到一些需要在游戏机制中准确保留的内容。其他内容可以简化，以便游戏不会变得过于复杂。在教育游戏中，游戏玩法和现实之间的权衡很难，作为教育者和游戏设计师，您需要同时考虑两者。从您的选择中，应该会出现一组核心机制。

·      Create a game model. Find those aspects of your subject that are inherently game-like. Think of ways to model the systems in the context of a game, based on the “mechanics” that drive the systems in the real world. If you feel stuck, a browse through BoardGameGeek.com should help. As you look over the descriptions of the games, think of how you could insert your subject into its design. You may encounter some content that needs to be preserved exactly in the game mechanics. Other content can be simplified so that the game isn’t needlessly complex. The tradeoff between gameplay and reality is difficult in educational games, and as both educator and game designer, you need to consider both. From your choices, a set of core mechanics should emerge.

·      创建可交付成果。 请注意，对于此挑战，您只需要一个核心想法，而不是一个完全可玩的原型。当然，如果您愿意，您可以进一步发展您的想法。

·      Create deliverable. Note that for this challenge you only need a core idea, not a fully playable prototype. Of course, you can take your idea further if you desire.

变体

Variant

不要创造自己的想法，而要批评别人的想法。找到一款现有的可以教授任何小学科目的视频游戏。准备一份口头或书面陈述，内容包括：

Instead of creating your own idea, critique someone else’s. Find an existing video game that teaches any grade-school subject. Prepare an oral or written presentation that includes:

·      游戏教授所选科目的方法

·      The game’s approach to teaching its chosen subject

·      游戏是否成功地传授了内容，以及原因

·      Whether the game succeeds at teaching the content, and why or why not

·      游戏是否有趣，以及为什么有趣

·      Whether the game is fun, and why or why not

·      游戏改进建议

·      Suggested improvements to the game

挑战三——历史战役

CHALLENGE 3—HISTORICAL BATTLES

学生可能会忽略历史战役的细节，尤其是因为战役数量太多。我们怎样才能让历史战役栩栩如生呢？方法和数百万玩家一样——把它们变成棋盘游戏。事实上，有一类游戏叫做“战争游戏”，可以让人们重现战役。

The details of historical battles can be lost on students, particularly because there are so many of them. How can we make historical battles come to life? The same way that millions of players have—by turning them into board games. In fact, there’s a whole genre of games called “war games” that allow people to replay battles.

在本练习中，选择一场历史战役，并创建一款将这场战役的主要特征融入其中的游戏。一种方法是修改现有的战争游戏，例如RISK、Axis & Allies ® 或Memoir '44 TM。另一种方法是从头开始创建自己的游戏，如果您选择的战役发生在其他游戏不易涵盖的独特条件下，则可能需要这样做。

For this exercise, select a historical battle and create a game that incorporates key features of the battle into it. One way to do this is to modify an existing war game, such as RISK, Axis & Allies®, or Memoir ’44TM. Another way is to create your own game from scratch, which may be necessary if the battle you choose takes place under unique conditions that aren’t easily covered by another game.

战争游戏的目的是让玩家了解双方领导人所面临的选择。因此，玩家应该做出此类战略选择，而不仅仅是掷骰子。

The purpose of your war game is to teach the choices that were faced by the leaders of each side. Therefore, the players should be making these kinds of strategic choices and not just rolling lots of dice.

所需组件

Components Required

·      现有战争游戏的副本（可选）

·      Copy of an existing war game (optional)

·      制作原型的材料

·      Materials to create prototype

可交付成果

Deliverable

·      可玩的棋盘游戏原型

·      Playable board game prototype

建议流程

Suggested Process

1.    选择一场战役。 大多数真正著名的历史战役都已经有几款基于它们制作的游戏。如果您是历史爱好者，请选择一场鲜为人知的战役，该战役可能以前没有发生过，但从游戏玩家的角度来看，它足够有趣，值得一玩。如果您选择了一场著名的战役，请不要寻找或玩任何其他基于该战役的游戏，直到您完成此挑战。不要让您的创造力受到以前发生的事情的限制。在您的原型完成后，将其与现有的商业游戏进行比较是一种极好的方式来批评您自己的作品。无论哪种方式，请选择一场双方都有真正获胜机会的战役。如果一个玩家总是赢，那么游戏就不怎么样！

1.    Choose a battle. Most of the really famous historical battles already have several games based on them. If you are a history buff, choose a battle that is obscure enough that it might not have been done before, but interesting enough (from a game player’s perspective) that it’s worth doing. If you choose a well-known battle, do not seek out or play any other games based on it until you are done with this challenge. Do not allow your creativity to be constrained by what has come before. After your prototype is complete, comparing it to existing commercial games provides an excellent way to critique your own work. Either way, choose a battle where both sides had a real chance of winning. If one player always wins, it’s not much of a game!

2.    研究和更多研究。基于历史的游戏需要比普通游戏更多的研究。考虑以下需要回答的问题：这场战役的历史背景是什么？这场战役为什么会打起来，为什么会如此重要？双方的指挥官是谁？他们拥有哪些部队？这些部队的相对能力如何？（他们可以穿越什么地形，是否有比其他部队更强大的部队，是否有任何部队拥有特殊的装备、能力或训练，使他们彼此不同？）双方的目标是什么（例如击溃敌人或控制战略位置）？这场战役在什么地形上进行？这种地形对双方有利还是不利？它对战斗方式有什么影响吗？从军事历史的角度来看，这场战役的哪些方面很有趣？例如，一支较小的部队击败了一支大得多的部队，还是领导者想出了一些出色而创新的战略或战术？

2.    Research and more research. Games based on history require more research than your average game. Consider the following questions that you need to answer: What is the historical context of this battle? Why was it being fought that made it important in the first place? Who was in command of each side? What forces did they have at their disposal? What were the relative capabilities of these forces? (What terrain could they cross, were any forces stronger than others, did any of them have special equipment or abilities or training that made them different from each other?) What was the goal of each side (such as routing the enemy or taking control of a strategic location)? What terrain was the battle being fought on? Did this terrain favor or hinder either side? Did it have any effects on the way the battle was fought? What aspects of this battle are interesting from a military history perspective? For example, did a smaller force beat a much larger one, or did the leaders come up with some brilliant and innovative strategy or tactics?

3.    创建核心。 考虑关于这场战斗的所有信息。突出那些对深入了解这场战斗绝对关键的信息。确保这些信息在你的游戏玩法中得到保留。事实上，战斗中最重要的方面应该是你的核心机制的基础。

3.    Create the core. Consider all of the information you have about this battle. Highlight the information that is absolutely critical to gaining a deep understanding of the battle. Make sure that this is preserved in your gameplay. In fact, the most important aspects of the battle should be the basis for your core mechanics.

4.    创建机制。 根据所有数据进行精确模拟很容易，但并不特别有趣。（玩家将花费更多时间计算射击轨迹和掷骰子，而不是做出重要而有趣的决定。）相反，花时间思考如何简化历史数据，以便保留总体思路，同时尽可能保持易学性和趣味性。

4.    Create the mechanics. Making an exact simulation based on all of your data is easy, but not particularly fun. (The players will spend more time calculating shot trajectories and rolling dice than they do making the important and interesting decisions.) Instead, spend your time thinking of ways to simplify the historical data so that the general idea is preserved while still being as easy to learn and fun to play as possible.

5.    创建可交付成果。

5.    Create deliverable.

挑战 4——我亲爱的关卡设计师

CHALLENGE 4—ELEMENTARY, MY DEAR LEVEL DESIGNER

每个人都有自己的家——无论是公主还是邪恶的战士。在本练习中，您将创建另一个“家”，即包含特别令人困惑的谜团解决方案的关卡。您的谜团可能是真实的或虚构的，已解决的或未解决的，但应该反映实际历史谜团中的主题。示例谜团包括：

Everyone has a home—from princesses to wicked warriors. For this exercise, you’ll be creating another “home” of sorts, a level which contains the solution of a particularly baffling mystery. Your mystery may be real or imagined, solved or unsolved, but should reflect themes found in actual historical mystery. Sample mysteries include:

·      埃尔哈特的飞机

·      Earhart’s plane

·      开膛手杰克

·      Jack the Ripper

·      复活节岛的摩艾石像

·      The Moai of Easter Island

·      百慕大三角

·      The Bermuda Triangle

您的级别必须至少包含以下内容：

Your level must contain at least the following:

·      玩家入口点

·      Player entry point

·      一个物理谜题

·      One physical puzzle

·      一件物品拼图

·      One item puzzle

·      一道谜语

·      One riddle

·      解决方案

·      Solution

通过这次挑战以及其他类似的挑战，您可以鼓励学生不仅探索主题，而且还探索其背后的奥秘。

Throughout this challenge and others like it, you can encourage students to explore not only topics but the mysteries behind them as well.

所需组件

Components Required

·      互联网用于研究

·      Internet for research

·      方格纸（可选）

·      Graph paper (optional)

可交付成果

Deliverable

·      关卡草图，或

·      Rough sketch of the level, or

·      方格纸层面设计，以及

·      Graph paper level design, and

·      允许玩关卡的游戏规则系统

·      System of game rules that allows the level to be played

建议流程

Suggested Process

1.    选择谜题。 记住这个挑战。由于您正在设计关卡，因此涉及在几个附近地点之间旅行的谜题最容易处理。您必须提供几种谜题，因此请确保您的谜题包含这些元素（或结构合理，以便您可以添加它们）。

1.    Choose your mystery. Keep this challenge in mind. Since you are designing a level, mysteries that involve travel between several nearby locations are the easiest to work with. You must provide puzzles of several kinds, so make sure your mystery has those elements (or is structured so that you can add them).

2.    逆向思考。 在写侦探故事或设计谜题时，作者通常从解决方案开始。玩家或主角发现的最终“答案”是什么？从那里开始，问问自己解决方案是如何发现的。可以拼凑在一起的线索是什么，这些线索在哪里找到？再往后退一步。为什么玩家会访问找到线索的地点？哪些早期的线索会引出后来的线索？继续这样逆向思考，直到找到开头。哪些事件引发了谜团？玩家是如何参与其中的？

2.    Work backwards. When writing a detective story or designing a puzzle, authors often begin with the solution. What is the final “answer” that the player or main character discovers? From there, ask yourself how the solution is discovered. What are the clues that can be pieced together, and where are those clues found? Step farther back. Why would the player visit the locations where the clues are found? What earlier clues lead to the later ones? Continue working backwards like this until you reach a beginning. What events set the mystery in motion? How is the player involved?

3.    勾勒关卡草图。将初始草图画得很粗略，以便让您了解玩家如何通过关卡。此时，您不需要确定所有细节。相反，要考虑“大局”。

3.    Sketch out the level. Make your initial sketches very rough just to give you an idea of how the player might move through the level. At this point, you don’t want to nail down all the little details. Rather, think “big picture.”

4.    设计关卡。 添加玩家需要找到的线索和谜题。设置开始条件：玩家入口点、所有物品和 NPC 的起始位置以及初始游戏状态的任何其他元素。定义胜利条件。要解决关卡必须发生什么？玩家必须面对的最终挑战是什么（例如谜题或敌对遭遇）？玩家获胜后会发生什么？

4.    Design the level. Add the clues and puzzles that the player needs to find. Set up the start conditions: player entry point, starting locations of all items and NPCs, and any other elements of the initial game state. Define the victory condition. What must happen for the level to be solved? What is the final challenge that the player must face (a puzzle or a hostile encounter, for example)? What happens when the player wins?

5.    理智检查。 一步一步地完成关卡。首先，确保关卡是可以解决的，并且没有（例如）两个谜题需要先完成另一个谜题。接下来，确保玩家可以获得完成每个谜题所需的所有线索。最好允许每个谜题有多个解决方案或多组线索，这样错过一些隐藏小细节的玩家就不会永远卡在关卡中。

5.    Sanity check. Walk through the level step by step. First, make sure it is possible to solve, and that you don’t have (for example) two puzzles that each require the other to be completed first. Next, make sure that the player has access to all of the clues he or she needs to finish each puzzle. Preferably, allow each puzzle to have multiple solutions or multiple sets of clues so that a player who misses some small hidden detail will not be permanently stuck.

6.    设计规则系统（可选）。玩家如何在这个关卡中移动？玩家可以采取哪些行动？是否还有其他考虑因素，例如 NPC 移动或时间限制？是否有对话系统？如果有，玩家如何选择要说什么（以及游戏如何知道如何响应）？

6.    Design the rules system (optional). How does the player move around in this level? What actions can the player take? Are there additional considerations, like NPC movement or time limits? Is there a conversation system, and if so, how does the player choose what to say (and how does the game know how to respond)?

7.    创建可交付成果。

7.    Create deliverable.

铁艺设计师挑战 5 — 活生生的历史

IRON DESIGNER CHALLENGE 5—LIVING HISTORY

玩游戏不需要围坐在桌子旁。事实上，它们可以现场玩。这类活动通常被称为“LARP”或真人角色扮演游戏。对于这个挑战，创建一个代表特定历史事件的 LARP。LARP 应该可以在一个有 20 到 30 名学生的高中或大学课堂上，在一个课时（一到两个小时）内进行。

Games don’t need to be played sitting around a table. In fact, they can be played live. Such events are often referred to as “LARPs” or live action role playing games. For this challenge, create a LARP that represents a particular historical event. The LARP should be playable in a high school or college class of 20 to 30 students, within a single class period (one or two hours).

你需要选择一个每个人都能参与的事件。事件不必完全按照历史上的方式发生。事实上，它可能不会发生，而这正是乐趣所在。玩过之后，学生们应该明白这个事件很复杂，而且许多不同的派别都有相互冲突的目标。当学生们被告知事件是如何发生的，他们应该明白结果是如何从最初的情况中产生的。

You need to choose an event in which everyone can play a role. The event need not transpire exactly the way it did historically. In fact, it probably won’t, and that’s part of the fun. After playing, the students should understand that the event was complicated, and that many different parties had conflicting goals. When told how the event actually transpired, the students should understand how the result emerged from the initial situation.

所需组件

Components Required

·      没有任何

·      None

可交付成果

Deliverable

·      为每位学生印制一套规则

·      Set of printed rules for each student

·      每位学生的性格表

·      Character sheet for each student

·      教师笔记

·      Teacher notes

·      正式课程计划（可选）

·      Formal lesson plan (optional)

建议流程

Suggested Process

1.    选择一个事件。 此挑战中最简单的事件是多个政党（每个政党都有自己的议程）在某种谈判或冲突中相遇。例如制宪会议、京都议定书或第一次世界大战。

1.    Choose an event. The easiest events for this challenge are those where a number of parties, each with their own agenda, met in some kind of negotiation or conflict. Examples include the Constitutional Convention, the Kyoto Protocol, or World War I.

2.    选择参与者。 你的活动不太可能正好有20到 30 名参与者。对于人数较少的活动，可以考虑将几名学生分配到同一个“团队”。对于实际参与者过多的活动，请选择最重要的或最有影响力的参与者。

2.    Choose the players. It’s unlikely that your event will have exactly 20 to 30 participants. For events with fewer people, consider ways to assign several students to the same “team.” For events with too many actual participants, choose the most important or influential ones.

3.    制定目标。 对于每个玩家或团队，问问自己他们过去的目标是什么。他们想推进议程吗？他们想要钱吗？自由？权力？还是这些东西？把它们都写下来，按参与者分类。参与者的目标很可能是相互冲突的——否则，事件中就不会有太多的历史！如果参与者有多个目标（或一个目标有几种成功或失败的程度），请为每个可能的结果分配数值以确定最终得分。所有参与者应该具有相同的最高可能分数。

3.    Create the goals. For each player or team, ask yourself what their goals were, historically. Did they want to advance an agenda? Did they want money? Freedom? Power? Several of these things? Write them all down, organized by participant. More than likely, the participants had conflicting goals—otherwise, there wouldn’t be much history in the event! If participants have several goals (or a single goal with several degrees of success or failure), assign numeric values to each possible outcome to determine a final score. All participants should have the same maximum possible score.

4.    制定规则。 参与者是否需要参与任何形式的直接冲突？如果是，你必须提供解决方法。由于玩家会不断四处走动并互相交谈，因此解决冲突必须简单而快速。一些 LARP 使用诸如单次掷骰子或一轮石头剪刀布之类的系统。如果参与者的能力不同（例如军事实力），请记下这一点。你可能需要在每个玩家的角色表中添加数字统计数据或特殊能力，以用于解决冲突。还要记下任何其他限制：时间限制、谁可以与谁交谈或互动的限制、允许的团队交流量等等。

4.    Create the rules. Do the participants ever need to engage in any kind of direct conflict? If so, you must provide a way to resolve it. Since the players will be constantly wandering around and talking to each other, conflict resolution must be kept simple and fast. Some LARPs use systems such as a single die roll or a round of Rock-Paper-Scissors. If participants have differing capabilities (such as military strength), make a note of this. You may need to add numeric stats or special abilities to each player’s character sheet to be used in conflict resolution. Also make note of any other constraints: time limits, limitations on who can talk to or interact with whom, amount of team communications allowed, and so on.

6.    创建可交付成果。 此时，您应该拥有正式编写规则、玩家或团队特定统计数据、目标和背景（以“角色表”的形式编写）所需的所有信息。您还可以将这些信息汇编成一系列紧凑的图表和脚注，供老师参考。您也可以选择创建正式的课程计划。在上述可交付成果中，添加一些历史背景说明，这些说明可以作为 LARP 开始前的简短介绍性讲座。最后还要添加汇报笔记，详细说明实际事件中发生的事情，以及关于实际事件和 LARP 结果的谈话要点和讨论问题列表。

6.    Create deliverable. At this point, you should have all the information you need to formally write up the rules, and the player or team-specific stats and goals and background (which is written up as a “character sheet”). You can also compile these into a series of compact charts and footnotes for the teacher. Optionally, you can also create a formal lesson plan. To the above deliverables, add some historical background notes that can serve as a short introductory lecture given before the LARP begins. Also add debriefing notes at the end, detailing what happened in the actual event, and a list of talking points and discussion questions about the actual event and the LARP outcome.

变体

Variant

创建一个迷你角色扮演游戏。与 LARP 类似，从历史中的特定事件中创建或选择角色并实际玩这个游戏。你必须确定这些角色的基本技能和统计数据，以及他们需要做些什么才能成功。RPG 通常是围坐在桌子旁玩的（而不是像 LARP 那样站着以自由形式互动），因此要为 4 到 6 名学生设计一个小组，并安排一名 GM 来裁判活动。较大的班级应该分成几个小组，每个小组玩同一个 RPG 的不同版本。在这种情况下，每个游戏都会有一名学生担任 GM（老师负责监督一切），所以除了老师的笔记外，你还需要一套类似的 GM 笔记。

Create a mini role-playing game. Similar to the LARP, create or select characters from a particular event in history and actually play it out. You must determine the basic skills and statistics of those characters, as well as what they will need to do to succeed. An RPG is normally played sitting down around a table (rather than standing around and interacting in a freeform way as with a LARP), so design for groups of four to six students and a single GM to referee the event. Larger classes would be expected to split into several groups, each playing its own version of the same RPG. In this case, a student would be the GM in each game (with the teacher overseeing everything), so in addition to the teacher’s notes you would need a similar set of notes for the GM.

非数字短片

NON-DIGITAL SHORTS

这些挑战鼓励您以多种方式在教育中使用游戏。

These challenges encourage you to use games in within education in a variety of ways.

1.    设计一款回合制策略游戏，由老师管理，学生在课堂外轮流完成游戏作为家庭作业。

1.    Design a turn-based strategy game to be administered by a teacher in which students complete turns as homework outside of the classroom.

2.    设计一款游戏，帮助学生为死记硬背的考试做好准备，例如艺术史或地理。

2.    Design a game that prepares students for a rote memorization exam, such as art history or geography.

3.    设计一个游戏来阐明入门代数的概念。

3.    Design a game that illustrates the concepts of introductory algebra.

4.    设计一款以基因复制和遗传原理为基础的系统游戏。

4.    Design a game featuring systems based on the principles of genetic replication and inheritance.

5.    设计一款游戏，教玩家如何组织非暴力抗议。

5.    Design a game that teaches players how to organize non-violent protests.

6.    为当地交通管理部门设计一款游戏，教人们如何乘坐公交车出行。

6.    Design a game for your local transportation authority that teaches people how to get around by bus.

7.    重新设计糖果乐园，向孩子们传授有关光谱以及光和颜色的物理知识。

7.    Redesign Candy Land to teach children about the spectrum and the physics of light and color.

8.    重新设计Go Fish ，教孩子们了解地质学。您不需要使用标准扑克牌。

8.    Redesign Go Fish to teach children about geology. You do not need to use standard playing cards.

9.    重新设计《生命游戏》来描绘您所选择的地点的十八世纪生活。

9.    Redesign The Game of Life to illustrate life in the eighteenth-century at a location of your choice.

10. 创建一个纸牌游戏，教授元素周期表中不同元素组之间的相互作用。

10. Create a card game that teaches the interactions between different groups of elements from the Periodic Table.

参考

REFERENCES

[GM01] http://www.theglobeandmail.com/servlet/Page/document/v5/content/subscribe? user_URL=http://www.theglobeandmail.com%2Fservlet%2Fstory%2FRTGAM.20060209. wxbrains09%2FBNStory%2FScience%2Fhome&ord=111952&brand=theglobeandmail&fo rce_login=true

[NPR01] http://www.npr.org/templates/story/story.php?storyId=4806921 [BBC01] http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/technology/2943280.stm_[MFG01] http://www.mayfairgames.com/ —click on “Teacher Zone”

 

 

 

 


 

 

19：严肃游戏

19: Serious Games

 

 

和任何其他艺术形式一样，游戏不仅仅具有娱乐性。让我们想象一下书籍。它们可以传达信息、教育、说服、号召行动等。主要目的不是为了娱乐的游戏被称为“严肃游戏”，游戏行业甚至严肃游戏制作者使用这个术语时都不太热情。

Like any other form of art, games are good for more than just pure entertainment. For a moment, think of books. They convey information, educate, persuade, and provide a call to action among other things. Games whose primary purpose goes beyond entertainment are called “serious games,” a term the game industry and even serious game makers use with something less than enthusiasm.

那么为什么是“严肃游戏”呢？首先，对一些人来说，“游戏”一词意味着这个话题有些琐碎。他们认为，游戏很有趣，纯粹是为了娱乐。除非前面加上“战争”一词，否则人们很少认为游戏有什么用处。当试图将游戏作为一种有说服力的媒介来销售时，早期业内人士发现将这类游戏称为“严肃游戏”很有用。

Why “serious games” then? For starters, to some, the term “games” implies that the topic has a degree of triviality. Games, they think, are fun and something we do purely to entertain ourselves. Unless preceded by the term “war,” people rarely think of games as useful for any particular purpose. When attempting to sell games as a persuasive medium, those in the business early on found it useful to refer to this class of games as “serious games.”

自严肃游戏诞生以来，该类型游戏已发展成为一个价值数百万美元的产业。国际游戏开发者协会 (International Game Developers Association) 内的一个 SIG 专门研究这一主题，它已成为全球多个会议的焦点。

Since the early days of serious games, the genre has grown to become a multimillion dollar industry. A SIG within the International Game Developers Association devotes itself to the topic, and it has become the focus of multiple conferences around the world.

本章旨在为您简要介绍此类游戏。有关该主题的完整书籍已经出版，有兴趣的人可以进一步研究。

This chapter is designed to give you a brief overview of this type of game. Complete books have been written on the subject, and those interested are encouraged to research further.

严肃游戏的类型

TYPES OF SERIOUS GAMES

严肃游戏种类繁多，令人眼花缭乱。快速浏览 WaterCoolerGames.com 网站，您就会发现这些游戏有多达 20 种不同的分类，而且不时还会添加更多分类。一般来说，严肃游戏不像传统游戏行业那样根据机制、动态、视角或游戏模式对游戏进行分类（例如“第一人称射击游戏”或“平台游戏”），而是倾向于根据目的而不是游戏玩法进行分类。

The array of serious games is nearly dizzying. A quick trip to the site of WaterCoolerGames.com reveals no fewer than 20 different classifications of these games, and more are being added from time to time. In general, rather than class games by mechanic, dynamic, perspective, or play pattern as the traditional game industry does (for example, “first person shooter” or “platformer”), serious games tend to be grouped by purpose instead of play.

下面介绍了一些比较流行的游戏类型。然而，与这个新兴领域的许多事情一样，这些名称既不是固定不变的，也不是详尽无遗的清单。相反，它们旨在让您了解该领域内的可能性。

Some of the more popular types of games are covered below. As with many things about this emerging field, however, these names are neither hard and fast nor an exhaustive listing. Rather, they are meant to provide you with an idea of the possibilities within the space.

训练游戏

TRAINING GAMES

训练游戏旨在让一个人经历一个特定的场景，让他或她在尝试做真正的事之前获得舒适感，甚至掌握它。最著名的训练游戏类型是军用飞行模拟器。飞行员在这些机器上花费了数不清的时间，然后才驾驶自己的飞机。

Training games are designed to put a person through a specific scenario and allow him or her to gain comfort and perhaps even mastery over it before attempting to do the real thing. The most well-known type of training games are military flight simulators. Pilots spend untold hours in these machines before heading off in a plane of their own.

不过，企业客户也开始加入进来。冰淇淋零售商 Cold Stone Creamery 专门为员工开发了一款培训游戏，教他们如何正确销售公司产品。其他零售商使用模拟游戏让销售人员在不同的顾客身上练习他们的销售技巧，同时衡量他们的方法的相对成功或失败。

Corporate clients are also getting on board, however. Cold Stone Creamery, an icecream retailer, commissioned a training game expressly for their employees to teach them the proper technique and measurements for the company’s products. Other retailers use simulations to allow salesmen to practice their trade on various customers while gauging the relative success or failure of their approach.

训练领域最近出现的内容之一是灾难准备。诸如HazMat: HotZone之类的游戏让玩家置身于末日场景中，以了解他们如何处理紧急服务部署、人口管理等。

One of the more recent entries into the training field is disaster preparedness. Games such as HazMat: HotZone put players into a doomsday scenario to seen how they handle emergency service deployment, population management, and more.

然而，大多数训练游戏的预算较少，而且针对特定受众的目的非常明确。游戏的制作目的多种多样，从教年幼的孩子如何避免网络犯罪到节约用水。

For the most part, however, training games are smaller budget and with very specific purposes that target specific audiences. Games have been made for every purpose, from teaching younger children to avoid Internet predators to water conservation.

有趣的是，在将游戏视为训练游戏时，我们实际上是在回顾游戏和玩耍的根源。玩耍本身就是一场真实遭遇战的练习，而游戏提供了一个测试战略和战术的机会，而不用担心后果。从掠食动物的本能游戏到后来演变成的战争游戏，游戏一直都有一个严肃的目的。

Interestingly enough, in looking at games as training games, we are actually looking back to the roots of games and of play. Play itself was a practice run for a real-life encounter, and game-play provided a chance to test strategies and tactics without fear of consequence. From the instinctual play of predatory animals to the war games that later evolved, games have always had a serious purpose.

健康游戏

HEALTH GAMES

健康游戏既指训练人们执行健康相关任务的游戏，也指使人们更健康的游戏。GlucoBoy和Re -Mission是此类游戏的两个极佳例子。另一个例子是广受欢迎的Wii Fit。像Wii Fit这样的游戏也经常被称为“锻炼游戏”，或简称为“exergames”。

Health games represent both games that train people to perform health-related tasks and games that make people healthier. GlucoBoy and Re-Mission are two excellent examples of games in this genre. The popular Wii Fit is another. Games like Wii Fit are also often called “exercise games,” or “exergames” for short.

和精密军事模拟一样，健康游戏为从业者提供了在宽容且具有指导意义的环境中训练的机会。然而，锻炼游戏最终可能会成为更大的市场。随着游戏机一代的年龄增长，对任天堂 Wii 等全能机器的渴望使得“游戏机”和“锻炼机”可能成为同一种东西。

Like precision military simulations, health games provide practitioners with an opportunity to train in a forgiving and instructional environment. Exercise games may end up being the larger market, however. As the console generation gets older, the desire for an all-around machine like the Nintendo Wii makes the “game machine” and the “exercise machine” potentially one and the same.

尽管《热舞革命》等游戏经常被标榜为“健康游戏”，但严格来说，它们并不是。《DDR》和类似的游戏确实在帮助玩家保持健康方面做得很好，但这显然不是游戏的主要目的。

Although games like Dance Dance Revolution are often billed as “health games,” strictly speaking, they’re not. DDR and games like it certainly do a great job of getting players into shape, but that was clearly not the prime intent of the game.

社交评论游戏

SOCIAL-COMMENTARY GAMES

正如前几代人举行静坐、集会和抗议一样，这一代人组建 Facebook 群组、创建博客并制作游戏（有时还会做其他事情）。游戏是一种非常强大的手段，可以传达观点并通过互联网将观点传播到全世界。Persuasive Games 的《Airport Insecurity》就是一个例子，它尖锐地批评了 9/11 事件后美国对航空旅行的过度限制。

Just as previous generations held sit-ins, rallies, and protests, this generation forms Facebook groups, starts blogs, and makes games (and sometimes does those other things, too). Games are an incredibly powerful means to get a point across and to spread that point via the Internet throughout the world. One example is Airport Insecurity by Persuasive Games, a biting commentary on the excessive restrictions on air travel in a post-9/11 United States.

另一种形式的社会评论游戏是政治游戏。大约每四年一次的选举期间，某个州的某个政党都会发布一款小游戏，旨在以某种形式展示本党的政策或揭露对手政策的谬误。

Another form of social-commentary games are political games. Around election time every four years or so, a political party in one state or another releases a small game designed to show its party’s policies in one form or another or show the fallacy of their opponent’s policies.

有时，社会评论游戏被归类为艺术游戏，因为它们的主要目的是政治和艺术表达。在发布《超级科伦拜恩大屠杀》时，角色扮演游戏设计师丹尼·莱多恩（Danny LeDonne）提出了政治和艺术方面的原因，并最终发布了一份艺术家声明，可在线获取。有关艺术游戏的更多信息，请参阅第 17 章“游戏即艺术”。

Sometimes, social-commentary games are classified as art games since their primary purpose is a political as well as an artistic statement. In releasing Super Columbine Massacre, RPG designer Danny LeDonne offered both political and artistic reasons for his, and ultimately released an artist’s statement, which is available online. For more information on art games, refer to Chapter 17, “Games as Art.”

广告游戏和反广告游戏

ADVERGAMES AND ANTI-ADVERGAMES

有些游戏的主要目的是为品牌做广告。汉堡王的游戏Big Bumpin和Sneak King就是最近备受瞩目的例子。许多预算较低的公司至少在其网站上有一个小型 Flash 游戏或一个面向电视剧粉丝的问答游戏。这些游戏被亲切地称为“广告游戏”。有关创建此类游戏（以及其他涉及许可或 IP 的游戏）的更多信息，请参阅第 9 章“什么是知识产权？”

Some games are created for the primary purpose of advertising a brand. The Burger King games like Big Bumpin and Sneak King are recent high-profile examples. Many companies with lower budgets have at least a small Flash game on their Web site or a trivia game for fans of, say, a television series. These games are affectionately called “advergames.” For more information on creating these kinds of games (and others that deal with licenses or IP), refer to Chapter 9, “What Is Intellectual Property?”

有些游戏是为了积极损害公司的声誉而创建的，因此被称为“反广告游戏”。其中一款游戏是Molleindustria 开发的《麦当劳游戏》 ，在 2006 年首次发布时引起了不小的轰动。这款游戏与麦当劳没有任何关联，它为玩家提供了诸如推平土著村庄以种植大豆或饲养牛来生产汉堡包等选择。这款游戏甚至还设有一个模拟会议室，其中“当权者”对 Molleindustria 眼中的公司状况进行了狡猾的评论。当然，麦当劳对这款游戏的发布并不太高兴，但作为一种社会评论形式，这家快餐公司未能阻止其出版和最终发行。

Other games are created with the purpose of actively damaging a corporation’s reputation, and have thus earned the term “anti-advergames.” One such game, The McDonald’s Game by Molleindustria, created quite a stir when it was first released in 2006. Not in any way affiliated with McDonald’s, the game gave players such choices as bulldozing native villages in order to grow soybeans or raising cattle for the chain’s hamburger production. The game even featured a simulated boardroom where the “powers that be” made sly commentary on the perceived state of the corporation in the eyes of Molleindustria. Naturally, McDonald’s was none too happy with the game’s release, but being a form of social commentary, the fast-food company was unsuccessful in stopping its publication and ultimate distribution.

教育游戏

EDUCATIONAL GAMES

与训练游戏类似，教育游戏通常针对学龄儿童。从数学冲击器或JumpStart系列等特定主题的游戏到更主流的《俄勒冈之路》和《卡门圣地亚哥在哪里？》，教育游戏利用游戏的自然教学能力，以促进主动学习的方式呈现材料。对于那些对这个主题感兴趣的人，Raph Koster 的书《游戏设计的乐趣理论》 对游戏为何是极好的学习工具进行了出色的分析。另一本书《电子游戏能教给我们什么关于学习和读写能力》，作者是 James Paul Gee，对游戏作为强大学习工具进行了迄今为止最好的分析之一。另请参阅本书第 18 章“游戏作为一种教学工具……真的吗？”，了解有关课堂游戏的更多信息。

Akin to training games, educational games usually target school-age children. From subject-specific games like Math Blaster or the JumpStart series to the more mainstream The Oregon Trail and Where in the World is Carmen Sandiego?, educational games use the game’s natural ability to teach in order to present material in a way that promotes active learning. For those interested in the subject, Raph Koster’s book A Theory of Fun for Game Design provides an excellent analysis on why games are excellent learning tools. Another book, What Video Games Have to Teach Us About Learning and Literacy by James Paul Gee, provides one of the best analyses of games as powerful learning tools yet written. Also refer to Chapter 18, “Games as a Teaching Tool...Seriously?” in this book for additional information on games in the classroom.

社会意识游戏

SOCIAL-AWARENESS GAMES

当《为达尔富尔而死》 发布时，没有人特别喜欢玩这个游戏。它的主要目标很可怕：你需要逃跑以避免受伤、被强奸或遭遇更糟的情况。这款游戏的开发是为了引起人们对达尔富尔人民困境的关注。尽管（或许是因为）让玩家感到不舒服，而不是仅仅试图制作一款有趣的游戏，《为达尔富尔而死》还是赢得了多个奖项。社会意识游戏特别擅长让玩家处于令人难以置信的不舒服的境地——即使他们只是考虑玩游戏。

When Dying for Darfur was released, no one particularly enjoyed playing the game. Its primary goal is horrible: you need to run to avoid getting hurt, raped, or worse. The game was created in order to draw attention to the plight of the people of Darfur. In spite of (or perhaps because of) making players uncomfortable instead of just trying to make a fun game, Dying for Darfur won several awards. Social-awareness games are particularly good at putting players in an incredibly uncomfortable situation—even if they merely contemplate playing the game.

目的是核心

THE PURPOSE IS THE CORE

每款游戏都有核心，即游戏的核心内容，无论是击退敌人、在各个平台之间跳跃还是在摇滚乐队中表演。严肃游戏也不例外。然而，它们的核心恰恰是它们的目的，即制作游戏的唯一原因。

Every game has a core—the one thing that the game is about, whether it’s blasting enemies away or bouncing from platform to platform or performing in a rock band. Serious games are no different. However, their core is precisely their purpose—the one reason that the game is being made.

之前提到过一款保护儿童免受网络侵害的游戏。由于游戏的目的明确，因此游戏中的每个功能都必须根据其实际帮助游戏实现该目的的有效性进行衡量。与传统游戏不同，实现该目的的方法通常与传统游戏略有不同。

Earlier, a game that protects children from online predators was mentioned. With its clear purpose, every feature in the game must be measured against how effectively it actually helps the game achieve that purpose. And unlike traditional games, often the means of getting to that purpose are a bit different than in traditional games.

专注力测试

THE FOCUS TEST

许多严肃游戏都获得了大量资金，而提供资金的人可能想看看游戏在多大程度上真正传授了它想要传授的知识。为此，需要建立焦点小组。建立焦点小组和监控游戏过程以及游戏结果的过程因项目而异。例如，本书的一位作者曾参与过一个项目，该项目的焦点测试由四个不同种族背景的独立小组组成，他们在游戏前、游戏后以及游戏一个月后再次测试对主题知识的测试。这些测试的结果对游戏设计背后的医生和政府机构非常重要。

Many serious games come with some serious funding, and those that provide the funds may want to see how well the game actually teaches what it was intended to teach. To do this, focus groups are set up. The process of setting up a focus group and monitoring the process of play, as well as the outcomes of play, is specific to each project. For instance, one of the authors of this book worked on a project whose focus test consisted of four separate groups of varying ethnic backgrounds whose knowledge of the subject matter was tested before the game, after playing the game, and yet again one month after playing the game. The results of these tests were important to the doctors and the government agency behind the game’s design.

为何要玩严肃游戏？

WHY SERIOUS GAMES?

当人们准备进入游戏行业时，他们眼中只有高多边形模型，而制作严肃游戏的想法很少进入他们的视野。为什么有人想制作严肃游戏？以下是一些原因：
