As people prepare to enter the game industry with high poly models in their eyes, the thought of making serious games seldom registers on their radar. Why would someone want to make serious games? Here are some reasons:

·      与 AAA 游戏行业相比，在竞争不那么激烈的领域找到工作

·      To get a job in a much less competitive field, as compared to the AAA game industry

·      教育

·      To educate

·      说服

·      To persuade

·      展示数字领域的个人信仰

·      To present a personal belief in the digital realm

·      为世界带来真正的改变

·      To make a real difference in the world

·      避免主流游戏产业的大消费主义

·      To avoid the big consumerism of the mainstream game industry

人们玩严肃游戏的原因有很多。例如，从事该领域的设计师经常谈论他们的产品被用来告诉孩子们为什么应该服用救命药是多么令人满足。

People come to serious games for many reasons. Designers working in the field often talk about how fulfilling it is that their product is being used to show kids why they should take life-saving medicine, for example.

挑战

CHALLENGES

在此挑战部分中，您需要创建能够启发、教育、定位和煽动的游戏。如果在小组环境中完成，挑战负责人可能需要在必要时设置可接受内容的限制。

In this challenge section, you are tasked with creating games that inspire, educate, target, and inflame. If done in a group setting, the challenge leader may want to set limits of acceptable content, if necessary.

挑战 1——卡特里娜飓风

CHALLENGE 1—KATRINA

本世纪初，卡特里娜飓风将新奥尔良夷为平地，全世界都在关注并等待救援的到来。截至本书出版时，许多人仍在关注并等待。对于这个挑战，你的目标是制作一款受卡特里娜飓风启发的游戏。你对这个游戏的处理方式——无论是飓风模拟还是“艺术游戏”——完全由你决定。你会进行教育、提供社会评论，还是做其他完全不同的事情？

When Hurricane Katrina blew New Orleans to smithereens in the early part of this century, the world watched and waited for help to arrive. As of the printing of this book, many are still watching and still waiting. For this challenge, your goal is to create a game inspired by Katrina. Your treatment of this—whether a simulation of a hurricane or an “art game”—is entirely up to you. Will you educate, provide social commentary, or do something else entirely?

所需组件

Components Required

·      互联网用于研究

·      Internet for research

可交付成果

Deliverable

·      基于 Katrina 或

·      Concept doc for a digital game based on Katrina or

·      基于卡特里娜飓风的非数字游戏

·      Non-digital game based on Katrina

建议流程

Suggested Process

1.    研究事件。 看看发生了什么。阅读新闻报道和目击者报告。事件的哪些方面涉及可以在游戏中建模的交互系统？事件的哪些方面真正触动了你或让你心烦意乱？即使是像一个人站在水中怒不可遏这样简单的事情，在合适的设计师手中也可以制作成游戏。

1.    Research the event. Look at what happened. Read news stories and eyewitness reports. What aspects of the situation involved interactive systems that could be modeled in a game? What aspects of the event really touched you or upset you? Even something as simple as a person standing in the water angry as hell could be made into a game in the right designer’s hands.

2.    找到核心。 选择这场灾难的一个方面作为游戏的基础。定义玩家做出的关键决策并创建驱动这些决策的机制。

2.    Find the core. Choose one aspect of this disaster to form the basis for your game. Define the key decisions players make and create the mechanics that drive those decisions.

3.    创建可交付成果。

3.    Create deliverable.

变体

Variant

考虑任何让你感动的悲剧，并考虑如何制作一款严肃的游戏。游戏可以涵盖任何内容，所以不要担心用游戏来掩盖某件事会使其变得微不足道。只有游戏中的处理方式才能做到这一点。然而，作为设计师，由你来决定如何处理和描绘这种处理方式。

Take any tragedy that personally moved you and consider how you would make a serious game about it. Games can be made to cover any material, so don’t fear that using a game to cover something trivializes it. Only the treatment within the game can do that. However, as its designer, it is up to you to determine how that treatment is handled and portrayed.

挑战 2——缩略词盛行

CHALLENGE 2—FESTIVAL OF ACRONYMS

“从 GDC 回来后，我和 IGDA 的 Jason 聊天。他说他们正在建立一些新的 SIG。最终，我想参与 QoL 或 WiG。我可能会在 MIGS 或 AGDC 再次见到他，到时候我会向他提这件事。”

“Coming back from GDC, I was talking with Jason from the IGDA. He said they were setting up some new SIGs. Eventually, I’d like to get involved with QoL or WiG. I’ll probably see him again at MIGS or AGDC, and I’ll mention it to him then.”

游戏行业是一个缩略词的盛会，当人们希望从业余爱好者转型为行业开发者时，他们很快就会意识到，有很多缩略词是他们不认识的。

The game industry is a festival of acronyms, and when people are hoping to make that transition from wanna-be to industry dev, they quickly become aware that there are a whole lot of acronyms that they do not know.

对于这个挑战，你的目标是制作一款游戏，让你的同伴了解这些行业缩写。当然，你的方法不需要明显具有教育意义。事实上，尽量不要。虽然问答游戏可能是测试知识的最明显途径，但人们还有其他学习方法。

For this challenge, your goal is to make a game that teaches your fellow players about these industry acronyms. Of course, you don’t need to be obviously educational in your approach. In fact, try not to be. While a trivia game might be the most obvious route to test knowledge, there are other ways for people to learn.

所需组件

Components Required

·      互联网用于研究

·      Internet for research

·      棋盘游戏或纸牌游戏的材料

·      Materials for a board game or card game

可交付成果

Deliverable

·      一款纸牌游戏或棋盘游戏，教授至少 20 个游戏行业缩略语

·      A card game or a board game that teaches a minimum of 20 game industry acronyms

·      制定规则

·      A rule set

建议流程

Suggested Process

1.    研究行业缩写词。找到至少 20 个缩写词。您可能会在阅读 gamasutra.com 或 gamecareerguide.com 并查找您找到的任何缩写词时遇到它们，或者您可以尝试通过 Wikipedia.org 搜索。您也可以查看此列表：IGDA、SIG、EMA、ESA、TRC、TCR、AP、EP、QA、OOD、QOL、ZBC、ECA、ESRB、SIGGRAPH、ROI、TDD、DD、AAA 和 PMP。

1.    Research industry acronyms. Find at least 20 acronyms. You might encounter them by reading gamasutra.com or gamecareerguide.com and looking up any acronyms you find, or you could try searching through Wikipedia.org. You can also take this list: IGDA, SIG, EMA, ESA, TRC, TCR, AP, EP, QA, OOD, QOL, ZBC, ECA, ESRB, SIGGRAPH, ROI, TDD, DD, AAA, and PMP.

2.    集思广益，想出游戏创意。这款游戏的目标是让玩家学习信息，这与其他需要死记硬背的教育游戏没有什么不同。你可以从这里开始，想出一些有助于学习的机制。想想你玩过的哪些游戏成功做到了这一点。这样的游戏可能不多。另一种方法是考虑这里的特定信息类型：首字母缩略词。你能想到任何特定于字母组而不是通用信息的机制吗？

2.    Brainstorm game ideas. The goal of this game is to have players learn information, which makes it no different from any other educational game that requires rote memorization. You could simply start there, coming up with mechanics that facilitate learning. Think of games you’ve played that have done this successfully. There are probably not many of them. Another approach is to consider the specific kinds of information here: acronyms. Can you think of any mechanics that are specific to groups of letters, as opposed to generic information?

3.    构建和迭代。 创建游戏原型，并与一些朋友一起玩（最好是那些不知道所有缩写的朋友）。游戏的哪些方面令人愉快，哪些部分无聊或令人沮丧？游戏是否实现了学习目标？回头根据游戏测试修改游戏。尽可能多地继续这样做。

3.    Build and iterate. Create a prototype of your game and play it with some friends (preferably friends who don’t know all of the acronyms). What aspects of the game are enjoyable and what parts are boring or frustrating? Does the game accomplish its learning goals? Go back and revise the game based on your playtesting. Continue to do this as many times as is practical.

4.    创建可交付成果。

4.    Create deliverable.

挑战 3——励志游戏

CHALLENGE 3—INSPIRATIONAL GAME

对于这个挑战，你的目标听起来相当简单：通过一款多人非数字游戏激励他人。然而，实现这一目标并不像看起来那么容易。为了激励人们，他们往往必须感受到他们所看到或正在经历的事情的影响，而且，还要感受到他们内心所激起的一切实际上都可以实现。例如，一幅画可能会以其美丽激励某人。那么他们会受到什么启发呢？这种灵感会流向何方？

For this challenge, your goal is rather simple sounding: inspire someone through a multiplayer non-digital game. Pulling that off, however, isn’t as easy as it seems. In order for people to be inspired, they often have to feel affected by what they see or are experiencing and, furthermore, feel that whatever has been stirred in them can actually be achieved. For instance, a painting might inspire someone with its beauty. What would they then be inspired to do? Where will that inspiration go?

所需组件

Components Required

·      互联网（供参考）

·      Internet (for reference)

可交付成果

Deliverable

·      一款启发灵感的非数字游戏

·      A non-digital game that inspires

·      制定规则

·      A rule set

·      总结您所希望获得的灵感，并简要讨论您认为有助于这一过程的机制。

·      A summary of your hoped-for inspiration, as well as a brief discussion on the mechanics you feel would assist in this process.

建议流程

Suggested Process

1.    探索“灵感”。你可以通过游戏激发灵感的方式有很多。想想玩家在游戏中可以做的事情，这些事情会让他们认为自己可以在现实世界中做同样的事情。事实上，一个起点可能是反过来思考这个挑战。你想激励别人做什么事？帮助无家可归的人？做志愿者？你会如何通过游戏来实现这一点？你也可以从列出你觉得鼓舞人心的事情开始。

1.    Explore “inspiration.” There are many ways that you can inspire through games. Think of things players can do in a game that would lead them to think they can do things in the real world. One starting place, in fact, might be to think of this challenge in reverse. What things would you like to inspire someone to do? Help the homeless? Volunteer? How would you bring this about through play? You could also start by making a list of things you find inspiring.

2.    确定一个灵感。 选择一个灵感，并列出可以创造这个灵感的方法以及这个灵感可以提供的一些奖励。

2.    Settle on an inspiration. Choose an inspiration and make a list of ways that one could create this inspiration and some rewards the inspiration could provide.

3.    确定媒介。 在你选择的特定方式中，激发灵感的最佳方式是什么？纸牌游戏、棋盘游戏还是数字游戏？或者根本不是游戏——也许小册子或网站会更有效（在这种情况下，选择一种新的灵感）。

3.    Determine a medium. What is the best way to inspire in the particular way that you chose? A card game, board game, or digital game? Or maybe not a game at all—perhaps a pamphlet or Web site would be more effective (in which case, choose a new inspiration).

4.    创建可交付成果。

4.    Create deliverable.

挑战 4——强有力的声明

CHALLENGE 4—A STRONG STATEMENT

有一样东西让你感到充满激情，无论它是赞成还是反对——政治家、事业、支持其他事业的人，甚至是另一个人。或者它可能是简单而温馨的东西，比如一款关于你对祖母的爱的游戏。无论它是什么，这款游戏都应该以成熟、现实、非数字化的设计反映你对该主题的感受。请记住，在这种设计中，你也在试图说服别人和你有同样的感受。很容易只创建一个向你不太喜欢的东西扔炸弹的游戏。然而，这样做虽然表达了观点，但你可能无法说服别人。考虑一下是什么让你有这样的感觉，看看你是否能给你的玩家灌输同样的感觉。

There is something you feel passionate about, whether it’s for or against—a politician, a cause, those in support of another cause, or even another person. Or maybe it’s something as simple and heartwarming as a game about your love for your grandmother. Whatever it is, this game should reflect your feelings about that topic in a mature, realized, non-digital design. Remember that in this design, you are also trying to persuade others to feel as you do. It is easy to merely create a game that flings bombs at something you don’t particularly like. However, in doing so, you make a statement, but you likely fail to persuade. Consider what makes you feel the way you do, and see if you can instill that same feeling in your players.

所需组件

Components Required

·      原型材料

·      Materials for prototype

可交付成果

Deliverable

·      可玩的棋盘游戏或纸牌游戏原型

·      Playable board or card-game prototype

·      制定书面规则

·      Set of written rules

·      简短的创作者声明，说明您的目标是什么以及为什么做出这样的设计选择。

·      Brief creator statement declaring what your goal was and why you made the design choices you did.

建议流程

Suggested Process

1.    选择一个话题。大多数人对某事都有强烈的意见。你呢？

1.    Choose a topic to cover. Most people have strong opinions about something. What about you?

2.    研究该主题。根据你的主题，你可能需要找到一些事实来支持你的工作。例如，如果你的游戏支持干细胞研究，你可能需要知道这种研究花了多少钱，到目前为止的结果是什么，或者哪些具体的立法是相关的。

2.    Research that topic. Depending on your topic, you may need to find some facts to support your work. For example, if your game is in support of stem-cell research, you might need to know how much money is spent on this kind of research, what the results have been so far, or what specific pieces of legislation are relevant.

3.    创建可交付成果。

3.    Create deliverable.

变体

Variant

作为替代和高级选项，考虑在游戏开始时让玩家不知道您对该主题的感受。看看您是否可以仅通过游戏来说服玩家，而不是通过游戏叙述、名称或其他方面的明显引用。

As an alternative and advanced option, consider making your feelings on the topic unknown at the time the game begins. See if you can persuade your players through play only and not through an obvious reference in the game narrative, name, or otherwise.

铁杆设计师挑战 5—真的吗？

IRON DESIGNER CHALLENGE 5—SERIOUSLY?

对于这一挑战，你至少需要另一名设计师，但最好可以分成两个或多个小组，每个小组有三到五名成员。

For this challenge, you will need at least one other designer, but preferably you can work in two or more groups with three to five members each.

每个小组需要列出六个可能适合制作严肃游戏的主题。主题可以很离奇，只要它们合理即可。如果你认为有人会给你资金来制作游戏，那么它可能就是合理的（但业内人士知道，这意味着什么都不合理）。

Each group needs to make a list of six potential topics about which a serious game could potentially be made. The topics can be wild, so long as they are plausible. If you think someone would give you funding to make it, it just might be plausible (but those in the business know that this means nothing may be plausible).

列表制作完成后，每个团队应掷骰子来确定从对方团队的列表中选择哪个主题。然后，团队将使用该主题为所选主题设计一个方案。

Once the list is made, each team should roll a d6 to determine which topic they get from an opposing team’s list. Using that topic, the team will then be tasked with coming up with a design for the selected topic.

所需组件

Components Required

·      互联网用于研究

·      Internet for research

可交付成果

Deliverable

·      设计概念文档或

·      Concept doc for design or

·      非数字化原型

·      Non-digital prototype

建议流程

Suggested Process

1.    研究。如果你不熟悉你的主题，请学习基础知识。

1.    Research. If you’re unfamiliar with your topic, learn the basics.

2.    集思广益。玩家代表谁或什么？游戏的目标是什么？当你想到这个主题时，会有什么机制立即浮现在你的脑海中吗？

2.    Brainstorm. Who or what would the players represent? What is the object of the game? Are there any mechanics that immediately spring to mind when you think of the topic?

3.    创建可交付成果。

3.    Create deliverable.

变体

Variant

不要创建概念文档，而是创建严肃游戏的非数字原型。这需要您手头有一些原型组件。

Instead of creating a concept doc, create a non-digital prototype of the serious game. This requires you to have some components for the prototype on hand.

非数字短片

NON-DIGITAL SHORTS

非数字游戏在严肃游戏领域的优势在于，它们可以在没有电脑或游戏机的地方广泛传播。这使得它们具有极强的通用性。

The benefit of non-digital games in the serious games arena is that they can be widely distributed where there are no computers or consoles handy. This makes them exceptionally versatile.

1.    设计一个游戏，训练人们如何在徒步旅行或露营时保持安全。

1.    Design a game that trains people on how to stay safe while hiking or camping.

2.    设计一款帮助人们成为更好的驾驶员的游戏。

2.    Design a game that helps people become better drivers.

3.    假设你雇佣一个人每周打扫一次你的房子或办公室。创建一个棋盘游戏来训练这个人完成任务。

3.    Imagine you are hiring someone to clean your house or office once a week. Create a board game that would train this person to complete the task.

4.    设计一个游戏，帮助糖尿病儿童了解和使用血糖测试设备。

4.    Design a game that helps diabetic children understand and use their blood sugar–testing device.

5.    设计一款适合一年级课堂玩的锻炼游戏。

5.    Design a game about exercise playable in first-grade classrooms.

6.    设计一个广告游戏来宣传您最喜欢的杂货店。

6.    Design an advertising game to advocate your favorite grocery store.

7.    与上一条不同的是，为您不喜欢的商店或公司设计一款反广告游戏。

7.    Alternatively to the previous bullet, design an anti-advergame for a store or company you dislike.

8.    设计一款评论禁毒战争的游戏。您可以选择表达赞成或反对的观点，但您的游戏必须传达清晰、可识别的信息。

8.    Design a game that comments on the war against drugs. You may choose to express either a favorable or an unfavorable perspective, but your game must have a clear, identifiable message.

9.    选择世界政治中的一个主题或问题，并设计一款游戏，让玩家根据该问题陷入不舒服的境地。

9.    Choose a topic or an issue in world politics and design a game that forces players into an uncomfortable situation based on that issue.

10. 选择任何仅通过意识就能解决的社会问题，而不是需要采取行动。创建一个能提高玩家对这个问题认识的游戏。

10. Choose any social issue that could be solved solely through awareness, rather than requiring action. Create a game that raises awareness of the issue in the players.



 

 

20：休闲游戏

20: Casual Games

 

 

这里十五分钟，那里十分钟。全世界的人都在玩休闲游戏。从Solitaire 到 Diner Dash ® 再到Bejeweled ® 再到Zuma™，休闲游戏是一个蓬勃发展的市场，一般来说，它们在完全不玩其他游戏的人群中非常受欢迎：30 岁以上的女性群体。这也是一个利润丰厚且不断增长的市场。

Fifteen minutes here. Ten minutes there. All over the world, people are playing casual games. From Solitaire to Diner Dash® to Bejeweled® to Zuma™, casual games are a booming market, and generally speaking, they are amazingly popular with people who ignore other games entirely: the 30+ female crowd. It’s a lucrative and growing market, too.

什么是休闲游戏？这个问题很难回答。IGDA 的休闲游戏 SIG 将休闲游戏定义为“游戏控制通常不太复杂，但游戏玩法或通关所需投入的总体复杂性较高的游戏”[CAS01]。休闲游戏协会将休闲游戏定义为“面向大众和家庭开发”且“有趣且易于学习和玩耍”的游戏 [CAS02]。

What is a casual game? It’s not an easy question to answer. The IGDA’s Casual Games SIG defines casual games as “games that generally involve less complicated game controls and overall complexity in terms of gameplay or investment required to get through the game” [CAS01]. The Casual Game Association defines casual games as those “developed for the general public and families” and which are “fun and easy to learn and play” [CAS02].

似乎休闲游戏的每条规则或描述都有例外。

It seems that there is an exception to every rule or description of what casual games are or should be.

休闲游戏的节奏往往比较慢，不像硬核动作游戏那样刺激，但Diner Dash甚至Tetris ® 最终都会让玩家感到压力过大，任务太多，速度太快。休闲游戏的规则往往比较简单，但Virtual Villagers ® 则相当复杂。休闲游戏不需要投入大量时间，但Yohoho Puzzle Pirates! ™和 Puzzle Quest无疑会激励玩家花上几个小时来提升自己的角色。

Casual games tend to be slower-paced and not as frantic as the more hardcore action games, but Diner Dash and even Tetris® eventually end by overwhelming and overloading the player with too many tasks that happen too quickly. Casual games tend to have simple rules, but Virtual Villagers® is quite complicated. Casual games don’t require a large time commitment, but Yohoho Puzzle Pirates! ™and Puzzle Quest certainly give players incentive to play for many hours to advance their characters.

休闲游戏往往难度较低且容易上手，但《Eets》 和《Professor Fizzwizzle》中的一些谜题足以让经验丰富的玩家沮丧不已。

Casual games tend to have a low difficulty level and be forgiving, but some of the puzzles in Eets and Professor Fizzwizzle are enough to make experienced gamers pull their hair out in frustration.

这些游戏不仅被归类为休闲游戏，而且都是成功的游戏。

All of these games are not only classified as casual games, but successful ones.

了解休闲游戏最简单的方法是什么？玩一、二、三或四款游戏，你就会明白。事实上，如果你是玩着Pac Man ®、Centipede等游戏长大的街机一代，那么你已经很清楚休闲游戏是什么样的了。

What’s the easiest way to understand what a casual game is? Play one, two, three, or four of them, and you’ll understand. In fact, if you were a part of the arcade generation that was raised on Pac Man®, Centipede, and the like, you already have a pretty good idea what casual games are like.

为什么休闲？

WHY CASUAL?

休闲游戏适合许多人的生活方式。曾经的铁杆玩家会花上几个小时来完善他们的 RPG 派对，而现在他们会在家庭和工作职责之余偶尔玩一会。与此同时，其他人则通过休闲游戏发现了游戏，他们先是玩 PC 上的 Solitaire，后来又玩了 Scrabulous 等游戏。

Casual games fit the lifestyles of many individuals. Where once hardcore gamers devoted hours at a clip to develop the nuances of their RPG parties, they now play a little here and there, amid family and job responsibilities. Meanwhile, others have discovered games through casual gaming, first with Solitaire on the PC and later with games like Scrabulous.

这些游戏有许多共同的特点。

These games share numerous features.

易于学习

EASY TO LEARN

大多数休闲游戏的说明非常有限，并且利用了假定的知识，这些知识与最初运行计算机所需的知识量大致相同。拖放、点击。像Diner Dash这样的游戏只需这些操作即可玩，大多数休闲游戏也是如此。

Most casual games have very limited instructions and take advantage of assumed knowledge, about the same amount of knowledge one would need to run a computer in the first place. Drag, drop, click. Games like Diner Dash can be played with only these actions, as can the great majority of casual games.

休闲游戏以两三句游戏描述开始，然后是实际游戏本身。游戏机制几乎总是一目了然，只需看一眼游戏即可。事实上，大多数休闲游戏都提供了出色的反馈，可在玩家玩游戏时提供指导。

Casual games begin with a two- or three-sentence description of play followed by actual play itself. The mechanics of play are almost always obvious just by looking at the game. In fact, most casual games offer excellent feedback that guides the player as she plays.

与 FPS 等游戏相比，对于普通人来说，进入 FPS 游戏环节可能会让人不知所措。你应该使用什么武器？你如何射击？你如何更换武器？你甚至如何移动？其中许多都是游戏玩家认为理所当然的事情。

Contrast this with something like an FPS. For the average person, stepping into a play session in an FPS can be overwhelming. What weapon should you use? How do you fire? How do you change weapons? How do you even move? Many of these are things that gamers take for granted.

降低复杂性

REDUCED COMPLEXITY

许多此类游戏的规则都相当简单。考虑一下前面提到的Diner Dash中的游戏玩法。模式如下：

The rule sets in many of these games are rather simple. Consider the gameplay in the previously mentioned Diner Dash. The pattern goes like this:

·      引导顾客就座。

·      Seat the customer.

·      接受她的订单。

·      Take her order.

·      在柜台下订单。

·      Place her order at the counter.

·      从柜台领取餐食。

·      Get the meal from the counter.

·      上菜。

·      Serve the meal.

·      领取支票。

·      Pick up the check.

·      清理桌子。

·      Clear the table.

按照休闲游戏的标准，这是一长串的任务。然而，这是我们作为游戏世界的一部分就已经知道的模式。随着餐桌坐满、顾客不断光临，这种已知模式一次又一次地重复，这种游戏模式可以吸引玩家。玩家甚至可以通过良好的表现获得某些升级，让餐厅的运营更加顺利。

By casual game standards, it’s a long line of tasks. However, it’s a pattern we already know from just being a part of the world. This known pattern repeats itself again and again and again as tables fill and customers continue to come, and this play pattern holds players. The player can even earn certain upgrades through good performance, allowing the restaurant to move more smoothly.

像《宝石迷阵》这样的游戏要求玩家将物品分成三组。就是这样。游戏会在你的路上设置一些障碍，玩家需要自己绕过它们。分组简单，界面简单，让玩家享受轻松的游戏体验，不会感到压力。

Games like Bejeweled ask players to move things into sets of three. That’s it. The game throws some roadblocks in your way, and it’s up to the player to navigate around them. The simplicity of the groupings and the easy interface allow for a relaxed play experience that doesn’t stress the player.

相比之下，比较一下享受典型的 RTS 或 RPG 游戏所必须完成的任务级别，列表相对简单。这正是休闲游戏玩家想要的 — 休息，而不是承诺。

By contrast, compare the level of tasks one must complete to enjoy a typical RTS or RPG, and the list is simple by comparison. That’s just what casual game players want—a break, not a commitment.

偶然冲突

CASUAL CONFLICTS

因为休闲游戏就是休闲游戏，所以游戏中的冲突也必须如此。生死攸关、肾上腺素激增、玩家被打得落花流水的场景并不特别适合休闲玩家，在 MMO 游戏中，40 名玩家进行长达四小时的突袭对抗 Boss 也同样不适合。

Because casual games are meant to be, well, casual, the conflicts present in the game must follow suit. A life-or-death, adrenaline fueled situation in which the player gets blown away isn’t particularly conducive to the casual mindset, nor is a four-hour 40-player raid versus a boss in an MMO.

一般来说，休闲游戏中的冲突有以下一种或多种形式：

Generally, the conflicts in casual games take one or more of these forms:

·      玩家对战游戏：游戏中的模式通过速度或适度的转变或阻止模式的执行逐渐变得更加困难，直到玩家打败游戏（例如，纸牌）或被击倒（例如，俄罗斯方块）。

·      Player vs. game: The pattern in the game gets progressively more difficult, either through speed or moderate shifts or blocks to the pattern’s execution, until the player either beats the game (for example, Solitaire) or is overwhelmed (for example, Tetris).

·      玩家与分数：玩家试图打破自己之前的分数，或者另一个玩家的分数。

·      Player vs. score: The player is trying to beat her last score, or the score of another player.

·      玩家与时间：玩家试图在规定时间内完成一项任务。

·      Player vs. time: The player is trying to do a task within a set period of time.

游戏时间短

SHORT PLAY TIME

休闲游戏的游戏时间通常较短，以分钟而不是小时来计算。不过，有些游戏采用了无尽模式或禅定模式，让玩家可以随心所欲地玩下去。

Casual games generally have a short play time that is measured in minutes vs. hours. Some games, however, have incorporated endless or Zen modes that let players play as long as they would like.

缺乏承诺

LACK OF COMMITMENT

许多休闲游戏的一大优点是它们愿意等待玩家（如果是多人游戏，则是等待对手）。如果玩家起身、打电话、开门，然后回到游戏中，一切都不会改变，也不会丢失任何东西。事实上，几天就可以过去。这种来去自如的能力，这种无需承诺的能力，是吸引人们玩这些游戏的关键特征之一。

One of the beauties of many casual games is that they’re willing to wait for players (or the opponent if it’s a multiplayer game). If the player gets up, talks on the phone, answers the door, and comes back to the game, nothing’s changed and nothing’s lost. Days can pass, in fact. This ability to come and go, this lack of commitment, is one of the key features that draws people to these games.

适合家庭

FAMILY FRIENDLY

一款游戏若要被视为休闲游戏，其默认设置是适合全家一起玩且不包含令人反感的内容。如果包含令人反感的内容，那么该游戏将被归类到其他书籍中介绍的另一类游戏。

For a game to be considered a casual game, it is, by default, family friendly and contains no objectionable content. If it did, the game would instead be classed in another category of games covered elsewhere in other books.

挑战

CHALLENGES

在完成以下挑战之前，建议你先玩几款休闲游戏，玩到你宁愿为了娱乐而不是为了学习的程度。一开始，尤其是如果你是一名铁杆玩家，这些游戏对你来说可能看起来微不足道。但过了一段时间，你会发现它们的简单性也是它们的一大优势。

Before doing the challenges below, it’s recommended that you play a few casual games to the point where you’d rather be playing them for fun instead of education. At first, and particularly if you are a hardcore gamer, the games may seem trivial to you. After a while, though, you’ll discover that their simplicity is also their great strength.

您成功完成的挑战的数字版本也可以成为出色的个人项目。

Digital versions of the challenges you succeed in also make excellent one-person projects.

挑战 1 — 不匹配 3

CHALLENGE 1—MISMATCH 3

许多休闲游戏要求玩家将三个相似的物体以相互接触的方式聚集在一起，从而将它们配对。你的老板非常清楚这一趋势，并希望你能想出一些类似但又不同的游戏。不过，他不希望你只是用宝石以外的东西重新包装《宝石迷阵》之类的游戏。他希望你以某种方式创新“三消”游戏风格，无论是通过关卡设计、关卡块还是其他完全不同的东西。

Many casual games require players to match three similar objects by gathering them in such a way that they touch one another. Your employer is more than aware of this trend and wants you to come up with something similar... but different. He doesn’t want you to just re-skin a game like Bejeweled with something other than jewels, though. He wants you to innovate the “Match 3” game style in some way, whether through level design, level blocks, or something else entirely.

所需组件

Components Required

·      互联网连接（用于研究）

·      Internet connection (for research)

·      其他三消游戏，例如《宝石迷阵》中可以添加哪些新机制

·      Other match-3 games, as an example of how several new mechanics can be added to Bejeweled

可交付成果

Deliverable

·      一款数字游戏的卡牌游戏原型

·      Card game prototype of a digital game

建议流程

Suggested Process

1.    研究。如果你不熟悉 Match 3 游戏，可以玩几款（至少玩过 Bejeweled、Zuma和Chuzzle， 这样你就能了解这类游戏的惯例）。

1.    Research. If you are unfamiliar with Match 3 games, play several of them (at least Bejeweled, Zuma, and Chuzzle to give you an idea of the genre conventions).

2.    集思广益。想想典型的 Match 3 游戏的玩法。它是否暗示了尚未利用的任何机制？考虑一下您熟悉的其他非Match 3 游戏的休闲游戏。您能想到任何可以适应不同类型游戏的有趣机制吗？

2.    Brainstorm. Think of the gameplay in a typical Match 3 game. Does it suggest any mechanics that haven’t been exploited yet? Consider other casual games you are familiar with that are not Match 3 games. Can you think of any interesting mechanics that could be adapted to a different genre?

3.    创建可交付成果。

3.    Create deliverable.

4.    创建数字原型（可选）。三消游戏受到刚开始进入休闲领域的开发者的欢迎，主要是因为它们比其他类型的游戏更容易编程。如果你有足够的编程技能来制作俄罗斯方块克隆版，你应该能够在相当短的时间内实现你的游戏创意。

4.    Create digital prototype (optional). Match three games are popular with developers who are just beginning to enter the casual space, mainly because they are easier to program than other types of games. If you have enough programming skills to make a Tetris clone, you should be able to implement your game idea in a fairly short period of time.

挑战 2 — 咔哒、咔哒、咔哒、咔哒……

CHALLENGE 2—CLICK, CLICK, CLICK, CLICK...

休闲游戏的“点击管理”风格，例如Diner Dash，涉及使用玩家已知的模式（在本例中，即就座和等待顾客的模式）。该模式会重复出现，因此玩家必须同时跟踪该模式的多个版本。随着关卡的推进，模式会变得更快或更复杂，或两者兼而有之。

The “click management” style of casual game, exemplified by Diner Dash, involves using a pattern that players already know (in this case, the pattern of seating and waiting on customers). The pattern is repeated, so that the player must keep track of several versions of it going at once. As levels progress, the pattern becomes faster, or more complex, or both.

你的老板意识到许多休闲游戏都使用我们已经知道的模式，所以要求你找出一种这样的模式，而不是服务员模式。根据该模式设计一款游戏，然后创作几幅概念艺术作品或一个非数字原型来传达基本设计。

Recognizing that many casual games use patterns we already know, your boss has asked you to identify one such pattern, other than waiting tables. Design a game based on that pattern, and then create a few pieces of concept art or a non-digital prototype that will convey the basic design.

所需组件

Components Required

·      互联网连接（用于研究）

·      Internet connection (for research)

·       Diner Dash 的免费版本用于研究模式如何变得越来越快并不断叠加

·      The free version of Diner Dash for research on how patterns can get faster and faster and layer upon themselves

·      用于概念图或原型组件的纸张

·      Paper for concept drawings or components for prototype

可交付成果

Deliverable

·      三张独立的潜在游戏界面概念图或

·      Three separate concept drawings of potential game interface or

·      非数字化原型

·      Non-digital prototype

·      图案中的步骤列表，可以标注在概念图上，也可以标注在单独的纸上

·      List of steps in the pattern, either noted on the concept art itself or on a separate sheet of paper

建议流程

Suggested Process

1.    选择一种模式。 回想一下Diner Dash。游戏中的主角 Flo 正在一遍又一遍地重复接受订单、服务顾客和清理桌子的模式。想想我们一遍又一遍重复的另一个模式。发挥你的想象力，考虑一下人们的爱好、奇怪的事情以及有多个步骤的事情。突出那些吸引你的。

1.    Choose a pattern. Think back to Diner Dash. Flo, the star of the game, is repeating the pattern of taking orders, serving customers, and clearing tables again and again and again. Think of another pattern that we repeat over and over and over. Stretch your imagination by considering hobbies, weird things people do, and things with multiple steps to them. Highlight those that appeal to you.

2.    详细描述模式。 对于你的模式，写下关闭循环所需的所有步骤。角色和玩家究竟需要做什么才能完成模式的一个循环？模式可以在“一轮”中重复吗？模式不应该让玩家感到陌生。记住，休闲游戏之所以休闲是有原因的。模式应该是玩家熟悉的。

2.    Detail the pattern. For your pattern, write all the steps required to close the loop. What exactly does the character and player have to do to complete one loop of the pattern? Can the pattern be repeated in a “round?” The pattern should not be alien to the players. Remember, casual games are casual for a reason. The pattern should be familiar.

3.    考虑反馈。 点击管理实际上是游戏的核心机制。玩家从 A 点移动到 B 点再移动到 C 点（以及必要时移动到中间的点）的能力是成功的关键。你将如何向玩家发出信号，告知他们需要做什么？你将如何向玩家发出信号，告知他们某个“点”已准备好进行交互？你将如何为玩家的进度评分？你如何输掉游戏？

3.    Consider the feedback. Click-management is effectively your core mechanic of the game. The player’s ability to move from point A to point B to point C (as well as points in between, if necessary) is the key to success. How will you signal what the player needs to do? How will you signal when a “point” is ready for interaction? How will you score the player’s progress? How do you lose?

4.    创建可交付成果。

4.    Create deliverable.

挑战 3 — 显而易见

CHALLENGE 3—IT’S OBVIOUS

 

 

为了充分利用电脑上休闲游戏的成功，您已签约创建一款真正像休闲游戏一样容易玩的卡牌、骰子、棋盘或方块游戏。您的客户希望通过将休闲游戏从电脑中移除，人们会更愿意与家人一起玩。决定您的设计是否成功的一个关键因素是：您的玩家应该能够坐下来，仅从游戏的外观和他们现有的知识来理解游戏。如果您愿意，您可以自由使用现有的 IP。

In an effort to capitalize on the success of casual games on computers, you have been contracted to create a card, dice, board or tile-based game that is truly as easy to play as a casual game. Your client hopes that by bringing a casual game away from the computer, people will be more inclined to play it with their families. A key factor in determining the success of your design is this: your players should be able to sit down and understand the game simply from the way it looks and the existing knowledge they have. You are free to use an existing IP if you like.

所需组件

Components Required

·      海报板和其他必要的组件，以创建棋盘游戏

·      Poster board and other components as necessary to create a board game

可交付成果

Deliverable

·      可玩的游戏原型

·      Playable game prototype

建议流程

Suggested Process

1.    找到核心机制。许多休闲游戏都利用了界面标准，例如点击、拖放。您的玩家已经知道哪些棋盘游戏机制？现实世界中已经存在哪些机制，您可以将其转化为棋盘游戏，使其功能显而易见？

1.    Find your core mechanics. Many casual games take advantage of interface standards, like clicking, dragging, and dropping. What are some board game mechanics that your players will already know? What mechanics already exist in the real world, that you can translate to board games in a way that make their function obvious?

2.    集思广益。根据你确定的一些机制来构建游戏。每当你添加新规则时，都要问问自己，这条规则是否显而易见，无需写下来或告诉玩家。如果不是，你必须找到一种方法来做到这一点，或者放弃这条规则，再试一次。

2.    Brainstorm. Build a game from some set of mechanics you identified. Whenever you add a new rule, ask yourself whether the rule is obvious without having to be written down or told to players. In cases where it’s not, you must find a way to make it so, or abandon the rule and try again.

3.    创建可交付成果。 对于这个挑战，你只需要创建游戏组件，而不是一套书面规则。请记住，你必须有一个规则非常明显的游戏，你不需要书面 规则！

3.    Create deliverable. For this challenge, you only need to create the game components and not a set of written rules. Remember, you must have a game where the rules are so obvious that you don’t need written rules!

挑战四——打破规则

CHALLENGE 4—BREAKING THE RULES

在本章中，我们探讨了休闲游戏的以下共同特质：

In this chapter, we’ve explored the following shared qualities of casual games:

·      易于学习

·      Easy to learn

·      复杂度低

·      Low complexity

·      游戏时间较短

·      Short play time

·      间接冲突

·      Indirect conflict

·      承诺低

·      Low commitment

·      适合家庭  

·      Family friendly  

选择其中一个特质并将其否定（例如，难以学习或直接冲突），同时保持其他特质不变。设计一款符合所有这些特质（包括否定特质）的游戏，但仍然是一款休闲游戏。

Choose one of these qualities and negate it (for example, hard to learn or direct conflict), while keeping the rest intact. Design a game that fits all of these qualities (including the negated one), but that is still a casual game.

所需组件

Components Required

·      没有任何

·      None

可交付成果

Deliverable

·      列出基本机制的三页设计文档。为清晰起见，请至少包含一个屏幕模型。

·      Three-page design document that lists the basic mechanics. Include at least one screen mock-up for clarity.

建议流程

Suggested Process

1.    研究你的规则。考虑一下你选择故意忽略的休闲游戏方面。为什么它是大多数休闲游戏的一部分？它能完成什么？它的目的是什么？

1.    Research your rule. Consider the aspect of casual games that you’ve chosen to intentionally ignore. Why is it part of most casual games in the first place? What does it accomplish? What is its purpose?

2.    打破规则。 一旦你理解了规则，想想你可能会打破它们的原因。在什么情况下你的规则不再有效？你是否知道任何打破规则的成功休闲游戏的例子？

2.    Break the rule. Once you understand the rules, think about reasons why you might break them. Under what conditions is your rule no longer valid? Are you familiar with any examples of successful casual games that break your rule?

3.    创建可交付成果。

3.    Create deliverable.

变体

Variant

掷骰子来选择要否定的品质之一，而不是自己选择一个。

Roll a die to choose one of the qualities to negate, rather than choosing one yourself.

铁艺设计师挑战 5 — 正针 1，反针 2（现场直播）

IRON DESIGNER CHALLENGE 5—KNIT 1, PURL 2 (LIVE)

办公室的门突然打开，营销人员冲了进来。他手里拿着织针。你希望他不要说出来，但他还是说了。“我明白了！织毛衣！织毛衣游戏！”据他说，这真是绝配。它比《猎鹿人》好玩！它比《美国陆军》好玩！现在，织毛衣是一项非常受欢迎的爱好，受众和休闲游戏爱好者一样（事实上，这是真的）。

The door to your office bursts open, and your marketing guy rushes in. He’s holding knitting needles. You hope he won’t say it, but he does. “I’ve got it! Knitting! A knitting game!” According to him, it’s a perfect fit. It’s better than Deer Hunter! It’s better than America’s Army! Knitting is now an incredibly popular hobby with the same audience that’s into casual games (it’s true, actually).

如果您认为自己了解休闲游戏，那么现在是时候测试一下了。将您分成 2 到 4 人的小队。让每个小队说出 30 岁以上女性中流行的一项爱好。每个小队由另一个小队分配一项爱好。您必须为休闲游戏创建概念宣传，以给定的爱好作为其主要主题。您有两个小时的时间。

If you think you know casual games, it’s time to put that to the test. Split into teams of two to four individuals. Have each team name a hobby that’s popular with 30+ year old females. Each team is assigned a hobby by another team. You must create a concept pitch for a casual game, featuring the given hobby as its main theme. You have two hours.

如果你在想自己的爱好时遇到困难，可以使用以下列表：

If you’re having trouble coming up with hobbies, use this list:

1.    针织

1.    Knitting

2.    烹饪

2.    Cooking

3.    古董

3.    Antiques

4.    绗缝

4.    Quilting

5.    观鸟

5.    Birdwatching

6.    珠宝制作

6.    Jewelry making

7.    园艺

7.    Gardening

8.    散步

8.    Walking

9.    剪贴簿

9.    Scrapbooking

所需组件

Components Required

·      互联网连接（用于研究）

·      Internet connection (for research)

可交付成果

Deliverable

·      非正式概念推介

·      Informal concept pitch

建议流程

Suggested Process

1.    研究。如果团队中没有人熟悉你指定的爱好，请在网上研究基础知识。是什么让这个爱好变得有趣（至少根据它的爱好者的说法）？这个爱好的核心要素是什么？

1.    Research. If no one on your team is intimately familiar with your assigned hobby, research the basics online. What makes the hobby fun (at least, according to its devotees)? What are the core elements of the hobby?

2.    集思广益。爱好的哪些方面可以很好地转化为游戏？想出一个能够抓住爱好本质的核心机制，然后在此基础上创建完整游戏的概念。

2.    Brainstorm. What aspects of the hobby translate well to games? Think of a core mechanic that captures the essence of the hobby and then build on it to create the concept for a full game.

3.    创建可交付成果。

3.    Create deliverable.

非数字短片

NON-DIGITAL SHORTS

通过以思想、纸质原型或数字形式探索这些主题来练习您的休闲游戏设计。

Practice your casual game design by exploring any of these topics in thought, paper prototype or digital form.

1.    从挑战四：“打破规则”列出的属性中选择三个，并以此为核心设计一个牌类游戏。

1.    Choose three of the attributes listed in Challenge 4: “Breaking the Rules” and design a tile game using these as the core.

2.    选择一款较长但简单的棋盘游戏（如《人生游戏》或《大富翁》），并重新设计它，使其可以在 10 分钟内玩完。

2.    Choose a lengthy but simple board game (such as The Game of Life or Monopoly) and redesign it to be playable in 10 minutes.

3.    大部分休闲游戏都是单人游戏。将Checkers重新设计为单人游戏。

3.    Most casual games are single-player. Redesign Checkers to be a solo game.

4.    拉米牌是一种经典的纸牌游戏，符合休闲游戏的许多特征。重新设计游戏以遵循“玩家与时间”模型。

4.    Rummy is a classic card game that fits many of the characteristics of a casual game. Redesign the game to follow the “Player vs. Time” model.

5.    对于#4，可重新设计拉米牌，以遵循“玩家与分数”模型。

5.    Alternatively to #4, redesign Rummy to follow the “Player vs. Score” model.

6.    选择一款复杂的棋盘游戏（任何比大富翁更复杂的游戏都可以），并重新设计它，使其适合 6-8 岁儿童学习和玩耍。风险是这项练习的理想选择。

6.    Choose a complex board game (anything more complicated than Monopoly will do) and redesign it to be learnable and playable by children aged 6–8. Risk is ideal for this exercise.

7.    创建一个可以作为“聚会”的休闲游戏。聚会游戏可以让人们在大型聚会上见面并互相问候。

7.    Create a casual game that also works as a “mixer.” Mixer games allow individuals to meet and greet one another at large parties.

8.    看到这么多员工玩休闲游戏，你印象深刻，当地一家零售店的经理找到你，希望你为公司的培训活动创建一款这样的游戏。

8.    Impressed by the number of employees who are playing casual games, you are approached by a manager of a local retail outlet who would like you to create one such game for the company’s training retreat.

9.    创建一个休闲游戏，同时教授合理的环境实践。

9.    Create a casual game that simultaneously teaches about sound environmental practices.

10. 制作一款休闲游戏，让妈妈们可以用它来教尚未识字的孩子学习字母。不要使用“翻转并匹配”的机制。

10. Create a casual game that mothers can use to teach their pre-reading children the alphabet. Do not use the “flip over and match” mechanic.

[CAS01] http://www.igda.org/wiki/Casual_Games_SIG/Whitepaper [CAS02] http://www.casualgamesassociation.org/faq.php#casualgames

[CAS01] http://www.igda.org/wiki/Casual_Games_SIG/Whitepaper [CAS02] http://www.casualgamesassociation.org/faq.php#casualgames

 

 

 

 


21：社交网络和游戏

21: Social Networks & Games

    

    

自计算机诞生之初，该行业就一直朝着社交网络和游戏融合的方向发展。游戏一直是一种社交体验，正如游戏设计师 Greg Costikyan 在 1994 年的文章《我无话可说，但我必须设计》中指出的那样，单人游戏只是历史常态中的暂时异常现象1。一旦技术发展到一定程度，人们就会再次一起玩游戏。当今的 MMO 和蓬勃发展的社交网络证明了这一点。

Since the earliest days of computing, the industry has been heading progressively toward a convergence of social networks and games. Games have always been a social experience, and as game designer Greg Costikyan noted in his 1994 article, “I Have No Words and I Must Design,” solo player games are a temporary aberration in the historical norm1. Once technology reached a certain point, people would be gaming together again. Today’s MMOs and burgeoning social networks attest to that.

说到社交网络和游戏，实际上有两种需要考虑：游戏之外的和游戏的一部分。排行榜、聊天室和公会论坛都是游戏之外的，无论社区与游戏的联系有多紧密，尽管那里可能会发生大量的战略制定，但并没有实际的游戏玩法。相反，Facebook 等社交网络上的游戏不仅使用社交网络在玩家之间传播游戏，而且有些游戏还完全融入了社交网络，使其成为一种动态游戏。《停车大战》就是这样一款游戏。玩这款游戏的朋友越多，可供停车的地方就越多。有时，这两个世界之间的界限很模糊，例如拍卖行是游戏之外的，但其结果会影响整体游戏玩法。

In speaking of social networks and games, there are really two kinds to consider: those outside of a game and those that are a part of the game. Leader-boards, chat rooms, and guild forums are all external to a game, no matter how closely the community may be tied to that game, and while a great deal of strategizing might take place there, there is no actual gameplay to be had. Conversely, games on social networks like Facebook not only use the social network to propagate the game player to player, but some also fully incorporate the social network, making it a dynamic of play. Parking Wars is one such game. The more friends you have playing, the more spots you have available to park your car. Sometimes, there is a blur between the two worlds, such as auction houses that are external to the game, but whose outcomes affect gameplay overall.

在本章中，我们将探索将社交网络完全融入游戏一部分的游戏。

In this chapter, we’ll explore games that fully incorporate the social network as a part of the game.

从游戏开发的角度来看，开发商和发行商都需要考虑三个重要因素。

From a game-development perspective, there are three important considerations for both the developer and publisher.

社交网络拥有内置的免费分发网络。一些社交网络服务于数千万会员，实际上就是他们自己的 MMO。社交网络游戏的资产要求低。与传统游戏开发相比，它们的成本极低。

Social networks own a built-in free distribution network. Some social networks serve an audience of tens of millions of members, in effect, their own MMO. Social network games have low asset requirements. They are exceptionally low cost compared to traditional game development.

社交网络游戏的分类

CATEGORIZING SOCIAL-NETWORK GAMES

虽然社交网络上的游戏往往类似于休闲游戏（例如，它们通常快速且易于玩），但为设计师增加了一定程度的难度。

While the games available on social networks tend to resemble casual games (for example, they are usually quick and easy to play), a level of difficulty is added for the designer.

对于希望在这个领域从事设计的人来说，了解社交网络游戏的各种类别非常重要。

Understanding the various categories of social-network games is important for those hoping to design in this space.

宏观类别

MACRO-CATEGORY

从最高层次来看，社交网络上的游戏分为以下三类：

At the highest level, games on social networks fit into one of three categories:

·      依赖网络：这些游戏无法脱离社交网络而存在，它们依赖网络来提供游戏动力。虽然这些游戏可以改变为独立于网络，但游戏的玩法机制与网络紧密相关，因此这种修改会导致游戏失去所有特色。当玩家添加应用程序时，他会立即开始与所有拥有该应用程序的朋友一起玩。《停车大战》就是这样一款游戏。如果没有朋友的街道供您停车，那么游戏就无从谈起。

·      Network dependent: These games cannot exist outside of a social network and rely upon the network for play dynamics. While these games can be altered to be independent of the network, the play mechanics of the game are so tied to the network that such a modification would cause the game to lose all its flavor. When the player adds the application, he immediately begins playing with all of his friends who also have the application. Parking Wars is one such game. Without friends’ streets to park your cars on, there’s no game to speak of.

·      网络集成：这类游戏可以存在于网络之外，但它们的设计使其非常适合社交网络支持的回合制游戏。它们使用社交网络来支持多人游戏。Scrabulous （Scrabble 的克隆版）和其他棋盘游戏的仿制品通常属于这一类。

·      Network integrated: These games can exist outside the network, but their design makes them ideally suited for the turn-based gameplay that social networks support well. They use the social network to support multiplayer games. Scrabulous (a Scrabble clone) and other knockoffs of board games usually fit in this category.

·      独立于网络：这些游戏不利用社交网络，或者即使利用，也只能以非常有限的方式利用，例如在好友的新闻源中发布信息（或类似的报告结构）。在许多情况下，它们是单人游戏，玩家之间不存在任何形式的直接冲突。《喷气人》是一款单人街机游戏，游戏中一名男子背着喷气背包试图飞越障碍赛道，这就是此类游戏的一个例子。

·      Network independent: These games don’t take advantage of the social network, or if they do, they take advantage of it in a very limited way, such as posting information in your friend’s newsfeed (or similar reporting structure). In many cases, they are single-player games where there is no form of direct conflict between the players. Jetman, a single-player arcade game where a man with a jetpack tries to fly through an obstacle course, is an example of this type of game.

游戏深度——游戏设计师 Scott Jon Siegel

PLAY DEPTH—SCOTT JON SIEGEL, GAME DESIGNER

游戏设计师 Scott Jon Siegel 在自己的博客上发表的一篇文章中，根据游戏的深度，将 Facebook 游戏分为三个不同的类别：平淡、浅薄和深厚。以下内容经其许可转载。

In an article on his blog, game designer Scott Jon Siegel broke Facebook games down into three distinct categories based on their depth of play: flat, shallow, and deep. The following text is reprinted with his permission.

·      扁平游戏在 Facebook 上存在，但它们也可能存在于其他地方。它们几乎都是单人游戏，并且不通过游戏玩法涉及可用的社交网络。（我想强调“通过游戏玩法”，因为许多此类应用确实利用网络来创建排行榜并分享高分，但这确实会影响核心游戏的运作方式。）例如Jetman、 Tower Bloxx等热门应用，以及让用户玩Snake和Tetris等经典游戏的大量街机合集应用。有时，这些应用只是移植到 Facebook 的 Flash 应用。

·      Flat games exist on Facebook, but they might as well exist anywhere else. They’re almost always single-player, and do not involve the available social network through the gameplay. (I want to stress “through the gameplay,” as many of these apps do take advantage of the network to create leaderboards and share high scores, but this does affect how the core game operates.) Examples are popular apps like Jetman, Tower Bloxx, and the copious arcade compilation apps that let users play classics like Snake and Tetris. Sometimes, these apps are simply Flash applications ported to Facebook.

·      浅显游戏确实在游戏中利用了社交网络，但通常程度相当有限。这方面的例子包括Texas Hold-'Em Poker和非常出色的Scrabulous 应用程序，这两个应用程序都使用您的好友列表来组织潜在对手。Scrabulous是我遇到的第一款巧妙利用 Facebook 的应用程序，它将Scrabble变成了一种绝妙的邮件式游戏体验。不过，游戏玩法基本上不受网络的影响。

·      Shallow games do utilize the social network in gameplay, but usually to a fairly limited degree. Examples of this include Texas Hold-’Em Poker and the ever-so-excellent Scrabulous application, both of which use your friends list to organize potential opponents. Scrabulous was the first app I encountered that made smart use of Facebook, turning Scrabble into a divine play-by-mail-esque experience. Still, the gameplay is largely unaffected by the network.

·      最后，深度游戏更直接地利用了 Facebook 的功能，围绕社交网络构建核心机制，并使用其他方法将整个 Facebook 融入游戏玩法中。最好的例子是狼人/吸血鬼/僵尸应用程序，它们将游戏玩法带到了 Facebook 的墙壁和 PM 上，玩家引诱毫无戒心的朋友以增强自己的权力。最近加入深度游戏的是 area/code 的Parking Wars，用户将汽车停在朋友的街道上，这是一种奇怪的停车导向版“胆小鬼”。这两款游戏都将社交网络重新想象成其他东西（无论是食物还是免费停车位），并围绕这一虚构内容构建游戏玩法。

·      Finally, deep games take more direct advantage of Facebook’s features, building core mechanics around social networks and using additional methods to incorporate the whole of Facebook into the gameplay. The best example of this is the Werewolves/ Vampires/Zombies application(s), which took the gameplay onto Facebook’s walls and PMs, as players lured unsuspecting friends in order to increase their power. A more recent addition to the deep end is area/code’s Parking Wars, which has users leaving cars on the streets of their friends in a strange parking-oriented version of “chicken.” Both games re-imagined the social network as something else (be it food or free parking), and built gameplay around this fiction.

案例研究：区域/代码的停车之争

CASE STUDY: AREA/CODE’S PARKING WARS

Parking Wars是一款简单的游戏。玩家从以自己名字命名的街道和两辆车开始。玩家的目标是在别人的街道上为这些车找到停车位。其他街道由玩家社交网络中也在玩这款游戏的人拥有。绿色汽车必须停在空地或标有“仅限绿色汽车”的停车位，否则可能会被街道所有者开罚单。汽车停在一个停车位上的时间越长，赚的钱就越多。停在一个停车位上的时间足够长，汽车的最高收入为 5,560 美元。

Parking Wars is a simple game. Players start with a street named after them and two cars. A player’s goal is to find a parking place for those cars on someone else’s street. The other streets are owned by people in the player’s social network who are also playing the game. Green cars must park in open spots or spots that read “Green Cars Only” or risk being ticketed by the street’s owner. The longer the car sits in one spot, the more money it earns. Sit in a single spot long enough, and the car tops off at $5,560.

大多数停车位都有限制：只限红色汽车、只限蓝色汽车、禁止停车等等。因此，如果玩家找不到合适的停车位，他们就必须非法停车，并冒着被其他玩家开罚单的风险。开罚单对开罚单的人来说是一项赚钱的举动，而对被开罚单的人来说则是一件赔钱的事情——收到罚单会导致分数相差 2 倍。随着您从停车和开罚单中赚到更多钱，您的等级就会上升并获得更多汽车。

Most parking spaces have constraints on them: red cars only, blue cars only, no parking, and so on. So, if players can’t find an appropriate spot for a car, they have to park illegally and risk getting ticketed by other players. Giving out tickets is a money-earning proposition for the ticketer, and a money-losing event for the ticketed—receiving a ticket has the effect of creating a 2*ticket difference in score. As you earn more money from parking and ticketing, you level up and gain additional cars.

Parking Wars最初是作为 A&E 的Parking Wars真人秀节目的广告游戏而开发的。尽管游戏最初最高奖金为 1,000,000 美元，但人们并没有停止玩。继续玩下去不会获得任何奖励，但这并没有阻止人们。受到玩家持续玩游戏的鼓舞，并响应他们的要求，2008 年初，Parking Wars开发者 area/code 为某些成就添加了徽章，还允许玩家购买新车，包括冰淇淋车（允许汽车以更高的速度赚钱）和拖车（可以拖走违章停车的汽车，无论它们在谁的街道上）。Applied01

Parking Wars was originally developed as an advergame for A&E’s Parking Wars reality TV show. Though play originally capped off at $1,000,000, people didn’t stop playing. There were no rewards to be gained by going further, but that didn’t deter people. Encouraged by their continued play and in response to their requests, in early 2008, Parking Wars developer area/code added badges for certain achievements and also let players buy new cars, including ice-cream trucks, which allowed cars to earn at a greater rate, and tow trucks, which could tow illegally parked cars, no matter whose street they were on.Applied01

什么最有效？

WHAT WORKS BEST?

社交网络上的游戏必须具备利用社交网络的机制。最终，这些机制会产生动态，从而扩大游戏玩家群。在《停车战争》的案例中，当玩家安装游戏或为其他玩家开罚单时，玩家的新闻源中会报道此事。因此，游戏的动态不仅在玩家的屏幕上，而且在所有玩家的好友屏幕上，都支持其发展并强化其广告信息。

Games on social networks must have mechanics that take advantage of the social network. Ultimately, these mechanics give rise to dynamics that lead to propagation of the game’s player base. In Parking Wars’ case, when the player installs the game or tickets another player, it is reported in the player’s newsfeed. The dynamics of the game, then, support its growth and reinforce its advertising message not just on the player’s screen, but on all the player’s friends screens, too.

在分析社交网络上成功的游戏设计时，出现了一些常数：

In analyzing successful game design on social networks, some constants emerge:

·      回合制：由于社交网络游戏的玩家可以随意进出，因此最能维持游戏体验的游戏是回合制游戏。所有玩家都可以在场，例如在线扑克游戏，也可以不参加，例如围棋游戏。然而，关键在于人们可以随意进出的自由。

·      Turn-based: Since players of games on social networks come and go as they please, the games that sustain play the best are turn-based games. All players may be present for play, as in online games of Poker, or not, as in games like Go. The key, however, is the freedom for people to come and go as they please.

·      多人游戏：在社交网络上，让好友之间互动似乎是一件理所当然的事。令人惊讶的是，社交网站上有很多单人游戏。然而，允许在社交网络内互动的游戏无疑是最成功的。

·      Multiplayer: On a social network, allowing friends to interact with one another seems like a no-brainer. Surprisingly, many single-player games exist on social network sites. However, games that allow interaction within the social network are far and away the most successful.

·      影响朋友：玩家可以对朋友做一些好事或坏事的游戏往往特别受欢迎。《吸血鬼》允许你以朋友为食，而《停车大战》允许你给他们开罚单并直接从他们的口袋里拿走虚拟钱。与传统游戏一样，打败朋友或帮助朋友比打败电脑更令人满足。

·      Friend affecting: Games where players can do something nice or something mean to their friends tend to be particularly popular. Vampires allows you to feed on your friends, while Parking Wars allows you to ticket them and take virtual money directly out of their pockets. As with traditional games, beating your friends or helping your friends is more satisfying than beating a computer.

·      易于传播：游戏要想获得商业效益和成功，就需要吸引大量玩家。因此，易于在玩家之间传播的游戏，或者更好的是，邀请好友可获得实物奖励的游戏最有可能获得成功。

·      Easy to propagate: In order for games to be commercially effective and successful, they need to be played by a wide audience of individuals. Therefore, games that allow easy propagation from player to player or, better yet, provide tangible rewards for inviting friends, have the best chance of succeeding.

·      具有状态功能的游戏：玩家喜欢对自己在任何类型的游戏中的表现感到满意。事实上，追求高分为街机游戏的所有者带来了很多季度的收益。在主游戏屏幕或新闻源更新中突出显示分数（或等价物）的游戏通常对玩家很有吸引力。有一款这样的游戏威胁（尽管是无意的）要在财务测验中显示玩家的分数。不止一个人公开表示怀疑，为什么有人会想让别人知道他们对财务的了解如此之少。有关更多信息，请参阅本章后面的“高分和社交网络”部分。

·      Games with a status feature: Players like to feel good about their performance in any kind of game. In fact, the pursuit of the high score earned many a quarter for owners of arcades. Games that make the display of a score (or the equivalent thereof) prominent in the main gameplay screen or in newsfeed updates are often attractive to players. One such game threatened (albeit unintentionally) to display the player’s score in a financial quiz. More than one person publicly wondered why on earth anyone would want anyone else to know how little they knew about finances. For more information, see the section “High Score and the Social Network” later in this chapter.

·      具有视觉显示功能的游戏：就像玩家喜欢游戏中的高分或排行榜一样，他们也喜欢允许他们自定义空间并向其他人显示该空间的游戏。Facebook 的Fluff Friends等游戏为玩家提供了多种在玩家页面上自定义游戏空间的机会。

·      Games with a visual display feature: Just as players like high scores or leader-boards in games, they also like games that allow them to customize their space and display that space to others. Games like Facebook’s Fluff Friends offer players multiple opportunities to customize the play space on the player’s page.

·      易于理解和玩的游戏：休闲游戏在社交网络上最受欢迎，尽管社交网络休闲游戏的类型与人们所期望的传统流行的单人休闲游戏（如《宝石迷阵》和《美女餐厅》）有所不同。最受欢迎的游戏易于理解，需要在社交网络内进行互动，并且游戏压力较小。

·      Games that are easy to understand and play: Casual games work the best on social networks, although the breed of social-network casual games is different from what one would expect of the traditionally popular single-player casual games like Bejeweled and Diner Dash. The most popular games are easy to understand, require interaction within the social network, and provide low-stress play.

·      需要重复访问的游戏：玩家需要定期、可预测地回到游戏中，这是游戏的一项要求。在《停车大战》中，有三种特定机制需要玩家返回。它们分别是：对在玩家街道上非法停车的汽车开罚单/兑现已达到最高收入的汽车的罚单/检查以确保停车位的限制没有从“只限红色汽车”变为“只限绿色汽车”，从而使玩家的汽车值得开罚单。/ 这与Scrabulous等未将时间整合到机制中的游戏不同。人们可以在最后一次移动一周或更长时间后返回Scrabulous 。与《停车大战》不同，它没有让人们返回游戏的动力。

·      Games that require repeat visits: Players are brought back to a game on a regular, predictable basis as a requirement of play. In Parking Wars, there are three specific mechanics that require players to return. These are the following: Ticketing cars that are illegally parked on the player’s street / Cashing in cars that have maxed out their earnings / Checking to make sure the restrictions on a spot haven’t changed from, say, “Red Cars Only” to “Green Cars Only,” rendering a player’s car ticket worthy. / This is different from games like Scrabulous that don’t integrate time into the mechanics. People can go back to Scrabulous a week or more after the last move. There’s no impetus to return to play like there is here in Parking Wars.

·      鼓励社区的游戏： Facebook 上的游戏越来越多地鼓励玩家共同努力以取得成功。例如，为了了解如何获得开发人员在 2008 年初更新的游戏中提供的徽章，玩家们一起合作，在 Parking Wars 论坛上宣布他们的成功并提出 问题。Applied03

·      Games that encourage community: Increasingly, games on Facebook are encouraging players to work together in order to succeed. For instance, in order to discover how to get the badges offered by developers in their early 2008 update of the game, players worked together and announced their successes and raised questions in the Parking Wars forum.Applied03

另一方面，违背这些惯例的游戏往往表现不佳。

On the flip side, games that run contrary to these conventions tend not to do as well.

社交网络传播机制

SOCIAL-NETWORK PROPAGATION MECHANICS

为了在社交网络上取得成功，游戏需要从一个用户转移到另一个用户。这是如何实现的？

In order to succeed on a social network, games need to move from user to user to user. How does that happen?

本书的一位作者目前正在研究开发者在 Facebook 社区中推广休闲游戏的机制。由于这些游戏的成功以及广告费和展示次数的回报与玩家数量和玩家实际玩游戏的时间有关，因此成功的 Facebook 游戏必须在社交网络中推广才能获得成功。

One of the authors of this book is currently studying the mechanics that developers use to propagate casual games throughout the Facebook community. Since the success of these games and the payout in terms of advertising dollars and impressions is related to the number of players and the amount those players actually play, a successful Facebook game must propagate within the social network in order to be successful.

在缺乏传统广告方式、AAA 级制作价值，甚至没有严肃的游戏评论结构的情况下，是什么促使人们玩 Facebook 游戏呢？

In the absence of the traditional methods of advertising, AAA-level production values, or even a serious review structure for the games, what causes people to play Facebook games?

金字塔骗局

THE PYRAMID SCHEME

最成功的 Facebook 游戏形成了金字塔式的计划，玩家可以通过邀请他人玩游戏获得收益，而他们反过来又通过邀请更多人玩游戏获得收益。《Parking Wars》和《Fluff Friends》等游戏就是很好的例子。然而，单人游戏在这方面却失败了。Facebook 上许多非游戏类的热门应用也会因为邀请他人而给予奖励。因此，玩家因邀请他人而获得奖励，他人因邀请他人而获得奖励，以此类推。由于 Facebook 的结构，很少有游戏被设计为利用完整的金字塔（因为没有更好的术语）——玩家不会因其邀请人的邀请而获得收益。

The most successful Facebook games form pyramid schemes where you benefit from inviting people to play, and they, in turn, benefit by inviting still more people to play. This is exemplified in games like Parking Wars and Fluff Friends. Solo-player games, however, fail in this regard. Many of the non-game, popular apps on Facebook give people rewards for inviting people, too. So a player gets rewards for inviting people, and they get rewards for inviting people, and so on. Due to the structure of Facebook, few games are designed to take advantage of the full pyramid (for lack of a better term)—the player doesn’t receive benefits for invitees of his or her invitees.

在一些流行的 Facebook 应用中，实际上大部分工作都是自动化的。玩家需要做的唯一“工作”是从好友列表中选择好友。如果他们的好友列表相当多，那么满足某些奖励门槛就相对容易。

In the case of some popular Facebook apps, much of the work is automated, actually. The only “work” players need to do is selecting friends from their friends list. If they have a sizable list of friends, it’s relatively easy to meet certain reward thresholds.

该机制的修改是为所有受邀者提供奖励，并为接受邀请的人提供额外奖励。

Modifications on this mechanic are bonuses for all invitees and additional bonuses for those who accept.

新闻推送“评价”

NEWSFEED “TESTIMONIALS”

安装游戏后，玩家好友的新闻源中会出现一份报告，然后新闻源条目将充当推荐。出现在该新闻源条目中的好友数量（例如，“您的五个好友有...”）以及他们对新闻源读者的意见的价值也会影响该人是否安装该应用程序。这表明更快的传播可能导致更快的传播。

With the installation of a game, a report appears in the player’s friends’ newsfeed, and the newsfeed item then serves as a testimonial. The number of friends to appear in that newsfeed item (for example, “five of your friends have...”) and the value of their opinion to the newsfeed reader affects whether or not that person installs the application, too. This suggests that faster propagation could lead to still faster propagation.

例如，五位游戏开发者安装了《停车大战》。当这款游戏出现在他们一位朋友的新闻推送中时，他们立即安装了这款游戏，这不仅是因为游戏数量，还因为他非常看重朋友们作为游戏开发者的意见。

For instance, five game developers installed Parking Wars. When the item appeared in one of their friend’s newsfeeds, they installed it immediately, based not only on the number, but on the value he placed upon his friends’ opinions as game developers.

新闻动态 播放更新

NEWSFEED PLAY UPDATES

Parking Wars和大多数游戏一样，每当达到某个里程碑时，都会不断提供新闻更新。对于Parking Wars来说，当玩家给别人开罚单或获得徽章时，游戏就会在新闻中发布一个项目。其他游戏会在玩家获得更高分数时发布消息。当人们对玩家的宠物做了什么或有抽象的比赛时， Fluff Friends会报道。在每种情况下，这些也是一种推荐形式。

Parking Wars and most games continually provide newsfeed updates every time a certain milestone is achieved. For Parking Wars, the game posts an item in the newsfeed when the player tickets people or earns a badge. Other games post when the player reaches a higher score. Fluff Friends reports when people do something to the player’s pet or there’s an abstracted race. In each instance, these too serve as a form of testimonial.

多人游戏授权

MULTIPLAYER MANDATE

有些游戏不能单独玩。《停车大战》就是这样一款游戏。然而，当它首次发布时，有些人就陷入了这种情况：如果玩家没有朋友在玩这款游戏，他就无法玩游戏，直到他能让一些朋友也安装这款应用程序。然而，最终，《停车大战》增加了“邻居”功能，这样多人游戏就不再是强制性的了。然而，它改变了游戏的整体动态。人们可以从后来增加的“仅显示朋友”或“显示朋友和邻居”中看到这一点。显然，从《停车大战》的玩家列表中给陌生人开罚单并不像给朋友开罚单那么令人满意。

Some games cannot be played alone. Parking Wars is one such game. When it was first released, however, some people were put into this situation: if the player had no friends playing the game, he was unable to play until he could get some of his friends to install the application, too. Eventually, however, Parking Wars added “neighbors” so that multiplayer playing was no longer a mandate. It changed the overall dynamics of the game, however. One can see this reflected in the later addition of “show only friends” or “show friends and neighbors.” Evidently, it’s not as satisfying to ticket an unknown person from Parking Wars’ player list as it is to ticket one’s friends.

多人游戏选项

MULTIPLAYER OPTION

有些游戏提供单人或多人游戏选项。Scrabulous就是这样一款游戏。它相对简单且熟悉，是最受欢迎的 Facebook 游戏之一。不过，与朋友一起玩游戏比与游戏的 AI 一起玩游戏更令人愉快。

Some games provide an option that allows play either solo or with another player. Scrabulous is one such game. Its relative ease and familiarity make it one of the most popular Facebook games. Still, it’s more pleasant to play the game with a friend than the AI of the game.

邀请奖励

REWARDS THROUGH INVITE

这与前面提到的金字塔骗局有关。在这种情况下，游戏会提示您邀请朋友，如果您这样做，它会为您解锁内容或提供类似的奖励。例如，Fluff Friends会为您接受的每条邀请提供 25 个“munny”。玩家通常会在首次安装应用程序时被诱惑邀请其他朋友。

This ties into the pyramid scheme mentioned earlier. In this instance, the game prompts you to invite friends, and it unlocks content for you if you do so or provides a similar reward. For instance, Fluff Friends gives you 25 “munny” for each accepted invite. The player is generally enticed to invite other friends during the player’s initial installation of the application.

人质事件

THE HOSTAGE SITUATION

“某某说了你什么。立即登录查看是什么！” Facebook 应用传播机制中最受欢迎的一种是“人质事件”。应用程序会通知你，你的朋友显然留下了一些关于你的有趣信息。为了获取这些信息，你也需要添加该应用程序。

“So and so has said [something] about you. Log in now to find out what!” One of the more popular Facebook app-propagation mechanics is the “the hostage situation.” You are notified by an application that your friend has evidently left some juicy information about you. In order to get the information, you need to add the application, too.

很明显，这个机制依赖玩家的好奇心来传播。

This mechanic quite obviously relies on player curiosity to propagate itself.

报复

RETALIATION

使用“报复”技巧，一个朋友对你做了 [行动 x]，应用程序邀请你对朋友也做同样的事，从而迫使你安装应用程序。如果你接受，它可能会进一步传播，因为如果你走得那么远，你也更有可能对其他人做 [行动 x]。例如，本书的一位作者开始使用Superpoke，因为一位游戏开发者“用鲑鱼打了 [她]”。为了对他做一些同样奇怪的事情，她也需要安装这个应用程序。值得称赞的是，Superpoke提供了广泛的选择，从节日问候到更无聊的事情，比如……向某人扔一头牛。因此，尽管某人可能不太可能安装该应用程序来报复鲑鱼的袭击，但选择的多样性在朋友中广泛传播。APPLIED04

Using the “retaliation” technique, a friend has done [action x] to you, and the app invites you to do it back to your friend, thereby forcing you to install the app. If you accept, it is likely to propagate still further, because if you go that far, you’re more likely to do [x action] to others, too. For instance, one of the authors of this book got into Superpoke because a fellow game developer “slapped [her] with a trout.” In order to do something equally odd to him, she needed to install the app, too. To its credit, Superpoke offers a wide range of options, from holiday greetings to the more inane things like... throwing a cow at someone. So, though someone may not have been likely to install the app to retaliate a trout attack, the diversity of options propagates it heavily among friends.APPLIED04

减缓传播

SLOWING THE SPREAD

作为一个游戏平台，Facebook 是一个相对较新的媒介，游戏动态与我们作为游戏开发者和设计师所熟悉的许多其他平台不同。整个模式已经改变——游戏的社交性质在很多情况下比游戏本身更重要。事实上，Facebook 游戏在实际游戏机制方面可能很陈旧，甚至一点也不好玩，但仍然会大获成功。另一方面，游戏可能很有深度、很持久，但无法传播。

As a gaming platform, Facebook is a relatively new medium, and the dynamics of play are different from many others with which we, as game developers and designers, are familiar. The whole paradigm’s changed—the social nature of the game is, in many cases, more important than the actual game itself. In fact, a Facebook game can be threadbare in terms of actual game mechanics or not even fun at all, and still be wildly successful. On the other hand, a game can be deep and lasting and fail to propagate.

哪些因素会减慢游戏传播的速度？

What slows down gameplay propagation?

达到临界质量

HITTING CRITICAL MASS

2007 年夏天，成千上万的玩家每天都会收到这样的信息：“亲爱的受害者，你被 [朋友名字] 咬了！开始咬吧！”删除这些消息后，另一波消息会涌来。这导致一位著名的游戏开发者使用他的状态行来告诉任何潜在的狼人、吸血鬼或其他传播者他们应该做些什么。这款游戏已经达到了临界点，它并没有变得有趣，反而让很多人感到厌烦，尤其是那些不玩游戏的人。

Over the summer of 2007, thousands of players received this message daily: “Dear victim, You have been bitten by [friend name]! Start biting chumps!” After deleting them, another wave of messages would arrive. It led one prominent game developer to use his status line to tell any potential werewolves, vampires, or other propagators precisely what they could do with themselves. The game had hit critical mass, and instead of becoming fun, it was becoming downright annoying to many, especially if they weren’t playing the game.

在“chumps”之后，有人注意到 Facebook 社区对咬人、踢人、西斯、绝地武士或以其他方式传播任何与这些应用程序相似的东西的反应非常谨慎。就像互联网早期一样，在某种程度上，向朋友发送个人娱乐或兴趣的垃圾信息是一种不礼貌的行为。

After “chumps,” some noticed a decided reserved reaction among the Facebook community to bite, kick, Sith, Jedi, or otherwise propagate anything that resembled these applications. Much like the early days of the Internet, at some point, it became bad etiquette to spam your friends with your personal amusements or interests.

奇怪的是，游戏可能会成为其自身成功的牺牲品。

Oddly enough, games can become victims of their own success.

外表/尴尬

APPEARANCE/EMBARRASSMENT

人们关心别人如何看待自己，重视好友列表中的联系人。如果人们讨厌邀请使用某个应用程序，他们就不太可能向其他人推荐该应用程序。推广该应用程序就相当于数字马鲛鱼。

People care about how others perceive them and value the contacts they have on their friends list. If people are annoyed by invites to use a particular application, they are much less likely to propagate that application on to other people. Propagating the application becomes the equivalent of a digital mullet.

再次尴尬

EMBARRASSMENT, AGAIN

安装应用程序时，有关该安装的新闻源报告可能会影响该安装是否被安装。例如，考虑添加调情应用“你有兴趣吗？”或“性感”的思考过程。首先，玩家真的希望所有朋友都知道他们安装了此应用吗？您并不总是可以选择在新闻源中拒绝报告。此外，此类应用对女性的吸引力可能较小，因为从刻板印象上讲，女性不太可能像男性那样说“嘿？想告诉我我有多性感吗？”，因为担心答案可能是“没那么性感”。（请参阅 Sheri Graner Ray 的《性别包容性游戏设计》一书，了解有关女性对游戏和玩游戏的人的反应的更多信息。）

When installing an application, the newsfeed reporting on said installation can affect whether or not the installation is installed in the first place. For instance, consider the thought process involved in adding the flirty Are You Interested? or the Hotness application. First of all, do players really want all their friends knowing they have installed this app? You don’t always have the option to deny the report in your newsfeed. Furthermore, such apps are likely to be less appealing to women who, stereotypically speaking, are less likely than men to say, “Hey? Want to tell me how hot I am?” for fear that the answer may come back, “Not so hot.” (See Sheri Graner Ray’s book Gender Inclusive Game Design for more info on how women react to games and people playing games.)

我对战你

ME VERSUS YOU

一般而言，人们更关心自己，而不是关心他人。利用这一点的 Facebook 应用程序比不利用这一点的应用程序更容易传播。例如，考虑“我的房间”应用程序。此应用程序允许玩家查看其他人对其虚拟房间所做的一切。自私的吸引力是什么？除了偷窥倾向之外，为什么一个玩家想要查看另一个玩家的东西，特别是如果这些东西对他们没有任何好处？虽然玩家可以创建自己的“我的房间”，但该信息的吸引力在于查看其他玩家的东西，而不是创建自己的东西。它无法激发玩家的积极性。

In general, people care about themselves more than they care about others. Facebook applications that take advantage of this are more likely to propagate than those that don’t. For instance, consider the My Room application. This application allows players to see all the things someone else has done to their virtual room. What is the selfish attraction? Apart from voyeuristic tendencies, why would one player want to see another’s stuff, particularly if there were nothing in it for them? While players can create their own My Room, the message’s appeal is to look at another player’s stuff, not create their own. It fails to motivate.

同样，那些立即将人置于从属地位的应用程序在玩家列表中也并不受欢迎。例如，有些应用程序允许您成为虚拟骑士并加入他人的宫廷。同样，这里的吸引力在于为他人做事，而不是为自己做事。

Likewise, applications that immediately put the person in a subservient position aren’t high on players’ lists either. For instance some applications allow you to become a virtual knight and join another person’s court. Again, the appeal here is to do something for someone else as opposed to doing it for themselves.

将此与其他应用（如《你将如何死去？》和《你是哪个摇滚明星？》）进行比较，这些应用的目标是玩家，而不是假设他们足够关心发送应用的人，以至于想加入他们的法庭或查看他们的房间。简而言之：在目标端的传播消息中，游戏应该针对他们对自身的兴趣，而不是发送消息的人。Applied04

Compare this with other apps like How will you die? and Which Rockstar are you?, which target the player and not an assumption that they care enough about the person sending the app to want to be in their court or view their room. The nutshell here is this: In the propagation message on the target side, the game should target their interest in themselves and not the person who sent it.Applied04

高分与社交网络

HIGH SCORE AND THE SOCIAL NETWORK

人们喜欢在现实生活中和游戏中受到关注。页面上显示高分列表会自动提升游戏的竞争力。由于社交网络的透明度，高分往往比传统游戏机或 PC 游戏具有更深远的影响，在传统游戏机或 PC 游戏中，玩家标签充其量只是常态。

People like to be noticed in real life and in games, too. Having a high-score list present on the page automatically ups the competitiveness of the game. Because of the transparency of social networks, high scores tend to have a more far-reaching effect than they do in traditional console or PC games where, at best, gamer tags are the norm.

当时间被加入其中时（例如，你必须每隔 x 小时做某事，就像在《停车战争》中一样），高分列表就会成为一个不断移动的目标，有意愿的人会继续向其射击。

When time is added into the mix (for example, you have to do something every x hours as you do in Parking Wars), the high-score list becomes an ever-moving target that the willing will continue to shoot at.

高分改动

HIGH-SCORE ALTERATIONS

如果一款游戏允许玩家通过游戏机制影响彼此的得分，那么高分榜单就变得更有意义，因为它不仅代表了玩家在自己游戏中的效率，还代表了玩家在与好友的较量中的表现。如果玩家不仅可以影响自己的得分，还可以影响其他玩家的得分，那么这会增加游戏的竞争性和乐趣。

If a game allows players to affect each other’s scores through game mechanics, the high-score listing becomes that much more meaningful as a representation not just of the player’s effectiveness in his or her own game, but also against his or her friends as well. It adds to the competitiveness and the enjoyment of the game if the player can affect not just his or her score but other players’ scores as well.

高分损失

HIGH-SCORE LOSS

不过，高分也有缺点。如果分数从某个特定点开始不断攀升，新玩家可能会因为这个分数而失去兴趣。这不断提醒其他玩家，他们永远也赶不上一列火车。

There is a down side to high scores, though. If the score starts at a particular point and keeps climbing from there, those new to the game may be turned off by that same score. It is a constant reminder to other players of a train they will never catch.

所以他们可能会决定不再玩了。当玩家觉得没有真正的战斗可打时，他们就不愿意继续战斗了。

So they may decide not to play anymore. Players are reluctant to keep up the good fight when they feel that there’s no real fight to be had.

一些游戏通过多种方式解决了这个问题：

Some games have addressed this problem in several ways:

·      滚动得分：​​滚动得分使用特定时间段（通常是 30 天）计算。玩家的当前得分等于过去 30 天内的个人得分。这样，新玩家仍然可以保持竞争力。Applied03

·      Rolling score: Rolling scores are calculated using a particular time period, frequently 30 days. The player’s current score equals the individual scores from the last 30 days. This way, new players can still be competitive.Applied03

·      定期重置：每场游戏持续 x 天，然后重置。有时，游戏会保留该期间的最高分数以供后人参考。

·      Periodic resets: Each game lasts for x days before the game resets. Sometimes, games preserve the highest score during that period for posterity.

·      玩家主导的重置：游戏不会每隔 x 天重置一次，而是持续到发生某个游戏事件导致一名或一组玩家获胜为止。游戏结束时可能会很紧张，整个社区会齐心协力阻止少数玩家获胜。

·      Player-directed resets: Instead of every x days, the game lasts until some game event happens that causes a player or a set of players to win. The end game can be tense with the entire community working together to stop a few players from winning.

社交网络和游戏的未来

THE FUTURE OF SOCIAL NETWORKS AND GAMES

预测社交网络的未来似乎是不可能的，但很有可能。然而，正如科斯蒂基安猜测游戏将回归多人游戏的常态一样，社交网络也让游戏有机会回归真正的社交本质，尽管是虚拟的。

Predicting the future of social networks seems impossible, and it may very well be. However, just as Costikyan suspected that games would return to their multiplayer norm, likewise, social networks allow them the opportunity to return to their truly social, if virtual, nature.

目前已有技术可供人们在社交网络中创建和传播游戏，并且这些技术还在开发中。一些社交网络甚至欢迎游戏开发者，允许他们免费在其网络上托管游戏。

Technologies are available and in development that allow people to build and propagate games within social networks. Some networks have even welcomed game developers by allowing them to host games on their network free.

这是否会延伸成为 3D 虚拟社交网络还很难说。到目前为止，像Second Life这样的 3D 社交游戏尚未吸引到同样数量的用户，这既是因为技术限制，也是因为玩家对这种媒介的熟悉程度。

Whether this will extend itself into a 3D virtual social network is hard to say. So far, 3D social games like Second Life have yet to attract the same volume of users, due to both technological constraints and player familiarity with the medium.

挑战

CHALLENGES

社交网络对许多人来说非常熟悉，但对游戏开发者来说也是一个有趣的新平台。制作一款游戏，更不用说制作一款好游戏，对许多人来说都是一项挑战。有很多因素需要考虑，而这些因素在我们所知的传统游戏中并不常见。在探索以下挑战之前，花点时间探索社交网络，并玩一两款游戏一段时间，以了解体验以及这些游戏的动态如何运作。

Social networks are phenomenally familiar to many, but also an intriguingly new platform for game developers. Creating a game, let alone a good game, is a challenge for many. There are so many factors to consider that are not common to traditional games as we know them. Before exploring the challenges below, spend some time exploring social networks, and play a game or two for a sustained period of time to understand the experience and how the dynamics of these games work.

挑战 1 — 初次涉足

CHALLENGE 1—GET YOUR FEET WET

许多企业都渴望利用 Facebook 和 Instagram 等社交网站上数以百万计的年轻专业市场。其中一家公司刚刚聘请你来吸引新员工。这家公司是谁？谷歌。他们希望你为 Facebook 制作一款游戏，既能为公司提供潜在员工的联系方式，又能满足玩家对谷歌游戏的期望。

Many businesses are eager to capitalize on the young professional market that lives by the millions on social networking sites like Facebook and Instagram. You’ve just been hired by one of them to lure in new job recruits. The company? Google. They want you to make a game for Facebook that will simultaneously provide the company with contacts to possible recruits and meet player expectation of a Google game.

所需组件

Components Required

·      用于研究的互联网接入

·      Internet access for research

可交付成果

Deliverable

·      一页概念文档，描述基本游戏玩法、网络组件和传播技术

·      One-page concept document describing the basic gameplay, networking component, and propagation techniques

·      界面模型

·      Interface mockup

建议流程

Suggested Process

1.    集思广益，探索各种可能性。如果你听说 Facebook 上有一款 Google 游戏，你会期待什么？如果你还没有玩过 Facebook 游戏（或使用过 Google），请花点时间熟悉一下这些游戏的典型设计。

1.    Brainstorm the possibilities. If you heard there were a Google game on Facebook, what would you expect? If you haven’t played Facebook games (or used Google), take a moment to do so to familiarize yourself with their typical design.

2.    勾勒设计草图。 根据你的基本期望列表，确定游戏的可能设计。玩家会做什么？游戏玩法的核心是什么？列出游戏的功能。

2.    Sketch out a design. With your basic list of expectations, determine a possible design for your game. What does the player do? What is the core of gameplay? Make a list of the game’s features.

3.    确定游戏的传播方式。游戏如何在玩家之间传播？

3.    Determine how the game is propagated. How does the game travel from player to player?

4.    考虑用户界面。你的游戏会是什么样子？休闲游戏需要让大量玩家能够快速理解。为你的游戏创建模型界面。

4.    Consider the user interface. What is your game going to look like? Casual games need to be understandable quickly by a huge range of people. Create mockup interfaces for your game.

5.    创建可交付成果。

5.    Create deliverable.

挑战 2——社交网络棋盘游戏

CHALLENGE 2—THE SOCIAL-NET BOARD GAME

在某些地方，有不少人想知道这些“社交网络”到底是什么。毕竟，自穴居人时代以来，人类就一直在社交和建立网络。正是考虑到这一点，您将在非数字空间中应用社交网络的独特性质：借助数字网络，所有想要社交和建立网络的人不必同时在场。使用与前面描述的相同的系列，创建一个最多可容纳 20 名玩家的棋盘游戏或基于图块的游戏。玩家应该能够随意进出，解决任务，独立于其他玩家或与他们一起行动，前提是他们同时玩游戏。作为设计师，您最大的挑战将是确定游戏如何结束或是否结束。您将如何为玩家提供持续的娱乐？如何阻止他们在一次游戏中快速通关？

Somewhere out there, there are more than a few individuals wondering what all this “social networking stuff” is about. After all, people have been social and networking since the caveman days. It’s with that in mind that you’ll apply the unique nature of social networks in a non-digital space: with the aid of digital networks, all of those wanting to be social and to network don’t need to be present at the same time. Using the same series as described previously, create a board or tile-based game that up to 20 players can play. Players should be able to come and go as they please, solve missions, and function independently of other players or with them, provided they are playing the game simultaneously. As a designer, your biggest challenge will be to determine how the game ends or if it ends at all. How will you provide your players with continuing entertainment? What’s to stop them from racing through in a single play?

所需组件

Components Required

·      棋盘游戏组件

·      Board-game components

可交付成果

Deliverable

·      完整的书面规则

·      Complete set of written rules

·      界面模型

·      Interface mockup

建议流程  

Suggested Process   

·      使用与上一个挑战相同的流程。

·      Use the same process as in the previous challenge.

挑战 3 — 哇！太糟糕了

CHALLENGE 3—WOW! THAT’S BAD

与任何平台一样，社交网络上也不乏糟糕的游戏。找到一款，分析它，然后设计解决方案。请记住，为社交网络制作优秀的游戏并不像看起来那么容易。

As with any platform, there are no shortages of bad games on social networks. Find one, analyze it, and design a fix for it. Remember, making good games for social networks isn’t as easy as it looks.

所需组件

Components Required

·      访问互联网

·      Access to the Internet

·      社交网站账户

·      An account on a social-networking site

可交付成果

Deliverable

·      对糟糕的社交网络游戏进行分析，包括报道其做对了什么、做错了什么，以及它在社交网络中迄今为止的表现（玩家数量、每日用户百分比等）（如果有的话）。

·      Analysis of bad social-networking game, including coverage of what it did right, what it did wrong, and its performance to date within the social network (number of players, percentage of daily users, and so on) if available.

·      重新设计游戏

·      Redesign of game

建议流程

Suggested Process

1.    识别劣质游戏。 与大多数劣质游戏一样，这并不难做到。

1.    Identify bad game. As is the case with most bad games, this isn’t too hard to do.

2.    分析糟糕的游戏。思考本章中涵盖的社交游戏的各个方面。游戏玩法是否涉及玩家的社交网络，如果是，如何涉及？游戏如何传播？除了社交方面，游戏玩法本身是否引人注目？列出游戏中的弱点。最后，游戏是否有什么做对了而你不想改变的地方？

2.    Analyze the bad game. Think about the aspects of a social game covered in this chapter. Does the gameplay involve a player’s social network, and if so, how? How does the game propagate? Aside from the social aspects, is the gameplay itself compelling? Make a list of weak points in the game. Lastly, is there anything the game did right that you don’t want to change?

3.    集思广益，想出解决办法。 对于您发现的每个问题，想想可以解决它的方法。考虑对机制、用户界面和传播方法进行更改。

3.    Brainstorm fixes. For each issue that you’ve identified, think of ways that you could fix it. Consider changes to the mechanics, the user interface, and propagation methods.

4.    创建可交付成果。

4.    Create deliverable.

挑战 4——领英希望加入

CHALLENGE 4—LINKEDIN WANTS IN

 

 

在本章的大部分内容中，我们重点关注社交网络中的游戏。游戏还可以利用这些社交网络上公开的信息，同时又不脱离这些社交网络。对于这个挑战，你的目标是创建一个与流行的专业社交网站 LinkedIn (www.linkedin.com) 无关的游戏。研究该网站、网站上的用户及其目的，并使用公开信息，创建一个符合网站整体美感的游戏概念。

Throughout a lot of this chapter, we’ve focused on games within social networks. Games can also harness the information publicly available on these social networks while remaining external to them. For this challenge, your goal is to create a game that is external to the popular professional networking site LinkedIn (www.linkedin.com). Study the site, the people who are on it, and its purpose, and using the publicly available information, create a game concept that fits with the overall aesthetic of the site itself.

 

 

所需组件

Components Required

·      互联网连接，用于研究

·      Internet connection, for research

可交付成果

Deliverable

·      单页游戏概念或

·      One-page game concept or

·      可玩的纸质原型，展示你的游戏概念

·      Playable paper prototype demonstrating your game concept

建议流程

Suggested Process

1.    研究 LinkedIn。 研究 LinkedIn 并确定哪些信息可供网站访问者公开。列出这些信息。实际上，这些信息将成为新游戏的统计数据、资源和属性。

1.    Research LinkedIn. Research LinkedIn and determine what information is publicly available to visitors to the site. Make a list of this information. In effect, this information will become the stats, resources, and attributes of your new game.

2.    考虑游戏类型。 利用这些信息，您可以开发哪些类型的游戏？首先想到的是大亨游戏，还有模拟类游戏。同时，休闲游戏、社交网络游戏或 ARG 游戏也是可能的。浏览一下各种可能性列表，并在您的小组内进行头脑风暴。

2.    Consider genres. What types of games could you build with this information? A tycoon game comes to mind, as do games in the simulation genre. At the same time, a casual game, social net game, or an ARG are possible, too. Run through the list of possibilities and brainstorm within your group.

3.    创建可交付成果。 为可能的游戏制定概念方案。

3.    Create deliverable. Develop a concept pitch for a possible game.

铁人设计师挑战 5——社交网络、实景角色扮演游戏

IRON DESIGNER CHALLENGE 5—SOCIAL NETWORKING, THE LARP

刺客是大学校园里流行的游戏。游戏发生在现实世界中，在课间实时进行。游戏规则多种多样，但一般来说，游戏中的每个玩家都必须“暗杀”另一个玩家（以游戏形式，可能使用 Nerf 枪或水枪）。这样，每个玩家都在追捕其他人，同时也被其他人追捕。当玩家“杀死”猎物时，他会将该人的目标作为新的暗杀对象。随着时间的推移，玩家被淘汰，圈子越来越小，直到最后两个玩家互相追捕。当只剩下一名玩家还活着时，他就被宣布为获胜者。

Assassin is a popular game played on college campuses. The game takes place in real time, in between classes, in the real world. There are many rules variations, but in general each player in the game must “assassinate” another player (in play form, perhaps using a Nerf gun or water pistol). In this way, every player is hunting someone else, and also being hunted by someone else. When a player “kills” his prey, he receives that person’s target as his or her new object of assassination. As time goes on and players are eliminated, the circle narrows, until eventually two players are hunting each other. When only one player is left alive, he is declared the winner.

对于这一挑战，您的目标是让这款游戏可以在 Facebook 等社交网络上玩。

For this challenge, your goal is to take this game and adapt it to be playable on a social network such as Facebook.

所需组件

Components Required

·      没有任何

·      None

可交付成果

Deliverable

·      游戏概念，包括核心机制的描述

·      Game concept, including a description of core mechanics

建议流程

Suggested Process

1.    找到必须改变的机制。 《刺客》 的某些方面根本无法从现实世界转移到虚拟社交网络。例如，《刺客》的乐趣之一就是永远不知道在日常生活中某个随机的人何时会攻击你，但 Facebook 没有离线组件。你必须对此采取一些措施。（如果你的游戏需要在 Facebook 之外采取行动，那么你需要一种方法来通知在线游戏发生了什么。）

1.    Find the mechanics that must change. Some aspects of Assassin do not translate at all from the real world to a virtual social network. For example, part of the fun of Assassin is never knowing when some random person is going to attack you during your normal daily routine, but Facebook has no offline component. You will have to do something about that. (If your game requires action to be taken outside of Facebook, then you will need a way to notify the online game of what happens.)

2.    传播。在《刺客》中，游戏通常需要人们在活动开始前注册。大多数 Facebook 游戏都是在人们开始玩之后才进行传播。您的游戏如何通过社交网络进行传播？
